SECTION: Section 6; Page 40; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 7648 words

HEADLINE: The Little Creepy Crawlers Who Will Eat You In The Night

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis; Michael Lewis is a contributing writer to the Magazine. He is writing a book about Silicon Valley.

 BODY:
There are two parts to this story, and the first, like most things in Silicon Valley, can be dispensed with quickly. It runs something like this: In the 1960's and 70's, the Santa Clara Valley got itself a new name by making silicon chips, personal computers and related goods. The sunshine, the absence of tradition, the willingness of Stanford University to do business with corporations and the presence of a counterculture intent on arming the masses with new technology all made the Valley the place to be for people with a knack for building new machines. Other things being equal, the new will arise where the old simply does not exist.
Soon, enough other things were not at all equal. It turned out that the market for engineers in Silicon Valley did not obey the old economic rules. Each new engineer who migrated into the Valley was not less but more valuable than the one before him. As engineers trickled in, they created even bigger opportunities for even more engineers. The rewards for quitting your job at Bell Labs or I.B.M., packing the wife and kids into the station wagon and driving across country to Paradise grew and grew. A trickle of engineers became a stream; the stream became a river; the river became a torrent. 
 The engineers refused to obey the law of diminishing returns because their technology refused to. The price of computing power fell by half each year, the speed of computers doubled and each new computer chip added value to the chips already in existence. "If these economics applied to an automobile," says John Doerr, a prominent venture capitalist in the Valley who helped to start Sun Microsystems, Netscape, Intuit, @Home and dozens of other new-technology companies, "it would cost 10 bucks, run thousands of miles without refueling and when it got old, you wouldn't bother to trade it in for a new one. You'd just throw it away."
Part 1 of the Silicon Valley story was about men -- all of them were men -- building machines, building them cheaper, faster, smaller and better. They built them so fast and cheap that they made themselves uninteresting. The world came to take them for granted.
Part 2 is what the world has not yet taken for granted. What has happened in the Valley over the past few years has the locals comparing themselves to Renaissance Florentines. It is, as Doerr puts it, "the single greatest legal creation of wealth in the history of the planet." Actually building machines is today a slightly second-rate occupation: the computer has become a commodity. Factories are messy, workers unnecessary. These days, the thrill is in dreaming up things for the ubiquitous computer to do. Software, in a word. Because change is happening too fast for large corporations to control it, the new game favors the new guys. "The little creepy critters who will eat you in the night," as a man from Xerox described them. The speed of growth of the Internet, in particular, has meant that neither AT&T nor I.B.M. nor Xerox nor even Microsoft can dominate the business. It's the age of the creepy critter.
And so all across Silicon Valley you find these office buildings crammed with little creepy critters who will eat you in the night. They are mainly young men who have just discovered their inner entrepreneur and hope to grab their little billion-dollar slices of the new world. Incubators, these buildings are called. Incubators shelter engineers and computer scientists whose ideas might make a fortune but are too fragile at this point to survive in the free market. Big companies like Xerox have incubator projects; venture-capital firms like the Mayfield Fund have them; even local city councils have taken to turning vacant office space into way stations for new entrepreneurs.
One incubator just off Interstate 280 across from a strip mall in San Jose is a case in point. It was created by the National Aeronautics and Space Agency in 1993, when the Valley was experiencing a recession. Granted, it's a little hard to imagine Silicon Valley in recession. With more than 3,000 new businesses starting up each year, unemployment approaching zero and the Valley surpassing Detroit as America's leading exporter, it's hard to believe that there was actually a time when engineers here worried for their jobs. It's true! The hardware businesses were maturing, and there was this fear that the test tubes with the magic potion had gone dry.
The original idea behind the Valley's NASA Incubator was to use funds being offered up by the Federal Government to create a home for technology spun out of the space agency. "The trouble was," says John Gee, the man hired to set it up and eventually to choose its occupants, "there were no businesses waiting to come out of NASA." For the first few months, Gee spent all of his time looking for entrepreneurs. There weren't any to be found. Then something happened.
The nature of the thing is still hard to describe. On April 4, 1994, Netscape was incorporated. Over the next 18 months the Web-browser company climbed in market value from nothing to $6 billion.There followed a raft of giddy Internet-related successes -- Yahoo!, Excite, Amazon.com, Onsale, @Home. But it wasn't just the Internet that was aflutter; the central nervous system of the engineer was aflutter, too. Even now, the odds against success for a new-technology company are extremely long, something like 30 to 1. Yet the combination of a bull market in stocks, a few new-technology billionaires and a zealous faith in the power of software has led a raging horde of boy-men to tell their mothers that they had chucked over the job at I.B.M. to become software entrepreneurs. "It used to be 5 percent of the Stanford masters in engineering wanted to start businesses," Gee says. "Then it was 10 percent, then 15 percent, then 20 percent. Then I'm running this highly selective process." Overnight, it seemed to Gee, the world around him got drunk on the idea of starting its own businesses.
There is no better place to observe this phenomenon than the NASA Incubator. In October 1996, John Gee left the Incubator to start his own new-technology company, and was replaced by Joe Boeddeker. By then, there was a line around the block of young engineers and computer scientists who had some new software in their heads, trying to get an office in which to download. You could have filled the Incubator -- a dreary squat building with the charm of a third-class German motel -- many times over with some of the most expensively educated people on the planet. Hundreds of young Werthers of technology were willing -- willing? delighted! -- to turn down the 85 or 90 grand from I.B.M. or AT&T to work for nothing. Usually they didn't even have a product, just this little idea for a computer program that would... change the world.
The first guy I met at the NASA Incubator was on his way out. His name was Eric Ver Ploeg, and he had come to the Incubator by way of Stanford's engineering and business schools. He had an idea about how to speed up access to corporate databases, and his software company, Angara, had just been handed a few million dollars by a pair of venture capitalists, and so he was moving to a real office. Ver Ploeg was an inspiration to entrepreneurs. Not so long ago, at age 31, he was living entirely off credit-card debt. Each month he received new offers from Visa and Mastercard at 0 percent interest rates; each month he rolled his debts from the old cards to the new. He rented a room in a house belonging to two gainfully employed friends. In the line on the credit-card application where they ask him for his "annual household income," Eric wrote his housemates' joint income, "$190,000." Then the venture capitalists came along and valued his company at a little under $7 million.
Ver Ploeg took me around the Incubator and introduced me to a low-slung man with a heavy Russian accent named Michael Shapiro, who was working on software to help factories manage their assembly lines. In the last days of the Soviet empire, Shapiro had grabbed his wife and, with $1,500 in his pocket, executed a dangerous escape from Moscow to Brest and then through Central Europe, just as you see in the movies. Destination: Silicon Valley. He knew that he would be paid much more to write software there than in Russia. "Do you expect to become rich?" I asked. "What do you mean rich?" he replied. "Fifty million dollars," I offered. He considered this with perfect seriousness, like a man who has forgotten the value of a ruble. "Fifty million is a good number. I would not be surprised if I was worth $50 million. But I do not need to make $50 million right away."
Never have so many had so little regard for the status quo. Just down the hall from Shapiro I met a 49-year-old Stanford researcher named Barbara Hayes-Roth. Hayes-Roth is everyone's picture of the impractical academic, large eyes blinking behind spectacles and lots of polysyllabs. She will tell you in the most professorial tones that never in a million years did she dream she would go into business. But in her Stanford laboratory she happened to create these computer cartoon characters. They could walk, talk, remember what you said to them and empathize with your problems. At some point, they ceased to be experiments and became products. Who would need real live salesmen when you could have electronic ones? You'd arrive, say, at the General Motors Web site to inspect the latest Cadillacs, and Hayes-Roth's creation would be waiting to greet you. You'd have this little... Internet friend. The friend would know your name, your tastes and a fair number of jokes. The friend never had a bad day. The friend is the basis for a company Hayes-Roth has started up called Extempo.
Around the corner from Barbara Hayes-Roth is a guy who never comes out of his office. He just sits hunched over his desk, clasping his forelocks in his fingers, 14 hours a day, thinking up ways to eliminate the phone as we know it. He is trying to create the software for an Internet telephone -- or at least that's what people think he's trying to do. He refuses to talk about it.
Across the hall from him is a 27-year-old Harvard Business School graduate who sleeps under his desk. He could be merging giant corporations for Morgan Stanley, but instead he is curled up with the software he markets. His name is Francis Tapon, and he and his colleagues at Sightech Vision Systems have created the software for a computer that can identify the tiniest flaws in a product being manufactured and eliminate them.
By Incubator standards, Sightech is financially unambitious. If everything goes exactly according to plan, it will be worth maybe $600 million. A mere $600 million... even so! On the rare days Tapon gets away from the office, he goes cycling up into the Santa Clara hills and gazes upon the kinds of houses he will be able to afford if his new technology replaces some old technology. A few weeks ago, when I was cycling with him, he found his dream house, a faux medieval castle owned by some Midwest mutual fund baron originally listed at $29 million but now reduced to $25 million.
From the moment he saw it, he wanted to see more of it. He cycled up and down the hills angling for the best view, until at length he found it. Like just about everyone else in the Incubator, Tapon is, at least for the moment, earning exactly nothing. But every so often he returns to his favorite spot and peers over the red brick wall at the $25 million house and says something that suggests he's serious about this house. "It's the maintenance that kills you," he'll say and peddle away.
You hear people in Silicon Valley talking about millions of dollars in the most familiar tones and you assume that you've arrived at their motives. You put a couple of drinks in them and pop the question: All this new technology is just about making money, isn't it? But if you do this, you expose yourself as a rank outsider -- one of those throwbacks who has crawled out from under some rock back East and simply has no idea.
When you set out to sell the world new technology you have no choice but to eschew ordinary financial ambitions. You are obliged to imagine yourself swimming in bathtubs filled with stock options. For if you succeed in persuading the world to ditch some old technology and adopt your new one, you will necessarily become very, very rich.
That's one of many things people in this new world feel that people in the old one don't understand about them: When a high-tech company offers shares in itself to the public for the first time (that is, an initial public offering, or I.P.O.), the founders do make huge sums of money. But in Silicon Valley, the money is just a byproduct. Anyone with a new concept in his head who says to himself, Once I've done my I.P.O., I'll probably scale back and spend some quality time with my family," does not belong here. To succeed on a grand scale -- to be Jim Clark of Netscape or Larry Ellison of Oracle -- you need the nerve never to be sated by money. If you want to be taken seriously, you must always be new. You must always have about you the aura of newness. You can't let the undeniable fact of $400 million swashing around some Panamanian bank account get between you and your next new thing.
Once a month, a hundred or so rich middle-age men (and sometimes a woman or two) gather for dinner at the Los Altos Golf and Country Club in Silicon Valley. What they have in common, other than their obvious wealth, is a love of new technology. They gather to see if there isn't some new technology coming down the pike that they can put their money behind, and thus create even more money to put into new technology. After the main course, they lean back in their chairs, nod their spectacles onto the ends of their noses and listen to younger men from new-technology companies explain why they deserve to exist. Each dinner, three new companies of the sort being started up in the NASA Incubator parade themselves before the diners, who call themselves the Band of Angels. No Angel forks over any money right at the dinner, but most of them write a check or two in the days following an Angels' gathering. It's an extraordinary little piece of capitalist theater that has been going on for just over three years, and in that time nearly 70 fledgling companies have raised the money to fly.
The Band of Angels is an answer to a problem in the Valley caused by the most recent boom. A tidal wave of investment has crashed down on the Valley. Venture-capital dollars have quintupled from half a billion in 1990 to two and a half billion last year, according to a local consulting firm, Collaborative Economics. The V.C.'s have been forced to become ever more ambitious. Once, they looked to finance companies that might one day, with luck, be worth $50 million. Now they cannot waste time on anything that might not soon be worth a billion. "Even if they get the thing up and running and sell it for $50 to $100 million, it's not of much interest to us," says Michael Levinthal of the Mayfield Fund, one of the Valley's larger firms. "I start out with $250 million to invest. I'm trying to return a billion dollars. I have 40 bets to make to do it. I need companies that have the potential to be worth a billion."
In short, the flood of capital has bored a hole in the local market: there is no one to finance technology companies that might one day be worth merely $100 million. It's not worth the trouble.
This hole coincides perfectly with a missing piece of the Northern Californian social structure: the semiretired engineer in his mid-50's with $20 million or so in the bank has no rightful place in this world. There is, of course, a long tradition of American businessmen not knowing what to do with themselves once they cease to be businessmen. But the situation in the Valley is especially acute. There is no society as such, nothing to dignify and organize the vast sums of old money, defined as any money made more than 10 years ago. The very lack of tradition and structure that made the economic miracle possible in the first place has inverted the usual snobberies about money. New money is the only money that really matters. The newer, the better.
The technology entrepreneur with 20 million slightly stale dollars doesn't find himself pulled into a society of other technologists with $20 million. Instead, he finds himself foot-stomped by 24-year-olds intent on making $50 million. The old money and its owner just sit there, a pair of large lonely lumps on a hill overlooking the Valley, wondering how long it will be before they will be consumed by the new technologies the young bucks down there are dreaming up. "When these guys make a jillion dollars, what do they do with it?" asks Hans Severiens, a 65-year-old venture capitalist who started the Band of Angels in January 1995 with a half-dozen of his richest friends. "They get the house. They get the boat. They get the apartment in the south of France. They get the new wife. But all that takes only a couple of million. What do they do with the other millions? These guys are not golf players. They like the thrill of being involved. Most of them are no longer in business. I think some of these people are a little bit lonely."
Severiens sits on the board of the NASA Incubator, but he barely has time these days to make the meetings. Truth to tell, the Band of Angels is seriously cutting into Severiens' leisure time. He went out looking for a bit of fun and has wound up being flattened by a gold rush. All those people who want to be a part of the greatest legal creation of wealth in world history see Severiens as their Great White Hope. Severiens does not want to be their Great White Hope. He has the accent and the gentle demeanor of the mayor of a small Dutch village who wants mainly to be left alone but who forever is being suborned by marauding armies.
On the one hand, there is the mob of would-be entrepreneurs who won't let him be. "They call every day," Severiens says. "It's always, 'We have the next software plan that is going to take over the world.' Everyone is the next Netscape. The whole Internet thing is out of control. It's crazy. I'm by myself. The phone rings. It rings and rings and rings. I dread picking it up." And so he doesn't. "But even if you leave the telephone off the hook," he continues, more than a bit wearily, "they have a way of finding you. I have no E-mail, purposely."
On the other hand, there are all those engineers who are friends, or friends of friends, with $20 million and no one to play with. They aren't as thin on the ground as Severiens originally imagined. Hundreds of rich old guys have emerged from the Santa Clara hills to ask Severiens if, maybe, they, too, might be Angels. Severiens, who started this thing to make everyone's life a bit more pleasant, finds himself cast as the thug at the door of the hoity-toity nightclub. He could, he says, just ring a gong and let every jillionaire in the Valley in. But then it wouldn't be a band but an army of...what? Four hundred, maybe even 500. And what then? There's not a restaurant in Silicon Valley that can hold all its decamillionaires.
One night in January, at Severiens's suggestion, I hitched a ride with Mike Thomas in a rented car to the Band of Angels monthly dinner. Thomas, at 49, is at least 15 years older than most of the people in his position. A few months before, he had left a lifetime of working for others to start a software company called Spear Technologies. The new software helps mass transit systems service their vehicles. Most cities, it turns out, repair their trains and buses either too often or too little. Whodathunkit? It's one of the many problems the world is being made aware of only because there is now a software solution to it.
Thomas's is the only company peddling this particular solution, and it seems to be catching on -- New York City has paid Spear a great deal of money to maintain its 3,600 buses, for instance. But revenues were not coming in as quickly as money was running out. Already Thomas had sold nearly half of his company to outside investors (among them the famous money manager Peter Lynch) for a bit more than $3 million. He had borrowed $2 million from a close friend, taken a second mortgage on his home and now, at last, had reached the bottom of his bank account.
He needed to raise $1.5 million by the end of the month, or he was in a deep, dark hole. He was willing to hand over another 25 percent of Spear Technologies to get it. The Angels were very close to a backer of last resort; he had no place else to turn. "Spear is a very, very good deal," Severiens, who vets dozens of companies each month to arrive at the three finalists, had said. The problem is that people might think it is too good a deal. Why's Mike selling it so cheaply?
Mike Thomas was selling the company so cheaply because he was terrified it wouldn't sell.
Thomas was to be given 15 minutes to persuade the Angels to see the world as he could: Spear can dominate a largely untapped market. No government could afford not to buy it: the money saved in vehicle repair would pay for the software in a year. "The danger," Thomas said, "is that the Angels won't understand this market. It's not the Internet."
Few of the Angels who met that evening at the Los Altos country club belonged to the club or any other; the only social organization they have in common is their monthly dinners. An hour of cocktails preceded the dinner. It could have been any Midwestern men's club. The lights were not dimmed for dinner; the wives were not present; of the 57 cups of coffee served after dinner, only two were decaffeinated. I actually saw a man tell a joke, slap his thigh and exclaim, "That's a good one!" What could be more Midwestern than that? Almost to a man, the Angels have the closed-crop assurance of the mechanically minded. Severiens is an exception in having been a financier as well as an engineer. It was a roomful of 55-year-old Mr. Fixits. If into this crowd you tossed a busted car engine, it would have been repaired before you came back from calling the tow truck.
As the chicken departed and the puddings arrived, Severiens introduced Thomas. Purposefully, he had scheduled Thomas first, since he thought that his was the best deal and that the attention of the Angels might waver. Thomas rose to face 10 round tables of Angels. A man with an unnaturally deep tan stuffed a lemon square in his mouth; others sipped wine, but most just watched Thomas attentively.
And then something happened. Some combination of Peter Lynch's name being dropped and encouraging questions and men nodding their heads in approval put Thomas in control. In the back of every mind was the same thought: He's new. He has the thing. He's the new guy whose new thing will be picked up by the stock market in 18 months and flung into the stratosphere. The deal was not done, by any means; at the end of his presentation Thomas had no idea whether he had sold the Angels or lost them for all time. Indeed, for the moment, he heard nothing but objections. But three days later, Thomas's little speech to the Angels would net him $2.4 million.
Thomas returned to his seat at the back of the room. He was followed by a man with a method for diagnosing ovarian cancer in its early stages. A roomful of men leaned back and pushed their glasses down their noses; the waning interest was palpable. Ovarian cancer was followed by Internet commerce -- in the person of a young man the size of an upholstered chair. "We estimate the market at $160 billion," he said calmly. "I'll tell you our strategy and how we are going to conquer that market." Hardly anyone seemed to be paying close attention. "How come the fringe benefits are almost half the salaries?" asked one of the engineers of another, pointing to some numbers on the overhead projector.
The second engineer laughed: "Dunno. Must be lots of family members employed."
Silicon Valley has developed a new twist to the old Oedipal struggle. The people who created the old technologies know that they will be displaced by younger men with new technologies. Rather than fight them, they finance them. The result is a closed system. The money from old technologies does not spill over into the nontechnological or into various social defenses of the old technology. It does not fritter away its energies on fripperies. It does not create clubs that exclude arrivistes. There is no point in excluding arrivistes: if you don't bend to their new thing, their new thing will destroy you. And so the old simply metamorphoses into the new. The entropy of success is kept to a bare minimum.
The man who comes closest to embodying the local idea of success is Jim Clark. Whatever else he is, Jim Clark is always new. He's 53, but when you talk to him, you feel as if you are grappling with a giant young yellow Labrador retriever straining at his leash. Back in 1982, Clark left his job teaching at Stanford to found Silicon Graphics. Silicon Graphics made stuff; it had factories. On the eve of the software boom, in 1994, Clark left Silicon Graphics to form Netscape. Eighteen months later, his Netscape stake was worth more than a billion dollars, but Netscape was feeling a bit stale. In 1996, Clark formed Healtheon, a health care industry service using the Internet. Even before Healtheon becomes viable, Clark's energies are shifting to some newer enterprise of shadowy intentions, which he houses in a few square feet on top of a Jenny Craig Weight Loss Center in Menlo Park. "The will to create" is how Clark describes the source of his fortune. "It's just kind of sheer will."
Clark is one of those people who would sit on top of the Silicon Valley social structure, were there a social structure to sit upon. When ambitious people in other parts of the world start thinking that they, too, might like to be successful, they often call up Clark. Most recently, Clark was asked to attend a series of meetings at Princeton University, which was hoping to learn how to create a new-technology boom around itself. After a few hours of listening to them talk about the primacy of pure research, Clark gave up trying to explain. "It can never happen here," he told them. "In my opinion, Princeton is doomed to mediocrity in computer science. You still think the finest thing is to be a physicist or a mathematician. You will never believe that the finest thing to be is an engineer or a computer scientist or anyone who does anything of practical value." And with that, he went back to creating new-technology companies in Silicon Valley.
The Valley has sped up capitalism's normal Darwinian process, and Clark is one of the few people who adapts at every turn to the rapid environmental changes. When he left Stanford to answer the call of entrepreneurship back in 1982, Clark knew little about money. He thought he simply could trust the venture capitalist who backed him, a man named Glenn Mueller at the Mayfield Fund. Before the company's I.P.O., Mayfield had squeezed Clark's share of Silicon Graphics down to about 5 percent. When Silicon Graphics went public in 1986, the V.C.'s made a killing while Clark, whose idea it was, became merely rich -- his stake in the billion-dollar venture was worth around $16 million. "They took advantage of me," Clark says. "And I never forgot that."
By the time he created Netscape, the engineer's hand against the money guys had strengthened: new technology in the right hands meant a new kind of power. Venture capitalists begged Clark to take their money, in exchange for a sliver of the new enterprise. Glenn Mueller was one of those doing the begging. He and Clark had remained friends. Clark came to the Muellers' annual Christmas party, the closest thing in the Valley to a society gathering.
And yet Clark told Mueller no; instead of going again with the Mayfield Fund, Clark called John Doerr of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Over the next few weeks, Mueller phoned Clark repeatedly, asking to be let in on the deal. He'd keep Clark on the phone for hours at a time. But Clark says he "couldn't forget what happened with Silicon Graphics."
The signature psychological disorder in Silicon Valley is paranoia. To those who have run the gantlet and achieved the aura of newness, a suspicion of those around you is not regarded as a mental problem but as simple street smarts. "Only the paranoid survive" is the motto of Intel's C.E.O., Andy Grove, and to judge from all accounts, he lives by it. It may seem strange to find neurosis alive and well in a purely practical place, but when you think about it, it only makes sense. People who create new technologies become successful by replacing old technologies. The act of creation in such a tightly wound market is, typically, also an act of destruction. From this it requires but a little effort to skip to the next thought: somewhere out there someone is creating something that will finish off me.
No one in Silicon Valley knew that Glenn Mueller was thinking along these lines. The man was at the center of the old Valley; the first boom left him worth upward of $100 million -- what could possibly harm him?
On April 4, 1994, Netscape was incorporated and Jim Clark told Glenn Mueller for the last time that he would not be given a piece of the deal. He would not be granted early admission to the new world. When he got the news, Mueller was on his sailboat off the coast of Mexico. That night, he walked into the cabin, put a gun to his head and shot himself dead.
Later, it emerged that Mueller had said some strange things at home about how the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. were out to get him and how others very close to him were out to destroy his business. "But at the time," Clark says, "no one saw a thing." No one except Clark thought to blame Clark. He spent the next six weeks grieving, recovering only to read a poem at a memorial service for Mueller.
All technology is inherently Political. The words stretched across the chalkboard at the Stanford Business School, behind the man who wrote them there. The man was neither young nor old. He wore gray wool slacks and a striped Oxford shirt open at the collar. He smiled easily and, in spite of what he had scribbled on the board, made a point of being pleasant. He could have been an Episcopal minister or the assistant headmaster at Deerfield, waiting diffidently for the congregation or the students to tell him what they needed.
The man is John Doerr, and he is standing in the eye of a storm. Investors in new technology -- the pension funds, the universities, the rich -- plead with Doerr to take their money and invest it in new technology. Engineers and computer scientists, who now more than ever before want to become entrepreneurs, beg Doerr to give them money. Five out of 10 times they take Doerr's money and make it vanish quickly; 4 out of 10, they return it without much interest. But 1 time in 10, they make it do the most extraordinary things that money has ever done. Netscape! America Online! Onsale! Amazon.com! Sun! The greatest legal creation of wealth in the history of the planet! By 1997, the Kleiner Perkins portfolio of technology companies employed 162,000 people, rang up revenues of $61 billion and had a stock-market value of $125 billion.
The world that swirls around Doerr invents not merely technology but ideas, and people to sell those ideas. Doerr himself is a local invention: his persona could not exist anyplace else but Silicon Valley. If you sent him to Wall Street and made him an investment banker, he would be loathsome. He'd be cast immediately as yet another Wall Street megalomaniac, and no matter how he might resist, the culture would force him to play the assigned role: Stealer of the Old Money Pie. But here the universe is new and ever expanding; in the Valley, Doerr is universally liked and admired. People ask: What's wrong with power? What's so bad about letting one guy cut the pie and hand out the pieces? What's not to like about a guy who came out of nowhere and is now worth $200 million? It's one of the many little miracles of the Valley that its most powerful financier is...a nice guy!
That's new, too.
Anyway, at the beginning of his Stanford performance, Doerr was given something to be nice about. The outline of his talk was supposed to be beamed directly from his computer through an overhead projector onto the white screen. But the projector rejected the computer connection and the lights refused to dim. No one in the audience -- not one of the 400 or so young business-school wizards, engineers, computer scientists, professors and deans who had broken the Palo Alto Fire Department code to get a glimpse of Doerr -- could figure out how to turn the lights off. A couple of guys in suits pressed the switches beside the stage and then started pulling apart a panel near the floor. Wires stuck out in 11 different directions. Still nothing happened. No one knew where to find the switch. So Doerr fiddled a bit with his computer, gave up and then started scribbling on the chalkboard, just as they used to, in the old days, before they had computers or even overhead projectors. He scrawled his slogan about technology being political, and then asked the eager audience to offer other topics and questions for him to consider during the next hour.
"The lawsuit against Microsoft," someone hollered from the back.
"Which one?" Doerr asked, and the room erupt-ed in knowing laughter.
In the Valley, Microsoft jokes are the equivalent of German jokes in France.
"Impact of Intel's Merced chip."
"Good question," Doerr said, and wrote this down. He could assume that everyone knew about something called "the Merced chip."
"How technology can bring parents and teachers together."
The strange thing about the people in the room was that they didn't seem to be out to curry favor directly with John Doerr. Probably some of them wanted to be venture capitalists. But what most of them wanted from Doerr was some insight into how to package their own ideas. They wanted to be the only truly admirable thing there is to be in this economy: an entrepreneur, a new man.
"Really good question," Doerr said, and wrote that one down, too. And so it went until the chalkboard was filled with questions about technology, at which point Doerr pulled down the white screen and tried his projector again. The engineers frantically flipped the switches and pulled the wires, but the lights remained obstinate. The projector went on, however. The bulb was just bright enough that even in the fully lighted room you could make out the black lettering:
OLD economy NEW economy
a skill lifelong learning
managers entrepreneurs
labor vs. mgt. teams
monopolies competition
wages ownership, options
hierarchical networked
sues invests
status quo speed, change
The list went on to describe not so much a new economy as a new way of life. Before you knew what had happened, it wasn't a speech but a worldview. The concepts slid down the minds of the audience as smoothly as Blue Point oysters, and for two hours after the talk, until you forgot what he actually said, the entire murky business of life was clear. Anyone who doubted whether this explosion in new technology could continue -- Is it a bubble? What if the stock market crashes? What if people cling irrationally to their old ways? -- needed only to have heard Doerr to have had his doubts allayed. "If you will permit me a little bit of optimism," he said, "I think it is possible that the Internet has been underhyped. It's like Big Bang -- it's like a creation of a whole new universe. It's going to go on a long, long time. And it's going to affect every part of society."
Part 2 of the Silicon Valley story is, according to Doerr, even better than Part 1: the products have the same magical economic properties, but this time they hardly cost anything to make. To build a new chip, you must build a new factory to build the chip. To create a software, all you need to do is think. Once you've had your thought, you pay a few programmers to handle the details. And once they've finished, there is no cost at all. Nothing. You just collect the toll as people download it from the Internet. "You tell me what it means when your cost of goods is zero," Doerr said, and the audience knew enough to quiver in awe.
When his hour was up, Doerr turned off the projector and took questions. The lights went out. At precisely the wrong moment, someone had flipped a switch in a sound booth at the back of the room. Four hundred pairs of eyes blinked in the dark. For 15 long seconds, the only sound was nervous laughter. Then the lights came on and everything was O.K.
In the new Utopia, invention and the social change it brings are no longer left to rogue geniuses tinkering in their basements. The Valley is a system of planned innovation: ever-more-rapid change brought about by people designed for the task. The message beamed into the renal cortexes of young engineers and computer scientists is simple: Invent something! Start something! For God's sake, man, the world is getting better! Look for something new to do!
That's the message that brought an unlikely 26-year-old Indian named Venkat Krishnamurthy to the NASA Incubator. A few years ago, Krishnamurthy had gone looking for something new to do. As 1 of 30 students chosen from a pool of 600 overqualified applicants to join the Stanford Ph.D. program in computer science, Krishnamurthy was obliged to seek out a problem that would interest a professor who would, in turn, take him under his wing. On the third floor of the university's Gates Building, he stumbled across a machine he had never before seen -- a square black table braced on one side by a three-sided black box and on the other by a long metal rod with a scanner mounted to it. Inside the scanner was a laser, attached to a computer located inside the black box. The apparatus was able to scan crude three-dimensional images into the computer.
The machine was called the Cyberware Scanner and had been created by a father-and-son team down in Monterey. Their original idea to stick the things in shopping malls and scan people's faces didn't pan out. The machine languished, waiting for someone to come along and find a use for it. "I just thought it was so cool," Krishnamurthy says. "I thought there must be something cool I could do with this."
In that seemingly innocent impulse was the energy to trigger a chain of events that might conclude with the death of an old technology, the birth of a new one and millions of investors baying for shares of an I.P.O.
What Krishnamurthy did with the machine was to address a longstanding problem in computer graphics: How do you get an object from the real world into the computer? How do you translate every nook and wrinkle and shadow on a complex solid object into digital data, so that it is no longer a picture of that object but a kind of digital clone that can be reshaped and manipulated at the will of the programmer? How, in other words, do you break down the difference between real life and computer life? "Reality merge" is the term of art sometimes used by people in the field. A Stanford professor named Marc Levoy had taken an interest in reality merge. Krishnamurthy joined Levoy's elite team of graduate students. Two years later, they had written software for the computer attached to the laser that more or less solved the problem.
Once again, the computer was being made to do something new. As Levoy's team progressed, Krishnamurthy came to know Domi Piturro, an artist who had worked with Sony developing models for their play stations division and with Viacom on television shows like "Star Trek: Voyager." In the technical progress of computer art over the past 20 years, Piturro saw an analogy to what had happened to the plastic arts during the Renaissance: the computer was groping toward more realistic depictions of nature. The Stanford technology represented a small Eureka! moment, the equivalent of Donatello's rediscovery of contrapposto. It meant you could quickly translate a human body into raw computer data; the data could be made to respond to a variety of manipulations exactly as an actual human figure. "We had broken through one of the big barriers between working in real life and working in a computer," Piturro says. "As an artist I found that exciting. It was like being Masaccio or something."
There was a time not very long ago when Piturro would have been thinking chiefly of finding a gallery in SoHo to represent him and Venkat would have been thinking chiefly of tenure. But this was Silicon Valley in the beginning of 1997, and they were surrounded by young computer scientists who wanted more than anything else to become entrepreneurs. It took about three weeks and a few conversations with people around Stanford for the artist and the engineer to think their way to the next step: keep the technology and exploit it themselves. "People will always pay to see a more realistic dinosaur," says Krishnamurthy, recalling his first commercial thought. "And we could now create a far more realistic dinosaur much more quickly and much more cheaply than anyone else." To create the dinosaur, they needed capital, a plan and someone to manage the business. They needed to figure out how many hundreds of millions of dollars their idea might be worth. They needed to learn how to sell their new machine to others. They needed, in short, to be plausible. "Me and Venkat running something alone," Piturro says. "It would be like just two tech guys doing cool stuff."
In April of last year Krishnamurthy and Piturro went to Stanford's office of technology licensing to secure the rights to the new software. There, they found more or less waiting an engineer with business experience and a degree from the Stanford Business School named Brian Kissel. Kissel had just turned 38 and was himself look-ing to create his first company. And to create a company in Silicon Valley, you need a new technology.
Kissel, like Krishnamurthy and Piturro, is a character who has redesigned himself for the new way of life. He finished near the top of his class at the Naval Academy and served for three years as an officer on a nuclear submarine. On the rare occasions he imagined himself being out of the Navy, he saw himself at Boeing or Pratt & Whitney or G.E. or some other monolith where he would lead the troops of some big business for 30 years. But then Kissel had one of those hell-if-he-can-do-it moments. Everyone who ditches a career to start one of these new-technology companies knows the sensation. Kissel had worked for a former Stanford Business school classmate at a company called Oblix. He liked and admired his old friend, but after a year of close observation, he found himself wondering, Hell, if he can do it.. . .
If the Silicon Valley boom had never happened, Kissel never would have become an entrepreneur; now that the Silicon Valley boom had happened, he couldn't imagine being anything but an entrepreneur.
By the summer of 1997, Krishnamurthy, Piturro and Kissel had formed themselves into a believable enterprise now named Paraform. At some point, it occurred to them that they needed an office, and through a friend of a friend, they found the NASA Incubator. And once you are inside the Incubator, you're no longer three guys who had never started a business. You're a company that has been selected by the Incubator. Lawyers and accountants lined up to offer their services in exchange for a tiny piece of the new company. Needing capital, Brian Kissel called the Band of Angels; before the Angels called back, Brian was on the line with a dozen venture capitalists, most of whom wanted a piece of the action. Soon enough, the co-founder of Microsoft, Paul Allen, had a jet waiting for the three new entrepreneurs on the Tarmac at the San Jose airport. It took them up to Seattle. They showed Allen and associates the product in action. Allen had but one thing to say: "Cool."
"He said 'cool' twice," Piturro says. "Everybody told us we'd be lucky to get one 'cool.' We got two." Between Paul Allen and Gordon Campbell, who runs a hot firm called Tech Fund, Paraform quickly cobbled together a couple of million dollars.
Their initial plan is to go out and grab the $20 million a year they calculated the movie studios are willing to pay for better dinosaurs. With the stock market valuing software companies the way it did, that would leave them sitting on top of a several-hundred-million-dollar company. All the value that accrued to the companies that made the old dinosaurs would be theirs. "Once we are successful," says Krishnamurthy, "there is a company in Utah that will be put out of business."
But why stop with dinosaurs? "One of my jobs," Campbell says, "is to make sure Brian and his guys don't self-limit. The computer is largely a two-dimensional experience. Why can't it be a three-dimensional one?" Every person who shops for clothing on the Internet, as every person one day might, will want his body translated into data so that it can be fitted on line. And once you start thinking in new-world terms, the applications are endless -- in medicine, industry, electronic games. Kissel doesn't want to get ahead himself, but he has no choice. If he doesn't think big, others will think big for him.
Transform computer space! Anyplace else, only a fool would entertain such a thought. Here, only a fool would object. Out there is a large malleable society, helpless before something new. Somewhere in Utah, a company, which actually is not very old at all, trembles.

Bottom: Angara before it graduated to a "real" office; Michael Shapiro likes the sound of $50 million; Francis Tapon dreams of a $25 million house in the hills. How Green Is the Valley? When it comes to the color of money and the harvesting of new ideas, very. Some 3,000 businesses start up every year and unemployment is near zero. The lack of structure that made the miracle possible in the first place has inverted the usual snobberies about wealth. The newer the money, the better. Making the Pitch Mike Thomas's presentation to the Band of Angels netted $2.4 million. High Living One of the residential areas where the new money is finding a new home. HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Finnish Modern: Defining a Nation By Its Designers

BYLINE: By PAULA DEITZ 

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland

 BODY:
WHILE THE frozen streets here glistened with new-fallen snow, the entrances to galleries and museums were aglitter with the same curvilinear glass vase filled with tulips. More than a harbinger of spring, the recurring vase evoked the spirit of its designer, Alvar Aalto, whose centenary this year is the cause for the festive mood in this capital city.
Though Aalto is the best known internationally, he was only one of many Finnish designers and architects whose works defined this country's Modernist sensibility. Streamlined, practical and durable, these designs are familiar in homes and offices all over the world. In addition to the Aalto vase, there are the ergonomically perfect Fiskars scissors, the Everyboy striped shirt made by Marimekko and the red enamel coffeepot designed by Antti Nurmesniemi. 
 The centerpiece of the recent events here is the reopening, after a major interior renovation, of the Museum of Art and Design along with a new permanent display that chronicles the history of Finnish modern design. Situated in a Gothic-revival school building, the museum, which opened in 1873, is the oldest in Scandinavia devoted to design. Its stores have grown rich enough not only to fill its own sleek showcases but also to make generous loans to the Bard Graduate Center in New York for its current exhibition, "Finnish Design: Utopian Ideals and Everyday Realities, 1930 to 1997." This show of 144 works was organized by Marianne Aav, curator of the Finnish museum, and her counterpart at Bard, Nina Stritzler-Levine.
To appreciate the evolution of Finnish design, one has to understand the history of the country. From the 12th century on, Finland was under the dominion of Sweden until it was conquered by Russia in 1809. Finnish architecture began to flourish under the czars, and, with its pale-ocher columned buildings, Helsinki took on the neo-classical style that made it the equal of St. Petersburg. When Finland became independent after the Russian Revolution in 1917, its designers, already leaders at international expositions, turned from a romantic tradition and used their work to assert a new identity. And in time, Finland tied its economic future to a strong domestic industry in the design of modern products.
Along with Finnish success abroad, local companies became synonymous with their products: Arabia for ceramics, Iittala for glass and Marimekko for textiles. Similarly, the packaging for the products, unlike that in other countries, advertised the designers' names, which themselves became household commodities.
Some of the articles displayed at the Museum of Art and Design were limited-edition art pieces. But the real attractions are the everyday objects that have lost neither their beauty nor their practicality even to people long accustomed to seeing and using them.
The first object a visitor encounters is a wooden armchair designed in 1909 by Eliel Saarinen, the famous Finnish architect whose son, Eero, later designed the T.W.A. passenger terminal at Kennedy International Airport. The chair was included in the father's design for the Helsinki railroad station, an elegantly functional building whose illuminated green tower is a beacon that still shines across this port city.
In 1932, four years before Aalto won a countrywide competition for his vase, his wife, Aino, created a ribbed, pressed glass and matching pitcher in various colors; the set is still sold in large quantities at Stockmann's, a local department store.
Viewing the Aalto vase itself in Finland, where it is produced at the Iittala glassworks outside Helsinki, one sees in it the contours of the lakes so prominent in the flat landscape. The museum show displays one in the rare Rio brown tint.
Though few offices are without the orange-handled Fiskars scissors designed by Olof Backstrom in 1967, it is not generally known that they were modeled on an 1880 pair of tailor's shears. The manufacturer just happened to have orange plastic in the machine when it produced the prototype, which was an instant hit with its own office staff. A version for left-handed people was eventually made in red.
IT HASN'T always been easy to get the now-plentiful porcelain cream pitcher designed for Arabia by Kaj Franck. Because of rationing after World War II, a customer wanting to buy one had to present a marriage license to do so. Tall and narrow and fitted with a cork stopper, it could be stored between windows for chilling. Other Arabia tableware on view, like dishes in Ulla Procope's brown Ruska pattern that were ubiquitous in the 60's, is still on the market.
Nothing has been overlooked here in Finnish design, not even a new model for the local trams nor the blue and gold wrapper for the popular Fazer chocolate bar. But no other designs evoke the snowy fields and forests of birch and pine that stretch to the horizon in this country better than Timo Sarpaneva's spooled candlestick or Tapio Wirkkala's drinking glass made in 1968 for Finnair's first trans-Atlantic flight. Blown into carved wooden molds, the glass surfaces resemble the rough ice of the winter landscape. The Wirkkala glass is known as Ultima Thule, after the mysterious Latin phrase for the remote northern reaches of Finland.

GRAPHIC: Photos: TAILOR MADE: A pair of orange-handled Fiskars scissors designed by Olof Backstrom in 1967.; HOUSEHOLD NECESSITIES: A ribbed glass and matching pitcher, above, by Aino Aalto and, below, a red enamel coffee pot by Antti Nurmesniemi are on view at the Museum of Art and Design in Helsinki. (Museum of Art and Design, Finland)

HEADLINE: Tax Offices Filling Up For Elder Exemption

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THE assessors' office does not often draw a crowd in Southold, a haven for retired people on the North Fork. But lately the three assessors have been so sought after that they have opened their office on weekends.
In Southold and elsewhere on Long Island, assessors are being overwhelmed by a rush of homeowners 65 and older with incomes of less than $60,000 who are applying for school-tax exemptions under Gov. George E. Pataki's School Tax Relief program, or Star. 
 The deadline for filing is tomorrow.
Of all the budget items and spending plans advanced by Mr. Pataki in New York and President Clinton on the Federal level, nothing matches Star for directly affecting a large number of Long Islanders, officials and others said last week.
Mr. Pataki has raised the potential effects with a plan to accelerate benefits, using $518 million of an expected $1.8 billion year-end budget surplus. If the Legislature agrees, school taxes for qualifying elderly taxpayers would be cut this year by at least 45 percent, sharply increasing exemptions that are assured under the program.
Democrats have criticized Mr. Pataki's $71.9 billion budget, which is 7.6 percent larger than the $66.8 billion last year, an election year plan intended to help Mr. Pataki, a Republican, win a second term in November.
James L. Larocca of Lloyd Harbor, a candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, also criticized Mr. Pataki for mailing a reminder to apply for the tax exemption. Mr. Larocca, a lawyer and former president of the Long Island Association, said the letter had been paid for with tax money and sent to people who were ineligible because of age or income.
The mailing, Mr. Larocca said in a letter to Mr. Pataki, "appears to have been sent to a wider audience, confirming that the real purpose is to promote your campaign for re-election."
In addition to accelerating the Star program, Mr. Pataki's budget also includes additional aid to education, increases in child and medical care for low-income families and more money for parks. It reflects a stronger economy in the state, spurred by gains on Wall Street.
Some critics said that it depended too heavily on continued economic gains and that a combination of increased spending and lower taxes could not be sustained in a downturn.
The Star program, a four-year plan intended to apply in coming years to property owners of all ages, is a major shift in school financing from property taxes to state aid. Revenues that school districts lose as a result of the exemptions will be made up by increased aid.
School officials on Long Island have supported the program. But they have also raised concerns about whether the state will make up dollar for dollar the losses through exemptions. "If the economy weakens the state can play a shell game with the school districts," said Stephen B. Witt, president of the Nassau and Suffolk School Boards Association.
With the application deadline tomorrow, assessors said they had never been busier. In Southold more than 4,000 of the 21,000 residents applied for exemptions that will save them as much as several hundred dollars. "We are doing our best," one assessor, Robert I. Scott Jr., said. "People are being very courteous. They know this is something our office was never designed to handle."
In Brookhaven, the geographically largest and most populous town in Suffolk County, eight part-time employees are helping. "We're getting about 700 people a day now, and those are just the walk-ins," said Town Assessor James Ryan. About 15,000 applications have been filed, Mr. Ryan added. The office will remain open until 10 P.M. tomorrow.
In Nassau, one of the two counties in the state where the county processes assessments, more than 101,000 applications were filed by an earlier deadline, Dec. 31. "It's been unbelievable," said Charles O'Shea, chairman of the County Board of Assessors. Mr. O'Shea said he expected several hundred additional applications by the extended deadline of tomorrow. He said average savings would be $350.
About 15 percent of the 1.3 million residents in Nassau are 65 or older. But that segment owns a far larger percentage of the 431,600 housing units. The statistics reflect an aging population in a county where more than 80 percent of houses are owner occupied.
Assuming an average exemption of $350 for each of the 101,000 applicants, the total exemption for the statewide program would be more than $35 million just in Nassau. Mr. O'Shea said he did not expect that all the applications would be approved, because some were duplicates or incomplete.
But the total exemption would rise if the Legislature approves Mr. Pataki's plan to accelerate the program with $518 million of the current surplus.
Mr. O'Shea said an approval would spare the elderly from reapplying next year, adding: "It would be a wonderful thing for senior citizens and for assessors. This program is designed for seniors who are getting crushed by school taxes and for suburban homeowners."
Marc M. Goloven, a senior regional economist for Chase Manhattan Bank, said the program was "going to have a very significant impact on Long Island, the outlook for the residential housing market and the amount people pay for school taxes."
School taxes account for more than half of property taxes for Long Island homeowners.
Mr. Goloven said another major effect would be an 8.5 percent increase in the proposed budget to improve public works.
The budget also increases money for renovation and building at State University campuses. Stony Brook would receive $36 million, Old Westbury $4 million and Farmingdale $2.5 million.
Some officials objected to the absence of new spending for community colleges. "There is not one dollar for any project at Suffolk Community College," said Suffolk County Legislator Brian X. Foley, Democrat of East Patchogue.
Social service departments, involved during the first years of the Pataki administration with reducing caseloads and searching for welfare fraud, welcomed the budget.
"Over all this is a beneficial budget for local social services departments," said Dennis J. Nowak, Social Services Director in Suffolk. Mr. Nowak said a surplus in state grants for needy families would be given to counties for child welfare under the budget. Suffolk's share could be $2.8 million, he said, and other surpluses could mean an additional $2.9 million for the county. The budget would also increase financing for child care, up to an estimated $630,000 in Suffolk.
Ruth A. Brandwein, a professor of social welfare at SUNY at Stony Brook and a former head of welfare in Suffolk, said she was "pleased with increases in health care for children," Tax breaks for education and added spending for child care in President Clinton's proposed budget would also benefit low-income families, Ms. Brandwein added.
In general, Long Island officials seemed less certain about the effects of Mr. Clinton's budget. Mr. Nowak, for example, referred questions about proposed changes in food stamps to Albany.
The Federal plan includes $50 million to New York for food stamps for immigrants and increases the local shares of costs for Medicaid and food stamps. The increase, estimated by state officials as $30 million a year, could also raise county costs.
Mr. Clinton's spending plan would also cut payments for school districts with large areas of tax-exempt federally owned lands. One district, East Meadow, could lose payments for students from federal housing at Mitchel Field.
A member of the school board, Robert Kushner, said the district had "never received anything that even approaches the per pupil cost." The district, Mr. Kushner said, received "a few hundred thousand dollars" last year.
The budget would increase by $1 million the $32 million in Federal aid to the Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point. Representative Gary Ackerman, Democrat of Queens whose district includes the academy, said the extra money showed strengthened Federal support.
Representatives Peter T. King of Seaford and Rick Lazio of Brightwaters, both Republicans, said Mr. Clinton's plan would cut financing for South Shore coastal projects. Mr. King said $9 million was needed to continue an Army Corps of Engineers restoration in Long Beach. "Clinton put zero in the budget, and the Army Corps has decided they don't want to be involved in beach restoration unless it involves more than one state," Mr. King said. "So we are going to have to fight for that."
Mr. Lazio criticized the budget for a 75 percent cut in a Housing and Urban Development program to build rental housing for the elderly. "The need for housing for seniors and disabled persons is growing on Long Island and across the country," Mr. Lazio, the Housing Subcommittee chairman, said. "This isn't a very compassionate housing budget."

HEADLINE: Q&A/Humphrey Tonkin;
Back to the Classroom, Shakespeare in Tow

BYLINE: By R. L. FELSON 

 BODY:
HUMPHREY TONKIN has served as a university president for 15 years, including a decade at the University of Hartford, a private 7,000-student liberal arts school. He will step down in June, spend a year on research as a visiting fellow at the Whitney Humanities Center at Yale, then return to Hartford and the classroom as University Professor of the Humanities, a new position in which he will teach courses relating to 16th- and 17th-century English, his field of expertise, as well as courses on language in society.
Mr. Tonkin, 58 years old, holds undergraduate and master's degrees from Cambridge University and a master's degree and Ph.D. from Harvard. 
 During his tenure at the University of Hartford, the school shifted from attracting primarily Connecticut and New York State students to one that draws from more than 60 nations and almost every state. Academic programs also have broadened, and a $5 million deficit, due largely to the recession of the early 1990's, has all but disappeared.
During an interview in his office, Mr. Tonkin, who is also chairman of the Connecticut Conference of Independent Colleges, spoke of the role of higher education in society, the changing role of the teacher and technology in the classroom, and the constant popularity of Shakespeare. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. The Connecticut Conference of Independent Colleges has lobbyists at the General Assembly. What relationship do private colleges have with the state?
A. Higher education is a public good. Students should have opportunities to attend any of the various institutions in the state -- be they public, be they independent.
And from the point of view of the taxpayer, independent higher education is an extremely good bargain. We give, for example, almost half of the four-year degrees that are given in the state. We give two-thirds of the graduate degrees. So we are a very big factor in the economy.
The reality is that if you simply subsidize a piece of the system, you may in fact not improve the system overall; you may simply move students from one place to another.
So what you really have to do is look comprehensively at the whole system, provide it with the kind of support that allows it to function well, and if you do that effectively then we'll end up keeping more of our students in Connecticut so that they don't wander off to other places, and also attracting good students into the state, who can then occupy some of those jobs for which industry has so much demand.
Q. What direction do you see higher education heading in general, and in the state?
A. I think we have a highly unstable economy in higher education. Independent institutions are getting more and more expensive for the people who attend them. And public institutions are absorbing more and more public money. We may have overextended ourselves in the provisions of resources to higher education generally.
Independent higher education could easily price itself out of the market, and public higher education could easily become so expensive that the states can't afford it.
We need to come up with something more rational. If you look at the state, specifically, if we spend money on the public sector, and we don't look after the independent sector, the result will be a weakening of the independent sector without a parallel strengthening of the public sector. The one will, in effect, simply draw resources from the other. So we need to be looking at a comprehensive public policy approach to higher education generally.
Q. Is that happening?
A. Not to the extent that it needs to be.
Q. Why are leaving your post as president of the University of Hartford?
A. Well, I've been president at one place or another now for 15 years, over a third of my professional life, and I think you reach a certain age where you say to yourself, is what I'm doing now the only thing I've ever wanted to do? So I reached the conclusion that it probably made sense for me to turn myself back into a faculty member.
The other thing is, I think that being a college president is something that one should do for a piece of time but not do forever, because in some sense a part of the job description is that the president be overworked. Go like crazy, and push really, really hard, but in the process of doing that you get tired. Having done 15 years of college presidencies, it's about the outer limit of one person should be able to stand.
Q. What is it about the classroom that excites you?
A. There are two things really. One is the simple give and take. At the end of the day, you feel as though you've done something that will have a long-term effect on people of a positive kind. The second, actually, has to do with the particular point in history that we've reached. I've been assisting other people to make use of new technology. I want to use the new technology, to see what it will do for me and the teaching process.
So there's both the notion that you're actually dealing with one-on-one with somebody on whom who you can actually have a positive effect, and also the very simple fact that the 90's are a terrific and exciting time to be involved in teaching. I'm watching other people do it and I find myself saying, "I want to get in there and do that too'."
Q. Would you say that with new technology in the classroom, the teacher's role is changing?
A. Oh, definitely. To an increasing degree the teacher is becoming guide and mediator in a process as opposed to the font of all wisdom. Students can engage in unmediated communication with a local web site. So the faculty member now plays the role of guide and facilitator.
It isn't that the alternative to learning in a classroom is ignorance, but that the alternative to learning in a classroom is confusion. It's the function of the professor to help students make choices in essence. That's very different from what we've seen before.
But at the same time, the technology can assist us to do things that we could never do before. If I can work with a group of students on Shakespeare, and have at my fingertips the entire text of Shakespeare, there are things that I can begin to do that I could never do before.
Q. What is it about Shakespeare that makes him still so popular?
A. Purely and simply, large numbers of people in this country have actually been through an undergraduate education. So they've read Shakespeare, and he's not somebody who scares people off. Back in 1939, there were 1.5 million people in higher education; today there are 14 million.
Now why does Shakespeare speak to us? I think mostly because Shakespeare tells stories. At the heart of every Shakespeare play, for all its complexity, there is a very simple story. An old man has three daughters, and he decides to divide his kingdom among those three daughters. There is the germ of the plot of "Lear," and you or I can make up the rest, and it will probably come out pretty much where Shakespeare comes out. In an odd kind of way, Shakespeare is both full of surprises and has no surprises. Shakespeare speaks to us in a very direct way.
Q. Do you believe a university has a role or responsibility in a community?
A. Yes. One of the things that we should do as custodians of not just simply intellectual resources, but of much of the expertise of a community, is to share that expertise with the larger community. It's essential to our well-being.
I've done my best to open up the university to other audiences than simply traditional undergraduates. Some years back I founded the President's College, with non-credit courses. Today there are literally hundreds of people taking courses through this program. The university isn't just something with walls around it and shut off from the community, but it's theirs and they can use it, share in it.
We now run the Hartford Scholars Program, whereby any student graduating from high school in Hartford could come to the university for half of the normal tuition. We've had hundreds of students, and many have gone back into the community.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Humphrey Tonkin, abandoning a university presidency for a hands-on experience with the new technology. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Antipoverty Group Fighting to Keep Its Center Open

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER 

 BODY:
CEILING tiles are falling down and there is a puddle of water in the middle of the worn wooden floor in the Manhasset-Great Neck Economic Opportunity Commission center's gym. The antipoverty group's basketball team has no place to practice, the computer room is vacant and paint is peeling on the columned facade of the former schoolhouse, constructed in 1929 as the segregated Manhaaset Valley School.
Jerome Blocker, chairman of the board of the community center, was in the last kindergarten class to attend the Negro school in 1964. Partway through that year, desegregation closed the facility and Mr. Blocker and his classmates were divided between the Munsey Park and Plandome Road schools. After class, Mr. Blocker, now a tax preparer who grew up in the projects across the road, returned to the brick building at the top of the hill on High Street, which reopened as a community center, to participate in scouts, music lessons and sports with his neighborhood friends. 
 His two young children may not have the same opportunity. The future of the center, once the focal point of this pocket of subsidized apartments and Cape Cod-style homes nestled between Northern Boulevard, Community Drive and Lakeville Road, is in doubt. In January, the E.O.C. of Nassau County voted to terminate the program, one of eight in the county. The center also houses the Head Start program for 3- and 4-year-olds from the Great Neck, Manhasset, Roslyn and Port Washington areas.
Additionally, in December, the Manhasset-Great Neck E.O.C. filed a lawsuit against the E.O.C. of Nassau County in State Supreme Court regarding the allegedly fraudulent transfer of the deed of the community center property from Manhasset-Great Neck E.O.C. to the E.O.C. of Nassau County in 1992. A temporary restraining order stopping the Nassau E.O.C. from interfering with the center's board, staff and programming has been extended until Wednesday, according to John Brickman, lawyer for the Manhasset-Great Neck E.O.C.
Mr. Blocker said the Town of North Hempstead sold the building to the Manhasset-Great Neck E.O.C. in 1980 for one dollar. While preparing for renovations recently, they discovered they no longer held the title. "This was done without the community's consent or knowledge," Mr. Blocker said.
Mr. Blocker said he had written a letter to the Nassau E.O.C., asking for the building to be transferred back. Besides the Head Start Program, which has 54 children enrolled, the Manhasset-Great Neck E.O.C. has 35 first and second graders in its Adventures in Learning after-school tutorial program. African dance classes, scouts, Planned Parenthood, Alcoholics Anonymous and civic associations meet in the building, which also has a food pantry. Eighty children participate in the center's summer program.
"They didn't respond," he said of the Nassau group. "They had an executive committee meeting. According to the minutes of that meeting, they indicated they had read the letter. A discussion ensued around the cost of maintaining the building. John L. Kearse, chief executive of Nassau E.O.C., Mr. Blocker said, "indicated that the property could be used as a Child Care Development Center and would be renovated by Head Start funds, which would effectively dissolve our board and our rights to the building. In other words, they didn't like my letter. They wanted to dissolve our board so that we had no recourse in the matter."
In an interview, Mr. Kearse said the E.O.C. "was in its right to effect the transfer of the deed." Since the local Manhasset-Great Neck board was in suspension from 1985 to 1994, Mr. Kearse said his agency needed control of the facility in order to obtain financing for renovations and programming. "We wouldn't do anything that we're not legally authorized to do," he said. "We then proceeded to go ahead with our normal policy of local empowerment."
Mr. Kearse, who has headed the E.O.C. since 1970 and is under Federal and county scrutiny for alleged credit union violations and for dismissal of several workers who refused to contribute to an agency-sponsored scholarship fund, said he hoped the entire center can be renovated.
"The administrative offices and certain sections of that building are not safe," he said. "We are not going to close down the Head Start. We have been very diligently searching to find another venue for them so it can be renovated and then everybody can be brought home as they should be. Our plans are to locate the funds with which to renovate and refurbish so it can be a useful community facility. It would be run by the commission. As much as we want to do something, there is no way we can put youngsters in a situation like that and feel comfortable. We've worked too long and too hard to have our communities settle for conditions like that."
The center has a budget of over half a million dollars a year. "There is no reason why the county, the town, even the state and the Feds should not help us get that building refurbished to help the community," he said. "Over the years, we put in more than $2 million into that facility." Mr. Kearse contended that when the building was transferred from the Town of North Hempstead, certain agreements were not kept, "a promise that says when we started out with the transfer of the building, minimally each year, the town would provide the agency with $40,000 for maintenance, taking the garbage away, keeping things clean. That never happened." He added that the county youth board also failed to fulfill a promise to provide financing.
Mr. Blocker said renovations have not been done to the building in 20 years. "We've tried to bring it up a number of times but they've been unresponsive," he said. "They spent $56,000 on the roof and it still leaks. We have trouble getting tables and chairs, much less renovations for the building. They're not telling the truth. What they're doing is retaliation for the lawsuit."
Since the injunction was filed, the executive director and outreach worker were dismissed, although they continue to report to work each day. Lights and telephone service were briefly disconnected. Officials from the Nassau E.O.C. showed up recently with a locksmith and moving company and started tagging tables and chairs. Last September, Mr. Blocker said that the "E.O.C. terminated half our staff because of a disagreement with Nassau County over funding. We had to cut back on programming."
While Mr. Kearse explained that the locksmith and moving company were sent to give estimates, Mr. Blocker maintained that had the police not been called, they would have been ejected that day.
"What's at stake here is our children and the welfare of entire community," he said. "Our community would be devastated. Where would our children go? We wouldn't have anyplace for our children to go and that's our No. 1 concern. We were on the verge of doing some really good things in terms of renovating the building and being able to expand our programming. We were getting a 10-station computer lab down here. We're talking about the economically disadvantaged in the area. There are pockets of poverty throughout the Manhasset-Great Neck area and they are abundant. People don't realize it in the midst of all this affluence."
Because the neighborhood is geographically isolated from the rest of Great Neck and Manhasset, the center is the only recreation facility available to many of the children. "Transportation is an issue and so is safety in getting to places. Great Neck and Manhasset are not the easiest places to get around if you don't have transportation," said Robin Wheat, executive director of the center, one of the dismissed employees.
The Town of North Hempstead Supervisor, May W. Newburger, who is on the center's advisory board, said the town would not allow the community center to be lost if the lawsuit fails. "It is so unfair," she said. "The people here have tried so hard in these last years to revitalize this center. I think they deserve every single bit of help they can get. I'm deeply sorry that John Kearse instead of helping them to become independent and working together, is taking the kinds of actions that have been taken here. It's just wrong. I believe that much more needs to be done and all of us have to be part of it. We're going to do something. I can't let them fail. Most important, what we don't see everywhere, the young people here have taken the lead and I think it's critical that we support them."
The County Legislature has also gotten involved. Lisanne G. Altmann, Nassau County Legislator in the 10th district, said she doubted the facility will be closed down. "We've been in the thick of things. The County Legislature voted to take the money away from the E.O.C. and we now in the County Legislature control a lot of the funding. We're able now to funnel money now and go around John Kearse.
"I believe that they'll be successful. I don't think that anybody's going to let this building get closed down. I think at that point they are going to bring the wrath of all kinds of people down on themselves. They are playing pretty tough tactics with this group here but I don't think they'd actually close them down.
"This is a very strong group of people who have really overcome, finally. I think this is the first E.O.C. that stood up and said, 'We're not going to take this kind of treatment anymore.' That's why they are in trouble with John Kearse, because they dared to stand up and say no. I'm very proud of them. We're making sure they get their money one way or another."
A grievance hearing Monday night was a "reaffirmation of fact that the group is not willing to abide by the the convenants and agreements we entered into or the rules and regulations we operate as a program," said Mr. Kearse, reiterating that the Manhasset-Great Neck community action program no longer has a board of directors or a staff.
"You can't terminate a contract without a hearing," Mr. Blocker asserted. "They were making up their own rules. They were going to ambush us and be done with us. This is all being done by Kearse."
