HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Where Disney World Meets Camden

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
EVERYBODY does it, Elaine Bey had insisted. Stealing from the schools of Camden, a city whose children are the poorest in the country, was no big deal, she seemed to believe.
This attitude became breathtakingly clear one day last September, when Mrs. Bey, 55, strolled out of a Federal courtroom in Newark after pleading guilty to misusing school system money to treat herself and others to restaurants, liquor, entertainment, car rentals and personal vacations while she was president of the Camden School Board. 
 Outside the courtroom, a reporter asked what she was going to do now.
"I'm going to the ladies' room," she declared brightly, smiling into the cameras. "And then I'm going to Disney World!"
Now Mrs. Bey will have to wait a while to take that vacation, as she is due to report to prison on March 30 to begin a five-month sentence that was imposed on her in January by a Federal judge. The judge also ordered her to pay back more than $23,000 in school system funds, and serve five months of house arrest after she gets out of jail.
If there were a criminal indictment of America's miserably failed urban policies, the city of Camden -- which stubbornly posted a 63 percent increase in homicides last year as the murder rate plunged almost everywhere else -- would be entered in evidence at the trial and labeled "the smoking gun." Ordinarily, the amazing audacity exhibited by a school board president who steals and laughs it off could be shrugged off as just another of the incremental outrages in Camden, a city of about 80,000 that has been systematically pillaged by one political regime after another for the past 50 years and now stands out as perhaps the most wretched, God-forsaken city in America.
In this case, however, that brazen taunt -- "I'm going to Disney World!" -- was still very fresh in mind recently when I got a phone call telling me that Leroy Palmer -- a Camden police lieutenant who grew up in the city, attended its public schools and whose career ambition was to be a good cop -- had been shot and critically wounded while coming to another officer's aid during an undercover drug stakeout that went very bad, very fast, on the night of Feb. 13.
All of a sudden, a few tiny disconnected wires in the tangled skein of abstract news touched and sparked with a personal jolt. Lieutenant Palmer's younger brother, Ralph, is married to my kid sister, Susan.
A Camden police officer for 23 years, Lieutenant Palmer, 46, went down in a gun battle at an East Camden intersection. The corner at Bank and Boyd Streets is a notorious drug market where dealers do a brisk business selling to customers who drive in from the suburbs to do the only shopping that still brings out-of-towners into Camden.
Lieutenant Palmer was coordinating the stakeout from an unmarked car just up the block. Dozens of arrests had already been made, and now the undercover officers were almost at the end of their tour.
Just before 11 P.M., though, a 38-year-old Williamstown man, informed that he was under arrest for buying crack cocaine from two undercover officers on the corner, pulled out a revolver and started firing. Joseph Badecki, 35, a state trooper, was the first one shot, in the arm. Tumbling out of the car, Lieutenant Palmer ran to the scene and was struck by a bullet that went through his side, pierced a lung and lodged near his spine. David Lick, 28, a detective with the Camden County Prosecutor's Office, was grazed on the head by another bullet.
The suspect, Byran Girard, was killed as the officers returned fire. The other two officers were treated and released at Cooper Hospital-University Medical Center. As of the other day, however, Lieutentant Palmer was still in critical condition at Cooper, breathing with the aid of a respirator -- and forcing himself to contemplate the horrible possibility that he may never walk again.
Lieutenant Palmer is known, personally and professionally, as an easygoing, decent man with a ready laugh. His wife, Terry, and his two children, Matt, 15, and Kristin, 12, are the center of his life. He was due for retirement in 16 months. After that, he and his wife had planned to move with their children to North Carolina.
"He's a fighter," said Ralph Palmer, 40, who grew up believing that his older brother could do anything, and who now believes that he will manage to get back on his feet before long. "If anybody can do it, he can," he said.
Incidentally, Leroy Palmer loved to take his family to vacations in Florida, including Disney World.
The fervent hope here, as a cop who went down a hero on a thankless job tries to put a life back together, is that Leroy Palmer takes his family on that trip once again -- and that they get there first.

HEADLINE: Multiplex Heralded As Linchpin To Growth

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
SCENE 1. Take 1. Roll the cameras!"
It is Mayor Joseph M. Delfino in the director's chair, and he is promising audiences here a good-news tale with a happy ending about their tattered downtown. 
 "Trust me, it's a true story," the Mayor said, his director's clapper in hand. "Just don't forget to save me an aisle seat when it opens."
Mayor Delfino has been euphoric since learning last month that Tishman Speyer Properties and Loews Theaters, a Sony company, plan to open a 24-screen, 5,200-seat theater in the heart of a shopping district that has been down on its luck of late, but -- like an aging star with a new role to play -- poised for a comeback.
The new multiplex, which will become a regional flagship theater for Loews, is to be at the site of an abandoned building once occupied by Macy's. And while not the largest Loews movie theater in the United States in terms of seating, it will have the most screens.
The former Macy's will be razed to make way for the new three-and-a-half-story building, which will feature a glass atrium facing Mamaroneck Avenue, the main thoroughfare where boarded-up storefronts now line the street. Tishman Speyer is also negotiating to buy two turn-of-the-century bank buildings on the block to include in the project. In addition to the theaters, Tishman Speyer/Travelers Real Estate Venture, a recently formed joint venture, plans to provide space for two levels of retail shops, several restaurants and about 300 market-rate apartments.
"It doesn't take a lot of vision to see how the downtown will change," Travis Reid, president of Loews Theaters, said. "This is a fairly densely populated and underserved market." White Plains has not had its own movie theater for a number of years.
Municipal officials, who have long struggled to halt a downslide in what was once known as the City of a Thousand Stores, said they were heartened by news of the $100 million project, which is to begin early next year and be completed by December 1999.
Mayor Delfino, who predicted the new construction would serve as a linchpin for the city's growth, said recently, "It's a major, major step in the overall revitalization of downtown White Plains and will play a crucial role in enhancing our position as the heart of Westchester County."
When Macy's moved out of the building it had occupied in the center of the downtown area for 47 years and into the Galleria mall nearby, its relocation was just another in a series of blows for the once prosperous downtown. Many of the merchants who continue to eke out a living in the shadow of three successful malls welcomed news of the plans.
"It has been so quiet during the last few years," Joseph Romano, the owner of Village Jewelers, said. "Maybe this will give shoppers a reason to come back to Mainstreet U.S.A."
In addition to the growth of malls, there have been other factors contributing to the decline of this once busy retail area. The downtown, at one time also a thriving banking and commercial center and the home of several Fortune 500 companies, has suffered from corporate downsizing and the steady emptying of office buildings.
The vacancy rate early in the 1990's soared to 30 percent and more, although last year it began to edge downward. In general, there appears to be an economic turnabout in the works, business leaders said in recent interviews.
Carl Austin, president of Austin Corporate Properties in White Plains, reported a number of positive signs, including news that Cohen Brothers Realty of Manhattan recently acquired the 623,000-square-foot now empty Kraft Foods complex in White Plains, and Cigna Investments has almost fully leased the 400,000-square-foot Gateway Building office tower formerly occupied by AT&T at the Metro-North Station in White Plains.
Mr. Austin said that the vacancy rate for Class A commercial real estate in White Plains was at last count in the mid-teens, although other properties remained difficult to rent.
The Federated Department Stores property at the corner of Mamaroneck Avenue and Main Street has always been considered a prime location and had been coveted by the movie company for years.
"Loews had been eyeing the site for some time," Jim Loeks, co-chairman of Loews said, "but Macy's was still selling socks there."
An earlier plan to build a multiplex theater near the White Plains train station has since been dropped in favor of the current plans to build downtown. Under the latest proposal, Loews will lease 118,000 square feet in the new structure from Tishman Speyer for its 24 theaters. All told, the retail and movie theater components will cover about 450,000 square feet.
Tishman Speyer and Sony Loews have another joint project -- in Berlin, where they built a two million-square-foot, mixed-use complex, which includes office space, an entertainment center and retail outlets.
Steven M. Wise, director of the project for Tishman Speyer, said market research studies indicated that White Plains was an ideal site for a multitheater complex and would draw from a broad geographical area, including Fairfield County. In addition, a strong infrastructure, including major highways, serves traffic generated by the theater complex, he said.
Several large projects are on the drawing board for theaters in other Westchester cities. In New Rochelle, which like White Plains has tried to attract business and enliven its deteriorating downtown, a 20-screen movie theater will be part of a 375,000-square-foot entertainment, sports and shopping complex. Called the New Rochelle Center, the $106 million project will also include a 70,000-square-foot supermarket, two ice-skating rinks and the county's first IMAX theater.
The complex planned for New Rochelle by AMC Theaters will not compete with the theaters in White Plains, Mr. Wise said, because each will tap a different market.
In Greenburgh, National Amusements, owner of the 10-screen All Westchester Saw Mill Complex in Hawthorne, is negotiating to buy space in a shopping center on Route 9A in Greenburgh for a second 10-screen complex.
In Mount Vernon, National Amusements is one of three bidders -- along with Regal Cinemas and Magic Johnson Theaters -- vying to open a multiplex theater.
In White Plains, David Rockwell, an architect specializing in entertainment properties, will design the megaplex -- which will have oversize movie screens, digital sound, stadium-type seating and either rocker seats or loveseats or possibly both. Every row will be at least 14 inches higher than the one in front of it, increasing sight lines. Plans for the lobby include several box offices, a concession stand and a kiosk featuring movie previews.
Local designers for the site include PEG/Park Architects in White Plains and Warshauer Mellusi and Warshauer, architects in Hawthorne.
"The theater industry is reinventing itself," Mr. Reid said. "It's becoming more service oriented."
In general, real estate developers and retailers are banking on entertainment -- which includes eating and drinking along with movies and games -- to lure increasingly alienated shoppers back. Malls, in particular, are trying to reinvent themselves, especially since the amount of time the average shopper spends at a mall on each trip has declined to about 70 minutes from more than 90 minutes in the early 1980's, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, an industry trade group based in Manhattan.
Mr. Reid observed that movie theaters in recent years have been in keen competition with other forms of out-of-home entertainment like restaurants and sporting events.
Loews, which operates 1,020 screens in 140 locations in 16 states, is merging with Cineplex Odeon, which operates 1,600 screens throughout the United States and Canada.
Tishman Speyer Properties is one of the oldest and largest real estate organizations in the United States and has developed or acquired properties valued at about $6 billion. In addition to its headquarters in Manhattan, the company has branches in Chicago, San Francisco, Stamford and Houston among other cities. It has international offices in London, Paris, Frankfurt, Berlin and Sao Paulo. Most recently, the company bought the Chrysler Building and the Kent Building, along with adjacent properties, between 42d and 43d Streets and Lexington and Third Avenues in Manhattan. It is also a co-owner and the managing agent for Rockefeller Center.
Neither Tishman Speyer nor Loews would disclose the purchase price of the property here.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: March 1, 1998

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 4; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1353 words

HEADLINE: Stamford's Old Town Hall Faces Developers

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
IN Stamford, where landmark buildings have been demolished by the hundreds over the last two decade and replaced by an eclectic array of corporate office towers, the Old Town Hall in the heart of downtown has seemed sacrosanct: a striking Beaux Arts structure gracefully bespeaking the city's past and aparently exempt from unending urban renewal.
But as years passed and the Old Town Hall sat unoccupied and deteriorating, following the move of municipal offices to other buildings a decade ago, city officials began wondering what to do with Stamford's architectural crown jewel. Committees were set up by several mayors, including the incumbent, Dannel P. Malloy, but none was able to come up with viable suggestions, or tenants, for the grand old building. 
 Meanwhile, in Greenwich and Norwalk, town halls of the same vintage as Stamford's 1906 stone structure were converted into multipurpose use. In Greenwich, the 95-year-old former town hall on Greenwich Avenue, in the heart of the business district, has thrived as an arts and senior center, offering space to work in galleries, to dance or play musical instruments in studios or to play checkers or cards. In Norwalk, the 86-year-old Colonial revival-style red brick former town hall was recently converted into a museum, although it also has a commercial tenant.
Now Stamford officials are mulling over a proposal: a developer plans to build a 13-story, $200-a-night hotel atop the Old Town Hall. It is a proposal that Mayor Malloy, a Democrat, seems to think may have some merit, as does the local newspaper, The Advocate, but to which many Stamfordites have reacted with alarm and outrage.
Even Don Russell, a longtime broadcaster and columnist in Stamford, who has, by and large, supported the city's transformation into a corporate mecca, has drawn a figurative line in the sand in the case of the Old Town Hall. "There are some things that are sacred to natives and longtime residents, such as parkland and, yes, the Old Town Hall," he recently wrote in The Advocate.
Similar sentiments have been expressed in letters to the editor of The Advocate. Comparing the proposal to the demolition of the old Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan more than three decades ago, Joseph Gatto Jr. of Stamford, wrote, "Stamford is on the verge of creating its own historic blunder, selling the Old Town Hall, having it converted into a luxury hotel and wiping out a piece of Stamford history forever."
In response to such negative comments, Stephen D. Julius 3d, the Stamford real estate developer involved, has said, "What's wrong with putting up something that will accommodate 264 bodies in a building that nobody's been in for 11 years?"
Mr. Julius, who is the president of Proteus Group LLC, explained in an interview, "Here we are, willing to restore the building at a cost of more than $6 million and then create more than 300 jobs in the hotel itself, along with generating other business for downtown Stamford."
Under his proposal, his company, in conjunction with Madison Equities, a Manhattan-based developer, would build an upscale hotel "that would be a major contributor to the city's tax base while removing a potential financial drain." In exchange for doing the necessary restoration, Mr. Julius said, his company and its associates in the venture would want to operate the hotel rent-free for three years. Initially, he also proposed reduced real estate taxes during that period, but that idea was abandoned.
Though the hotel would be designed for an affluent clientele, Mr. Julius said downtown employes and other Stamford residents would be welcome to use the hostelry's restaurants, bars, meeting rooms and other rooms. "We might even put a museum in the basement where traveling art exhibits could be displayed," he said. "And of course the hotel could be used for wedding receptions and other functions."
Mayor Malloy, who recently began a second term, did not return telephone calls about the hotel proposal. But in response to the hotel proposal and one for a brew pub and restaurant (which has since been dropped), the Mayor has been quoted as saying, "The Old Town Hall has been closed for approximately 10 years and life will be brought back to one of our most historical landmarks located in the core of our downtown."
Not many Stamfordites seem to think that the Old Town Hall with its majestic style -- spiral staircase and striking Depression-era murals on the interior, clock tower, plaza and semi-circular staircase on the exterior -- should be brought back to life with a hotel atop it.
"The negative public reaction has been the greatest to any proposal made since urban renewal began," said Renee Kahn, a dedicated preservationist and the director of Stamford's Historic Neighborhoods Preservation Program. "There's been this great sense of outrage, and I don't think the proposal has a snowball's chance in hell."
Others are equally vociferous. "Profit is what has driven all of the redevelopment in Stamford," said Ralph Loglisci, a Republican and the minority leader of the Stamford Board of Representatives. "Everything's done to maximize profit and in the process we have failed to save a lot of historic buildings in town. And building a hotel on top of the Old Town Hall is a terrible idea. If the people of the city chose to save the building, we can do so. Like some other reps, I'm getting a lot of calls on this, and they're all against the hotel idea."
Another representative, Maria Nakian, a Democrat, said she is getting a similar reaction, from constituents and members of the Board of Representatives, which can kill the proposal since the Old Town Hall is city property.
"The consensus among the members is not to approve the hotel proposal," said Ms. Nakian, who is chairwoman of a 12-member committee from the Board that is studying the proposal and is to give a report to the full board tomorrow. "The Old Town Hall is prime real estate and should be used for community purposes," she said. "We should not let the building be caught up in a commercial venture."
Ms. Nakian said that the hotel proposal could be killed by any one of three city boards: planning, finance or representatives. "I doubt very much if it will go through," she said.
Mr. Loglisci and Ms. Kahn were among a group including several city representatives who toured the old Norwalk City Hall, now the Norwalk Museum. "Everyone was impressed with what they've done," said Ms. Kahn, an art historian. "And look what they've done in Greenwich. There's no reason why Stamford can't do the same, or even more."
In Greenwich, the upper two floors of the 93-year-old former town hall, now known as the Greenwich Senior/ Arts Center, were renovated at a cost of about $125,000, all of which was privately raised, according to Betsy Jordan Hand, the executive director of the center.
Meanwhile, almost $235,000 in Federal funds were used to put in a fire alarm system and renovate the lower level and first floor, which serve as the senior center. That money was obtained through a Federal Community Development Block Grant, which provides benefits for low- and moderate-income people, says Nancy Brown, the Greenwich Director of Community Development.
"We're totally self-supporting," Ms. Hand said of the Greenwich Arts Center. "There's always something going on in the building. And we have a waiting list of artists and sculptors who want to lease space, which has to be done for at least a year."
Ruth Sims -- the Greenwich First Selectman from 1978-1981 credited with proposing and fostering the transformation of the hall -- said:"It was one of the major issues I ran on. And the building has been a great success.
"It's a perfect solution with what to do with a functional and attractive old building. And it's benefited the entire town."
Ms. Kahn, the Stamford preservationist, said, "We have an even more attractive building than Norwalk and Greenwich, and it's right smack in the heart of downtown.
"An expensive hotel on top of our beautiful Old Town Hall is certainly not the way to go."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1180 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
For Rye Brook, 429-Home Village in a Village

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: RYE BROOK

 BODY:
AN unusual residential project, designed to encourage interaction among neighbors and replicate some of the aspects of life in a small town, is scheduled to break ground next month on 140 acres along King Street, one of the last remaining parcels of land left in this village.
Called BelleFair, the innovative project contains elements that in combination have never been tried before in a Westchester residential community. 
 Designed to evoke the ambiance and architecture of a village or small town, BelleFair will have houses that look out on a village green, many with front porches. Half of its 429 units of housing will be targeted to the elderly, empty-nesters and retirees, the other half to young families. There will also be 12 moderately priced units in three town houses, with priority given to Rye Brook employees.
In addition, there will be a village green, a general store, a community center and a day-care center.
"The young families will be able to take advantage of an on-site day-care center, which is a first in a residential development in Westchester as far as I know," said Mitchell Hochberg, president of Spectrum Skanska, of Valhalla, one of three partners in the joint venture. The others are CareMatrix Corporation, of Needham, Mass., a provider of housing for the elderly, and Benenson Capital Company, a privately owned development concern based in Manhattan.
In designing the project, the developers borrowed concepts from "new urbanism," which in its purest form is meant to create self-contained communities, with their own shops, schools and recreation.
"New urbanism really means trying to eliminate the car completely, and we're not trying to do that here," Mr. Hochberg said. "I don't think that, in its purest form, new urbanism really works. What we're trying to do here is borrow the best of it, which means having all kinds of people together and give them space and reasons to gather. I think it's something that's been happening in other parts of the country, but it's been very slow in coming here."
The houses will be designed to look like those in a place like Charleston, S.C., Mr. Hochberg said. The garages will be at the backs of the houses, with porches on the fronts, to encourage people to congregate outside. "This way people can sit on their front porches and see their neighbors pass by on their way to the village green or the community center.
The focal point of the development will be an oval-shaped village green, which will be almost as large as a football field. The 18,000-square-foot community center nearby will have a pool, full-court basketball gym and a computer room. "From 4 P.M. to 8 P.M., we'll have a teacher at the computer room," Mr. Hochberg said. "We hope to attract 8- to 16-year-olds, and give them something to do after school."
Two of the more unusual features of the project are a 2,400-square-foot free-standing day-care center and the 3,000-square-foot general store.
"The store is very important to me," Mr. Hochberg said. "I envision it as the old-style store, where a bell rings when you open the door. There'll be an old-fashioned soda fountain. We plan to have a wide selection of magazines and newspapers. People can come in to buy their staples like milk and bread, or can sit and have a cappuccino."
The name BelleFair suggests the community's bell tower, which will be the focal point of the village green, Mr. Hochberg explained. "We combined it with the idea of an old town fair where everyone would congregate and there'd be a lot of activity. That's what we hope will happen here."
In a previous incarnation, the project's name was to have been High Point Village, since it was being built on a site once occupied by High Point Hospital, a psychiatric hospital that closed in 1995. "Rye Brook decided that it didn't want a residential community to be called a village," Mr. Hochberg said. "So we had to come up with another name."
The joint venture partnership purchased the 140-acre property in 1995 for $9.1 million. Its final approvals were granted on Jan. 27, and construction is expected to begin in April. The rezoned property, off heavily trafficked King Street, had been zoned for up to 1.2 million square feet of office space. "This use is much better for the village, especially with such a high concentration of housing for the elderly," said Mayor Salvatore M. Cresenzi. "Many of those people won't even have cars."
SINCE the property borders the Westchester County Airport, noise issues were a concern, the Mayor noted. As a result, several noise reduction features, such as triple pane windows and extra insulation, will be added in the construction.
There will be 203 detached three- and four-bedroom homes, 30 of which will be built around the village green and called "village homes." The homes will range in size from 2,000 to 3,200 square feet and be priced from $369,000 to $525,000.
The village homes will start at $429,000, Mr. Hochberg said, since they are "the most desirable, fronting either the village green or green corridors directly off it."
The component for the elderly, which is being developed by CareMatrix, will include a 168-unit, three-story building with studio, one- and two-bedroom apartments, some with dens. Monthly rents of $2,700 to $4,500 will include housekeeping, meals and transportation.
"Residents can also use a fitness center on site," said Michael J. Zaccaro, an executive vice president at CareMatrix, "and get a personalized fitness program. There will also be a on-site health-care coordinator who can visit residents in their homes."
All apartments will be equipped with a push-button emergency response system, Mr. Zaccaro added. "The button will be on the phone, but residents can also wear one or attach it to the wall," said Mr. Zaccaro.
When depressed, it emits a radio frequency that activates the phone system. "An employee will immediately be able to speak to the resident, and someone will be dispatched to the apartment," said Mr. Zacarro.
CareMatrix is also developing 46 "maintenance-free" villas designed for empty-nesters and retirees. These homes, which will be side-by-side duplexes, will have master bedrooms on the ground floor. They will range in size from 1,540 square feet to 2,200 and be priced from $359,000. Residents will have access to services at the community for the elderly on a fee basis. Mr. Zaccaro said the fees have not yet been set.
CareMatrix has developed more than 30 communities nationally, and has an additional 60 under way, according to Mr. Zacarro. "About 30 of those are now under construction," he said. This is the company's first experience in a project not exclusively for the elderly.
"It's great for us," Mr. Zaccaro said, "because our residents can have all the services that we provide and also be able to use the development's recreation as well.
"I hope we'll be doing more such projects in the future. But it's not a strategy that we are pursuing. There aren't a lot of opportunities to do projects the size of this one."

GRAPHIC: Photo: From the left, rendering of BelleFair's 2,400-square-foot day-care center, 3,000-square-foot general store, 18,000-square-foot community center and bell tower. (The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Do You Know These Women?

BYLINE: By DIANE NOTTLE 

 BODY:
ANNIE OAKLEY slept here -- in Nutley, where she settled for 10 years after touring Europe with Buffalo Bill.
So did Elizabeth Cady Stanton, in Tenafly, where she and Susan B. Anthony began writing their mammoth history of the women's suffrage movement. So did their comrade Lucy Stone, in Orange, West Bloomfield and Newark, until she moved to Massachusetts to carry on her crusade for equal rights. 
 And then there's Christine Todd Whitman. But you know all about her.
In New Jersey as elsewhere, women hold up half the sky -- slightly more of it, in fact. In 1996, an estimated 50.7 percent of the state's population was female, according to the Current Population Survey conducted by the United States Census Bureau. Among its female residents, past and present, the state has had its share of heroines, sung and un-.
Heroine is, of course, a relative term, depending on which side of any given revolution you're on. Most New Jerseyans have heard of Molly Pitcher and the mental health crusader Dorothea Lynde Dix. But what about Sarah Kiersted, Elizabeth Haddon, Betsey Stockton?
Women's History Month honors all of them. This March is the 12th annual Women's History Month declared by Congress, and since 1998 is the 150th anniversary of the world's first women's rights convention in Seneca Falls, N.Y., the observance is doubly significant this year.
Under the broadest definition of feminism -- "the principle that women should have political, economic and social rights equal to those of men," according to Webster's New World Dictionary -- New Jersey women of the last three centuries have been feminists whether they knew it or not. And their concerns have changed surprisingly little over the years.
Marital property rights? The wife of the colony's first English governor had a prenuptial agreement. Sexual assault? The rapes of New Jersey women by British and Hessian soldiers during the Revolutionary War are seldom noted among the tales of sacrifice and patriotism. Equal opportunity? Clara Barton taught school in Bordentown for 20 years until she was passed over for a principalship in favor of a man, and only then made a career change into nursing. Working women? When have New Jersey women not been working?
Many shrines of women's history are long gone, and many institutions of debatable value to women's cause remain. (The Miss America pageant is still going strong in Atlantic City 30 years after feminists who were soon labeled as "bra burners" protested the image of young womanhood that the pageant promoted.) Yet, one by one, the women of New Jersey have indisputably left their mark on the state and the nation.
 
Settlers, Slaves And Suffragists
Who was New Jersey's first heroine? Whoever she was, there's a good chance her name was Elizabeth. Lady Elizabeth Carteret, for whom Elizabethtown was named in 1669, was briefly proprietor of East Jersey in the early 1680's but never actually set foot in the colony, preferring to stay home on the Isle of Jersey in the English Channel. Then there was Elizabeth Smith Lawrence Carteret, she of that prenuptial agreement, a widow who married the first English governor of East Jersey. A century later, Elizabeth Ray Clark Bodly founded Port Elizabeth and set the town on its path to becoming a trade and glassmaking center.
Another candidate is Elizabeth Haddon, founder of Haddonfield. The daughter of a London Quaker family that was friendly with William Penn, Elizabeth was bitten by the New World bug at an early age and traveled to New Jersey -- just 20 years old, alone and bearing her father's power of attorney -- to develop a 500-acre plantation he had bought. Depending on which account you believe, she either came here in hot pursuit of her future husband, a Quaker missionary named John Estaugh, or simply married him here. In any case, she was apparently a woman who knew what she wanted and went after it.
Even before the Elizabeths, a Dutch housewife named Sarah Kiersted was learning the language of the local Lenape Indians, possibly as early as the 1640's. She became a channel of communication between Dutch settlers and the Lenape Chief Oratam, and for her services the chief granted her almost 2,300 acres -- comprising all of Ridgefield Park and sections of Teaneck and Bogota -- in 1666. Even when the English captured the territory three years later, she proved her land grant legitimate and was allowed to keep it. (As for any individual Lenape heroines, they seem to have vanished, not surprisingly, into the mists of history.)
Through the 1700's, women did what women everywhere do: they worked, cooking, cleaning, cultivating, doing whatever was necessary to make their families and the colony prosper. In doing so, some found ways of expressing themselves. Patience Lovell Wright, a Quaker who at 23 had become the young wife of an elderly farmer, at 44 found herself a widow with three children to support. She parlayed a hobby -- modeling clay, bread dough and eventually wax -- into a paying career as a sculptor, especially of commissioned portraits in wax. Within a few years she opened a New York studio (which her children accidentally burned down) and then took her trade to England, where she became friendly with King George III and Queen Charlotte. Her first commission there was a bust of a son of William Penn; later she became known for her images of Benjamin Franklin and William Pitt the Elder, the head of which is still on view in Westminster Abbey, the body having been destroyed in the Blitz. When the Revolution came, she stayed in England but did a bit of spying for the Colonial cause before moving on to Paris during Franklin's ambassadorship there.
For the women back home, the Revolution was not a garden party. New Jersey's leading symbol of female heroism is still Molly Pitcher -- now immortalized as the namesake of a rest stop on the New Jersey Turnpike.
Now generally considered a composite figure of women who carried water to the battlefields for the soldiers, Molly Pitcher "is both as real and as legendary as G.I. Joe," writes Linda Grant De Pauw in her book "Fortunes of War: New Jersey Women and the American Revolution."
One such "Molly" was Mary Ludwig Hays McCauly, born near Trenton in the 1750's; she later migrated to Pennsylvania as a domestic servant but returned to home territory when her husband's Seventh Pennsylvania Regiment was fighting in New Jersey. She earned her nickname for her services at the Battle of Monmouth in 1778, but when her husband fell wounded, she put aside her pitcher and stepped in, loading the cannon and helping to keep the Colonial Army on track to victory.
Eventually McCauly was granted a pension not as a war widow, but for her own services. In addition to the rest stop -- not an inappropriate tribute, given the nature of her work -- she has been honored with a postcard issued by the United States Postal Service in 1978, as well as a bronze monument at the battle site in Monmouth, which was stolen some years ago.
The soon-to-be-state did have its more traditionally feminine leaders, among them Annis Boudinot Stockton of Princeton. Counting two signers of the Declaration of independence among her family, she was the mistress of the estate called Morven, choosing to stay there with her four children when her husband, Richard, traveled to England in 1766. No mere chatelaine, Annis was also a prolific poet, known particularly for her odes to, and correspondence with, George Washington..
Another Princeton woman named Stockton -- this one black -- serves as a reminder of the underside of early American history. Betsey Stockton, born a slave in the household of Robert Stockton in 1798, was given to his daughter, who married the president of what was then the College of New Jersey. Freed at age 20, she educated herself in the library of a family for whom she worked as a domestic servant, then traveled to Hawaii as a missionary four years later. After more than a decade there, she returned to Princeton to do a different kind of missionary work: teaching black children by day and black adults by night. She was also a founder of the Witherspoon Street Presbyterian Church in Princeton, which has a plaque and a stained-glass window in her memory.
During Betsey Stockton's childhood, New Jersey passed the first of a series of laws meant to phase out slavery in 1804, but the process was long and slow.
Many prominent 19th-century feminists had in fact begun their work as social reformers in the abolitionist cause. After the Emancipation Proclamation and the Civil War, women were in turn freed to turn their attention to their own grievances, and their own advancement. In 1867 the New Jersey Woman Suffrage Association was founded, headed by Lucy Stone -- a national suffrage leader who had, publicly and scandalously, kept her own name upon marriage and later refused to pay taxes on her house in Orange on the basis of no-taxation-without-representation.
 
Voices Heard In the Working World
Women like Stone in many ways personified the theory of 19th-century feminism; countless others were the practice as a farm-based economy gave way to business and industry.
Among them was Mary Philbrook. Born in Washington in 1972, Philbrook grew up in genteel poverty after her father left and her family moved to Jersey City. After graduating from Jersey City High School, she found work as a legal secretary but after a few years decided to become a lawyer herself. Applying to the state bar in 1894, she was refused admission not because she lacked a legal education -- most lawyers in those days "read law" in the course of their work, as opposed to attending law school -- but essentially because no other woman had been admitted. Philbrook pressed on and indeed became a lawyer, thanks to feminists' lobbying for a special law, not to mention the first woman to argue before the Supreme Court of the United States.
Years after her death in 1958, a virtually forgotten Philbrook was nevertheless still wielding her influence. In the mid-1970's, Barbara Petrick of Jersey City was looking beyond her home to do graduate work. "I was not interested in women's history," Mrs. Petrick said. "I was really an English major and a teacher. But I had three small children and couldn't travel very far; it was the old story of women." So she went to Jersey City State College, which had no graduate program in English but did have one in history. When she was looking for a thesis topic, she went to the New Jersey Historical Society and found a pamphlet saying the society had the papers of Mary Philbrook.
"They brought up the box, and I started going through it," she said. "What fascinated me was that she was from Jersey City and went to the high school where I now teach. She wasn't a Catholic, but she did social work in the parish where I grew up. She lived a few blocks away. You couldn't get more local than that. I really identified with her."
Today, Mrs. Petrick holds a doctorate in history from Rutgers University and is the head of the history department at Dickinson High School in Jersey City. Her contact with Philbrook "did change my life in a very profound way," she said.
Philbrook also changed other New Jersey women's lives in ways they probably do not recognize: when the current state constitution was being written in 1947, "she managed to change the wording taking out the references to sex," thereby implicitly giving women equal rights under state law, Mrs. Petrick said. "She felt it was her big accomplishment. It has proved to be a crucial point in many anti-discrimination cases."
 
Yesterday's Message For Tomorrow's Women
During the years Philbrook was fighting for on-the-job equality, descendants of the first suffragists were still campaigning for the vote. The idea of votes for women was not an entirely new concept in New Jersey. A state constitution passed two days before the Declaration of Independence gave anyone worth 50 the right to vote, apparently including women and free blacks, and women could vote in local elections from 1790 to 1807, when the state Legislature adopted white male suffrage.
The disenfranchised do not seem to have raise an outcry then, although later in the century, women like Stanton and Stone did. But New Jersey's native daughter who was one of the longest-lived and most militant campaigners for suffrage and beyond was Alice Paul of Mount Laurel.
Born in 1885, she lived until 1977. She held three law degrees and a doctorate in economics. As a young graduate student in England, she went to prison with the Pankhursts, forced feedings and all, and in America she was jailed for picketing the White House in support of suffrage during the Presidency of another New Jerseyan, Woodrow Wilson. Along the way, she founded the National Woman's Party, which eventually grew to 50,000 members; led a coalition that succeeded in adding equal rights for women to the 1964 Civil Rights Act, and in 1923 wrote the text of the Equal Rights Amendment, working toward its passage for 54 years.
Paradoxically, she opposed the amendment as passed by Congress in 1972 because it included a 10-year ratification limit that eventually killed it. But she continued lobbying for it until she died. "People would walk into her nursing home and she would say, 'Who do you know in Indiana?' when it was coming up for a vote in Indiana," said Lucy Beard, president of the Alice Paul Centennial Foundation. "She'd be on the phone from the nursing home lobbying for the E.R.A."
Paulsdale, her home in Mount Laurel Township, is a three-story Greek Revival house built about 1800. After a major renovation in 1880, Alice Paul's father bought it in 1883, and she was born there two years later, living there until she left for Swarthmore College in 1901. Later she used it as home base for her suffragist activities.
In 1984, seven years after her death, a group of volunteers created the foundation to commemorate the centenary of Paul's birth and further her legacy.
Now a National Historic Landmark, Paulsdale is once again a center for teaching women to take charge. In 1993, the foundation formed a committee to provide leadership training to women, and specifically future women: eighth-grade girls, who learned about female leaders of the past and present at one-day workshops in 1995 and 1997. On March 26, the house will be the site of a third workshop, "Leadership 2002: Share Your Voice."
Since the coming of suffrage with the passage of the 19th Amendment, women have been active in politics in increasing numbers. Five have represented New Jersey in Congress: Mary T. Norton, a Democrat who entered politics as soon as women were given the vote in 1920 and served from 1924 to 1950; Florence Price Dwyer, an eight-term Republican who held her seat from the late 1950's to the early 70's; Millicent Fenwick, the outspoken liberal Republican who was prominent in the 1970's (and became known nationwide as the model for Lacey Davenport in the comic strip "Doonesbury"); Helen Meyner, a Princeton Republican who served in the mid-1970's, and Marge Roukema, a Ridgewood Republican who has been in Congress since 1981.
Since 1974, the height of the modern wave of feminism, the state government has had its own Division on Women, with its 11-member Advisory Commission on the Status of Women. "We were originally established to serve as state government's central permanent agency for the coordination of programs and services for women," said Linda Bowker, the division's director. "That means we can do anything we have the money to do." Since she came to the division in 1994, it has focused on economic self-sufficiency and the prevention of violence against women.
The division's projects have included its Rape Care Program, the Domestic Violence Hotline (800-572-SAFE), a Women's Referral Central (800-322-8092), a center for displaced homemakers, and centers for urban and Hispanic women. In addition to monitoring legislation, it has coordinated the Governor's conferences on women in 1996 and 1997 and Take Our Daughters to Work Day for state employees. It also works toward educational equity, "making sure girls are getting same opportunities in education as boys, throughout the system," Ms. Bowker said.
In pursuing educational equity, the state division is carrying on the work of Mabel Smith Douglass, the first dean of the New Jersey College for Women, which opened in 1918 and evolved into Douglass College at Rutgers University. Businesswomen can look back on role models like Mary G. Roebling, who, as a young widow named executor of her husband's estate, began a long career as president of the Trenton Trust, and Lillian Moller Gilbreth of Montclair, whose career as an efficiency expert may have been at least partly a response to her life as the mother of 12. (Remember "Cheaper by the Dozen"?)
Women in the health-care professions may be carrying on the work of Clara Maass of East Orange, who nursed in Cuba and the Philippines during the Spanish-American War and in 1901 literally gave her life -- at 25 -- by volunteering to contract yellow fever so that doctors could study and combat the disease. Or Cora Hartshorn of Short Hills, who helped found Newark Maternal Health Care Center in 1928 to teach married women about birth control. Or Dr. Virginia Apgar, the Westfield native who in 1952 devised the Apgar score used to to assess the health of newborns.
Adventurous souls may look up to the globe-hopping photographer Margaret Bourke-White, whose early industrial images were inspired by her father's foundry in Dunellen, or Anne Morrow Lindbergh, the Englewood-born writer who traveled the world with her aviator husband and survived one of the most publicized cases of maternal bereavement in history. And then there was Alice Huyler Ramsey of Hackensack, who in 1909 became the first woman to drive a car cross-country, who paved the way for women to take the wheel and thus gave themselves the freedom of the road.
In a quieter way, some New Jersey women, who would probably be astonished to find themselves to be remembered at all a century or two after their deaths, told their own stories -- like Jemima Condict, whose diary from her girlhood in the mid-1700's to her death at 24, painted a vibrant picture of New Jersey life before and during the Revolution. Or Sarah Tabitha Appleton Reid, a Monmouth County farm wife whose journal, written from May 1869 to December 1872, is the basis for an exhibition of artifacts from her time on view through June at the Monmouth County Historical Association. But a vast majority of New Jersey heroines -- the mothers, the teachers, the mill girls, the domestic servants -- may have left no trace of their lives, except in the memories of those whose lives they touched.
It has long been said that Anonymous was a woman. But she doesn't have to be anonymous anymore. That's what Women's History Month is all about.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
The Art of Managing a Motley Crew, and Keeping a Smile

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
IGNATIUS J. REILLY, the misfit hero of "A Confederacy of Dunces," John Kennedy Toole's 1981 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, winds up as a New Orleans hot-dog hawker. And as denizens of the French Quarter can tell you, Ignatius's eccentric, fictional employer -- Paradise Vendors -- has an eccentric, real-life counterpart: Lucky Dogs Inc.
A haven for the unconventional and the previously unemployed, Lucky Dogs has been managed for the last 25 years or so by Jerry E. Strahan, who began working in the Quarter during high school and never left. Now Mr. Strahan, who also found time to get a master's degree in history, has written a frank and funny corporate biography of sorts. 
 "Managing Ignatius: The Lunacy of Lucky Dogs and Life in the Quarter" (Louisiana State University Press, $24.95) engagingly spins out true tales about this quirky company, its offbeat vendors and the unique precinct it calls home.
Lucky Dogs and its seven-foot-long, wiener-shaped wagons have for years been a legal monopoly in the Quarter. Even the United States Supreme Court has blessed the arrangement, saying the pushcarts, which have been around since the 1940's, are part of the essential charm of old New Orleans.
By the early 1970's, when the author begins as a night manager in the funky warehouse at Lucky Dogs, tourists are plentiful in the Quarter, but so are drug users, prostitutes, strippers, gamblers and lost souls. Reliable, upstanding, sober-citizen-type employees, on the other hand, are scarce.
So Mr. Strahan manages a motley crew: carnival workers between gigs, seamen between sails, unsettled Vietnam veterans and drifters in need of money and -- sometimes -- medication. Still, this ever-changing band sells those steamed dogs, sometimes with flair and wit.
But management problems? Oh, yeah. Some vendors openly guzzle bourbon as they sell the franks. Others give away their dogs when threatened by street toughs. A few workers walk away with the night's take to hop on an interstate bus.
By the time Mr. Strahan is general manager of the 24-hour-a-day operation, he is accustomed to his "diverse work force," as he dryly calls his crew, and is rolling with the punches -- occasionally literally. He is also accustomed to a good deal of autonomy: Doug Talbot, the company's owner, is a trusting, off-premises boss.
Managing this group of transients -- for the most part a decent and likable bunch -- takes imagination and heart. And Mr. Strahan, a self-described "conservative redneck," develops both. He counsels the heartsick and the jealous, hides a vendor who witnessed a mob-related murder, puts up unofficial "wanted" posters in the Quarter to track down those who abscond with company revenue and lays down the law about decorum.
"We do have rules," he writes with mock gravity, after one particularly nondecorous incident. "One is that male vendors are not allowed to fondle other males while on the job. A similar rule applies to heterosexuals."
Beyond the people skills, there are strategic matters to handle -- including expansion. Lucky Dogs is now at the New Orleans International Airport and Disneyland Paris, among other places. There is even a test cart in Beijing.
Mr. Strahan, who also wrote "Andrew Jackson Higgins and the Boats That Won World War II" (also published by Louisiana State University Press, in 1994), is occasionally too generous with storytelling detail. But the book is short on numbers -- there is no mention, say, of the company's annual sales.
Still, "Managing Ignatius" is a terrific entrepreneurial story, one that captures the year-round drama of doing business on the street and the seasonal rhythms of the French Quarter, where vendors await Mardi Gras as eagerly as Macy's anticipates Christmas.
 
DRUCKER REDUX The century's best-known management guru, Peter Drucker, is at the center of two new books this month.
"Peter Drucker on the Profession of Management," edited by Nan Stone (Harvard Business School Press, $29.95) is a straightforward collection of 13 essays published over the years by Mr. Drucker in the Harvard Business Review.
More ambitious is "The World According to Peter Drucker," by Jack Beatty (Free Press, $25). Mr. Beatty, a senior editor at The Atlantic Monthly, where Mr. Drucker has also published, aims for a biographical and intellectual portrait.
But there is only a bit of biography here, with few outside voices and a frankly adulatory tone as the author tries to trace Mr. Drucker's theories through his 29 books. Even this is thwarted as the narrative jumps in and out of quotes and from one decade to another.
Mr. Beatty contends that Mr. Drucker is, at bottom, a moralist. And the book is at its best at the beginning, when it suggests why. In the chaotic and brutal battlefield management of World War I and in the postwar relief organization that saved lives around him, the author says, the young Peter developed a horror of incompetency and an interest in developing a "society of organizations."

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Who Will Harvest The Nation's Bounty?

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DEBATES about overhauling tax policy have never lacked vigor, but for the last 15 years they have been restrained by the huge Federal budget deficit, which has rendered talk of any sweeping tax reduction largely academic.
Now the deficit is all but gone, and the tax-cutting wing of the Republican Party is panting at the prospect of big surpluses that could be returned to voters by lowering taxes. But they have already run head-on into another fiscal problem -- the impending insolvency of the Social Security system -- and the determined opposition of President Clinton, who views large-scale tax reductions as an excuse to eviscerate needed Government programs; he even sees a risk that the tax cuts would plunge the budget back into deficit. 
 As a result, a lengthy, high-volume political clash is likely to extend through this year and next and into the Presidential race in 2000, encompassing not just the size and composition of any tax cuts but also the very nature of the tax system.
"To the extent there is a surplus, it enables the Congress to propose all these tax changes," said Gregory F. Jenner, the national director of tax policy at Coopers & Lybrand in Washington. "Having said that, it's obvious the President has a different agenda. They're going to have to find some common ground."
On an ideological level, the conflict is clearly drawn. Although there is a growing rift within the Republican party about how hard to push this year for a big tax cut, many Republicans see taxes as the economy's No. 1 enemy, sapping the nation's entrepreneurial spirit, leaving families working ever harder to make ends meet and feeding the growth of an intrusive, power-hungry Federal bureaucracy. Some Republicans see big tax cuts as a good start, but their ultimate goal remains a radical overhaul of the way the Federal Government raises revenue, starting with the abolition of the progressive income tax and its replacement with a single-rate flat tax or some form of sales or consumption tax.
"The more the Government takes, the less families have to invest in themselves, their children, their retirement, their health care and their communities," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. "When the Government takes away the resources people were counting on to help themselves, the people will turn to big Government to solve their problems."
Democrats say they are just as eager to reduce the tax burden -- but not at the risk of repeating what happened after President Ronald Reagan's big tax cuts in the early 1980's, when the deficit spiraled out of control, undercutting the economy's health. What the nation can afford, they say, is a set of modest reductions and credits that address specific problems, like paying for child care and college.
The Administration proposes $24.6 billion worth of these narrowly drawn tax cuts and breaks over the next five years, paid for by the elimination of what it calls unwarranted tax breaks and loopholes. Mr. Clinton favors tightening rules on the tax treatment of real estate investment trusts and annuities, and changing the way multinational corporations are taxed on their sales abroad. All these proposals are strenuously opposed by the industries involved.
The Republicans have not totaled the cost of their various tax-cutting proposals, but many of them would reduce Federal revenues by large amounts. For example, one of their main goals is to eliminate the so-called marriage penalty, the quirk of the tax code that often makes the taxes owed by a husband and wife who both work and who file jointly higher than the sum of those owed by two single persons with the same incomes. The revenue loss from substantially eliminating the penalty could approach $30 billion a year. Less-costly proposals would reduce the penalty without wiping it out.
By comparison, the package of tax cuts included in last year's bipartisan budget agreement amount to $9 billion this year, rising to $35 billion a year by 2003.
ANY talk of broad tax cuts, Democrats say, must wait until the country solves the looming problems of Social Security. And they view the Republican proposals for overhauling the tax system as nothing more than a tax break for the wealthy at the expense of the middle class.
"Under no circumstances can we take any steps that will undo the fiscal discipline we have worked so hard to achieve," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said. "We propose targeted tax cuts that are fully paid for, in the context of a balanced budget, to benefit working families. We believe there should be no tax cuts that are not fully paid for."
In political terms, the outlook is murky for tax legislation this year. Heading into the midterm Congressional elections in November, Republicans are eager to keep taxes at the top of the agenda, believing that tax cuts will be a winner on the campaign trail.
But the Republicans remain divided about how to pursue their tax agenda, and they have not yet found a way to pay for the tax cuts they favor. Mr. Archer wants to use half of any surplus for tax cuts. Some other Republicans say Congress should look first to further cuts in Government spending to offset tax cuts.
Seeing great political risk in opposing Mr. Clinton's call to put the surplus off limits until the problems of Social Security are addressed, some Republicans are eager to seize on another of the White House's initiatives -- creating a $65.5 billion pool from the proceeds of a settlement with the tobacco industry -- and turn it to their advantage. Instead of spending the money from a tobacco settlement on social programs like hiring more elementary school teachers and building and renovating schools, some Republicans want to designate any windfall from a tobacco settlement for broad-based tax cuts.
Whatever problems they face in enacting their agenda, the Republicans have an ambitious one.
"Some of the Republican proposals are irresistible enough that there will be tremendous pressure to do something, and the marriage penalty is a prime example," Mr. Jenner said.
A couple in which each spouse earns $30,000 and who file jointly, taking the standard deduction, would face a Federal income-tax bill of $7,795 -- $880 more than what their combined tax bills would be if they were single, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The marriage penalty affects more than 20 million couples, the office says, but about 25 million couples pay lower taxes than they would if they were single because one spouse does not work or earns substantially less than the other.
REPUBLICANS also see a squeeze on middle-class taxpayers. To address it, they would consider extending the bottom income-tax rate of 15 percent to higher income levels or allowing taxpayers to deduct the payroll taxes for Social Security and Medicare.
One proposal for widening the 15 percent tax bracket was introduced by Senator Paul Coverdell, a Georgia Republican. He would raise the upper limit of the 15 percent bracket to $35,000, from $25,350, for single filers for 1998; to $70,000, from $42,350, for married couples, and to $52,600, from $33,950, for single heads of households. Mr. Coverdell estimates that his plan would reduce Federal revenues by $37 billion a year.
Republicans are also examining proposals to exempt certain interest income and to simplify the multi-tiered treatment of capital gains introduced in last year's tax-cut law. And they are keeping up their criticism of the alternative minimum tax and of the Federal estate tax.
Even the most ardent tax cutters acknowledge that they will have to narrow their ambitions. But there is still little consensus among Republicans about which goals to concentrate on.
Social conservatives tend to favor taking action on the marriage penalty, seeing that as the most family-friendly option. Economic conservatives see the broad rate reduction implicit in expanding the 15 percent tax bracket as the best way to stimulate stronger growth. The powerful small-business lobby is pushing hard for further reductions in the estate tax, contending that a business cannot be passed viably from one generation to the next if parts of it must be sold to pay estate taxes.
For now, Congressional Democrats have for the most part lined up behind President Clinton in opposing any broad-based tax cuts. And they have eagerly endorsed his idea of using tax credits, rather than new Federal spending, to address a broad range of social issues.
The biggest Administration proposal is a $6 billion set of tax incentives to help school districts and states build or renovate schools and hire more teachers over the next five years. The Administration also proposed a $5.6 billion package to expand the child and dependent care credit to reduce the tax burden on lower-income families and give a tax break to employers who provide child care.
The Administration is also seeking $3.6 billion in tax incentives for energy efficiency, including a credit of up to $4,000 for buyers of vehicles that get at least three times better gas mileage than the base fuel economy for their class.
THE fate of tax legislation this year will be tied largely to the pace of continued improvement in the Government's fiscal condition. The Congressional Budget Office and the White House's Office of Management and Budget are currently forecasting a small deficit for this year, followed by increasingly large surpluses in coming years.
But early indications are that tax revenues are flowing into the Treasury this year at an unexpectedly strong rate, raising the possibility that Congress and the White House could have a windfall of tens of billions of dollars on their hands far sooner than anticipated. And if that happens, members of both parties said, the temptation for Congress to enact tax cuts and spending increases before they go home to campaign this fall could prove irresistible.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Seeing a Surplus"
Thanks mostly to a healthy economy, the Federal Government is facing the prospect of having large budget surpluses, after years of running in the red. Graph tracks deficit and surplus figures, from 1980 through a projected 2008. (Source: Office of Management and Budget)(pg. 20)
 
Chart: "How to Spend a Windfall"
Republicans have laid out an ambitious set of tax-cutting proposals, some fueled by the prospect of budget surpluses in coming years. But President Clinton wants to hold any surpluses in reserve until Social Security's looming financial proplems are solved. And he is demanding that any tax cuts be paid through tax increases or spending reductions. RICHARD W. STEVENSON
 
End the Marriage Penalty
 
GOAL -- Eliminate or reduce the quirk in the tax code that penalizes 20 million two-income, married couples who pay more in taxes than would two single people with the same incomes.
COST -- Up to $30 billion a year.
SUPPORT -- This is a top Republican priority. The White House has not ruled it out, provided the change is not prohibitively expensive.
PROSPECTS -- If any big-ticket tax cut gets through this year, this is likely to be it. But because of the cost, any action is likely to eliminate only part of the penalty.
 
Expand the 15 Percent Bracket
 
GOAL -- Provide a tax cut for middle and upper income earners by raising the ceilings for income taxed at the lowest rate. The limits -- currently $25,350 for individuals and $42,350 for couples -- have not changed since 1986.
COST -- Depends on how high the ceilings are raised. A plan by Senator Paul Coverdell, Republican of Georgia, would cost about $37 billion.
SUPPORT -- A favorite of supply-siders and economic conservatives. It also has strong appeal to members of Congress with big middle-class constituencies.
PROSPECTS -- Doubtful this year because of the cost, unless there is agreement to use some of the budget surplus for tax cuts. Democrats fear that it could plunge the budget back into deficit.
 
Revive the Interest- and- Dividend Exemption
 
GOAL -- Give a small tax cut to nearly 60 percent of taxpayers to stimulate more savings and investment. A proposal by Representative Kenny Hulshof, Republican of Missouri, would exempt the first $400 for married couples and $200 for single filers.
COST -- $15 billion over the first five years, at the levels proposed by Mr. Hulshof.
SUPPORT -- Viewed favorably by many Republicans, including Representative Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
PROSPECTS -- Could make it into law, although the benefit to most taxpayers would be very small -- as little as $30 a year for a single person.
 
Change the Treatment Of Capital Gains
 
GOAL -- Roll back some changes made in the 1997 tax bill. That measure created a three-tier system of holding periods to determine capital gains tax rates. Republicans want to go back to a two-tier system but keep the top rate at 20 percent.
COST -- Small, according to Republicans. A $100 million increase in revenues over five years, then a small decline over 10 years.
SUPPORT -- Mr. Archer has vowed to include the plan in the tax bill this year, but the Administration is likely to oppose it on the grounds that it encourages stock market speculation.
PROSPECTS -- Has strong political appeal at a time when more and more people are investing in the stock market.
 
President Clinton's Proposals
 
GOAL -- Provide a series of small-scale tax breaks intended to address issues like child and dependent care for low- and middle-income families, installation of home solar-energy systems and worker retirement savings plans.
COST -- $24.6 billion over five years, paid for by tax increases and closing some tax loopholes.
SUPPORT -- White House officials believe their proposals have strong public support; many Democrats are enthusiastic about provisions like an expanded child-care credit.
PROSPECTS -- If there is a bipartisan compromise this year, as there was last year, some of Mr. Clinton's initiatives are likely to survive, perhaps in watered-down form. (pg. 20)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 16; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1082 words

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Computing Returns the Feel-Good Way

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS 

 BODY:
NOT everyone who has a computer at home trusts it entirely. Lurking in the back of many a PC owner's mind is the nagging fear that the machine is booby-trapped to foul up unfixably for an unknowable reason at an unpredictable but crucial moment.
Meanwhile, on a typical nonaccountant's list of pleasant experiences, preparing an income tax return falls somewhere below root canal and just above a three-day bout of salmonella poisoning. 
 Put the two together -- computers and taxes -- and the potential for torn hair and a quick resort to aromatic spirits is sky high.
So when it comes to tax software for consumers -- either bought in a store or used on the World Wide Web -- the important issue is not accuracy, comprehensiveness, the best advice or even cost. It is comfort. Much of the programming horsepower is now devoted to coddling and reassuring the taxpayer before, during and after the ordeal.
Last year's price war knocked some marginal players out of the arena, leaving two main competitors in the sold-in-a-box home tax software field: Intuit's Turbotax for Windows and Macintax for Macintosh, the market leaders, and Kiplinger Taxcut for either operating system from Block Financial, a subsidiary of H& R Block. The products are remarkably similar.
Each program offers three comfort levels: a full interview; a fast-track interview, in which savvier taxpayers can readily skip sections they know they will not need, and a straight-to-the-forms mode for battle-hardened veterans.
In the full interview, the novice is taken by the hand and led gently, step by step, through a tax return. The program asks for just a few answers or bits of information at a time and provides ample opportunity to look up unfamiliar terms and to obtain guidance.
The programs walk a fine line between helpful and annoying. For example, Taxcut needlessly belabors the entering of miscellaneous income from a 1099 form by stepping through the boxes on the form one at a time, even though on 99 percent of such forms all but one of the boxes will be blank.
Both programs have a few quirks that tend to heighten, not allay, a user's foreboding. In the Intuit programs, for example, entering a zero in some fields instead of leaving them blank may cause the program to generate unnecessary forms and stubbornly resurrect them each time they are deleted. Taxcut demands an unimportant "copy number" when entering miscellaneous income; the form that the taxpayer gets from the payer is usually marked "Copy B," but Taxcut insists on a number.
On the noncomfort issues -- convenience, accuracy and completeness -- not much separates the two leading programs. Either is an economical alternative, $20 to $50, depending on the version, to a paid preparer, who would typically charge several times as much. Test drives of a moderately complicated return produced similar refunds, similar red flags about potential Internal Revenue Service queries and similar suggestions about changes to make next year to avoid withholding too much. As for speed, an organized taxpayer using either program can finish a moderately complex Federal and state return in a few hours.
But it is clear that both publishers put the most emphasis on reducing stress.
In the deluxe multimedia versions of the programs sold on CD's, video clips are interspersed at strategic intervals. In them, celebrity personal-finance experts and magazine editors offer a few sagacious sentences on the topic at hand. These warm and fuzzy but time-consuming clips can grow tedious but are not hard to bypass. More usefully, CD-ROM versions of both products let a user click on important terms and obtain relevant text from I.R.S. publications or from a library of tax-advice sources.
Easy access to those I.R.S. publications looms especially large this year because of a swarm of complex changes in the tax code. Software publishers must rewrite their products every year and are at the mercy of the I.R.S. when it comes to timing; this year, each had to ship software before new versions of many forms and publications were available.
Harder to excuse are sloppiness and bugs in the programs; Taxcut this year seems plagued, especially in the version for Macintosh computers, which seems cobbled together as an afterthought. Only a few state tax returns are supported; there are glitches in the way text is displayed on screen; several advertised features seem to be missing, including importing of data from previous returns generated by competing programs; many data fields are too small, obscuring some content, and the shipped version showed a discomforting propensity for crashing.
These two factors -- missing forms and bugs -- make Internet access a must for any buyer of home tax software, preferably through a fast modem. Form updates and bug fixes for both programs can be downloaded from the publishers' Web sites, but the files are large and seem to take forever to arrive at low modem speeds. Users without Internet access must make a toll call during business hours to a customer service line to arrange for update disks to be shipped. An update from Block's Web site corrected the most serious, but not all, problems with the Macintosh version of Taxcut.
Those with fast Internet connections can also take advantage of a growing third option for home-computer tax preparation: preparing the return on line. The leader is Securetax from Universal Tax Systems; Intuit has just introduced a similar service called Turbotax Online.
Instead of selling tax software, Universal makes it available free. The company's Web site (www.securetax.com) is similar to Turbotax or Taxcut, with a comforting interview process, amply larded with tips and advice, guided by a cartoon character named Steve. Users log in through an encrypted link, receive an ID number and password and may store their work if they do not finish in one sitting. The company charges $14.95 for electronic filing and unlimited printing of a 1040 return or $9.95 for a 1040EZ form.
But working over the Internet takes considerably longer than running a program at home; after all, they don't call it the World Wide Wait for nothing.
And there is the comfort zone. Sending important personal tax data flying around the Web can be even more angst-provoking than filling out tax forms. A user starting the Securetax interview gets a screenful of fine print disclaiming any assurance of security or reliability of data. So much for warm and fuzzy.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA -- UPDATE;
Eyesore Out, Gallic Cafe In

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
It was vacant for nearly five years, boarded up and derelict. But the restaurant at 470 West 23d Street, on the southeast corner of 10th Avenue, has finally reopened, despite the opposition of some neighbors to its sidewalk cafe.
Situated on an increasingly fashionable block near the heart of Chelsea's booming gallery district, the restaurant is now called Le Solex, after a French moped that was popular in the 1950's and 1960's (Brigitte Bardot rode one). It is run by Robert Arbor, who also runs the popular Greenwich Village restaurant Les Deux Gamins, as well as Le Gamin on 21st Street. 
 Mr. Arbor, who has held the lease to the space for more than a year, said the city's Department of Consumer Affairs granted a temporary operating permit for the restaurant's outdoor cafe a few weeks ago, after minor changes in the restaurant's appearance had been cleared by the Landmarks Commission. Approval for a permanent license was endorsed by members of Community Board 4 last month, he said, with only two dissenting votes.
One of the dissenters on the board was Ed Kirkland, who has long sought removal of the restaurant's cafe, calling it an eyesore unfit for the historic character of the neighborhood. He said that he still believed that the cafe should be removed for that reason, even though it was built in 1979 and predates the creation of that part of the Chelsea historic district.
But Mr. Arbor says it would be economically impossible to run the restaurant without the added sidewalk space, which increases the size of the premises from 450 to 1,200 square feet. And many people in the neighborhood, tired of looking at a graffiti-covered shed, are pleased that the space has at last been occupied.
"It looks like a very nice place," said John Bowe of the West 400 Block Association. BERNARD STAMLER
