HEADLINE: Clinton Staff Starts to Put Race Policy Into Practice

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Back in December, Jon Jennings, a White House Fellow, was trying to figure out what he could do to further President Clinton's Initiative on Race. To get the message out to a broader audience, he decided to use his contacts in professional sports; before his White House Fellowship, Mr. Jennings had been an assistant coach with the Boston Celtics.
Calling acquaintances and friends in the world of sports, Mr. Jennings eventually reached executives of the National Football League who agreed to produce a public service announcement by Mr. Clinton and broadcast it just before the introduction of the players at this year's Super Bowl. As a result, an estimated 133.4 million viewers heard Mr. Clinton say: "As we enjoy today's Super Bowl, let's remember that Americans of all races and ethnic groups are on the same team. Working together we can win." 
 Securing a free 30-second commercial during the third most-watched television show of all time is just one of the ways -- some large, many small -- that Mr. Clinton's much-touted and often-criticized race relations initiative has begun to permeate the Administration's thinking.
Much of the public attention given to the President's Advisory Board on Race has been on the missteps, including the fact that the panel's early public meetings were criticized for lacking focus and excluding conservatives. In recent months, the Administration has been spewing out ideas and policies and holding events designed to bolster race relations and to enhance the living and educational standards of minority groups.
In many cases, the actions consist of little more than sponsoring seminars within executive branch agencies, or making sure that Government reports contain chapters on the status of racial and ethnic minorities, or getting Cabinet and sub-Cabinet level officials to participate.
Some students of the country's racial dilemma say that the initiative is not doing enough to tackle politically difficult issues like continued segregation in public schools and housing.
Perhaps the area where the race initiative has had the biggest impact has been in Mr. Clinton's budget for the 1999 fiscal year.
In November, the Advisory Board for the Race Initiative, headed by the historian John Hope Franklin, recommended that the Administration strengthen enforcement of Federal anti-discrimination laws.
The budget sent to Congress in February proposed an increase of $86 million, or more than 16 percent, in financing for agencies like the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.
The Office of Management and Budget revived the practice of analyzing the budget's impact on civil rights, an effort that had been dropped in the Reagan Administration. When the budget was being prepared late last year, Judith A. Winston, executive director of the Race Initiative, met with Franklin D. Raines, director of the Office of Management and the Budget.
As a result, the budget has several policy initiatives on race relations and minority advancement, including an increase in housing vouchers for poor families who leave welfare, restoration of food-stamp benefits for legal immigrants, and a Hispanic education proposal.
"It affects your budget decisions," said Gene Sperling, director of the National Economic Council, referring to the race program. "You go through the agency's requests and say, what are you doing in this area?"
Whether the items in the budget related to race are approved by Congress is an open question.
Still, Administration officials say many ideas that have been bubbling beneath the surface within several agencies have received renewed life.
Last month, Mr. Clinton announced a five-year, $400 million plan to increase life expectancy and health standards for minority groups.
Recently, the Administration announced an agreement with the major automakers to raise to 5 percent the number of contracts going to minority suppliers. And in recent weeks the White House has also announced an increase in loan guarantees to businesses owned by Hispanic people and blacks.
Weekly reports submitted to the White House by executive departments now must include events or policy directives that are completed or contemplated that will help the race initiative. And the annual report on the economy put together by the Council of Economic Advisers has, for the first time, contained a separate chapter on how racial and ethnic minority groups are faring.
In addition, Cabinet secretaries and sub-Cabinet officials have been a part of more than 140 race relations dialogues in more than 40 cities since the start of the initiative.

HEADLINE: Americans Abroad Learning Studies Now Offer a Bargain

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Marie Claire Santos-Lim returned to Yale University this winter after a highly satisfying autumn semester in which she immersed herself in Spanish language and culture at the University of Seville.
"It's an amazing experience to study abroad," said the 21-year-old Manhattan woman, who expects to graduate in May with a major in American studies. 
 Just as amazing -- to her parents -- was the discovery that sending their daughter on a once-in-a-lifetime adventure abroad was also a way to trim thousands of dollars from the cost of a semester of college.
With the average bill for private schools in this country now more than $20,000 a year -- and costs elsewhere in the world much lower -- a growing number of families are finding that an experience that once was largely restricted to the well-to-do is turning into something that the middle class can no longer afford to ignore.
The number of Americans studying abroad has jumped 84 percent over the last decade. And while economic globalization is the most frequently cited cause, "the financial consideration is significant," said Mary Anne Grant, executive director of the International Student Exchange Program in Washington.
"One of the things students say is, 'Can I afford this?' " she said. "And I tell them, if your tuition, room and board costs $24,000 a year, you can probably find a program that costs $10,000 less."
The number of students seeking bargain educations abroad has grown so quickly, in fact, that a backlash has been seen, both at American schools and those in foreign countries.
The University of Pennsylvania, for example, now charges students going abroad the same amount they would pay on campus in Philadelphia. Some countries that heavily subsidize higher education, including Britain, have taken to charging foreigners full price.
A decade or two ago, foreign study was generally an "elitist undertaking" aimed at acquiring a new language, said David Larsen, director of the Center for Education Abroad at Beaver College. The suburban Philadelphia school runs one of the country's largest foreign-study programs and was a pioneer in translating foreign credits and grades for acceptance by American institutions.
Now, though, the luxury has become so democratized, Dr. Larsen said, that many students going abroad are from relatively inexpensive state universities. They find that it can cost even less to study in Toulouse -- or possibly Paris -- than, say, in Columbus, Ohio.
Indeed, increasing numbers of students are looking beyond the traditional destinations of Britain, France and Spain, venturing to low-cost countries in Eastern Europe, Latin America, Africa and the Far East.
In most cases, students receive full credit toward graduation for their overseas classes, though courses do not always count toward a major or a student's grade-point average.
Moreover, many institutions allow their financial aid to accompany students abroad. The Government now requires that all Federal support, such as Stafford loans and Pell grants, be portable.
Ms. Santos-Lim's semester in Spain, coordinated by Sweet Briar College in Virginia, cost $7,870 plus air fare. Though she has a need-based scholarship that covers her tuition -- every penny of which Yale contributed toward Ms. Santos-Lim's study abroad -- that still made for a substantial saving, according to her father, Jose Lim, a building manager in Manhattan.
"For going to Spain, it cost us about $4,000," he said. "For staying at Yale, the out-of-pocket would have been $6,000 or $7,000." Mr. Lim called the saving "a pleasant surprise" -- especially gratifying since he would have otherwise paid for his daughter to take an expensive European trip after graduation.
Another example of enriched education at a handsome saving is Megan Hoyt, a 1996 graduate of Carleton College. Ms. Hoyt, a Russian major, studied at the University of Glasgow during the first semester of her junior year and then moved on to the Russian State University of St. Petersburg for the remainder of the year. The total cost? About half the $23,375 that year would have cost at Carleton, in Minnesota.
"Not only is it broadening for the student, it very definitely is a boon to the parents financially," said her father, Sam Hoyt, a New York investor relations consultant. With the help of Carleton's financial aid, Mr. Hoyt estimated, "I wound up paying something like $5,000 for the entire year."
The number of American college and graduate students studying abroad for credit has almost doubled over the last decade, to more than 89,242 in the 1995-96 school year, the most recent for which the Institute of International Education, a leading exchange and training group, has compiled figures. And the tempo is continuing to pick up, according to Edwin A. Battle, the group's director of publications.
"There has been an explosion of new programs attracting students to areas that were once considered very out of the way or, in the case of the former Soviet Union, almost inaccessible only a few years ago," Mr. Battle said.
The growth seems only marginally affected, experts say, by incidents in which students come to physical harm abroad, such as the rapes of five American students in Guatemala in January, and the resulting movement to hold universities legally liable.
While administrators and students acknowledge that saving money is often a consideration in the choice to study abroad, they insist that the paramount factor is the educational experience. Career-oriented students, specialists say, recognize the value that corporations place on time spent abroad in today's increasingly global markets.
"We've got companies beating down the door," said John Grandin, director of an unusual engineering program at the University of Rhode Island under which students are provided with paid six-month internships in Germany. In effect, they get five years of schooling -- including a B.A. degree in addition to their B.S. -- for the price of four years at home.
The program is part of a pattern in which business and science, as opposed to just languages and the arts, have emerged as common subjects for study abroad. The shift holds for both men and for women, who continue to account for two-thirds of the Americans studying abroad.
Not surprisingly, the huge saving available these days -- especially for students paying the full cost of expensive private colleges -- has made some administrators and professors uneasy about the revenue loss and the absence, albeit temporary, of those who are often among their best students.
"There are some institutions that are sort of desperate to keep their enrollments up," said J. Michael Delaney, director of study abroad programs at the University of Colorado.
Some, he said, are limiting the number of students they allow to go abroad.
Others, even schools like Middlebury College in Vermont that are less pressed, have had to nudge more students to take their terms abroad in the autumn so the school will not suffer so much from empty dormitory rooms and classroom seats during the far more popular spring term.
Still other colleges -- particularly smaller, financially struggling institutions, many of them church-related -- are insisting that students who go abroad pay regular, stay-at-home fees. The schools then pocket the savings from lower-cost foreign study. (For its part, Penn says it uses the difference to upgrade and improve the monitoring of study-abroad programs.)
And publicly supported institutions, of course, are leery of the criticism they might face for using taxpayer money to support students in glamorous overseas settings.
"It is much less common now to have schools aid travel," said Dr. Larsen, at Beaver College. "The treasurers are taking over."
Some foreign nations are tightening controls, as well. Though schools in Canada are heavily recruiting price-conscious American students, some popular European countries have become decidedly less interested in having foreigners fill their subsidized classroom slots.
For instance Britain -- still host to more than twice as many Americans as any other country -- charges foreigners full, unsubsidized costs, as do Ireland and Germany. France has also raised fees for foreign students substantially.
But while the choicest destinations are becoming more expensive, money-saving choices are more numerous than ever. It is just that a student may wind up in Salamanca or Braunschweig instead of Madrid or Berlin. And one still profits, most students and administrators agree, if foreign study proves no better than a break-even financial proposition.
"It can cost no more for a student to be in Australia or Hungary or Japan than to be here," said Layne Hoppe, who until September served as director of international education at Texas Lutheran University in Seguin, Tex.
So all things being equal, he said, Texas Lutheran is happy to see its students go overseas.
"We're in a part of the country where study abroad is not a part of the culture," he said, "so that's important to us."

HEADLINE: Pastor to President Says Morality Includes Courage, Caring and Proportion

BYLINE: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When the Rev. J. Philip Wogaman, a noted Christian ethicist, inherited the plum pulpit of Foundry United Methodist Church here six years ago, his predecessor bequeathed him a bombshell powerful enough to shatter the church.
Foundry's beloved former minister, the Rev. Edward W. Bauman, sent a letter to each church member confessing that during his nearly 28 years as their pastor, he had "relationships of a sexual nature" with several women in the congregation. 
 The next Sunday, Mr. Wogaman delivered what he regards as his "most important sermon" ever, and a telling prelude. He told the congregation that Mr. Bauman had violated the boundary between clergyman and congregant and that the church could not condone his behavior. "But at the same time," Mr. Wogaman said, "I acknowledged the immense fruitfulness of his ministry, which had been a shaping influence in the lives of many people for a long period of time."
Now, as the pastor to President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, Mr. Wogaman finds himself once again preaching, above all, a sense of proportion when judging the personal morality of public leaders. What might sound to some like an elaborate apologia for the President is to Mr. Wogaman a demonstration of how he applies Christian ethics to a complicated controversy.
Sexual misconduct does not automatically render a leader immoral, Mr. Wogaman said in a recent interview in Washington. He said he believed that the morality of politicians should also be judged by indicators like courage, concern for the poor, fostering world peace, running the economy responsibly and furthering racial equality.
Mr. Wogaman emphasized that he believed the President's adamant denial about the accusations of sexual impropriety and perjury. But if the accusations should be proved true, "there are credible stories of what you might call moral lapses by Martin Luther King Jr.," Mr. Wogaman said. "But to define his life on the basis of those moral failings would be to miss the point about Martin Luther King Jr."
In an era when the loudest preachers are those who say that morality is absolute, Mr. Wogaman is a preacher who likes to weigh the relativity of issues. He says the only absolute is God, and when human beings make absolutes out of a "cultural expression" like heterosexuality or sexual fidelity, then they have succumbed to "idolatry." He has been attacked by conservatives as being too liberal, but his colleagues insist he has been mischaracterized.
"There isn't an ideological bone in his body, in the sense that he's going to know ahead of time where he's going to come out," said Larry Rasmussen, a professor of social ethics at Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan.
Mr. Wogaman, 65, shocked his academic colleagues when he returned to pastoring after 26 years of teaching Christian ethics, 11 of those as dean at Wesley Theological Seminary, a Methodist school here. His books on ethics are used as textbooks in Protestant seminaries across the country.
His outspokenness on social and political issues has often landed him in the hot seat with religious conservatives, many in his own denomination. He has spoken out against racism in the church, written in books about his opposition to pacifism, led a task force investigating the Swiss company Nestle's marketing of infant formula to the poor, testified in favor of sanctuary for Central American refugees and written a pamphlet advocating abortion rights. He recently became president of the Interfaith Alliance, a group formed as a counterpoint to the religious right.
"I think Phil obviously has been one of our most visible United Methodists," said James V. Heidinger 2d, president of Good News, an evangelical movement among Methodists, "and it has been painful for many of us that our most visible United Methodist has been taking views that many of us feel can't be supported by the biblical text."
Mr. Wogaman lives in northwest Washington with his wife, daughter and granddaughter in a pillbox brick house decorated for living in, not for show. Games and children's books are stacked on shelves in the small living room. Photographs of his four grandchildren and four children -- a musician, a Marine major, an artist and a lawyer -- are propped up on the bookcases and the piano. On first impression, Mr. Wogaman's serious demeanor is offset by an incongruous wiggly smile. But when he speaks, his tone is deep and weighty, giving him a gravity perfect for the pulpit.
He declined to discuss his pastoral relationship with the First Family, and would not say whether he has any privileged information on which to base his skeptical view of the accusations against President Clinton. But he criticized the ethical standards of others involved in the crisis enveloping the White House: the press, the legal establishment and Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating the relationship between President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky.
"The whole purpose in having a special prosecutor is to insure that, in the examination of wrongdoing by people very high in public office, there will be no hint of partisanship or self-interest infecting the professional decisions made," Mr. Wogaman said. "I think the public is perceiving that the special prosecutor's office has not risen to that standard and that things are being pursued almost in the spirit of a desire to find something to bring the President down."
When he took the Foundry's pulpit in July 1992, Mr. Wogaman had no idea that a future President and his wife would be joining him for worship. Foundry is a gray stone church on 16th Street, about a mile northwest of the White House in the Dupont Circle neighborhood, with a membership of 1,320. The church was established soon after the War of 1812 by a wealthy Georgetown foundry owner, and was the church of President Rutherford B. Hayes. Former Senator Bob Dole and his wife, Elizabeth, president of the American Red Cross, worshiped there for many years. Former Senator George McGovern still does.
The Clintons, when they first moved to the nation's capital, visited many churches. But eventually Mrs. Clinton, a Methodist, began frequently attending Foundry, while Mr. Clinton, a Southern Baptist, worshiped two blocks away at First Baptist Church. After First Baptist changed its pastor, the entire Clinton family, including Chelsea, became regulars at Foundry. They are not formal members, however, having kept memberships in their home churches in Little Rock, Ark.
For a few years, Mr. Wogaman preached simultaneously to both the Democratic President and Mr. Dole, who would challenge Mr. Clinton for the Presidency as the Republican nominee in 1996. But the Doles left in 1995, about the same time that a conservative research group, the Institute on Religion and Democracy, released a scathing report on what it called Mr. Wogaman's liberal influence, and Cal Thomas, a conservative commentator, wrote a syndicated column chastising the Doles for attending Foundry, saying "Wogaman's theology is as liberal as his politics."
On an issue that has divided the Methodist Church for years, Mr. Wogaman said he used to believe that gay men and lesbians were "either pathological or sinful." He said his opinion has since changed. Mr. Wogaman has served on a Methodist Church committee whose majority recommended, after four years of study, that the denomination drop its position that homosexuality is "incompatible with Christian teaching."
The denomination's ruling assembly did not agree. Two years ago, Foundry's board decided in a close vote to become a "reconciling congregation," one of 143 Methodist churches that have declared themselves to publicly welcome the full participation of gay men and lesbians. Mr. Wogaman supported that move as well.
Wesley Pippert, a Foundry member since 1966, said that a handful of evangelical and charismatic Methodists have left the congregation because they said Mr. Wogaman emphasized the social gospel more than personal faith. Still, the church embraces liberals and conservatives, people who come for laying on of hands on Wednesday nights, and openly gay couples from Dupont Circle, Mr. Pippert said. "I don't think the church is any less diverse now."
Mr. Wogaman said his approach to the ministry was inspired by his father, a Methodist minister who was a pastor at small churches in Ohio and agricultural towns in Arizona's Yuma Valley, where white migrant farm workers from Oklahoma vied with Hispanic workers for jobs. When signs went up in the grocery store in Somerton, Ariz., saying "No Colored Trade Solicited," Mr. Wogaman said his father went to a labor camp to invite Jamaican farm workers to worship in his church. They came, he said, and the signs came down.
As a clergyman, Mr. Wogaman came of age in an era when progressive Protestant leaders were in the forefront of social causes. Now mainstream denominations like the Methodists are in a period of "quietism," said M. Douglas Meeks, the dean at Wesley Theological Seminary.
"We sometimes have lost confidence in the Gospel's ability to speak to the realism of the world," Mr. Meeks said. "But Phil Wogaman is a great exception."

LENGTH: 1268 words

HEADLINE: COURTS EXPANDING EFFORT TO BATTLE WATER POLLUTION

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
A wave of lawsuits brought by environmentalists is compelling state and Federal authorities to enforce a long-dormant provision of the Clean Water Act, opening a new front in the struggle over pollution and requiring the Government to make new assessments of whether water standards are being met.
Environmental advocates, in lawsuits in about half the states, are demanding that regulators move from controlling individual points of pollution -- like factories or waste-water treatment plants -- to improving the overall quality of larger watersheds. 
 This river-by-river, stream-by-stream approach on pollution may be a powerful legal tool for environmental advocates to influence many kinds of economic activity -- from logging in national forests to spreading manure on cornfields -- that were not rigidly controlled before.
"This is like the Tet Offensive," said Oliver A. Houck, director of the environmental law program at Tulane University's law school, referring to the 1968 uprising by Communist forces that shocked the American military establishment during the Vietnam War. "All the old assumptions are challenged."
In a Federal court case in Manhattan, plaintiffs are demanding that the Environmental Protection Agency force the state to set pollution limits in upstate watersheds at levels strict enough to protect New York City's drinking water. The plaintiffs are also demanding that citizens groups be allowed to participate in setting pollution limits.
Similar lawsuits involving 13 other states are on the Federal dockets, according to the E.P.A.'s count, and more suits are expected.
Already, Federal courts have ordered the E.P.A. to establish pollution limits in nine states -- Alaska, Arizona, parts of California, Delaware, Georgia, New Mexico, Oregon, Pennsylvania and West Virginia -- if the states themselves do not impose acceptable ones. All but two of those court orders were imposed last year. In only a handful of states have environmental litigants lost in the courts.
The 1972 Clean Water Act required states to issue permits telling polluters what technologies to use to keep from fouling the water at specific discharge points. In a provision that has routinely been disregarded, the law also told states to measure the local water quality more broadly in order to determine if the system of permits was working, and to impose across-the-board limits on pollution from all sources until clean water standards were actually met.
But 25 years later, many watersheds are still polluted, often by runoff from farms, cities and enterprises that are not required to have these pollution permits. In about two dozen states, plaintiffs have now sought to force state or Federal authorities to list these polluted waters accurately, and to clean them up.
The environmental advocates have embarked upon a new strategy in which they ask the Federal courts to force the Environmental Protection Agency to intervene where states have not acted to meet broader pollution standards.
In some states, the courts have ordered profound changes. Last year, Judge Marvin H. Shoob of the Federal District Court in Atlanta imposed strict and detailed cleanup schedules on Georgia and on Federal environmental agencies. He threatened that unless they complied, no new pollution permits could be issued for streams where the new limits were not being enforced.
The ruling is tantamount to holding economic development hostage until the state corrects its longstanding violations of the law.
"He threw down what we call the nuke, which was telling E.P.A. that he would order them to take the whole clean water program back from the state of Georgia," said Doug Haines, executive director of the Georgia Center for Law in the Public Interest, one of the plaintiffs.
The E.P.A., for its part, would rather leave enforcement up to the states, and it has recently heightened pressure on the states to produce acceptable cleanup plans. By April 1, every state is supposed to give the agency a new list of polluted waters and a cleanup schedule for them.
All over the country, local environmental groups are scrutinizing those lists and preparing to challenge inadequate ones, said Jessica Landman, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Correcting these problems will take time. About 1,000 watersheds around the country -- close to half of all total -- are expected to show up on those problem lists, according to the E.P.A. The agency has indicated that it expects corrective actions to take eight years or more, and the courts so far have been accepting cleanup schedules from the states that are of the same time frame.
And while the pollution limits are supposed to address polluted runoff from farms and city streets as well as the discharge pipes of factories and sewage treatment plants, it is much harder for the agency to enforce controls on runoff.
Still, E.P.A. Administrator Carol M. Browner said in an interview that the new approach is becoming "the cornerstone of how you deal with pollution watershed by watershed, and it is the centerpiece of the President's clean water action plan." The White House last week proposed a five-year, $2.2 billion Federal program intended to improve watershed quality across the country.
Several elements of that plan, from issuing grants to the states to imposing water-quality rules on lands owned by the Federal Government, are linked to the new stream-by-stream pollution limits.
The limits are called "total maximum daily loads." Basically, a "total maximum daily load" is a quantitative assessment of water quality problems and those sources contributing to pollution. It specifies how much each pollutant needs to be reduced to meet water quality standards, and allocates pollution control responsibilities among all the sources of pollution in a watershed.
Under the law, the states identify specific waters where problems exist or waters that are protected, and make all the main decisions, subject to approval by the E.P.A.
Congress viewed this approach as an insurance policy that would guarantee continuing progress toward cleaning up the nation's waters, while leaving maximum power in the hands of the states.
A Federal advisory committee, in a draft report, urges the E.P.A. to deny new permits to sources of pollution in waterways where contamination is exceeding the maximum daily loads, and demands that the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management adhere to the limits when approving timber sales or grazing permits on public lands.
"Waste-water treatment plants for communities and industry may need new technology," says a fact sheet published by the state of Oregon. "Farmers and ranchers may be asked to use alternative methods in their operations to prevent fertilizers and pesticides from reaching rivers. Cities may be required to control and treat runoff from their streets."
Now, plaintiffs are making increasingly stiff demands on states like New York, which has already agreed to set limits around the reservoirs upstate that supply New York City's water. The Natural Resources Defense Council, in its litigation, asserts that these agreements do not satisfy the full demands of the law. A court may rule soon on E.P.A.'s request to reject the complaint.
According to Mr. Houck, of Tulane's law school, without these lawsuits nothing would have been done to enforce the 1972 law. "Nothing works in environmental law unless citizen pressure forces the regulators to move on the regulated entities," he said. "It is like a fish nipping at a fish nipping at a fish."

HEADLINE: City Hall Memo;
Is This Henry Higgins Playing to the Nation?

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Perhaps there is need for pause when a big-city mayor's call for basic civility becomes national news. Then again, the city is New York, where anyone who smiles is regarded as mentally unbalanced. And the Mayor is Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose charms tend to be muted by a sometimes abrasive manner.
Given those dynamics, one can understand why the three major networks recently televised segments that portrayed Mr. Giuliani as Prof. Henry Higgins, poised to teach proper soup consumption and other manners to a city of Eliza Doolittles. 
 But questions naturally arise. Does the Mayor feel the need to distinguish himself before a broader audience from New York's huddled masses of jaywalkers, spitters and foul-mouthed louts? In his call for mutual respect, is the Mayor trying to minimize the bad publicity surrounding the Federal indictments of five police officers in a matter of gross disrespect -- the alleged brutalization of Abner Louima? Just what is the Mayor up to?
Although he clearly enjoys the adoring national publicity -- one TV segment positioned him in City Hall Park, where birds obediently chirped -- Mr. Guiliani has, to his credit, tried to counter the hyperbole surrounding his proposal.
He has explained that when he delivered last week's speech, one bearing the ambitious title "Creating a More Civil City," he was not handing down a set of municipal commandments; there is no plan for parochial-school uniforms for everyone. Instead, the city will enforce traffic and bicycle laws more diligently and improve the quality of cabdrivers, all to stop the rise in fatalities among pedestrians. It will crack down on illegal car alarms and other unnecessary noises, with the police conducting what he called "intensive noise sweeps."
He also called on city employees to respect citizens and, he emphasized, vice versa. "We realize the meaning of considerate behavior, which lifts the city up and eventually brings us all together as human beings," he said.
Who could argue with such sentiments? Crime is down, the economy is up, and while other matters need urgent attention -- the poor conditions of schools, for example -- Mr. Giuliani assures us that he can do many things at once.
Then why has the Mayor's Platonic call received some measure of resistance -- even ridicule?
One reason is that by answering inquiries about his political ambitions with winks and grins, Mr. Giuliani encourages us to view his second-term performance in the context of a probable pursuit of higher office. Fanning such speculation are his plans in the coming weeks to deliver speeches at Republican fund-raising events in Michigan and Arizona.
The Mayor's advisers say that no polling has been done since his re-election in November, that no political calculation is at play; his personality alone drives the mayoral agenda. He genuinely yearns for another time -- maybe one that exists only in his mind -- when New Yorkers were sarcastic, curt, combative, but always respectful. And if that captures the nation's fancy, they say, all the better.
"It's like chicken soup; it can't hurt,' said Raymond B. Harding, a close adviser who could not resist a gentle taunt of former Mayor Edward I. Koch. "I don't think anybody has ever said of Rudy Giuliani that the totality of his ambition would be fulfilled by playing a judge on NBC television."
Another reason why the Mayor's call for civility has prompted a New York response along the lines of "Whatta-you-kidding-me?" centers on his personality. Mr. Giuliani can be earnest, diplomatic and, at times, very funny. He can also be snide, vindictive and, at times, very nasty.
Cristyne F. Lategano, the Mayor's communications director, said that respecting people's rights does not mean that one cannot also be tough -- even "colorful," to borrow one of the Mayor's descriptions. And when he lays into critics like Mr. Koch and former Mayor David N. Dinkins, he is simply defending himself.
Ms. Lategano dismissed a suggestion that the Mayor's call for civility might be strengthened if he showed more restraint in responding to the barbs of his predecessors. And she somehow turned the suggestion into an attack on Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Koch.
"Instead of acting like statesmen, they're constantly picking and poking and ridiculing, and it's almost to the point of embarrassing," she said. "What the Mayor is doing is sticking up for himself like any good New Yorker."
Those who watch Mr. Giuliani for a living, then, are left with conflicting images of the man who would have us be civil. He flashed one image on Friday, when he smiled warmly at the "Today" show's Katie Couric and admitted that "I have to improve my behavior just like everyone else."
The other image came three weeks ago. The Mayor had just spent 90 minutes enthusiastically explaining his many accomplishments to the public. But the last question from the press centered on the latest zing from Mr. Dinkins -- critical of the Mayor's handling of the Grammys -- and Mr. Giuliani's face turned to stone.
"If I had his record I'd be kind of embarrassed to even show my face," the Mayor said, then went on to defend his refusal to embrace the Grammys because its top executive had been abusive to one of his aides. "That's a matter of principle. I wouldn't expect that my predecessor would have any understanding of that."
Having eviscerated a man who has been out of public office for more than four years, the Mayor had one more thing to say before leaving his stunned audience: "Thank you."

HEADLINE: At Brookhaven, a New Charge That Radiation Threatens Water

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: UPTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Raising new questions about pollution at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, a former scientist there has charged that the lab has jeopardized local drinking water by draining millions of gallons of discarded water into basins near an old but still potent radioactive hot spot.
The scientist, Robert Ramirez, a hydrologist, voiced fear that decades of seeping waste water, along with rain, may have caused the radioactivity to penetrate far into the underground water supply. 
 Some environmentalists say this could turn out to be the worst of the many pollution problems at Brookhaven Laboratory's sprawling campus here, which was declared a Federal Superfund cleanup site in 1989. After concluding last year that the laboratory had placed science ahead of environmental safety, the Federal Department of Energy, which owns the lab, dismissed the lab's longtime contractor.
Laboratory officials dispute the contention that radioactivity has entered the drinking water, and tests at nearby county wells have not detected any contamination.
But lab officials concede that the 90-by-90-foot site is dangerous, and in recent interviews, they said for the first time that they would probably spend millions of dollars to dig up tons of contaminated soil at the site and ship it as far as Nevada or Utah for disposal. The site was contaminated in the 1950's and 60's by the improper disposal of wastes from the cleaning of tainted equipment.
The environmentalists contend that while removing the toxic topsoil would be a welcome step, it would not recapture the radioactivity that they believe has moved beyond Brookhaven's 5,300-acre campus in Suffolk County.
The hot spot and the rest of the laboratory complex sit atop deep strata of wet sand, formed in the glacial age, that stretch across Long Island and serve as the sole source of its water supply.
Until now, much of the public attention and cleanup efforts at Brookhaven have centered on other underground plumes of chemical and radioactive tritium contamination resulting from various laboratory activities. Some plumes have drifted beyond the southern borders of the lab into the adjacent community of Shirley.
As a precaution, Brookhaven Laboratory has paid for 1,400 families in Shirley to abandon their private wells and hook up to the Suffolk County Water Authority.
Laboratory officials have acknowledged that the hot spot is one of the most contaminated sites here. To prevent needless exposure to the radiation, an eight-foot-high barbed wire fence surrounds the patch of overgrown grass, weeds and shrubs. Ominous bright yellow and purple contamination signs warn people to keep out.
But the fence and signs were erected only three years ago, even though the hot spot dates back at least four decades. And so far, it is the only remedial action the laboratory has taken there.
Critics say the fence offers no protection to the groundwater below. They also accuse Brookhaven -- which did not provide for excavation when it adopted its initial cleanup plan for the hot spot in 1996 -- of reversing itself now, under pressure. Laboratory officials deny that, claiming they have been considering excavation all along.
The water authority -- which has eight well fields near Brookhaven's campus, including one directly across the road -- has raised its own concerns about the hot spot. In 1995 the authority formally asked the laboratory to cap the site with clay or concrete to prevent seepage to lower levels. Brookhaven's officials rejected that request as unnecessary, saying that the contamination, described by one critic as "a lethal soup," had stabilized in the top few feet of soil.
Brookhaven's past mistakes and current cleanup efforts pose a major challenge to the laboratory's new management, which formally takes over today. The new operators, Brookhaven Science Associates, led by the State University of New York at Stony Brook, have said that environmental concerns are a top priority.
The Brookhaven complex includes 350 buildings where 3,000 employees work on sophisticated medical, commercial, academic and government research. Its equipment includes a high flux beam reactor now shut down because tritium had leaked from a fuel pool without detection for at least 12 years. Energy Department officials are debating whether to reopen the reactor, which is used for neutron beam research in medicine and technology.
Mr. Ramirez, the former Brookhaven hydrologist, said he became frustrated in working on the cleanup programs there and left in 1996. He recently took his research to the environmental group Standing for Truth About Radiation Foundation, saying he hoped to prompt action. The group, known as the Star Foundation, contacted The New York Times.
Mr. Ramirez said he fears that "we're impacting the residential neighborhood in Shirley, and have been for decades, with a slew of radionuclides."
Scott M. Cullen, a lawyer for the environmental group, said, "What makes the hot spot worse than the other problems is both the toxicity of what's there and its potential spread."
Both sides have cited data from soil and water samples to support their arguments.
Laboratory officials contend there is no proof that the radiation has moved much. The institute's interim manager for environmental restoration, Robert F. Howe, said: "We're not 100 percent certain, but we're pretty confident that it's not moving, and if we find something, we'll address it. We're not going to walk away from it."
The hot spot, right in the center of Brookhaven's semirural property, has radioactive cobalt, cesium, europium, plutonium, radium and strontium. All are highly carcinogenic; plutonium is one of the deadliest substances known. Other contaminants there include arsenic, cadmium, calcium, copper, lead, magnesium, manganese, mercury, nickel, vanadium and zinc.
"You've got a lethal soup there," said Star Foundation's vice president, Dr. Helen Caldicott, a pediatrician, author of books on radiation and founding president of Physicians for Social Responsibility. "This stuff is in the aquifer and will be there for hundreds of years," she said. "That's all you need to know."
Contamination at the site -- officially known as the Building 650 Sump Outfall Area -- dates back at least 40 years. Brookhaven's records do not show the beginning date, but by 1959 workers were using an outdoor concrete pad next to Building 650 as a platform for steam cleaning contaminated equipment. The waste water was supposed to be stored in underground tanks and discharged to the laboratory's sewage treatment plant for safe disposal.
But in 1969, a release of five curies of tritium at Building 650 failed to show up in testing at the treatment plant. A follow-up investigation discovered that the wastes had instead been going into a leaky 800-foot-long underground clay pipe. The pipe ended in a modest concrete abutment in the woods, where the wastes flowed down into a natural depression in the ground, creating the hot spot.
The institute immediately halted the discharges. Regular testing of the hot spot did not begin until about 1972. It continued over the years, including aerial inspections for radiation. In 1989, Federal officials designated the site "a source of groundwater contamination, a potential direct contact hazard and an area of known radiological contamination with an undefined nature and extent."
Mr. Ramirez said his concern focused on the role of two huge drainage basins next to the hot spot.
About 1.5 million gallons of used cooling water from the laboratory has been discharged there every day for years, to be drained into the ground. Because the water's high natural iron content might otherwise foul the plumbing, chelating agents were added to keep the iron in solution. A significant amount of the water flowed through the sandy soil around and under the hot spot.
As a staff member, Mr. Ramirez said, he warned his superiors that the repeated daily surges of cooling water, and its chelation, posed a major threat of picking up radioactivity and carrying it far from the hot spot. Groundwater moves through the soil here at 9 to 12 inches a day, adding up to hundreds of feet a year and a mile in 15 to 20 years.
Mr. Ramirez said he was especially troubled by elevated radiation -- about 10 times the average in the area -- found in water sampled from a test well at the institute's border, near the homes in Shirley. His analysis concluded that the underground action of the cooling water was the cause.
But he said that laboratory officials brushed his concerns aside and that they had already decided what to do about the hot spot. "It was squashed," he said of his concerns.
Now those officials say they recall little about Mr. Ramirez's expressing concerns, but they agree that the basic mechanism he outlines is quite plausible. They say they share the concern and are monitoring the site with various soil and water tests.
"We're very much aware of this possible scenario," said Mr. Howe. "We're still investigating it." So far, evidence shows only modest movement of the contamination, apparently because the radioactivity is bonding with carbon in the soil, he said.
But laboratory officials discount the elevated radiation that prompted Mr. Ramirez's concern, saying they suspect it was an erroneous reading or naturally occurring radioactivity.
Disputing Brookhaven, Mr. Ramirez and the Star Foundation say the laboratory has glossed over troubling test results and limited its research. Little contamination has been detected in the nearby sandy soil, they say, because it has virtually no carbon to bond and hold the radioactivity, which they contend has moved farther away.
Although no final decision has been made to remove the hot spot's contamination, Mr. Howe said he hoped excavation could start by the end of 1999. But before that can happen, the project requires the approval of the three regulatory agencies overseeing the cleanup: the Federal Department of Energy, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency and the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
Paying for the excavation and removal would require Federal funds, and there are already complaints that the Government is shortchanging other cleanup efforts here. The lab's annual budget is about $400 million.
Although institute officials say money was never a deciding factor in the cleanup efforts, their records raise the financial issue.
The current projected cost for removing all contaminated soil at the complex is $40 million, with the Building 650 hot spot accounting for about a tenth of the volume to be excavated, or about $4 million of the total cost.
But in 1996, when the institute declined to choose excavation, it estimated a cost of up to $34 million to remove just soil from the sump outfall hot spot. The reasons for the drastic drop in price, institute officials say, are economies of scale, cheaper packaging methods and new options of shipping the waste to Utah or Nevada instead of to Washington State, the basis of the first estimate.
In originally rejecting excavation, the institute's records show that its analysts concluded that "there is a high cost associated with excavation and storage of radiologically contaminated soil." They added that the more limited action chosen then was "the most cost effective."

HEADLINE: Uneasy Renaissance on Harlem's Street of Dreams

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
On 125th Street in Harlem, where the stories and myths and frustrations of black urban America resonate with every step, a new economy is coming.
But Calvin T. Copeland will not be there to greet it. Mr. Copeland, whose restaurant on 145th Street, Copeland's, has been a Harlem institution since 1970, expanded onto 125th Street two years ago, aiming to catch the street's long-promised boom. But the new restaurant failed, driven out after only a year by rents that Mr. Copeland said had climbed beyond what his business could support. 
 His 125th Street storefront, for which he was paying $22,000 a month, is now being renovated for a Metropolitan Life Insurance office.
"I would never go back," Mr. Copeland said of the street celebrated as Harlem's Park Avenue, Broadway and Main Street rolled into one. "It hurt me and messed me up so bad, I wouldn't want to be part of it -- I'd rather go someplace else, anyplace else."
Harlem's street of dreams is breaking a lot of hearts these days. Even as projects like Harlem USA, a mall that will include the area's first Gap and Disney stores, prepare to begin construction this spring, older businesses say they are struggling.
"It's not for us; it's no longer for us," said Isis, the owner of Isis & Associates, a retailer of African-American books, greeting cards and gifts, who said that sales at her 12-year-old business had dropped 90 percent in the last two years. "We've held the fort, we created the market, and now other people are going to come in and reap the benefits."
At the moment, 125th Street stands poised between depression and boom -- signs of both are everywhere. New food, clothing and music stores have opened, and the magical name of Disney, in particular, is encouraging other retailers and entertainment companies to announce ambitious plans.
But unlike Times Square -- another long-neglected corner of New York that is being redeveloped -- 125th Street is also the center of a community where divisive issues of race and history swirl alongside the new opportunities. And the thousands of tourists who are expected to arrive in buses for shopping stops in Harlem are not here yet.
Established businesses say they are being driven out by rising rents and by a sharp drop in pedestrian traffic that followed the city's removal of hundreds of street vendors two and a half years ago. The arrival of chain stores like Duane Reade and Rite Aid has also cut into the sales of smaller shops.
In a place where politics and economics are deeply intertwined, these changes are fueling debate about 125th Street's future, the nature of capitalism and the role of government.
Some business owners say, for example, that they believe that the clearing out of small minority-owned businesses is not incidental but deliberate. The 125th Street that was both an economic and cultural icon for blacks is being transformed, they say, into a center of mainstream youth-culture merchandising: music, clothes and entertainment set in a kind of hipper Times Square in which black culture will be only part of the marketing package.
To these critics, the changes spark deep ambivalence -- echoing the renaissance of the 1920's, when white-owned clubs exploited the Harlem mystique for their white audiences.
"In the first renaissance we were allowed to be entertainers and we were allowed to be in the service industry," said Lloyd Williams, the president of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce. "In the second renaissance we are allowed to be entertainers and in the service industry and consumers, but I don't see us being allowed to own, being allowed to determine which direction we want to go in and being a part of the plan."
Economic development officials in Harlem, led by the 125th Street Business Improvement District and the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, an 18-month-old Federal business-loan program, admit that the new Harlem will take its toll.
But rather than seeing a conspiracy, they attribute such failures to the chaotic energy of capitalism, from which they say Harlem has been shielded by poverty and by government support programs.
The large numbers of vacant properties, the officials say, are similarly a holdover from the decades in which mostly absentee landlords let properties sit unattended. One building on the street suffered a disastrous fire more than two years ago, for example, and the owner has yet to respond, either to fix the building or sell it to one of the many potential buyers who have called the Business Improvement District to inquire.
The president and chief executive of the empowerment zone, Deborah C. Wright, said that some of the concerns about the evolving economy of 125th Street are perhaps justified in the eyes of the community.
But the fact is, she said, capitalism has no plan, except to go where money can be made. It is up to the businesses here, she said, to figure out how to join that new competitive era and exploit it for themselves. The empowerment zone gives loans, not grants, and requires a business plan and a repayment schedule.
"It's scary, frankly, because, as you know, one of the basic tenets of capitalism is that you can't control it," Ms. Wright said. "Nor do I think we want to. We want to prepare people to compete in a market-based economy because that is the only thing thus far that has been shown to be sustainable."
The executive director of the 125th Street Business Improvement District, Barbara Askins, preaches a similar sort of tough love.
"You've been asking for something to happen -- it's here, but that means you now have to compete," she said, referring to the local merchants. "If you can prepare yourself, if you can get that customer that Disney can draw to come into your store, then you can survive."
Some businesses are clearly making that leap, and some -- already displaced, and struggling -- are not. Between them, they make up a portrait of 125th Street's transition.
At Manna's Restaurant, for example, a lunch-hour passer-by can now order chitlins -- a soul food staple made of fried pork intestines -- with a side order of tofu and sushi. The restaurant, using an $80,000 loan from the empowerment zone, closed for two months last fall and re-emerged with new lighting and signs and an expanded menu and a salad bar that the owner, Betty Park, said reflect the evolving taste and broader mix of her customers.
At Executive Fashions, a high-end men's clothing store that opened in December using only private capital, the co-owner, Thomas Garrett, said he honed the idea -- personalized service, using computer profiles of every customer's tastes, purchases and measurements -- on the Upper East Side. Harlem, where Mr. Garrett grew up, was not ready for something like this in the past, but now, he said, it is, and business has been good.
But there are many other instances of despair and anger. At 125 Mart, an indoor shopping center, some merchants said they felt left behind. The stalls in the mart are rented month to month -- not on longer-term business leases -- and most banks will not consider a loan to a business without a lease that anchors it to a location.
And the conditions for the former street vendors, who were removed from 125th Street in 1995 and relocated to an open market on 116th Street, are perhaps even more dire. The market, which Mr. Williams at the Chamber of Commerce likened to a "shantytown," was mostly empty of customers on a recent rainy afternoon. The shop owners, many of them West African immigrants, sat smoking cigarettes under their dripping tarps.
Mohamed Dillo, a 45-year-old immigrant from Sierra Leone who sells mostly jeans and shirts, said he pays $57 a week for his stall and recently went a whole week without a single sale. But he cannot quit, he said, because he does not have a work permit that companies require in hiring.
"Last six or seven months -- no business," Mr. Dillo said.
But the constantly repeated business message here -- a new kind of capitalism for a new Harlem -- has also been picked up by some retailers who see it as a social message.
Dorothy Pitman Hughes, the owner of Harlem Office Supply, said she had to mortgage her house last year to save her 15-year-old business. Then she realized that saving the company could also send a message to the community. She took the store public and started selling shares right there from the store, for $1 each, with the goal of having the community own 29 percent of the business. She holds seminars every week, teaching children and adults about the stock market.
"We cannot allow the 21st century to come in here without people owning something," Ms. Hughes said. "We now have several thousand shareholders who might go to a Gap or a Blockbuster on the first day they open and say, 'I want to purchase, but I don't want your trinkets today. I want shares in your company.' "
Ms. Hughes said that the response from residents who want to be involved in saving the store and participating in the stock market has convinced her that she is onto something -- that people want to be a part of what happens here. Schools have taken entire classes of children to the store, each with his or her own dollar. And other customers have been thinking ahead to the next generation.
"Fifty-two unborn Harlem black babies own shares in this company," she said. "They will know who Dow and Jones is."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Dierker Decided He Could Manage, and the Astros Proved Him Very Right

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: KISSIMMEE, Fla.

 BODY:
As Larry Dierker waited to take his turn on a series of managers' conference calls with reporters in December, he asked the public relations person, "Are you going to cue me?"
Listeners to the start of that interview might have suspected that Dierker was still playing the baseball broadcaster instead of the manager he had become. 
 But by leading the Houston Astros, who had not won a title since 1986, to the National League Central championship, Dierker showed the skeptics that he could indeed manage despite an absence of experience even as a coach.
Dierker, a former pitcher, said he became convinced of that around the middle of last season.
"I think somewhere around halfway through I realized I could do what was necessary," Dierker said. "I'm not presumptuous enough to think I can just walk out there and I'm better than somebody else and we'll win all the time because I'm the manager. I know it's mostly the talent you have."
But, he added, "I also have a theory that you can screw up a good team if you're a bad manager. So about halfway through, I began to be satisfied that I wasn't going to screw the team up and in some ways I might be able to help them."
Since the Astros had last appeared in a post-season series, Hal Lanier (two seasons), Art Howe (five) and Terry Collins (three) had failed to get them back there. Then came Dierker, the neophyte of neophytes.
The Astros were in first place for all but three weeks of the season, but the remarkable Pittsburgh Pirates didn't allow Dierker to breathe easily as he guided the team to its first-place finish. Early in September, the Astros led the Pirates by only a game and a half.
"I very keenly felt the pressure of September," he said. "That's the thing I remember most about it. I felt I was able to keep my cool and make reasonable judgments throughout the whole process even when things got tough. It was very satisfying."
Not so satisfying was the playoff series against the Atlanta Braves, but Dierker said the pressure then was not as great as during the heat of the September chase.
"One of the things that increased the pressure of September," he said, "was the fact that the Pirates with their 10 or 12 million-dollar payroll were the ones we were trying to hold off. If it had been the Cardinals or the Reds, a team that had some bona fide star type players, you might not have felt so much pressure because it wouldn't have been an embarrassment to lose."
Dierker added that he did not mean to demean the Pirates, but :"I think there was a sense that we can't blow this. It would be embarrassing. If it had been some other team, it might not have been that way."
He recalled a football game burned into the memories of Houston fans, the playoff game in which the Oilers squandered a 35-3 lead and lost to Buffalo. "I certainly didn't want to have something in Astros' history comparable to that and I think it would have been," he said.
But the Astros held off the Pirates and won the right to lose to the Braves in the divisional series.
That series, Dierker said, was different because "it's never embarrassing to lose to the Braves, so there wasn't that sense that we had to win that series or otherwise we'd be abject failures."
But, he added: "I was tremendously disappointed in the way we played. They just brushed us off like we were nothing. It took me a couple of weeks to get over that. I wasn't very happy when the season was over."
Dierker related one other experience from his rookie season that stood out. He was curious to see how he would fare against Tony La Russa of St. Louis and Jim Leyland of Florida because of their reputations as two of the "smartest strategic managers" in the game.
"I found against the Cardinals last year practically every matchup I wanted to avoid I was able to avoid and practically every matchup I wanted to get I was able to get," Dierker said.
Against the Marlins, however, "it seemed like I couldn't avoid getting trapped into something I didn't want to do," he said. "The way the game played out, I couldn't get it the way I wanted it. I don't think that means that Jimmy Leyland is smarter than Tony La Russa or I'm smarter or dumber than anyone else. I just think the way the game plays out is going to dictate, and it's mostly the players and the execution."
Nevertheless, Dierker did feel it was important to gain the respect of his more experienced peers.
"I wasn't going to go up to the batting cage and start rubbing shoulders with these guys and act like I was a member of the club because of the unusual circumstances under which I got this job," he said. "I felt I had to perform first and talk later. I didn't talk to too many of them. But when I did they seemed fine."
Dierker said he was especially pleased to receive congratulatory notes from LaRussa and Jim Riggleman of the Chicago Cubs.
"I was touched by those things," he said. "It indicated they thought I was worthy. I think that would mean something to anybody."
 
International Thinking
Major League Baseball keeps talking about expanding its international horizons, so a group of internationally minded baseball people has proposed an interesting idea: instead of having the annual general managers meetings in Florida or Arizona, conduct them in the Dominican Republic.
The idea was proposed recently in a letter to Paul Beeston, baseball's chief operating officer. The letter was signed by Juan Marichal, the Hall of Fame pitcher, who is the Dominican Republic's sports minister, and assorted officials and scouts, including Omar Minaya, the Mets' assistant general manager, and Ralph Avila, a Los Angeles Dodgers vice president.
Noting that baseball's player population is more than 30 percent foreign, the writers said a meeting in an international setting such as the Dominican Republic would "go hand in hand with the growth and evolution" of baseball on an international level. Furthermore, they wrote, the meeting would provide executives an opportunity to see some of their players in their own country.
The letter did not mention golf courses, but the site proposed was Casa de Campo in La Romana. It has two courses, Teeth of the Dog (par 72) and The Links (par 71).
 
The Knoblauch Sweepstakes
At one point during the winter, the Yankees, the Atlanta Braves and the Cleveland Indians were competing for Chuck Knoblauch, the Minnesota Twins' outstanding all-round second baseman who had asked to be traded. At the end only the Yankees were standing; the Braves and the Indians had lost interest.
"We had serious talks at the beginning," John Schuerholz, the Braves' general manager, said. "But we re-evaluated our feeling on it and decided of our own choice not to stay involved. We wanted to keep the lineup we had." Knoblauch would have been a good leadoff hitter, Schuerholz said, but the Braves were not comfortable with the way the trade would have affected the club, "so we decided to stay with what we have."
The Twins initially wanted a starting pitcher in return, but their desire in later talks for Ryan Klesko led the Braves to bow out.
John Hart, the Indians' general manager, said the Twins "came after us hard." Among others, the Twins wanted some of the Indians' best young players, just as they were asking from the Yankees. But Knoblauch's $6 million-a-year salary finally sent the Indians in retreat.
"As we evaluated the trade," Hart said, "the asking price was pricey, but it wasn't just the players. We had to really look at the economics. Between payroll we were going to add and the luxury tax, it would have put us in a deficit-spending situation, so you walk away from the deal."
Without the Indians and the Braves, the Yankees benefited because the Twins had no choice but to settle for less.
 
Paying for Spring Training
Holding spring training at the handsome new Disney baseball complex, the Atlanta Braves are believed to have become the first team whose workouts before the exhibition schedule began were not free. Anyone wanting to watch pitchers' fielding practice and catchers' popup-catching drills had to pay $8.
Disney officials explained that the price was general admission for the entire sports complex, which includes other attractions. But if a fan wanted to go only to the Braves' workout, he or she still had to pay $8.
When a budding 3 1/2-year-old fan was told the Braves were practicing at the Disney complex, he said, "Well, where are they when they really know how to play?"

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Southeast Asia Officials Call for Market Access

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Southeast Asian finance ministers meeting today urged the United States, Europe and Japan to help the region's battered economies by opening their markets more to Asian imports.
During the one-day meeting, members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations agreed that wealthier countries should do more to help their economies. "Hey, buy more from us -- open up your trade more to Asian countries," said Finance Minister Salvador Enriquez Jr. of the Philippines. 
 The Indonesian Finance Minister, Mar'ie Muhammad, called on the United States to encourage more investment in the region and urge banks to open more lines of credit.
South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia are receiving multibillion-dollar bailout packages from the International Monetary Fund that require sometimes painful economic reforms. Skepticism is growing in the West about whether Indonesia is taking seriously the fund's reforms. The country's progress is lagging behind that of its neighbors.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
It's The Economy, Genius

BYLINE: By DAVID ROSENBAUM 

 BODY:
THE American economy is a behemoth, driven by forces so vast and unpredictable that they are difficult to track and impossible to control. In the short term, economists agree, Presidents have almost no influence over the ups and downs of the business cycle. What effect their economic policies do have is often felt long after they have left office.
 But largely because Presidents take so much credit when the economy is strong and bear so much blame from their political opponents when it is weak, the public's opinion of a President rises and falls, polls show, depending on how well people think he is dealing with the economy. 
 There may be other reasons why Bill Clinton remains popular. One, no doubt, is that he has opponents, such as Speaker Newt Gingrich and Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, who are unpopular. But the public's favorable view of how Mr. Clinton is dealing with the economy seems, more than anything else, to be the main basis for his popularity.
 In the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, 75 percent of those surveyed said they approved of the President's handling the economy, significantly higher than any other President had scored on this question since The Times and CBS News began posing it regularly in 1977. At the same time, 68 percent said they approved of his handling of his job overall, the highest of his Presidency.
 Times are unusually good. The economy has been growing at a steady pace ever since Mr. Clinton took office. The unemployment rate, 4.7 percent in January, was the lowest since 1973. No inflation is on the horizon. Mortgage rates are as low as they have been since the 1960's. And stock prices, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, cracked still another barrier last week.
 The public's opinion of Mr. Clinton's performance on the economy has often exceeded his overall job-approval. This has not been the case for any other President in the last two decades except for Ronald Reagan during one month in 1983.
 Over the years, other factors have occasionally figured into a President's popularity. The highest score, for example, was George Bush's 88 percent in March 1991, right after the fighting stopped in the Persian Gulf War. The economy was then in a recession. The recession ended, and a tepid recovery began. But Mr. Bush's popularity fell steadily as soon as the war was out of the news. By the time of the 1992 election, his job-approval rating was down to 37 percent, and only 18 percent liked his handling of the economy. DAVID ROSENBAUM
