HEADLINE: For the Small Landlord, All Problems Are Big

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
THE walls seemed to move the first time Jeff Dunayer, a fledgling landlord, stepped into his first tenant's apartment that afternoon back in 1983.
The tenant -- "I'm not going to use his whole name, just say Vinnie," Mr. Dunayer insisted -- was a hard-working family man. "Wife, three kids," Mr. Dunayer said. 
 Vinnie would be up and out of the house -- a two-family, wood-frame building on Atlantic Avenue in Richmond Hill, Queens -- in the predawn dark, on his way to another long day at the Hunts Point produce market in the Bronx. And, dutifully, every evening, he'd arrive home bearing a box of fruit -- along with lots of little fellow travelers.
"Roaches," Mr. Dunayer said. "Thousands of roaches. You had to see this! Up the walls. On the furniture, and they're all moving."
And then there was the tenant who went out for a pack of cigarettes and never came back. "I think somebody was after him," Mr. Dunayer said. "He left a cigarette in the ash tray" -- and an apartment full of furniture.
"To which my lawyer said, 'If you're standing up, sit down, 'cause you can't get rid of any of that stuff.' "
Mr. Dunayer could either leave the elusive tenant's possessions in the apartment or, if he wanted to rent the unit, place them in storage, his lawyer said, until such time as the storage fees equaled the estimated value of the furnishings, at which time he could dispose of them. Storage fees to be borne by -- guess who?
Vinnie was eventually evicted. The other tenant, of course, required no such legal urging. And these were faithful rent-payers, Mr. Dunayer pointed out, not like the family that didn't pay for several months and then, under cover of darkness, slipped away.
Jeff Dunayer is no Donald Trump. Nor is he Simon Legree. Like thousands of other small landlords -- perhaps best described as those owning 10 units or less -- he is just trying to make a living, selling a commodity and dealing with customers, almost all of whom pay promptly. But a few don't, sometimes because they can't, or, in other cases, won't, because they know all the intricate ways to get away with it. And, unlike one troublesome tenant out of a hundred living in a large apartment complex, the lone bad tenant in a 10-unit building might represent 10 percent of that landlord's income, not to mention a whole lot of headaches.
For New York City's small landlords, many of whom tiptoe near the financial edge, survival constantly hangs on the imbalance inherent in what is called economy of scale -- for them, nothing comes cheap.
Because no great volume can be purchased, there is no discount on the fuel bill. Because there is no plumber or electrician on staff, the skilled tradesman called in for the emergency gets top dollar. Because the commission would be small, tax lawyers will not take the small landlord's assessment appeal.
"The biggest single cost factor in running a building is taxes," said Dan Margulies, executive director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, a trade association of 2,500 building owners. "About 20 cents of every rent dollar goes to the city for water, sewer and real estate taxes. But in smaller buildings, it's often 30 cents, because they don't know to protest their taxes or they can't get an attorney to do it. There's not enough to save in these buildings to be worth an attorney's time, even though it's significant for the owner."
It is a theme that runs through the small landlord's life. Many are too small to hire workers, so they or their spouses do the sweeping, the painting, the bulb changing, the garbage hauling -- often in a building where they, too, live.
"There are the little guys and there are the 800-pound gorillas of the industry -- the Trumps, the LeFraks," said Vince Castellano. "But we all get lumped together."
Mr. Castellano owns two buildings with five apartments and six commercial units in Rockaway Beach, Queens. He also produces and hosts "Real Estate Nightmares," an hourlong venting of landlord lament and spleen at 7 P.M. Wednesdays on radio station WEVD (1050 AM).
Many people, Mr. Castellano said, consider even the small owner "a land baron -- greedy, uncaring, with money to burn -- when the reality is he's just another Joe Schmoe or an Abdul trying to make a living.
"Lots of immigrants, lots of plumbers -- though not the master-license plumbers, because they make too much money -- blue-collar types trying to climb the economic ladder," Mr. Castellano said.
There are, of course, villainous -- even vicious -- landlords.
There are incidents of illegal eviction, of harassment and outright intimidation of tenants -- "of hiring goons to come in the middle of the night," said Andrew Scherer, director of the legal support unit of Legal Services of New York, "or renting to drug dealers to chase people out."
There are cases of illegal service cutoffs: no heat, no hot water, no gas, mounds of garbage left to rot. Anne Pasmanick, director of the Community Training and Resource Center, a nonprofit organization that educates tenants about their rights and responsibilities, recalled working with people in a building where the owner, "in an effort to drive people out, boarded up all of the windows in the building, blocked off all the light."
There are overcrowded hovels. "I worked with tenants in a building on the north side of Williamsburg," Ms. Pasmanick said, "where the landlord had 18 men in a one-bedroom apartment; they slept in shifts."
Even Mr. Castellano, the radio landlord, readily admits that "there are some property owners who belong in jail."
And Mr. Margulies of the Community Housing Improvement Program -- commonly called CHIP -- said: "Of course, there are bad owners. And there's probably a handful of just crazy people who shouldn't own property; I really think that the worst cases are people who have a screw loose."
But most small landlords are honest people struggling to maintain a profit margin in less than affluent neighborhoods where the rents that the market will bear hover just above, and sometimes dip below, operating costs.
"It puts tremendous pressure on them," said Michael Schill, director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law. "Even the most well-meaning owner is not going to be able to maintain his or or her building when faced with declining tenant rent-paying ability and increasing costs."
ONE cost of particular current concern to small landlords is the city's shift from water taxes based on building frontage to water meters.
"You're likely to find the small landlord owning older buildings, frequently in areas with lower incomes, where doubling up is more likely," Professor Schill pointed out. "More people per apartment leads to higher water consumption, and old, broken-down plumbing creates leaks that waste water. If a landlord has trouble making ends meet, he may have no choice but to cut back on maintenance or become delinquent in paying property taxes."
According to the 1996 New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey, 61.7 percent of the rental buildings in the city have fewer than 50 apartments. The survey does not provide data on how many buildings have fewer than 10 units.
But according to computations by Samantha Friedman, a research fellow at the N.Y.U Law School's real estate center, using data from the housing survey, there are 1,597,390 renter households in the city -- not including those living in public housing, those in city-owned (or in rem) buildings, or those who are subletting co-ops or condominiums. Of those, 22.6 percent -- or 360,779 -- live in buildings with three to nine units. The median income for those households is $25,400, and the median rent is $600 -- meaning that they pay 28.3 percent of their income for housing.
Particularly in poorer neighborhoods, said Ms. Pasmanick, the tenant advocate, "Many of these landlords are in over their heads." Ms. Pasmanick's organization currently runs a program, in coordination with the city's Housing Court, that trains small owners who are first offenders to avoid subsequent heating-code violations.
"You come out of these classes a little stunned sometimes," she said, "because some people go into a business they really shouldn't be in, and some of these owners are only marginally better off than their tenants."
Of the approximately 125 landlords who have -- as an alternative to legal penalties -- attended the nine-hour program on how to maintain their heating systems and communicate with tenants 74 percent are foreign-born.
"Most of them had no prior experience owning and managing property," Ms. Pasmanick said, "and no training in either how to operate the systems of a building or in what their requirements are as owners: providing a lease, what they are entitled to as a rent increase, what they're obligated to provide in repairs and services."
Then there is the paperwork.
"For a lot of small owners, particularly the immigrants, it's very confusing," Mr. Margulies said. "Running a building in New York City requires a lot of record-keeping and a fair amount of legal help. If you don't have a certain scale of operations, a seemingly minor paperwork error can cost you thousands of dollars in fines."
There are 26 governmental agencies that regulate one or another phase of rental housing in New York City -- including, among others, the Buildings Department, the Fire Department, the Sanitation Department, the Rent Guidelines Board, the Landmarks Preservation Commission, the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance and the Bureau of Electric Control.
And while the LeFraks and the Rudins have their retinue of lawyers and clerical help to deal with the forms, Ron Hason had Ron Hason -- at least in those early years after he first bought, gutted and renovated a ramshackle nine-unit building in the East Village.
"There's four different inspectors who go into my boiler room yearly," Mr. Hason said, "the boiler division of the Department of Buildings, Air Resources from the city's environmental department, the Fire Department and the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. You would think they could nominate one of them to do one comprehensive inspection, charge one fee and give you one certificate.
"If you posted all the signs in your building that are required by law, you could wallpaper the lobby," Mr. Hason said. "Some inspector shows up and says he can't see your sticker from the outside. Well, where does it say that you're supposed to see it from the doorway? It says posted in the lobby. And you get a violation; $270 down the drain."
Mr. Hason is a little guy who got bigger; he now owns nine buildings with about 150 apartments, scattered about Manhattan. "When I was little it hurt a lot," he said. "You get numb; I got big enough that I don't feel the pain as much."
After a decade-long odyssey through the bureaucracy, Pari Dulac is still feeling the pain -- even though she won.
Ms. Dulac owns a four-story, eight-unit brownstone at 24 Minetta Lane in the West Village -- a building that had been converted from cold-water flats to fully appointed apartments by a previous owner.
Ms. Dulac, who bought the building with her former husband in 1984, decided in 1998 that she no longer wanted to rent, but to bring her two grown sons and their families to live with her in the building. Exercising that legal option, she informed her tenants that she would not be renewing their leases.
ONE tenant refused to leave. "I take him to court," Ms. Dulac said, "but he filed with D.H.C.R." -- the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal -- "that I am overcharging him. He said his rent should be $30 a month because this apartment is rent controlled." At the time, the tenant, who has lived in the apartment since 1966, was paying $427 for a three-bedroom apartment.
The judge in Housing Court declared that he could not rule on Ms. Dulac's petition to evict the tenant until the D.H.C.R. decided whether the apartment was rent controlled or rent stabilized. And it took 10 years of hearings, appeals and six back-and-forth rulings by the D.H.C.R. until, last December, the state agency ruled in Ms. Dulac's favor.
For all but two of those 10 years, the tenant did not pay rent -- and relations between the parties were, to understate it, strained. "It is like you are a battered wife," Ms. Dulac said. "But you can leave your husband; I cannot leave him." On advice of counsel, the tenant, who plans to appeal, declined to comment. According to the D.H.C.R. ruling, he owes $59,500 in back rent.
Tenants can be difficult.
Mr. Hason recalled his squeeze between the wishes of tenants and the mandates of bureaucracy. "They wanted me to lock the back door for security reasons," he said. "The Fire Department prohibits me from locking the back door because of fire egress. Now, what do I do? A tenant locks the back door and I get the violation."
Mr. Dunayer, who had to fumigate after his fruit-fancying first tenant finally left, said: "Day to day, usually, there's not many problems, even though you're on call, on the beeper, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, forever. The horrors usually begin when the people stop paying rent."
One tenant, he said, "would shut off the boiler, give the heat complaint bureau a call, and then, right before the inspector showed up, flip the boiler back on again."
That way, the apartment would be cold, even though the boiler was on, "and it seems that I'm not giving enough heat," Mr. Dunayer said. "That's to divert attention from the fact that they are not paying the rent."
Another tenant "removed a new hung ceiling in the bathroom and reported it to the city," Mr. Dunayer said, "which violated me for not having a ceiling in the bathroom -- again, to divert attention because they were not paying the rent."
In the rent-regulation battles of last year, said Mr. Margulies of CHIP, landlords in poor communities (where market and regulated rents are often on par) were less concerned with elimination of the entire system than with enactment of a rent-deposit law for Housing Court -- a goal they achieved. "The horror stories are not so much about the tenants as about the courts, which are a tremendous burden on the small owner," Mr. Margulies said, citing what he called long and costly delays.
The new law requires tenants sued for nonpayment of rent to deposit the contested amount in an escrow account if they ask for a second adjournment of the case, or if the case has been in court for more than 30 days. It also requires the tenant to deposit the full amount of a judgment against them if they come to court asking for a postponement of eviction more than five days after the ruling.
But, in a case called Lang v. Pataki, the Legal Aid Society has filed suit contesting the constitutionality of the law. And although the judge in the case, Justice Edward H. Lehner of State Supreme Court in Manhattan has issued no injunction against enforcement of the deposit law, it has, at most, been sparingly imposed as building owners and housing court judges await a ruling.
Obviously, small landlords are hopeful. "In a nonpayment case," Mr. Margulies said, "you could spend six months in court and win, but still lose six months rent because the tenant then skips. So, it's a pretty hollow victory.
"And if you're dealing with a low-rent building in Brooklyn or the Bronx where the average rent might be $600 a month, and you get the apartment vacant, you're still only going to get about $600 a month for that apartment, because that's what the market will bear."
MR. SCHERER of Legal Services (an organization that only handles civil cases and is distinct from Legal Aid) counters: "The reality for low-income people is that there is no affordable housing. They don't just withhold rent and skip, because there aren't apartments that are available, even at $600 a month.
"And another reality that he's ignoring: there are still about a million people in New York City receiving public assistance. The shelter part of the welfare benefits is nowhere near $600 a month." The shelter allowance for a family of four on public assistance is $312 a month.
Mr. Dunayer, for one, has found a solution to many of the small owner's problems -- he rents to homeless people.
"I got involved in the Emergency Assistance Re-Housing Program," Mr. Dunayer said.
Under the program, run by the Department of Homeless Services, rents ranging from $650 for a one-bedroom apartment to $1,100 for a four-bedroom are paid directly to the landlord. The landlord also gets a one-time bonus payment of $600 per person.
And one other significant bonus for the troubled landlord is that both the city and the owner screen prospective tenants. "You pick your own people," Mr. Dunayer said. "The clients I've had have all been very good. Many of them just needed a chance.
"And if there's a problem with the tenant -- like damage or they play music too loud -- you call the city and, usually, they rectify it."

HEADLINE: Russian Immigrants At Home on East End

BYLINE: By MERYL SPIEGEL 

 BODY:
IN the summer of 1991, Leonid and Larissa Mouzykine and their two daughters packed their bags in their apartment in Russia for a trip to eastern Long Island. While they were excited about experiencing the American way of life, they did not realize that they were leaving Russia for good.
At the time, the family owned a two-bedroom apartment in St. Petersburg, a new car and a small dacha in the country. "Things were not so bad," Mrs. Mouzykine, a middle-aged woman said in broken English in an interview partially translated by her 17-year-old daughter, Nadia. 
 In the former Soviet Union, the couple earned a good living. A pentathlete with a master's degree in sports, Mr. Mouzykine was the director of swimming at St. Petersburg University and managed a large swimming pool, while Mrs. Mouzykine worked as an electrical engineer, a career she had pursued for 23 years.
However, while visiting Polish friends on the North Fork, the political situation deteriorated as the Communists fought to regain power after Boris Yeltsin had been elected president of the new republic of Russia.
In August, when the Communists staged a coup and a state of emergency was declared, the Mouzykines decided to stay on Long Island temporarily. Today, seven years later, the family remains on the North Fork, she working long hours as a house cleaner and he as a winery worker. They live in a modest rental home in Mattituck.
The Mouzykines are typical of a small but growing number of Russian immigrants who have settled in and around Riverhead and on the North Fork amidst the rolling farmland and vineyards in pursuit of a peaceful, healthy new life.
In many cases, they have discovered the bucolic region through a network of Polish friends from Eastern Europe who have connections to the large Polish community centered in the Suffolk County seat and extending to Orient.
Typically, these immigrants are highly educated or skilled workers who have reluctantly left their homeland and traded their careers and middle-class life for manual work, hoping to build better lives first for their children and secondly for themselves.
Donna Fry, former administrator of Literacy Volunteers of America's East End office, who taught tutors to teach English as a second language, said she had noticed more and more Russian newcomers attending classes in recent years.
Although she is not aware of huge numbers, and could not provide exact figures, she said that there were pockets throughout the East End, especially in Riverhead, Mattituck and Southold.
"They start out in service areas in the tourism industry working behind the scenes in hotels and restaurants," she said . "They also find work in agriculture, on the farms and at vineyards. Usually, they have Polish friends. It is rare that they arrive without some support network in place."
She added: "They are not uneducated and are coming over with university degrees. Some are teachers and there are a lot of engineers. Everyone is an engineer in Russia.
"It's very different from the Hispanics, where we are dealing with illiteracy in their native language."
There has been a large influx of Hispanic immigrants on the East End in the 1990's.
When the Mouzykine family first settled on the North Fork, Nadia said, they seemed to be one of the only Russian families in the area; but recently, the community of immigrants from the new republics seem to be growing. "Probably because it's so easy to leave now," she added.
Although her grandparents remain in Russia, saying they are too old to start over, Nadia's uncle has also emigrated to Mattituck and the family knows a handful of people with similar backgrounds who attend their small Russian Orthodox Church in Shirley on the South Shore.
Mother and daughter also said that sometimes when they shopped in Riverhead they often overhear Ukrainian conversations and do not recognize the people speaking. To them, that is a sign that their community is growing.
In Riverhead, a Polish-Russian restaurant called Polonez opened a year ago on Main Street. Offering an array of Slavic delicacies, the restaurant is owned by Elizabeth Sorokal, a Polish-American, and Alla Kovznetsova, a Russian newcomer.
Talking over coffee in the cafe about why she left her country five years ago and relocated to Flanders, near Riverhead, with her husband, Alex, and daughter, Natalie, who was 12 at the time, the Russian-born woman said there were political problems, no work, and her husband suffered from asthma.
In St. Petersburg, air pollution is a serious health problem, said both families. Since moving to the East End, Mr. Kovnetsov feels much better, he said in a later interview at his home.
"After living in the big city, I like the country. This place is the best," said Ms. Kovznetsova.
A computer programmer for 12 years who was also trained as a nurse, the restaurateur said she could not continue her profession in the United States because "my level is too low for this country and I have to study English." Because she is a perfectionist, she said, she did not want to be a bad programmer.
Therefore, when she first arrived, Ms. Kovznetsova started a cleaning service while Alex, a railroad engineer, became a contractor doing small construction jobs. Then, in 1995, she met Ms. Sorokal at a New Year's Eve party at Polish Hall. Because she had attended a professional cooking school in St. Petersburg and had always enjoyed cooking, she decided to open her own restaurant with her Polish partner last year.
During the spring and summer, the cafe attracted tourists from Manhattan and Nassau County, where there is a large enclave of Russian-Americans in Glen Cove.
Although several families interviewed for this article appear fond of the United States, where work can be found and people are optimistic, smiling and friendly, the choice to leave the land they love and their familiar surroundings has been heart wrenching.
"When the turmoil began, it triggered my parents to wait and see how it goes, at least until the next summer," Nadia explained. At that point, the family hoped things would stabilize over the winter and they could return within a year.
"There is no future for my children in Russia," Mrs. Mouzykine said. In other words, the new economic system has wiped out the large middle class and spawned a society of haves and have nots. A small percentage of the people, about 5 percent, are very rich, she said, while the remaining 95 percent are growing poorer and poorer.
In the Russian newspapers, there are many advertisements for jobs, she went on. But the new entrepreneurs, who opened small businesses 10 years ago under Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika, are looking for young people only, those under 35, and they must speak English, she said.
Indeed, English proficiency appears to be the key to success for Russians in America as well. When Nadia entered the country at the age of 11, she was just learning the language. Seven years later, she speaks seamless English without a trace of an accent, is second in her class at Mattituck High School, has won state vocal competitions, and hopes to attend Georgetown University and eventually work for the United Nations.
Learning English has been harder for her mother, who relies on the young woman to translate and be "the secretary of the house" regarding all important matters. Moreover, Ms. Mouzykine explained that she had been unable to find a job in electrical engineering on Long Island because she is not fluent. And, employment in the field in America requires computer skills that she does not possess.
Two years ago, Ivan and Maja Brativnyk, arrived, leaving their two sons, aged 12 and 13, behind until they could afford to bring them here. An architect and landscape designer in their country, they now work as a painter and house cleaner.
In an interview translated by Alla Kovznetsova in her four-bedroom rental home, the Bratinvnyks said that they now made more money at their current menial jobs in the Riverhead area than they did in their professions in the Ukraine.
"Simple workers make more money than people with higher educations," Mr. Kovznetsov explained. For example, he said that driving a train, he earned five times the salary that his wife made as a computer programmer.
However, the Ukrainian couple said the transition had not been easy. They are homesick and miss their children, whom they have not seen since emigrating.
One of the hardest things, said Evan, 37, has been the lack of conversation. "We don't know the language, can't read the newspaper, and can't talk to anyone in the street," he said in his native tongue.

HEADLINE: Lonely At The Top

BYLINE: By Ronald Steel; Ronald Steel, a professor of international relations at the University of Southern California, is the author of "Temptations of a Superpower."

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Let us be clear about what happened in the recent confrontation with Saddam Hussein. It was not the use of force that brought about the agreement brokered by the United Nations; it was the threat of force. The difference is crucial, and therein lies an important lesson.
For a nation with the virtually unchallenged power of the United States today, the use of force is a constant temptation. Sometimes it is unavoidable. But it is not always appropriate, and there are times when it is self-defeating. 
 The hardest part of statecraft is knowing the difference. The use of force is, in a real sense, an admission of defeat. It means that a nation has found it impossible to achieve its objectives by other means. And other means are generally better, because force has consequences that cannot be controlled or fully foreseen.
In the case of Iraq, the United States could easily have bombed Baghdad to punish Mr. Hussein for his intransigence. But even advocates of that course admit it would not have prevented him from building more chemical and biological weapons, nor induced him to cooperate with United Nations inspectors, nor weakened his dictatorial hold over his country.
It would, on the other hand, have killed many civilians, inflamed Arabs against the United States, weakened friendly regimes in the region and caused dissension here at home as television reports showed the victims of American bombing. There are times -- and this was one of them -- when the threat of force brings greater success than its application.
But there is another lesson here as well: that the United States, as the world's most powerful nation, faces greater constraints on its freedom to use force than does any other country. This may seem paradoxical, for the United States dominates the world in every realm: in military power, in economic strength, in cultural influence. We are truly, all of us, living in an American Century.
But the very scope of that power raises apprehension and stimulates resistance. The more the United States, because it is so powerful, arrogates the right to act alone without regard to the wishes of other nations, or even in defiance of them, the more it loses the legitimacy to act in their name. And what has the United States been doing these past weeks with regard to Iraq other than acting as self-appointed sheriff of the world community?
Washington officials have repeatedly asserted that they were seeking to punish Iraq not for American purposes, but for the world's good. Yet unlike in 1991, when the United States organized a coalition to liberate Kuwait from Iraq, this time America stood virtually alone.
This is America's late-century dilemma. Instead of being praised for its selfless defense of international justice and morality, it runs the risk of being accused, even by its allies, of acting like an international bully -- especially when it prepares to attack small nations, however criminal their behavior.
In truth, no great power is without self-serving ambition. But if American officials seek to wrap themselves in the mantle of morality, proclaiming themselves to be the world's conscience and enforcer, they invite others to hold them to a higher standard than is applied to the normal run of devious statesmen.
This is where the trouble begins. For if the power is really being exercised for mankind's sake, mankind demands some say in its use. But neither the Constitution, the Congress nor television's Sunday pundits would allow that. And the other nations of the world have not assigned Washington the right to decide when, where and how their interests should be served.
Thus the United States is in a conundrum of its own making. The more that Washington speaks in the world's name and demands the world's endorsement of its actions, the less freedom of action it enjoys.
Nobody, except its own citizens, loves a superpower. To behave like one is to invite criticism and breed resentment.
During the cold war it was different. Washington's use of force was, for the most part, treated more tolerantly by allies and neutrals because it was applied in the context of the containment of a greater evil. But with the disappearance of the Soviet Union, Washington's assertion of an international police power has been treated less tolerantly. The resigned shrug has given way, even among allies, to accusations of arrogance.
There is nothing inherently wrong with being an arrogant superpower. That is, after all, the usual definition of a hegemon. But hegemons, because they throw their weight around and assume that mankind's interests correspond to their own, foster envy and resentment.
Challengers arise to put them in their place. Coalitions form to contain them. Success breeds rebellion. The only way that a No. 1 can avoid this fate is to restrain itself and behave as though it has less power than it actually does.
 A superpower like the United States, in other words, can remain a global hegemon -- what Madeleine Albright calls the "indispensable nation" -- only if it refrains from acting like one. That is what the fracas with Saddam Hussein has taught us. And that is why being No. 1, a Gulliver tied down by a thousand resentful Lilliputians, is not as satisfying as it is supposed to be.

HEADLINE: San Francisco Tries to Retain Its 'Multimedia Gulch'

BYLINE: By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
On any given sunny afternoon, scores of workers pour out onto an oval stretch of scrappy grass known in San Francisco as South Park. The surrounding neighborhood, once home to immigrant families, printing plants and an occasional flophouse, now features a few high-end restaurants, coffeehouses and a lot of workers in the interactive media industry who come out for lunch from the renovated lofts surrounding the park.
Welcome to the cultural hub of San Francisco's trendy interactive media district, otherwise known as Multimedia Gulch. In the half-decade since software companies began migrating north from sprawling Silicon Valley into converted warehouse space in this condensed 10-square-block area, San Francisco has overtaken its southern suburban neighbor as the more popular home of interactive media, a catchall label that has come to mean everything from Internet service companies and Web site developers to interactive game makers and CD-ROM publishers. 
 But Silicon Valley to the south and Silicon Alley in New York City have interactive media communities of their own, and the rivalry between the jurisdictions is palpable. And San Francisco officials want to make sure these easily portable businesses stay near the Golden Gate.
Last year, interactive media companies based in San Francisco numbered roughly 380 and employed nearly 35,000 workers, an almost 70 increase over 1995. Revenues of those companies skyrocketed 150 percent.
But despite the many amenities of having a headquarters in the city, executives of interactive media start-ups are beginning to grumble about increasingly high rents, a lack of parking and a city bureaucracy that can make it tough for any company to expand. Roughly half of those companies responding to a recent survey said they would consider moving or expanding to another place within the San Francisco Bay Area, or out of the area all together.
This grumbling has not been lost upon Mayor Willie L. Brown, who last week met with several hundred industry executives, city officials and analysts to figure out how to keep the city attractive for start-ups.
San Francisco, the Mayor said, is "almost certainly at risk" of losing whatever lead it may have, given what he called the "portable" nature of the interactive media business. "You've got an industry that's like a motor home, and you have to be careful to make sure your motor home park is in order," he said.
Although San Francisco's interactive media companies typically are small, with average revenue of only about $5.8 million, taken as a whole, the interactive media industry has become an important one: The same study by Coopers & Lybrand, shows that last year such businesses had an overall impact on the San Francisco economy of $4.2 billion.
And with New York and Los Angeles throwing considerable resources into attracting new interactive media businesses, Mayor Brown knows San Francisco has to move fast. In fact, by some accounts, New York has already jumped ahead of San Francisco, particularly in incentives it offers to interactive media start-ups. Those include a special venture capital fund and a program called Plug 'n' Go, which provides discounted rental opportunities. And last week, Mayor Richard J. Riordan of Los Angeles announced that his city would henceforth be known as Digital Coast, in hopes of becoming "the new-media capital of the world."
But while New York has the publishing industry as an anchor for its burgeoning new-media business and Los Angeles the film industry, executives from San Francisco's interactive media companies like to point out that they have the huge talent pool of Silicon Valley to draw from, not to mention the computer science majors coming out of Stanford University, the University of California and other nearby colleges.
Already, San Francisco has responded to complaints: for one, it is speeding up the permit process for new-media companies wanting to expand. It used to take five to seven weeks to get a permit, but it now takes only five to seven days, said Mara Brazer, the director of the San Francisco Partnership, a nonprofit organization working to keep businesses in the city. The city is also looking for a site for a multimedia center, like the Information Technology Center in New York, where start-ups can find reduced rent.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Motorola, once a darling among technology stocks, has made some missteps in recent years.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder 

 BODY:
AS the wireless communications industry transforms itself from analog to digital technology, Motorola Inc., whose reputation for innovation, high-quality products and smart strategic thinking flourished in the early 1990's, has looked surprisingly clumsy at times.
The latest embarrassment stemmed from reports last week of a falling out with Primeco Personal Communications L.P., which has a $500 million contract with Motorola to help build a nationwide digital wireless phone system. Primeco has apparently become so annoyed with disruptions in service that it is planning to cancel the contract and perhaps take the drastic step of ripping out equipment already purchased. 
 Analysts say the direct impact of ending the Primeco relationship would be minimal; Motorola had nearly $30 billion in annual sales last year. But the news certainly does not help a corporate image tarnished by several missteps in new markets in recent years, missteps that make analysts worry that other customers may become more hesitant to sign major new contracts with Motorola.
Making matters worse, Motorola is also confronted with some challenges beyond its control. The biggest is the economic crisis in Asia, where it got 26 percent of its revenue last year. No wonder Motorola, the Schaumburg, Ill.-based semiconductor and telecommunications giant, has Wall Street anxiously wondering how the company will regain the momentum that made it so popular among investors in the early 1990's.
"The range of earnings projections for Motorola this year and next is wider than usual," said Charles Hill, director of research at the First Call Corporation, which monitors reports from 29 analysts at brokerage firms that follow the company. Nine of those analysts have strong "buy" recommendations on the stock, but one has an outright "sell" recommendation -- rare for Wall Street -- and 12 others list Motorola as a "hold," which is about as negative as most analysts will get.
For many, the biggest uncertainty comes from the same questions hanging over much of American industry: how deep will Asia's financial woes get and how long will they persist? Asia affects Motorola in two ways. Demand for semiconductors and other key products has weakened during the months of financial turmoil in East Asia. Telephone companies in struggling nations like Indonesia have put big-ticket contracts for new cellular telephone network equipment on hold.
And Asian manufacturers selling products like cellular phones are likely to be tougher competitors, if they are based in countries like South Korea where the local currency has plummeted in value, giving them a sizable cost advantage.
But Wall Street has also been worried -- and far more frustrated -- by the ways Motorola has been hurting itself. As the Primeco episode highlights, the biggest such problems at the moment are in wireless communications products, especially the cellular telephone business.
Much of the luster investors attached to the Motorola name -- the stock is still rivaled only by Intel as a favorite technology holding of investment clubs -- was gained when demand for its pagers skyrocketed and its analog cellular technology dominated the market along with that of L. M. Ericsson of Sweden.
But over the last three years, Motorola ranked 97th of the 100 largest publicly traded companies in the total return it offered its investors.
Industrywide downturns in the huge semiconductor business hurt. So did the failure of the Power PC microchip Motorola developed with I.B.M. to grab significant market share in the personal computer business. And cable modems, which allow consumers to connect to the Internet over cable television lines, failed to take off as anticipated.
The last thing the company needed was another blow to its image as a technology pioneer. But that came last Monday when Crain's Chicago Business reported that Primeco wanted to cancel its contract and remove already-installed Motorola equipment. On Tuesday, after The Wall Street Journal published additional details, Motorola's shares fell nearly 5 percent, to $57.625. They closed on Friday at $55.625, down $1.625. In July, it reached its 52-week high of $89.9375.
Neither company was willing to discuss the reports in detail.
Analysts fret that the problem with Primeco will scare away some potential customers. The Primeco problem drew attention to unrelated trends, like the sharp decline for prospects of semiconductor growth in Asia. It also reminded Wall Street of the other problems Motorola has had getting competitive products to market quickly and keeping customers happy. For instance, Motorola's models of special digital telephones are just reaching the consumer market, far behind nimble competitors like Nokia of Finland.

HEADLINE: Spyglass, a Pioneer, Learns Hard Lessons About Microsoft

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: NAPERVILLE, Ill., Feb. 27

 BODY:
Few people are more familiar with the real-world nature of Microsoft's market power than Douglas P. Colbeth, the 42-year-old chief executive of Spyglass Inc. His Internet software company has been a supplier to Microsoft, providing the software engine for its Internet Explorer browser. Spyglass has also been a Microsoft competitor, briefly, in the browser market.
Both roles proved to be sobering for Spyglass. So much so that the company's current strategy is mainly to stay out of Microsoft's path, finding specialized markets for Internet software and services that the software giant ignores. 
 Spyglass's course corrections offer a lesson in the complexities of software competition and software innovation, and what it means to compete with the Microsoft Corporation, whose chairman, William H. Gates, is to testify at a Senate hearing Tuesday in the midst of a persistent industry debate on the company's practices.
Microsoft's supporters view it as a high-technology national treasure, whose success deserves unqualified praise. The company's critics assail it as a new-era monopolist, whose control of the personal computer software market thwarts competition and stifles innovation.
Mr. Gates, who will testify along with a couple of industry allies and a couple of rivals, comes to Capitol Hill as the Justice Department is pursuing a highly visible antitrust case against Microsoft.
The Senate hearing, said Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah and chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, is intended only as a forum to educate Congress and the public. "We want to hear firsthand industry testimony on the real-world nature of market power in the software business," he said.
These days Spyglass, which operates in the world that Senator Hatch wants to understand, even chooses its customers with Microsoft in mind. "When we look at potential customers," Mr. Colbeth explained, "we look for companies with defensible different businesses from Microsoft or companies that are in an entirely different business."
But while the Spyglass story to date -- a rise, fall and a recent effort to reinvent itself -- helps show why there are concerns about the extent of Microsoft's market power, it also indicates why Government intervention would be so tricky, risking a remedy from Washington that might well be worse than any perceived flaw in the working of fast-moving high-technology markets.
Mr. Colbeth approaches Microsoft from the vantage of a battle-tested pragmatist, not as a lawyer or economist. Microsoft, he says admiringly, is filled with brilliant, tireless workers. "It's a great company," he said. "I have tremendous admiration for Bill Gates as a businessman."
But Microsoft shapes the environment, Mr. Colbeth says; others must adapt. "Does Microsoft squeeze suppliers? You bet it does," he said in his office in the Chicago suburb of Naperville. "But that is just the reality in any industry where one company has an 85 percent share, as Microsoft does in the operating-system market. That gives it enormous leverage in the market, and it uses it.
"And do you lose innovation in the software business because companies figure it's crazy to compete with Microsoft? Yes, I think you do," Mr. Colbeth said. "But I also think the effect is to drive innovation into other parts of the information technology business. You can't compete head on against Microsoft, so you are forced to innovate in other areas."
Spyglass is known, if at all, as the "other browser company," besides Microsoft and the Netscape Communications Corporation. The software for browsing the Internet's World Wide Web traces its origins back to work done at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois.
The key technical people at Spyglass were research students at the university, as was Marc Andreessen, Netscape's co-founder. In May 1994, Spyglass was chosen by the University of Illinois as the licensee to develop and market a commercial version of Mosaic, the original Web browser.
Mosaic was a second chance for Spyglass, which Mr. Colbeth joined as chief executive in 1991, a year after it was founded. The company's early years were spent marketing three-dimensional software tools used by scientists in medical, geological and meteorological research. It was pioneering software, by all accounts, but the company struggled in a fragmented niche market that was dependent on declining government research funds.
By then Mr. Colbeth, whose money had been put into Spyglass, had three mortgages on his house and no net worth. The older of his two children was nearing college. "Hey, trying to start a business is risky," he recalled.
Yet the Internet was on its way to becoming a household word, and all the major technology companies feared being left behind. As a company, Microsoft was a bit late in noticing the rise of the Internet, but by late summer 1994 it was negotiating with Spyglass to license Mosaic.
Its original offer in August 1994, Mr. Colbeth said, was $100,000. That would have more than doubled the cash Spyglass had in the bank at the time, but the amount seemed extremely low for an important technology that Microsoft would put into millions of PC's. "It was our experience and it is the accepted belief within the industry that the first offer from Microsoft on licensing deals is always $100,000," Mr. Colbeth said.
Microsoft's argument for why Spyglass should accept the offer, Mr. Colbeth said, was twofold: the endorsement value of having Microsoft license Spyglass technology would help it enormously in marketing and if Spyglass refused to license its technology on Microsoft's terms, Microsoft would develop it in-house.
But that would take six months or a year, and Netscape, backed by Microsoft rivals, was getting ready to begin selling its browser. Microsoft talked to Netscape about licensing its browser, then struck a deal with Spyglass in December 1994 for $2 million, for use with its Windows 95 operating system.
Later licensing deals to use Spyglass technology on other operating systems, including Apple's Macintosh and Windows 3.1, and a final payment for all future use brought the total that Microsoft paid to Spyglass to $13.1 million.
By the end of 1995, Spyglass had also licensed Mosaic to 82 other companies, including I.B.M. and Digital Equipment, for use in their software products. The revenue stream from the licensing deals was around $20 million a year.
But in December 1995, when Mr. Gates announced that Microsoft was shifting its product development to "embrace and extend" the Internet, he also said Microsoft would be giving its browser away. A byproduct was that the Spyglass browser licensing revenue quickly disappeared, as smaller Internet software companies went out of business and many big customers shifted to Microsoft's free browser.
"Twenty million in revenues went away -- poof -- in a year," Mr. Colbeth said.
So, once again, Spyglass overhauled its strategy. No longer in the market for Internet software for the PC market, it is focusing on software that enables non-PC devices to tap into the Internet. This market, just beginning to emerge, is expected to range from cellular phones and television set-top boxes to fax machines and even to gasoline pumps (screen-equipped for downloading local road maps). By 2001, it is estimated there will be 48 million non-PC devices worldwide.
Spyglass is not only selling specialized software to companies in the device market, but also doing consulting work for companies like Xerox, RCA, Nokia and I.B.M. Still, Spyglass has a long way to go. In its most recent fiscal year ending last September, it reported revenue of $21 million and a loss of $9.7 million. It is expected to again lose money this year, but hopes to return to profitability in 1999.
Microsoft, Mr. Colbeth predicts, will be in the device software market, getting perhaps 30 or 40 percent. But the market for small-scale software used in devices, he believes, is more diverse and fragmented than the PC market. "And 30 or 40 percent is a world apart from 80 percent," he said. "The balance of power will be very different."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Douglas P. Colbeth at the Spyglass headquarters, contemplating the Microsoft wars. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Taking In the Sites;
Corporate Intelligence: A Cloakhold On the Web

BYLINE: By SREENATH SREENIVASAN 

 BODY:
Competitive intelligence, known variously as CI and business intelligence, is more than just a buzzword thrown about by management consultants. Gathering information on rivals can be one key to success in the cutthroat corporate world. But some of the cloak-and-dagger may be giving way to the mouse and keyboard as an increasing number of resources become available on the World Wide Web.
"Many people don't realize just how much you can learn about your rivals by accessing the Internet," said Leonard M. Fuld, founder of Fuld & Company in Cambridge, Mass., which specializes in competitive-intelligence issues. "From prospective clients to product specs, it's out there. And we are not talking about some secret Web site that you need to access." He is talking about the seemingly innocuous company home page. 
 Mr. Fuld and other experts say that organization charts, customer lists and executive biographies can all be plumbed to learn about the state of a company. Corporate plans, mergers and strategic alliances can also be discovered if the documents are properly analyzed. "Of course, the Internet is a tool and not an answer machine," Mr. Fuld said, "so you need to be really patient and able to dig deep."
Digging deep can lead to strategies for research and development and information about new products. Another area to pay close attention to is the news-release archive. Because the great majority of such releases are never printed in newspapers or other publications, the archives can hold hints of future opportunities and challenges.
Human resources departments, in their quest to attract candidates, provide extensive job postings that can signal areas that a corporation is focusing on.
"The problem is compounded by the fact that many sites are created by divisions within a company or by outside design firms that are not as cautious about content as headquarters is," said Robert D. Aaron, president of Aaron/Smith Associates, an Atlanta consulting firm on competitive intelligence.
Small businesses as well as large ones are using the Web to gather information about rivals. For example, an independent stationery store can benefit from studying the on-line catalogues of chains to identify trends and offer competitive pricing.
This abundance of information, much of it given out unwittingly, is a result of companies' trying to maintain active and extensive Web sites without thinking about some of the consequences. The easy access and in-depth nature of a site that makes it so different from, say, an annual report is also a disadvantage. Not only are potential customers looking at the site, but competitors are too. It seems likely that in the years ahead, corporations will reduce or curb the kinds of features that are open to the public.
A good place to start a Web tour of competitive-intelligence sites is the Fuld Internet Intelligence Index, which has links to more than 300 sites related to intelligence gathering, arranged by industry and interest area. The site features a "strategic intelligence organizer," a useful guide that suggests questions to ask when trying to gather information about topics like information technology, employee defections and deregulation.
There is also an interactive questionnaire that says it can determine how intelligence-savvy a company is.
The sites of other consulting firms vary greatly in quality and presentation. Some are nothing more than bare brochures, while others are quite handy. The site of the Montague Institute of Montague, Mass., offers a Web journal that tackles topics like "Using the Internet for Competitive Intelligence."
The site of the Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals, though designed for members, is helpful to others, as well. Among the resources: a data base of 350 competitive-intelligence experts available to discuss their areas of specialization, and various research reports. It also answers questions like: "Is CI espionage?" Answer: "No. Espionage is the use of illegal means to gather information. In fact, economic espionage represents a failure of CI."
Naturally, corporate espionage remains an area of much concern, and the Web reflects that. The School of Criminal Justice at Michigan State University has teamed up with the society to produce a site dedicated to intelligence and espionage laws worldwide.
Also worth visiting is the World Intellectual Property Organization in Geneva, with its arbitration and mediation center and texts of various agreements, including the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property of 1883.

HEADLINE: Suharto Is Still Weighing a Drastic Economic Move

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 1

 BODY:
President Suharto said today that the austerity measures demanded by the International Monetary Fund to overcome Indonesia's economic crisis have not yet borne fruit and that the country must find its own formula for recovery, something he said might be called "I.M.F.-plus."
In a major address today, he thanked the international community for its assistance and said Indonesia would continue to work with the I.M.F., which he called an "authoritative and highly effective international institution." 
 But he said he was still considering pegging the exchange rate of the rupiah to the dollar, a drastic measure that is strongly opposed by the I.M.F. and the United States.
"In the end, our fate rests in our own hands," he said.
His remarks came in a state-of-the-nation address on the first day of a Parliamentary session that is set to hand him a seventh Presidential term next week. Mr. Suharto, 76, has led the country for 32 years.
The well-orchestrated session demonstrated his continued political dominance despite Indonesia's economic turmoil, which has been marked during the last two months by rapidly rising inflation, unemployment and an outbreak of riots over rising prices.
But in a signal that political orchestration is not enough, the speech also came on the eve of the arrival here Monday of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, who is bringing a message of concern from President Clinton over Mr. Suharto's handling of the crisis. Officials in Washington said Mr. Mondale's visit was intended to convey a sense of urgency over the carrying out of austerity measures Mr. Suharto agreed to last month in return for a $40 billion economic rescue package organized by the fund.
Mr. Suharto insisted today that he was moving ahead with the austerity measures, but that the key to recovery was to find a way to strengthen the Indonesian currency, the rupiah, which has fallen by more than 70 percent in value since last summer.
"Unless this is achieved, I don't see any possible improvement in the near future," the President said.
One way to do this, he said, would be to set up what is known as a currency board, which would fix an artificially strong value for the rupiah, backed by Indonesia's foreign-currency reserves. Most economists say that Indonesia's economy is too fragile to withstand the fiscal pressures of such a step.
"I must remain careful in cautiously contemplating the possible introduction of the currency board," Mr. Suharto said, adding, "Whatever measures we take, we need the support of the I.M.F."
A fund delegation is currently reviewing his compliance with an economic restructuring plan that he signed under international pressure on Jan. 15. The agency will decide in mid-March whether his level of compliance warrants continued release of support financing.
Officials in Washington say Mr. Mondale's visit is in part due to what they called Mr. Suharto's foot-dragging in carrying out these measures.
In his speech, Mr. Suharto said, "We have carried out parts of the program, while other parts will follow later."
So far, he said, Indonesia has toughened its annual budget, as required, has moved to ease investment procedures, withdrawn state financing for expensive and money-losing projects, and has begun to restructure its banking system.
In spite of these steps, he said: "The exchange rate of the rupiah continues to be weak. It strengthens for a while, then sinks again."
Unemployment is growing, he said, and prices are rising for imported and locally produced goods, including medicines.
"People's lives are becoming more difficult," he said, adding that he shared the distress of housewives struggling to feed their families.
The President said the region's economic difficulties, which began a year ago in Thailand, had struck Indonesia much sooner and harder than had been expected, threatening his economic achievements of the last three decades.
Since taking power, Mr. Suharto has presided over spectacular economic growth, which in the last decade has averaged more than 7 percent a year. Now, he said, "It seems that everything we have built, with great difficulty, sometimes with pain and sacrifices, has suddenly been undermined."
Mr. Suharto's speech was marked by an unusual level of self-criticism and candor. In addition to external monetary forces, he said, Indonesia's hardships are the result of "our own internal weaknesses," though he did not elaborate.
In what appeared to be a reference to recent riots in which the shops of ethnic Chinese merchants have been looted and burned, he said Indonesians should unite to solve the country's difficulties.
"We do not have to look for a scapegoat," he said. "It is useless to look for a scapegoat."

HEADLINE: Longwood Journal;
In Mobile Homes, Sitting Vulnerable to Tornadoes

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: LONGWOOD, Fla., March 1

 BODY:
At 91 years old, Martha Carney lives on a street of manicured lawns, decorative windmills and pink flamingos. It is the kind of neighborhood where people can mingle at their own private clubhouse and a stranger's car would be quickly noticed and even reported to the manager's office.
But small communities like the Spring Hammock mobile home park here were ground zero for the tornadoes that ravaged parts of central Florida last week, as winds of more than 200 miles an hour hurled homes and occupants into the air with such force that searches for the missing extended hundreds of feet, into creeks and over highways. Of the 40 people who died, state officials said, at least 24 were in mobile homes. 
 Spring Hammock in Seminole County, where 11 of the 12 people killed were in mobile homes, was spared any damage. But Irene Shriver, Mrs. Carney's 72-year-old daughter who is visiting from West Virginia, said she now worries more about her mother. Any talk of moving, however, has been pointedly rejected.
"West Virginia is for the birds," said Mrs. Carney, who has lived alone since her husband of 67 years, a retired Morse code operator, died six years ago. "As long as you can take care of yourself, you're better off where you are."
There are more than half a million mobile homes in Florida and nearly 200,000 recreational vehicles, which are usually traveling motor homes but include camping trailers. The occupants include migrant agricultural workers and winter visitors, in one of the largest concentrations of such homes in the country.
For the elderly, mobile homes are an economical alternative for retirement or a second home where the weather is warm or, as in the case of Mrs. Carney, who pays $230 a month for the lot where her mobile home sits, the only way to hold on to independence. Families and younger people can gain the advantages of a house at a lower cost than either a house or an apartment -- backyards, room for pets and children, safe streets for play -- and others use them as transitional shelter while they build up their savings.
They can be a young couple's dream first home in well-kept parks where the manufactured homes feature carports, screened porches and even decks by a lake, or can be a reminder of an unbroken cycle of poverty in rundown lots where many of the homes seem to be falling apart.
"Of course no one wants to live in a trailer," said Cindy Mitchell, 27, a cashier at a fast-food restaurant who grew up in a two-bedroom mobile home with her parents and five siblings. She now shares another one, a rental for $375 a month, with her 7-year-old son, boyfriend and a dog in the city of South Daytona. "It basically comes down to money," she said. South Daytona is in Volusia County, which took the brunt of the recent tornadoes.
"Having a child, we wanted to have a yard and a safe area for him to ride his bike," she said. "Living in an apartment is too confined. My son wouldn't have a normal life. He would be locked up.
"It's not exactly the most beautiful place to live but we do what we can do."
A neighbor on the same low-income street, Glenn Boyer, 32, who makes race-car engine parts for a Daytona Beach company, said that moving into his first mobile home with his German shepherd three years ago was a calculated choice.
"I want to get bedroom sets and electronic equipment before I move into a house," he said.
But there are trade-offs, like thin walls that make summers hotter and winters colder, or easy deterioration. "Anywhere there's water they rot," Ms. Mitchell said.
Last week, many of the homes became death traps. The National Weather Service says that preliminary findings show that at least six tornadoes touched down the night of Feb. 22 and early Feb. 23 across several counties between Tampa and Daytona Beach, four of them with winds of 158 m.p.h. to 260 m.p.h. Federal Government standards for mobile homes require them to be strapped down and able to withstand winds of 100 m.p.h. to 110 m.p.h., Florida state regulators said.
Now Florida officials are looking into new systems to alert residents to tornado warnings -- last week's tornadoes caught many people asleep -- with special attention to mobile home and recreational vehicle parks. They say that in order to drum up more business, some parks now include permanent buildings that could be used as shelters for hurricanes and tornadoes.
Frank Williams, executive director of the Florida Manufactured Housing Association, a group that represents manufacturers and retailers, said the homes could be made more sturdy but they would become too expensive.
"Nobody could afford them nor would anybody want them," he said. "It's a public policy question: Do you force people to pay twice as much for a home for a freak of nature like this?"
But for Lucille and Jack Lawley, both 75, the freakish is beginning to appear normal. During Tropical Storm Gordon in November 1994, their four-bedroom, 60-by-40-foot mobile home in Big Tree Shores in South Daytona filled with a foot and a half of water. They replaced the floors, the carpet and a refrigerator.
This time, the tornadoes tore off their roof. Mr. Lawley said he looked out the window and saw the wind-folded roof fly by and thought it was a flying saucer. Today, 13 buckets and 2 plastic garbage cans collected water from leaks in the aluminum roof underneath the one torn away, covered by a blue tarp.
"It seems like all I've done since I've retired has been work on this house," said Mr. Lawley, a former manager for the AT&T Corporation. "I work and work."
But while Mr. Lawley favors selling both the mobile home and the couple's house in Washington to buy a house in Florida, his wife insists they keep their winter home of 15 years. They had paid $65,000 for the home and lot.
"It'll never happen again and if it does, it does," Mrs. Lawley said of the powerful tornadoes. "I guess I'm a fatalist."
Some mobile home dwellers say the tornadoes have scared them into thinking about moving. Kelly Dunham, 26, a student at Daytona Beach Community College who lives in a rented mobile home with her boyfriend and two children, ages 7 and 4, said she wants to move as soon as possible to a permanent home with a solid foundation. "It's definitely not my idea of fun to live your life worrying about a tornado sucking you up," she said. "We rocked and swayed."
Next time, she said, "I'll go to Winn-Dixie. It's open 24 hours. They can't kick you out." Others said they would be more mindful of tornado watches but planned to stay put. They noted that last week's twisters were unusually strong for Florida, which mostly gets tornadoes that have winds of less than 112 m.p.h., are short-lived and less life-threatening than those in the Midwest. Houses and other permanent structures were also leveled in the tornadoes, they said.
Mrs. Carney, who weathered the tornadoes by taking one of what she calls her "nerve pills" and huddling in the bathroom with a candle, said next time she will have her son or grandson who live in nearby Winter Springs pick her up, when she hears of a tornado watch. But in the aftermath of Florida's deadliest tornadoes, she said she was not worried.
"So what?" she said. "I'm past 90 years old. I've had a good life."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Safety concerns have been raised about mobile homes after last week's deadly tornadoes, which killed 24 people in them. Adam Dunham, 7, left, played ball in the yard of his family's mobile home in South Daytona, Fla., joined by Billy Ray Mathis, 5, and Michael Mitchell. Many people see trade-offs in living in mobile homes: they are relatively inexpensive but are often less sturdy than traditional housing. (Photographs by Phillippe Diederich for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Unions Unite In a Campaign For Child Care

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Hoping to make New York the first state to provide child-care benefits as generous as those in Europe, 10 New York City labor unions have begun lobbying state lawmakers to spend $200 million more on child care and pressing employers to create a multi-union child-care fund.
Vowing to make child care an overriding priority, these unions, representing almost a million workers, want Albany to subsidize 50,000 more child-care slots, to build more day-care centers and to train child-care workers better. 
 The 10-union coalition, which includes the teachers and communications workers, asserts that the scarcity and expense of good child care leaves thousands of children ill-prepared to start school and many workers so distracted by child-care problems that their productivity is hurt.
Deborah King, an official in the hospital workers' union who heads the newly formed child-care coalition, said: "We've had a dramatic change in the past 25 years -- there are many two-parent families where both parents work, and there are many single-parent families where the parent works. But our workplaces have not changed to reflect that reality. We don't have adequate child care."
Some union officials acknowledge that it will be an uphill battle to persuade Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature, especially the Republican-controlled Senate, to approve the whole $200 million. But they say they expect the Legislature to approve more than the $21 million in increased child-care spending proposed by Mr. Pataki.
Brian McLaughlin, president of the New York City Central Labor Council, said, "The state's surplus and a windfall of Federal funds make expansion of child care feasible at this time."
New York and other states are increasing the number of subsidized child-care slots to help welfare mothers make the transition to work, but union officials say that those plans still leave millions of moderate-income workers unable to afford child care. France, among other European countries, has elaborate, heavily subsidized child-care programs that serve millions of families and often work on a sliding scale, with wealthier parents paying more.
Labor leaders say they have seized on this issue because their members have voiced so much concern about inadequate child care. Indeed, union officials say they hope to bring about improved child care the way the labor movement once led the way to some fundamental innovations that Americans now take for granted: the 40-hour workweek, Social Security, unemployment insurance and minimum wage laws.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, John J. Sweeney, went to a Brooklyn day-care center last Thursday to join the city's labor leaders when they announced their new child-care push. At that meeting, bus drivers, garment workers and municipal employees said they often faced a two-year wait to get their children into day-care programs, and some workers complained that they had spent more than one-third of their income on child care.
The unions have also begun a campaign to press New York State to imitate many European countries and begin paying for six months of maternity or paternity leave.
Ms. King said that no state in the country pays for maternity or paternity leave. "Considering New York's history of leadership, we think it should be the first state to start such a program."
Such a program is expected to cost at least $50 million a year. Union officials in New Jersey are also pushing for legislation to create paid parental leave, arguing that mothers and fathers of newborns should receive money under the state disability law.
Asked last night about the union's proposals on child care and maternity leave, Charles Deister, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, said, "As for the specifics of the proposals and the cost involved, we'll have to take a look at it."
Mr. Deister added, "Over the Governor's term, he has increased day-care slots by 64 percent, which is one of the largest increases in state history, and he's proposed a $21 million increase this year."
Labor leaders have praised the Governor for proposing to increase the number of subsidized child-care slots by 49,000 over the next two years, to 125,000. But they say Mr. Pataki's plan does not go far enough -- they want financing for 50,000 subsidized slots this year, and tens of thousands more in future years.
Union officials estimate that in New York State more than one million children of low-income and moderate-income families need subsidized care.
Mr. Pataki has called for spending $21 million more on child care, but union officials say this amount is inadequate. Asserting that the Governor plans to increase the number of slots far more sharply than the amount of money, they calculate that under his plan the subsidy per child would fall to $2,450 from $4,225. A lower subsidy, they argue, would make it harder for many low-income and moderate-income parents to afford child care, which usually costs $4,000 to $10,000 per child per year.
The unions' child-care coalition includes the United Federation of Teachers; the Union of Needletrade, Industrial and Textile Employees; District Council 37, which represents 120,000 municipal workers; the Communications Workers of America; and 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union. The effort, known as the Child Care That Works Campaign, has the backing of two dozen other groups, including the League of Women Voters, the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies and the United Jewish Appeal.
The unions' new strategy calls for demanding that public and private employers contribute to what would be the nation's first multi-union child-care fund. For instance, in its next contract talks, the teachers' union might ask New York City to contribute several million dollars a year to the fund.
Each union participating in the fund could use some of the money to send its members' children to day-care programs, after-school programs or summer camps. In addition, union leaders said, some of the money might be used to build A.F.L.-C.I.O. child-care centers -- an idea that would seek not just to provide more and better facilities, but also to integrate unions more into the lives of workers.
Not surprisingly, one aim of the plan is to pay child-care workers and have more of them join unions. Deborah McWilliams, a worker at the Crown Heights center that Mr. Sweeney visited, said: "We've been perceived as baby sitters. We're educators. We're nurses. We're social workers. We have to see things the parents don't see. We need a decent wage."
Ms. McWilliams receives $20,000 a year for her full-time work, which she noted is less than half of what many teachers are paid.
The labor unions are supporting a pilot program, in conjunction with the City University of New York, to provide home-based day care to 400 low-income children. The day-care workers would be supervised by neighborhood child-care centers in a plan intended to improve training of home-based day-care workers.
The teachers' union is one of the most enthusiastic supporters of the new initiative, partly because so many teachers have young children. "People worry that their children are not being taken care of very well," said Randi Weingarten, the new president of the United Federation of Teachers. "How can they concentrate on their work when they don't have quality day care?"
