HEADLINE: To Social Security Critics, The Argument Is Simple

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
As the nation begins debating how to shore up Social Security for the aging baby-boom generation, advocates of fundamentally changing the system are honing their argument to a single theme: that as an investment Social Security is a bad deal.
Conservative groups, Wall Street executives, members of both parties in Congress and other proponents of turning Social Security into a vehicle for investing in stocks and bonds are attacking the current system with research showing that many people will receive little more in retirement benefits than they contribute through payroll taxes. 
 Younger people, especially, will get a bad deal relative to people born longer ago, the critics said. And some demographic groups, including black men, who have lower life expectancy than the general population, will lose money on Social Security, the advocates add.
The results, they said, are particularly striking when the system's payoff is compared with the much higher rates of return available in the stock and bond markets. Allowing part of Social Security taxes to be invested in such areas would allow even low-income workers to accumulate significant wealth in their working lives, the critics contend.
"The only way to save Social Security for the long term, meaning 50 years from now, is to transform the program so that it can become a source of wealth," said Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat who favors using part of the payroll tax to finance personal retirement accounts for every worker.
President Clinton has called for Congress and the White House to find a bipartisan solution next year to the looming financial problems of Social Security. The possible solutions include raising taxes, cutting benefits, increasing the retirement age, dedicating Federal budget surpluses to the problem and turning Social Security into a more investment-based program.
Social Security has long been viewed as one of the most successful and popular Government programs, a guaranteed intergenerational insurance program for the elderly, the disabled and survivors of people who die during their working lives. Relatively few Democrats have publicly endorsed any shift toward a more investment-oriented approach, and many liberals oppose the idea, as do politically powerful advocacy groups for the elderly. Mr. Clinton has not announced a position.
But the idea is winning widespread support among Republicans. Some like Representatives Mark Sanford of South Carolina and Nick Smith of Michigan are sponsoring plans that would gradually replace the longtime system with private accounts. Others like Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire advocate using part of payroll taxes to finance private investment accounts while maintaining a reduced but guaranteed Social Security benefit as a safety net.
"We've got to give incentives for saving and allow individuals to handle more of their resources for retirement," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa. "That would include some aspect of individualization. But I don't have my mind set on the extent."
Proponents of a more market-oriented approach received fresh ammunition this year from a study by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative group that favors changing the system. The study said, "The Social Security system's rate of return for most Americans will be vastly inferior to what they could expect from placing their payroll taxes in even the most conservative private investments."
Although supporting measured steps to improve financial performance, defenders of the system said that much of the new research on rates of return was flawed or misleading and that it glossed over the possibility of major declines in stock prices. Moreover, studies about rates of return generally fail to look at disability and survivors' benefits, which are distinct from retirement benefits and account for nearly a third of the program payments.
Requiring individuals to invest on their own would mostly be a windfall for Wall Street, the defenders said, allowing investment companies to charge fees to nearly every working American.
More fundamentally, the defenders added, Social Security should not be seen as a giant 401(k) program in which economic security depends on individual financial acumen.
Research like the Heritage study constitutes an effort to shatter a consensus on Social Security by pitting the generations, the races and other groups against one another in a grab for money, the defenders said.
"The Social Security system cannot be compared to investment in the private market," said Roger Hickey, co-director of the Institute for America's Future, a group that advocates maintaining the system. "Everyone involved in Social Security knows their benefit will be there until they die. They know their parents will be taken care of. There are many returns that cannot be as easily quantified as stock-market returns."
Social Security has more than enough money to pay today's retirees and other beneficiaries. But it will become pressed as the 76 million people born in the 20 years after World War II begin retiring around 2010. Unless changes are made, the system, experts say, will become insolvent around 2029, able to pay 75 percent of promised benefits.
One middle-ground approach under consideration calls for the system, rather than individuals, to invest directly in the markets, much as pension funds do. That approach is favored, within limits, by the American Association of Retired Persons, the lobbying group for the elderly.
Social Security's financial reserves are now held in special Treasury bonds, which are virtually lossproof but offer low yields compared with the stock market.
"You can improve the investment performance of the savings portfolio within Social Security," said John Rother, the legislative director of the A.A.R.P. "The whole experience with the stock market is pushing us toward some component of greater investment in the market than ever before. It can be good as long as it's done prudently."
The Heritage study illustrates the central argument of those who are calling for a more market-oriented system. A couple with children in which both partners are 30 and both earn $26,000 a year would pay, along with their employers, $320,000 in Social Security taxes by the time they retire and would receive $450,000 in retirement benefits before dying, an inflation-adjusted annual return of 1.23 percent, the study said.
By contrast, the stock market generated average annual returns of 7.56 percent from 1926 to 1996, after accounting for inflation, according to Ibbotson Associates, a research concern. Allowing the couple to invest its Social Security taxes in a mutual fund with a 5 percent rate of return would more than double, to $975,000, the money available for their retirement, the study said.
The study found that rates of return were becoming steadily lower for each succeeding generation, primarily because of increases in payroll taxes over the years. A single man with an average income born in 1950 could expect an annual return from Social Security retirement benefits of 1.34 percent, the study said, compared with a return of 0.47 percent for a single man born in 1970.
Lower-income workers do better with the system than higher-income workers, in keeping with the original goal to fight poverty. But black workers tend to receive much lower rates of return on their payroll taxes than white counterparts, the study said.
A single black man, 30, who earns $12,800 a year, half the average wage, would pay $82,000 in taxes in his working life, including his employer's share. He would receive $72,000 in benefits in retirement, a loss equal to a negative annual rate of return of 0.55 percent.
Critics of the study said it was misleading on many counts.
Steve Goss, the deputy chief actuary at the Social Security Administration, said other studies using different assumptions and techniques had found substantially higher rates of return. The 0.47 percent return for single men born in 1970, for example, was found to be 1.28 percent in a report released last year by an advisory council on Social Security.
The Heritage study particularly skewed the findings for returns to black people, Mr. Goss said in another study this month, calling the Heritage conclusions greatly exaggerated, in part because they failed to take full account of the lower life expectancies for black men compared to the general population.

HEADLINE: After the Oxford Debacle

 BODY:
Oxford Health Plans made the remarkable admission last week that its losses during the last months of last year exceeded the total of all its previous profits. Oxford's performance is more embarrassing than even its stunning losses indicate. Its management did not have a clue how much money it was paying out to doctors or collecting from members. In fact, Oxford has been losing money for some time, but no one knew. Late last year, its bookkeepers caught up to a sorry reality.
Now Oxford is off to a new start, with an infusion of $350 million from an outside investor and a new chief executive, Norman Payson, who replaces the company's visionary but managerially challenged founder, Stephen Wiggins. The new Oxford starts out with a strong customer base and a large roster of high-quality doctors and hospitals. It also inherits an inchoate reform that Mr. Wiggins designed for the future but which makes even more sense now that his old business strategy has come unglued. If managed well, Oxford can prosper. 
 Even so, Oxford's two million members are facing rougher times. Mr. Wiggins built up business by offering middle-class families affordable premiums and a physician roster that often included their existing doctors. But vast networks make it difficult to control costs or quality. Oxford thrived, largely because Mr. Wiggins's strategy rapidly drew in new customers. Last year's financial collapse proves, however, that soaring premium revenues were masking an underlying rot.
The new Oxford will probably need to raise premiums and limit the choice of doctors. But these changes would have taken place anyway. Mr. Wiggins had already begun to transform Oxford into an umbrella organization within which teams of specialists compete against one another for Oxford's members. This strategy mirrors that of managed care plans in California, traditionally the bellwether for health care across the country. Closer to home, Michael Stocker of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has adopted a strategy by which Empire will offer its members competing medical groups, including one centered around the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
Increasingly, then, the important medical decision families will make is not whether they join Oxford or Empire or some other large insurance plan but which medical group they choose within a plan. Even an employer that offers its workers only one plan will indirectly be offering them a potentially wide choice of medical groups. What C.E.O.'s like Mr. Stocker and Mr. Wiggins have been figuring out is that they need small networks to tightly monitor health care costs and quality. They hope to offer customers what they want, a choice of medical groups, but keep those groups small enough that the insurance plan can maintain tight supervision.
Mr. Wiggins did not know how to manage a far-flung insurance company. But he did know how to size up powerful market forces. He may no longer sit atop Oxford. But his vision still might.

HEADLINE: Freedom in Math Class May Outweigh Tests

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
When the results of a major international mathematics and science test were made public last week, showing American 12th graders near the bottom of the industrialized world, leaders reacted with well-rehearsed alarm. They warned that Americans would not be able "to continue to be global competitors in the new knowledge economy," as Education Secretary Richard W. Riley put it.
Fingers were pointed, hands were wrung. Officials lamented that the country continued to be, as the title of an influential 1983 education report had it, "A Nation at Risk." 
 But with the United States standing today as the world's unchallenged technological powerhouse, the trendsetter for a global computer and information economy that Asian and European countries are struggling to match, the scripted furor has drowned out a quiet, embarrassed debate. Top scientists and educators are wondering whether the country is succeeding despite loose educational practices or at least in part because of them.
"Like America, science is a fundamentally optimistic endeavor, a kind of child's play, where little attention is paid to getting it right immediately and there is little stress on canons," said Dudley Herschbach, a chemistry professor at Harvard University and a 1986 Nobel laureate. "I have noticed that graduate students who get straight A's are often lost when it comes to research. Maybe we have let kids wander all over hell in high school, but that preserves some energy for later when it is better spent."
But Professor Herschbach acknowledged that his opinion was based on little more than anecdote and hunch, and that he might only be rationalizing the dismal results. But he was not alone to voice such educational sacrilege.
Larry Cuban, a professor of education at Stanford University, said, "American ingenuity and innovation seem to be so nimble in responding to difficult problems that one could speculate that the progressivism that so many critics claim has seized American schools is the very fountainhead for that creativity and innovation."
Nearly all educators agreed that American schooling required improvement, that teachers were poorly paid and trained and that students were underserved and insufficiently challenged. But the educators said the links between those problems and economic performance were apparently far less direct than had been supposed.
Many expressed alarm and puzzlement over the results, released on Tuesday, of the Third International Mathematics and Science Study, widely seen as the most comprehensive and rigorous comparison of quantitative skills across nations.
American 12th graders were outperformed in mathematics and science literacy by their counterparts in 12 countries out of 20 and did better than students in just 2, Cyprus and South Africa. In advanced mathematics and physics, no country performed more poorly.
In the same study, American fourth graders scored above the international average and eighth graders about average. So some educators took the opportunity to argue that recent attention to standards and better schools had begun to pay off but had not reached the upper levels of schooling.
The trouble is that this pattern has been consistent for as long as comparative tests have been given. American students start out equal with or ahead in basic skills and steadily decline the longer they stay in school, compared with the students of the country's main trading partners.
When in the late 1950's the Soviet Union put a rocket in space ahead of the United States and in the 70's and 80's, Japanese cars and computers were leaving American products behind, the gaps in students' mathematics and science scores were used as damning evidence of an imminent national decline and a reason for spending money to improve schools.
But today Asian and European educators are coming for visits to see what they might learn from the American system.
"I remember," said Gerald W. Bracey, a researcher and writer on education, "when the Education Minister of Singapore came here, and people said: 'What are you looking here for? Your kids consistently score on top of all international tests.' And he said something like, 'All that our kids can do is take tests.' He understood that we are nurturing more creativity here than the Asians."
Howard Gardner, a professor of education at Harvard University, said the United States was "a country of infinite second chances."
"There are a thousand ways to bounce back," Professor Gardner said. "What harms you in other countries is the straight and narrow path you have to follow. If you fall off, it is very hard to get back on. Here it is a more chaotic system. But the world economy is more chaotic. So that's good."
With technology changing so rapidly, American corporations are investing billions in on-the-job training at hundreds of so-called corporate universities. Such training focuses the mind on specific tasks in ways that some analysts say can be more effective than traditional schooling.
"Adults can be very good at practical math yet do poorly in pencil-and-paper tests," said Robert J. Sternberg, a professor of psychology and education at Yale University who conducts research on intelligence. "People can also do well on managerial or sales or military skills and not do particularly well on those tests. If we are talking about success in life, these tests are incomplete measures."
Of course, despite all the talk of creative genius, a number of less radical explanations for the poor 12th-grade results and simultaneously booming economy are also being offered.
Most experts argue that American universities, widely seen as the best in the world, most likely make up for many failings of high schools. The experts add that it takes only a small number of top technicians to design computer chips and related products.
John H. Bishop, an economist who is chairman of the human resource studies department at Cornell University's School of Industrial Relations, said an unusual feature of American higher education was its close connection to industry. Professor Bishop added that American economic strength was a result of decisions made 40 years ago when the G.I. Bill of Rights offered college educations to thousands of returning veterans, making up in quantity what it lacked in quality.
He and others also say a steady stream of foreigners is filling the graduate and professional programs in mathematics and science.
Data from the National Science Foundation lend support to that point. One-fourth to one-third of doctorates in science and engineering awarded in the United States over the last 10 years have gone to foreigners, and many of those trained foreigners have stayed and made their careers here.
American science has always benefited from the attractiveness to foreigners and the need of many to flee oppressive regimes: witness Albert Einstein and Enrico Fermi. What is happening today may be seen as a continuation of that movement.
Professor Herschbach of Harvard said that was no coincidence, because good science depends on freedom -- freedom of inquiry, freedom of communication and freedom of spirit -- all at the core of the American ideal.
He added that what is missing in school may be made up for in informal science fairs and similar events. The Intel Science Fair, with which he is associated, brings together 1,200 youngsters selected from nearly 1 million participants in hundreds of feeder fairs involving thousands of adult volunteers.
"These are not eggheads, but a cross section of America," he said. "When a kid does a project, he or she really takes ownership of a piece of knowledge."

HEADLINE: Theodore Schultz, 95, Winner Of a Key Prize in Economics

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Theodore W. Schultz, an economist at the University of Chicago whose research on agriculture and education was honored with a Nobel Memorial Prize in 1979, died Thursday at a nursing home in Evanston, Ill.
The cause of death was an infection that did not respond to treatment, his family said. Mr. Schultz was 95. 
 The eldest of eight children born on a farm near Arlington, S.D., Mr. Schultz never went to high school. Despite the opposition of his parents, he did attend South Dakota State College, earning bachelor's and master's degrees in agricultural economics in 1926. He went on to graduate school at the University of Wisconsin and, armed with a Ph.D., joined the faculty of Iowa State College in 1930.
 At Iowa State, then a land grant college with little tradition of scholarship, he organized what came to be one of the best economics departments in the country. Among the faculty he recruited was a young man with a freshly minted Ph.D. from the University of California named John Kenneth Galbraith.
Mr. Schultz left Iowa State in 1943 after a bitter battle over academic freedom. One of his colleagues had written an essay comparing margarine favorably with butter as a way of economizing on resources for the war effort. Dairy interests protested -- the vegetable oil-based spread was viewed as a commercial threat -- and the college administration tried to prevent publication. While Mr. Schultz successfully led the charge against censorship, he left for the University of Chicago.
"That incident provoked some serious soul-searching," recalled D. Gale Johnson, a fellow agricultural economist, pushing land grant schools to broaden their mission to include truly independent research.
At the University of Chicago, Mr. Schultz again showed his talent for organization. "When he arrived," said James Heckman, an economist at the university, "the economics department was a mess of bickering." By the early 1960's, under Mr. Schultz's leadership, it had emerged as a center of innovative economic thinking.
But the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science is not handed out for exceptional management skills. Mr. Schultz is widely credited for bringing agricultural economics into the mainstream, focusing on how education, technology and financial incentives have significantly raised productivity. "He's a transitional figure who bridged the gap between the old-style study of institutions and modern economics" that relies on theory and statistical analysis, Mr. Heckman said.
Mr. Schultz's focus on education as a key to raising productivity led to the modern emphasis on "human capital" as a factor in production. Indeed, his work paved the way for the Nobelist Gary Becker's more celebrated analyses of human skills as a source of productivity growth.
Perhaps Mr. Schultz's most important insight was that farmers could play a key role in economic development, provided they were given the right incentives. That may seem obvious today. Agricultural change was critical to American development in the 19th century. And development specialists now look to free-market agriculture to jump-start the badly lagging economies of Africa. But in the 1950's and 1960's, development planners had a Soviet model in mind -- one in which agriculture's only role was to feed the industrial labor force.
Mr. Schultz formally retired in 1970 but remained an active researcher and colleague until he fractured his hip in 1990 and became bedridden. He is survived by two daughters, Elaine Glickman of Winnetka, Ill., and Margaret Schultz of Chicago, and a son, T. Paul Schultz of Madison, Conn.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 12, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on March 2 about Theodore W. Schultz, an economist whose research on agriculture and education was honored with a Nobel Memorial Prize, referred incorrectly to his efforts, while on the faculty of Iowa State, to hire the economist John Kenneth Galbraith. Though he recruited Mr. Galbraith, Mr. Galbraith chose to go to Harvard.

HEADLINE: Wary Astronomers Ponder An Accelerating Universe

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
AT their telescopes in the last few years, astronomers have been searching the heavens for evidence that the expansion of the universe is slowing down. The mutual gravitational attraction of all matter in stars, planets and everything else known or hypothesized should be putting a gradual brake on the outward rush of space since the explosive moment of cosmic creation in the theorized Big Bang.
The preliminary results of the search are now in, and they are stunning. The expansion of the universe appears to be accelerating, instead of decelerating. 
 "Our observations show that the universe is expanding faster today than yesterday," Dr. Adam Riess, a young astronomer at the University of California at Berkeley, said in an interview last week. An analysis by him and an international team of scientists indicated that the cosmic expansion rate is about 15 percent greater now than when the universe was half its current age, about seven billion years ago.
The group including Dr. Riess and another one, led by Dr. Saul Perlmutter of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, used similar techniques of measuring the cosmic expansion rates over time by studying distant exploding stars, called supernovas. At first, the astronomers were not sure they could believe what they were seeing. But as they examined more supernovas and explored sources of possible error or alternative explanations, they have grown bold in describing the implications of their research at recent meetings.
"Try as we might, we have not found any errors," Dr. Alexei V. Filippenko, a University of California astronomer who has worked on both teams, told colleagues 10 days ago at a meeting in Marina del Rey, Calif. "We get a nonzero cosmological constant."
Translated, that means the astronomers are increasingly confident that they have detected the first strong evidence that the universe is permeated by a repulsive force, the opposite of gravity. The simplest explanation, other astrophysicists agree, is that the force is something called the cosmological constant. As conceived by theorists, this force is a property of the vacuum of space itself, an energy that acts on a large scale to stretch space and thus counteract gravity's restraining power.
If the observations are correct, this is one more case of astronomers handing cosmologists a new piece to a jigsaw puzzle, which is always maddeningly incomplete, and asking them to find a way to fit it into a satisfying theoretical whole. Knowledge of an accelerating expansion could lead to a revised recipe of just what the universe is made of. It could resolve a paradox raised by previous controversial suggestions that the universe appears to be younger than its oldest stars. It could also change thinking about cosmic evolution and the ultimate fate of the universe.
Reflecting the cautious excitement and fervid conjecture touched off by the new findings, Dr. Michael S. Turner, an astrophysicist at the University of Chicago and Fermi National Laboratory, said: "If it's true, this is a remarkable discovery. It means that most of the universe is influenced by an abundance of some weird form of energy whose force is repulsive."
If he were alive, no one would be more bemused by this turn of events than Albert Einstein. Soon after he invented his general theory of relativity in 1915, Einstein was unsettled to find it demanded that the universe either expanded or contracted over time. But like nearly all scientists at the time, he assumed the universe was static, neither expanding nor contracting. What to do?
To compensate for what he considered a flaw in his theory, Einstein introduced the idea of the cosmological constant, symbolized in equations by the Greek letter lambda. The repulsive energy force would presumably counteract gravity and make the universe in his theory stand still. Soon after Edwin P. Hubble discovered the expanding universe in 1929, Einstein renounced the cosmological constant as the greatest blunder of his career.
For years, scientists agreed, dismissing lambda as "that fudge factor." In the last decade, however, they reluctantly dusted it off as a means of balancing the books on the matter and other forces that are required to support the favored interpretation of Big Bang theory.
In this model, called the inflationary Big Bang, the universe should contain a critical density of matter, just enough to slow expansion to a halt, given infinite time. Scientists express this condition of critical density as omega equals one. Too little mass -- if omega equals less than one -- and the universe would expand forever, growing ever more tenuous. If omega equals more than one, then the universe would collapse of its own weight, contracting in what is called the Big Crunch.
So far, astronomical observations and other research have established that the mass density of the universe amounts to no more than 30 percent of the preferred critical value. That includes the mass from ordinary matter in galaxies and a large component of mysterious exotic particles, invisible and still hypothetical. Despite this matter deficit, cosmologists clung to inflation theory because it had passed many tests and provided a satisfying explanation for early conditions in the universe.
In 1990, reviewing all the data, Dr. Turner proposed a formula for a "best-fit universe" that accorded with inflation theory. By his calculations, the universe contained 5 percent ordinary matter and 25 percent mass in the form of cold dark matter, invisible and exotic. The cosmological constant, the energy of empty space, would account for the balance of 70 percent, bringing the universe up to critical density.
The new findings appear to make a prophet of Dr. Turner and others who were beginning to share his views. In January, both teams studying supernovas, measuring how fast these stars were rushing outward when they exploded, reported that the cosmic expansion rate had slowed little or not at all over billions of years. The universe's mass, in ordinary and exotic matter, added up to no more than 20 to 30 percent of critical density. The universe, therefore, seemed destined to expand forever.
After more analysis of the observations, the teams realized they were probably seeing the direct evidence for the mysterious background energy known as the cosmological constant. Not only was the universe's expansion not slowing down, it was speeding up.
Dr. Perlmutter's group, the Supernova Cosmology Project, has studied 40 distant supernovas in detail. Describing their results in January, Dr. Perlmutter acknowledged that the evidence strongly suggested a cosmological constant, but went no further. "We were trying to be very conservative until we had more observations," he said last week.
The other group, called the High-Z Supernova Search Team, has examined only 14 supernovas but was less restrained in its more recent report. Dr. Brian Schmidt of the Mount Stromlo and Siding Spring Observatory in Australia, said in an interview reported in the current issue of the journal Science that his team concluded with a statistical confidence of between 98.7 and 99.9 percent that cosmic expansion is receiving an antigravity boost, presumably from energy of the cosmological constant.
"My own reaction is somewhere between amazement and horror," said Dr. Schmidt, the team leader. "Amazement, because I just did not expect this result, and horror in knowing that it will likely be disbelieved by a majority of astronomers -- who, like myself, are extremely skeptical of the unexpected."
Dr. Riess, whose research led to the conclusion of an accelerating expansion, said: "We are trying not to rush to judgment on the cosmological constant. There could be some other sneaky little effect we have overlooked, something that makes the supernovas dimmer and appear to be farther away than they really are or some variations in the behavior of more distant supernovas that are deceiving us."
But nothing has emerged to make the astronomers doubt their findings, he said. The accelerating expansion indicates that the repulsive force could account for at least 65 percent of the critical density, thus closing the gap between known mass and the much-admired model in which the universe is characterized as omega equaling one. And if the universe was once expanding more slowly than it is now, this would make it older -- about 14 billion years old, or a billion years or more than new estimates for the age of the earliest known stars.
Dr. Perlmutter saw a need to observe more nearby supernovas for comparison with ones being observed at distances of seven billion light-years. This should produce a more refined measure of differences in the expansion rate over time and perhaps reveal any distorting variations in supernovas then and now.
Still, many astrophysicists and cosmologists are beginning to think that Einstein was on to something, though for the wrong reason. The cosmological constant as a repulsive energy force may exist, after all. Physicists can think of no known principle to forbid it. Indeed, theories of quantum mechanics suggest that the energy of the cosmological constant could come from "virtual particles," which may be winking in and out of existence in empty space.
"Actually, the cosmological constant is the least interesting explanation, and that's pretty interesting in itself," Dr. Turner said.
Astrophysicists conceive of other possible sources of repulsive energy in forms that go by such names as X-matter and quintessence. These are speculative concepts in which mysterious textures in the early universe that created conditions for a cosmic background energy and might even help explain the formation of galaxies. Scientists are likely to venture other ideas if evidence for an accelerating universe continues to mount.
"It gives us confidence that two groups that are very competitive and very good are getting the same results," Dr. Turner said.

HEADLINE: Scientists Are Turning to Trees to Repair the Greenhouse

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

 BODY:
ON 80 acres of the wettest land in Catahoula Parish in Louisiana, an experimental crop of hardwood saplings is seizing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and locking it up in wooden cells.
The foot-high seedlings of ash, oak, and pecan are barely two years old. Still overshadowed by annual weeds, they are struggling to establish roots under the perennial floods of the bayou. But on each acre, the trees probably take in as much carbon dioxide each year as a typical automobile puts out, according to the scientists at Louisiana Tech University who manage the project. 
 So while there are skeptics, this experiment in what scientists call the sequestration of carbon, if it can be replicated on a large scale, could represent a significant weapon against the risk of global warming caused by manmade carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.
To stop carbon dioxide from reaching dangerous concentrations in the atmosphere may require people to shift away from fossil fuels, according to most of the experts advising the nations who have signed the international treaty to combat the problem. In the meantime, the world's forests represent an enormous reservoir for carbon dioxide, which is naturally removed from the air when trees and other photosynthetic organisms grow and multiply.
The role of trees in mitigating carbon dioxide emissions can be expanded further if they can be used as renewable fuels, offsetting the use of fossil fuels, if wood products substitute for energy-intensive products like steel, and if shade trees are planted in cities and neighborhoods, reducing the demand for air conditioning.
"The carbon problem is very huge," said Neil Sampson, a forestry consultant who has extensively studied the role of wood in fighting global warming. "It looks to us like trees and forestry can handle perhaps 30 percent of it. That is a significant role, if you don't expect it to be the only role."
Pilot studies suggest that it will cost just a few dollars per ton of carbon -- estimates range from less than $1 to more than $30, depending on the circumstances -- to increase the sequestration of carbon dioxide in trees by expanding the planet's total forested area.
That is considerably cheaper than the costs some economists have projected for controlling industrial emissions of carbon dioxide. And if the new protocol to the climate change treaty that was negotiated in Kyoto in December goes into force, and the United States sets up a market-based system for encouraging the least costly steps to reduce net emissions of carbon, growing trees could be one profitable path to the goal.
The prospect, though, has stirred up a powerful debate over how to measure the complex cycle in which trees take carbon from the atmosphere and slowly release it after they die, how to verify that reductions are actually achieved, and how to encourage foresters to capture the largest possible benefits.
Doubters say that allowing emissions in one place to be offset by trees grown somewhere else is unfair and unreliable. Even its advocates say that forestry can only handle a fraction of the greenhouse gas problem.
And adding to an already heated debate, some United States lawmakers who have not previously supported action on global warming, but who favor expanded logging on public lands, have been arguing that it makes the most environmental sense to cut down mature forests, which are no longer growing quickly, and replace them with vigorous saplings, which bulk up more quickly.
"Science has proven to us that carbon dioxide, the leading greenhouse gas, can be taken out of the atmosphere by properly managing our forests," said Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, the chairman of the House Resources Committee. "Carbon dioxide is kept out of the atmosphere by harvesting the forest before it begins to decompose or burn, thus storing the carbon in wood products that are environmentally friendly, as well as providing an economic benefit to society."
Other experts said that Mr. Young has oversimplified the situation. And indeed, the question of how best to use the world's forests to fight global warming has only begun to be addressed in detail.
At the Kyoto talks, where the world's industrial nations pledged to reduce net emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases by an average of 5 percent below 1990's levels over the next 10 to 15 years, they agreed to count additions and subtractions of carbon dioxide caused by "direct human-induced land use change and forestry activities, limited to afforestation," or turning land into forest, "reforestation, and deforestation since 1990."
But they left to a specialized committee the task of setting up accounting rules, and there is likely to be scientific and political debate before important questions are settled.
"If sequestration is done correctly, it can produce many benefits," said Michael Oppenheimer, a climate scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, an advocacy group based in New York. "It can enhance ecosystems and remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. But done poorly, it can make the greenhouse problem worse and do a lot of damage to the ecosystem."
Dan Becker, the head of climate programs at the Sierra Club, is more dismissive.
"In order to offset U.S. industrial emissions, you would need to plant a new forest on an area the size of Australia," he said. "You are taking carbon that is safely sequestered underground, as coal or oil, and bringing it up, and adding it to the atmosphere. And then you are temporarily storing it in a closet made of trees. I am all for preserving forests, and I am against cutting down forests. But is it a good thing to pollute more because you have done that? No."
Mr. Becker and other skeptics said that it would be almost impossible to verify the amount of carbon being set aside in forests, especially if the projects are widespread and if international conservation programs are used to offset domestic emissions in the United States, as is already being ventured.
But Steven P. Hamburg, who teaches environmental studies at Brown University and has been closely involved in the United Nations research into forestry's role in global warming, said that the difficulties of estimating the amount of sequestration are exaggerated.
"The bottom line is that we have been assessing the growth of forests for a century, and we have very well-established methods for doing it," he said. "We can measure with confidence the carbon in trees with an uncertainty of plus or minus 10 percent, without any difficulty." In carefully controlled studies of forests in Russia, he said, the standard formulas used by American scientists predicted actual carbon content of trees within an accuracy of 3 percent.
Perfecting the estimates is one objective of the small experiment in Louisiana. But other goals include figuring out what methods work best in turning abandoned bean fields back into bottom land hardwood wetlands. For the past few decades this type of wetland has been disappearing fast, but with changing farm policies there are opportunities to restore trees to vast areas of the Mississippi River Valley.
Like other forestry projects across the country and around the world, this plot of land, managed by scientists at the School of Forestry at Louisiana Tech in Ruston, is being paid for by companies that usually produce watts, not woods. Electric utilities, which voluntarily promised the Energy Department that they would reduce their emissions of carbon dioxide by 2000, are using tree projects as one way to meet that commitment.
Utilitree Carbon Company, a consortium of utilities, has projected that the $176,000 project in Louisiana will remove tens of thousands of tons of carbon dioxide from the air over the next several decades: just seven tons an acre per year, but hundreds of tons per acre by the end of the 70-year growing cycle.
There are other benefits to growing trees in wetlands.
The Louisiana tract is part of a 7,000-acre area trees can be grown next to a state wildlife refuge, and quite aside from its role in offsetting the emissions of greenhouse gases far away, putting it into trees will provide important wildlife habitat and other environmental benefits.
And there is a lot of similar land available for forestry projects. Over four million acres of bottom land hardwood forests were cleared in the Mississippi River Valley in the 1970's for agriculture, even though the land was poorly suited for that purpose.
Mr. Sampson, who edited a two-volume collection of research for American Forests, a conservation organization, has estimated that the forests offer ways to reduce net carbon emissions in the United States by 314 million tons to 695 million tons per year, or between 21 and 46 percent of estimated annual emissions of 1.5 billion tons. He bases his estimate on a diverse package of forestry-related programs: planting trees on marginal land, altering forest management practices to speed growth of existing timber, increasing the use of renewable wood fuel, and planting trees in cities and near houses, where they can reduce energy consumption for air conditioning.
In Congress, pro-logging lawmakers have suggested that the best way to maximize sequestration might be to cut down mature forests and replace them with fast-growing plantations of trees, keeping the carbon locked up in the wood for decades after it is harvested, in the form of homes, telephone poles, books and the like.
In October, the House passed a nonbinding resolution calling on the United States "to manage its forests to maximize the reduction of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, among many other objectives."
That wording was a compromise to mollify environmentalists and their supporters in the House. But the resolution was pressed by Mr. Young, Representative Helen Chenoweth, Republican of Idaho, chairwoman of the forestry subcommittee, and other pro-logging lawmakers.
They draw their argument from researchers like John Perez-Garcia, an associate professor of forestry at the University of Washington, who has argued that some forest conservation efforts have perversely added carbon dioxide to the atmosphere by depressing logging. That, he argues, leads to the use of steel and other substitute materials, while allowing forests to get overgrown to the point that they burn.
Indeed, there have been estimates that managing a Douglas fir forest in the Pacific Northwest as a monoculture plantation, and harvesting all the trees every 60 years, could sequester more carbon in the wood and in wood products while the tree farm's growth is at its peak than could be accomplished through other approaches. The alternatives studied included leaving the forest alone, or harvesting parts of the forest year to year while leaving its complex ecosystem more or less intact.
But this kind of calculation ignores important facts about the carbon cycle and the overall health of forests. For example, when a forest is clear-cut, the carbon in its soil begins to dissipate almost right away, a source of carbon dioxide emissions that lasts for decades. And the other benefits of a forest, such as watershed protection, rich habitat, and recreational use, are destroyed.
"In general, I don't think that is good management," said Dr. Hamburg of Brown. "I don't think you could come up with any data to suggest that you could intensively manage those forests and increase carbon sequestration."

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
The Vienna Mirrors Yet Reshapes The Past

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND

 BODY:
In three concerts with the Vienna Philharmonic last weekend, Riccardo Muti created original experiences from an old tradition. The only hint of current events was on Sunday, in Hindemith's E Flat Symphony from 1940. Mozart, Mahler, Brahms and Beethoven made up the rest.
Making the past seem new is not easy. We can resuscitate forgotten composers, but most forgotten composers have been forgotten for good reason. Almost every worthwhile example of the Classical-Romantic tradition has been explored, and what unsung masterpieces still exist remain mute mainly because their formats do not fit current concert life. (See Schubert's music for piano-four hands.) 
 Conducting programs on Friday, Saturday and Sunday at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Muti divided his energies equally, giving us relaxing amounts of what we already knew, then making us sit up at attention and feel real surprise. Given the Vienna Philharmonic, the familiar music took on a special aura. Mozart's warm, clarinet-driven E Flat Symphony (No. 39) on Friday was an exercise in hedonism: plushness without confusion, energy expressed with ease and confidence.
The Mahler Fourth on Saturday was a mirror for the orchestra playing it. It was certainly written with the Vienna Philharmonic's properties in mind, and there is little reason to believe that the orchestra sounds much different today than it did at the turn of the century. (Mahler was to adjust the orchestration for a decade more, presenting his final version in 1911 with the New York Philharmonic.)
Do we have to describe again the Vienna's qualities: a warmth and glow that seem to rise from the floorboards, the distinctive horns, the elegant separation of colors, the clarity between parts despite the suffusing blanket of sound? Mr. Muti handled the difficult transitions of tempo very well and knew when to let this orchestra go its own way. Were it not for Ruth Ziesak's virtually inaudible soprano solos in the finale, this would have been a Mahler Fourth for the ages.
The other comfort was the Brahms Second Symphony on Sunday afternoon; its familiar elements poured out seemingly in one unbroken, liquid wave. The surprises came even at Friday's all-Mozart affair. Framed by the early Divertimento in D and the E Flat Symphony, five ballet movements for the opera "Idomeneo" offered a color, character and format strikingly different from their surroundings. The overtures do bring a little of the theater to concert life but mainly as brief synopses, previews of coming attractions. The ballet music, on the other hand, is fully driven by what Mozart saw; gone is symphonic architecture as a model and constraint. It is not often that the concert Mozart and the stage Mozart are set so closely side by side. One almost felt the presence of two different composers.
Saturday's provocation came in the form of Beethoven's F Minor Quartet (Op. 95) bulked up by Mahler into a version for full string orchestra. Arrangements are benign distortions and come in two kinds. There are first the keyboard and chamber music reductions of grand symphonies, creating a kind of X-ray vision free of flesh and fat; then there are the inflations from smaller formats to full orchestral size.
Neither way offers truth, but both can instruct. The Vienna players worked admirably to sort out the four voices, but private arguments raised to parliamentary debate lose their original character; Beethoven would never have written an orchestra piece with this kind of contrapuntal texture. And if a mighty string quartet is really a small piece dreaming of becoming a big one, turning the implication of bigness into fact is dangerous business. Beware of getting what you wish for.
The Hindemith alternates between loud martial fanfare and sober, dignified reflection. Knowing its time of composition makes it easier to attach to the outer movements another adjective: warlike. There is a drunken waltz to brighten the third movement, that is if German humor is to your taste. But the Vienna strings played too beautifully. This is tough, relentlessly busy music, a harsh cityscape in the manner of Leger. Hindemith celebrates the work ethic, rejects the merely pleasurable.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Constance C. R. White

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy

 BODY:

American Designers Abroad
There are more American accents in the voices and clothes at the Italian women's shows here this week than in past seasons. Victor Alfaro and John Bartlett are scheduled to present their collections, dealing a blow to New York's show roster. 
 Mr. Bartlett, in a year-old deal with Genny, based in Ancona, Italy, has chosen Milan instead of New York because of the advantages in catching the retailers before their ordering dollars are depleted later in the season. Mr. Alfaro's defection is more of a surprise and comes courtesy of Gilmar, which had $200 million in sales last year and has led the trend for partnering with American designers, signing deals five years ago with Marc Jacobs and Anna Sui. The deal with Mr. Jacobs ended when he was hired away last year by Louis Vuitton.
The arrangement with Mr. Jacobs has since dissolved, and the Gerani family, which owns Gilmar, is rebuilding. It has formed a joint venture with Mr. Alfaro and has signed Inacio Ribeiro to consult on the Iceberg line. He designs Clements Ribeiro with Suzanne Clements, his wife. "We had always hoped to get the right consultancy," Mr. Ribeiro said. "Iceberg is a strong name, but it is not exploited."
The arrangement with Mr. Alfaro is a joint venture called Victor Alfaro L.L.C., with the designer owning 60 percent of the business and Gilmar the remainder. And Gilmar, in turn, is licensing the Alfaro name from Victor Alfaro L.L.C. The first collection is to be sold exclusively in New York, where Mr. Alfaro's vintage chic is a favorite of Mariah Carey and several young socialites.
Expansion abroad and into men's wear, cosmetics and a secondary collection are part of Paolo Gerani's dream for the label. "Since 1993 when we signed Marc and Anna, I've been interested in American designers," said Mr. Gerani, a vice president and the creative director of Gilmar. "But with Marc, thanks to Vuitton, we couldn't keep going."
 
Additional Shows
About the last thing that journalists and retailers attending the presentations here need is more shows on their schedule. But that is what they have in Milan, where there are 16 additional shows this season, which is something like the National Basketball Association adding 16 teams to its roster all of a sudden.
At least half of these designers could take a note from a book by the British designer Mark Whittaker. Last week, during the London collections, instead of receiving an invitation to his show, insiders got a video showing his clothes and a note urging them to make use of the accompanying eye pack, lip balm and massage oil while watching the video and avoiding another runway show.
At least one reason for the explosion of shows can be traced to the number of foreigners who showed successfully in Italy during the fall men's season in January, said Beppe Modenese, a vice president of Camera Nazionale della Moda Italiana, the organizing body for the Milan shows. But most of the new names are Italian and not well known. Even with the Asian economic crisis, they are seeking global expansion more aggressively. "A lot of them are young people," Mr. Modenese said. "I'm surprised it's happening so fast, but it's not unexpected."
Massimo Rebecchi staged his first show in Milan on Sunday, a response, he said, to interest from Asia and in anticipation of his opening a store in New York soon. His sleek, refined sportswear does well in Asia, and his company, which is 10 years old, has 12 stores in Italy, including in Milan. "We're professionally ready to do this for expansion," he said.
One thing that has not changed in Italy is the jousting over which of the Milanese fashion titans will close the season. While designers like Mr. Rebecchi contented themselves with any slot, final word on the schedule was held up as the Versace and Armani camps debated over who would show last, Mr. Modenese said. The result: Versace will show on Friday and Armani on Saturday. The clothes will look the same as they would if the order were reversed.

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD;
Finding Cultural Roots in the Rhythms of Carnival

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

DATELINE: FORT-DE-FRANCE, Martinique, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Martinique is celebrating the 150th anniversary of the abolition of slavery, and the subject, quietly, pervasively rippled through the four days of carnival this week. It was everywhere, in the women's gold necklaces that symbolized the chains of bondage to the rhythm of the drum choirs that rustle in the distance like a soft wind, then sweep through the streets furiously.
The reaction to slavery manifested itself in the burlesque that informs the Martinican carnival, the endless streams of the largest potbellied men ever to wear blond wigs and women's underwear, and on the minds of the island's intellectuals. It was in the transgressional rebellion of the carnival songs that puncture this normally restrained society with extraordinarily graphic and joyously vulgar lyrics. 
 Martinican society -- the West Indian island is a department of France -- enjoys a largely middle-class existence, and 30 percent unemployment hardly dents the island's standard of living and spirit of fun. Carnival, the four-day frenzy of partying and music that ends with Lent, starts early, and ends late, on Ash Wednesday, a day after everybody else's.
And in Martinique, the music of carnival, which is everywhere, gives a good representation of how the culture functions, with its tensions between Europe and Africa, the past and the future.
At a pre-carnival party at the Marouba Hotel on the beach a little north of the island's capital, Fort-de-France, the band of the moment, Taxikreol, is making the dance floor churn.
The hit of carnival this year was "En la Casa de Tu Mama," a song in Spanish and Creole that suggests that the singer had fun with the mother, and maybe the daughter too. The band breaks into parodies of French pop songs, with, for example, the woman in the band, Danielle Rene-Corail, singing about unrequited love to a gay man. Around 3 A.M., the Plastic System band comes charging into the audience, with its 20 or so drummers and a pile of horns, its rocking, percussive music driving the audience wild.
The music is somewhere between the carnival rave-ups of New Orleans, Rio de Janeiro and Cuba. The marching-band tradition dates back only to the late 1970's, when there was a struggle to define Martinican culture anew. The effort was completely self-conscious.
Like so many Creole societies, Martinique's people are constantly reassessing their antecedents, African and European, which creates a relationship fraught with pressure because France still runs the place. For example, a decision was made to rid the streets of floats that were based on the carnival traditions of Nice, the seaside resort in France, and to find a Martinican alternative.
"People on the left were looking to end the policy of assimilation supported by the right," said the sociologist Serge Domi, who is also the head of the department of culture of Le Lamentin, a nearby town.
The alternative came in the form of marching bands. The musicians studied Brazilian samba schools, and the Cuban comparsas, and put together an inventory of portable percussion. Carnival today has some 40 bands; 20 years ago there were 3. Twenty years ago, the stigma against drumming was powerful enough to have made it an oddity.
Things have changed, if just a bit.
"Carnival brings out the Creole in us," said Patrick Chamoiseau, the Martinican author of the novel "Texaco" and a leader of the Creolite movement among Martinican intellectuals. "For four days we become more African; it restores us to being the sum of all our parts. We become Martinican."
"The rest of the year," he said, "our Creoleness is crushed."
Mr. Domi, the sociologist, explained it this way: "Anytime a dominant culture holds power, the dominated take their vengeance. In the period of slavery, black people waited all year to show what they felt. That's the power in today's carnival. Resentment exists, and there's a sense here that things are not well, even if people have everything they want. What we don't have is a feeling of a collective future."
That could be because Martinique is profoundly international; the French identity jostles with the Caribbean and the Creole. Cable television brings in a Spanish-language music channel, a French Antilles music channel, pop videos from around the world. Martinican radio mixes Cuban salsa with Haitian music, along with reggae and hip-hop.
"Especially in music, we're an international culture," said Mr. Chamoiseau. "But there's so much pressure to accept the monoculture of France and the United States that music sometimes seems like the only holdout against the worst of internationalism. We're a divided culture. It's hard to get people to appreciate themselves here. People are ashamed of their past as slaves."
Eric Andrieux, the director of Declic Records, which records some of the best Martinican and Guadeloupean bands, said: "We have something individual here, and we have to figure out how to make the traditional music modern, without losing its quality."
At the post-carnival parties that make the surrounding hills ring, the younger generation goes to dance, partying instead of worrying about issues of a Creole identity. One party charges admission and takes credit cards. Disk jockeys played their specialties, one working with soca, calypso and reggae, another with carnival music, a third with salsa.
And the rich variety of music isn't just on the airwaves or coming from disk jockeys' sound systems. Cuban bands play the hotel circuit, and virtually every major hotel has some sort of dance. Music is everywhere. On Sunday, at the La Fontane restaurant, a group of older musicians, Les Compagnons de la Chanson, played courtly beguines, waltzes and mazurkas to an house full of couples in their 60's and 70's, light-skinned Creoles reliving the days when they too danced all night to the island's indigenous music.
While younger generations are dancing in the streets and at parties to the sound of the drum, the older, more refined tradition is quietly vanishing.
"It's tragic that this older culture is losing its popularity," said Jacques Bajal, who works in the Martinican tourist bureau and plays in a traditional drum group. The men and the women dance carefully controlled steps to light music led by a clarinet. The dance is deeply elegant, and the women, wearing Creole gold jewelry and madras headdresses, float across the floor in a beautiful last gasp of a fading culture.
By the end of carnival, after the ritual burning of the carnival god, Valval, on the beach in Fort-de-France, two bands were still playing to the faithful on the outskirts of Le Lamentin. To the music of Matjilpa, a marching band, young women were dancing competitively, challenging each other, or soloed as the roaring waves of drums powered them. The women danced together, and out in the fields, with a warm, moist night to bid it goodbye, carnival slipped slowly away.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bands and dancing are part of the revelry during carnival in Martinique. (Marcelo J. Duek for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Index Shows A Faster Pace For Growth At U.S. Plants

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The manufacturing sector of the economy grew at a faster clip than expected last month without suggesting rekindled inflation, a monthly survey showed, as production and new orders increased.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its index of business activity, compiled from interviews with corporate purchasing executives nationwide, rose to 53.3 in February from 52.4 in January. 
The increase reversed three consecutive months of declining growth and was a surprise to economists, who had expected the figure to be unchanged from its January level. Prices paid by manufacturers fell in February, but at a slower pace than in previous months, the report said.
The data were consistent with the trend of steady growth with tame inflation -- the combination behind Wall Street's continuing success. The stock market displayed little reaction to the report, but in the bond market, the yield on the long bond rose to 6 percent.
The purchasing report is widely followed by economists because it is usually the first indicator of how the economy fared in the previous month. Any reading over 50 is a sign that manufacturing is growing.
"The manufacturing part of the economy is humming," said Raymond Worseck, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. "Across the board, it's good news."
The gap between exports and imports shrank last month, the report said. Import growth slowed, but the decline in exports also slowed.
The results suggest that Asia's economic troubles will hurt American exports but not devastate them, said Robert Brusca, chief economist at the Nikko Securities International Company. "There is a negative Pacific Rim impact," he said.
Purchasing executives are optimistic about future growth in manufacturing, but their outlook is tempered somewhat by Asia's problems, the study said.
Separately, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that Americans' personal income increased a strong six-tenths of a percent in January, bolstered by cost-of-living increases for Social Security recipients and raises for Federal employees.
Without those and other special factors, incomes would have increased a still-healthy five-tenths of a percent. Incomes had increased four-tenths of a percent in December and seven-tenths of a percent in November.
Consumer spending, meanwhile, rose a moderate four-tenths of a percent in January, the same as in December and November.
President Clinton, in a speech to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, hailed the income increase as "fresh new evidence the economy continues to grow."
"Since 1993, family incomes are up about $2,200," he said.
In a separate report, the department said construction spending rose seven-tenths of a percent in January, the second consecutive increase and the largest in three months. Increases in housing and commercial construction more than offset a drop in government projects.
Most categories of income increased in January, including the most important -- wages and salaries, up seven-tenths of a percent. Also higher were transfer payments, such as Social Security and welfare, and business owners' income and interest and dividend income.
After adjustments for taxes, disposable, or after-tax, incomes jumped eight-tenths of a percent, the largest increase in 19 months, and the savings rate rose to 4.2 percent of disposable income, the most in seven months and up from 3.9 percent in December.
Construction spending was led by 1 percent gains for both residential and commercial construction. Gains were recorded for single-family homes, apartments, industrial buildings, offices, hotels and motels and stores and malls.

HEADLINE: Corning to Sell Most of Its Cookware Unit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Corning Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell most of its Corning cookware business to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the New York investment firm, for $583 million.
The accord comes after an agreement to sell the business to AEA Investors Inc. for $825 million fell through. Kohlberg Kravis will pay $583 million in cash and assume $10 million of Corning debt, for which it will get 92 percent of the unit, which makes Corning Ware, Revere Ware and Pyrex cookware. It may pay as much as $15 million more depending on how profitable the business is. 
 The sale allows Corning to focus on its optical fiber, related telecommunications equipment and other technology businesses, while it gives Kohlberg Kravis some of the best-known brands in cookware at a price that analysts called a bargain.
"The price is really more in line with what people originally expected," compared with the possible earlier deal, said Lissa Bogaty, an analyst at Prudential Securities who rates Corning a "buy."
Corning will retain an 8 percent equity interest in the cookware business, which will be managed by Borden Inc., which Kohlberg Kravis also owns.
Corning said the sale would result in a "modest" after-tax gain when the transaction closed, which is expected within 30 days.
While Corning's brand names are widely known and the unit's earnings have improved, largely because of moves to make the manufacturing more efficient, Corning lags behind its competitors in profitability.
Corning's operating profit, as a percentage of sales, is about 8 percent, compared with 18 percent at the Newell Company, one of the nation's largest consumer goods companies.
AEA Investors, an investment fund founded by some of the wealthiest families in the United States, dropped its offer to buy the division early in December because of concerns that economic turmoil in Asia would hurt the unit's sales next year.

HEADLINE: Shrewd Politics, Sound Policy

BYLINE: By Alan S. Blinder; Alan S. Blinder, an economics professor at Princeton, was vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
Since President Clinton introduced his budget for the 1999 fiscal year, there has been much praise for -- and some grumbling about -- the political acuity of his pledge to "reserve" the looming budget surpluses until Social Security has been reformed. Yes, it looks like shrewd politics. But the more important question is, Is it also sound policy? I believe it is. Here's why.
Our nation faces three distinct problems, all related to Social Security. First, the Social Security program is not actuarially sound in the long run. As the baby boomers start to retire, the current Social Security surpluses will dwindle, then disappear, then turn into sizable deficits. 
 But so what? Skeptics will point out, correctly, that the Social Security trust fund is not a trust fund in the usual sense. Money is not being stashed away for the future. Rather, the fund is a mere bookkeeping device -- and bookkeeping can be changed.
With appropriate adjustments in the law, Social Security's books could be balanced with a stroke of the pen. For example, we could simply assign some income tax revenue to the trust fund. Current proposals to invest Social Security money in the stock market would have a similar effect, by infusing revenue into the system. That, however, would come at the expense of the rest of the budget, since the Treasury, deprived of its best customer -- the trust funds -- would have to sell more bonds to the public, and thus pay more in interest.
The second problem is more fundamental: our aging population will create great demands on the Federal Government as more benefits are paid out to retirees and more people go on the Medicare rolls. Whatever budget position we take into the year 2010 -- when the baby boomers begin to retire -- the budget will inexorably move toward deficit thereafter. A farsighted Government would start preparing for that rainy day now.
But even the overall budget surplus or deficit is not the heart of the matter. If Americans were squirreling away enough savings for retirement, economists would not be greatly concerned about the fiscal balance. After all, what the Government does is a minor part of the overall saving and investment equation. To prepare for our grayer future, what the United States really needs is more investment, which builds capital, which in turn generates the earnings required to pay our public and private bills. In short, the third and deepest problem is that America is not saving enough.
Far from being a mere political ploy, the President's plan -- though admittedly vague and certainly short of a full solution -- would ease all three problems. Let's work backward.
Running Federal budget surpluses rather than spending them clearly boosts national saving by adding new Government saving (the annual surpluses) to our paltry private saving. This is precisely the argument economists used for years in urging the Government to reduce the deficit.
Second, the President's proposal would probably put the Federal Government in a better overall fiscal position in 2010. Maintaining modest annual surpluses, instead of spending the money or giving it away as tax cuts, would leave us with a cushion and a smaller national debt when things start to deteriorate.
I do not mean to rule out worthwhile Government expenditures, especially on programs that provide for the future. But each should be weighed against the virtues of having a surplus when the boomers start retiring. Both the deficit and the debt will surely balloon after, say, 2015. Temporary moderation is prudent preparation for our more profligate future.
Finally, let's go back to those so-called accounting fictions, the trust funds for Social Security and Medicare. Economists may call them fictions, but they are facts -- because they have standing in law. Social Security benefits may be paid from only two sources: current payroll tax receipts and the accumulated balance in the trust fund. If the fund runs dry and receipts no longer cover promised benefits, taxes must be raised or benefits trimmed. And changing the rules governing Social Security is politically delicate, to say the least.
The President has called for a yearlong dialogue on the Social Security issue. I cannot predict how that debate will turn out, except for this: It seems almost inevitable that any comprehensive repair will involve both infusing revenue into the system and paring the benefit structure somewhat.
If there is any revenue component at all, the nation will look back on Mr. Clinton's proposal to "reserve" the surplus and think, "That sure was smart."

HEADLINE: Hate Groups in U.S. Are Growing, Report Says

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 2

 BODY:
With a boost from the Internet, white power rock-and-roll music and even the approach of the millennium, the number of organized hate groups in the United States has continued to increase, a research group has concluded in a new report. The increase comes despite a robust economy, which experts contend typically discourages the proliferation of such organizations.
The report, to be issued on Tuesday by the Intelligence Project of the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Ala., says 474 hate groups and their chapters were involved in racist behavior last year. 
 The law center, which tracks and monitors hate groups and paramilitary groups, used a new method this year in its annual count of hate groups. That makes it impossible to compare last year's number with the tally from previous years. But if the center's old methodology had been used, the number of hate groups in 1997 would have represented a 20 percent increase from the year before, according to a new edition of the group's quarterly Intelligence Report.
The increase comes mostly from growth in the number of chapters of pre-existing groups like the Ku Klux Klan and in the number of churches belonging to the Christian Identity movement, which cites biblical foundations for white supremacy and anti-Semitism.
On one level, the findings are surprising because sociologists and experts on hate groups typically argue that such groups are nourished by economic hardship.
"It really is remarkable growth for a year in which the economy is steaming right along," said Mark Potok, the editor of the report.
But Mr. Potok said the proliferation of hate-group Internet sites and of racist rock music seemed to be fueling the increase. Those developments are particularly alarming, he said, because they provide new ways to recruit young people.
"The hate movement in the United States has done very poorly in recruiting young people, by and large, and it may be turning the corner," Mr. Potok said.
Less than three years after a Klan member named Don Black created the first neo-Nazi site on the World Wide Web, there are now 163 Web sites advocating racial hatred, according to the report. Mr. Potok also estimated that hate-oriented music labels each year were selling 50,000 copies of recordings by groups like No Remorse and Bound for Glory that use incendiary lyrics to advocate violence against minorities.
A third factor, Mr. Potok said, is the approach of the millennium.
"Many of these groups really do see the year 2000, if not literally as Armageddon, then as the coming of the end times, and they feel that they must go to war," he said.
In 1996, 8,759 bias-motivated crimes were reported to the Federal Bureau of Investigation by state and local law-enforcement agencies, compared with 7,947 in 1995. But because many police departments are just starting to quantify hate crimes as a distinct category, the F.B.I. cannot determine whether the increase is real or a matter of improved reporting, said Debbie J. Weierman, a spokeswoman for the agency.
James Cavanaugh, the special agent in charge of the Birmingham, Ala., office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, which is investigating the Jan. 29 bombing of an abortion clinic in that city, said he also thought that the splintering of organizations was responsible for some of the increase in hate groups. But he agreed that the Internet was also generating new interest.
"Just as it has helped Wall Street and the media industry, it has also helped hate groups," Mr. Cavanaugh said. "Before they were more isolated. Now it's easier for them to see like-minded bigots. The country has shrunk."
