HEADLINE: Sticking to the Formula;
DuPont Insists Mundane and Exotic Products Mix Well

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
Charles O. Holliday Jr. knows that a lot of investors think he should break up DuPont, the $45 billion chemical industry giant where he was put in charge this year. He knows they think that mundane products like polyester and petroleum are a distraction from hot items like genetically altered corn or fancy new drugs.
He knows -- he just does not agree. When Chad Holliday talks to DuPont's divisional people, he does not hear a cacophony. He hears an orchestra tuning up, one that once it gets its research, marketing and production instruments to augment their solos with ensemble play, will sound just fine. 
 "I am absolutely convinced that all our technologies are better off working with each other," Mr. Holliday said.
But can he convince investors that he is right? That E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, based here, is better off pushing products ranging from oil to pesticides to bulletproof vests, instead of homing in on drugs, enhanced crops and other nutrition and health-oriented life sciences businesses?
Competitors do not seem to think so. "Chemicals and life sciences are entirely separate businesses, requiring different management and attracting different investors," said A. Nicholas Filippello, a vice president of the Monsanto Company, which spun off its chemical operations in September.
So far, DuPont's investors are hanging in -- the company's stock trades at a respectable 16 times estimated 1998 earnings. It closed Monday at $62.5625, up $1.25. That's enough to satisfy most members of the DuPont family, who hold about 15 percent of the stock. "I like being in a spectrum of promising businesses," Edward B. DuPont, a director, said. "And most of my assets are in this company."
But nonfamily investors are getting restless. They have seen the stocks of rival chemical companies soar when they shed older products -- Monsanto's shares trade at more than 40 times the 1998 earnings that analysts project -- and they want some of the same action.
Specifically, they want DuPont to sell Conoco, the oil company it bought in 1981; to spin off the chemical operations to shareholders, and to concentrate on life sciences.
"There aren't any advantages to being so complicated," said Roger E. Ford, managing director at Prudential Investments, which sold all its DuPont stock last summer. "DuPont should be three companies: life sciences, chemicals and oil."
This is a dangerous time for DuPont to trust in the status quo. Mr. Holliday, a 28-year DuPont employee who became chief executive in January, has promised that earnings will grow at least 10 percent a year through 2003. But the rich prices DuPont paid for several agricultural and basic chemical acquisitions in 1997 will dilute earnings for at least a year. The strong dollar, Asia's weak economy and dropping oil prices all mitigate against a terrific 1998.
"Meeting that 10 percent goal, without life sciences being a bigger part of the mix, is going to be a real challenge," said James F. Stanley, a portfolio manager at the Delaware Management Company.
DuPont is certainly not ignoring life sciences. Last year it spent more than $3 billion to buy Ralston Purina's Protein Technologies International, a soya products company, and 20 percent of Pioneer Hi-Bred International, a seed corn company. It is building a new biotechnology research center in Wilmington now.
Mr. Holliday has told investors that he wants life sciences to contribute at least 30 percent of earnings soon, up from about 18 percent now. Some of the life sciences executives are even more gung-ho. "We see plant genetics as tomorrow's Silicon Valley," said William F. Kirk, senior vice president of DuPont Agricultural Enterprise, a newly created division that expects about $3.5 billion in sales this year.
But what rankles some outside investors is that DuPont is spending just as heavily on businesses that they want it to shed. The company spent more than $3 billion to buy Imperial Chemical Industries' industrial whiteners and polyester film operations. About half of its $1.1 billion research budget is devoted to chemicals. And it bought vast oil reserves in Texas and Venezuela to beef up Conoco -- a move that even fans of its chemical conglomerate structure cannot abide.
"DuPont has enough money to fund its global chemical business along with life sciences," said Leslie C. Ravitz, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. "But I don't understand why they are holding onto Conoco."
Mr. Holliday insists that the question is not one of "either-or," but one of "and."
"If we'd seen another $6 billion of life sciences acquisitions, we would have made them," he said. "But we aren't missing any opportunities by investing in chemicals or Conoco."
In fact, he is out to prove that he is gaining a lot. Mr. Holliday is plumbing every DuPont business and function, seeking ways they can piggyback on one another's efforts.
Life sciences researchers are trying to "grow" chemicals -- say, by incorporating genes from spiders into a plant that could make a fiber with the strength of a spider's web, or substituting fermented plant glucose for petroleum-based chemicals. Chemists, meanwhile, are classifying chemicals for possible use in pharmaceuticals and pesticides.
"Why not use molecular biology and genetics to make plastics and fibers?" asked Joseph A. Miller Jr., DuPont's chief technology officer.
DuPont's product chiefs are collaborating more these days, too. The group that makes Lycra -- DuPont's brand name for spandex -- has found a way, for example, to use it in women's dress shoes. Now they are working with the Kevlar group to see if Kevlar, known best for bulletproof fabrics, would work for shoe heels. "We're looking for economy of scope, not just economy of scale," said Steven R. McCracken, vice president of DuPont Lycra.
In a sense, it is easy to understand Mr. Holliday's continued affection for chemicals and oil. Both businesses earn more than the cost of capital. Joint ventures with Asahi, Dow Chemical and others have given DuPont relatively inexpensive access to new markets and technologies. The Imperial Chemical businesses, meanwhile, have given DuPont a formidable presence in Europe.
"Chad said loud and clear, 'See how you can grow this business,' " said Ellen J. Kullman, the vice president responsible for industrial whiteners. "He did not say, 'Turn your business into a cash cow.' "
Ms. Kullman and other executives in basic chemicals have been wringing costs from or adding attributes to products widely viewed as generics. DuPont has squeezed 40 percent out of the cost of polyester resins for bottles. It has a catalyst in the works that can give inexpensive chemicals like polyethylene, used to make plastic wrap and other basic goods, some of the strength and flexibility of chemicals that sell for much more. It has fine-tuned its Dacron fibers so that they make more pliable pillows and more flexible clothing.
Such tinkering does not pack the punch of earlier DuPont innovations like Teflon, Dacron and nylon. But it can add years of life to aging products. "We may not have home runs anymore," William Ghitis, Dacron's managing director, said, "but we sure can score singles."
Score them, yes -- but selling them is another matter. Just ask Kurt M. Landgraf, Mr. Holliday's second in command. At Mr. Holliday's behest, Mr. Landgraf recently assessed DuPont's marketing practices; he was horrified at the vacuum that pervaded not just industrial chemicals, but consumer brands.
DuPont's fluoroproducts division, which makes nonstick coatings like Teflon and Silverstone, had a finance man running marketing because "it was a good development tool for him," Mr. Landgraf recalled, his voice still registering disbelief. "When it comes to marketing, DuPont has missed the boat big time."
Now, the businesses are swimming fast to catch up. Mr. Landgraf is showing them how to market directly to end users -- to farmers, say, for pesticides; to athletes for Lycra-based clothing -- with the idea that if consumers request DuPont brands, dealers will stock them. And he is trying to persuade the businesses to stress service.
"Offer just-in-time delivery or global support or input into new product research, and you could set a piece of wood apart from the pack," Mr. Landgraf insisted.
That kind of thinking is a sea change for DuPont, which has never put much marketing muscle behind industrial products. But then, Mr. Landgraf and Mr. Holliday represent a sea change themselves.
Mr. Landgraf, 51, is the former chief executive of DuPont Merck, and is the first DuPonter to rise to the No. 2 spot through the pharmaceutical and marketing ranks. Mr. Holliday, at 49, is the company's youngest leader in 50 years. An industrial engineer who spent many years running various DuPont fibers businesses, he is the first chief to have done a stint in Asia.
He faces different problems from his predecessors. Edgar S. Woolard Jr., DuPont's chief executive from 1989 through 1995, spent much of his tenure cutting bloated costs and increasing sluggish productivity. He also arranged the company's 82 product lines into 16 profit centers, each responsible for its own technology, marketing and bottom line.
John A. Krol, who took over in 1995, reshaped the product portfolio. He shed ancillary businesses like printing and medical products, and he negotiated last year's acquisitions. Thus, when Mr. Krol, who is 61, opted for early retirement -- a decision that the board insists, and analysts believe, was his own -- Mr. Holliday inherited a company with solid earnings and cash flow, manageable debt and low costs. Mr. Holliday has promised to cut costs even more, but most DuPont watchers expect him to focus on proving that the company can move as nimbly as specialized competitors.
"He's not just reducing costs, he's eliminating structural empires and bureaucracy," said J. Jeffrey Cianci, an analyst with Bear, Stearns.
Now Mr. Holliday must give DuPont's business units the skills to handle autonomy. Mr. Landgraf's marketing push is part of that. So is an in-house financial college that Gary M. Pfeiffer, the chief financial officer, has spearheaded to teach the businesses how to manage cash.
"I want the businesses to have their own lawyers, their own finance people, everything that will speed up their decisions," Mr. Holliday said. "I want to see charts tracking customer satisfaction in every office."
Sounds nice -- but investors would prefer charts of a soaring stock price. Thus, DuPont's biggest marketing job may yet be convincing investors that its life sciences baby needs its older chemical siblings.
"We're like this school of little fish," Mr. Pfeiffer said. "If they swim together, they can cast an enormous shark-like shadow."

They cite the examples of some of its competitors and other big companies, like AT&T, that have done so recently. But management says that the company's different operations benefit from being together. HEADLINE: Rumors of Gingrich in Presidential Race Lead to Jostling Over a Successor

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
For months the rumor ricocheted from office to office on Capitol Hill, but it never quite sank in. The buzz was that Representative Newt Gingrich, the first Republican Speaker of the House in 40 years, would step down early to run for President.
Mr. Gingrich, whose approval ratings are slowly inching up, says officially that he still plans on being the Speaker through Jan. 3, 2003, when he is obliged to step down under term limits adopted in 1995. 
 But even though guessing Mr. Gingrich's course remains speculation, in the frenzied world of House Republicans it has led to real elbowing and jostling.
For a few days last week, Representative Bill Paxon, the Buffalo Republican who was once a favorite of the leadership until he joined in a coup against it last summer, gripped his hat brim, ready to throw it into the ring. Then he reversed himself and announced that he would leave Congress altogether.
That decision might have had something to do with the emergence of another front-running contender for the job: Robert L. Livingston, the popular Louisiana Congressman who heads the powerful Appropriations Committee.
Several other committee chairmen are also likely to consider a run for Speaker, sensing a wide-open field if Mr. Gingrich voluntarily leaves, observers say.
There is at least one person who does not see any need for a competition. He is Representative Dick Armey of Texas, who as the majority leader ranks second to Mr. Gingrich of Georgia in the Republican hierarchy. Majority leaders, after all, have traditionally had a claim to the Speaker's chair, at least when House Democrats wrote the script.
But there is no clamor for Mr. Armey, and the scuffling of last week was a plain indication, many members agreed, that Mr. Armey, the folksy, conservative Texas ideologue, was not ready for the job.
"There is widespread concern with the question, 'Is Dick promotable?' " said Representative Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican who is among Mr. Armey's most fervent critics, recounting the round of discussions in the past two weeks. "If he wants to get promoted, he needs to honestly assess where he is with members."
The turn of events last week also signaled that Republicans would not necessarily subscribe to the Democratic tradition of succession.
"The question of who is going to lead this party, post-Newt Gingrich, is a wide open question," said W. J. (Billy) Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who was once a Democrat. "Nobody better assume they have some clear track in that position because of where they sit or have sat. This party is not bound by the old rules of the majority. I don't think the lines of succession are going to mean as much."
The events leading up to Mr. Paxon's decision to retire from Congress have served as a communal wake-up call for House members; many of them had been lulled into thinking that Mr. Gingrich, whose in-house popularity has shot up since a record low last summer, would wield the gavel for another four years.
Then, in recent weeks, the talk about Mr. Gingrich's Presidential ambition became intense. Last week, Mr. Paxon, citing conversations with Mr. Gingrich's advisers, called it an "absolute certainty" that the Speaker would run for President. And two weeks ago, Mr. Livingston, who was contemplating retirement, changed his mind after a private conversation with Mr. Gingrich. Then, all of a sudden, he said that he would be interested in running for Speaker if the position came open in 2000.
"I can only tell you when a rumor reaches this level you take it seriously," Mr. Tauzin said. "It's the reason all of this got started. There would not have been all this turmoil but for the strong belief that Newt might run for President."
No one appeared more alarmed by the turn of events than Mr. Armey, who had seen his standing among some colleagues sink in the past year as Mr. Gingrich's had risen.
The idea of a Paxon challenge made Mr. Armey plainly nervous, members say. Two weeks ago, he began canvassing members for votes. It also unnerved Mr. Gingrich, who swiftly backed Mr. Armey and made it known that he wanted no division in the Republican ranks, especially in an election year.
By midweek, when Mr. Paxon announced that he planned to retire, it seemed evident that Mr. Armey would have weathered the race. But the short-lived challenge, as well the mutterings about Mr. Livingston's qualifications for Speaker, disquieted Mr. Armey and prompted deeper soul-searching.
"The leader came away from this that much stronger than he was before," said Representative Jim Nussle, the Iowa Republican who was enlisted by Mr. Armey to count votes. "And in this instance, he learned from it. He learned and will make changes."
For Mr. Armey, the tide began to shift last summer.
A staunch flat-tax advocate, abortion opponent and free-market cheerleader, Mr. Armey had become a role model of sorts for the conservatives in the 74-member class elected in 1994. They were so confident in his fealty to the cause, and dubious of Mr. Gingrich's, they requested that Mr. Armey be the one to safeguard their interests in the balanced budget negotiations with the White House.
Then, last July, a small group of rebel conservatives, disillusioned with Mr. Gingrich's hands-off style and willingness to compromise, began talking about ousting the Speaker. Mr. Armey, the rebels say, attended those conversations with several other leaders.
Mr. Armey has said he took no part in the scheme. But several conservatives maintain that Mr. Armey's decision to tell Mr. Gingrich of the plot, and then distance himself from it, severely hurt his credibility and lost him an important chunk of his most dependable supporters.
But some say Mr. Armey's problems run deeper than concern over the attempted coup last July. Keen on anecdotes about his fishing trips and his passion for conservative causes, Mr. Armey, a former economics professor, has faced a wave of criticism in the past year. Members say he is often politically clumsy, coming across as unpolished, a man too enamored of his cowboy boots. He lacks star power, they say.
Some members simply want Mr. Armey to behave more like a leader. Many say he is ill-suited to the world of glad-handing and sound bites, and unenthusiastic about the one-on-one chats that he must hold with the rank-and-file.
"He is not nearly as articulate as Gingrich and he does not come across as effectively as Gingrich on television," said Representative Howard Coble, Republican of North Carolina, who has been a member of the House since 1985. "If you can give that 30-second sound bite effectively, you are ahead of the game."
Listening, they say, has not been Mr. Armey's strong suit.
Clearly, it is something he recognizes. Last month when Republicans went on a retreat, members were asked to state the one thing they had learned in the past year. Mr. Armey stood up and said the importance of two-way communication.
But members also acknowledge that playing No. 2 to Mr. Gingrich is an unglamorous job, one which Mr. Armey performs capably and quietly. One Republican consultant wondered whether Mr. Gingrich does not in fact relish Mr. Armey's role as the perfect foil.
"Armey is to Newt what Dan Quayle was to George Bush," one Republican strategist said. "He's a loyal soldier, and if he's a bit of a bumbler, that's even better."

HEADLINE: Clinton Attacks G.O.P. Tax Overhaul Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
President Clinton took aim today at a Republican proposal to abolish the current Federal tax code by the end of 2001, calling it an irresponsible gimmick that could endanger the nation's prosperity.
Setting up a political clash over a fast-developing issue that the Republican leadership in Congress has put high on its agenda this year, Mr. Clinton said the proposal would create so much uncertainty for businesses and individuals that the economy could come grinding to a halt. 
 The proposal, which Congress could vote on within the next few months, would require that the current tax law be scrapped by Dec. 31, 2001, allowing three years for a national debate on what kind of new system to adopt. The proposal would not specify what should take its place but calls for Congress to decide on a new tax code by the middle of 2001.
The Senate version of the bill has 25 Republicans sponsors and is supported by Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader. The House version has 137 sponsors and the support of Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia. White House officials said they took seriously the possibility that the legislation could pass this year, though its chances of overcoming Democratic opposition in the Senate appear slim.
But in a speech today Mr. Clinton all but promised to veto the measure if it ever reached his desk.
"Under the guise of reform, they have proposed what, to me, is an irresponsible scheme to eliminate our tax laws without any system to replace them," Mr. Clinton said.
Without knowing what the tax code would be, Mr. Clinton said, companies would be unable to make investment decisions and families would face considerable uncertainty in planning for buying homes, saving for college and retirement and other economic decisions. In the vacuum, he said, growth could stall, and job creation and the nation's newfound fiscal stability could be put at risk.
"Scrapping the home mortgage deduction, scrapping the other middle-class tax cuts without presenting a clear alternative is simply reckless for the economy, reckless for businesses, reckless for families' budgets," Mr. Clinton said. "And I will not permit it, if I can stop it, but it shouldn't pass in the first place."
Clearly concerned about being portrayed by Republicans as a defender of the current tax system, with all its complexities and abuses, Mr. Clinton repeatedly said he was not opposed to an overhaul of the tax code.
But he left no doubt that neither of the leading Republican ideas -- a single-rate flat tax and a national sales tax -- would meet his requirement that the tax burden not be shifted from the wealthy onto middle- and low-income people. And while he said the Administration would continue to look for ways to simplify the income tax system and make it more fair, he offered no sweeping overhaul proposals of his own.
Senator Tim Hutchinson, the Arkansas Republican who is a sponsor of the Senate bill, said, "I will leave it to the President to defend today's cumbersome tax code, but I will continue to call for a fairer, simpler tax system that benefits taxpayers of all income levels."
"I trust the American people will be able to decide which is more 'irresponsible' -- our current incomprehensible tax code or a better system rebuilt from the ground up," Mr. Hutchinson said.
While many Republicans believe that creating a new tax code is both good economic policy and good politics, they have been unable to agree among themselves on which of the main alternatives to support.
Many Democrats are happy to see the topic become an issue in this year's midterm elections, believing that any new tax system will become difficult for Republicans to defend, once they have to address such specific changes as the elimination of the deductions for home mortgage interest and charitable contributions, as most versions of the flat tax and the national sales tax would require.
Republicans who support setting a drop-dead date for the current system believe that is the best way to force a decision on an issue that will put members of Congress in the line of fire from nearly every special interest group.
"If we don't create a deadline, it will be much harder to make tax reform happen," Mr. Lott said. "Clearly, this President needs to be forced to consider fundamental tax reform, just like he needed to be forced to fix the I.R.S."
As part of a strategy to make taxes a central issue both in this year's midterm Congressional elections and in the 2000 Presidential race, Republicans led high-profile hearings last year into the complexities of the tax code and abuses of taxpayers by the Internal Revenue Service.
After initially opposing legislation intended to rein in the tax-collection agency, the Administration reversed itself and backed an I.R.S. overhaul bill passed overwhelmingly by the House. The Senate will soon take up its version.
But while the Republicans have kept the White House on the defensive over the I.R.S., they have yet to show that they can make creating a new tax system a winning political issue for the party.

HEADLINE: School Spending Debate Returns to Court

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 2

 BODY:
The State Attorney General and lawyers representing students in urban districts argued before the New Jersey Supreme Court today about whether the state should spend more money for new education programs and improvements to school buildings to help students overcome the disadvantages of poverty.
The arguments represented the latest chapter in the state's long-running legal battle over inequities in spending between the state's poorest and wealthiest school districts. But what was different today was that the court for the first time was considering whether to order the state to provide specific social services and early childhood education programs. 
 The Attorney General, Peter Verniero, contended that the state's highest court should back away from the debate and leave decisions about educational policy to the Whitman administration and the State Legislature.
But lawyers representing schoolchildren in the state's 28 urban school districts urged the court not to abandon the activist role it has played for almost three decades. They asked the court to require New Jersey to pay for supplemental programs that range from psychological counseling for high school students to preschool for children as young as age 3. They also asked the court to demand that the state cover the cost of repairing and renovating deteriorating school buildings.
Almost a year ago, in its latest ruling in the case, the court ordered the state to spend more on its poor school districts. The state responded by increasing aid to the urban districts by $248 million to bring per-pupil spending in those districts up to the same level as the state's wealthiest school districts. The poor districts were already receiving $2.3 billion in state funds, a little less than half of what the state spends annually on public education.
The court also instructed state officials last year to identify additional academic programs and services to help schoolchildren in the financially needy districts to succeed. In addition, the court ordered the state to determine how many school buildings in those districts needed to be replaced, expanded or repaired.
In response, the Whitman administration proposed new programs that Mr. Verniero said today could be paid for within existing school budgets. He requested that the court leave it up to the state to determine what those programs should be and how they should be financed. He said that they include a new reading program for elementary school students that has worked well in other states. He said the schools could also put students in touch with community-based organizations that could provide whatever social services they needed. Administration officials have previously said that the courts should not determine how school repairs and renovations are handled.
He said that ending the spending disparity between rich and poor districts was no longer the "core" issue. "This case is now about programs," he said.
Mr. Verniero said that the court should defer to the State Education Commissioner's judgment and allow the administration and the Legislature to implement educational policy. "It's the question of which branch of government shall determine, control and ultimately implement the educational policies of New Jersey."
David Sciarra, executive director of the Education Law Center, the organization that has led the fight on behalf of poor schoolchildren for almost three decades, argued that the administration's plan does not go far enough to assist economically disadvantaged students, as the court requested last year. He urged the court to direct what specific programs the state should offer and how much it should spend.
Bolstering Mr. Sciarra's argument is the finding by Judge Michael Patrick King of the Appellate Division of Superior Court, who was asked by the Supreme Court to make a recommendation on what programs and services should be supplied.
In January, Judge King recommended a host of supplemental programs that would cost the state about $312 million more a year, including all-day preschool for 3- and 4-year-olds. He also recommended the state spend $2.8 billion on a long-term program to repair and replace deteriorating school buildings in the state's cities.
After Judge King's recommendations, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Republican legislative leaders began to publicly question whether the courts should be further dictating how state education dollars should be spent.
In her budget address last month, Mrs. Whitman cited all that the state had done to assist economically disadvantaged children in the 28 urban districts. "The Legislature and this Governor know what our jobs are and we know how to do them," she said.
Last week, Assembly Speaker Jack Collins and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco wrote a strongly worded letter to the Supreme Court's seven justices that said that lawmakers "do not have a blank check when it comes to funding education."
It is unclear what the court might do based upon the questions posed by the justices during today's session, which lasted more than three hours.
Chief Justice Deborah Poritz, who had recused herself from the school financing issue last year because she had served as attorney general in the Whitman administration, was among those justices asking questions today. She decided last month to join her colleagues on the bench for these arguments, saying that she no longer saw a conflict of interest.

HEADLINE: Jesse Jackson Jr. Is His Father's Son, But He Reaches Beyond the Rainbow

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: FLOSSMOOR, Ill.

 BODY:
Tudor architecture and pricey boutiques line the broad sidewalks of Sterling Avenue in this elegant Chicago suburb, where a Land Rover slips into a parking lot near a micro-brewery.
Out of the vehicle steps a young man in a crisp white shirt and blue tie, the collar of his overcoat stylishly upturned. 
 The man on the move is Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., a rising political star at 32. He has spent the day striding across his turf, stretching from the South Side of Chicago deep into suburbia: the broken-glass-strewn neighborhoods of Ford Heights, median-income and racially mixed Matteson, well-to-do Flossmoor.
"My colleagues in Washington tend to see me as simply 'the guy from the South Side, the guy from the neighborhood,' " Mr. Jackson says, his voice a mix of amusement and annoyance at the stereotypical soul brother image. "And during campaigns, I'm usually asked to run the 'black circuit.' They usually don't tell the press I'm in town, because they don't want to scare the white voters. But I tell them, the white voters in my district love me."
After just over two years in Congress, Mr. Jackson has become a force in Illinois politics in a way that eluded his father, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson. Courted by politicians in both parties, the young Democratic Congressman has become best known here as a champion of south suburban interests, pursuing a meat-and-potatoes agenda of jobs and economic development and joining forces with a conservative Republican powerhouse, Representative Henry J. Hyde, in pressing for building a new airport in the cornfields 40 miles south of downtown Chicago.
If his father came to embody one moment in history, Representative Jackson may come to reflect another: the suburbanization of black political power. His district is 65 percent black and 35 percent white; it is also one-third suburban, a percentage that is growing fast as middle-class blacks leave the South Side.
"Jesse Jackson Jr.'s persona is very different from his father's," said David Bositis, a political analyst for the Joint Center for Political Studies, a research group focused on black concerns. "He represents the new black politics, the new black middle class."
When Mr. Jackson entered Congress in 1995, filling a vacancy left by the resignation of Mel Reynolds after his criminal conviction for having sex with a teen-age girl, there was plenty of skepticism about this young man's easy path to elective office -- his first. He was regarded, even by many who voted for him, as a child of privilege with a famous name who would take predictable stands on the issues and make fiery speeches denouncing the evils of racism in America. Before he became a Congressman, he was a field director for the Rainbow Coalition, the organization founded by his father.
But Mr. Jackson quickly won over many skeptics. He ran virtually unopposed in 1996, and is expected to coast to re-election this fall.
Since the 1970's, blacks have been leaving American cities for the suburbs at the same rate as whites. In Chicago, blacks have largely moved to the mostly white south suburbs, where housing is more affordable than on the woodsy, wealthy North Shore. This changing racial mix has met with some fears among whites, many of whom left the city a generation ago as neighborhoods changed from white to black, sometimes in what seemed an instant, and property values collapsed.
Despite the anxieties among whites -- and some blacks, who fear resegregation -- the experience of racial change in the suburbs has not brought a decline in property values. Middle-class blacks who are moving to places like Homewood, not to mention those buying $400,000 houses in Olympia Fields and Flossmoor, tend to share economic perspectives with their white suburban neighbors.
This changing mix has complicated district politics and blurred some traditional divisions between blacks and whites, suburbanites and city dwellers. When Mr. Jackson talks about attracting people to the south suburbs "who share our values," he is speaking for blacks and whites.
In Congress, Mr. Jackson's voting record is reliably liberal. But he defies easy categories. A man who likes to hunt and enjoy a fine cigar, young Mr. Jackson is not uncomfortable in the company of Republicans. He has not ruled out endorsing a Republican in the race for governor if the Democratic nominee opposes the airport.
On race relations, Mr. Jackson has emerged as an uncommon Chicago politician who can speak a language that seems to be understood by blacks and whites alike. He talks of the difficulties of a black man hailing a cab on Capitol Hill. And he talks with empathy about whites anxious about racial changes in the suburbs.
"White people in the far south suburbs drive down Dixie Highway every day, and this is what they see," Mr. Jackson said, lifting his hand from the gear shift of his Land Rover and pointing toward the shuttered factories and stores of Harvey, once a vibrant working-class steel town, a community that has been withering since its smokestacks vanished a decade ago. "They see an increasing African-American population. They see problems. And they say, 'I don't want that coming my way.' "
In the view of Mr. Jackson, the color that matters most is green. It is the collapse of the industrial economy, not the influx of blacks, that has brought down towns like Harvey.
"Ninety percent of the racial debate is really about economics," he said. "If we frame the discussion in terms of growth, jobs, the economy, we can move beyond the racial battleground."
Toward that end, Mr. Jackson has been single-minded in his drive to build an airport in the south suburbs, a $2.7 billion project that would shower the region with jobs. It would also transform suburbs like Ford Heights, so poor it cannot afford a police department, into property that is suddenly quite valuable.
It is not altogether surprising when Mr. Jackson drives through black neighborhoods, and people respond with honking horns and clenched fists, as if to honor a hero. But it is astonishing in suburban Chicago to see so many whites fawn over a black liberal, some of them the same people who scorned his father.
At a breakfast shop in Chicago Heights, a working-class town with a history of racial tension, blue-collar white men crowded around Mr. Jackson as if he were an old pal.
Mr. Hyde, who has made joint appearances with Mr. Jackson at rallies to promote the new airport, said Mr. Jackson had earned the respect of his colleagues by working hard and acknowledging that, as a freshman, he had a lot to learn.
In the view of political experts in Illinois, Mr. Jackson's appeal among whites and suburbanites, as well as urban blacks, makes him a political figure of enormous potential.
"The upside for this guy is the moon -- I mean it's unlimited," said Paul Green, a professor of political science at Governor's State University in the south suburbs. Mr. Green said Mr. Jackson was in a special position to reach across racial boundaries, given the reservoir of good will many blacks have for the son of a famous civil rights fighter.
"With his name, there is very little he can do to alienate black voters," Mr. Green said. "He's like Daley with the Irish: there's always going to be that cushion of support."
As a result, Mr. Green said, Mr. Jackson can take some chances that other black politicians cannot, like forging alliances with conservative Republicans and playing down racial politics. In fact, Mr. Green said that some black leaders privately complained that Congressman Jackson was too moderate but that they did not dare criticize him publicly.
Some liberals in Chicago say they hope he will run for mayor, a move Mr. Jackson dismisses. But most political experts seriously doubt that Mr. Jackson would make such a run, especially against an incumbent mayor as popular as Richard M. Daley. Most analysts say it is more likely that Mr. Jackson would someday try for the Senate.
But first, he must build a record. So far, he has been careful to tend to business at home, building roads and working on Federal grants for jobs. In more than two years in Congress, he has not missed a vote. And he has held only four news conferences.
It was the rap on the elder Mr. Jackson that he was always looking for the TV cameras, never staying to finish a job. "Jesse Jetstream," the Chicago press long ago nicknamed the father, a man always flying off to the next news conference.
The upbringing of the younger Mr. Jackson, of course, differs starkly with the childhood of his father, a product of poverty and the segregated South. The younger Mr. Jackson attended the prestigious St. Albans preparatory school in Washington, a bastion of the well connected, the alma mater of Vice President Al Gore. He has a law degree from the University of Illinois and lists fencing among his hobbies.
As a child, Mr. Jackson said, he was shaped more by his mother, Jacqueline, than by his father, who was often on the road. Time spent with his father, he recalled, "was often a 15-minute ride from the airport to another meeting."
But the father has taught him some important lessons, he said.
Representative Jackson recalled a time, more than a decade ago, flying with his father over Iowa. His father called him to the window and told him to look down. The son saw great expanses of cultivated corn and bean fields. But it was impossible to see the sweat of the farmers, or their struggles, below.
"Son, if you're flying high, you miss a lot of the details," the Congressman said his father told him. "It was his way of saying, 'Don't get too heady.'
"He was also telling me, 'You've been given a lot. A lot is expected of you.' "

HEADLINE: Senate Agrees To Give States More Money For Highways

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Taking advantage of a booming economy and a balanced budget, Senate negotiators reached an agreement today on the broad outlines of a six-year, $173 billion transportation bill that would significantly increase spending on roads and bridges in every state.
Though details of the agreement must still be worked out, the legislation is expected to call for shifting a larger portion of Federal highway funds to Southern states, which have long complained that they do not receive their rightful share of revenues from a Federal gas tax that finances transportation projects. 
 At the same time, the agreement does not provide any new money for mass transit, dealing a sharp blow to the New York metropolitan region, which traditionally has received one of every five Federal dollars spent on buses and subways.
Mass transit advocates said they are now pinning their hopes of getting more money on either floor amendments in the Senate or negotiations with the House, where support for mass transit is stronger. But the advocates were not optimistic about their chances.
Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, said he expected the Senate to pass the bill in the next week or two. The House, which is considering a version of the measure that spends significantly more than the Senate agreement does, has not yet taken up its bill.
The Senate transportation agreement calls for increasing spending on roads and bridges by nearly $5 billion a year over current levels, a total of $28 billion over six years.
Under the Senate agreement, money for the new transportation spending would come from a 4.3-cent-a-gallon Federal tax on gasoline sales at the pump. Until last year, those revenues had been put into the so-called highway trust fund and largely used for reducing the Federal deficit. But with the budget now balanced, Congress has decided to use most of those revenues for their original purpose: highway construction and repair.

HEADLINE: Moynihan and D'Amato Back Rail Tunnel

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

 BODY:
A proposal to build a rail freight tunnel under New York Harbor received the crucial endorsements of Senators Daniel P. Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday as the city moved forward with a study of what could eventually become its biggest building project in decades.
The ambitious plan, which seeks to link the city with the rest of the country by rail and transform the Brooklyn waterfront, is still years away from any groundbreaking. But the public nod by the two Senators gave momentum and the necessary step in securing Federal money for a project that is expected to cost billions and is sure to encounter the economic and political difficulties that have felled other big city projects, like Westway and the Second Avenue subway. 
 "New York City is going to resume its place as a city where great public works occur," Mr. Moynihan predicted at a joint appearance at City Hall with Mr. D'Amato and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
At the news conference, Mr. Giuliani announced that the city had selected a company, Edwards & Kelcey Engineers, to begin the two-year study, which will look at engineering, economic and environmental considerations and is expected to cost $4 million to $4.5 million.
"This is critical to going forward with this project," Mr. Giuliani said. "A study like this has to be done under the law, which essentially looks at all alternatives. We're very hopeful the end result will be a freight rail tunnel."
And with the city counting on the Federal Government to pay for 80 percent of the study, the Senators' support is important. What is more, the Senators' role in getting Federal money in the future for the $900 million tunnel will be crucial. The Senate is now taking up one of the largest public works bills in the nation's history, and senators from various regions are expected to fight over its contents.
"The fact that D'Amato and Moynihan are supporting the tunnel means that New York is united behind the project," said Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, a Manhattan Democrat who has fought for a tunnel since 1979. "In terms of getting the Federal funding, it's important to find the support for the tunnel, and to make this project credible, it's important to have the support of our two Senators."
Indeed, overcoming considerable opposition in Congress, Mr. Moynihan was able to secure millions of dollars in Federal funds for the renovation of Pennsylvania Station earlier in the 1990's.
The Mayor first brought up his support of the tunnel in his State of the City address last year. He said that the tunnel and revival of the Brooklyn waterfront, which is projected to cost billions of dollars, would create 53,000 jobs. And he argued that the most recent generation of deep-hulled ships, which cannot navigate the shallow channels leading to the New Jersey harbor, would gravitate to New York City's deep, natural harbor if it were modernized.
New York is the only big American city that receives its goods almost exclusively by truck. So a freight tunnel linking Brooklyn with New Jersey was proposed as far back as 1920, and was actually the basis for the creation of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in 1921.
But the project went nowhere for decades, and the city's reliance on trucks for its shipments is believed to have led to untold costs in wear and tear on its roads and bridges, as well as in more pollution.
"It will take close to a million tractor-trailers off of the highways," Mr. D'Amato said, adding that that fact would improve the city's air quality.
The city is considering a tunnel that would run from a rail yard at 65th Street in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to either Staten Island or New Jersey. The tunnel would connect existing rail lines. Either route would require the cooperation of New Jersey, which would have to upgrade its public works, said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
After the current study is done, the project would have to go through an environmental impact study, which might take another few years, and public hearings. "You're talking five years out at best," said H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, a private group that examines economic and environmental issues affecting the metropolitan area. "It's not a sexy issue. You can't immediately say it will benefit Company X. Therefore, it's difficult to develop a political constituency. There will be lawsuits, the normal painful process."
Mr. Shostal supports the tunnel. But other groups have raised doubts about its cost, and whether cheaper alternatives could accomplish the same goals. Bill Yates, project coordinator for the Tristate Transportation Campaign, a coalition of private environmental groups, said the city could expand the use of an existing barge that can carry freight cars between Brooklyn and New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Henry Steele Commager, History Scholar and Defender of the Constitution, Is Dead at 95

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE

 BODY:
Henry Steele Commager, one of the nation's most distinguished historians and teachers, a prolific author, editor and essayist, and an eloquent defender of the Constitution, died yesterday at his home in Amherst, Mass. He was 95.
For decades, the name Henry Steele Commager was synonymous with American history. Starting in the 1930's, he published a torrent of histories, biographies, textbooks, anthologies and inquiries into the nature of democracy and the American mind. His essays in newspapers, journals and magazines were an important part of any dialogue on the issues of his day. 
 He also taught history and American studies for 65 years, 36 of them at Amherst College, 18 at Columbia University and 12 at New York University. He was still teaching into his 80's and he said he could not imagine not doing so. "What every college must do," he said, "is hold up before the young the spectacle of greatness" in history, literature and life.
He accomplished all this while plagued by poor eyesight that deteriorated to near blindness, relying on a phenomenal memory and extraordinary energy.
Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian, called him "a great teacher and one of the century's notable historians." Mr. Schlesinger said Mr. Commager brought to his profession an "analytical keenness, grace and lucidity of expression, and a disciplined passion for the integrity and hope of the democratic experience."
He also was remembered for his early stand against McCarthyism. Alfred Kazin, the author and critic, said the historian showed "extraordinary bravery and openness amid the broiling hysteria."
David Oshensky, a Rutgers University historian, added that Mr. Commager waged "one of the great battles of his era -- when it was very dangerous to do so and other intellectuals were cowed."
Among his important books were:
*"The Growth of the American Republic" (1930), of which he was co-author, and which became a standard college textbook for more than four decades.
*"The American Mind" (1951), regarded by many historians and critics as his best work, which explored the cultural and philosophical forces that shaped the nation's outlook.
* "The Empire of Reason: How Europe Imagined and America Realized the Enlightenment" (1977), was described in The New York Times as "his most brilliant work." In it he rejected what he termed the "sterile" economic determinism inspired by the historian Charles A. Beard and held that Americans of the late 18th and early 19th centuries had the courage and audacity to put into practice and law the principles of the Age of Enlightenment only envisioned by great European philosophers.
*"Documents of American History" (1934) and "The Blue and the Gray: The Story of the Civil War as Told by Participants" (1950), two anthologies invaluable to American historians, which were part of the work that prompted Albert Fried, a historian at the State University of New York at Purchase, to call Mr. Commager "the greatest anthologist America ever produced."
In 1966 Mr. Commager warned against American involvement in Indochina, appealing to Congress on constitutional grounds to reassert its authority over the waging of war, and appealing to the public on moral grounds.
His opposition to the war in Vietnam was not confined to his writing. He galvanized an anti-war rally on the Amherst campus in 1970 with the fluency and force of his contentions. "Having the United States in Vietnam is like having the Chinese invade the shores of Long Island!" thundered this jaunty little man with the thatch of white hair.
 
The Learned Man Behind the Textbooks
 Henry Steele Commager was born in Pittsburgh on Oct. 25, 1902, the son of James W. and Anna Elizabeth Commager. He was orphaned in childhood and raised by his maternal grandfather of Danish origin, a founder of American Lutheranism.
He grew up in Toledo, Ohio, and Chicago, where he graduated from high school and enrolled at the University of Chicago, working as a harvest hand in the summers and tending furnace at night in winters. He earned his bachelor's degree at Chicago in 1923, his master's the next year, and his doctorate in history four years after that. He spent a year at the University of Copenhagen studying Danish naval history. While he was earning his degrees, he taught at Chicago, in Europe and at N.Y.U.
By the time he was 28, Mr. Commager had been been appointed to the N.Y.U. faculty and completed two books, "The Reform Movement in Denmark," for which he received the American Historical Association's award for the best first book by an American historian, and "The Literature of the Pioneer West."
His reputation then soared with the publication of "The Growth of the American Republic," written with Samuel Eliot Morison of Harvard. (William E. Leuchtenburg joined the collaboration in 1969 for subsequent editions.) It was principally through this work, a readable and detailed narrative, that thousands of college students obtained their basic knowledge of their country's history.
Like all of Mr. Commager's work, the book is suffused with his Jeffersonian belief in the American Constitution and his trust in reason: People can learn, he insisted. Issues can be explored, explained and debated, and the people of the new American democracy, armed with knowledge and freedom to dissent, argue and choose, will make the right decisions for their common welfare.
Such a vision had its detractors. Garry Wills, in his 1990 book "Under God: Religion and America," maintained that historians like Mr. Commager and Mr. Schlesinger discounted the importance of religion in shaping the United States and its politics.
"Commager and Schlesinger are to American history what Michael Dukakis was, in 1988, to American politics," Mr. Wills wrote. "Much of American (indeed, of human) experience is off their mental maps. They have a serene provincialism, dismissive of the ordinary torments of people less optimistic, irreverent, and pragmatic than they."
In later years, his work also would come under criticism for what some historians believed was insufficient attention to Native Americans and African-Americans.
Mr. Commager left N.Y.U. in 1938 to accept a history professorship at Columbia, but his life there was soon interrupted by World War II. He worked as a consultant with the Office of War Information and was a member of the State Department's committee on the history of the war.
He also published several books. "America: The Story of a Free People" (1942), written with Allan Nevins, became a best seller. "The Pocket History of the United States" and "Majority Rule and Minority Rights" both appeared in 1943, and "The Story of the Second World War" was published in 1945.
"Majority Rule," his first book applying constitutional history to current issues, defended Franklin Delano Roosevelt's attempt to enlarge the U.S. Supreme Court after it ruled against several New Deal programs.
 
Exploring the Forces That Shaped a Nation
 Back at Columbia, he produced in 1950 his magisterial work, "The American Mind," subtitled, "An Interpretation of American Thought and Character Since the 1880's." With the exceptions of slavery and the Civil War, he described the nation's first century as marked by triumphant progress. He said 19th-century Americans were extraordinarily pleased with themselves and incurably optimistic: "Nothing in all history had ever succeeded like America, and every American knew it."
But he voiced pessimism about developments after 1890. He found 20th-century America "urban but not yet urbane," hurried, less happy, less confident. Confronted by two major crises, the Depression and World War II, the American people "showed themselves resourceful, mature and magnanimous." But after those trials, he wrote, citizens exhibited a moral and intellectual softening.
Events had begun unfolding as he worked on "The American Mind" that struck him as darker in some ways than any the nation had faced. In 1947 he wrote an article in Harper's magazine attacking loyalty oaths as an abuse of power that violated the Constitution and illegally resulted in the loss of livelihood to those Americans who refused to sign them. In Senator Joseph McCarthy and his followers, Mr. Commager saw an internal threat to the principles of the Constitution that was as serious as the threat of a foreign invader.
In 1956, Mr. Commager accepted a teaching post at Amherst and remained on its faculty until 1972. He then was named Simpson Lecturer, the college's most prestigious faculty appointment, and held the position until he was 92. Among his predecessors were Robert Frost and Archibald MacLeish.
"Commager on Tocqueville," his last book, published at the age of 91, was described by Herbert Mitgang in The New York Times Book Review as a "brilliant new interpretation of Alexis de Tocqueville's 'Democracy in America.' "
 
A Serious Scholar With a Wry Humor
 Though deadly serious on social and political issues, especially those involving the Constitution, he was remembered as something of a campus character. Despite an extraordinary memory for historical data, he had difficulty remembering the names of his students and so called most of them Mr. or Miss McGillicuddy.
Mr. Commager's nickname was Felix, after the Latin word for happy, and he was happiest working. He seemed to be writing nonstop -- on buses, planes, cars, even when on vacation. Friends and relatives said he not only read everything there was to read but also heard all the music there was to hear. He could quote pages verbatim from the stories of P. G. Wodehouse, whether those around him wanted to hear them or not, and he could whistle Beethoven, Schubert and Mozart compositions in their entirety.
He was also remembered for his self-assuredness. What colleagues called "Commager's No. 1 Rule" -- "I'm right" -- was an important factor in his success, in their view, because it lent a clarity and authority to his writing and gave him the boldness to take unpopular or risky positions.
Mr. Commager was a member of the National Academy of Arts and Letters and was awarded its Gold Medal for History in 1972. He was the recipient of scores of other scholarly awards, honorary degrees and tributes. Among them was the 1967 publication of a collection by Harper & Row titled, "Freedom and Reform: Essays in Honor of Henry Steele Commager."
Mr. Commager was married to the former Evan Carroll, an author of children's books, from 1928 until her death in 1968. He is survived by his second wife, Mary Powlesland Commager; two daughters from his first marriage, Nell Lasch of South Newfane, Vt., and Lisa Demlinger of New York; five grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. His son Steele Commager, a classics professor at Columbia, died in 1985.
"History is a story," Mr. Commager once wrote, and "if history forgets or neglects to tell a story, it will inevitably forfeit much of its appeal and much of its authority as well."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asia's Interest In U.S. Market Suddenly Cools

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 2

 BODY:
When Korea's Hyundai Electronics Industries acquired Symbios Inc. from the AT&T Corporation for more than $300 million in 1994, it marked the beginning of a spurt of investment by South Korea's ambitious companies in the American market.
Now Symbios, a Colorado semiconductor company, might represent the beginning of a wave of divestitures in the wake of Asia's financial crisis. Anxious for cash, Hyundai just sold Symbios to Adaptec Inc., a Silicon Valley company it had beaten in the bidding in 1994. The deal, announced Thursday, took less than three weeks to complete at a price, $775 million, considered by analysts to be low. 
 "There's nothing like having an I'm-going-to-sell-this seller and a willing buyer," F. Grant Saviers, president of Adaptec, said.
The Asian financial crisis has dealt a body blow to the United States operations of South Korean and other Asian companies. Subsidiaries and real estate are being sold, branch offices closed, people laid off or brought home, and once-ambitious investment plans are being scaled back or put on hold. The impact has been felt most in New York and Los Angeles, where Asian investments and businesses are concentrated.
"Most of the companies in Korea are cutting back," said Young M. Kim, president of the Korean Chamber of Commerce and Industry in the United States. "Every subsidiary in the United States should follow suit." Mr. Kim said the situation was so dire that he expected the chamber to forgo the collection of dues from its 700 members this year.
The conundrum is that with their own economies ailing, Asian companies need their overseas sales more than ever. At the same time, the sharp weakening of their currencies has made their products more competitive overseas, although most companies have been unable or chose not to make dramatic cuts in their United States prices.
But the devaluation of currencies also makes it more expensive for Asian companies to pay the expenses of their operations in the United States. Their American subsidiaries are having trouble raising cash because American banks are reluctant to lend to them -- except at prohibitive interest rates -- and neither the parent companies nor Asian banks have the money. South Korea's Finance Ministry, worried that money-losing overseas business operations will drain it of scarce foreign reserves, is asking to see financial statements of overseas subsidiaries and pressing for closing those that are not consistently profitable, executives said.
"They really need these offices running on full cylinder right now, and it's very painful to do so," said Stewart M. Kim, managing partner of Pacific Gemini Partners, a Los Angeles investment management firm that is half-owned by South Korea's Ssangyong Investment and Securities Company.
The American operations, for instance, have been a lifeline for the Kia Motors Corporation, a South Korean auto maker that fell into bankruptcy last year. The American subsidiary was asked to accept shipments of extra cars, said Greg Warner, executive vice president of Kia Motors America. United States sales were up 65 percent last year and in January were nearly triple the level of a year earlier, because of the devaluation of the won and because new dealers have opened. But dealers are having trouble getting financing, Mr. Warner said.
Hyundai Motor America has not lowered car prices because it does not want to cheapen the image of its cars. But it is offering hefty rebates on some models. The company has had two rounds of layoffs since December, one of them at its financing subsidiary, which has had trouble raising funds and ended its leasing program.
The cutbacks and other changes are not limited to Korean companies. Indonesian, Thai and other Southeast Asian companies are affected but have a smaller presence in the United States. Hong Kong and Taiwan companies, many of which are big investors in this country, have not been hit as hard by the Asian crisis.
The biggest impact, however, could come from Japanese companies, whose ownership of United States businesses, factories and real estate dwarfs that of all other Asian nations combined.
Japan's financial problems are not as sudden or as acute as those of South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia, so the reaction of Japanese companies has been more gradual. Japanese investors, who ran headlong into waves of xenophobia in this country when they purchased trophy hotels, office buildings and golf courses in the late 1980's, have been selling $3 billion to $5 billion of United States real estate annually in the last few years, according to Jack Rodman, head of Pacific Rim activities for E & Y Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group, which tracks Japanese property investment in the United States.
Still, some analysts think the selloff of Japanese-owned businesses and real estate will accelerate because Japan's Government is getting more serious about cleansing bad debts from the banking system and because United States real estate prices have been rising. Sumitomo Bank announced it was looking to sell Sumitomo Bank of California. The Inter-Continental Hotel chain, which includes United States properties like San Francisco's Mark Hopkins Hotel, is being sold by Saison Group to Bass P.L.C. of Britain. Taisei, a construction company, is said to be selling the Sheraton Grande Torrey Pines in San Diego and a big office building in Chicago.
According to Commerce Department figures for 1995, the latest available, there were 109 nonbank affiliates of South Korean companies operating in the United States, with sales of $23.8 billion and 22,900 employees. Few Korean companies have set up United States factories in the way that Japanese companies like Honda and Sony have. So many of the most recent cutbacks since then have been in sales and administrative personnel and have tended to be small.
Samsung Group, one of South Korea's largest companies, closed its American headquarters in Ridgefield, N.J., and dispersed its 30 employees to other subsidiaries. Asiana Airlines, Korea's second-largest carrier, stopped flying to Honolulu in January and closed its 15-employee office there. SK Group, the fifth-largest conglomerate, is in the process of laying off a quarter of its 200 employees in the New York area.
South Korean banks are closing their American branches and selling loan portfolios. Korean banks collectively had 26 branches and 7 subsidiaries in the United States with total assets of $21.2 billion at the end of 1996, according to the Bank of Korea.
The branches generally do not take deposits and instead raise funds by borrowing from other institutions, a strategy that has now become untenable. "Our funding cost has shot up to a level where we are no longer competitive at all," said a manager at Korea First Bank, which is closing its three United States branches.
The sale of Symbios has heightened speculation that Korean companies might sell their interests in such well-known companies as AST Research Inc., the Zenith Electronics Corporation and the Maxtor Corporation that were acquired over the last few years to gain technology, brand names or new businesses.
Cheil Jedang, a food company, has had second thoughts about the $300 million it committed for an 11 percent state in Dreamworks SKG, the Hollywood studio started by Steven Spielberg and other luminaries. But despite Dreamworks' slow start, a Cheil official said the company intended to stick with the studio.
The Samsung Electronics Company, a company that is under financial pressure because of the sharp drop in the prices of computer memory chips, completed its acquisition of AST, a personal computer maker in Irvine, Calif., only last spring. Now it has delayed the planned expansion of its chip factory in Austin, Tex., and is reportedly seeking a hefty capital infusion from the Intel Corporation.
Tom Scott, senior vice president of AST, said the company's brand name and presence outside South Korea made it more valuable than ever for Samsung, which, he said, has no intent to sell.
Likewise, LG Group, which owns a controlling stake in Zenith, "has no thought of selling it and we're in it for the long run," said Peter McDermott, executive vice president of LG of the Americas. But the credit ratings of the Glenview, Ill., television maker were recently lowered out of concern that the Asian crisis would make it more difficult for LG to support Zenith, which it has not been able to make profitable.
As for Maxtor, a disk drive maker, it is owned by Hyundai Electronics Industries, the same company that unloaded Symbios and that is trying to complete a billion-dollar chip factory in Oregon.
Some smaller, lesser-known investments have already been sold off. The Ssangyong Group, struggling to avoid bankruptcy, sold the Riverside Cement Company to Texas Industries for $120 million and two Marriott Residence Inns, in Sacramento and San Diego, to Sunstone Hotel Investors for $30.5 million. Sunstone also bought two hotels in the Los Angeles area from the bankrupt Halla Group for $16.5 million.
Besides the need to raise cash quickly, other factors could be motivating Asian owners to sell American real estate. Prices in Asia have dropped so far and American prices have risen so high that it might be time to take profits here and invest them back home. The weakness of the Asian currencies adds to this effect.
Richard Rosenberg, the director of North American real estate for Octagon Group in Pasadena, Calif., which is part of an Indonesian conglomerate, said his company bought American real estate when the exchange rate was about 2,200 Indonesian rupiah to the dollar. "If you can sell those assets at 10,000 rupiah, it's an absolute windfall," he said.
But Richard Alter, the managing director of the Financial Capital Investment Company in Los Angeles, which pools money from ethnic Chinese investors in Hong Kong, Taiwan and other countries to purchase United States properties, said his clients were continuing to invest in this country because it offers stability. "What all this crisis does is make more instability" in Asia, he said, "which is why our investors are coming here."
Some South Korean companies say their American subsidiaries have barely been affected by the crisis. While their countrymen back home were bracing for austerity, LG executives were in Florida recently sponsoring the LG Championship golf tournament, awarding $1.2 million in prizes.
Two South Korean companies said they planned to go ahead at least with the first phase of construction on polyester-product plants expected to cost about $300 million each.
"When you're doing this size of a project, it's not for today or tomorrow," said Eugene Chin Yu, president of Hankook Synthetics/America, part of the Ehwa Group. "We're looking for the long run." He said the company had arranged 80 percent of the financing for its plant locally, with 20 percent coming from Korea.
A manager at SKC Inc., the SK Group subsidiary building the other plant, said half the financing had been arranged but that the rest was becoming harder to obtain. "Anyone who has a Korean tie has a difficult time financially," he said.
Even as companies soldier on here, expatriate managers, who generally receive housing allowances that have become more expensive in terms of Asian currencies, are being called back home. That could open up more opportunities for Americans, who are often shut out of upper-level jobs at Asian companies.
"The number of Koreans stationed in the U.S. has been drastically cut, and they will be replaced by local hires," said Sung Ho Lee, cargo marketing manager for Korean Air Lines in Los Angeles. His department, he said, now has one manager from Korea, down from three a couple of years ago.
Although the South Korean won has lost nearly half its value against the dollar since the crisis began, prices of Korean products here have dropped only a little. That is because the costs of imported raw materials and energy needed to make the products have gone up in terms of won. Higher interest rates also add to costs.
"The big impact that everyone sort of hoped for has not really materialized," said Bob Jones, executive vice president of the American sales arm of the Samick Musical Instrument Company, a large South Korean piano and guitar manufacturer. Still, he said, his company has cut its United States prices by 6 to 8 percent, helping it better compete against Chinese manufacturers.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Doubts About Slowdown Push Yields to 1998 High
Investor skepticism about a widely expected weakening in the economy rattled the bond market, depressing prices and elevating the 30-year Treasury yield to 6 percent for the first time since mid-December.
Analysts attributed the change to new evidence that the economy was not slowing, as well as fear of inflation expressed last week by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. The reversal suggested many investors fear Asia's economic crisis will not repress inflation as much as hoped. Page D9. 

Manufacturing grew at a faster clip than expected last month, a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management showed. Reports on personal income, consumer spending and construction spending also showed strength. D4.
 
Stocks finished mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 4.73 points to close at 8,550.45, another record high. But broader market indicators fell. D9.
 
Bidding Brawl for Insurer
American International Group, one of the nation's largest insurers, raised its friendly bid for American Bankers Insurance Group by 23 percent, to $58 a share, or $2.7 billion, matching a hostile bid by the Cendant Corporation, a discount shopping and franchising company. D2.
 
Corning to Sell Cookware Business
Corning agreed to sell 92 percent of its Corning cookware business to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the New York investment firm, for $583 million. An earlier agreement to sell the business to AEA Investors for $825 million fell through. D6.
 
Shares of BTR P.L.C. rose 16 percent after Britain's biggest industrial holding company agreed to sell its glass and packaging businesses to Owens-Illinois for 2.2 billion in cash, or $3.6 billion. D4.
 
Wang Buys Olivetti Unit
Wang Laboratories reached an agreement to buy Olivetti's computer services subsidiary for more than $395 million in cash and securities. The agreement marks another step in Olivetti's transformation into a telecommunications company and will greatly expand the global reach of Wang. D4.
 
New U.S. Pressure on Indonesia
Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale arrived in Indonesia with a sobering message from Washington for President Suharto to proceed with economic austerity measures. Mr. Mondale is the second personal envoy sent by President Clinton to pressure Indonesia in less than two months. A3.
 
Philip Morris Chairman on Stand
Geoffrey C. Bible, chairman of Philip Morris, swore under oath that he does not know if cigarettes can kill. But Mr. Bible, the first top executive of a major cigarette company to testify in a tobacco trial, said he believed smoking was a "very significant risk factor" for cancer. That was as close to an admission as lawyers for the State of Minnesota could get from Mr. Bible, a pack-a-day smoker of Marlboro menthols. A16.
 
Prudential Insurance Profits Off
Prudential Insurance reported a 43.4 percent drop in 1997 profits to $610 million. D2.

HEADLINE: In Praise of Smaller Farms

 BODY:
Suburban sprawl looks like a natural product of American growth until one realizes that it was largely shaped by state and Federal policies affecting highway construction, lending and zoning. The same is true of farm country. The concentration of land in fewer and fewer hands, the steady demise of small farms, the vertical integration of food production -- all this looks like the inevitable result of economic forces. Actually it has been largely caused by a prolonged bias toward industrial farming in the Agriculture Department and the agricultural establishment that has led to the depopulation of farm towns, the loss of soil, the pollution of land and water, and the demoralization of America's small farmers.
A special commission appointed last year by the Secretary of Agriculture, Dan Glickman, has now published an important study titled "A Time to Act," which reiterates what is almost forgotten knowledge. Even by raw economic standards, small farms -- farms having less than $250,000 in gross receipts, with labor and management provided by the owners -- are no less efficient than megafarms. 
 By any more meaningful standard of efficiency, one that takes into account the social, economic and environmental health of rural America, small farms are a vital resource. They foster biological and social diversity. They keep alive and develop anew a wealth of cropping practices. Their size prevents the concentration of animal wastes, inevitable in factory farming, that turns valuable manure into a pollutant.
The agriculture envisioned by the commission is practical and available. Federal policy needs to be changed to reflect and support the value of small farms. "A Time to Act" recognizes the fact that every good farm is a laboratory and that every farmer is a student of his land. It imagines an agriculture in which vertically integrated companies can be owned, as one farmer told the commission, "by the folks at the bottom, and not just the folks at the top." Its recommendations are financially modest but far-reaching. They deserve to be put into action.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk
