HEADLINE: For Urban Wastelands, Tomatoes and Other Life

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN

 BODY:
On an industrial strip in Buffalo, where just over a year ago the remains of a steel mill sagged on an oil-soaked lot, bumblebees now dance among the yellow blossoms of 170,000 tomato plants growing in artificial soil in a computer-controlled greenhouse. This month, 125 workers will start picking what the greenhouse company says will be at least seven million pounds of vine-ripened tomatoes each year.
In Trenton, a supermarket, office complex and 70 new apartments for the elderly now occupy a jumble of long-dormant factory buildings where workers once wove cables for suspension bridges -- and left traces of toxic metals and industrial chemicals. 
 And on a patchwork of decontaminated factory sites and empty lots near the waterfront in Bridgeport, Conn., fresh sod was laid last month on the infield of a $14 million minor-league ball park. The Bridgeport Bluefish are to toss their first pitch in May.
The economic boom, new commitments from local, state and Federal Government agencies, and technical advances have opened the way to aggressive redevelopment of contaminated patches of inner cities, long shunned as environmentally hazardous and financially risky.
The land is desirable for the reasons businesses once favored inner city locations -- proximity to transportation and easy access for suppliers and customers. And the reclamation of sites known as "brownfields" is taking root across the urban Northeast, Midwest and almost everywhere else that fenced tracts of tainted soil, rusting iron and falling brick pay tribute to the decline of many manufacturing centers. None of the sites, though, have been deemed hazardous enough to qualify for cleanup money under Federal or state Superfund programs.
With new streams of government money aimed at these projects and demand for urban real estate rising, an entire industry of financial consultants and environmental scientists has grown to attend to them.
In New York, the picture is mixed. New York State has committed $200 million to clean brownfields in the 1996 bond act, but has so far spent only $8.4 million. The state also lacks a law protecting prospective developers from unforeseen cleanup costs, prompting many developers to shop elsewhere.
New York City has identified more than 6,500 such tracts, most of them in old industrial areas of Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens. The city has put together some successful pilot cleanups and has several more in the works. Among the most notable successes is the cleanup of the 96-acre Harlem River Rail Yard, which is also slated to include an industrial and commercial complex.
But some environmental experts in the private sector say the city is taking too long to compile and market a list of usable sites.
"These neighborhoods can't wait," said Walter Hang, president of Toxics Targeting, who participated in a New York City task force on brownfields. "Every day, every year you delay, structures are falling apart, the work force is leaving, the community is dying."
Randy Mastro, the First Deputy Mayor, defended New York City's record, saying that a wide array of sites, from the Bronx to Staten Island, were being returned to productive use after decades of neglect. "It's in our interest to do so," Mr. Mastro said. "It's both environmentally sound and good planning for the city."
Elsewhere, redevelopment of polluted sites is becoming a thriving business. Mr. Hang, whose company is based in Ithaca, N.Y., said that more than a third of his work involved sifting data bases of environmental agencies for records of spills before a real estate sale took place.
Sensing a new business in the making, several insurance companies, including American Insurance Group and Kemper Insurance, have created divisions offering policies that protect developers of polluted real estate against unforeseen cleanup costs or lawsuits.
Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, has sharply expanded a division focused on evaluating cleanup costs for brownfields, creating five regional divisions last year to handle the work load, Jennifer Johnson, a manager in the division, said.
"There's a lot of capital out there looking for the highest rate of return, and brownfields are a source of that," Ms. Johnson said. "More and more people are finding their way through the muck."
 
Laws, Technology And Attitudes Evolve
Laws and regulations governing cleanup have been changed recently in more than three dozen states. Many of the changes limit the potential liability of new buyers to known cleanup costs -- freeing them from the specter of some surprise discovery years down the road.
Some cleanups are being financed through loans by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development and pilot grants from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. The E.P.A. has awarded more than 120 grants to municipalities to identify and fix sites, with $85 million in this year's budget for more grants.
In addition, a Federal law enacted last year allows developers of brownfields to write off their cleanup costs in the year they are incurred, instead of stretching the tax break over several decades. The tax breaks are expected to amount to $2 billion over the next three years.
Adding momentum to the shift, many private environmental groups that once aggressively fought to have all contaminated parcels cleaned to a single high standard now are supporting state and Federal efforts to set different standards of cleanliness depending on the eventual use of each site. In other words, dirt under a new parking lot need not be as clean as dirt in a new playground.
The technology of cleaning spills and other contamination has also improved, lowering costs.
"There was a time when many people saw a leaking underground tank as a half-million-dollar issue," said Randy Muller, vice president of environmental services at the Bank of America, in Chicago. "We see that as a $35,000 issue."
The condition of abandoned industrial sites still varies tremendously from state to state and city to city. Some spots with severe liabilities will never find a market. And even in places where sites are being restored, mainly the most valuable ones -- "the low-hanging fruit," in the words of one Federal environmental official -- have been rehabilitated so far.
 
A Legacy of Pollution Across the Nation
Since the early 1980's, when Love Canal and other toxic discoveries spawned strict Federal and state cleanup laws, almost any urban property -- whether severely or lightly polluted -- has had the potential to become a tangle of costly, time-consuming cleanups and lawsuits.
As a result, an enormous inventory of unused parcels has built up around the United States. As many as 450,000 such tracts have been tallied in various government and private studies.
The properties, now unused, range from 100-acre railyards and even larger steel mills to dry cleaning shops and corner gas stations, but they all share a common legacy: suspected or low-level contamination with harmful metals, chemicals, or petroleum.
Many sites may not be polluted at all. But they remain padlocked and silent, with no investors willing to gamble on cleaning them. In many cases, owners -- to avoid taxes and cleanup costs -- have gone bankrupt and sometimes literally dropped off the keys at City Hall.
That was how New York City acquired its dubious portfolio of more than 1,300 acres of pollution-stained empty lots or industrial buildings, 40 percent of the total of 3,300 acres of tainted sites in the city.
The stigma surrounding such sites is one factor that helped push industry into the suburbs, according to many urban planners and environmental experts, creating new environmental problems and eating up increasingly rare open space.
Even though there are other costs in building on farmland or woodlands -- laying sewers and power lines and the like -- they are at least measurable and predictable, developers say, unlike a city lot with a questionable past.
So the urban properties were shunned, weighing down surrounding -- mostly poor -- neighborhoods that have been trying for decades to revive.
 
As Risks Recede, Revival Gains Ground
Now, though, signs of life abound. So far, most of the successes in turning around these sites have come where communities have made a concerted effort to build a package of tax breaks and liability protections big enough to outweigh the risks of a cleanup. Federal environmental officials point to Chicago, Buffalo and Trenton as some of the cities most aggressively pursuing cleanup deals.
New Jersey enacted its brownfields law in January, offering tax breaks and protecting buyers of tainted industrial sites from future cleanup costs once they have followed a state-approved plan to restore a site.
Developers who avoided the state last year, including Ronald B. Bruder, the chairman of Dames & Moore/Brookhill, are already conducting helicopter surveys of possible purchases there.
Progress in New York State is still halting, partly because the $200 million from the 1996 bond act can only be spent if sites are cleaned to a standard as stringent as that for Federal Superfund sites. This condition was insisted upon by some private environmental lobbying groups in return for their endorsement of the bond legislation.
Many mayors have said it simply is not worth applying for such restrictive aid, because cleanups could take years.
But other communities are cashing in. Yesterday, Gov. George E. Pataki handed a check for $2.9 million to the Hudson River village of Irvington to transform two industrial sites into a park.
Mr. Pataki has also proposed brownfields legislation similar to New Jersey's, but he and the Democratic-controlled State Assembly have never agreed on the details of such a law.
Meanwhile, Mr. Pataki used administrative changes to create a "voluntary cleanup program" that protects developers who correctly follow cleanup plans approved by the state.
That program has helped clean some brownfields. But private developers say they still prefer to look for land outside the state, where the protections are firmer and clearer.
Connecticut offers developers the chance to put money into a pool -- equal to 3 percent of the value of a property once it is cleaned -- that is then used to cover unanticipated cleanup costs.
Like Massachusetts and Ohio, Connecticut also has a new licensing system for private environmental specialists who monitor and certify industrial cleanups. Their work can be audited and there are substantial penalties for cheating, said Michael Freimuth, the director of planning and economic development in Bridgeport.
The biggest benefit of the new state programs, Mr. Freimuth said, is that companies seeking to build in long-suffering downtowns can finally undertake what has always been a given in real estate -- a straightforward weighing of risks and rewards.
"Risk is the foundation of investment," Mr. Freimuth said. "We've finally been able to put some risk analysis back into the mathematics of brownfields. Without that, we were in a perpetual Never Neverland."
 
Careful Planning And Creativity Sought
No one involved in rehabilitating old urban sites expects all the scars of a century of heavy industry to be erased. And market forces alone cannot do the job, said Alan Mallach, the director of housing and development for Trenton.
The shape of a city will still best be determined through careful planning and creative problem solving, he said. He cited a recent challenge faced in Trenton, which in 1995 lost its biggest employer, Hill Refrigeration, when the company moved to Virginia and sold its 24-acre plant site.
In a negotiated deal with the owners of the property, Trenton received $200,000 toward a cleanup, subdivided the land and found seven new tenants, including a Canadian company that builds refrigeration equipment.
"They came here specifically because we had this great trained work force," Mr. Mallach said.
In Buffalo, city officials decided to pay part of the costs of digging out the oil-soaked dirt at the old steel mill site, clearing the way for workers to erect the glass panels of the high-technology greenhouse last fall. The tomatoes are isolated from any possible remaining contamination, with their roots growing in bricks of synthetic, wool-like fibers, not in the dirt.
The benefits of that investment quickly became apparent, said Alan H. DeLisle, the president of the Buffalo Enterprise Development Corporation, which owns the land and leases it to the vegetable growers.
"The first day of job interviews, they had 700 people lined up for 175 jobs," Mr. DeLisle said.
Inside the sprawling greenhouse, shielded from the cold rain of a blustery late winter day, workers in shorts and T-shirts tended the fast-growing vines.
Richard Hughes, a 55-year-old security guard at the 18-acre complex, Village Farms of Buffalo, said he had spent 17 years working just up the road at the Shenango Steel mill, which closed in 1982. As he surveyed the still-vacant lots around the greenhouse, he marveled at his new work place, with its drip-irrigated plants and polished panels of greenish glass.
"I grew up a little kid over there on Oak Street," he said, pointing toward downtown, past the windswept spaces where steel furnaces once roared and glowed. "Never thought I'd see a greenhouse in Buffalo. But here it is. It's new blood for an old man."

HEADLINE: SOCCER: NOTEBOOK -- PROJECT 40;
Boys to Men: Boost For U.S.?

BYLINE: By ALEX YANNIS

 BODY:
Project 40, a joint venture between the United States Soccer Federation and Major League Soccer to develop young American players, took a major step last week toward putting the youngsters in a professional environment almost year round.
In order to provide more than 40 competitive games, the federation and M.L.S. have arranged for a Project 40 select team to compete in the Pacific Division of the A-League, which is the main breeding ground for the 12 teams in M.L.S., a breeding ground for the World Cup team. 
 Sunil Gulati, the vice president of the federation and the deputy commissioner of M.L.S., named Tim Hankinson as the coach and Jan Osborne as the general manager of Project 40. Hankinson has been the director of player development for the league, and Osborne has been a consultant.
"One of the major goals of the program is to create leaders on the field," Hankinson said. "These players will have an impact in the United States on both the international and professional level."
The select team will play 27 regular-season games in the A-League, all on the road because there is no home base.
"We'll make adjustments to the roster as the season progresses," Osborne said. "This will raise the performance of our teams in the next Olympics and the World Cup, along with developing future players for M.L.S."
 
METROSTARS
The MetroStars had their first practice yesterday in Italy. They will play at AC Milan in an exhibition game on Thursday. The MetroStars also have exhibitions scheduled in Rome and Palermo before returning to the United States on March 19.
The MetroStars will open their Major League Soccer season March 28, at Los Angeles.
 
WORLD CUP
Sepp Blatter, the general secretary of FIFA, the sport's governing body, said that extra tickets should be available to fans outside France for the World Cup finals this summer.
"We have asked France for the remaining tickets that were reserved for the retail market in France to be returned to FIFA," Blatter told German television on Sunday. "That will allow the federations of the countries in the finals to get more tickets." Blatter did not say how many extra tickets the sport's governing body was expecting to get.
The European union, UEFA, had warned the French organizing committee that it was monopolizing most of the tickets, making it difficult to buy them outside France. But the French committee and FIFA have said that they were following guidelines agreed to by UEFA two years ago.
 
EUROPEAN LEAGUES
Manchester United closed in on its third consecutive championship in England with a 1-0 triumph over Chelsea on defender Phil Neville's first goal for the team. United is 9 points ahead of the Blackburn Rovers, who were 5-3 victors over Leicester City behind a hat trick by Chris Sutton, who was rejected by the national team.
Brad Friedel of the United States made his long-awaited debut with Liverpool in England's Premier League on Saturday and lost by 2-1 to Aston Villa. Friedel's start in goal broke a streak of 212 games for David James, Liverpool's premier goalkeeper.
Celtic opened a 2-point lead at the top of Scotland's Premier League with a 1-0 victory over Hibernian on Marc Riper's 25th-minute goal. Its closest rivals, Rangers and Hearts, played to a 2-2 tie when Rangers got the tying goal in the game's final minutes.
Juventus retained its 4-point lead over Inter Milan in Italy with a 1-0 victory over Bari on an own-goal by Bari's Rachid Neqrouz, and third-place Lazio was held to a scoreless deadlock at Atalanta of Bergamo. Inter kept the pressure on Juventus with a 2-0 victory over Napoli, with Ivan Zamorano and Ronaldo getting the goals.
Bayern Munich, one of the challengers for the German title, suffered a shocking 2-0 defeat at home to Cologne, which is 13th in the Bundesliga standing. The result left Bayern 6 points behind Kaiserslautern
Porto retained its 8-point lead in Portugal after a 1-0 victory over Vitoria Setubal, with the Yugoslav LjubiNko Drulovic scoring the goal.
Ajax appears on its way to its 27th title in the Netherlands after beating NEC Nijmegen by 3-0.

Japan scored two minutes from the end of a match on Sunday to beat South Korea by 2-1 in the first game at Yokohama's International Stadium, the most likely site for the 2002 World Cup final. Striker Shoji Jo scored the game-winner with an accurate header before a sellout crowd.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Who's Biased Now?

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
Remember the biased "mainstream media" that would stop at nothing to protect the Clinton White House? Funny how you don't hear about that anymore. If there's one certain casualty of Monicagate so far, it's the notion that the likes of Newsweek, The Washington Post, The New York Times and the big three networks will suppress news out of loyalty to a supposed liberal comrade.
This was always a canard. To take just one example, it was Jeff Gerth of The Times who broke the Whitewater story six years ago this week. And it's conservative media that more often do bidding for their ideological own. The most unabashedly partisan figure among media magnates is hardly Katharine Graham or Michael Eisner -- it's our naturalized Citizen Rupert Murdoch. 
 Citizen Murdoch not only uses his empire to promote his allies and punish his enemies (from Bill Clinton to Ted Turner); he goes so far as to put politicians on the payroll. That brilliant author Newt Gingrich was offered a $4.5 million payday from Mr. Murdoch's publishing house, HarperCollins, just as telecommunications matters financially crucial to the mogul's Fox properties were in play on Capitol Hill. Last week it was revealed by the London newspaper The Daily Telegraph that Mr. Murdoch had again misused HarperCollins, this time in a manner that even his political allies might find offensive. Yet there has been mostly silence from conservative journalists about this scandal -- even in American media properties that Mr. Murdoch doesn't own.
What Mr. Murdoch did was to see to it that HarperCollins canceled its scheduled fall publication in Britain of a memoir by Chris Patten, the last British Governor of Hong Kong. Despite a HarperCollins cover story, The Telegraph uncovered a smoking in-house memo that revealed the truth: Mr. Patten's sin had been to criticize the Government of China, whose favor Mr. Murdoch needs if he is to expand his already burgeoning TV and movie deals in the vast market it controls.
This is at least the fourth time that Mr. Murdoch has sold out the principles of an independent press to curry favor with China. He removed BBC World News from his satellite TV broadcasts to China after the Chinese complained of its coverage of dissidents; he had HarperCollins publish a propagandistic biography of Deng Xiaoping by Deng's daughter while Deng was still in power; he invested millions in a joint venture with The People's Daily, China's Communist Party paper.
Mr. Murdoch's latest outrage should horrify anyone who believes in human rights, particularly American conservatives who've spoken out about religious persecution in China. They'd cheer Mr. Patten's book. In pages I've seen from the manuscript-in-progress -- to be published in the U.S. this fall by Random House's Times Books imprint -- he eloquently rebukes unnamed Westerners who pursue the "crude and cynical strategy" of "tempering criticism of China's behavior at home or abroad in return for market access."
Mr. Patten further argues that the "sensible management of a developing economy" should have nothing to do with "torturing people, censoring what they can read or write, locking them up without due legal process, hunting opponents into silence or exile, dispersing crowds with bullets. . . ." What does it tell us about Rupert Murdoch's journalistic priorities that he would kill Mr. Patten's book at the same moment his Fox News Channel (slogan: "News without bias") hires the cybergossip Matt Drudge?
In England, the journalist and historian Timothy Garton Ash has in protest dumped HarperCollins as his publisher; the novelist Doris Lessing, another HarperCollins author, has declared Mr. Murdoch's editorial intervention "so shocking I can't find words for it." In America, let's see how much of this scandal even makes it into Murdoch publications like The New York Post and The Weekly Standard, let alone if any prominent conservatives, whether HarperCollins authors like Robert Bork and Peggy Noonan or not, speak up in protest. Will those who've accused the "mainstream media" of being in cahoots with a Democratic Administration remain silent while their own media patron toadies to the most powerful totalitarian Government in the world?

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Index Unchanged for a 2d Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators, a measure of forthcoming trends in the economy, was unchanged in January for the second consecutive month to show a moderating pace of economic growth, the Conference Board said today.
The index last rose in November, by one-tenth of a percent. 
 "The leading indicators point to moderation of the expansion and low risk of a recession in 1998," a statement from the private business research group, based in New York, said.
In a survey, Wall Street economists had forecast the leading indicators index would rise by a tenth of a percent.
In a separate report issued today, the Commerce Department said that sales of new homes surged 10.3 percent in January to an unexpectedly strong seasonally adjusted annual rate of 877,000 units. The supply of unsold homes fell to a record low.
"The strength reflects an extremely favorable financing environment, consumers that are extremely confident and extremely unusual weather," Richard Berner, chief economist at the Mellon Bank Corporation, said.
The increase reversed a 9.4 percent drop in home sales in December, when the annual sales rate was 795,000 units.
But analysts said January's sales pace could not be sustained for long, in part because the financial crisis in Asia might slow growth in the United States.
"The outlook is good, but we are anticipating some slippage," probably beginning in the second quarter, David Seiders, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders, said.
Five of the 10 indicators that make up the leading index rose in January, with the most significant increases in the money supply, manufacturers' new orders of nonmilitary capital goods and consumer expectations.
The biggest negative factors in the leading index were manufacturers' new orders of consumer goods and materials, the interest rate spread and vendor performance.
The report also said the index of coincident indicators, a gauge of present economic conditions, rose by three-tenths of a percent after a rise of four-tenths of a percent in December that was previously reported as a three-tenths of a percent rise.
January's 877,000 units matched November's rate, and was the highest since March 1986, when the rate was a record 880,000, the Commerce Department said.
Sales jumped 19 percent in the West and 13.1 percent in the South. Sales dipped 1.4 percent in the Northeast and 1.2 percent in the Midwest, the department said.
The median price of a new home in January was $148,000, up from $143,000 in December.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Leading Indicators" tracks index of 10 indicators designed to "lead," or predict overall economic activity. Graph runs from August 1996 through January 1998. (Source: The Conference Board)

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Invites Iraqi to a Talk About Oil

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 3

 BODY:
Secretary General Kofi Annan today invited the Iraqi Foreign Minister to New York to talk about problems with the program that allows Iraq to sell limited quantities of oil to buy food and medicine.
Discussions on the "oil for food" program have normally been conducted in Baghdad by lower-level officials. 
 The Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, could arrive as early as next week, shortly before the United Nations sends a team of experts to Iraq to assess the country's ability to pump and export more oil.
The Security Council last month agreed to allow Iraq to sell $5.2 billion every six months; Iraq says it can produce only $4 billion and wants money to repair its equipment.
Iraq has also complained that the United Nations is meddling with Iraqi prerogatives in plans it has drawn up for an enlarged oil-for-food plan, including a proposal to increase supply of electricity to Kurdish-held areas of the country. All United Nations-supervised imports and improvements in the country are intended to relieve the suffering of Iraqis who have lived under sanctions for more than seven years.
Mr. Annan's willingness to hear out Iraq's many grievances about United Nations programs is a departure from earlier practice, when the Security Council -- under urging of the United States -- sought to isolated Iraq, demanding that Baghdad abide by the rules and not try to change them.
The Secretary General, taking a different line, has spoken of the need to not humiliate Iraq but to draw it back into the community of nations. His comments here and in Baghdad about understanding and respecting the Iraqis are at considerable variance with the more punishing language often used in Washington.
Iraq has been under a comprehensive economic embargo since its 1990 invasion of Kuwait and must be certified free of all weapons of mass destruction before those sanctions can be lifted. Even then, it will be subject to extensive monitoring.
In the last year, however, Iraq has experimented with a variety of tactics for evading the arms inspection system that is closing in on some of President Saddam Hussein's most sensitive properties, where arms inspectors believe that documents and possibly weapons or their components may be hidden.
After threatening in recent months to end cooperation with the inspectors of the Special Commission, Iraq scored a diplomatic point when Mr. Annan went to Baghdad last month to broker an agreement that averted American military action. Some members of the Council, in particular Britain and the United States, would have preferred that the Iraqis did not get the opportunity to deal directly with the Secretary General.
On Monday, British and American diplomats hailed the Security Council resolution endorsing Mr. Annan's agreement because it returned the initiative to the Council's control even though the document did not authorize the use of force against Iraqi violations.
Today Mr. Annan was completing plans for a new kind of inspection system to be used at eight Iraqi "presidential sites," a departure Baghdad demanded. The Secretary General met with Richard Butler, executive chairman of the Special Commission; Hans Corell, the United Nations legal counsel, and Jayantha Dhanapala, Under Secretary General for Disarmament Affairs and leader of the group of diplomats and inspectors who, working under the commission, will visit the sites together.

HEADLINE: Budget Surplus Nears, And Plans for It Appear

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Just hours after the Congressional Budget Office predicted that the first Government surplus would appear this year, the chairman of the House Budget Committee said today that Congress should consider using part of the surplus to create Individual Retirement Accounts for workers paying into the Social Security system.
The chairman, Representative John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, made the suggestion flanked by the House Republican leadership, which had gathered to take political credit for the budget office's forecast of a surplus of $8 billion for the 1998 fiscal year ending Sept. 30. 
 The office also projected a $9 billion surplus next year, and a $67 billion surplus by 2002.
Injecting a new idea into the debate over the 1999 budget, Mr. Kasich suggested that some of the surplus could be devoted to tax cuts and some to the creation of I.R.A.'s.
"Why not let every single taxpayer who's currently paying into Social Security get an individual retirement account established that will be filled with money that comes from the surplus?" he asked.
With surpluses emerging for the first time in three decades, this year's budget debate is expected to be dominated by the question of how to use the influx of new revenue.
President Clinton, in an effort to keep Republicans from seeking to use the surplus for tax cuts, has already called for the surpluses that are projected for the next five years to be preserved to shore up the Social Security system for the retirement of the baby boom generation. Senate Republicans are looking to use the surplus to start paying down the more than $5 trillion national debt.
Speaker Newt Gingrich also called today for surpluses to be used to "protect Social Security for our parents" and "to begin the transition so that our children have the opportunity to have a personal retirement account with an interest buildup."
But he did not specifically endorse Mr. Kasich's idea, which would throw into an election year the politically sensitive question of whether to reshape Social Security.
Mr. Kasich did not say what portion of the surplus he would devote to I.R.A.'s or who would be given the authority to manage the investments, calling the idea preliminary.
"The bigger the surplus we end up with the more can be put into an Individual Retirement Account," he said.
With Republicans fractured over issues of tax cutting and spending, the House is not expected to unveil its own budget proposal until late April. While the Senate budget committee is considering $30 billion in tax cuts over five years -- somewhat more than proposed by President Clinton -- House Republicans are pushing for higher tax cuts.
Social Security is currently financed out of payroll taxes levied on workers and their employers, and benefits are paid out of those taxes. A shift toward I.R.A.'s would change it so that rather than drawing on payroll tax receipts to pay benefits, retirees would draw on money saved and invested in the stock and bond markets in the years leading up to retirement.
Any transition from the first system to the second would be difficult because if individual accounts were financed out of today's payroll taxes, the Government would then be short of money to pay current retirees. Using the surplus could help make the transition.
But while Wall Street and conservatives favor such a move, it would be enormously controversial. Individual accounts are strongly opposed by powerful groups that lobby for the elderly and relatively few Democrats have publicly endorsed any shift toward an investment-oriented approach. Liberal Democrats have long run for office as the protectors of the Social Security system.
Mr. Clinton has called for a national debate this year over how to preserve the solvency of the system when 76 million members of the baby boom generation begin retiring in 2010. He has proposed a White House conference on the issue for December -- after the election.
The election was also very much on the minds today of the Republican leaders who wanted to showcase the surplus as an accomplishment of the Republican-controlled Congress and steal some of the credit from the President.
"Everyone was projecting deficits for the rest of our lives," Mr. Gingrich said.
The deficit has dropped to $22.6 billion for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 from a high of $290 billion in 1992. The Congressional Budget Office's surplus projections remain lower than that of many private sector economists who say the surplus could reach as high as $50 billion this year.

HEADLINE: LIFE BY DESIGN;
Fertility For Sale

 BODY:
As reproductive technology has advanced, the law of supply and demand has inevitably clicked in. Some clinics have had trouble finding women to donate their eggs for implantation in infertile women. That has led to a medical and ethical debate over whether donors should charge for their eggs and, if so, how much. The St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., recently accelerated that debate by offering $5,000 for donors, double the rate of many clinics. A variety of experts were asked whether women should be permitted to sell their eggs on the open market:

Robert Wright is the author of "The Moral Animal: Evolutionary Psychology and Everyday Life." 
 Is a woman who gets several thousand dollars for a few eggs being exploited? The claim is not on its face ridiculous; a donor undergoes an unpleasant and risky procedure that is invasive both physically and in a less tangible sense. What is ridiculous is the idea that the woman is more exploited if she gets $5,000 than if she gets $2,000. Yet that is the implicit logic of some who argue for limiting fees lest we degrade women by turning their eggs into commodities.
Critics of high fees say it's all right to compensate donors, just not to entice them. But that distinction faded years ago, when infertile women began paying more than a few hundred dollars for eggs. They found that if they didn't pay real money, they'd get no eggs. This is the market at work: a willing buyer, a willing seller. Is there any reason to get between them?
Sometimes society plausibly says yes, as with drug sales and prostitution. Personally, I don't see a comparably strong argument in this case. If there is one, maybe we should take eggs off the market. But what's the point of pretending they aren't already there?
 
Cynthia Gorney is the author of "Articles of Faith: A Frontline History of the Abortion Wars."
A precedent for limiting compensation for egg donation was set 15 years ago, when the most heated argument in infertility circles was about surrogate mothers -- women who volunteered to undergo artificial insemination and carry a baby to term for infertile couples. The ethical consensus then was that if a woman offers to lend out her own reproductive system because she wants to help someone else, we suppose we can't stop her, but she shouldn't be tempted to do it because she wants or needs money: a surrogate should be paid for medical expenses and lost time at work, and perhaps offered some modest extra cash to offset the physical discomfort of pregnancy. But the money should not be generous enough to make surrogacy an attractive line of work.
And as a rule, surrogate mothers still don't collect much money, nor should they. To be sure, this is partly because they deliver up fully developed human beings, which by law and venerable tradition may not be bought and sold. But it is also because surrogate mothers deliver up their own bodily organs -- their eggs and the use of their wombs -- and we have equally venerable tradition forbidding people to sell their body parts for profit.
Galloping technology and the escalating hopes of infertile couples are working together to push us much too far, too fast. There has got to be a point at which society declares to the infertile couple: We are sorry for your situation, but you cannot buy everything you want. We will not let you offer that young woman $10,000 for some of her eggs, just as we will not let you offer her brother $10,000 for one of his kidneys. The potential cost to both of them -- and to all the rest of us -- is too high.
 
Lee M. Silver, a biology professor at Princeton, is the author of "Remaking Eden: Cloning and Beyond in a Brave New World."
Why are physicians and bioethicists -- who are mostly male -- trying to limit monetary compensation to women who donate their eggs? In no other part of the economy do we limit the amount of money that can be paid to people who participate in risky or demeaning activities. Indeed, college students have long been enticed by high fees into participating in risky medical experiments.
But society expects women to be altruistic, not venal. And it insists that women be protected from themselves, on the assumption that they are unable to make rational decisions about their own bodies. And perhaps men feel threatened by the idea that women now also have a way to spread their seed upon the earth.
 
Robert Coles, a physician, is a professor of social ethics at Harvard and the author, most recently, of "The Youngest Parents: Teen-Age Pregnancy as It Shapes Lives."
We really don't know the long-term medical consequences for women who donate their eggs. There have been a few reports of serious side effects, like renal failure. But have researchers studied carefully enough what exposure to these fertility drugs does to women? If poor women become repeat donors because the process keeps getting more lucrative, will they increase their risk down the line for ovarian cancer? These are unanswered questions.
Most important, the widening divide between the rich and the poor poses an ethical dilemma: can we condone the "harvesting" of eggs from poor women, who may be putting their health at risk, for the benefit of the affluent?
 
Elizabeth Bartholet, a professor at Harvard Law School, is the author of "Family Bonds: Adoption and the Politics of Parenting."
The selling of human eggs puts at risk the donors' health and sacrifices their human dignity. It also encourages women to bear children who are not genetically related to them, so that their mates can have genetic offspring. This practice produces children who have lost one genetic parent -- in a world that already has an abundance of orphans who need homes.
We need to call a halt to further commercialization of reproduction to give policy makers a chance to consider the ethical issues involved in reproductive technology like egg selling, cloning and sex selection. We should follow the lead of other countries and establish a national commission to resolve these issues rather than leave them to the market.
 
Lori Arnold is a doctor at the Fertility and I.V.F. Center of Miami.
Most women who donate their eggs at our clinic do so because they want to help provide the gift of life. Many have children of their own; they want to help others experience the joys of motherhood.
The motive is altruistic, but that should not blind anyone to the practical difficulties. Donors are required to undergo treatment with fertility drugs, counseling, screening, ultrasound monitoring, blood work and numerous office visits. It takes weeks. And retrieving the eggs from their ovaries is a surgical procedure.
Also worth factoring in is that the donors are giving a couple the chance to have a family, with a child who has the father's genetic makeup. The donor also gives the recipient a chance to experience pregnancy, delivery and breast-feeding, thereby facilitating mother-baby bonding.
Thus compensation given to an egg donor is well deserved. Of course, there comes a point when a fee becomes self-defeating, since the cost is paid by the recipient -- few couples can afford to pay an unlimited amount. But donors deserve something more than a token. Ours receive $1,500 to $2,000; no one should begrudge them that.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Fall for 2d Day as Home Sales Surge

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were hammered again yesterday after the Government reported the pace of new-home sales surged 10.3 percent in January, casting more doubt about whether the economy could slow enough to keep inflation benign.
The 30-year bond price dropped 26/32, to 100 25/32, to yield 6.07 percent, up from 6 percent on Monday and the highest since mid-December. 
 The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, may have added volatility to the trading session. In testimony to the Senate Appropriations Committee, in support of funds for the International Monetary Fund to help the Asian economies, he said: "Many argue that the current crisis should be allowed to run its course without support from the International Monetary Fund or the bilateral financial backing of other nations. They assert that allowing this crisis to play out, while doubtless having additional negative effects on growth in Asia, and engendering greater spill-overs onto the rest of the world, is not likely to have a large or lasting impact on the United States and the world economy." Some traders may have taken that to mean that the American economy would not slow enough to hold down inflation.
But Mr. Greenspan added that while people who took that stand might well be correct, there was a small but not negligible possibility that the Asian events could have unexpectedly large negative effects in the United States. And while the odds are small, he said, it should not be left to chance.
Reaction to yesterday's strong housing data was predictable, analysts said. Traders sold, as they had on Monday, when the National Association of Purchasing Management index was stronger than expected.
The pace of new-home sales climbed to 877,000 units in January, up 10.3 percent relative to the 795,000 unit pace of sales during December.

HEADLINE: Heated Debate Is Expected Over Rate for Student Loans

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Congress has delayed a vote scheduled for today on reauthorizing the $40 billion Higher Education Act, the most important piece of Federal assistance to students, colleges and universities, so that Congress may air intensely conflicting views on interest rates for federally guaranteed student loans.
Unlike the rates on home mortgages and car loans, which are set competitively by banks, the interest rate on these college loans is fixed by Congress. And that makes for controversy. So while a House subcommittee hearing on the act will be held today, the debate on the interest rate has been reserved for tomorrow. 
 For the 33 years that the Government has been in the business of guaranteeing student loans, student organizations (frequently allied with Democrats) have lobbied for lower rates, while lenders (often joined by Republicans) have urged Congress to raise the rate so they can earn what they consider to be a fair profit.
Unless Congress acts, the interest rate will drop on July 1 -- to about 7.1 percent from 8.25 percent -- because of a change in the calculation of the formula. Banks oppose the drop and say they will have to curtail lending if that happens.
But Terry Hartle, a spokesman for the American Council on Education, a research and lobbying organization in Washington, said, "The question to be asked is: If I can get a mortgage for 6.75 percent, why do the banks need 8.2 percent to make a federally guaranteed student loan?"
The conflict is unusually heated this year partly because there are more than five million beneficiaries of Federal student-loan programs, more than the number of beneficiaries of any other social program except Medicare and Social Security.
A relatively small change in the interest rate can have a large impact. An undergraduate who borrows $20,000 at a rate of 7.45 percent, and repays it in 10 years, will pay a total of $28,426 -- of which $8,426 will be interest. If the rate was 8.25 percent, the student would pay nearly $30,000, of which $9,436 would be interest.
A student who borrows $80,000 to go to medical school, at a rate of 7.45 percent, and who pays it back in 25 years, will pay $176,580, of which $96,580 will be interest. If the interest rate was 8.25, the student would pay $189,228, $109,228 of it in interest.
Students and the Clinton Administration are delighted with the prospect of the continued low rates.
"We want to make the cost of education lower," said Vice President Al Gore last week, when he announced an Administration compromise plan that would set the rate at 7.3 percent, to pre-empt a larger increase.
But lobbyists for the lending institutions and their allies in Congress warn that the if rates are too low, many lenders, convinced that such loans would be unprofitable, would not make them. They warn that this could play havoc with students, colleges and universities nationwide.
In past years, the lending institutions have issued similar warnings without result. Yet, observers say, the lenders seem more serious now. Mark Brenner, a spokesman for the Education Finance Council, which represents institutions that buy student loans from banks, said yesterday, "It comes to this: Do you want to play chicken with July 1, 1998?"
The conflict is rooted in the question of what constitutes a reasonable profit for the lending institutions. The 1993 budget act requires that banks lend to students at the 91-day Treasury bill interest rate plus 3.1 percent, which currently comes to 8.25 percent, a figure that banks consider to be fair.
But the act also specifies that after July 1, the formula will change to one based closely on a Government bond rate, to be determined by the Secretary of Education. This is expected to produce a student loan rate of about 7.1 percent. Lenders say they cannot make a profit with such a low rate.
In reauthorizing the Higher Education Act, Congress has several options: It could let the lower rate stand; accept the Administration's compromise, or as lenders and their Congressional allies hope, substantially raise the rate.
Jean Frohlicher, executive vice president of the National Council of Higher Education Loan Programs, an umbrella organization of student loan providers, said, "Student loans are very difficult to manage. The lender is forbidden by law from making a credit investigation, which is what he normally would do, and then the student can keep on deferring payment of a loan.
"After he graduates from college, he may decide he's the world's greatest heart surgeon and go to medical school," Ms. Frohlicher continued, "and then when he gets his medical degree, he may join the Peace Corps or get some other low-paying job. And so the lender has his money hanging out there for 20 or more years."
While past debates have tended to follow party lines, the coming debate is not likely to, observers said.
Barmak Nassirian, a policy analyst for the American Association of State Colleges and Universities, which advocates for students, said, "The Congressional leadership, especially Buck McKeon, deserves credit for their commitment to fairness to the students."
Representative Howard (Buck) McKeon, Republican of California is the chairman of the House subcommittee on postsecondary education, training and lifelong learning and will preside at the hearing tomorrow. ,
"I'm not in love with the bankers," Mr. McKeon said. "I'm trying to do what's right for everybody."
In 1995 he unsuccessfully backed a bill that would have obliged students to start paying interest on their loans before graduation.
Still, Congress is faced with a Solomon-like decision. As Mr. Hartle put it, "Ultimately, the best Congress can do is come up with a bill that will make everybody a little unhappy, but not too unhappy."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Dream of Glory. Penn Station's, That Is

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
PHILIP K. HOWARD grew up as a minister's son in the hills of Kentucky, which he says was a lot like living in the Bible. There were floods, there was typhoid, and in 1958, when he was bitten by a rabid cat, the vaccine had to be flown in by the state police. So he can still recall his wonder when he arrived at Pennsylvania Station, the glorious colossus then under destruction. It was 1963, and he was 14.
"I was dragging a trunk, and I remember the chaos of being in a building that was obviously grand, and that for some reason was being torn down all around me," he said. "I knew that something bad was happening." 
 Three and a half decades later, it surprises no one who knows him that the well-connected Mr. Howard -- lawyer, author and polished promoter -- has brought forth 11th-hour plans from the Municipal Art Society to turn virtually the entire General Post Office that stretches from Eighth Avenue to Ninth Avenue into a new Penn Station that recalls the original. Mr. Howard says the present Penn Station is a "slop sink" that makes arriving in New York "feel like coming through the service entrance."
Never mind that a bouillabaisse of city, state and Federal agencies has its own plans for the post office and Penn Station. Never mind that Mr. Howard, the new chairman of the Municipal Art Society, does not have a seat at the negotiating table. Never mind that Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who began pushing the idea six years ago, favors a more modest plan.
And never mind that the United States Postal Service has so far said it would give up only one-fifth of its neo-classical building, designed, like the original Penn Station, by McKim, Mead & White.
"It's not easy to go into some place and say, 'Get out, we want it all,' " said Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation, the three-year-old state agency charged with overseeing the project.
But Mr. Howard, who wrote a 1995 best-selling book, "The Death of Common Sense," about the evils of bureaucracy, insists he understands his enemy better than anyone, and that he will eventually win.
"Bureaucrats are not risk takers; they're not initiators," he said in an interview last week. "They are people who respond to the pressures and projects before them in a logical fashion." Bureaucrats, he added, "never come up with vision and hope and a sense of greatness."
Mr. Howard sees his part in the Penn Station drama as a creator of public opinion -- a traditional role for the Municipal Art Society, which led the fight for the Landmark Preservation Law after the original Penn Station was torn down. Mr. Howard argues that building a great train station would be "like giving millions of people the grandest home in the world."
MR. HOWARD spoke in a conference room at his law firm, Howard, Darby & Levin, which has floor-to-ceiling second-floor windows that give him an excellent view of life on the Avenue of the Americas. "There's Herb Wachtel," he said, as the Wachtel, Lipton lawyer passed by. Sometimes people wave up to Mr. Howard from the street. Once John Gutfreund, whom Mr. Howard was representing in Mr. Gutfreund's dispute with his old firm, Salomon Brothers, made what Mr. Howard describes as in impolite gesture from the corner.
"He's a very funny guy," said Mr. Howard, who by this time was giving a tour of another conference room decorated with photographs of Amelia Earhart and a wooden propeller from an airplane that won a 1913 race across the English Channel.
"Artifacts of human accomplishment," Mr. Howard said.
He continued his tour into the men's room, to show off William Eggleston photographs of the Old South. "We're leaving," said a cheerful Mr. Howard when a startled colleague walked in.
The law firm offices were designed by Richard Nash Gould, the same architect who drew up the Municipal Art Society plans for Penn Station. Under these designs, the new Penn Station would have a ticketing hall and a seating concourse each the size of Grand Central Terminal's main hall, as well as an auditorium and a conference center. Other proposals are far more modest -- and realistic, officials there say.
Postal officials are in fact meeting this week, and could approve a scaled-down compromise -- bad news for Mr. Howard. Mr. Howard, who two weeks ago took his plans to a lawyer in the office of Erskine Bowles, President Clinton's chief of staff, says he will continue to take his plans to the public, the Congress and the White House.
"No way are we going to accede just because they reach a compromise," he said.
Mr. Howard, 49, first came to the northeast as a scholarship student at the Taft School in Watertown, Conn. He went on to Yale, majoring in economics and city planning, toiled very briefly as a photographer for Glamour magazine, went to the University of Virginia Law School, and worked at the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. In 1983 he started his own firm. He has four children, and lives in a 1908 building in Gramercy Park. His wife, Alexandra Cushing Howard, is an architectural historian.
In the early 1980's, Mr. Howard joined the board of the art society, which a decade earlier had helped save Grand Central. He became chairman of the society last year.
"A great train station," Mr. Howard said, "makes the meanest of us feel rich and powerful."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Philip K. Howard, who was saddened by the destruction of Pennsylvania Station in 1963, hopes its glory can be re-created. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Saying He's No Isolationist, Gephardt Backs New Aid to I.M.F.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
Declaring that he had been "misunderstood and misrepresented" as a protectionist and isolationist last year, the Democratic leader of the House, Richard A. Gephardt, yesterday threw his support behind the Clinton Administration's efforts to win $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Gephardt successfully led the drive last year to kill new authority for President Clinton to negotiate trade agreements, after a long fight over whether to require that America's trading partners adhere to minimal standards for treating workers and curbing environmental pollution. Unable to win over enough members of his own party, Mr. Clinton withdrew the legislation, after charging that Mr. Gephardt's ardor for protecting American workers had harmed the country's ability to use trade accords as a tool of foreign policy. Administration officials have indicated they see no chance for a new accord on what is called fast-track authority now, as mid-term elections approach. 
 For the White House, last year's trade defeat made Mr. Gephardt's support for financing the I.M.F. essential, especially at a time when the markets are looking for signs of whether Congress will continue to support the fund's effort to stabilize the reeling economies of Asia.
For Mr. Gephardt, of Missouri, his speech yesterday was also tinged with Presidential politics. He is widely expected to challenge Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic nomination for President, and his appearance in New York seemed part of his effort to repair ruptured relations with foreign policy specialists and major players -- and donors -- on Wall Street, whom he met over a private lunch.
Mr. Gephardt's last public appearance on Wall Street was during a street demonstration last fall on the trade legislation, pitting him directly against America's largest multinational corporations, which had campaigned unsuccessfully for the new trading authority.
Mr. Gephardt's speech to the Council on Foreign Relations yesterday offered a detailed explanation of his position on fast-track legislation and his support for trying to help put America's fiercest economic competitors back on their feet. Though he has not demanded that the I.M.F. insist on labor standards or environmental protection as a condition of bailouts, Mr. Gephardt opposes any trade accords that fail to contain such requirements.
"There is no contradiction," Mr. Gephardt said after his speech.
"We have patients in the emergency room," he said of the Asian countries receiving the fund's aid. "You try to bring them back to life before you talk to them about their diet." The fund, however, has insisted that the patients agree to other tough conditions, like requiring South Korea and Indonesia to open their protected industries to foreign competition, and to break up politically connected monopolies.
Mr. Gephardt, who described himself as "a progressive internationalist," said that Washington had to demonstrate that it "has the ability to repair minor damage to the foundation" of the international economy, "or allow it to widen into a chasm which swallows the entire structure."
As Mr. Gephardt spoke, the Administration gained other allies in its effort to win passage of the financing for the I.M.F. The second-ranking Democrat in the House, David E. Bonior of Michigan, suggested that he is reconsidering his opposition to providing the $18 billion. His spokeswoman, Gretchen Kline, said that he might vote for the financing if the Administration pressed for an overhaul of the I.M.F.'s programs. The White House has said that it supports reforms, but notes that it controls only 18 percent of the vote within the fund's governing board.
Conservative Republicans, however, have insisted that they will vote against the bill unless it includes a provision barring American foreign aid to institutions that counsel or perform abortions. President Clinton appears likely to veto any bill that includes the abortion language; the same dispute scuttled an effort to win financing for the I.M.F. in the last Congressional session.

HEADLINE: An 'Icon of Technology' Encounters Some Rude Political Realities

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
William H. Gates walked into the Senate hearing room today flanked by his two home state Senators, Slade Gorton and Patty Murray of Washington, like a couple of bodyguards ready to ward off the blows.
Mr. Gates arrived in town Monday to lay the groundwork, shake hands, answer questions and play the political game he had been accused of ignoring for way too long. But in a few short hours before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Mr. Gates saw his spruced-up image sputter all over again. 
 The word monopolist bounced around the room so many times it felt like an echo chamber. His company, the Microsoft behemoth, was likened to a giant hair ball that consumes everything in its path and an 800-pound gorilla with one too many calluses. It was suggested he was disingenuous and greedy and naive.
The Senators of the Judiciary Committee, who had gathered to hear Mr. Gates state his case, took a kind of giddy delight in making the wealthiest man in America squirm in his seat. And if Republicans felt any skittishness about their trustbusting line of questioning it did not show.
"At the end of the day, what really counts is building good software," a shellshocked Mr. Gates said just before the hearing concluded, summing up his corporate philosophy.
"But not if there is predatory pricing and monopolistic practices," said Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah, a state with a fair computer industry of its own. Mr. Hatch, who heads the committee and invited Mr. Gates to testify, said, "It isn't just the business of selling software, but selling it fairly."
It was clear everyone was really there to see and hear Mr. Gates, whose net worth ticked up from $46 billion with every passing minute. Not even Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader from Mississippi, could resist making a morning cameo appearance.
The line for a seat in the hearing room started before dawn and by 10 A.M. it snaked around corners, up ramps and down hallways.
Two State Department interns took the day off to watch history unfold, they said. "It's the first time in our generation that we have been able to witness something like this," said Eric Reed, as he waited for a seat, a dog-eared copy of "Cannery Row" in his hand. "He's the icon of technology. You can always see a Senator or a Congressman, but not Gates."
To his credit, Mr. Gates never lost his composure. With his loose-fitting suit and his raspy voice, cracking like an adolescent's, he talked shop with the Senators. Painting himself as a kind of plucky Horatio Alger, he talked about his philanthropy and the vigor of the high-technology industry. Look at all the jobs, he said, and the money that is being pumped into the economy.
But his competitors would have none of it. "They have done everything they can think of to put us out of business," said Jim Barksdale, the president and chief executive of Netscape Communications, Microsoft's chief critic and its largest competitor on the Internet landscape.
"How many of you use PC's," Mr. Barksdale said, asking the spectators to raise their hands. About three-quarters of the room did. "Now how many of you have a computer with Internet Explorer?" he asked, referring to Microsoft's product. Almost the same number of hands flew up again.
"That is a monopoly," he said, happily.
In another exchange, several Senators said they had conducted their own expeditions. They had their staffs call up sales representatives for Dell Computer. In each case, representatives gave the clear impression they could not offer Netscape.
"I'm not quite sure," Senator Mike DeWine of Ohio quoted one representative as saying, "it has something to do with Microsoft."
Senator Herb Kohl, the Wisconsin Democrat, asked why Microsoft's percentage of sales to profits was so much higher than those of businesses in other industries. His not so subtle suggestion was that Mr. Gates was a monopolist looking to safeguard his treasure chest.
"That's an extraordinary profit level in America," Mr. Kohl said. "If your industry would be a lot more competitive, your prices would be a lot lower, your profits would be lower, the value of the shares would go down, and the value of your shares would go down. That's just the way it works."
But it was Senator Hatch, whose state is home to another Microsoft competitor, Novell, who demanded a yes or no from Mr. Gates on whether his company interferes with Netscape's ability to promote or market itself.
"You are not giving me an answer," Senator Hatch said bluntly.
In the end, Mr. Gates delivered a nuanced answer that did not fully satisfy the Senator.
Clearly relieved, Mr. Gates walked up to a cluster of microphones and delivered a few final words to reporters, no more questions allowed. "I enjoyed this opportunity," he said. Then he left, walking into a crowd of cheering high school students who spied him on his way out.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Linking Aid to Jakarta To Its Reforms

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Hours after President Suharto of Indonesia met a special American envoy, top Administration officials told Congress today that the White House could not support additional emergency aid to Indonesia from the International Monetary Fund unless Mr. Suharto makes "adequate progress" toward economic reforms he agreed to in January.
The statement by the Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, came hours after the envoy sent by President Clinton, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, emerged from a 90-minute meeting with Mr. Suharto without a commitment that he would end Indonesia's resistance to the mandates for change that were part of a $43 billion I.M.F. bailout. 
 Under questioning today by members of a subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee, Mr. Summers said that "appropriate policies would be a prerequisite for support" for the United States to back the disbursement of an additional $3 billion to Indonesia, perhaps as early as March 15.
The United States holds 18 percent of the votes in the I.M.F., a multinational organization that is assisting several Asian countries, but it exercises a virtual veto over its actions.
In an interview after his testimony, Mr. Summers emphasized that he was not threatening Indonesia, but merely restating "the standard U.S. position," when it comes to judging whether nations have complied with the conditions set by the I.M.F.
Nonetheless, senior American officials said the Administration was trying to send a signal that Indonesia's population, its strategic importance in Asia and the possibility of heightened violence would not result in a special dispensation for Mr. Suharto to ignore the conditions contained in the aid package he signed in mid-January.
It is clear, however, that some officials in the Administration are loath to cut off Indonesia's aid, even temporarily. Treasury officials are worried that a retreat by the I.M.F. could lead to further economic deterioration as remaining investors flee, fearful that the bailout of the country is collapsing.
At the State and Defense Departments, and among participants in the daily White House meeting on the Indonesia emergency, there are fears of further outbreaks of ethnic violence against Chinese in Indonesia, who own many of the country's businesses. New violence, one official said recently, "would be blamed on the Fund, and on us."
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, alluded to these concerns today in responding to questions from the Foreign Operations Subcommittee in the Senate.
"The I.M.F. faces a very difficult issue," he said, adding that "on the one hand, it seems to me that you do have to have compliance with their conditions if they're going to release," the next $3 billion in aid.
"On the other hand, I don't think any of us should have illusions about the seriousness of this decision because Indonesia is in a very difficult situation, and there are all sorts of very serious consequences that can come from that," he said.
This is, he said, "a very grave moment" in Indonesia.
In Jakarta today, a spokesman for Mr. Suharto repeated the President's insistence that he would put together his own economic policies, which he has called "I.M.F.-plus."
"President Suharto explained the importance of I.M.F. support because of its high reputation, but the President also explained that there had been no convincing signs that the rupiah will recover in the short term," said the spokesman, Murdiono, referring to the plunge in the value of the Indonesian currency.
"The President stated that he will implement the program led by the I.M.F.," said Mr. Murdiono, who like many Indonesians uses only one name. "However, the 'plus' in 'I.M.F.-plus' is to find ways to stabilize the rupiah at a fair level."
Mr. Mondale's meeting with Mr. Suharto was described by American officials today as inconclusive. The Indonesian leader, who emerged as Indonesia's ruler in the aftermath of a coup in 1965, apparently hinted at some imminent actions that might give the I.M.F. a justification for releasing the next installment of funds.
But the decisions all belong to Mr. Suharto, who in recent weeks has often overruled his economic advisers. Mr. Mondale's trip was motivated in part by rumors that Mr. Suharto is preparing to dismiss most of his economic team and replace them with close friends who are assumed to be more hostile to the terms laid out by the I.M.F.
Mr. Suharto is also expected to bring aboard a new Vice President, B. J. Habibie, whose expensive Government project to build a national airplane was attacked by the Fund as a waste of Government resources.
Emerging from the meeting this morning, Mr. Mondale said the two men had discussed Mr. Suharto's controversial idea of artificially pegging the rupiah to the dollar, a risky step that could send interest rates soaring and lead to a rash of bank failures. Faced with strong opposition from the United States, Japan and Europe, Mr. Suharto has recently said the currency plan would be delayed but not scrapped. His threat to proceed with the plan, some analysts in Jakarta and Washington say, is proving to be both a useful bargaining chip and a symbol of his autonomy.
"I think he is trying to show that he does not want to be dependent on the I.M.F.," an Indonesian economist said. "He doesn't want Indonesia being told what to do by the I.M.F."
Today, Mr. Mondale was cautious in describing his meeting, telling reporters: "The way to deal with the severe currency problems faced by Indonesia is to deal with the underlying problems. There are no quick fixes that provide an alternative."
Mr. Mondale made no references to any discussion of Mr. Suharto's vice presidential choice or other political issues, though Administration officials said such talk was one reason that a former Vice President, rather than an economic official, was sent to Jakarta. It is a delicate issue, touching on who will be in a position to succeed Mr. Suharto who is 76.
Signs of an anti-American backlash have emerged here in statements ranging from newspaper columns to Government officials to ordinary citizens.
"We are now in a very humiliating position: some foreigners are coming to dictate to us," said Adi Sasono, who manages a policy institute headed by Mr. Habibie, the next vice president.
On Monday, as Mr. Mondale arrived in Jakarta, one member of that assembly, Amir Santoso, had a tart word of welcome.
"Walter Mondale may give advice, but he must not dictate to us because we are a sovereign nation," Mr. Amir said.

HEADLINE: KEY SENATE PANEL PASSES RESOLUTION TO EXPAND NATO

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted overwhelmingly today to reshape the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, founded in 1949 to stop the spread of Communism in Europe, by adding three former foes, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.
The committee's 16 to 2 vote, reflecting only modest misgivings on the right and the left, sent a resolution to approve NATO expansion to the full Senate, which is expected to pass it later this month by the necessary two-thirds majority. 
 The committee chairman, Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, said it appeared that the NATO resolution would pass the full Senate "on a substantial positive vote." He called the vote today "an obvious vote of confidence in the democracies of Eastern Europe."
Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, the senior Democrat, said that "NATO enlargement is an historic opportunity for the United States, and voting to enlarge NATO now sets a positive course, expanding the zone of stability eastward." He called the measure "truly a bipartisan document, and one that will serve the interests of our country well."
Senator Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana, said that "NATO expansion will set the foundation for decades of European peace and prosperity." And he warned, "If we fail, historians may look back at the early post-cold-war period as a tragic loss of opportunities."
The opponents to the measure represented the ideological poles on the commmittee. On the right, Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri voted no because he was worried about what NATO's role might become. On the left, Senator Paul D. Wellstone of Minnesota argued that expansion to include former Soviet-bloc countries would dim the prospects for Russian democracy, economic reform and commitment to arms control.
And Senator Robert C. Smith, a New Hampshire Republican, began to circulate a letter, signed this evening by about a dozen Senators, his staff members said, that asks the Senate leadership to postpone the vote by the full Senate until after June 1.
The letter asks for the delay to allow for clarification on the questions raised about expansion, including its cost and whether or not new NATO members should first be admitted to the European Union.
While the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said he was not inclined to postpone the vote more than a week or two, senior Administration officials were more cautious. "We think we will win this vote, but this adds a little last-minute, last-ditch drama," one official said. "When the Senate votes is up to the Senate."
Senator Wellstone, a Democrat, said that he had agonized over voting no, that the Czech President, Vaclav Havel, "is a hero to me," and that "of all the decisions I've made as a Senator, this is the most difficult one."
But he added: "I'm very worried -- I've got a prickling in my finger tips -- about a redivision of Europe." Such an event, he said, would cause "a poisoning of relations with Russia and ultranationalists coming into power."
Senator Wellstone said that his father was born in pre-Soviet Ukraine and had fled before the 1917 revolution, and that his father's family was believed to have been murdered in the Stalin-era purges.
"He was the wisest man I've ever known," the Senator said, "but I think he'd be in agreement with George Kennan," the American diplomat and historian who said a year ago that "expanding NATO would be the most fateful error of American policy in the entire post-cold-war era."
Senator Ashcroft, a Republican who is considering a Presidential race, questioned in today's hearing "what the role of NATO is" now that the collapse of the Soviet Union has removed any threat to the alliance.
He said he worried that NATO was moving "from a defense of territory to a defense of the interests of member countries" anywhere in the world. "I have real reservations about what the role of NATO is, and should it be expanded not just to include new countries but redesigned as an instrument of international policy around the world."
"We need limits and safeguards," Mr. Ashcroft added. "Maybe we need a new organization, like a United Nations, with a standing army."
Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, said she had begun nearly a year's worth of hearings on NATO expansion "with an anti-NATO bent, and I've changed my mind." Citing the benefits of NATO forces in Bosnia, she said that a larger NATO would improve "a solidification of the European community" and a closer binding of the United States to Europe.
Her theme -- that this first round of expansion is fine, but let's be careful about a second round -- was echoed by other liberal and centrist Senators today. Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he would vote for this first round but added, "I share a lot of the concerns expressed about NATO."
Senator Kerry also expressed skepticism about the stated costs of NATO expansion, saying, "I've been very suspicious of cost analyses that keep getting reduced as the vote approaches."
Senator John Warner, Republican of Virginia, has introduced an amendment to delay any second round of NATO expansion for three years after the current round is approved. The Clinton Administration has sharply opposed any binding time delay.
His co-sponsor is Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who today introduced his own amendment, co-sponsored by Senator Warner, that would bar Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic from joining NATO until they are first admitted to the European Union.
In an interview today, Senator Moynihan cited the words of Mr. Kennan and said he was most concerned about the impact of expansion on Russia. "It's time to say, 'Hey, let's talk this one out, my heavens,' " the Senator said.
Administration officials said they took the worries over expansion seriously, but noted that the number of Senators expressing the most concern had been hovering at 20 or so since the summer.
