HEADLINE: ASYLUMS BEHIND BARS: A special report.;
Prisons Replace Hospitals for the Nation's Mentally Ill

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Michael H. had not had a shave or haircut in months when he was found one recent morning sleeping on the floor of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in suburban Lancaster, next to empty cans of tuna and soup from the church pantry.
There was little to suggest that he had once been a prosperous college graduate with a wife and two children -- until he developed schizophrenia, lost his job and, without insurance, could no longer afford the drugs needed to control his mental illness. 
 Charged with illegal entry and burglary, Michael H. was taken to the Los Angeles County Jail. The jail, by default, is the nation's largest mental institution. On an average day, it holds 1,500 to 1,700 inmates who are severely mentally ill, most of them detained on minor charges, essentially for being public nuisances.
The situation in the jail, scathingly criticized as unconstitutional by the United States Justice Department last fall, is the most visible evidence that jails and prisons have become the nation's new mental hospitals.
On any day, almost 200,000 people behind bars -- more than 1 in 10 of the total -- are known to suffer from schizophrenia, manic depression or major depression, the three most severe mental illnesses. The rate is four times that in the general population. And there is evidence, particularly with juveniles, that the numbers in jail are growing.
Some of these people have committed serious, violent crimes. But many more are like Michael H., whose family agreed to discuss his case on the condition that he not be identified: homeless people charged with minor crimes that are byproducts of their illnesses. Others are picked up with no charges at all, in what the police call mercy arrests, simply for acting strange.
The mentally ill at risk of being jailed include adults like Helen Rose Akanni, a woman with paranoid schizophrenia who was mistakenly charged with drunken driving and held for a week before a psychiatrist saw her. They include teen-agers like Jason E., a manic-depressive whose violence gives his father the choice of having him jailed or endangering his family.
"Part of mental illness in America now is that you are going to get arrested," said Laurie M. Flynn, executive director of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, an advocacy group of relatives and friends of people with mental disorders.
What experts call the criminalization of the mentally ill has grown as an issue as the nation's inmate population has exploded and as corrections officials and families of the emotionally disturbed have become alarmed by the problems posed by having the mentally ill behind bars.
The trend began in the 1960's, with the mass closings of public mental hospitals. At the time, new antipsychotic drugs made medicating patients in the community seem a humane alternative to long-term hospitalization. States also seized the chance to slash hospital budgets. From a high of 559,000 in 1955, the number of patients in state institutions dropped to 69,000 in 1995.
But the drugs work only when they are taken, and when they work, patients are tempted to stop, because of the unpleasant side effects. As states lagged in opening a promised network of clinics and halfway houses to monitor patients, obtaining treatment became harder. Health insurers restricted coverage, for-profit hospitals turned away the psychotic, and new laws made it more difficult to commit disturbed people. Thousands fell through the cracks.
Coincidentally, with voters willing to spend freely to fight rising crime rates, states were building more jails and prisons. Jails became the only institutions left open to the mentally ill 24 hours a day.
Homelessness was the most public sign of the problem. But for growing numbers of people, the price of mental illness was arrest. Ms. Akanni, for example, became upset when she could not find her 2-year-old daughter; the girl had fallen asleep under a bed. To calm herself, Ms. Akanni went for a drive, but she got in an accident. When she gave her name as the Lord God Almighty, an officer arrested her for drunken driving. A week passed before a psychiatrist saw her and she was able to explain that she had a 2-year-old at home, alone.
When Ms. Akanni was released, she was arrested again, for abandoning her child. The girl had survived by eating garbage.
"The inmates we see in jail today are the same people I used to see in psychiatric hospitals," said Dr. Eugene Kunzman, the former medical director of the mental health program at the Los Angeles jail.
In many states, so many public hospitals have closed, or the laws regulating admission to hospitals have been made so tight, that sometimes the only way to get care is to be arrested. Resources are especially scarce for juveniles.
In Dallas, social workers advised Jason E.'s family to have him jailed to get treatment. He had assaulted both parents and his brother, and hospitals were too expensive or refused him because he was violent. Jason's father rejected the advice and kept him at home, only to be warned he could be charged with endangering his other son.
"It's tragic," said Judge Hal Gaither of the Dallas County Juvenile Court. "If you are a young person and mentally ill, you have to get arrested to receive treatment."
Though some people do benefit from regular medication while in jail, others suffer as the stress deepens their depression, intensifies delusions or leads to a psychotic break. Suicide is a risk: 95 percent of those who commit suicide in jail or prison have a diagnosed mental disorder, a study in the American Journal of Psychiatry found.
Locking up the mentally ill also has high costs for the nation's crowded prisons and jails.
Because judges are often reluctant to grant bail to the mentally ill, and because they need special treatment, they tend to stay in jail much longer than other inmates. On Rikers Island, New York City's jail, where 15 percent of new inmates have serious mental disorders, the average stay for all inmates is 42 days, but it is 215 days for the mentally ill, said Dr. Arthur Lynch, the official in the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation who oversees treatment in the jail.
Last year, when Rikers admitted 133,300 inmates, the city jail system treated 15,000 of them for serious disorders. And in a state that has only 5,800 adult patients in its public mental hospitals, New York's state prisons treat 6,000 inmates, 8.7 percent of their population, for serious disorders.
Legal Aid lawyers in the city are seeing more "junk arrests" of homeless mentally ill people, said Susan L. Hendricks, director of litigation for the Legal Aid Society in New York. "The city has turned prisons and jails into a catchment for mentally ill people who get into trouble," she said.
Jails and prisons often find themselves unprepared to deal with the mentally ill. Guards may not know, for example, how to respond to disturbed inmates who simply are not capable of standing in an orderly line for meals; a common result is that the inmates are put in solitary confinement.
"We are doing the best we can, but it is definitely frustrating for the officers," said Gayle Ray, the county sheriff for Nashville, where 142 inmates on antipsychotic medication, 8.6 percent of her jail system's 1,630 inmates, are housed on one floor of the Criminal Justice Center. "Jails were not designed to be mental hospitals, and what's happening is a real passing of the buck to another part of the system."
Advocates for the mentally ill say the clock is being turned back to the 19th century, when it was common in the United States to confine people with mental illness in jails. Mental hospitals, or asylums, grew out of a crusade in the 1840's by Dorothea Dix, the Boston reformer, who warned that "insane persons" were being confined in "cages, closets, cellars, stalls, pens: chained, naked, beaten with rods and lashed into obedience."
"Criminalization," said Dr. E. Fuller Torrey, a leading researcher of schizophrenia in Washington, D.C., "has been both a personal disaster for the mentally ill, and an institutional disaster for the criminal justice system."
 
The Jail
Faulting System In Los Angeles
In Los Angeles, an average of 1,000 new offenders a day are brought to the county jail system, seven separate jails spread across 4,000 square miles housing a total of 22,000 inmates. It is a logistical nightmare.
When the Justice Department investigated the jail last year, this was the screening procedure it found: On entering, each prisoner was issued a sheet and towel and was shown an informational video. Among other questions, the video asked new arrivals to tell jailers if they had a mental health problem.
Many of the sickest new arrivals did not, because they were in denial. Others did not respond because they had been to the jail before. They knew that if they did, they would be issued yellow jumpsuits, which made them easy targets for guards or other inmates. They might be locked 23 hours a day in dirty isolation cells. And any medication they had would be confiscated until a jail psychiatrist saw them, which could take weeks.
"Unconstitutional conditions exist at the Los Angeles County Jail," the report by the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division concluded, "including a deliberate indifference to the inmates' serious mental health needs."
The study, prompted by relatives of people who had been jailed, was the first Federal review of the predicament of the mentally ill in jail. It produced a case study of the forces that draw the mentally ill into jails, and of the problems that they pose for jails and that jails pose for them.
"The problem I see is that the whole concept of treatment of the mentally ill in jail is an oxymoron," said David Myer, who directs the Los Angeles Mental Health Department's programs in the jail. "Jail is a horrible place. It isn't good for people who are well. For someone who is mentally ill, it is terrible."
The troubles begin with the fact that the county jail is a jail, not a hospital. It is run by the sheriff's department, whose main mission is to keep discipline among its large population and to process inmates for court.
In addition, most deputies have little training in dealing with the emotionally disturbed, said Anita Dunsay, a recently retired clinical psychologist who worked in the jail. "The deputies tend to be fresh graduates of the sheriff's academy, and baby-sitting isn't what they joined up for, so they easily get angry at the mentally ill," she said.
One result, the Justice Department charged, was that even though l,700 inmates a day got some form of treatment, many more had mental illnesses that were going undetected. This was particularly true of those who were quietly depressed or had personality or anxiety disorders, illnesses for which California law does not mandate care. The Justice Department report also charged that record-keeping was so haphazard that some mentally ill inmates were lost in the system, while many illnesses were misdiagnosed and patients were given the wrong medication.
As a visitor toured the Central Jail three months after the report's release, mentally ill inmates in yellow jumpsuits could be seen meeting with a psychiatrist on a steel bench in a busy corridor. A stench from the jail's blocked sewer caused people to cover their noses and mouths. Cells reserved for the mentally ill were so crowded that some men had to sleep on the floor. Some babbled; others complained that they could not sleep because of rats in their quarters.
The physical conditions improved dramatically in January, when the sheriff's department, under threat of a Justice Department lawsuit, moved most of the mentally disturbed inmates to the county's new Twin Towers jail There, in an area dedicated to the mentally ill, the inmates are housed in clean, modern, one- and two-man cells.
The screening process was also updated: deputies now directly ask new arrivals if they are on medication. Already the number identifying themselves as mentally ill has increased, and Mr. Myer said he expected it would eventually climb by 50 percent.
"The moral of the story," Mr. Myer said, "is that if you want to get something done, you need to bring the power of the Federal Government in and threaten to take over your jail."
But even as the Los Angeles jail moves toward, in effect, creating its own mental hospital, there are still problems inherent in dealing with the mentally ill in any jail. Inmates, said Dr. Kunzman, the former medical director, are seldom in jail long enough to be stabilized on the right medication, to offer them adequate therapy or to plan for their care after release.
And so far the changes at the Los Angeles County Jail have affected mainly physical conditions, not treatment, said Marianne Baptista, an administrator at Step Up on Second, a mental health agency in Santa Monica whose caseworkers often search the jail for missing clients. "On our end, nothing's changed," she said.
Her agency's clients still often disappear into the jail after being arrested, without any notification to the clinic. "More often than not, once in jail, their medications are taken away from them or they are given something different, and then their symptoms come out again," she said. "Being in jail may make them more crazy."
That cycle can cause long-term physical damage, said Kay Redfield Jamison, a professor of psychiatry at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. "Every relapse you have increases the odds that your brain is being damaged and that you will have another relapse faster, just like with heart attacks," she said.
Without the state hospitals, experts say, a revolving door has been created, in which many mentally ill people cycle from clinics to homelessness to jail.
In Los Angeles, more than 70 percent of the severely mentally ill homeless have been arrested at least once, according to a report prepared for the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors by Carla Jacobs, a board member of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill.
Many mentally ill people do manage to get treatment and do not end up in jail, of course, especially those with higher incomes. But the magnitude of the problem is suggested by a survey by the alliance of families with a seriously mentally ill member; 40 percent of the ill individuals had been arrested.
Jails and prisons have only recently begun to keep statistics on the mentally ill who pass through them, and those numbers can vary according to the quality of a jail's screening or which mental disorders are counted.
On an average day, said Linda A. Teplin, a professor of psychiatry at Northwestern University Medical School, 9 percent of men and 18.5 percent of women in local jails -- about 56,000 people -- are severely mentally ill.
An estimated 10 percent of all inmates in state and Federal prisons, or 122,000 people, are severely mentally ill, said Allen J. Beck of the Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. And about 20 percent of juveniles in criminal justice facilities, or 20,000 people, are that ill, said Joseph Cocozza, director of the GAINS Center, a research organization in Delmar, N.Y.
It was Professor Teplin's research that first demonstrated that the mentally ill are arrested much more often than people in the general population. But the problem, she said, is not police callousness. "The police arrest the mentally ill because they have no other alternative," she said.
She recalled riding with the police in a Midwestern city one night when they received a call about a crazy man on a bus. The man, named Charlie, was both schizophrenic and a drunk. They took him to a detoxification center, where he fell asleep. But the detox center recognized him and insisted he was crazy, not drunk, so the police drove him to a hospital.
At the hospital the doctors also knew Charlie. Regarding him as difficult, they said he was an alcoholic to avoid admitting him.
Finally, the police arrested Charlie, Professor Teplin said. It was a cold night and they did not want him to freeze to death. He was charged with disorderly conduct.
 
The Delinquent
Young, Mentally Ill And Bound for Jail
The 16-year-old girl suffered from delusions and hallucinations. The diagnosis was "psychotic, not otherwise specified." Her father was in prison for sexually abusing her sister. Her mother was an alcoholic. Not surprisingly, the girl began skipping school. She got pregnant. She assaulted her mother.
Before most state hospitals were closed, the girl would probably have been committed to a state psychiatric hospital. But in Texas, where she lives, the juvenile court declared her a delinquent and sent her to the state's juvenile justice agency, the Texas Youth Commission. The commission sent her to its Corsicana Residential Treatment Center for seriously emotionally disturbed youths.
The girl personifies the problems facing many young people with mental disorders, said Linda Reyes, a psychologist and assistant deputy executive director of the commission. "Unless you are wealthy and can afford private doctors, you have to get arrested to get treatment," she said.
Even so, the commission is limited in what it can do. The girl refuses to take antipsychotic medication, and because Corsicana is not a hospital, its staff cannot make her take it. She is not making progress -- she walks around naked and urinates on the floor -- but by law, when her term expires, she must be released.
Incarcerating mentally ill adolescents is "tragic and absurd," Dr. Reyes said. "The system we have created is totally ineffective. It doesn't rehabilitate the kids. And it doesn't even take care of public safety, because when she is sent home, she will just get picked up again."
Of the 4,791 juveniles in the Texas agency's custody, 22 percent suffer from schizophrenia, manic depression or major depression. The national figure is similar: an estimated 20 percent of incarcerated juveniles are seriously emotionally disturbed.
When other psychiatric disorders are included, the percentages rise sharply. A recent survey by the California Youth Authority found that 35 percent of boys in its custody and 73 percent of girls need treatment, said its director, Francisco Alarcon.
One reason for the higher percentage of young people with mental illness in jail, specialists say, is that many states have cut budgets for adolescent psychiatric hospitals even more than those for adults.
"I had a 15-year-old girl who was hallucinating and psychotic," said Cathy Brock, a supervisor at the Letot Center in Dallas for runaway children. "And a staff member from Mental Health and Mental Retardation agreed she needed hospitalization. But then she said they were over budget for the year, so couldn't I find an offense that would get her arrested, like an assault?"
The Dallas County Juvenile Department has as large a budget for psychiatric hospitalization, $6.6 million this year, as the county's mental health department.
As a result, Ms. Brock said, "When I have a kid who is severely mentally ill and has been arrested, and the family has no resources, I will do everything I can to make sure that kid gets adjudicated." But urging judges and families to convict children, she said, "presents all kinds of ethical binds.".
Another reason these young people are incarcerated disproportionately is that they act out their illnesses more than adults, usually in aggressive and impulsive ways that can get them arrested, said the president of the National Mental Health Association, Michael Faenza.
There is evidence that the number of disturbed young people being arrested is increasing. At Corsicana, Dr. Reyes said, the proportion of juveniles on antipsychotic drugs has doubled to 80 percent since 1990.
But it is unclear whether this trend indicates more mental illness, or reflects tougher sentencing laws that are driving greater numbers of all young people behind bars.
Dr. Torrey, the schizophrenia expert, said he does not believe that social conditions, like the breakdown of the family and bad parenting, cause young people to become mentally ill. "What we are seeing," he said, "is the breakdown of the public mental health system."
 
The Asylum
Well-Meaning Plan To Close Hospitals
For a growing number of the mentally ill, it has come to this, said Dr. Michael Pawel, executive director of the August Aichhorn Center for emotionally disturbed juvenile offenders in Manhattan: "Jail has become the place where, when you have to go there, they have to take you in."
As thousands of the mentally ill end up behind bars, no one has estimated the cost of shifting so many of the mentally ill from one kind of institution, hospitals, to another, jails and prisons. Hospitals can cost three to four times more than prisons, but prisons cost more two to three times more than community clinics, not counting the substantial extra expense involved in treating the mentally ill in prison.
But because of the price exacted on the mentally ill themselves, some therapists and mental health advocates are reconsidering what they did in helping to close state hospitals.
"I was not wrong that antipsychotic medications were good," said Dr. Richard Lamb, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Southern California School of Medicine. Dr. Lamb worked in a state hospital in the 1960's and was among those pushing for the treatment of people outside hospitals. "But I was wrong about discharging so many people with severe problems."
Part of the premise, he recalled, was that governments would build places in communities where discharged patients could continue to take their drugs and get therapy. But, largely for economic reasons, this was never done.
Now, Dr. Lamb said he realizes, "Some people just need more structured care."
Thinking over what seemed at the time like a wonderful reform, he likened himself to the British colonel in "The Bridge Over the River Kwai." The colonel built a bridge for his Japanese captors because the idea was so magnificent. "What have I done?" he asked himself.

HEADLINE: Fraud Ruling Invalidates Miami Mayoral Election

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 4

 BODY:
Citing "a pattern of fraudulent, intentional and criminal conduct" in the casting of absentee ballots, a Florida judge voided Miami's mayoral election today and ordered a new vote to be held in 60 days.
The ruling, which overturned first-round balloting on Nov. 4 that led to the runoff election of Mayor Xavier L. Suarez, leaves the city without a mayor until the City Commission appoints one in the interim. Under the city charter, the commission, which is the city's legislative body and which is to meet on Thursday, has 10 days to make such an appointment. 
 The judge, Thomas S. Wilson Jr. of Circuit Court here, ruling in a lawsuit brought by the defeated incumbent, Joe Carollo, said there was no evidence that Mr. Suarez knew about the fraud.
The unusual court decision has thrown the city of about 360,000 residents into fresh turmoil as it tries to recover from a financial crisis that required appointment of a state oversight board in 1996 and from the convictions of a former city manager and a city commissioner who went to prison for bribery and obstructing justice.
The official who presides over the five-member commission, Commissioner Humberto Hernandez, is awaiting trial on Federal charges of mortgage fraud and money laundering in a case unrelated to city business.
Many Florida officials praised today's ruling for sending a message that election fraud would not be tolerated. Gov. Lawton Chiles said in a statement that the decision would "help restore integrity to the elections process and give people confidence that democracy works."
A state criminal investigation has so far led to the arrest of four campaign workers on charges of voting fraud in the election last November.
Today's ruling did not address the question of who should function as mayor in the interim, and both Mr. Carollo and Mr. Suarez immediately laid claim to the office. Members of the commission said today that they were considering holding the new election on May 5.
"It's going to bring pain to the city because it's going to be an abrasive campaign," Commissioner Tomas Regalado said of the special election, "but we needed this to clear the name of the city. To me this is the best thing that could have happened because after this election we come out clean."
Judge Wilson's ruling was a sweeping indictment of the absentee ballot system, which last month was the subject of a state grand jury report that found it riddled with flaws. The panel's finding included the casting of ballots in the name of dead people and manipulation of elderly voters.
Miami-Dade County has begun reforming the system by tightening requirements for the request and delivery of absentee ballots.
After a two-week trial last month in which 27 witnesses asserted their Fifth Amendment rights and refused to testify, Judge Wilson said 60 other witnesses he heard from gave ample evidence of fraud.
In his written decision the judge said the absentee ballots cast in the election included those from people who did not vote, did not live in Miami or the district in which their ballot was cast, and did not qualify as unable to vote at the polls. Several ballots were even doctored to alter a vote for Mr. Carollo into one for Mr. Suarez, the judge noted.
"This scheme to defraud, literally and figuratively, stole the ballot from the hands of every honest voter in the city of Miami," Judge Wilson wrote.
In a similar case in 1993, a state judge also threw out the results of a mayoral election in the nearby city of Hialeah and ordered a new vote.
Mr. Carollo, 42, a businessman who served as Mayor from 1996 to 1997, said he felt vindicated.
"It's a great day for Miami because democracy has been defended and protected," he said at a news conference outside the court. "We live in a great country, and I'm proud of being an American."
Mr. Suarez, 48, a lawyer who served as Mayor from 1985 to 1993 and has had a controversial four-month second tenure, said he would not appeal the decision because he was certain to win again. He said he ran a clean campaign and that he planned to implement measures for the new election "to assure that every single vote is exactly as proper, legal and kosher as a human being can possibly make it."
Mr. Carollo won a majority of the ballots cast at the polls in a first-round election, which included five candidates, but was 155 votes short of a majority over all because Mr. Suarez won most absentee ballots.
Mr. Suarez won the runoff on Nov. 13, with 23,598 votes to Mr. Carollo's 20,739. Judge Wilson's ruling today overturned the first-round election, thus invalidating the runoff.
Judge Wilson found that Mr. Hernandez's district was "the center of a massive, well-conceived and well-orchestrated absentee ballot voter fraud scheme."
A secretary for Mr. Hernandez is among the four campaign volunteers arrested in the ongoing criminal probe.
Mr. Suarez himself has contributed to the tragic-comical political scene here since the election by appointing Mr. Hernandez to preside over the commission despite his legal troubles and engaging in antics that have earned him ridicule.
Mr. Suarez has made headlines by trying to dismiss a popular police chief, threatening The Miami Herald with the withdrawal of city advertising unless the newspaper was "a lot nicer" to him and calling a state senator with a hard-to-pronounce name "Senator Cabbage" in a formal meeting.
Many Miamians said they were glad they would get another chance to vote.
"I hope there's a third candidate," said Jorge Gonzalez, 58, a construction worker.

HEADLINE: Report Shows a Strong and Diverse Job Growth for New York City

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The New York City economy added more new jobs in 1997 than in any year since 1984, the New York State Department of Labor said yesterday.
Perhaps just as important, the growth was diverse. The city even added jobs in what has been one of its historically most important, but chronically weak industries: apparel manufacturing. For the first time since 1978, the garment industry added workers -- only 400, but a gain nonetheless. 
 The new numbers -- the result of annual revisions to monthly job estimates that all states make at this time of year, a kind of economic summing up -- show that New York City added 54,800 net new jobs, up 69 percent from the 32,500 added in 1996 and the best one-year performance since the 77,700 jobs that were added in 1984. The city also continued to lead the state in economic performance. Of the 106,000 new jobs added statewide, 52 percent were in the city's five boroughs, the state said.
Most of the new jobs in the city were in so-called business-services fields like accounting and law, many of which are linked to Wall Street, and in retail and food service jobs that are linked to the boom in tourism and in construction. Manufacturing over all, aside from the garment industry, declined, but by a lesser amount -- 2,000 jobs lost in the city -- than in many previous years.
"The region's economic performance is still strong and as good as it's been in a long time," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, an economic consulting and research firm. Another plus, Mr. Zandi said, is that the growth has not been based on just a few pillars. Although the city and state economies have certainly been energized by the billions of dollars in bonuses and profits generated by Wall Street -- which leads indirectly to new job growth in areas like real estate and retailing -- the industry itself has been only one among many that added new workers during the year.
But the revisions, however strong, still represent what by some measures is a half-empty glass for the city and the state. Economic growth in New York City and New York State and in New Jersey all lagged behind growth in the nation as a whole in 1997. And in comparison with genuinely booming places like California and high-technology corners of the South, the region looks almost anemic.
Total nonfarm employment in California, for example, rose 3.5 percent last year, according to the revised job numbers, and the national average -- which will not be released until sometime this spring -- is expected to be about 2.7 percent, according to estimates by Regional Financial Associates.
In New York City, by contrast, the job count rose 1.7 percent, while New York State saw growth of 1.3 percent in total nonagricultural employment. New Jersey did slightly better, up 2.4 percent for the year.
Unemployment in New York City also remains far higher than in the nation as a whole. Even with the revisions, which added 8,600 private-sector jobs to the preliminary total, the average unemployment rate for the city over the year was 9.4 percent. In more than a few months, the unemployment rate was twice the national average.
New Jersey, which released its numbers on Tuesday, also had a strong year in 1997, its best performance in adding new jobs on a year-to-year basis since 1987, the State Labor Department said. For the year, New Jersey employers added 86,500 new jobs. As in New York, the strongest growth was in the broadly defined service category.
Of the new jobs, 48,400 were in services, including 13,200 in the personnel supply industry, which provides temporary workers to companies, 6,300 in computer and data processing jobs and 8,000 in health care.
Stephen Kagann, the chief economic adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, said he thought another important trend for the year was what he called a turnaround in the manufacturing of durable goods in upstate New York, where job growth in many communities has been weak or nonexistent through much of the 1990's.
Companies making durable items -- those meant to last longer than a year, like machinery or furniture or computers -- employed 1,100 more people over the year in upstate New York, the first gain in perhaps a decade, he said. In the 10 counties of the New York City metropolitan area, by contrast -- the city plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties -- manufacturing of durable goods continued to decline, down 1,800 jobs from 1996, Mr. Kagann said.
Other numbers in the report similarly jumped out not so much for their magnitude as for their direction. As recently as Tuesday, state officials said they had expected the job totals for apparel manufacturing to follow the long-ingrained pattern downward. The projected loss for 1997: about 1,600 jobs. The upward revision of 2,000 jobs, inched the category into positive territory, if only just barely.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Matchmaking, or How Conductors and Orchestras Get Together

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

 BODY:
Symphonic matrimony is rarely for life and not always for love. Odd couples abound in the relationships between conductors and the orchestras they direct. Some are marriages of convenience. Others involve a dowry of sorts. For every good coupling there are others one can't quite understand.
Christoph von Dohnanyi and the Cleveland Orchestra show us that one plus one can equal four or five: a good conductor and a fine orchestra reacting chemically into music-making higher than the sum of its parts. Esa-Pekka Salonen energizes the Los Angeles Philharmonic with his youth and progressive ways. Moving in the opposite direction, Kurt Masur's sterner tenure has put a brake on the New York Philharmonic's tendencies toward excess. 
 Like Mr. Dohnanyi, Mr. Masur will apparently leave his orchestra in four years. If this divorce is not quite free of dispute, his colleague's in Cleveland appears to be amicable.
But how are we to explain long-term unions like Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony? The rumbles of unrest between Mr. Ozawa and his players have been heard for years, but he is celebrating his 25th season at the orchestra and doesn't seem to be going anywhere. Wolfgang Sawallisch seemed a perfect balancing weight in Philadelphia, tempering the orchestra's opulence with his sober, no-nonsense sense of style. And yet he is on his way out, perhaps voluntarily but without any undue protestation from management.
I am delighted to hear of recent successes by Riccardo Chailly and the Concertgebouw Orchestra. Yet it remains an unlikely pair: an Italian of almost flaky personality and tastes conducting a Dutch orchestra of historic conservatism? If they have over 10 seasons come to coalesce happily in some of the standard repertory, the players can sound distinctly uneasy in less standard pieces, almost to the point of unwillingness.
Why, indeed, do orchestras and their boards hire the conductors they do? The correct reason will be that players want them (although musicians often like conductors for the wrong reasons) and that enlightened management has decided that the leader and the led will be a good musical fit. Fit also applies to music directors and their local public. For the job, at least in this country, includes serious gladhanding, schmoozing and all the strategies of good public relations and salesmanship.
Some orchestras need help from within. James Levine goes to the Munich Philharmonic, inheriting a second-rate orchestra long conditioned by the dubious ministrations of the late Sergiu Celibidache. He also comes into a relatively new concert hall troubled by acoustical problems since its opening.
Mr. Levine, year by year and section by section, has built the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra into one of the best and most contented groups of musicians in the world. At the Met, his control over artistic decisions has been near total. In Munich, as an American, a Jew and the locus of rumors about his private life, he is already facing unpleasantness from the German press and public.
But up to now Mr. Levine has been primarily an opera conductor. Munich gives him an orchestra of his own and with it the opportunity to transform a bad ensemble into a good one. Reportedly, Mr. Levine could have had the Philadelphia job but refused it. Success in Germany will mean quite a triumph for all parties. I admire his courage.
Some orchestras hire conductors for what they bring with them to the marriage, either a fat personal recording contract in which the new orchestra will share, or a certain glamour that can be exploited by marketing departments. When Andre Previn came to the Pittsburgh Symphony years ago, a regular presence on public television with his new orchestra created publicity that could scarcely be bought.
There is a lot of money and the recording clout of London/Decca behind Mr. Chailly. Without them, he is still an undeniably talented man. But he is also a musician whose repertory and inclinations run against the grain of his orchestra. The Concertgebouw is probably glad to have Mr. Chailly, however. Proud but sagging in both visibility and resources, it used his dowry wisely.
Never forget as well that Mr. Ozawa is a national hero in Japan and that corporations like Sony and NEC contribute heavily to the Boston Symphony. There are gray areas of cause and effect in these matters, but it would be naive to imagine that no cause and effect exists.
Hiring a name often backfires. Philippe Entremont's engagement at the New Orleans Symphony some years ago had certainly as much to do with his nationality in a French-influenced city as it did with Mr. Entremont's zeal as an orchestra builder. When the New Orleans's fragile financial problems intensified, Mr. Entremont simply left, only to be hired by the Denver Symphony, which offered him an attractive contract and limited obligations. When that orchestra developed economic troubles, Mr. Entremont left again. The rubble in both cities has yet to be cleared.
Mstislav Rostropovich enjoyed a long and visible relationship with the National Symphony in Washington, one propelled equally by bearish personal charm and cold war politics. Taking a charismatic Russian cellist and conductor, also an eloquent rebel against Soviet Russia, and depositing him in the capital of the free world was an image too succulent to be denied.
Mr. Rostropovich is a great cellist and a conductor capable of doing a number of Russian orchestral standards in exciting fashion. The National Symphony, whose poor reputation stretches back to my wartime childhood days with Hans Kindler, badly needed a teacher and a builder, and Mr. Rostropovich was neither. Now the orchestra has both in the form of Leonard Slatkin, a conductor said to be interested in Washington's extramusical sources of power as well. Secretary of Music? Minister for the Performing Arts? Who knows?
Occasionally an orchestra position becomes a refuge. Simon Rattle's emergence as a boyhood sensation in Britain was followed by some rough guest-conducting experiences in places like Tel Aviv, Amsterdam and Cleveland. Mr. Rattle wisely grasped the principle of too much, too fast and settled in at the city of Birmingham in Britain. There, in relative safety, he could develop his considerable talents and demonstrate what hard musical preparation and spectacular salesmanship could do for a provincial orchestra of marginal individual talents. An adoring British press helped not a little.
In Birmingham, Mr. Rattle once again made the case for the whole exceeding the sum of parts, but now he seems restless and ready to move on. There have been big successes recently, especially at the Berlin Philharmonic. The reported stirrings of discontent from Berlin about its current head, Claudio Abbado, must have been real, for Mr. Abbado has just announced his resignation as of 2002.
If Berlin does not beckon, America will. For years Mr. Rattle was the shadow candidate in Boston and all but public heir apparent; but with few prospects in Europe, Mr. Ozawa seems to have dug himself even deeper into his job.
Mr. Rattle has recently been courted by the Philadelphia Orchestra and has appeared with it in successful concerts. The players want him; it is a fine orchestra; but no amount of charm and ambition could reduce Mr. Rattle's problems in a conservative and culturally lethargic city, an old-money town that clings stubbornly to its aged and acoustically disastrous Academy of Music, that drags its feet over a long-planned new concert hall and that has had its fund-raising problems in recent years.
It does no good to pine for the days when conductors came, bought a house, sent their children to local schools and stayed for 20 years. When transportation was slow, global ambition was necessarily tempered. Now two or even three careers are only a Concorde ride apart.
If you want sanity in the orchestra-conductor business, go to smaller places, where good sense is imposed by the conditions. One of the most instructive trips I have ever taken for this newspaper was to Cedar Rapids, Iowa, a year ago. The Cedar Rapids Symphony has in miniature the same anxieties as orchestras with many times its budget, but it has a sense of home and a longtime music director who is of the place he works. Let's keep the Concorde out of Cedar Rapids.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Fell In February, Hurt by G.M.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 4

 BODY:
Auto sales dipped slightly in the United States last month, as very weak car sales at the General Motors Corporation offset flat or rising sales at other companies, particularly the Chrysler Corporation and the Korean auto makers, which offered big rebates and other deals on small cars.
G.M. announced today that its sales fell 7 percent in February from a year earlier, as a 2.5 percent increase in sales of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans failed to offset a 14.1 percent plunge in car sales. Because G.M. still holds nearly a third of the American auto market -- more than every foreign auto maker combined -- the weak sales at G.M. were enough to drag overall auto sales down by seven-tenths of 1 percent last month. 
 G.M.'s sales of small cars fell the most. While the company's Oldsmobile and Cadillac divisions showed little change in sales and Buick's sales actually rose last month, the Chevrolet, Pontiac and Saturn divisions each had car sales that dropped by about a fifth.
"The small end of the market is just a battleground, and that is where we had our biggest declines," said Donald R. DeVeaux, G.M.'s director of North American market analysis.
The Ford Motor Company said today that its sales edged down by half a percentage point last month, as a slight gain in sales of midsize cars was offset by an 11 percent drop in sales of full-size pickup trucks. Ford introduced a new and larger full-size pickup on Feb. 26, and Ford officials said today that some customers appeared to have been waiting for the new model to reach dealerships before making purchases.
Ford ended production of several small-car models last year, and so has been hurt less than G.M. by weak demand and intense foreign competition in that segment of the market.
The industry sold cars and light trucks in February at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15.1 million vehicles. This was in line with forecasts for the full year and substantially higher than in January, when demand was weak following numerous year-end sales in December.
Nicholas J. Colas, an auto analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, said sales were likely to continue at February's level, because many Americans are refinancing their home mortgages at lower interest rates, freeing money to buy new vehicles. "We should look forward to another four to six months of pretty good vehicle sales," he said.
Chrysler announced on Tuesday that its sales had climbed 3.1 percent in February. The auto maker has stanched sales losses in small cars by offering $1,500 rebates on the Dodge and Plymouth Neon, and by converting some Neon options into standard equipment. The introduction of the big Dodge Durango sport utility vehicle also led to a 35 percent increase last month in Chrysler's sales of utility vehicles.
The biggest gainers in sales last month were two South Korean makers of small cars: the Kia Motors Corporation reported a 145 percent increase in sales, while the Hyundai Motor Company's sales were up 60.3 percent. Both are offering generous deals in the United States and expanding their dealership networks here to try to offset weak sales in their home market.
Mercedes-Benz, a unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., said today that its sales had risen 58.8 percent last month from a year earlier, as demand remained strong for the ML-320 sport utility vehicle it introduced last year. Across the industry, sales of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks rose 5 percent and accounted for 46.3 percent of all light-vehicle sales last month. Car sales fell 5.1 percent from a year earlier and made up the rest of the market.
G.M.'s market share, which has been falling for three decades, dropped to 28.9 percent last month, compared with 31 percent a year earlier. The drop in sales from February 1997 was particularly bad news because G.M. had not done especially well then either.
G.M. started last month with an unusually large inventory of unsold cars. According to Ward's Communications, a market data company in Southfield, Mich., G.M. had a four-month supply of Chevrolet Cavaliers, for example, at the beginning of February. Yet G.M. said today that Cavalier sales dropped by a third last month from levels a year earlier. G.M.'s failure to sell small cars could put pressure on the company to cut back production in the months ahead.
Executives at the company, the world's largest auto maker, acknowledged that they faced a tough task. "The overall economy is strong, and we look at that as a big plus, but there is no denying this is going to be a very tough, very competitive year for us," said Ronald L. Zarrella, G.M.'s vice president and group executive for North American auto marketing.
But G.M. fared better in the markets for midsize and luxury cars. Sales of its five new midsize cars -- the Oldsmobile Intrigue and Cutlass, the Chevrolet Malibu and the Buick Century and Regal -- were 43.6 percent higher than sales a year ago of the eight models they replaced. Sales also rose for the new Chevrolet Corvette and the Cadillac Seville and Catera.

HEADLINE: Spring Directions;
Striking Gold With Grand Economy

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
GREAT style never comes on like gangbusters. This spring, more than ever, subtle refinement is the key to fresh interiors.
"It's not about spare minimalism but the glorification of pared-down shapes, an appreciation for color and the intelligent understanding of engineering, of making things work the right way," the New York designer Carl D'Aquino said. He is guided by common sense but creatively charged by modern art and architecture. 
 "I'm passionate about certain modernists," Mr. D'Aquino said, citing particularly the inspiration of the Italian architect Renzo Piano, designer of the Menil Collection museum in Houston, and the American painter Arthur Dove, who distilled nature into "clean, clear-cut geometry," as Dove once said of his work.
It's an approach that encourages lyrical solutions to the most quotidian design problems -- like where do we hide the television if we want to watch it over dinner in the living room?
In a downtown apartment for a couple in their late 20's -- the kind of bland new construction that makes the heart sink -- Mr. D'Aquino was challenged to work within a strict budget in a less than sumptuous space: two small bedrooms, 1,200 square feet. With children pending, the couple didn't want to invest in major structural changes. Still, that didn't stop Mr. D'Aquino from drawing on sources as far flung as Frank Gehry's Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain (for hall lighting), and a 1970's Paco Rabanne chain-mail disco dress (for movable screens).
Here, his goal was to evoke youth, elegance and a knowing eclecticism out of what he called "a new sheetrock box." Striking gestures were focused in the living-dining room and hall. Nor did the small scope of the job deter Mr. D'Aquino from commissioning artisans for a few carefully calibrated touches of pizazz. Instead of installing an ornate mantel for an undistinguished fireplace, he hung over it a large Tramp Art mirror framed in found wood. He added more texture with subtle-hued, unpolished granite pavers for the fireplace.
To hide a television set in a corner of the living room, Mr. D'Aquino designed a three-panel screen of steel, sandblasted acrylic and patinated Formica, which rolls out on a semicircular track. "Remember those interlocking chain-mail dresses from the 70's?" he asked. "That's what I wanted the pattern to look like." The designer added that his aim was to make the screen a bit of a teaser, both translucent and shiny. A matching screen slides over the kitchen door and camouflages an ungainly pass-through to the living room. (He calls that dubious modern convenience a "yuppie food hole.")
"We really tried to thwart the floor plan envisioned by the developer," said Dawn Barry, Mr. D'Aquino's design associate. "It was so predictably mundane," she added, pointing to a small alcove in the living room near the entrance, which was obviously intended to be the dining nook.
Instead, it became a library corner. The designer lined the wall with bookshelves made of inexpensive stained composite wood, finessed with a translucent acrylic back, and aglow with fluorescent lights.
Mr. D'Aquino said the couple arrived in New York from Hong Kong with nothing but "their cassettes and book cartons." In setting up their first home in New York, they wanted to live elegantly -- but not with pretension. Hence, the television in the living room (the husband's choice). "I've done enough armoires in my day," Mr. D'Aquino said, referring to the chronic "entertainment center" quandary. "The screen was a nicer way out of it."
Within the embrace of the bookshelf walls stands a Victorian fainting couch. "The piece was crucial," said Mr. D'Aquino, who is soft spoken but determined. "Once I knew that my client would buy it, I knew I could go with character pieces." There's nothing arbitrary about Mr. D'Aquino's eclectic taste in living-room furniture, which also included a 16th-century-style Knole sofa at the other end of the room, a Federal-style table, and a 1950's chandelier -- all as distinctive as sculpture.
One of the advantages to keeping the furnishings select is the chance to draw attention to scale. "I love to fool around with size," he said, pointing to a diminutive Turkish tray table in front of the massive Knole sofa and to towering carved maple lamps fabricated by Stephen McKay, which stand sentinel in the corner "like guests that never leave," the designer said.
One problem with the apartment's dumbbell-shape plan is that it admits light only into the living room and bedrooms, not the connecting hallway, kitchen or bathrooms. Undaunted, Mr. D'Aquino, in a personal homage to Mr. Gehry, designed what he calls clouds of bent acrylic, reflectors on tracks the length of the hallway. The drama is heightened by hand-rubbed Venetian plaster walls tinted silver to bounce the light (the "clouds" also disguise institutional high-hat ceiling spotlights).
The window treatment had to have an opulent edge without blocking light. Mr. D'Aquino layered two curtains, one striped and sheer over a second of silvery 100 percent silk taffeta, trimmed on the bottom in gold satin. Meeker souls might prefer a sturdier silk blend, but Mr. D'Aquino considered the billow and crinkle of the real thing worth the shorter life expectancy. "Do we really need to save our curtains for the next generation?" he asked.
An inexpensive green velvet curtain to cover two walls in the bedroom was also practical. "We didn't want to do a big paint job in the bedroom," Ms. Barry said.
The bedroom is a strong contrast to the rest of the apartment. "They wanted it to be soothing, deep and dramatic, all about upholstery," she said. Mr. D'Aquino calls it "the velvet cocoon." It is sparsely decorated: a French 40's sleigh bed, signed by the designer Jules Leleu, and an acid green plastic side table designed by Antonio Citterio and Glen Oliver Loew (for the video games).
The marriage of a French 40's antique and an avant-garde table from Milan is typical of Mr. D'Aquino's inventive but practical way. "I work backward from the way my clients want to live, where they're going to read a book, or how close they want to be eating together," he said. "Then I choose the pieces that will help make it happen."
His only regret is that the apartment's other inhabitants are "two of the biggest long-haired cats I have ever seen in my life." The owners wanted them to have full lounging rights. So far, he says, the velvet curtains haven't been touched.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries End 2-Day Slide as Traders Await Jobless Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury market managed a mild rebound from its two-day slide yesterday, even as traders remained focused on the February employment report, which will be announced tomorrow.
The 30-year bond rose 24/32, to 101 14/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.02 percent, from 6.07 percent on Tuesday. 
 Traders said investors were bottom-fishing after the Treasury market had been significantly cheapened over the last few days, a result of strong economic reports that suggested the economy might not be slowing. Some had expected it to slow because of the Asian financial crisis. The strong reports earlier this week from the nation's purchasing managers and on new-home sales raised fears that the Federal Reserve might tighten monetary policy.
Additionally the central bank was in the market yesterday as a buyer of various maturities. One reason for the upward pressure was short-covering, but profit taking on the upticks kept a cap on the day's gains.
Short sales occur when some market participants sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices, and pocket the difference. If prices begin to rise instead of fall, these participants often cover their short positions by buying back the securities immediately to limit their losses.
James Padinha, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis concern in Menlo Park, Calif., said that although the Treasury market opened down after overnight weakness, the decline was less than some had expected and that set off the round of short-covering that bounced the market up.
With the employment report only days away, there is little chance investors will make big bets or change investment strategy, Mr. Padinha said. He is forecasting a gain of 270,000 new jobs, above the average estimate of 225,000.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, testifying before the House Budget Committee yesterday, said he saw the risks in the economic outlook as evenly balanced between a potential slowdown stemming from the turmoil in Asia and faster growth spurred by consumer spending, a view he had expressed on Tuesday in Senate testimony.

HEADLINE: NATO Myopia

 BODY:
NATO expansion received a strong endorsement this week from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, but the most interesting thing about the Senate's handling of this issue is the ambivalence so many members express. Rarely has such an important matter seemed headed for approval with so little enthusiasm or attention. That should indicate that something is amiss. The United States ought not to take such a fateful step without a compelling justification and fervent conviction.
Serious doubts about the financial cost of enlargement remain, even among supporters of expansion. There is considerable concern about the long-term effect on Russia of advancing NATO eastward. Some senators understandably resent White House pressure to approve the admission of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic because President Clinton has committed Washington to the plan and rejection by the Senate now would undermine America's international leadership. 
 The clearest sign of ambivalence is a proposal by a Republican, John Warner of Virginia, and the Democrat Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York to freeze expansion for three years after the first round of growth. The amendment is a well-intentioned but inadequate way of dealing with the fear that once begun, eastward expansion will be difficult to stop until it reaches the Russian border, a prospect that worries many senators almost as much as it does the Russians.
A freeze offers the illusion that NATO expansion can be stopped after the admission of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, and that their membership alone will not produce a divisive new line across Europe. Neither assumption is true. Expansion will create a new East-West divide, and that in turn will produce great pressure for further expansion as excluded countries press to join the elite NATO club. Romania and Slovenia have all but been promised admission already.
To bring the NATO military alliance to Russia's doorstep is clearly to invite a resumption of chilled relations with Moscow and even a turn away from democracy in Russia. To stop short of the Russian border somewhere in central Europe is to create two Europes, one democratic, prosperous and defended by American might, the other politically adrift, economically disadvantaged and militarily insecure. It would be far better, as Mr. Moynihan proposes, to put off NATO expansion altogether and let the European Union take the lead in unifying Europe through economic cooperation. Those senators ready to support NATO expansion should understand the political and financial price. Those who are uncertain should not vote for expansion in the expectation that it can be contained.

HEADLINE: Clinton Aides Spread Data Critical of Starr as Lawyer for G.M.

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
A week after the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, ordered a White House official before a grand jury to account for accusations spread about prosecutors, President Clinton's aides today circulated a batch of material critical of Mr. Starr's performance as a lawyer for the General Motors Corporation in the early 1990's.
The material summarized a complaint filed on Monday by a South Carolina plaintiff's lawyer that asks the Justice Department to investigate Mr. Starr for obstruction of justice. The complaint, by J. Kendall Few, asserts that Mr. Starr sought to cover up perjured testimony in a civil lawsuit in which Mr. Few's clients had been injured in a car accident. 
 Mr. Few said Mr. Starr had misused the lawyer-client privilege in an appeals court argument to conceal false testimony by an engineer for General Motors at previous trials over the combustibility of fuel tanks.
Justice Department officials said today that they would read Mr. Few's complaint before deciding whether it merited a more formal review.
"We open our mail," one official said.
General Motors and its lawyers today denied the accusation and pointed out that Mr. Few had been sanctioned $53,000 in the case for falsely accusing the company of withholding documents.
Mr. Few said in an interview today that Mr. Starr had misused the lawyer-client privilege to conceal from jurors an embarrassing 1973 memorandum by a G.M. engineer that provided a cost-benefit analysis explaining why it did not make economic sense to improve fuel tanks and reduce the likelihood of fires in accidents.
The engineer, Edward Ivey, had testified that he did not know why he prepared the memorandum or whether he had circulated it among company executives, so the memorandum was never introduced as evidence at trials related to the fuel tank problems. In statements made in 1981 to G.M. lawyers, Mr. Ivey apparently said he had been ordered to prepare the report and had probably sent it to five executives of the Oldsmobile division, Mr. Few said.
Mr. Starr successfully argued before a Federal appeals panel that the engineer's 1981 statements were protected by the lawyer-client privilege, and the case was settled for terms that have never been made public.
Kyle Johnson, a G.M. spokesman, noted that a Federal appeals panel had unanimously ruled in the company's favor on the issue.
"In that case, General Motors properly asserted claims of attorney-client and attorney work product privileges with respect to certain documents generated by its counsel," Mr. Johnson said. "Mr. Starr and Kirkland & Ellis's representation of General Motors in the case was proper in every respect."
Mr. Few said he was raising the complaint now because a Florida judge in a different case involving General Motors had recently unsealed documents that revealed the engineer's statements.
He said also he had had no contacts with White House officials.
"This has absolutely nothing to do with the President," Mr. Few said.
But G.M. officials noted that Mr. Few still had a number of cases against the company. And supporters of Mr. Starr suggested that the new complaint was intended to undermine his efforts to fight claims of lawyer-client privilege. The privilege has been invoked by several witnesses, most notably Monica S. Lewinsky and top White House aides.
White House officials, hoping to capitalize on Mr. Few's complaint, faxed to reporters excerpts from Mr. Starr's brief in the case in which he embraced the lawyer-client privilege in behalf of G.M.
"It is well established that the attorney-client privilege is the oldest privilege protecting confidential communications, and is also one of the most sacred and absolute," Mr. Starr wrote. "The public interest will be served by honoring the public policies that underlie the fundamental protection offered litigants by the attorney-client privilege."
At a closed hearing today, Judge Norma Holloway Johnson of Federal District Court heard arguments between prosecutors and Ms. Lewinsky's first lawyer, Francis D. Carter, over whether the lawyer-client privilege protected his conversations and written work. Participants said Judge Johnson had not issued a ruling but suggested that she would make one soon.
Mr. Carter's lawyer, Charles J. Ogletree Jr., declined to provide any details of the hearing and said his client was not suspected of doing anything improper.
"One thing was crystal clear," said Professor Ogletree, who teaches at Harvard Law School. "There was a clear expression that there is no interest in Frank Carter. Their argument has been that he was an unwitting participant in any improper effort by Lewinsky to misuse the affidavit process."
Prosecutors are trying to determine what Mr. Carter knew about Ms. Lewinsky's affidavit in the Paula Corbin Jones case in which she denied having a sexual relationship with Mr. Clinton.
In some of the secretly recorded conversations with Linda R. Tripp, Ms. Lewinsky contradicts the affidavit and acknowledges having a sexual relationship with the President, according to people who have heard the tapes.
Last December, Mr. Carter took Ms. Lewinsky as a client on the word of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the President's close friend. Mr. Jordan began testifying before the grand jury on Tuesday and is expected to continue on Thursday.

HEADLINE: The Threats to Mass Transit

 BODY:
In agreeing to provide an extra $26 billion for the nation's highways this week without a commensurate increase for mass transit, the Senate has thumbed its nose at a majority of the American population, the nearly 55 percent of all Americans who live and work in more than 40 major metropolitan areas. Boosting the share of spending for roads and bridges without providing a reasonable increase in aid for commuter trains, subways and buses ignores the complexity of mobility in metropolitan America. Moving workers to their jobs depends on a network of decent roads and reliable mass transit. Without rapid transit, many of these metropolises would be parking lots at rush hour.
In this decade, spending for mass transit has generally amounted to 20 percent of the total Federal aid for highways, bridges and mass transit. To maintain this 80-20 ratio, transit spending, mostly for capital programs, has to rise whenever highway aid does. But this modest approach has come under attack as power in Congress has continued to shift to the South and West. Some Southern and Western states, which got back substantially less than a dollar in aid for every dollar in gasoline taxes sent to Washington, resented the way existing aid formulas tied to energy and environmental goals and aging systems gave Eastern and Midwestern states more than a dollar in aid for each dollar of gas taxes. 
 The Senate is currently working on a $171 billion highway spending bill for fiscal years 1999 through 2003, including the $26 billion added this week. But pending mass-transit legislation, sponsored by Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York, would set aside only about $36 billion for transit, or about 17 percent of total highway and transit spending. The short-term task Senator D'Amato and his colleagues have set themselves is to win $5.2 billion more for mass transit. If they are successful, even that amount will not cover transit's capital needs, which are roughly $13 billion to $15 billion a year. As a matter of long-term economic self-preservation, members of Congress who represent metropolises should organize to push for a higher level of aid.
States with transit systems face other threats as well. Under several legislative proposals, each state, regardless of need, would be guaranteed a level of mass-transit aid equal to 70 to 90 percent of the Federal gas tax revenue it contributed for the mass-transit account of the Highway Trust Fund. That would divert money from vital projects to secondary ones. When the highway and transit bills are merged to form the new Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, the Senate should insure that it does not undermine the transportation networks of the nation's metropolises. Reliable rapid transit remains an effective tool for cutting congestion.

HEADLINE: For the Mayor by the Bay, the Honeymoon Is Over

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27

 BODY:
For a while now, San Franciscans have been griping that Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. is taking on imperial airs.
First there were the $1 million festivities surrounding Mayor Brown's inauguration two years ago, then his penchant for limousine motorcades with motorcycle escorts, then a proposal to adopt as his official residence an admiral's mansion on an island in San Francisco Bay. Finally, as the cost of renovating City Hall neared $300 million, he announced that given the space needed for a ballroom, a catering kitchen and an expanded office of protocol, there would be no office space left in the Beaux Arts palace for those city employees he described as "pencil pushers." 
 In February, while the Mayor toured the Philippines and Vietnam, cartoonists back home sketched "King Willie" wearing a crown and holding a scepter. On his return, Mr. Brown, paying no heed, paraded down the runway of a Chinatown fashion show, dressed in robes of a Chinese emperor.
"People have been trying to label me for years and years and years," the 63-year-old veteran politician said in an interview the other day, brushing aside the label of majesty. And if he happens to carry a high profile, well, that comes with a benefit. "I get more national attention for this city," he said, "than the previous two mayors combined."
But after walking on air for much of his first two years as Mayor, the exuberant and elegant Mr. Brown is losing altitude.
"The bloom is off the rose," said Mervin Field, the dean of California pollsters. "For the first year, he could do no wrong. He was like the man on the flying carpet; you could not see what was keeping him up."
Since then, Mr. Brown's approval ratings have slid like a cable car down one of San Francisco's famous hills -- to percentages in the mid-40's from the mid-60's. A recent survey of 600 city voters by the polling firm of Fairbank, Maslin, Maullin & Associates found that only a third of them wanted him re-elected in 1999. And the same poll indicated overwhelming support for two anti-Brown measures on the ballot this June: one to return a full complement of municipal employees to City Hall when the renovation is complete next year, the other to dilute the Mayor's control over redevelopment of the former naval base on Treasure Island.
"The guy could be in real trouble," said Paul Maslin, a partner in Fairbank, Maslin. Noting that Mr. Brown's two most recent predecessors, Frank Jordan and Art Agnos, had failed to win second terms, the pollster warned, "He'd better make some progress in the next 12 months, or he is going to be unbelievably vulnerable."
Yet few people have ever made much money betting against Willie Lewis Brown Jr., master politician and master communicator. From his first job, as a black shoeshine boy in a white barbershop in East Texas, Mr. Brown has thrived in adversity. In California, where blacks account for only 7 percent of the population, he not only became Speaker of the Assembly but also held the job for 15 years, a record. In San Francisco, where blacks are only 11 percent of the population, he became the first black mayor.
Further, he is running this beautiful city at a time when it is hard to go wrong. Since his inauguration in January 1996, a booming economy has cut local unemployment almost in half, to 3.5 percent. With tourism and real estate surging, swelling tax receipts have transformed an $89 million budget deficit into a $78 million surplus. On the political front, a series of retirements has allowed the Mayor to appoint almost half of the 11-member Board of Supervisors, or city council.
Mr. Brown has also planted seeds for a crop of public works projects that should reap baskets of votes on Election Day 1999.
"The Mayor has commitments to build two new stadiums, two new museums, a new zoo, a new civic center and an expansion of the convention and visitors center," said John Whitehurst, a Democratic political consultant here. "Previous mayors would have been happy with just one of these. By November 1999, a lot of ribbons will be cut, a lot of ground will be broken."
Mr. Whitehurst forgot to mention the $2.4 billion expansion of San Francisco International Airport -- the largest airport construction project under way in the nation and the largest public works project in local history.
Looking through this cloud of construction dust, it is hard to determine whether Mr. Brown is suffering from anything more than a big-city mayor's routine midterm dip in the polls.
For all of that, though, some elements of his style have not played well here. Back-corridor jokes that entertained reporters and politicians for years in Sacramento are bombing in the Bay.
"The one-liners, where he thought he would get a laugh, are getting him an outraged public reaction," said James Richardson, author of "Willie Brown: A Biography" (University of California Press, 1996).
In December, for example, when Latrell Sprewell, a basketball player for the Golden State Warriors, tried to choke his coach, P. J. Carlesimo, the Mayor said: "His boss may have needed choking. It may have been justified."
Angry letters flooded local newspapers. At a stadium groundbreaking ceremony a few days after his remark, the Mayor was booed. "Fault lines have become more and more visible between the administration of Willie L. Brown Jr. and the people," said an editorial in The San Francisco Examiner.
Further sapping support for the Mayor has been his lack of progress on two issues that bedevil the city: its role as a regional magnet for the homeless (average welfare payments here are 50 percent higher than in neighboring communities) and its creaky transit system.
As many as 15,000 poor people sleep on the streets here every night, and the issue of homelessness contributed to the political demise of Mayors Jordan and Agnos. Mr. Brown, who was a critic of past policies on homelessness, has himself made little headway against it. When clandestine encampments of the destitute and the mentally ill spread through the 1,000-acre Golden Gate Park, he proposed borrowing an Oakland city helicopter equipped with heat-sensing equipment to detect camp sites.
"Shopping-cart confiscations, citations for camping in the park after it was closed, open-container violations -- are all up under this administration," complained Paul Boden, director of the Coalition on Homelessness. "These are all the things he blasted Frank Jordan for, things he blasted as racist and classist."
Mr. Brown now describes the homeless as an intractable problem. "Forty percent of homeless people in San Francisco are single male veterans, all of whom ought to be the Federal Government's problem," he said in the interview the other day.
The other main irritant to voters here is the city's mass transit system, the San Francisco Municipal Railway, commonly known as Muni.
While tourists revel in San Francisco's turn-of-the-century cable cars, locals complain that the rest of the bus and rail system is not much more modern. Almost 700,000 passengers ride the system, which was starved for decades by mayors seeking to balance budgets. As the average age of buses and streetcars hits 10 years, breakdowns are frequent, schedules are fictitious, and commuter frustrations are high.
Willie Brown the candidate promised to repair the system in 100 days. Willie Brown the Mayor has learned that it can take up to three years for manufacturers to deliver new rolling stock.
At one point, the Mayor tried -- and failed -- to soothe riders by proposing a largely mysterious concept of "flexible schedules" and suggesting that the riders needed to learn patience, "to live in the real world." But in recent weeks, the Mayor's famous political instincts have kicked in. He has taken to riding the buses and trains incognito, and is starting a campaign against transit obstacles like jaywalkers.
Somewhat chastened, the Mayor now explains that he is grappling with a legacy of "25 years of inefficiency, 25 years of chaos, 25 years of underfunding Muni." As for overcoming that legacy, "even God couldn't do that in 100 days."

HEADLINE: First Union to Acquire Money Store for $2.1 Billion

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
The First Union Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Money Store Inc. in a $2.1 billion stock swap that creates the largest home-equity lender in the country. The deal also promised to bring a measure of conservativism to the lower end of the consumer finance industry, which had been hammered over the last year by earnings problems related to overly optimistic accounting practices.
A home-equity loan allows borrowers to tap into equity stakes they have built up in their homes. Home-equity borrowing has grown quickly as lower interest rates and a greater acceptance of debt have made it more attractive to consumers. Home-equity debt totaled about $96 billion at the end of the third quarter last year, up from $85.3 billion for all of 1996 and $79.1 billion in 1995, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. 
 Money Store, which specializes in home-equity and mortgage lending to people with troubled credit histories, is one of the more visible lenders in the so-called subprime business. Until recently, the subprime market has been enormously profitable -- often at the expense of less sophisticated, low-income borrowers, the industry's critics say -- and bigger banks see subprime lending as a growth opportunity.
"This makes strategic sense for First Union because we're in a fight for the consumer in banking right now," said R. Harold Schroeder, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. "The more banks can widen their product set and broaden their distribution channels the better off they are."
Analysts expect further consolidation in the consumer finance businesses, as companies like the Associates First Capital Corporation and Household International Inc., the top two players in the industry, look to solidify their dominance. Weaker companies in the industry have become more affordable to potential acquirers because their share prices have softened as price competition and lax lending standards have eaten into many lenders' margins.
The Beneficial Corporation, the third-largest consumer finance company in the country, has seen its earnings come under pressure and recently put itself up for sale. Bank advisers say Household has emerged as the leading candidate to take over Beneficial.
First Union, based in Charlotte, N.C., and Money Store, of Union, N.J., said they did not expect the transaction to result in office closings or substantial layoffs. First Union, the nation's sixth-largest bank, is paying $34 a share for Money Store, or a 24 percent premium to Money Store's closing share price of $27.50 on Tuesday.
Although Money Store's shares have been underperformers during the last year, the stock has risen steadily since The Wall Street Journal reported a few weeks ago that the lender was putting itself up for sale. First Union's shares fell 75 cents, to $52, and Money Store's shares rose $4.25, to $31.75, yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
While some analysts and bank advisers regard $2.1 billion as a rich price for Money Store, First Union will be able to finance Money Store's loans more cheaply than Money Store could on its own. Money Store, which also has a strong presence in small-business lending, will retain its name and management and operate as a separate division within First Union's consumer business.
First Union is expected to bring tighter accounting standards to Money Store's business. Though Money Store is not considered to be nearly as free-wheeling an operator as many of the small subprime companies that have gotten into trouble over the last year, it still has made use of "gain on sale accounting." This type of accounting allows Money Store to immediately recognize anticipated profits on loans that are packaged and sold as securities. "Anticipated" is a key word here, for each company sets its own target for what it expects those profits to be -- and last year many subprime lenders proved to be too aggressive in recognizing lush returns.
An auto lender, the Mercury Finance Company, suffered the most prominent meltdown, but other financing companies, like the Cityscape Financial Corporation and the First Merchants Acceptance Corporation, also encountered problems.
Money Store's fourth-quarter profits plummeted to $111,000, from $29.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1996, in large part because of charges it took when it abandoned the sub-prime auto lending business.
Money Store has 4,800 employees and operates nationwide. First Union, which agreed to acquire the Corestates Financial Corporation for $17.1 billion late last year, has 44,300 employees, mainly on the Eastern Seaboard.
Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company advised First Union on the transaction, while Money Store was advised by Prudential Securities Inc. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter.
