HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Ends Hot Streak and Fears About Asia Reappear

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market took a break from its record-setting run yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 45.59 points, to 8,539.24. The Dow had set five highs in a row.
In one sense, the modest selloff was nothing extraordinary, considering that the Dow had risen 13.3 percent, or 1,000 points, between Jan. 9 and Tuesday's new high. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index had jumped 16.9 percent in that time and hit another new high yesterday, rising 2.56, to 1,759.70. 
 But two events yesterday may have raised concerns that could turn a one-day pause into something more.
First, the Dow was led lower by Walt Disney, which plunged 3 1/8, or 2.8 percent, to 106 7/8, after several analysts had downgraded the company's earnings outlook.
"I think people are worried about first-quarter earnings," said Timothy M. Ghriskey, senior portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation, acknowledging this was not the case just a week ago. "We are in a period now that if a company is going to have bad earnings, they will announce them." First-quarter earnings reports will begin to be released in mid-April.
Then, after the market closed, Intel announced that its first-quarter results would be below expectations. That announcement was even more surprising than the Disney news and could help send technology stocks -- and possibly the broader market -- lower today.
Intel's news comes on top of Compaq Computer's announcement on Tuesday that competition had kept prices lower then expected in the first quarter. Compaq fell 1 13/16 yesterday, to 28.
Intel rose 1 1/8 yesterday, to 86 7/16, ending a four-day slide. But in after-hours trading, Intel plunged 9 7/16, or 10.9 percent, to 77. Other technology stocks also fell. Dell Computer ended regular trading up 7 15/16, to 139 1/16, but fell 8 7/8, to 130 3/16, after hours.
In another negative sign, the futures contracts for the 30 stocks in the Dow and the 500 in the Standard & Poor's index also fell sharply after the market had closed.
The Intel announcement was additionally worrisome because it could revive concerns about the impact on American corporate earnings from the economic turmoil in Asia. That anxiety, along with general earnings concerns, had subsided after the relatively positive reports from the fourth quarter finished coming in last month. Intel has significant business in Asia.
The S.& P. index of 500 stocks also fell yesterday, finishing down 4.69, at 1,047.33. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 644.3 million shares, above average for the year, and decliners led gainers by 1,738 to 1,231.
The analysts who lowered Disney earnings forecasts cited soft ratings at its ABC television network and poor showings for some recent films. Jill Krutick of Salomon Smith Barney said all Disney's fiscal second-quarter gains expected in film and broadcasting had been wiped away. Analysts from Schroeder & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company also put out reports on Disney yesterday.
Ms. Krutick lowered her earnings projections for the second quarter to 50 cents a share from 54 cents and cut her forecast for all of 1998 to $3.17 a share from $3.25. But she noted that the downgrades she and other analysts had made "might be perceived more negatively than usual" because of Disney's strong run-up this year. Disney shares, which had risen to a 52-week high of 115 3/4 on Feb. 23, have drifted nearly 8 percent lower.
The reports from the analysts were made after Disney had disclosed new information on its film performance and other areas in response to calls from analysts yesterday. Disney, however, made no public statements, meaning that the companies the analysts work for had the first opportunity to trade on the negative news. Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said in a speech last week that he was worried about such trading advantages.
Yesterday, there were large order imbalances that delayed the opening of trading in Disney, which finally began trading at 10:05 A.M. at 106 7/8.
Drug stocks also fell sharply yesterday, led down by American Home Products, which fell 2 13/16, to 91 3/4. Late on Tuesday, the company announced that it had withdrawn an application to the Food and Drug Administration for approval of the hypertension drug Tasosartan from its Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories. American Home cited unresolved concerns about the safety of the drug.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW;
Philip Johnson Geometry In an Advertising Wrapper

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
Philip Johnson is back, with yet another plan for Times Square. This is the fifth proposal Mr. Johnson has prepared for this location since 1983, when he unveiled his scheme for four gigantic towers designed to straddle what was then a bedraggled Crossroads of the World.
Times Square has turned around since then, and so has Philip Johnson's health. Two years ago, at the age of 90, the architect was overcome by complications following heart surgery. His office was closed. Interlopers sat themselves down at his fabled corner table at the Four Seasons restaurant. A vacuum settled in. "How are you feeling?," a reporter called to ask a year ago. "How do you think I'm feeling?" came the crotchety reply, before the phone crashed down. Then some kind of miracle -- genetic? medical? both? -- kicked in. The architect's hands, which once looked aged, are now pink. 
 But please stop whatever you're doing and read a chapter or two of "Nietzsche in Turin," Lesley Chamberlain's charming book about the philosopher's life in 1888, his last productive year of writing. Contemporary art and architecture, and Philip Johnson's place within it, make infinitely more sense when viewed against the backdrop of late 19th-century romance. Architecture is the art of not upsetting the apple cart. Yet this art thrives on the imagination of those who rattle the cart with relish. Mr. Johnson's new Times Square design is Nietzschean in this disturbing sense.
Mr. Johnson's plan has been scaled back, from four towers to two. Prudential, the corporate moneybags behind the original scheme, has sold off the other two parcels to different developers. One of these, the Conde Nast headquarters, is now in construction. The second, which will house the North American division of the Reuters news agency, is to break ground in September. The New York firm Fox & Fowle are the architects for both of these projects.
One point can't be made too strongly. This project, which started out with the abysmal intention of turning Times Square into one more gray corporate canyon, has been turned around in completely the right direction. Thanks mainly to the grit and determination of one person -- Rebecca Robertson, a former New York State official who was in charge of redeveloping 42d Street -- Times Square is well on its way toward realizing its potential as the media hub of the world.
Mr. Johnson is as yet without a developer. Prudential is still shopping around. But never mind. Built or not, Mr. Johnson's project has earned a place in the history of ideas. His site is the two parcels on the south side of 42d Street, with Seventh Avenue running down the middle. The basic shape of the two buildings is nearly identical to the version Mr. Johnson prepared in 1994: a geometric composition with a rectangular core of glass with faceted corners.
But the envelope now comes with a new wrapper. Mr. Johnson and his associates, including the Los Angeles designer Deborah Sussman, have come up with a new, patent-pending form of curtain wall. Rectangular panels clipped to the walls' spandrels would provide a surface for advertising that would rise the full height of the buildings.
The spandrels could be made of plastic, embossed with simple graphics. Or they could be equipped with electronic gear to accommodate illuminated ads that move. While windows would interrupt these surfaces, they are narrow enough that the image can jump across the surface, as it does, for example, across the exhaust grills on the backs of New York City buses.
On the main portion of the facades, the spandrels would be of normal width. Instead of forming a continuous sign, illuminated spandrels would be sprinkled across the surface (like those snowflakes stapled to the sides of 666 Fifth Avenue at Christmastime). Or, they could be programmed to send signals into the night. Drink Diet Pepsi. Dance the rumba. Call your mother. Rent This Space, in other words, and you can design these buildings yourself.
Apollo in the Marketplace. That is the phrase Walter Gropius used to describe the architect's place in a capitalist society. But the marketplace is itself a Dionysian precinct, nowhere more riotously than in Times Square, with its gigantic incitations to revelry and lust.
Philip Johnson has long flourished in this precinct. Throughout his career, Mr. Johnson has used his Apollonian mentor, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, as a foil to define his own esthetic identity. Mies once said, "You cannot invent a new architecture every Monday morning." Mr. Johnson said, more or less, of course I can, you old coot. Mies said, "I don't want to be interesting, I want to be good." Mr. Johnson said, "I wouldn't know how to be good."
Actually, Mr. Johnson can be excellent. But he has played a far more valuable role in the culture by daring to be dreadful. This is the architect who hung Andy Warhol's huge "13 Most Wanted Men" on the side of the New York State Pavilion at the 1964 New York World's Fair. Who dreamed up the Chippendale top for the A.T.&T. (now Sony) Building in 1983. Who once declared himself a whore.
Even fans of Dionysius want architecture to be Apollonian. That is why Nietzsche moved to Turin, with its ordered Baroque arcades. And, to this day, many architects dream of creating an Apollonian order. They imagine that this is what architecture is supposed to do: control emotion, restrain chaos and reinforce convention. Mr. Johnson himself fell into that mode as the apostle of Mies. Some think he should have stayed there.
It's probable that Mr. Johnson's Times Square design, if built, will not achieve the landmark status of the Seagram Building, on which he collaborated with Mies in 1958. And yet, the Times Square design represents our historical moment as fully as the Seagram Building represented mid-century New York. The Seagram Building arose at a pivotal time, when the industrial city was dying and the mass media city was being born. Times Square is the heart of this new city. Its economic base rests not on production, but on promotion. No architect alive is as thrillingly attuned as Philip Johnson to promotion's sordid glories.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 7, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An architecture review on Thursday about Philip Johnson's proposal for two new towers in Times Square referred incorrectly to the status of Mr. Johnson's firm while he recovered from heart surgery two years ago. The firm, Philip Johnson/Alan Ritchie Architects, did not close; it continued to work on projects designed by Mr. Johnson and new designs under Mr. Ritchie's direction.

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Two Warhols, Together Again
Last month Christie's used its annex at 308 East 59th Street together with its Park Avenue showroom to exhibit a collection of cutting-edge art, almost as if the auction house were a gallery or a museum. The purpose of the exhibition was mysterious: the group of artworks from the 1960's and 70's had no prices or estimates on them, and Christie's offered no definitive schedule of which, if any, of the works would eventually find its way to auction. 
 Now Sotheby's is putting on an exhibition, this week through March 14 at Andre Emmerich, the East 57th Street gallery that it bought two years ago.
Unlike Christie's, Sotheby's has a clear mission, to promote highlights of its sale of contemporary art on May 14. And estimates are available on all but one of the works on view.
The work without a price tag is Andy Warhol's "Early Colored Liz." The famous 1963 image of Elizabeth Taylor, taken from the film "Butterfield Eight," belongs to Irving Blum, the Manhattan dealer. It is part of his private collection, and he says he has no intention of selling it.
Mr. Blum agreed to lend his prized Warhol because it came from the famous Stroher collection, which includes another well-known Warhol, "Orange Marilyn," that will be in the May sale. "Orange Marilyn" is one of the most important examples of Pop Art to come to auction in years and carries a hefty $4 million to $6 million estimate. Sotheby's officials said they hoped that seeing the two Warhol portraits displayed together, as they once had been, would cause a stir.
"Orange Marilyn," the 1964 iconic image of Marilyn Monroe based on a film still from the movie "Niagara," is being sold by a descendant of Karl Stroher of Germany. His collection of 20th-century works was one of the first in Europe to include American Pop Art.
Also on view at Emmerich is Lucian Freud's famous "Large Interior, WII (After Watteau)." Painted between 1981 and 1983, it was inspired by Watteau's 1712 "Pierrot Content," now in the Thyssen Collection in Madrid, and depicts two of Freud's children and three friends in a rundown London interior. The Freud painting is estimated to go for $2.5 million to $3.5 million. It is being sold by James Kirkman, who was Freud's dealer from 1972 until 1992.
In addition to these two big-ticket paintings, Sotheby's is showing a selection of Minimalist pieces by artists including Carl Andre, Robert Ryman and Dan Flavin.
With so much fuss being made about art that won't be sold for more than two months, is Sotheby's worried that these works will seem like old news by the time they reach the auction block?
"I'm not worried, because these are such extraordinary works nothing you can do will over-market them," said Tobias Meyer, the head of Sotheby's contemporary art department worldwide. "Several museums are interested in the Warhol, and this way board members can see it at their leisure. It's a client-oriented thing."
 
The Art of the Phone
For the last few years museums and their sponsors have been cooking up creative marketing strategies to heighten the public's awareness of the sponsor's name and draw visitors to the exhibitions they are financing. The latest idea involves the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Nokia, the mobile telephone manufacturer and one of four major sponsors of the Guggenheim's "China: 5,000 Years" exhibition, on view at its Fifth Avenue headquarters and its SoHo branch through June 3.
Today through April 30, owners of Nokia mobile phones are invited to take them to either of the Guggenheim branches and with the purchase of a ticket, have a friend admitted to the museum at no charge.
While Nokia has supported athletic events like the Sugar Bowl in New Orleans, it has never financed a museum exhibition.
"The profile of our consumer is similar to that of the Guggenheim's museum visitor in their economics, life style and preferences," said Jim Bowman, Nokia's vice president for corporate communication. "They also appreciate art."
Nokia is advertising the special promotion in newspapers and at retail outlets.
"It's good for the sponsor because it's widespread recognition of their product, and it's good for us because it means increased admission," said Judy Cox, a museum deputy director.
Officials at the Guggenheim say they have big plans for Nokia. They hope that the phone company will become a regular sponsor and that it will continue to support the China exhibition when it travels to the museum's branch in Bilbao, Spain.
The traveling show will combine the traditional Chinese art on display at the museum's Frank Lloyd Wright building on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street and the contemporary section now on view in SoHo. It opens in Bilbao on July 17 and runs through Oct. 22.
The museum also hopes that Nokia will sponsor "America: 300 Years," a selection of works from the Guggenheim's permanent collection and from other American museums and private collections. That show is scheduled to open later this year at the China National Art Gallery in Beijing and in early 1999 at the Shanghai Museum.
If Nokia agrees to help sponsor any or all of these shows, the Guggenheim says, it will offer visitors the same take-your-phone offer.
 
The Spirit of the Square
The dressing up of Times Square has reached inside some of the area's office buildings. Take the 40-foot domed ceiling in the lobby of 1500 Broadway, at 43d Street.
The ceiling was recently transformed by Luke Gray, a 36-year-old New York artist, with "Transmission 1998," a bright mural that uses 23 colors reminiscent of Pop Art, though not Pop images. Instead, the work has fragments of images that the artist describes as "animal, cosmic and molecular."
Orna Shulman, executive vice president of Intertech Corporation, the building's owner, said she first saw Mr. Gray's work at Snyder Fine Art, the 57th Street gallery.
"He's an interesting artist because of his expressionistic style," Ms. Shulman said. "We have done public art in other parts of the country, but because this is Times Square, the fanciful aspect of this work just seemed appropriate."
Rather than spending time on carefully conceived and labored studies of the work, Mr. Gray spontaneously created the mural, his first public project, in one six-hour session.
"I called it 'Transmission' because it looks like all the colors are flowing out of the building's central column like a power station," Mr. Gray said.
The artist said he has also used a spontaneous process for his paintings on canvas. "For me it's a great adventure," he said. "You don't lead the work. It leads you."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 41; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1366 words

HEADLINE: DESIGN REVIEW;
Thinking Big and Designing Small: Finnish Grace in Everyday Objects

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
A cup shaped to fit the hand or a chair that coddles the bottom may not seem like crucial considerations. But in 20th-century Finnish design, a concern for comfort has been as much a part of the game as simplicity, elegance of form and ease of production. It goes with the distinctly Finnish development of modernism evolving from the progressive design movement that swept Europe after World War I.
That the Finnish spirit helped in humanizing the formalities of modern design -- its rigid geometricism, no-frills austerity and mass production imperatives -- comes across clearly in "Finnish Modern Design: Utopian Ideals and Everyday Realities, 1930-1997," at the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts. The show is part of the big culture fest in New York this season that marks Finland's 80th year of independence. 
 Organized by Nina Stritzler-Levine, director of exhibitions at Bard, and Marianne Aav, who holds the same post at the Museum of Art and Design in Helsinki, "Finnish Modern Design" is a fine companion piece to the current retrospective of Alvar Aalto's architecture at the Museum of Modern Art. In the Bard show, the work of Aalto (1898-1976), an artist- craftsman as well as an architect, is also much in evidence.
The display of 140 objects -- chairs, coffeepots, lamps, textiles, bowls, glasses, vases, plaques, wearables, even a pair of ergonomic pruning shears -- is divided into two parts: one covering the years 1930 to 1960, the other from 1960 to 1997. The objects, mostly designed for industry or for limited production in artists' studios, are handsomely laid out, and although the exhibition galleries are small, everything seems to fit handily into its own space.
In 1930, the Stockholm Exhibition introduced international modernism to Scandinavia. Already, Aalto and other Finnish architects were doing major public buildings in modern style. The field of applied arts and crafts began to follow suit. The glassworks of Iittala, Karhula and Riihimaki and later the Arabia ceramics factory retuned their product lines as did textile designers and other individual craftspeople.
Still, the traditional Finnish love of the countryside, the deep regard for natural forms and materials, did not fade out. It melded with modernism to create a strong Finnish presence. Among the classics in the show is an exquisitely streamlined platter in the shape of a leaf made of laminated birch by Tapio Wirkkala (1915-1985). Imbued with the Finnish love of wood, Wirkkala used thin laminated striations to represent the leaf's veins in a highly stylized piece that is really a paean to the spirit of earth. Another such form is "Calla" (1946), by Gunnel Nyman (1909-1948), a vase of shaded green glass whose unadorned but lyrical shape suggests a calla lily, a staple of the Finnish landscape.
Glass and ceramic design became, in fact, one of the great Finnish success stories, helped in part by a peculiar economic circumstance.
After World War II, Finland, which had allied itself with Germany hoping to regain territory ceded earlier to the Soviet Union, had to pay heavy reparations to the Russians in the form of manufactured goods. The demand was for products from the metal and engineering industries, whose leading companies also had glass and ceramics factories. To get foreign currency for the expansion of heavier industry, the companies promoted the export of glass and porcelain to the United States and Switzerland, pushing artisans to strive for quality and innovation.
Two major designers for these companies were Wirkkala and Kaj Franck (1911-1989). In 1946, Wirkkala produced for Iittala a clear mold-blown vase engraved with vertical striations, called "Chanterelle" because of its flaring mushroom shape. It came to symbolize the nature-inspired elegance of Finnish art glass, and, as seen in the show, still works its magic. Aalto, too, explored glass, and his suave "Savoy" bowl of 1946, an undulating form in clear blue, has become a legendary token of Finnish design.
Franck, designer for the Arabia company, was the leading advocate of functionalism in glass and pottery. He is known for, among other things, his phenomenally successful "Kilta" dinner service of 1949, a group of 10 minimal shapes in oven-proof faience, made in a modular format that allowed the pieces to be mixed and matched. Among his glassware designs in the show are a handleless clear glass pitcher and cocktail shaker in laboratory-flask shapes, with glasses fitting inside the pitcher to save space. This handsome design was a concession to the American market; at the time, a cocktail shaker was foreign to Finns.
As for furniture, in the early period Aalto was the star, particularly lauded for his experiments with bentwood and molded plywood. His sleek cantilevered "Armchair Model No. 31," designed in 1931 of bent laminated birch and molded plywood, accomplished his goal of an all-wood version of the ideal modernist chair. The graceful roll of the laminated seat and back is beautifully set off by the curves of the bentwood arms and legs. But although "No. 31" was an esthetic hit, as with many of Aalto's designs its high production costs forestalled mass marketing.
Far more successful, in production terms, was the 1946 "Domus" made by Ilmari Tapiovaara. Of solid birch and molded pressed plywood, this sturdy looking chair with short arms and a particularly user-friendly seat incorporated ideas that Aalto had introduced in the 30's, including stackability. Its attractive modernity along with its ease of assembly and transport made it an international success.
To American viewers of a certain age, some objects in the early part of the exhibition, along with "Domus," may seem like old pals. There are, for instance, the birch stacking stools designed by Aalto in 1932; the simple bell-shaped hanging lamp of white-painted sheet metal perforated to diffuse light, made in 1947 by Lisa Johansson-Pape (1907-1989), and Antti Nurmesniemi's squat, homey little red coffeepot of enameled steel with stick-out handle of 1957.
If the second part of the display seems, with certain exceptions, less even than the first, there are reasons. The period it covers, from 1960 to now, has had its ups and downs for designers. For one, in the hairy late 60's they were attacked for elitism, and many left for other parts. The energy crisis of the 1970's strained industrial resources, and the collapse of the Soviet Union, with which Finland had an exclusive trading partnership, led to factory cutbacks and unemployment. (One writer in the well-rounded catalogue suggests that the vast but dull Soviet market dumbed down Finnish invention anyway.)
Still, there is plenty of oomph in this section, which stresses the use of new technologies and materials over the past decade or so. The jewelry and textiles seem more assertive, with strong entries like "Planetoid Valleys," Bjorn Weckstrom's 1969 moon-terrain necklace of rough-surfaced silver squares, and "Seagull," Maija Isola's bold cotton hanging of 1961 for the textile and clothing manufacturer Marimekko, repetitively printed with big sine waves in alternating reds, yellows, blues and greens outlined in black.
Chairs, too, have a more adventurous look, for example Hannu Kahonen's "Trice" of 1985, its high back and flared seat made of thin, paperlike white polyester set on a black coal fiber frame with broad red ribbons for arms, and Ilkka Suppanen's 1994 "Nomad," a thick sheet of white felt spread on a frame of painted black steel. In the clothing line, there is "Ryppypeppu" ("Wrinkled Behind"), designed in 1966 by Annika Rimala, a jumpsuit in a bright orange chain pattern, with wrinkles built in at knees, elbows and bottom.
There's more, much more, to this lively digest of Finnish design, which with its lucid catalogue will tell you all and then some about one of the world's outstanding achievements in modern design. And Bard presents it with customary finesse.
"Finnish Modern Design: Utopian Ideals and Everyday Realities, 1930-1997" is at the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, 18 West 86th Street, Manhattan, through June 14.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 3098 words

HEADLINE: The Oscar Chase: Power and Dollars

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, March 5

 BODY:
Forget Saddam Hussein. Forget Kenneth W. Starr and Bill Clinton.
The countdown to the 70th annual Academy Awards, on March 23, has enough tension and spin control to teach those fellows a few Hollywood-style lessons. For example, when up against "Titanic," the front-runner in the race for best picture and the all-time, worldwide box-office champion, flatter your opponent, but gently (or not so gently) put him down. 
 Here's what Harvey Weinstein, co-chairman of Miramax, which is distributing "Good Will Hunting," one of the five best-picture nominees, has to say about the Oscar race: "It's a battle. 'Titanic' has great special effects, but in 'Good Will Hunting,' the special effects are the words."
Sandy Reisenbach, executive vice president of marketing and planning at Warner Brothers, which released "L.A. Confidential," another best-picture nominee, said of "Titanic": "It sank once. Maybe it'll do it again."
And Curtis Hanson, director of "L.A. Confidential," said: "There are a number of potential icebergs out there in the water. 'L.A. Confidential' is one of them."
"Titanic," made by 20th Century Fox and Paramount, may hit an iceberg or two on Oscar night, but the film will, in all likelihood, dominate the three-hour ceremonies at the Los Angeles Shrine Auditorium. James Cameron's 3-hour and 14-minute blockbuster, about a fictional love affair aboard the doomed vessel, has earned 14 nominations, matching the record of the 1950 classic, "All About Eve." More important, this week "Titanic" became the first film to pass the $1 billion mark in ticket sales.
How can the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, composed of the Hollywood establishment, ignore all that money?
"The only unanswered question about 'Titanic' is whether it will beat the record set by 'Ben-Hur,' which won 11 Oscars," remarked Damien Bona, co-author with Mason Wiley of "Inside Oscar: The Unofficial History of the Academy Awards," most recently updated in 1996 and published by Ballentine Books. He added, "It certainly could."
But the studios that produced "Titanic" are not taking any chances, pouring hundreds of thousands of dollars into the push for an Oscar. Robert G. Friedman, vice chairman of Paramount, which is distributing the film in the United States, insisted that the campaign was "low profile," and that "we believe in the light touch." Still, the company has used the standard tactic of sending videos of the film (it takes up two cassettes) to all Academy members. And like the producers of the other best-picture contenders, which include Fox Searchlight's "Full Monty" and Sony's "As Good as It Gets," it has also advertised prolifically in the trade press.
These kinds of efforts, along with the dizzying spin control, have accelerated each year, making the Oscar contest increasingly resemble a political campaign. In Hollywood terms, the stakes are even higher. An Oscar victory generally translates into huge profits at the box office; can transform careers, and enshrines a film in the Hollywood pantheon.
But such benefits cost. The Oscar campaign for "Titanic" and its competitors, as well as for the individual acting and other awards, is running up a bill for studios and distribution companies of at least $1 million -- for advertising, for the production and distribution of cassettes and for appearances by nominees.
Though most of the advertising campaign is focused on the trade press, producers have bought more time on television and space in newspapers in Los Angeles, certainly to promote the nominated films to audiences but also to create interest among Academy voters.
Miramax and Warner Brothers seem to be spending the most on advertising generally. And both have taken the extra step of sending out screenplays of their nominated films -- "Good Will Hunting" and "L.A. Confidential" -- to all Academy voters.
Warner Brothers' Oscar campaign seems partly motivated by the hunger of the studio for a winner after a lackluster year with flops like "The Postman," starring Kevin Costner, and "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil." The studio's advertisements concentrate on Mr. Hanson, nominated as best director as well as for his screenplay, whose co-writer was Brian Helgeland; it is also heavily promoting Kim Basinger, nominated for best supporting actress.
Hollywood executives said Miramax was putting a lot of money into advertising in The Los Angeles Times in its campaign for "Good Will Hunting." And Mr. Weinstein, the Miramax chief, has displayed formidable talents as a master spinner, insisting to every reporter and gossip columnist that the movie will emerge like "Chariots of Fire" as an unexpected Oscar winner.
But it's not just advertising and spin. Again as in a political race, appearances and interviews by the candidates are considered crucial.
Many veteran stars, like Robert Duvall, nominated for best actor for "The Apostle," or Gloria Stuart, a star of the 1930's nominated as best supporting actress for "Titanic," seem to understand this and are eager to appear on television to discuss their Oscar prospects. But some younger actors, like Ben Affleck, nominated for the screenplay of "Good Will Hunting," and Kate Winslet, nominated as best actress for "Titanic," have publicity agents who, improbable as it seems, are keeping them under wraps, a move that may hurt their chances.
Betting on the best-actor category centers on three veterans: Mr. Duvall, Jack Nicholson for "As Good As It Gets" and Peter Fonda for "Ulee's Gold." Mr. Fonda has been doing a lot of interviewing; Mr. Nicholson has not been that visible.
Also nominated are Matt Damon for "Good Will Hunting" and Dustin Hoffman for "Wag the Dog." Leonardo DiCaprio, the star of "Titanic," was not nominated.
The best-actress race is considered extremely close, but since most of the candidates are British, they have not been doing the usual round of interviews here. Judi Dench was the initial favorite for her role in "Mrs. Brown," partly because Academy voters traditionally adore British stage actresses in costume dramas. Now the odds are improving for two other British actresses, Helena Bonham Carter, also in a costume drama, "The Wings of the Dove," and Julie Christie in "Afterglow."
Ms. Christie, a top star of the 1960's and 1970's who has not appeared in many films lately, is a sentimental choice, but her movie has not quite found an audience. On the other hand, if "Titanic" sweeps the Oscars, Ms. Winslet could win in an upset.
Still, the lone American nominee, Helen Hunt, for "As Good as It Gets," is also emerging as a favorite. Like many political candidates, Ms. Hunt is juggling several jobs, including her television series, "Mad About You," yet managing to speak to as many journalists as possible, often from her car phone.
 
Getting Personal?
There's more than political maneuvering in this year's races. Filmmakers here generally view the nominations as among the most hopeful signs in years that Hollywood is experiencing a small resurgence of more personal movies, driven by story and character.
"Think of 'Boogie Nights' or 'Wag the Dog' or 'L.A. Confidential' or 'The Sweet Hereafter' or 'Good Will Hunting' or 'As Good as It Gets' or other films up for Oscars," said Mr. Hanson, whose "L.A. Confidential" won virtually every critics award in the nation and has been nominated for nine Oscars. "These are personal movies both in subject matter and budget; they're so-called 'adult movies,' and they fall into a category that was considered extinct a few years ago."
"They're not high-concept, they're not star-driven, they're not theme-park rides," he continued. "These pictures not only got made, but they did better on a profit basis and with the Academy than many of those big films that got made solely because of who was in them or because of their apparent 'marketable hook' that studios have been preferring." He added, "I'm not so naive as to say we're in a golden era, but the door is ajar, and hope is alive."
James L. Brooks, director and co-writer with Mark Andrus of "As Good as It Gets," which earned seven nominations, said the best-picture nominees, including "Titanic," had each resulted from a director's intense yearning to create an original, even a personal film.
"What they have in common is someone passionately wanted to make this specific picture because it wasn't like anything else," Mr. Brooks said. He added: "A couple of years ago, if you said you felt passionate about an original idea, people would turn deaf ears. I don't think that's true now."
Last year's nominations were dominated by films like "Shine," "Fargo" and "The English Patient," made by so-called independent film companies (which are mostly owned by conglomerates). Unlike standard Hollywood fare, those movies were generally more personal and offbeat, featuring more unknown British and Australian stage actors than Hollywood stars.
But this year, in the emphasis on more personal stories, the nominations offer a glimpse of how the lines have blurred between Hollywood studios and the independent companies.
"As Good as It Gets," for example, is a small and quirky love story, even though its cast is led by Mr. Nicholson, one of the biggest Hollywood stars. "Good Will Hunting," about a blue-collar mathematical genius in South Boston, was directed by Gus Van Sant, well known for "Drugstore Cowboy" and "My Own Private Idaho," edgy films out of the independent movement. Though Robin Williams, nominated for best supporting actor, has an important role, the other stars include once-unknowns like Mr. Damon and Mr. Affleck, who co-wrote the movie.
"L.A. Confidential," adapted by Mr. Hanson and Brian Helgeland from the James Ellroy novel about the underbelly of Los Angeles life in the 1950's, has no stars and uses an ensemble cast, including two Australian actors. Even "Titanic," in Mr. Brooks's analysis, has some of the sensibility of an independent film in that it grew from the personal vision of its creator, Mr. Cameron.
Then there is "The Full Monty," a gritty comedy about six unemployed men in Sheffield, England, who regain their self-respect by stripping in a club for women. The film had no stars and cost only $3.5 million. It has grossed more than $210 million around the world, making it far more profitable so far than "Titanic."
But the fact that the film's maker, Fox Searchlight, is a division of 20th Century Fox, owned by Rupert Murdoch, which helped finance "Titanic," underlines the impossibility of distinguishing an independent from a studio film.
Why the success of "The Full Monty?," which was nominated for four Oscars, including best screenplay and director. Simon Beaufoy, who wrote the screenplay, said he thought the theme of unemployment and the desperate quest for self-respect struck a nerve among audiences. The notion of male strippers with imperfect bodies helped.
"It was really important that they were as imperfect physically as the rest of us," Mr. Beaufoy said. "That's the bottom line as to why the film is successful. It would be any man up there doing it. It's not George Clooney. It's not Woody Harrelson. It's you and me."
 
Butterflies for Cameron
Though "Titanic" seems to be the current favorite in the best-picture race, there's plenty of speculation about an upset by "The Full Monty" or "L.A. Confidential." Mr. Bona, the Oscar expert, pointed out that often the biggest moneymakers, like "E.T." and "Star Wars," have not been rewarded with the Academy Award. Still, he said, "The fact the production of 'Titanic' was such a crap shoot, and paid off in spades, means that the industry will pat James Cameron on the back."
Mr. Cameron said that he was too nervous to think about winning the Oscar and, as unlikely as it sounded, that he almost wished he wouldn't.
Almost.
Facing that crowd at the Shrine Auditorium and the television audience, possibly one billion people, was a "horrifying" prospect, he said. "I'm petrified," he continued. "Directors choose that role because they want to be behind the camera, not in front of it. That's for actors. It's horrifying to me. You reach a point at one of these ceremonies where you hope someone else wins so you don't get up and embarrass yourself."
Mr. Cameron was pilloried in the press and across Hollywood for going $100 million over budget on his $200 million movie. He's now Hollywood's king.
"We went in with a harebrained theory," the 44-year-old filmmaker said. "Let's do a romantic epic because no one's done one in a long time. All the big commercial heavyweights in the last few years have been science-fiction films. And we thought there was a hunger for emotion, for character, for drama."
Mr. Cameron said the film's length, which was initially seen as commercially disastrous, worked to its advantage. "The good side of it is that in the first hour and 40 minutes, nothing much happens, we get to know the characters, it's all talking heads," he said. "By normal Hollywood mainstream filmmaking standards, it shouldn't have worked. But it does."
"It does because we've been conditioned as an audience to an accelerated pace of editing and a certain style of filmmaking that's more and more frantic," he added. "So something like 'Titanic' comes along -- it's so old that it's new again."
 
A Celebrity at 87
With the final ballots mailed on Tuesday to the 5,371 voting Academy members, many nominees are anxious and, to some degree, delirious.
"Has my life changed? Oh my lord," laughed Ms. Stuart who, at 87, is the oldest person ever nominated for an Acadey Award. She said: "My life has changed from climbing into my car to go to the supermarket to spending my life in limos. It's changed so that couturiers want to dress me for the Oscar. I picked Escada. Harry Winston called to decorate me in jewels. My calendar is full of social events. And I'm getting scripts."
Ms. Stuart retired from acting in the late 1980's. She was working as a book illustrator and artist when Mr. Cameron came to her home to test her after seeing her in a laser disk reissue of the 1932 James Whale cult melodrama, "The Old Dark House." Since "Titanic," she's been offered a number of roles.
"I was offered a script where I play a space woman," Ms. Stuart said. "I don't see myself as a space woman. She continued: "Another one had too much violence and kinky sex. I wouldn't want to be part of that. There have been some others, but there really hasn't been a great role for an old lady since Jessica Tandy in 'Driving Miss Daisy.' "
Similarly, Robert Forster, a 56-year-old Hollywood veteran, said his struggling 30-year career had been abruptly revived by his nomination as best-supporting actor for his role as a bail bondsman in Quentin Tarantino's "Jackie Brown."
"It's amazing," he said. "This is all too much for a guy my size -- you have to be 200 pounds to handle this, and I'm 40 pounds short." He continued: "The first thing you do is get offers for material that's not so great but lots of money. I'm cautious about that. I want material that will keep my career alive for as many years as I've got."
As to the inevitable question about his outfit for the Big Night -- virtually all the prominent nominees are provided free clothes by well-known designers -- Mr. Forster said simply: "Armani has offered me a free tuxedo. Who am I to refuse Armani?"
Ms. Hunt said that as hard as she worked -- she's in her sixth year of "Mad About You," is directing several shows of the series and is weighing a play in New York and several film scripts -- there is only one thing people are curious about. "They keep asking about the dress," she said. "I've got to turn the dress drama down."
Even Atom Egoyan, the reflective 37-year-old Canadian filmmaker nominated as best director for "The Sweet Hereafter," said he was unexpectedly shaken by the clothes issue. "The nomination is a very big deal in Canada, and all sorts of designers want to outfit you," he said.
He said his wife and collaborator, Arsinee Khanjian, has been approached by virtually every Canadian designer. "My wife is completely overwhelmed," Mr. Egoyan said
But headded: "Actually, this whole thing is a real ride. I've been feeling giddy from the morning I was nominated. I just can't stop smiling."
 
Voting Members: 5,371 With Perks
 HOLLYWOOD, March 5 -- It's one of the world's more exclusive and powerful clubs.
The Oscar electorate now comprises 5,371 voting members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences -- the figure varies almost monthly -- whose decisions on the night of the Academy Awards (March 23) can make careers, shatter egos and add millions of dollars to the profits of a winning film.
The voters are, in a sense, the cream of the motion picture business.
Who are they? John Pavlik, an Academy spokesman, said members were divided into 13 branches, the largest among them actors. The other branches include directors, writers, cinematographers, producers, sound technicians, editors, executives and musicians. There are also members-at-large.
Mr. Pavlik said the Academy kept no records of the age of its members, but it is believed that most voters are men over 40.
Oscar nominees are automatically considered for membership in the following year. Otherwise, candidates are sponsored by two members. Generally, applicants have worked five to eight years in the movie business.
The executive committee of each branch meets twice a year to assess prospective candidates. Final approval comes from the 39-member board of governors, made up of members of each of the branches. The current president is Robert Rehme, a producer. Recent presidents have included the director Arthur Hiller and the actor Karl Malden.
Dues are $200 a year. This entitles cardholders to free films at the Samuel Goldwyn Theater, the Academy's plush private auditorium. During the Academy Award campaign, cardholders can also see films free at many theaters in Los Angeles, New York and elsewhere.
Perhaps it is not surprising that talent agents are the one powerful group in Hollywood bypassed for full membership. Agents, who are often resented because of their clout, are associate members of the Academy, leaving them relatively powerless. Virtually every year the Academy's leadership hears a proposal to give agents full membership. Inevitably the proposal has been rejected, one of the rare occasions when actors, writers and directors can thumb their noses, albeit anonymously, at agents. BERNARD WEINRAUB

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Unsold Apartments to Yield Larger, Fancier Units

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A developer is renovating 80 apartments that it bought in January in a 208-unit building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and combining at least 15 units.
The builder, Essex Capital Partners Ltd., is to invest $30,000 to $95,000 to upgrade each of the one- and two-bedroom units, with 593 to 981 square feet, at 200 East 90th Street. The combined apartments are being reshaped to create three- and four-bedroom units with 1,264 to 2,052 square feet, as well as one with up to five bedrooms and 3,600 square feet. 
 Financing for the $16.5 million project, including the acquisition of the units, is coming from investors, lending institutions and the developer. Essex Capital buys and develops underperforming residential and commercial properties along the East Coast.
The company, with offices in Manhattan and Washington, bought the units, as well as 7,500 square feet of retail space, in the 18-year-old building at Third Avenue, which was converted from rental to a co-op in 1988. Forty-four units were sold through 1990, when the market declined sharply, and the rest were rented. Eight years and three owners later, an additional 84 had been sold.
The seller of the remaining unsold units was a financial institution that took back the apartments in an uncontested foreclosure from the previous owners. The previous owners had improved the lobby and common areas, but their plan, also to upgrade and combine units, was cut short.
Peter Hauspurg, chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a real estate investment banking company, said it was unusual to find a large block of units available because as a result of the boom-and-bust-cycle of the late 1980's, most have been sold.
"But there are deals that were bandaged together, only to crash again," Mr. Hauspurg added, noting that the deal could work if the units were purchased and improved at a price lower than what it would cost to build new ones.
That was a factor in buying the units, a move that the president of Essex Capital, Mitchell B. Rutter, said "represented an opportunity to buy a building within a building in a good location."
Because most of the units are or will soon be vacant, Mr. Rutter said, he will not have difficulty renovating and selling them. Another factor is that the 29-story building is a co-op, but its rules are similar to those of a condominium. Owners can buy and sell units without board approval and have more flexibility in subleasing them. That, along with upgrading and combining units, will make the project more competitive, he said,
"We are hopeful, and all indications are positive, that everything Essex Capital plans to do will be carried out," the secretary of the co-op board, Eric M. Dessen, said. "It would increase the value of all the apartments and bring stability to the building."
Meryl Sacks, a senior account executive at Charles H. Greenthal Management, which manages the building, said, "An active sales program is the last piece of the puzzle."
The building has been down this road before. In its life as a co-op, sales have been hampered by factors like the recession and the changing ownership of the unsold units. Despite that, the finances remained stable because the rental income was sufficient to cover operating costs, Ms. Sacks said.
Mr. Rutter said the difference with his plan was that it is well capitalized, allowing Essex Capital to invest more money in the units and sell them at a higher price.
What brokers say is on Essex Capital's side is timing, because demand is outstripping supply, especially for larger units and those with high-quality finishes. "Buyers today are not looking as much for location as they are space and or good quality apartments," said Diane M. Ramirez, executive sales director at the Halstead Property Company, a large brokerage firm.
The 80 units will have kitchens with granite countertops and bathrooms with marble floors and walls. Asking prices are $175,000 to $317,000 for the smaller units and $565,000 to $950,000 for the combined units. The agents expect the five-bedroom unit to cost $1.2 million to $1.6 million.
By comparison, the Real Estate Board of New York recorded the median sales price at the end of last year for co-ops in postwar East Side buildings at $162,000 for one bedroom, $439,000 for two bedrooms, $650,000 for three bedrooms and $1.69 million for those with four or more bedrooms.
Monthly fees, including real estate taxes, at 200 East 90th Street are $543 to $2,247. Those for the biggest unit are estimated at $3,584. In the three weeks since sales started, contracts are pending on 14 apartments, said Aimee Mandossian, director of sales and marketing.

HEADLINE: A New Penn Station

 BODY:
Negotiators for the United States Postal Service and a city-state development agency have finally reached a tentative peace agreement that would transform part of the James A. Farley Post Office on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan into a railroad station. One big question is how much the Postal Service is willing to part with. But the news that both sides are now willing to get started is welcome. New Yorkers need and tourists deserve a new terminal on the West Side that is not only comfortable and efficient but evokes the grandeur lost when New York City foolishly dismantled the old Penn Station in 1963.
The shape of the project will begin to emerge only when the Postal Service and the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation draft a memorandum of understanding that spells out exactly how much space the Postal Service will provide and what plans it has for the rest of the 1.4-million-square-foot building. But the vision of a grand new gateway to the city, long nurtured by organizations like the Municipal Arts Society and public figures like Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, seems somewhat less remote than it was a few weeks ago. 
 The big issues are size and scheduling. During its negotiations with Amtrak a few years ago, the Postal Service said it would give up 325,000 square feet for a terminal that would accommodate Amtrak's proposed high-speed rail service and commuter rail lines. There is no firm evidence that it is willing to go much beyond 350,000, which represents only about a quarter of its space and is clearly inadequate to accommodate not only the trains but the shops, restaurants and other amenities that will help underwrite the estimated $315 million cost.
In addition, the Postal Service is thinking of gradually moving its operations out of the station. Would it not be better to find a new site for its midtown postal operations and then relinquish much or all of the property at one time, to insure coordination in design and construction? The Farley project should be guided by the same principle that produced Rockefeller Center, the United Nations and other great public buildings and spaces that define New York. These projects were not conceived in pieces or developed in fits and starts.

HEADLINE: China's Paragon of Corruption;
Meet Mr. Chu, a Hero to Some, an Embezzler to Others

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: YUXI, China

 BODY:
Chu Shijian is still a hero in this ramshackle town, even though he stands accused of diverting more than $145 million from state coffers, one of the most spectacular cases of corruption in China since the Communist Party came to power nearly 50 years ago.
A short and impetuous man, often seen on a factory floor with his sleeves rolled up and a Red Pagoda cigarette dangling from his lower lip, Mr. Chu cut a distinctive figure at the tobacco company he led for 17 years. Mr. Chu, who turned Red Pagoda into the most popular brand in all of China, now languishes in jail here in Yunnan Province. 
 Many residents credit Mr. Chu with single-handedly bringing prosperity and pride to Yuxi, creating thousands of jobs, and building the town's only skyscraper. In Beijing, the authorities portray Mr. Chu as a criminal degenerate who skimmed the difference between the low official price and a much higher sales price on billions of cigarettes each year, yielding a huge off-the-books income that he channeled into dozens of hidden bank accounts.
In between these two extremes lies a more nuanced picture of Mr. Chu as a talented manager working in a system so economically irrational that it encourages inaccurate financial reporting as well as outright embezzlement. Low state-mandated prices, mixed with high market demand, invariably invite trouble.
Mr. Chu and the story of Red Pagoda embody a central paradox of China today: virtually any multimillion-dollar company, striving to become modern in a system that remains stubbornly old-fashioned, is wide open to so much corruption that success almost inevitably leads to financial shenanigans that can spoil any chance of efficiency or genuine profitability.
The authorities like to portray corruption in China as the fault of a few immoral individuals, or as a minor obstacle to reform, rather than as a symptom of deeper trouble. Yet corruption is virtually built into a system where prices are controlled but finances are not.
As executives and officials here acknowledge when pressed, there barely exists a large company in China today that does not have hidden accounting, secret decision making, tiny salaries and lavish perks for managers, all of them invitations to greater financial impropriety. Corruption is now so endemic in China's businesses that no one can accurately see where it begins and ends.
"There is no way to measure corruption in China's state-owned enterprises," said Kenneth G. Lieberthal, a China scholar at the University of Michigan. "But the fundamental structure of Chinese enterprises provides management with ample opportunities to engage in significant self-dealing."
The hand-in-hand collusion of business and government is at the root of structural problems that underlie the Asian financial crisis in many of China's neighbors. Though China has so far avoided a currency or stock market dive, it suffers from cronyism as much as, if not more than, Indonesia, Thailand or South Korea.
Hundreds of company executives were disciplined for corruption last year, though it is widely believed that many thousands more have gone unpunished. Without a working legal system, wrongdoing is typically investigated by "discipline inspection teams" that are heavily political, leaving the well-connected free to flout the law.
What seems most remarkable about Mr. Chu's case is that it was ever exposed. With no independent media, and no incentive for government officials to admit how bad corruption has become, it is the rare case where the head of a company loses his or her political connections so completely that the case is made public. Yet that is what happened to Mr. Chu, who is now 70.
"Chu thought he was untouchable, after all he had done," said a Chinese businessman who works with Red Pagoda, known in Chinese as the Hongta Group. "His connections were not as strong as he thought."
In January, the authorities announced that they had expelled Mr. Chu from the Communist Party for "serious economic crimes," a virtual guarantee that he would eventually be charged, tried in court and found guilty.
An official report on his wrongdoing, recently printed in People's Daily, was almost like a catalogue of how to run a family empire, with Mr. Chu's wife and daughter running a huge bribe-taking scheme.
When Mr. Chu was named general manager of Red Pagoda in 1979, it was a small factory, earning less than $1 million a year by making a hodge-podge of local brands of cigarettes. Like most state-run companies, Red Pagoda was required to hand over all its profits to the Government, while its managers and employees alike earned under $25 a month.
Mr. Chu recognized that as China's booming economic growth gave ordinary people the buying power to afford cigarettes, promoting the factory's flagship Red Pagoda brand all over the nation was the way to maximize income.
It worked. Red Pagoda became so popular that the official price of $1 a pack was outstripped by the market price that eventually grew to $1.50 to $2. Still operating in a system that required the company only to report income from the official, artificially low price, Mr. Chu found that he could set aside millions of dollars earned at the higher, market price.
Mr. Chu spent some of Red Pagoda's unreported income on new machinery, insisting that his company have the most up-to-date operations to spur production. He also built new apartment buildings for his employees and modern offices for his staff, since waiting for officials to do so might mean waiting forever.
Yet there was a dark side, too. By 1995, when the company rolled more than 100 billion cigarettes, the Red Pagoda brand was so sought-after that distributors were willing to pay bribes to Mr. Chu and his family just to gain access to his product, even at inflated prices.
Since his official salary remained less than $250 a month, the temptation for graft proved irresistible. The same is true, Chinese business leaders agree, at many large Chinese companies.
"The investigation showed that Chu Shijian abused his power to approve the illegal purchase and speculative profiteering of cigarettes from 1991 to 1995," the official report said. "His family members and other relatives received large bribes."
Mr. Chu personally pocketed at least $1.7 million in bribes, the report said, while his daughter took more than $5 million and his wife took more than $1 million. But even that is a fraction of the more than $145 million that Mr. Chu diverted from the Government, hiding it in various company bank accounts.
In 1996, Red Pagoda reported an income of $2.3 billion, though it is anyone's guess how much more was coming in unofficially.
"Only a fool reports his company's income accurately," said another Chinese businessman in Kunming, the capital of Yunnan Province. Most companies, the executive said, operate multiple sets of company accounts, often making it impossible to decipher true revenues or profits.
One of the glaringly unanswered questions in the official report is how Mr. Chu operated his scheme for years without detection by local tax collectors, auditors and tobacco officials. It would have been impossible to divert such a towering amount of cash, Chinese executives who did business with Red Pagoda say, without systematically bribing local officials.
For years Mr. Chu was protected politically. His biggest backer was always Pu Chaozhu, a boyhood friend who rose in the provincial hierarchy to become Communist Party chief of Yunnan Province in 1985. Mr. Pu remained there 11 years, before he was forced to retire in 1996, the same year that Mr. Chu came under investigation.
Businessmen in Yunnan also say that Deng Zhifang, the youngest son of Deng Xiaoping, the paramount leader who died last year, was one of the many "princelings" -- the offspring of China's leaders -- who were associates of Mr. Chu. Neither Mr. Pu nor Mr. Deng has been charged with wrongdoing.
"For every corrupt act, it takes a manager to engage in it and an official to tolerate it," said Yasheng Huang, a China scholar at Harvard Business School. "Unlike owners of private firms, public officials do not gain economically from efficient uses of the state-owned assets. At best, they do not actively punish managers who abuse state-owned assets. At worst, they use their power to benefit themselves."
When Mr. Chu's empire began to crumble, it did so quickly. In 1996, his wife and daughter were arrested. Mr. Chu's daughter, Chu Yingqun, died in prison, apparently from suicide.
The report also fails to accurately document another side of Mr. Chu's illegal activity. Because of onerous taxes on domestic sale of cigarettes, businessmen say, Red Pagoda exported millions of dollars worth of cigarettes each year, only to smuggle them back into China, where they could be sold without paying tax.
Mr. Chu's son headed Red Pagoda's overseas operations in Singapore, the Asian center for cigarette trading, an industry long dominated by organized crime. In 1993, Tommy Chui, a distributor for British American Tobacco agreed to testify for the prosecution in a smuggling case, only to have his corpse turn up floating in Singapore harbor, padlocked in an industrial laundry bag with his mouth taped shut.
Mr. Chu's son remains at large, and is believed to be in Singapore.
According to the authorities, the elder Mr. Chu tried to escape overseas after he realized that the investigation into Red Pagoda's activities could not be stymied by "hundreds of thousands of dollars" in bribes he attempted to give investigators. He was stopped at a border checkpoint, trying to enter Vietnam in December 1996, and has been held in custody since.
In Yuxi, however, Mr. Chu remains a hero, even after the publicizing of his purported wrongdoing.
"After all he did for this company, he should be forgiven," said a financial officer at Red Pagoda, whose 5,500 employees are now led by Zi Guorui. "He's an old man."
The executive, standing outside Red Pagoda's headquarters in Yuxi, gestured at the gleaming skyscraper behind him.
"Look at this building," the executive said. "No one else could have done what Chu Shijian did for us."
The Chinese businessman in Kunming offered a slightly different view.
"He did what every other company head in China does," the businessman said. "He just messed up his connections."

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid to Help Train People on Welfare as Child Care Workers

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Officials in the South Bronx and Harlem plan to use Federal economic development aid to train welfare recipients as child care workers, helping them find work while creating thousands of sorely needed day care openings for children, thus making it possible for even more jobless parents to work.
The two communities' efforts are meant to address what experts have called a missing link in the welfare-to-work progression: many people motivated -- or required, under new workfare programs -- to look for jobs or enter training programs have been unable to for want of an affordable, safe place to leave their children during the day. 
 In the next two years, more than 2,500 new child care spots could be created through the two initiatives, which officials said would cost more than $3 million. They said the Harlem effort would start first, in May.
Officials of New York's Empowerment Zone, whose management is divided between agencies in Manhattan and the Bronx, said their child care initiatives were an important part of any overall economic development strategy. "We're creating entrepreneurs, and making more people available to go to work," said Nancy Devine, chief program officer at the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Corporation.
Four organizations have already been chosen by the Harlem part of the empowerment zone to train 400 people to provide what is known as family day care, for small groups of children, typically in the provider's home. Trainees will be instructed in early childhood and educational development, nutrition, first aid, safety, health and small-business skills.
The groups are the Dominican Women's Development Center, Rena Day Care Centers, Union Settlement Association and a partnership of Harlem Congregations for Community Improvement and Child Care Inc. The Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Corporation will provide $1 million; the four groups will add $1.4 million from other sources.
The shortage of child care in Harlem is estimated at 9,350 slots, Ms. Devine said. Her agency's two-year program, which is to get under way within two months, should reduce that gap by 2,000, she said.
Meanwhile, the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, overseen by Fernando Ferrer, the Borough President, intends to train about 50 people to provide family day care. "It's a very smart investment," said Mr. Ferrer, who announced the plan, "Bronx Cares," yesterday in his State of the Borough address. "We're talking about creating, for starters, 50 providers, who'll be able to work at home. That opens up 500 slots, 10 per provider, with a minimal amount of money. That's mothers who can go to work, who can qualify for a job in the empowerment zone or for a job training program."
Bronx officials are hoping to provide subsidies to attract established group day care centers, which can serve dozens of children at a time in classroomlike settings, to open in the South Bronx. The Bronx development agency will spend $2 million in the first year for day care programs.
Robin C. McClary, a senior project manager at the Bronx agency, said that in the South Bronx part of the zone, there were only two day care centers, serving fewer than 200 children despite a population that includes 4,000 children under age 6, and in which more than half the families were on public assistance.
Child care experts lauded the two programs but warned that training family day care providers could be more difficult than anticipated.
"We've been doing family day care provider training in the South Bronx for four years," Nancy Biberman, president of the Women's Housing and Economic Development Corporation, said.
"We've trained 125 women, and we now have 30 providers in our network, and 100 kids in day care," she said. "But we've actually gotten only four women off welfare and into self-sustaining businesses. It sounds good, but it's extremely complex."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Factory Orders Up; Jobless Claims Down

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
The Government reported a rebound in monthly factory orders and a large drop in weekly jobless claims today, which analysts called evidence of a vibrant economy.
They said the numbers also suggested the economy had yet to feel any significant impact from Asia. 
 The Commerce Department said orders for goods produced by factories rose five-tenths of a percent in January, to $337.4 billion, compared with a 2.6 percent drop in December.
The Labor Department said the number of people filing first-time claims for state unemployment benefits in the week ended last Saturday dropped by 16,000, to 304,000.
The Labor Department also said continuing jobless claims in the week ended Feb. 21 fell by 103,000 to the lowest level in more than eight years.
The department releases its employment report for February on Friday. Analysts expect it to show the unemployment rate fell back to a 24-year low of 4.6 percent from 4.7 percent in January, and many predicted 247,000 jobs were created.

HEADLINE: The Rot in Indonesia

 BODY:
Indonesia faces an immediate financial crisis that the International Monetary Fund can help fix, and a longer-term political crisis that can be remedied only by reforms that President Suharto seems incapable of adopting. Though the monetary fund is right to be concerned about corruption and financial favoritism in Indonesia, it should be concentrating on the economic problems that threaten to bankrupt that country. The other problems, including the business manipulations of the Suharto family, will require sustained American pressure.
The I.M.F. came to Indonesia's rescue with a $40 billion bailout out of concern for its 200 million citizens and out of fear that the country's financial collapse would ripple around the world. The most pressing problem is the collapse of the rupiah, the Indonesian currency. That has raised the price of food and other imports and frightened away foreign investors. As a result, interest rates have soared to levels that have devastated Indonesian companies and their creditor domestic banks. The proper remedy for this financial chaos is financial reform. President Clinton's emissary, Walter Mondale, properly warned Mr. Suharto that he must stop evading such reform. 
 In Indonesia's case, that means the appointment of competent economic ministers. Unfortunately, Mr. Suharto recently appointed a political hack as head of the central bank. Reform also means that Mr. Suharto must first pledge, then keep, a tight lid on the money supply. If he does, inflation, which last month exceeded 200 percent a year, will fall and the rupiah will rise. He must also negotiate a feasible repayment schedule with foreign creditors and control government spending, but not as tightly as the I.M.F. insists since its targets would force him to cut back on food subsidies that Indonesia's citizens desperately need.
Mr. Suharto has made progress in cleaning up the banking industry. The I.M.F. insists that he close failing banks and prop up solvent ones so they can reopen lines of credit to cash-starved Indonesian factories. Here is where I.M.F. money and other international aid can play a significant role.
Once core financial problems are addressed, Washington must press for other reforms. Indonesia should end the cartels through which Mr. Suharto's family and friends control trade in plywood and other products. Special banking deals for family members should be eliminated, and his friends and relatives should not get a cut of international business deals. The I.M.F. should play a role in pressuring him to accept these changes. For now the emphasis must be on the financial problems that threaten economic collapse. But Mr. Suharto should not think that is all that is required of him.

HEADLINE: Miami Delays the Naming of an Interim Mayor

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 5

 BODY:
The question of who is the mayor of Miami remained up in the air today after the City Commission postponed making an interim appointment in response to a court ruling that voided the last election because of ballot fraud.
The commission delayed the decision because one candidate, the previous Mayor, Joe Carollo, is planning a legal challenge to the ruling. 
 Mr. Carollo, whose lawsuit challenging the validity of the vote led to the court decision, said he planned to go to court on Friday seeking to be allowed to serve as interim mayor until a new election.
On Wednesday, Judge Thomas S. Wilson Jr. of Circuit Court in Miami overturned the first-round balloting on Nov. 4 that led to Xavier L. Suarez's defeat of Mr. Carollo in a runoff on Nov. 13. Judge Wilson ordered that a new election be held in 60 days.
But the judge did not address the question of who would act as mayor in the meantime. The city charter gives the City Commission 10 days to fill the vacancy, but Mr. Carollo says that because he was in office before the election, he has the right to resume his duties until a lawful successor is elected in early May.
Today his lawyer, Kendall Coffey, sent a letter to City Hall advising the commissioners that Mr. Carollo would seek "an emergency appeal" of Judge Wilson's decision to the Third District Court of Appeals.
While postponing their decision on an interim mayor until Wednesday, the five commissioners emphasized that Miami was not a city in chaos.
"The city will continue to do business and provide services to our residents, and everything is going fine," said Commissioner Wifredo Gort. "We are running City Hall. We're giving instructions to the city manager, and the city manager follows these instructions."
Despite such assurances, the political uncertainty comes at a sensitive time for Miami, which is still trying to recover from a financial crisis that required Gov. Lawton Chiles to appoint a financial oversight board in 1996 to steer it toward solvency.
After considerable progress over the last year in reining in spending, the city faces a shortfall of at least $25 million in this year's budget after the commission balked at imposing a fire-rescue services fee to raise revenue, state officials said.
But Joe Pena, a special assistant to Governor Chiles who is working with the oversight board, said the problems at City Hall should not interfere with the financial recovery plan because most of the work was being done by an administrative staff still in place.
"We've got to continue to stay focused," Mr. Pena said. "We're confident that we'll continue to strengthen the City of Miami."
Officials with Miami-Dade County, which encompasses the city, have also taken pains once again to keep Miami's problems from detracting from an area that is heavily dependent on tourism and international trade. While the city carries the name Miami, it is only 1 of 30 municipalities that best define the area outsiders identify as Miami.
The city represents only 6 percent of the region's budget and 17 percent of its residents, county officials said. Nationally, Miami ranks 44th among cities with more than 100,000 residents, with 358,600 people counted in the 1990 census and a 1996 estimated population of 365,100.
County officials also said they were working to repair the absentee ballot system, something that national experts said was also susceptible to fraud across the country. Some experts said it was a good sign that the fraud in Miami had led to at least four arrests.

Stocks Fall Sharply Following Intel Warning
Stock investors rushed to sell yesterday in the aftermath of a late Wednesday warning from the technology leader Intel that its first-quarter results would fail to meet expectations.
