HEADLINE: ANTIQUE FORTRESS: A special report.;
Park Ave. Armory Is Losing the Battle Within

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB and CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
The Seventh Regiment Armory stands like a fortress overlooking Park Avenue, a crenelated, red-brick landmark with a formidable presence that befits its role as the premier showplace in New York City for internationally renowned art, antiques and crafts shows.
But inside, the 118-year-old armory is something else: a long-neglected giant in such disrepair that crumbling ceilings and leaky walls are endangering portions of the building's permanent multimillion-dollar collection of American paintings, decorative arts and military artifacts. 
 Parts of a first-floor ceiling have collapsed over the last two years, ruining original hand-stenciled walls and damaging historical paintings. More ceiling damage occurred last week when torrential rains caused chunks of plaster to fall in the south portion of the building's main corridor. State officials in charge of the armory, which was built with private money on city-owned land, have closed two architecturally prized rooms whose portrait-covered walls and oak floors were drenched by cascading water from the leaks.
Yet while repairs and maintenance have been postponed for lack of money, the obscure state agency that runs the building has rented out the armory's huge former drill hall for exhibitions at what amounts to bargain-basement prices to a small group of show sponsors.
Exhibition promoters clamor for dates that many experts say can produce $1 million in profits for a show running a week to 10 days. But the state rents the space without competitive bidding for less than $7,000 a day.
Such lost economic opportunities and deterioration are among the findings of an inquiry by The New York Times into the state of the storied armory.
Government officials in charge of the building attribute the problems to years of neglect under previous state administrations, which they say they are correcting. And they defend their rental practices as cost-efficient and responsible. But civic leaders still fear for the future.
"We are really worried about saving the building," said Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society, the private group that has long campaigned to preserve the city's architectural heritage. "It is a storehouse of city and national treasures, but it is not being treated like a landmark."
The armory, which occupies the block bordered by East 66th and East 67th Streets and Park and Lexington Avenues, is a bit of New York in a bottle. Along with National Guard members, it attracts affluent art collectors worldwide who come to New York just to attend galas and high-priced charity openings of prestigious art gatherings like the International Fine Art and Antiques Dealers Show or the Winter Antiques Show. The armory is also frequented by a hundred homeless women who live in a shelter on two of the building's five stories.
On many days, 40 boys and girls in crisp uniforms march down the armory's hallways in formation, the latest incarnation of a century-old military youth corps known as the Knickerbocker Greys. Patrons dine in the Seventh Regiment Mess Hall, a dark, wood-paneled restaurant lined with moose heads.
And on days when booths are being built for art shows, the armory can be a lucrative workplace for more than 40 union carpenters with suspected organized-crime affiliations or criminal records. Those backgrounds led the state in 1995 to bar them from work at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. After they were ousted from the convention center, , their union put them on a preferential hiring list for armory shows.
The agency responsible for the building is a little-known branch of state government, the grandly named division of military and naval affairs, which oversees the state's National Guard, including the guard's air and naval units.
Maj. Gen. John H. Fenimore 5th, who was appointed by Governor George E. Pataki in 1995 to lead the division, acknowledged the significant repair problems. But he blamed "decades of underfunding" by previous legislatures and gubernatorial administrations for maintenance not only of Park Avenue, but of many of the state's 65 armories.
For the 1997-1998 fiscal year, General Fenimore said, about $3 million was allocated by the Legislature for maintenance and repairs at the armories, although about $35 million is needed for essential work.
General Fenimore and other division officials defended their management as the best that could be expected given the shortage of money, and they pointed to more than $500,000 worth of repairs undertaken at the Park Avenue armory in the last fiscal year.
The absence of competitive bidding for show dates, they said, is a sound practice given the smooth operation and prompt payment of leasing fees by the armory's longstanding show promoters.
"To the best of my knowledge, the building has been maintained as well as possible," General Fenimore said in an interview. "It is underfunding, not lack of willingness, that has caused the problems."
But some critics say the division is responsible for the armory's problems.
"They are letting this building rot and fade away," said David C. Dalva, a dealer in French antiques and a trustee of the Seventh Regiment Fund, an 89-year-old group founded to preserve the armory's art and military collections. The group and the state are locked in court battles over which of them is the rightful owner of the collections.
Because of concern over the building's deterioration, the fund, without the state's permission, lent four paintings worth an estimated $1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the late 1980's for safekeeping.
While state lawyers defend the ownership of the collection, it is clear that the Pataki administration is unhappy with the military affairs division's management record. In an interview, Charles A. Gargano, a top economic adviser to Governor Pataki, said extensive managerial changes could be coming.
"In my opinion," said Mr. Gargano, who is chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency, "the building needs rehabilitation, and the private sector is best suited for that."
 
Built to Last
A Palatial Home For Elite Soldiers
Vanderbilts. Morgans. Auchinclosses. Winthrops. These families and others with wealthy New York bloodlines are amply represented in the Seventh Regiment rosters. So are the poet Ogden Nash, the artist Thomas Nast and August Belmont, the financier who was a leading figure in building Belmont Raceway and the city's first subway line.
The regiment was formed in 1806 as a militia by city residents who elected officers and provided their own elaborate uniforms and weapons.
Dubbed the Silk Stocking Regiment because of its cadre of wealthy and prominent New Yorkers, the unit volunteered for duty in the War of 1812 and made its mark as one of the first militias to march to the defense of Washington at the outbreak of the Civil War. In 1863, it helped suppress the anti-draft riots in Manhattan.
In the 1870's, the regiment privately raised $601,536, commissioned a design by Charles W. Clinton, one of its veterans, and built its grand home on city-owned land. The armory opened in 1879.
The building's highlights include a massive truss system enclosing a 31,000-square-foot Drill Shed, which is bathed partly in natural light and is now used primarily as the exhibition hall for art and antiques shows.
The armory's dozen ornately decorated rooms are among the finest surviving examples of the American Esthetic Movement, whose hand-crafted designs were a defiant reaction to the manufactured products of the Industrial Revolution.
Portions of the interiors were designed by the architect Stanford White, and many of them were furnished and detailed by Louis Comfort Tiffany, along with Associated Artists, the firm in which Tiffany was a partner. He included many examples of the stained-glass lighting and windows for which he is best remembered.
One of the most elaborate rooms is the Veterans Room, commonly referred to as the Tiffany room. Tiffany decorated the room with five stained-glass windows, wrought-iron candelabras, a stenciled aluminum-leaf pattern on the ceiling and recessed iron tiles, designed by White, that resemble plates of armor.
Since the day it opened, the armory has also been decorated with artworks and furniture donated for the most part by Seventh Regiment veterans.
This collection, dominated by Nast's huge canvas of the regiment departing New York for battle in 1861, is conservatively valued in excess of $10 million. It contains ornate regimental silver, a trove of uniforms, battle flags, weapons and other military memorabilia, and one of the country's richest repositories of Civil War art.
"These are the icons of battle art," said Harold Holzer, co-author of "Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory: The Civil War in Art" and vice president for communications at the Metropolitan Museum. "These are the images that launched a thousand prints."
In 1942, the National Guard took over the management and maintenance of the building from the city. Five years later, when the Federal Government reorganized state national guards, the Seventh Regiment ceased to exist as an active military unit. Members of the old regiment were incorporated into the 107th Infantry, and they and other guard units were assigned office and training space in the Park Avenue building.
Although the actual ownership of the armory is murky, because the original owner, the Seventh Regiment, no longer exists, the state has been responsible for the building's upkeep for 55 years.
During the last decade, the 107th virtually ended its military functions at the armory, with most of its training held elsewhere. As military needs declined, the building was put to its diverse uses.
"The armory is like Broadway, cutting across different groups, classes and cultures in the city," said Susan A. Nayowith, the director of the women's shelter at the armory, run for the city by the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, a nonprofit agency.
Some staff members and shelter residents say there are awkward moments when restaurant patrons encounter women in nightclothes in the building's lone elevator. And there are some bruised feelings when the homeless are told to enter and leave through an unmarked basement door instead of the canopy-covered staircase used by restaurant and exhibition visitors. Still, there is a hearty dose of bonhomie amid the sprawl.
"We coexist peacefully," said Ms. Nayowith.
 
Assessing Damage
Concrete Evidence Of State Cutbacks
The diminished military use over the last 15 years was paralleled by a decline in state spending on maintenance. State officials said records of maintenance expenditures in the 1980's were unavailable, but that cutbacks at the armory stemmed partly from wider state budget problems in those years on into the 1990's. They noted that in 1993, only $78,000 was allocated for major repairs, and in 1996 that figure fell to $21,000.
In a structural study of the city's armories 12 years ago, the New York Landmarks Conservancy, a private nonprofit group, found that the Seventh Regiment Armory needed extensive repairs because of water collecting, mainly behind the walls of the south side of the building. For example, the report cited serious plaster damage in the elaborate Board of Officers Room.
Pamela Hawkes, who worked on the report as a partner in Ann Beha Associates, a firm of architects in Boston, said her firm detailed the findings to the division of military and naval affairs. Peg Breen, the Conservancy president, said the division had been notified of the study 10 years ago.
Walt Wheeler, a division spokesman, said the agency's officials had never received the report and were unfamiliar with its contents. But he said that the division had allocated "a larger proportionate share of maintenance and repair funds to the Park Avenue armory" than to others in the state that also need help.
Between 1993 and 1997, he said, the division spent $1,595,048 on repairs at the armory, and it has three projects under way valued at about $145,000.
But the damage is outpacing the division's ability to correct it. Out of concern for safety, the division in November 1996 closed the celebrated Clark Room, once lined with portraits of former regimental commanders, to the public because of leaks and falling plaster. The following March the state put the adjacent Mary Divver Room off limits, citing safety problems.
To prevent further damage to paintings in the rooms, the division has stacked them side by side on the floors alongside rolled-up oriental rugs.
State officials said it was unclear when the rooms could be used again.
 
Checking the Books
Dubious Payments, Past and Future
Four years after the Landmarks Conservancy first documented structural problems at the armory, the state Comptroller's office uncovered equally troubling financial problems. Audits in 1991 and 1993 found that the state was losing money because the division of military affairs had negotiated leases below fair market rates with show sponsors and other groups. The Comptroller said the division allowed some renters to default on bills.
The backdrop for the audits was a scandal within the division. James Doolan, the armory's superintendent through much of the 1980's, pleaded guilty in 1993 to extorting $100,000 in cash and gifts from show organizers and exhibitors. After the audits, division officials promised to tighten oversight. But today, with the success of the armory shows growing, the bargain rents persist and seem even more glaring.
Division officials said in recent interviews that they did not look at the exhibition rentals primarily as an income-generating opportunity, even though they produced $1.4 million in revenue last year, up $400,000 from 1996. The money is deposited in the state general fund.
"The armory rental program is intended to be a public service, not a profit-maximization program," Daniel J. Travers, the division's director of facilities management and engineering, said in a written statement. For show organizers, though, the armory can be a money mill.
At the longest and most lavish events, some promoters charge exhibitors $10,600 to $26,000 for space, and most shows are jammed with more than 70 exhibitors. In addition, the organizers keep the entrance fees, with tickets costing between $8 and $16 and as many as 22,000 people attending the most popular shows. Profits, say several organizers, can be $1 million for a six-day event.
What does the state glean from this? Forty thousand dollars in a good week.
The division leases the Drill Shed for $6,667 a day, or $40,002 for a six-day show. Nonprofit groups are charged less, $3,400 a day for fund-raisers. The state gets no percentage of the entrance fees, as some exhibition hall operators in other cities do.
It is difficult if not impossible to compare the rental rates at the armory fairly with those at other exhibition halls.. With its Upper East Side location, the armory is often the only site that promoters of upscale shows will consider, because it can attract what is probably the country's most exclusive walk-in neighborhood clientele. Many show organizers now shut out of the armory said they would be willing to pay rental fees of as much as $20,000 a day if they were allowed to compete for the best dates. But often, several of them said, they did not even get their calls returned. Among those with stories of futilely sitting by the phone are a prominent antiques dealer, the host of a public television program, and representatives of the Kremlin Museums in Moscow.
"I would have thought, given who we were calling for, that we would have gotten a response," said Peter L. Schaffer, an owner of A la Vieille Russie, the Fifth Avenue gallery that was acting on behalf of the Russian show in the late 1980's.
Chris Jussel, the host of "Antiques Road Show" on PBS, which invites the public to bring objects for appraisals, portrayed his unsuccessful armory dealings as "a voyage through a maze of Byzantine machinations." "The state won't give you any information," he said. "You have to guess what's available and hope they'll offer it to you." From December 1996 through February 1997, executives with his show said, they called several times for information and got no response.
Scott Swenson, the armory's superintendent, did not return numerous telephone calls from reporters for comment on charges that he did not respond to requests from show organizers for possible dates.
Without singling out any official, General Fenimore, the military affairs division's commander, acknowledged that there have been managerial problems at the armory. But he emphasized that the state intended to overhaul policies there and at other armories.
"The procedures have to be brought up to modern business standards if we are going to properly market these armories," he said.
But competitive bidding, routine in any situation involving big government contracts, does not appear to be on the agenda.
"Using the competitive bidding process would be cumbersome for short-term arrangements, said Mr. Travers, the division official in charge of the rentals, in a written response to reporters' questions. He added, "It is generally considered good business practice to maintain working relationships with established good customers who pay their bills in a timely manner, conduct their events without adverse incident and demonstrate care in the use of a historic facility."
 
Paying the Price
Carpenters With Connections
It is not only potential show sponsors who complain about the armory, however. The dealers who fill up the Drill Shed during shows also have complaints. The draw of doing business in this prime East Side location is indisputable, some said, but they described setting up shop there as as gut-wrenching at times.
"I grimace every time I do it," said W. Graham Arader 3d, a dealer who exhibits at the armory's Winter Antiques Show. Mr. Arader often has to pay extra money directly to workers hired for the shows, he said, to get essential services performed.
"Unless you want to have a booth that's unpainted and dark, somebody's always got to be paid off," he said. "By the time you're through, you're paying about $500 an hour."
Rental fees at most shows at the armory generally range from about $4,500 to $20,000, depending on booth size and show.
What dealers rent is an essentially empty booth: they have to pay contractors chosen by the show producers for virtually all additional work. Electrical floor outlets, for example, can run $150 each, dimmers are $75, and eight-foot track lights $250. Raising a booth's ceiling a few feet can cost more than $6,000.
"At Grosvenor House in London, our outside contractors and assistants are more than welcome," said Mr. Schaffer, the dealer in Russian art and objects. "But here, we cannot bring in our own electricians or wallpaper hangers."
Or carpenters.
In 1995, the state barred 94 carpenters from work at the Javits Center after background checks turned up criminal records or suspected links to organized crime. But after being ousted from the center, 43 carpenters were included on a referral list of 300 workers authorized by their union for employment at the armory. The jobs pay about $50 an hour in wages and benefits.
Officials in the military affairs division said they did not conduct background checks because the armory was essentially a third party in the hiring arrangements. The carpenters, they said, were hired through agreements between private contractors and the union, the District Council of New York City and Vicinity of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners.
Last November, one of the contractors, the ESR Company of Teterboro, N.J., informed the union that a carpenter who had been banned from the Javits Center, Richard Mazzarella, had threatened to hit an exhibitor with a wooden block at an antiques show in October. The company said it would no longer use him at the armory. Mr. Mazzarella could not be located for comment.
The inclusion of the 43 carpenters for armory work was called outrageous by James F. McNamara, the research director for the Association for Union Democracy, a private group that monitors labor problems. "It's amazing," he said, "how so many connected people end up in one job site, given the tremendous number of fully qualified union members who have been out of work for long periods."
After inquiries by The Times, a union official said an expanded referral list was being prepared that would permit most of the union's 20,000 members to qualify for jobs at the armory. The official, Douglas J. Banes, a vice president, said the union had no legal grounds to expel the 43 from
For all this, it is unlikely that the attraction of the armory as a show site will diminish, unless the structural damage becomes more extreme. As Sanford Smith, who puts on six art and antiques shows a year at the armory, said: "The city doesn't have any other spaces like this. It's location, location, location. There's nothing like it."
Mr. Schaffer, the dealer in Russian art, agreed. "The armory is like no other place in the world," he said.
 
A Public Place
 The historical rooms and much of the permanent art collection of the Seventh Regiment Armory are normally closed to the public. But a spokesman for the state Division of Military and Naval Affairs, Peter P. C. Kutschera, said that tours could be arranged by calling the armory's superintendent, Scott Swenson, at (212) 879-9713.
The Seventh Regiment Fund, a veterans' group, also conducts occasional tours for groups interested in art, architecture and history. The fund's number is (212) 744-2968.
Several of the building's prized paintings, including Thomas Nast's "Departure of the Seventh on 19th of April, 1861," are hanging in the building's main corridors and can be viewed by visitors to art, antiques and craft shows and by patrons of the Seventh Regiment Mess, a restaurant in the building. The mess is open to the public for dinner Tuesdays through Saturdays, with access through the main armory entrance on Park Avenue.
"Works on Paper," an art fair featuring more than 90 dealers, is at the armory through Sunday. The fair features watercolors, prints, photographs, posters, drawings and illustrated books. Information: (212) 777-5218.

HEADLINE: Craft Sees Signs Of Water as Ice In Moon Craters

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
An American spacecraft has found evidence that relatively large amounts of frozen water exist on the Moon, scattered in craters over vast spans of the north and south poles, scientists announced today.
Rather than being entirely a dry wasteland, the scientists said, the Moon may have enough water, in the form of small ice crystals mixed in loose dirt, to sustain lunar colonies and provide fuel for rockets exploring the solar system. 
 The preliminary findings, from the Lunar Prospector spacecraft, which was launched on Jan. 6 to study the composition of the Moon, inspired excited scientists to speculate about returning humans there after a quarter-century absence.
"We have found water," said the mission's principal scientist, Dr. Alan B. Binder of the Lunar Research Institute in Gilroy, Calif.
But some experts cautioned that finding water is one thing, and coming up with an economically feasible way of extracting it from a harsh and unforgiving environment is another.
Dr. Binder said the orbiting spacecraft's measurements of atomic particles escaping from the Moon were the "first unquestionable results" showing water at both lunar poles.
In 1996, a Defense Department spacecraft called Clementine was diverted to the Moon and bounced radar signals off the surface that suggested that deposits of water ice lay in deep craters near the south pole.
Researchers working with Clementine said they thought they had found ice but were not positive. Their interpretation of radar signals indicated that 110 million tons to 1.1 billion tons of frozen water could be contained in an area of up to 5,500 square miles.
Preliminary estimates of Lunar Prospector data suggest that there are 11 million tons to 330 million tons of lunar water ice in sun-shielded craters scattered over as much as 25,000 square miles of lunar surface, scientists said. The new results also suggest that there is frozen water on both poles, the scientists said, and almost twice as much at the north pole as at the south.
Dr. William C. Feldman, a co-investigator from Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, said data from the spacecraft's neutron spectrometer instrument "are consistent with the presence of water ice in very low concentrations across a significant number of craters."
In areas where water ice is found, it appears to make up only 0.3 percent to 1 percent of the Moon's rocky soil, known as regolith, the scientists said at a news conference at the Ames Research Center, a NASA field installation near Mountain View, Calif. Still, they said, over such a wide area, this could represent 2.6 billion to 26 billion gallons of water.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration noted that a typical person used 100 gallons of water daily for drinking, food preparation, bathing and washing. At this rate, 33 million tons of water, or 7.2 billion gallons, could support 1,000 two-person households on the Moon for over a century, without recycling, the space agency said.
Once recovered, the moon water could also be broken down into its constituents, hydrogen and oxygen. Hydrogen could be used as a powerful rocket fuel, and oxygen for breathing.
Scientists say they believe that the Moon was created four billion years ago, possibly from debris thrown into space from the collision of a young Earth with a large meteor or comet. The Moon formed as a dry body, many believe, and any water present would have come from its bombardment by comets. The only water that would remain on the airless Moon would have to be hidden in craters in places shielded from sunlight, which would evaporate any moisture.
Apollo astronauts who visited the Moon six times found no evidence of water, but all of their landings were in the equatorial region, where temperatures reach 250 degrees Fahrenheit, and not at the poles, where craters shielded from sunlight by high rims remain frozen at 280 degrees below zero.
The polar regions appear to be covered with these craters filled with ice-tinged soil, Dr. Feldman said.
"This is a significant resource that will enable a modest amount of colonization for centuries," he said.
Dr. Wesley T. Huntress Jr., the space agency's Associate Administrator for space science, said the new findings were primarily of scientific interest now and several obstacles would have to be overcome to turn lunar ice into a resource.
"A cost-effective method to mine the water crystals from within this large volume of soil," Dr. Huntress said, "would have to be developed if it were to become a real resource for drinking water or as the basic components of rocket fuel to support any future human explorers."
Dr. Binder said it should be relatively simple to free water from the lunar soil by scooping it up, heating it in a chamber until the water evaporates out, and collecting the moisture in a distiller. The biggest problem, he said, would be developing equipment that could work at the extremely cold temperatures found at the poles.
Dr. Bruce C. Murray, a planetary scientist at the California Institute of Technology, said that while the spacecraft's findings were significant, he was very concerned by the contention that water could be easily and economically extracted from lunar soil. It would be easier and cheaper, Dr. Murray said, to bring water to the Moon from Earth than to mine it from a low-volume source.
"Water found at 1 percent by volume is not a resource," Dr. Murray said in a telephone interview after listening to the news conference, "It's just not at high enough levels to extract it economically. For something to be a resource, it has to be, by definition, economically viable; and this would not be."
Dr. Murray, a co-founder of the planetary Society, a space advocacy group with 25,000 members, said raising unrealistic hopes about lunar colonization based on these findings could hurt space exploration in the long run.
"Raising false hopes that fail makes people more cynical about space," he said.
The Lunar Prospector scientists said that their findings were based on only a month of data and that more readings would be needed to confirm the form, location and quantify of frozen water. The spacecraft, four feet in diameter and 650 pounds, is to collect data for at least another year. Toward the end of its mission, it is to be lowered from its current orbit of 62 miles to about 6 miles to give scientists an even closer look at possible water deposits and other materials making up the lunar surface.
The spacecraft measured lunar water indirectly by looking at the behavior of neutrons, subatomic particles that constantly bombard the surface. As neutrons bounce off materials at or near the surface, they lose energy and speed depending upon what they strike. Neutrons detected by Prospector produced signals signifying water, scientists said.
Researchers noted that the $65 million spacecraft's instruments actually detected hydrogen, the element that combines with oxygen to make water. Scientists consider this a "water signature" because water is the best candidate for the way hydrogen can be stored on the Moon. For instance, the researchers said, it would have to be much colder on the lunar surface for the instruments to be detecting hydrogen in a substance like stable methane.
"The presence of water is a logical conclusion, but it is a leap of faith," Dr. Binder said. "We will have to sample it before we really know for sure."
NASA officials said that there were no current plans to send a spacecraft to the surface of the Moon to confirm the water finding but that such a mission might be proposed in light of the new discovery.

The Lunar Prospector found water ice on the surface of the Moon by registering the speeds of neutrons dislodged from the Moon's crust by cosmic rays. Areas that have little or no water emit hot and fast neutrons; moist areas emit cool and slower neutrons.

HEADLINE: Many at the Saturn Auto Factory Are Finding Less to Smile About

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: SPRING HILL, Tenn., Feb. 28

 BODY:
Every week, hundreds of curious tourists make pilgrimages to this small town to take a tour of the Saturn factory. They watch yellow and orange conveyors flow through it like veins carrying car parts to the heart of the assembly line.
Many come to see where their beloved Saturns were built. They wave at workers, who smile and wave back. Indeed, the scene resembles the touchy-feely image created by Saturn's advertising campaigns -- one of cheerful, dedicated Americans working in teams to build quality cars. But all is not well on the factory floor. 
 Some workers are embarrassed by the television ads that continue to portray them as a contented work force. "We want to sell cars and build an image, but I want to feel like I'm living the truth," said Daniel R. Lawrence, 45, who installs batteries at the factory here.
The market for small cars is collapsing, and even Saturn's well-liked no-haggle pricing policy and reputation for good customer service could not keep Saturn's sales from plunging. The cheerful workers in Saturn's advertisements have been complaining about what they see as bungling by Saturn's parent, the General Motors Corporation. They have watched their annual bonuses dwindle and have begun to fear for the first time that Saturn may be approaching the kind of catastrophe that would cause layoffs.
On March 10 and 11, Saturn's 7,200 unionized workers will vote on whether to ask G.M. to jettison the innovative labor contract forged here by Saturn and the United Automobile Workers union in favor of the traditional contract that governs the Big Three's 400,000 other unionized workers. If dissident workers prevail, the U.A.W. and G.M. would presumably begin discussing what to do next. There are no formal provisions in the current contract on how to overturn it. At the very least, a negative vote would be a staggering blow to corporate America's most ambitious continuing experiment in labor-management relations.
The vote, which is expected to be close, "represents a confrontation between the new and the old, the future and the past," said David E. Cole, director of Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan.
G.M. executives, fearful of tipping the union vote against the Saturn contract, have refused to comment since workers decided in late February to vote on changing the contract, which -- an unusual feature -- has no expiration date. The U.A.W. national union also refused to comment.
In the meantime, the company is quietly fighting back. Last week, it agreed to make it easier for Saturn workers to earn bonuses, by allowing them to win up to $1,860 this year if quality goals are met and letting them keep half of any cost savings they discover. In addition, if the factory produces 280,000 cars a year -- 30,000 cars fewer than before but still 30,000 more than the factory churned out last year -- they could earn a few thousand more. Many workers are skeptical about reaching the quota anytime soon.
The 75-page Saturn labor contract is a bare-bones document compared with the 1,470-page tome that covers workers at other G.M. factories. The Saturn contract requires managers and hourly workers to cooperate in teams. On the other hand, the traditional contract divides responsibilities with hierarchical precision. Managers are required to go through union officials to make many requests of workers. Workers get higher base pay but forgo the chance to earn the big bonuses Saturn workers have received in past years.
G.M. assembly line workers, on average, earn $40,622 a year, plus a bonus tied to corporate performance that has amounted to $2,439 over the last six years. Saturn workers, by contrast, on average earn between $36,774 and $41,787 a year, depending on whether the factory meets its quality, health and safety, and training goals. They have earned additional bonuses amounting to $32,829 over six years for reaching production targets.
The crucial difference in the contracts, from the standpoint of Saturn workers, is that workers here are protected against layoffs except during "unforeseen or catastrophic events or severe economic conditions." Saturn is in deep enough trouble, many workers say, that layoffs are increasingly likely.
The traditional U.A.W. contract allows layoffs but requires G.M. to continue paying idled workers 95 to 100 percent of their base pay until they are offered another job or retire. The Saturn contract offers no explicit protections.
Thomas W. Hopp, 39, said his two decades of experience working at G.M. factories had taught him a simple truth. "If we're not making cars, your job is in jeopardy," said Mr. Hopp, who helped organize Concerned Brothers & Sisters of Local 1853, which forced the contract vote. "I get scared when that line isn't running."
Slow sales are the root of the problem, and Saturn is suffering along with the entire market. Small-car sales peaked in the 1980's but have fallen 20.0 percent just in the last four years.
Until 1996, Saturn sheltered itself from the downturn by increasing its market share, mainly by building a nearly cultlike following with its folksy advertisements featuring workers. But for the last two years, Saturn has been stuck with a dwindling share of a withering market.
Small-car sales have faltered for a number of unrelated reasons. With a gallon of gasoline priced less than bottled water, few want to buy small, fuel-efficient cars. The Asian currency crisis has helped foreign small-car makers drop prices to woo Saturn buyers. And the proliferation of sport utility vehicles and other light trucks is hurting sales of small cars, whose drivers find the bigger vehicles blocking their view of the road.
Saturn has fared better than some competitors, but its sales still dropped 9.9 percent last year. In October, Saturn lowered prices on its 1998 models. In January, with unsold Saturns piling up at dealerships, the company stopped building cars on Mondays. Workers use the time to maintain equipment or take additional courses on creative thinking, conflict resolution and other Saturn standbys. Last month, Saturn lowered lease prices: its cheapest car can be had for $129 a month.
Precisely because Saturn workers are used to taking pride and responsibility in the cars -- and company -- they have built, they are doubly frustrated by what they view as mistakes by management. The disputes are fueling an extraordinary debate between labor and management over how the company should be run.
Many workers and local union officials believe General Motors has missed several opportunities to expand on Saturn's success as a popular small-car maker. G.M. should have helped Saturn grow into a company selling cars and trucks of all sizes and shapes, they contend.
"If Saturn is to take its place as initially stated to be an import fighter, well, the imports are fighting us on a lot of fronts," said Joseph D. Rypkowski, president of Saturn's Local 1853. With more than 70 percent of Saturns sold to non-G.M. customers, he sees lots of potential. "If we can do that in the small-car market, we can do that in midsized and there's no reason we can't do it in trucks," he said.
But until next spring, nearly a decade after the first Saturns rolled off the assembly line, dealers will have nothing to show loyal customers who had children and outgrew the small cars. Only then will dealers begin selling the Saturn LS, its first mid-sized sedan.
Similarly, G.M. did not act on workers' suggestions two years ago that Saturn begin selling a small sport utility vehicle, and workers have watched Honda's CR-V and Toyota's RAV4 sell like hot cakes instead. Saturn now is considering selling a small sport utility vehicle, but not until 2002. And instead of sending Saturn the Catera, a small, sporty near-luxury sedan, G.M. doomed it to slower sales by christening it a Cadillac and hoping it would attract buyers without gray hair to G.M.'s luxury brand.
Executives at General Motors said they had little choice but to starve Saturn. The parent corporation nearly ran out of money in the early 1990's and had to cut back in the development of new cars and trucks at all its divisions.
G. Richard Wagoner Jr., G.M.'s president of North American auto operations, said early last month that it was easy to second-guess G.M. now, but acknowledged that Saturn would be better off if it were already selling a midsized car. "Clearly we would like to have it," he said.
Last summer, Michael E. Bennett, chairman of Local 1853, took the unusual step of proposing that G.M. spin off Saturn as a separate company. That request was rejected.
Indeed, instead of increasing Saturn's autonomy, G.M. is increasingly integrating it into the corporate parent. That's part of G.M.'s strategy to capitalize on worldwide efficiencies by using common parts and processes for many of its different cars, and by having workers around the world jointly develop new models. The coming Saturn LS was developed in Europe as the Opel Astra and will be built at a spare factory G.M. owns in Wilmington, Del.
That has alarmed workers. "They think that General Motors is swallowing us back up, which in fact it is," Mr. Bennett said. "The problem with that is that Saturn was set up to be a different kind of car company and a different kind of car, and the two strategies aren't fitting very well."
All of these issues add up to matters of pocketbooks and pride. The G.M. decisions have hurt Saturn sales and profits, which have caused workers' bonuses to fall to $2,200 last year from $10,000 in 1995 and again in 1996.
Some workers argue that the Saturn contract, and the style of factory life it makes possible, should not be abandoned. "If this was a normal G.M. plant under a national agreement, we'd already have a layoff," said Dennis Adams, who assembles about 500 front doors a shift here, and plans to vote to keep the current labor agreement. "We have a better system here," said Mr. Adams, who worked at other G.M. factories for 16 years before coming to Saturn in 1993.
Local union leaders, who favor retaining the contract, said Saturn had not faced such a challenge before because times had been good. "We're really for the first time getting a test," Mr. Rypkowski, the union president, said.
Many workers who want to return to the traditional U.A.W. agreement said they were embarrassed, not proud, of Saturn's image because of all the changes in the last couple of years. Boyd R. Burton, 38, who has worked at Saturn for nine years, recently had some friends over at his house when a Saturn commercial was shown on television.
"They asked if that's really the way it was there," Mr. Burton said. He told them: "That's not reality -- it isn't working like that."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Fund-Raising Points To Running for Higher Office

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Just two months into his second term, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his aides sent a strong signal yesterday that he plans to seek higher office, saying they would hold a series of fund-raising events this year, including a $1,000-a-plate dinner in May.
When asked at a news conference yesterday about the May dinner -- an annual event that has raised at least $1 million in the last four years -- Mr. Giuliani said this year's dinner would be "for the future possibility of running for an office" that has not been specified. 
 "That's probably not going to be determined until some time well into the future," he added. "But the reality is that you have to raise money for the possibility of running for public office in cycles of three, four and even five years."
To that end, the Mayor's political aides said other events were planned for this year, including a private reception already scheduled for next month and a dinner at the St. Regis Hotel in December. These are in addition to his plans to speak at Republican fund-raising events in Buffalo and in Michigan and Arizona.
Mr. Giuliani has received international attention for the crime reductions and economic gains that, supporters say, have restored New York City's luster during his four-year tenure. In recent weeks, he has also bolstered his persona as an Eisenhower-era disciplinarian by ordering a crackdown on jaywalking and delivering a citywide call for civility. The formula appears to work, at least in New York City; several polls have put his approval rating among city residents at close to 70 percent.
The Mayor, who is prohibited by local law from seeking a third consecutive term in 2001, declined to say whether he was considering running for governor, United States senator, or President -- only that he was keeping his options open. "And the only way you can exercise the option of running for another office someday is if you raise money," he said.
The tentative arrangements for the fund-raising dinner in May, which were reported yesterday in The New York Post, underscore the uncertainty that Mr. Giuliani harbors about his political destiny.
John H. Gross, who has served as the Mayor's campaign treasurer in the past, said he would probably establish two committees -- one complying with Federal campaign finance laws, the other with state law -- so that contributors could choose how to direct their donations.
"We will have two separate committees which will comply with the separate laws of government, state and Federal," Mr. Gross said.
Despite the strong support that Mr. Giuliani enjoys among New York voters, his ability to appeal to a broader audience remains to be seen; political positions that are de rigueur in New York City do not always travel well. His support for abortion rights, gun control and domestic-partnership benefits for gay couples are unlikely to endear him to the social conservatives who have dominated Republican Presidential primaries in recent years.
In addition, some Republicans will never forgive the Mayor for supporting the Democratic incumbent, Mario M. Cuomo, in the 1994 race for New York governor that was eventually won by George E. Pataki.
"He's not very viable in the Republican Presidential race," said Michael Murphy, a Republican consultant and self-described Giuliani admirer. "If his people are telling him he is, he needs to get new people. They owe him better. Iowa and New Hampshire are not outer boroughs."
Mr. Murphy, whose campaign work includes last year's re-election of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in New Jersey, said the Mayor could beat Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan or any other Democrat in a New York race for Senate -- a political pursuit that one aide says does not interest the Mayor.
"That's his race," Mr. Murphy said. "If he were paying me for advice, that's where I'd tell him to go."
But John McCain, a Republican Senator from Arizona and a likely Presidential candidate, said Mr. Giuliani "clearly has national potential."
"I think that there's tens of million of Americans who visit New York every year, and the overwhelming majority of them are impressed at the dramatic changes that have taken place under his stewardship." Mr. McCain said. "It's hard for them to believe they can walk through Central Park, that there's no squeegee people and that practically everywhere you look, there's the presence of law enforcement."
Mr. Giuliani's scheduled appearance at a fund-raising event for the Senator in Arizona sometime this spring has heightened interest among campaign contributors, Mr. McCain said.
"People know of what he's done in New York. And there's something interesting to people in the West about the Mayor of, in the view of some, the nation's premier city," he said.
Asked whether he would consider Mr. Giuliani as a running mate if he were to run for President, Mr. McCain said, "I think he would have to be considered by anyone at the top of the ticket, because he brings an enormous advantage in New York and the Northeast, an area we have had difficulty with."
The publicity and the public approval have clearly convinced the Mayor and his advisers that his message -- a melange of fiscal prudence, governmental accountability and "personal responsibility" -- is resonating with people who live outside the city's five boroughs.
"People seem to be listening," Mr. Giuliani said. "Not always agreeing, but they seem to be listening, and we seem to be actually -- even more than in the first term -- able to set the agenda of what people discuss."
Whether city residents are responding to a set agenda or simply to whatever their Mayor is saying, they are paying attention to the Mayor, often on subjects that at times seem unrelated to municipal government. A sampling of his actions since his second term began in January include: calling for an overhaul of the City University of New York system, vocally attacking the president of the Grammy Awards for impertinent behavior, requesting that New Yorkers be more civil with one another, and declaring the city to be safe haven for the original Winnie-the-Pooh doll.
This week, he again managed to attract national attention. CNN broadcast a segment on the Mayor's collaboration with a writer-illustrator on a children's book that features his dog, Goalie.
For all the interest in Mr. Giuliani's political ambitions, his aides nevertheless express surprise when subjects like fund-raisers and out-of-town trips arise.
Cristyne F. Lategano, his communications director, answered questions about the fund-raising dinner by saying that for the last several years, the Mayor has held events like this in late May, around the time of his birthday. They are invariably held at the Sheraton New York on Seventh Avenue and 51st Street.
Of course, those annual May events have all been to help his election and re-election campaigns for mayor. Why now, she was asked.
"If you don't raise money, you begin to close options as opposed to keeping them open," she said.
Mr. Giuliani also took a matter-of-fact approach to the subject, saying he enjoys his job -- "right now."
"When I was running for mayor, every single day people would ask me to make a solemn pledge that I would finish every day of the term," he said. "And I said those were unrealistic promises to make. I'm hardly going to make that same promise today when I didn't make it when I was running."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT;
Jobless Rate Drops, Thanks to Aberration

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WETHERSFIELD

 BODY:
The state unemployment rate continued dropping in January. But state economists warned that the latest monthly figure was exceptionally low because of a statistical aberration.
The rate, which relies heavily on sample data from a population survey, dropped, to 3.8 percent, the Labor Department reported yesterday. 
A labor statistics supervisor, Salvatore DiPillo, said an unexpected drop in the population figures led to the decline. Mr. DiPillo said he expected the blip to correct itself in a few months, when figures are adjusted, sending the unemployment rate closer to the 4.4 percent rate reported in December.
An estimated 1.6 million residents were employed in January, an increase of 38,700 over January 1996.
Job losses were reported in areas including wholesale and retail trade, 2,300; services, 2,300; government, 500, and transportation, communications and utilities, 400. Construction and mining added 1,200 jobs, and manufacturing grew by 900.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Incubators for Long Island

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
New York State officials announced $22 million in financing yesterday for four business incubators on Long Island aimed at nurturing entrepreneurs in biotechnology and software.
Two other programs are also being contemplated by the state to help Long Island enhance its reputation as a center of high technology. Only one of the state's existing 37 incubators is on Long Island, at the State University at Stony Brook. 
 "Long Island has always had a high-tech economy, with the defense firms, its highly skilled labor force, hospitals and Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories," said Michael F. McKeon, a spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki. "This is a natural fit for Long Island."
Support programs for new biotechnology companies will be established at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset and the State University of New York at Farmingdale. The SUNY program will be operated in conjunction with the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories.
An incubator for software producers will be located at Briarcliffe College in Bethpage. The state will contribute $500,000 to complete and expand a previously announced program for software manufacturers at SUNY Stony Brook.
The incubators provide space to new companies and offer experts to give management advice, and help in writing business plans and obtaining investment capital. TERRY PRISTIN

HEADLINE: Not to Bury Homer but to Update Him

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Who killed Homer?
The question is at the heart of a bitter debate among scholars over who is to blame for the crisis in classics education. With a declining interest in ancient studies at universities across the country and a fear that the disciplines are becoming irrelevant, classicists worry that the founding ideas of Western literature, art and philosophy are losing ground. 
 In fact, "Who Killed Homer: The Demise of Classical Education and the Recovery of Greek Wisdom" is the title of a new book due out next month that argues that American classicists are "peewee gladiators" who have "lost sight of any real intellectual or educational goal" through their obsession with "tenure, promotions, leave, salary, visiting lectureships, positions on editorial boards, prestige."
"The dumbing down of the classics is under way," says John Heath, a professor of classics at Santa Clara University, who wrote the book with Victor Davis Hanson. "There will be nothing left in a generation."
For more than a decade, classicists have been slugging it out in articles, books and conferences over who's murdering Homer.
The quarrel erupted in print in 1987 when America's premier classical publication, the American Journal of Philology (a love of words and literature; it comes from the Greek words philein and logos) warned it would not publish articles lacking "rigorous scholarly methods" or based on "mere speculation." The editorial was widely seen as a declaration of war by traditionalist scholars on the modernists or "theorists," who apply modern analytical methods drawn from feminist studies, poststructural criticism and multiculturalism to the ancient world.
"I thought the traditional approach just fine," says Georg Luck of Johns Hopkins University, who wrote the controversial editorial, "but I had no idea saying so would produce such an uproar."
The traditionalist approach is based on a close study of ancient languages and literature. At its base is the belief that the values of ancient Greece and Rome provide the "essential core of Western learning in language, reasoning, ethics, esthetics and philosophy," as Professors Heath and Hanson put it.
Feminists and theorists, on the other hand, stress the ancient world's elitism, indifference to women, tolerance of slavery and glorification of bellicose white male heroes instead of democracy, free inquiry and human rights. They argue that they are making the classics more relevant by asking the same questions about the ancient world that we ask about our own, questions about the social, political and economic forces shaping literature and thought.
"To keep Latin and Greek vital we must keep asking new questions," says Barbara K. Gold, a classicist at Hamilton College. "Purist approaches are no longer attractive to students. We can't ignore the multicultural campus."
Amy Richlin, a feminist scholar at the University of Southern California, says: "I want to inject the excitement we find in feminist and other modern studies into the classics. I want to invigorate it."
For many theorists, the great texts of antiquity have no immutable significance and can mean different things to different readers. While some find in antiquity the origins of the glories of Western civilization, others see what Nancy Sorkin Rabinowitz of Hamilton College called "a formative moment of misogyny" in her introduction to "Feminist Theory and the Classics" (Routledge, 1993).
Tina Passman of the University of Maine, who describes herself in the same book as "a lesbian, radical feminist and classicist," berated traditionalists for failing to see that the male-dominated ancient Greek world was built on the ruins of an earlier "harmonious matriarchal/ matrilineal culture." Other essays in the volume include "The Primal Mind: Using Native American Models for the Study of Women in Ancient Greece" and "The Case for Not Ignoring Marx in the Study of Women in Antiquity."
Such approaches infuriate traditionalists, who accuse theorists of imposing a preconceived political agenda on the ancient world that denigrates Greek and Roman civilization.
"How will students learn to love the classics when their professors write incomprehensibly about a world they hold responsible for all the neuroses of present-day society?" asks Professor Hanson, who teaches Greek at the California State University at Fresno.
This struggle between traditional and multicultural approaches to scholarship exists in practically every discipline on campus, from literature to mathematics. What creates special bitterness among the classicists, however, is each school's belief that its rivals are to blame for falling student enrollments, declining linguistic standards and the "watering down" of the core discipline through the use of translations and the inclusion of ancillary subjects like mythology and ancient art.
"These are perilous times for classics in America," Bruce Thornton of California State University at Fresno wrote in a survey of the dispute last year. He said the classics were caught between "a utilitarian right," which doubts its relevance, and the "multiculturalist left," which accuses the ancients of "patriarchy, oppression, sexism, colonialism and God knows what other crimes."
Amy Richlin laments weak linguistic skills, saying many students starting the classics without high school Greek "just don't have time to really master it."
To some extent, the quarrel between traditionalists and theorists may be distracting both schools from the real common enemy they face. This is what is known as "presentism" or the tendency to focus on very recent events.
As an example, Professor Richlin cites next year's planned Berkshire Conference of Women Historians, saying that 80 percent of the discussion will be on events after 1789 and half on those after 1900.
"The growth of presentism is the greatest danger we face," she warns. "Historical studies which ignore 3,000 years of history will not bring good results."
While no one denies that the classics have declined in prestige and importance on university campuses, other scholars question whether the future is as dark as the Cassandras warn.
Matthew S. Santirocco of New York University says the classics can infiltrate mainstream university studies through multidisciplinary courses, where texts are read in translation and students study nontraditional aspects of the ancient world like the role of women, theater and art. N.Y.U.'s Ancient Studies Center offers interdisciplinary courses on such themes as death and the ancient world and Alexander the Great and the lands he conquered.
Meanwhile, a recent study by Richard A. LaFleur of the University of Georgia suggests the classics are holding up reasonably well and may even be in for a revival. While the number of enrolled college Latin students had fallen from 39,600 in 1965 to 24,398 by 1972, it has remained fairly stable since then and reached 25,897 in 1995, the last year surveyed.
Greek fared less well with the number of enrolled undergraduates dropping from 19,500 in 1965 to 16,272 in 1995. But again it has held fairly stable at around that level since 1986.
Professor LaFleur's study, suitably entitled "Latina Resurgens," also shows public secondary school Latin enrollments rising 15 percent between 1990 and 1994 to the highest level since 1970, with a similar increase at private schools, suggesting more classics majors are in the pipeline. New York City private schools often tout their Latin classes as a lure for prospective parents. "Gaudeamus, igitur" is his conclusion. (That's "Therefore, let us rejoice," in case you were wondering).

HEADLINE: THINK TANK;
The Country Club: The Good Life or a Greedy One?

 BODY:
In "The Theory of the Leisure Class," the economist Thorstein Veblen said: "In order to gain and to hold the esteem of men, it is not sufficient merely to possess wealth or power. The wealth or power must be put in evidence, for esteem is awarded only in evidence." In a book being published this month, "The American Country Club: Its Origins and Development" (Rutgers University Press), James M. Mayo, a professor at the school of architecture and urban design at the University of Kansas, quotes various writers on this suburban oasis.
The Country Club . . . is everywhere a clear American felicity; a complete product of the social air and soil which alone have made it possible. . . . It becomes, for the restless analyst, one of the great garden lamps in which the flame of Democracy burns whitest and steadiest. Henry James in "The American Scene," 1907. 
 There, paradoxical as it may at first appear, is the idea of the country club as it should be, and as sometimes it is. It is really the love of home and the love of friends whom one would have about one's hearth that has brought about their organization. For the love of home involves also the neighborly idea, the love of one's fellows, of companionship, of something beyond "highballs" and poker and the scandal or shop talk of the smoking room. Frank S. Arnett, Munsey's Magazine, 1902
Country clubs are the result of the centralization of population, the increase of wealth and the discovery of America by the game of golf. . . . Country clubs could hardly flourish in great numbers without golf. To a majority of the active male members, golf is the great attraction. Golf keeps up the membership and makes the club strong. E. S. Martin, Harper's Weekly, 1900
The country club seems almost destined to satisfy the somewhat communistic dream. . . . To begin with, the country club is not the result of a movement, but it is a growth which in itself better favors permanent place and power. Without the stress and tension of new-century town life, so generally condemned, country clubs could not have so multiplied. The amazing wholesomeness of country club life becomes the complement of the worst evils of the money struggle. Robert Dunn, Outing, 1905
The country club . . . serves as a clearinghouse for social paper. Did the Garveys get their Packard second-hand?. . . . Did the Sacketts live as regally as they would have us think, that weekend they motored east in April? Charles Merz, The New Republic, 1923
The whole intention. . . . to give an air that one would find in the most friendly and cheerful of homes, and yet, perhaps, here and there a touch of formality to insure not only the impersonal note so necessary in a club house but also the sense of contrast between such life and actual home life. For a club, though a close relation of the home, is not an effort at imitation; it is an extension of the home, not an enlargement of it. Miss Swift, Arts and Decoration, 1925
Lack of ethnic diversity hangs like a specter of past evils over today's clubs. The recent acrimonious flap over the lack of minority members . . . has continued to reverberate through the private club world. This is to be expected when moral and ethical issues collide with legal rights and principles. Club managers will need to take a position of strong, if quiet, leadership in their clubs, recognizing the delicacy of their position as employees, yet pressing to bring their clubs in line with the late-20th-century social and moral values. Tom Finan, publisher of Club Management, 1990
It is, above all, a single yet complex expression of both greed and magnificence, an expression of the continually evolving American Dream that embodies the best of its optimism and native exuberance along with its native excesses and its uncritical acceptance of the good life. William Wyckoff, "The Making of the American Landscape," edited by Michael P. Conzen (Unwin Hyman, 1990)

HEADLINE: Russia Seeking Senior Role On Inspection Teams in Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 6

 BODY:
In an effort to expand its influence on the special commission charged with disarming Iraq, Russia has asked Secretary General Kofi Annan to name a Russian as co-deputy chairman of the panel, United Nations officials said today.
The move is believed to require Security Council approval because the resolution setting up the commission specifically mentioned a chairman and a deputy and made no mention of other officers or of the nationalities of the officers. 
 Richard Butler, an Australian arms-control expert, is now chairman; Charles Duelfer, an American, is his deputy.
A question still being debated among American officials is whether a Russian co-deputy would best serve Unscom's interests, given Moscow's arguments that economic sanctions on Iraq should be eased, despite Baghdad's record of concealing its weapons programs.
In Washington, a State Department official who requested anonymity said, "We encourage broad international participation in Unscom and have confidence that Chairman Butler will make personnel decisions with the best interests of Unscom in mind."
The Russians had proposed five deputy positions, one for each permanent member of the Security Council: Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States. France, which suggested the number be kept to two, has assigned a political adviser to the commission's headquarters here. Russia and France have been more sympathetic to Iraq than most Western nations.
Some officials and diplomats see the request by Russia as a further test of Mr. Annan's willingness to be flexible with Iraq. But in this case, the action would mean the Secretary General was treading on Security Council territory. Mr. Annan has said repeatedly that he would not or could not dilute the authority of the Security Council or Unscom, which the Council established in 1991 as a semiautonomous body.
A series of steps that Mr. Annan has taken this week, including the appointment of a political representative in Baghdad, and his willingness to consider the Russian request have raised questions among diplomats about about whether there were any side agreements to the accord he struck with Iraq last month to open some previously closed sites. United Nations officials have denied any secret deals.
In recent months, Russia has supported Iraq's demands that the commission -- and in particular its inspectors -- be more broadly representative of the United Nations. President Saddam Hussein has accused the inspectors of being American spies and has said that both Mr. Butler and Mr. Duelfer are beholden to Washington and insensitive to Iraqi concerns about sovereignty.
Commission officials and American diplomats dismiss these charges, saying Iraq is trying to blunt the effectiveness of the commission or sideline it entirely because it is closing in on some important sites for inspection.
Russia has been critical of the inspection process, complaining that the inspectors are too aggressive and too slow to complete their task.
Suspicions about Russia were raised when United Nations inspectors reported finding a document indicating that Russia and Iraq had discussed the sale of equipment that could be used in a biological warfare program. There also have been complaints that confidential information about proposed inspections have reached the Iraqis through the Russian Embassy in Baghdad.
Russia stands to gain if United Nations sanctions against Baghdad are lifted because Iraq owes Russia billions of dollars for weapons, and Russia has a commitment to develop oilfields in Iraq.
United Nations officials have drawn up procedures for inspecting eight "presidential" sites that Mr. Hussein agreed to open in talks with Mr. Annan in Baghdad on Feb. 22. Under the agreement, these sites are to be visited by inspectors accompanied by diplomats.
Fred Eckhard, spokesman for the Secretary General, said the procedures would be presented to the Security Council and made public on Monday, after the arrival in New York of Iraq's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf.
Iraq complains that the United Nations monitoring infringes on the Government's rights, an accusation that has become the theme underlying all discussions with Baghdad for more than a year.
But United Nations searches of sites not classified as presidential have continued without incident. On Thursday, Scott Ritter, an American expert on concealment whom the Iraqis had barred in January, returned to Baghdad with 50 inspectors to complete the job the Iraqis had interrupted. He and his team, drawn from 11 countries, visited three "sensitive" sites today without incident. Sensitive sites are another category to which Iraq wants to control access.
There were no efforts to prevent Mr. Ritter from returning to Iraq, although Iraqi officials barred television crews from recording his arrival at Habbaniya air base, about 70 miles west of Baghdad. Iraq does not allow inspectors to land at Saddam International Airport, on the edge of the capital.
On Monday, Jayantha Dhanapala, the Under Secretary General for Disarmament Affairs, is to go to Iraq to begin laying the groundwork for visits to the presidential sites. Mr. Dhanapala, a Sri Lankan arms control expert, is to direct the visits -- officials in Mr. Annan's office do not call them inspections -- with Mr. Butler.
In planning how to handle the presidential sites, members of the special commission, which had little input into drawing up the procedures, worry that diplomats, with little or no expertise, could limit the inspectors' work.
The diplomats, for example, are seen as being sympathetic to Iraqi demands for "dignified" searches.
Iraqi officials have complained about what they see as a gangbuster style among inspectors, accusing them of barging into private living quarters unannounced. Commission experts respond that unless they can make unannounced inspections, objects or documents can be hidden from them.
Inspectors are concerned that diplomats may hint to Baghdad when searches are planned, reducing visits to "ritual searches" that Iraq can use to argue that it has met the requirements of the agreement with Mr. Annan.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Rise Despite Strength In February's Report on Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday despite a strong February employment report. Investors, resigned to the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will not lower interest rates anytime soon, took advantage of the slide in bond prices earlier in the week and bought.
Most of the gains were on the long end of the yield curve, with the 30-year Treasury bond up 22/32, to a price of 101 16/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.02 percent, from 6.06 percent on Thursday. 
 The Labor Department said yesterday that 310,000 jobs were added in February, more than the consensus forecast of 250,000 new jobs, while average hourly wages rose six-tenths of 1 percent.
The report provided evidence of the economy's strength, a sign that would typically rekindle inflation worries. But some market analysts said the number of new jobs was not as big as some had feared. In addition, after a recent slump and with the prospect of a Fed rate cut quickly diminishing, the 6 percent plus yield on the long bond began to look attractive, bringing buyers into the market.
Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said that the root of yesterday's rally might have stemmed from a small dip in the Employment Diffusion Index, which is released with the employment report. The dip suggested the latest surge in jobs was somewhat less widespread than in the previous report.
The index declined to 57.3 in February, from 64.2 in January, its lowest reading since August 1997, when it bottomed out at 56.5. "Anytime that this index declines, it increases the probability that a good part of the jobs gains were due to special factors, rather than solid widespread fundamental trends," Mr. Chan said.
Many investors were also assured by a loss of 2,000 jobs in manufacturing. "The reason for the credit market's optimism." Mr. Chan said, "is that many investors assumed that with Intel and Motorola screaming about Asia, it might make sense to assume that the 2,000 decline in manufacturing employment might be an indication that the Asian flu is also beginning to impact the overall economy more broadly."
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, noted that the Labor Department had warned that some of the data, like the hourly earnings increase, might be distorted because of a a statistical anomaly.
Still, "regardless of any possible distortion, the data indicate a continued very tight labor market," Ms. Schaja said. "These data, in themselves, will not push the Fed to firm monetary policy because inflation remains extremely tame and the potential impact from the Asia crisis still looms," she added.

HEADLINE: D.C. Ennui

 BODY:
A new axiom on domestic affairs seems to have taken hold in Washington this year. It is, simply, the less you do, the more popular you become. Take the Republicans in the House, who once vowed to make history by remaking government. This year they seem content with mini-measures on school vouchers, drugs and crime. Indeed, House members are much more involved in palace intrigue than in any item on their agenda. Yet the approval ratings of Congress, like those of a President Clinton who offered his own list of sound-bite policies in the State of the Union speech, have soared to record levels.
The virtues of not doing much were discovered last fall, when Speaker Gingrich and Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, adjourned early for the year. Now Congress is back in session, but who would know it? Where Republicans and Democrats once waged epic ideological battles, they now jockey over modest changes in the distribution of highway money. With a booming economy, a balanced budget and the fire-breathers on the left and right unable to get a majority, there is not much more to do except push through a status-quo budget. 
 As sometimes happens, the ennui has produced a new effort by Republicans to chew themselves up. The widely reported intention of Mr. Gingrich to run for President has accelerated the battle over who might succeed him. This in turn unleashed a torrent of criticism of the putative heir, Dick Armey of Texas, the combative majority leader. The infighting has widened divisions that opened up last year, when Mr. Gingrich quashed an attempted coup attempt by some of his closest allies.
The jockeying has been complicated by the surprise decision by Bill Paxon of Buffalo, a once-rising star, to retire from the House and from politics altogether. In leaving, Mr. Paxon declared that he probably could have beaten Mr. Armey, whose real friends could caucus in a phone booth. The rest of the House Republicans, many of them moderates from the Northeast and Midwest, are searching for an alternative. One result is that Robert Livingston of Louisiana, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, has quit talking of retirement and now seems ready to run for Speaker.
Another reason that Republicans have the luxury to fight with each other is the peculiar state of Mr. Clinton's political situation right now. Though he goes higher and higher in opinion polls, the allegations against him have banished fears among Republicans that they could lose Congress to the Democrats in the fall. Complacent about their fortunes, Republican leaders have decided that cooperation with Mr. Clinton on the basics is what the public wants, and they seem willing to endure the criticism of the emotionally distraught but suddenly impotent right wing. There is a lot of Republican talk about flat taxes and other transformation of the tax system, but no one seriously thinks that can happen anytime soon.
The last President who, like Mr. Clinton, lost his Congressional majority after his first two years and then was re-elected with a Congress from an opposing party was Dwight Eisenhower. Like Mr. Clinton, Eisenhower and Congress jockeyed over a centrist program and both remained popular as long as the economy did well. Some say Mr. Clinton's popularity is wide but shallow and could dry up if the economy wilts. But that is always the case.
The nation has a long list of unmet needs in education, retirement programs for an aging population and lifting up the poor. It used to be said that you needed a vision on such things to succeed. In the politics of this moment, vision has become passe. Barring some unforeseen disaster, this is the era of the lethargy thing. It is not elegant, but it is working well enough to satisfy the incumbents.
