HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
S.& P. 500 Jumps 2% as Bargain Buyers Fuel Trading

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
If the market is lower, it must be a buying opportunity.
Investors followed that mantra with a vengeance once again yesterday, scooping up technology shares and other issues that were battered in a selloff on Thursday that had pushed most major stock market indexes down more than 1 percent. 
 Stocks zoomed, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up nearly 2 percent to a record close and the Dow industrials up nearly 1.5 percent. At least temporarily, buyers disregarded concerns about the outlook for corporate earnings, highlighted by a double dose of profit warnings from the technology bellwethers Intel and Motorola, as well as anxieties about the impact of Asia's financial crisis on American multinational companies.
But late news from Compaq Computer that excess inventory and price cuts would lower first-quarter profits below expectations was a reminder that stumbling blocks loom in the market's path. Compaq, whose announcement came after the market had closed, closed at 27 5/8, up 1/2.
While trading was in session, investors took all news as good news. They viewed a February decline in unemployment, equaling the 24-year low it hit last November, as a sign that the domestic economy was motoring along at a healthy pace. That could offset the impact of Asia's slump, said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Zurich Kemper Investments.
"In the corporate earnings picture, there's a big question mark about what's going to happen in Asia," he said. "So the driver of the profit engine is going to be the United States."
"The stock market knows the only way companies are going to be profitable is if the domestic economy is strong," Mr. Froehlich added. "And for the economy to be strong, consumers must be strong and buying. And they can't stay strong unless they have a job. Forget everything else. If they don't have a job, they can't drive anything."
American stock markets also gained from strong showings overseas, where most stock markets in Europe and Asia finished higher.
The buying spree erased much of the losses of Thursday and pushed the S.& P. 500, up 20.64 points, to 1,055.69. While no other major market indexes pushed further into record territory, the Dow Jones industrial average surged 125.06, to 8,569.39. The Dow stands just 15.44 from its closing high of 8,584.83 reached last Tuesday.
On the New York Stock Exchange more than 665 million shares traded, the highest daily volume since Feb. 5
Despite its 2.43 percent climb, the technology-laden Nasdaq composite failed to recoup all of Thursday's 2.72 percent loss. It closed at 1,753.49, up 41.57.
The demand for stocks, especially technology shares, indicated investor unwillingness to miss a chance to participate in another leg of the market rally, said Michael W. Clark, head of American equity trading at Credit Suisse First Boston.
While Intel sank almost 13 percent on Thursday after the company said product demand was sluggish, after further reflection, investors decided the shares were cheap and rushed in to buy, Mr. Clark said.
Investors viewed the announcements by Intel and Motorola as indications of temporary problems and not signals of fundamental weakness in their sectors, said Jack Geraghty, semiconductor analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston.
"It appears that some of the companies have inventory problems," Mr. Geraghty said. "If there were something wrong with demand, Dell would not be having a good quarter."
In addition to technology shares, airline stocks also benefited from the change in investor sentiment.
The stocks were helped by the overall rally and by a sharp drop in crude oil prices, said Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline analyst at Paine Webber. Crude oil contracts fell 42 cents a barrel, to $14.91, the first fall below $15 in four years.
"On a day when the market is up and oil prices are down, I'd be surprised if airline stocks were not leading the charge," he said.
The American Stock Exchange airline sector index was one of the best-performing indexes yesterday, up 3.97 percent. So far this year, it is up 13.91 percent.

HEADLINE: JOBS JUGGERNAUT CONTINUES SURGE; 300,000 FIND WORK

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
After seven years of economic growth, the American job juggernaut has not even begun to slow down.
In February, for the fourth consecutive month, employers added more than 300,000 jobs, the Labor Department reported yesterday. And as it has month after month, the surge in hiring far exceeded the expectations of economists. The February data brought the total number of jobs created in the last six months to an astounding two million. 
 The unemployment rate edged down to 4.6 percent from 4.7 percent, returning to the 24-year low that it reached in November. Also, the proportion of Americans working -- 64.2 percent -- remains at an all-time high. And perhaps most important, the report underscored how briskly the real pay of average American workers is now rising.
The labor market has not been this strong for this long since before the oil crisis in 1973, reflecting a happy confluence of optimism, low inflation, moderate interest rates, high stock prices and a soothing absence of economic policy blunders.
While it is hard to imagine that the current pace can continue for long, there are few signs of an abrupt slowdown. "What's amazing isn't the demand for workers but the ability of the economy to keep delivering them," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
Total hours worked rose sharply in February, and the January increase was revised higher as well. The steep rise in hours -- at a 6.5 percent annual rate so far this year -- implies that the gross domestic product is continuing to grow at a fairly robust pace this quarter. And a sharp pickup in temporary employment -- a gain of 52,000 such jobs in February -- is another possible forerunner of more permanent hiring. (A recent study by the Chicago Federal Reserve suggests that temporary hiring is a reliable leading indicator of future growth in payroll jobs.)
While the labor market is getting tighter, pay increases are coming faster. This was perhaps the biggest news buried in yesterday's employment report. Average hourly earnings jumped by 8 cents in February, to $12.60. Although the Labor Department cautioned that the measure was volatile and that last month's figure might have been exaggerated by statistical anomalies, the increase for the last 12 months is just over 4 percent, a sharp acceleration from a 3 percent gain the previous year.
"Tight labor markets are having an effect," said David Wyss, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, reflecting the opinion of most economists. "There's been a clear escalation since 1994 and 1995."
Overheated labor markets helped end the long expansions in the 1960's and 1980's. Naturally, economists are watching labor costs carefully for signs of incipient inflationary pressures. Such pressures would prompt the Federal Reserve to rein in the economy.
Still, the bond market took the glowing employment report calmly yesterday, perhaps because interest rates have already moved up from their lows. Stock and bond prices rallied yesterday, as investors once again decided to look for bargains.
With wages continuing to outpace inflation, workers are clearly benefiting from the recovery that once was derisively dismissed as the "jobless" or "stealth" recovery. The cost of living has risen a scant 1.6 percent over the last 12 months, while the real, inflation-adjusted gain in average hourly pay for production and nonsupervisory workers has been 2.5 percent -- the strongest 12-month increase in more than two decades.
The unemployment rate for adult men remained unchanged from January, at 3.8 percent, its lowest point in two decades. The rate for adult women edged down to 4.3 percent in February from 4.4 percent in January. Much of the recent growth in employment reflects increased participation of women, particularly women with high school educations or less. Alan Krueger, an economist at Princeton and the former chief economist at the Labor Department, said this pool of workers was not drying up. "If growth were coming from college-educated workers, we'd be exhausting the pool," he said.
Low-wage, less-skilled workers are finally benefiting -- as they usually do in recoveries -- disproportionately from tighter labor markets. Unemployment rates among high school dropouts are much higher than for college graduates, 7 percent versus 1.9 percent. But the situation is improving much more for the low-wage group. In the nearly eight years of the economic recovery, unemployment among college-educated workers, for example, has fallen from 3.2 percent to 1.9 percent, slightly more than one percentage point. By contrast, unemployment among high school dropouts fell from 11.9 percent to 7 percent in February, nearly a five-point decline. Two-fifths of that decline has come in the last year, said Tom Nardone, an economist at the Labor Department.
The boon for workers is causing some headaches for companies. Employers continue to complain that workers, especially ones with college degrees or special skills, are in short supply -- not surprising given the extremely low unemployment rate for this group. The latest survey by the National Federation of Independent Business, also released yesterday, shows that in February, 26 percent of businesses had openings they could not fill (a bit lower than in January but far higher than the 15 percent of five years ago). But, so far, the rising labor costs faced by businesses have not resulted in higher prices for consumers -- or a higher rate of inflation.
In another economic report, the Federal Reserve said borrowing by consumers increased at a 2.8 percent annual rate in January, down from a 4.7 percent rate in December. A slowdown in auto lending offset a pickup in credit card borrowing.
Somewhat surprisingly, the recession in Asia seems to have had only a modest effect on American labor. About one-quarter of America's factory output is exported, including shipments to Asia. Moreover, many companies compete with imported goods, and Asian products will become cheaper because of the collapse of many of the region's currencies. Manufacturing employment in the United States was indeed basically flat in February, for the first time in several months. Factory hours actually fell by half a percentage point, and two industries that had been hiring heavily -- electronic components and industrial machinery -- did not add workers.
But these signs of weakness were overshadowed by robust hiring in construction and services last month. Aided by the lowest mortgage rates in four years -- just under 7 percent -- builders added 41,000 jobs. Mild weather in parts of the country and the cleanup and rebuilding that followed flooding and ice storms in other areas also stimulated construction. The boom in mortgage refinancing added thousands of jobs in the financial services sector.
Most of the hiring, however, was done, as usual, by the giant service sector, which added 146,000 workers, including 25,000 in health care, 25,000 in computer and data processing, and 17,000 in financial services.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Move Up

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Home mortgage rates rose this week, according to Freddie Mac. Thirty-year mortgages increased to an average 7.19 percent from 7.09 the previous week, while 15-year loans rose almost the same amount to 6.80 percent from 6.69. One-year adjustable- rate mortgages also inched upward to an average 5.70 percent from 5.65 percent, according to Freddie Mac, a corporation that is chartered by Congress and buys mortgages from lenders and packages them into securities for investors.

HEADLINE: A Small War to Control a Crumbling Armory and Its Art

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL and SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
With questions arising over the upkeep and management of the landmark Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, a struggle has erupted over who will control the building and the millions of dollars of paintings and artifacts it contains.
Charles A. Gargano, a top aide to Gov. George E. Pataki, says the state may transfer control of the building to a private group. The Municipal Art Society of New York, a nonprofit organization that has long championed the cause of historic preservation, is pressing for a civic organization to take over the building, privately constructed on city-owned land and opened in 1879. And a veterans' group established decades ago is claiming ownership of the armory's multimillion-dollar collection of paintings and military regalia, setting off a protracted legal battle with the state. 
 But the obscure state agency that runs the building says it is poised to reverse the armory's structural decline and is committed to continuing its management, even if it must form a partnership with a private group. The agency, the Division of Military and Naval Affairs, which oversees the state National Guard, blamed the chronic physical deterioration in the building on past state budget cuts and a "massive deterioration and decline of the New York National Guard from 1985 to 1995."
The guard's personnel decline, the officials said in a statement, has been reversed, allowing the division to focus "on solving inherited and deferred problems as they relate to an aging infrastructure." They estimate that the building needs $2 million in repairs.
At stake is the future of one of New York City's most prominent landmarks, now damaged by water leaks that have gone unrepaired for years. In the last decade, as the number of art and antiques shows in the city has quadrupled, the Upper East Side armory has become the most prominent site in the country for such lucrative events.
The New York Times reported yesterday that structural problems at the imposing red-brick building bordered by Park and Lexington Avenues and East 66th and 67th Streets have become so severe that a portion of a ceiling recently collapsed, ruining hand-stenciled walls.
Leaders of civic and veterans' groups, as well as art and antiques dealers, have also questioned the division's policy of renting the enormous drill hall for shows at what they say are bargain-basement rates without competitive bidding.
Neighborhood residents also say that the recent boom in shows has generated problems to which the armory management has been unresponsive. Walter L. Deane, president of the East 66th Street and East 67th Street Block Associations, said that among the most serious grievances are the loading and unloading of materials late at night and in the early morning, rat infestations from mounds of garbage bags on the sidewalk, and double- and triple-parking, which has tied up traffic.
Maj. Gen. John H. Fenimore 5th, who heads the Military and Naval Affairs Division, said in an interview that he had been unaware of the complaints but that he would try to solve them. If the community leaders contact him at his headquarters in Latham, an Albany suburb, General Fenimore, added, "I'll be happy to meet with them."
Despite the division's promise of changes, the leaders of several civic and veterans' organization say they are concerned that the decaying armory could imperil the collections of art and military memorabilia and the shows held there.
Estimating the true cost of repairs in the millions, Brendon Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society, said that more funds for maintenance could be raised through higher rental fees.
Funds should also be spent to air condition the building, he said, so it could be used for summer events like traveling art exhibits and concerts. Over the years, the armory has been discussed as a summer home for the New York Philharmonic.
In addition to an infusion of government and private funds, Mr. Sexton said, the building's rescue lies in having a conservancy or nonprofit trust take over the management.
"We have talked with Mr. Gargano and people in the Governor's office, and we are trying to set up a not-for-profit group that would ask the state and the city for permission of taking on the task of rescuing the building," Mr. Sexton added.
Mr. Gargano, who as chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation is a top economic development aide to Governor Pataki, acknowledged in an interview that the building was in need of extensive rehabilitation.
Asked if the administration wanted to turn over the armory's management to a private group, Mr. Gargano said: " At this, point we don't have a definite plan. But it would be a prudent course of action to get a feel of what the private sector's interest might be."
Major General Fenimore said he would not oppose a partnership with a private group.
The most bitter fight over control at the armory, which is now in the courts, is between the state and the Seventh Regiment Fund, a veterans' group established in 1909 to help conserve the armory's art and military gifts. The dispute centers not on the building itself, but on the trove of Civil War paintings, silver and military artifacts that were donated to the regiment, which no longer exists. With its centerpiece canvas by Thomas Nast of the unit going off to war in 1861, the collection is valued at more than $10 million.
Fund officials claim ownership because during the Korean War, title to the collection was transferred to their organization by the commanding officers of the Seventh Regiment's successor unit, the 107th Infantry. The National Guard officers were concerned that the outfit might be sent overseas and that the armory's possessions would be best protected by the fund.
The state argues that the transfer was improper and invalid.
The dispute started in 1996, when the Pataki administration sent auditors to make an inventory of artifacts in the state's 65 National Guard armories. At the Park Avenue armory, fund officials refused to allow an inspection unless the state acknowledged that the fund owned most of the art and military regalia.
The State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, retaliated by suing the fund, charging that the veterans had illegally created a private museum for themselves from a collection that was state property.
The fund countersued in November, based on a complaint by Kenyon B. FitzGerald Jr., the organization's president, that the state had attempted to seize the collection before resolution of the legal questions.
Both suits are awaiting rulings in state courts, but the dispute has spread into the armory itself.
David L. Dalva 2d, a fund trustee, contends that the division retaliated against him in December by abruptly evicting the nonprofit Seventh Regiment Rifle Club, which he headed, and which had operated a shooting range in the basement for more than a century. The division cited problems of lead contamination and other health hazards at the range. Mr. Dalva said studies by the club found no environmental problems.
Also entering the fray is the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, whose predecessor, Edward V. Regan, conducted audits in the early 90's that found faulty financial practices at the armory. A spokesman for Mr. McCall said a new audit was being planned. "It is something we are going to look into," the spokesman, Jeffrey Gordon, said, describing the armory's popularity as "an unusual situation."
"Most of the other armories are rust buckets, and no one is breaking down doors to lease space in those places," he said.
Some civic leaders believe the battling over the armory may itself cause further harm to the building.
"We have been telling state and city officials and the veterans' groups that everyone has to agree to quit their claims on the armory," Mr. Sexton said. "Otherwise we could lose this outstanding building."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Delays Indonesian Aid; Reforms Seem to Be Stalled

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Saturday, March 7

 BODY:
As criticism grew of President Suharto's failure to press ahead with the International Monetary Fund's economic program, the fund said Friday that it was delaying the release of further financing for Indonesia.
In a statement, the agency said it was holding back on a scheduled infusion of $3 billion, which had been due this month, until at least April, according to wire service reports. It said the "basic conditions" for the financing had not yet been met. 
 The I.M.F. has organized a $40 billion economic rescue package for Indonesia, in return for which Mr. Suharto agreed in January to end monopolies and cartels, reorganize the banking sector, remove price supports and end expensive and money-losing projects.
But the I.M.F. and its key partner, the United States, have recently warned that the continued release of funds could be withheld because of what they said was Mr. Suharto's failure to press ahead with many of these steps.
In Washington on Friday, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said, "There obviously are issues of concern," Reuters reported. "I think what Indonesia needs to do is to re-establish financial stability and be on a sustained reform program."
The I.M.F. statement said the agency was delaying a review of Indonesia's performance, which had been scheduled to take place March 15. A team of I.M.F. experts is already in Jakarta.
"The I.M.F. management aims at the speedy renewal of the review discussions as soon as the basic conditions are met and the required changes in a few macroeconomic assumptions of the program can be made," the Fund said.
"Assuming this can be achieved, and given the existing I.M.F. procedures, the date of the executive board discussion of the conclusion of this program review could not be expected before April."
It noted that its decision to resume financing would involve discussions with Indonesia's new Cabinet. Indonesia is now in the middle of an electoral assembly session that is expected this month to name President Suharto, 76, to a new five-year term after 32 years in power.
For the last several weeks, Indonesia has been preoccupied with the politics of this electoral assembly. Its Cabinet and Finance Minister have been hobbled in their work on economic reform by the likelihood that many of them will not be reappointed.
Before the announcement by the I.M.F. of a delay, Finance Minister Marie Muhammad said today that any such action would hurt investor confidence and slow the recovery of the weak currency, the rupiah.
For the last two days, the rupiah has fallen in value, after nearly a month of relative stability, primarily because of a rising expectation that the I.M.F. funding would be delayed, according to financial analysts.
"Any delay in the disbursement will have a negative effect on the process of confidence recovery," Mr. Muhammad said. "This will adversely affect not only Indonesia but also efforts to strengthen and stabilize currencies in Southeast Asia."
But if there is a delay, he added, "Any differences of interpretation of the implementation of the I.M.F.-brokered reform package of Jan. 15 will be resolved as quickly as possible."
Mr. Suharto's most recent interpretation of the package came in a speech on Sunday in which he insisted that he was carrying out the reform program but that his policy might be described as "I.M.F.-plus."
At least in part, this "plus" includes his continued consideration of what is known as a currency board, a system that would artificially raise the value of the rupiah with economic consequences that outside experts say could be disastrous for Indonesia.
The possibility of a sudden increase in the value of the rupiah by decree helped support its value over the last month as traders held on to the currency, financial analysts said. But the President's hesitancy about reform has been a major factor in the continuing weakness.
"He is dodging the tough steps, and it just adds to the uncertainty," Mr. Malik said. "At this time, he should be trying to make an all-out effort to eliminate as much uncertainty as possible so that the markets have a clear picture, a game plan, of how Indonesia is going to tackle the problem."
Without this clear picture, experts said, investors will continue to stay away from Indonesia, unable to make their own plans.
"There's a kind of paralysis, and no one can see a way out of it," Linda Lim, an expert on Southeast Asian economies at the University of Michigan, said.
"Nobody is putting money into Indonesia, short term or long term, and the reason has got to be political risk," she said. "Political risk doesn't just mean the risk of political unrest and social unrest and food riots; it can also mean a paralyzed Government which cannot implement any of the policies that are required to bring back market confidence."
The decline in the rupiah's value has driven up the cost to Indonesia of its foreign debt, which is denominated mostly in dollars, to levels that are all but impossible to pay. Even with the temporary freeze on debt payments announced last month, the burden of more than $65 billion in corporate debt seems insurmountable.
This debt has pushed almost all of the country's major corporations past the level of bankruptcy, although they remain technically alive. Foreign banks have pulled back from their contacts with Indonesian banks, local lending has nearly stopped and business transactions have been put on hold.
"The devaluation is happening so fast that prices have not been able to catch up," an American businessman said. "How can you increase prices by 500 percent? People will start throwing rocks through your window. But if you don't, you lose money on everything you produce. And if you're an exporter and all your lines of credit are cut, how are you going to proceed?"

HEADLINE: Study Panel On Medicare Begins Work, In Conflict

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
A Federal advisory commission that will study the future of Medicare kicked off a year of work today with members declaring a desire for bipartisan agreement but skirmishing over President Clinton's proposal to open the program to millions of people 55 to 64 years old.
One member, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, former chief economic adviser to Mr. Clinton, cited new data from the Congressional Budget Office to show that his proposal would not increase the Federal deficit or harm the Medicare trust fund. 
 The budget office said that Mr. Clinton's proposal would increase Medicare spending by $9.4 billion over the next five years but that the new beneficiaries would pay most of the cost, with premiums totaling $7.9 billion. Mr. Clinton would make up the difference with measures to crack down on Medicare fraud and abuse.
The President's proposal "essentially pays for itself," Ms. Tyson said, so Congress can pass it this year without waiting for the commission to issue its report and recommendations next March.
In contrast, the chairman of the commission, Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, predicted that Congress would wait to hear from the panel, the National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare.
The 17-member panel, which includes 10 members of Congress, was created by the Balanced Budget Act of 1997. The law explicitly requires the commission to make recommendations on proposals to change the eligibility age for Medicare, now 65.
Rather than letting people buy into Medicare, Mr. Breaux said, "I am intrigued with the idea of allowing the uninsured to buy into the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program." That program is, in effect, a supermarket through which 350 private health plans are offered to nine million Federal employees, retirees and dependents.
In their two-hour meeting today, the commissioners seemed eager to disprove the conventional wisdom that they will become bogged down in partisan bickering. They agreed that Medicare had been immensely successful in improving the lives of elderly Americans, but said that bold changes were needed to preserve and strengthen the program for 76 million baby boomers.
Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, said, "This commission will fail if we limit the discussion purely to one about money." He called for improvements in Medicare benefits to add or expand coverage of prescription drugs, long-term care and mental health services.
Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, called for an "income test," which would require elderly people with incomes over $75,000 a year to pay higher Medicare premiums.
And Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said that "Medicare should have a budget," rather than being an open-ended entitlement program.
Nine of the commissioners are Democrats, but liberals appeared apprehensive that they might be outvoted.
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan; Bruce C. Vladeck, former director of the Medicare program under President Clinton, and Ms. Tyson said they wanted to be sure that commissioners could file a minority report if they disagreed with the majority.
The 1997 law says the commission's final report shall contain a detailed statement of only those recommendations and conclusions that get at least 11 votes.

HEADLINE: Privatizing Social Security Wouldn't Pay Off;
What Higher Returns?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The projections of high returns in a privatized Social Security system cited in your March 2 front-page article are the result of two important accounting errors. 
 First, these calculations assume the stock market can continue to give over the next 75 years the same rate of return in an economy that is projected to have less than half the growth that it did over the last 75 years.
Second, calculations showing higher returns in a privatized system typically ignore the taxes that would be needed to finance the switchover. In a set of projections that correct for this error, the Employee Benefit Research Institute found that a privatized system will provide young workers with a negative return on their payments.
 
DEAN BAKER
Washington, March 2, 1998
 
The writer is an economist with the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Ladies Sing the Blues

BYLINE: By Francis Davis; Francis Davis is the author of "Bebop and Nothingness" and "The History of the Blues."

 BODY:

BLUES LEGACIES
 AND BLACK FEMINISM
 Gertrude "Ma" Rainey, Bessie Smith,
 and Billie Holiday.
 By Angela Y. Davis.
 Illustrated. 427 pp. New York:
 Pantheon Books. $27.50. 
 AS a consequence of slavery and segregation, Angela Y. Davis contends in "Blues Legacies and Black Feminism," her study of the recordings of Billie Holiday and the blues vaudevillians Gertrude (Ma) Rainey and Bessie Smith, "black social consciousness has been overdetermined by race," with too little attention paid to sex and virtually none to class. Davis, a professor of something called the "history of consciousness" at the University of California, Santa Cruz, would have a hard time selling such a notion to this country's black poor, who are understandably inclined to blame the legacy of white racism for their poverty. But she's right in step with the more radical of her academic colleagues, even if her ingrained cultural nationalism prevents her from joining them in dismissing race as an arbitrary social construct with no basis in anthropology. Race, according to current academic thinking, is a smokescreen that has drawn discussion away from the more crucial issue of class.
If this sounds suspiciously like Marxism, it is Marxism gone post-modern: a tool for the analysis of literary and other "texts," not necessarily a call for the exploited masses to rise. One of the side effects of this recent trend has been to restore the credibility of certain black intellectuals and activists of the 1960's and 70's, whose Marxist ideals might otherwise make them seem like relics not of their own day but of the 1930's. Davis made the news in 1969, when the Regents of the University of California attempted to bar her from teaching at U.C.L.A. because she was a member of the Communist Party, and again a year later, when she briefly became a fugitive after being accused of supplying the brother of George Jackson with the firearms for his one-man raid on a Marin County courthouse. (Jonathan Jackson was killed, along with three others, in the ensuing shootout. Davis was later apprehended, tried and acquitted.)
Davis's thesis in "Blues Legacies and Black Feminism," in a nutshell, is that Ma Rainey and Bessie Smith, among other flamboyant women blues singers of the 1920's and 30's, helped not just to articulate black working-class consciousness but to shape it. "Women's blues," Davis writes, "provided a cultural space for community-building among working-class black women . . . in which the coercions of bourgeois notions of sexual purity and 'true womanhood' were absent." The songs performed by Rainey and Smith, in particular, served as "historical preparation" for a kind of social protest of which Billie Holiday's 1939 recording of "Strange Fruit," a song that condemned lynching, is a prime example.
Davis has never been the ideologue the popular media once cast her as. Though she takes an entire book to say what might have been said more effectively in an essay, "Blues Legacies and Black Feminism" is filled with powerful ideas. Davis observes that slavery, which often required women to work at the same jobs as men, "established a distorted form of gender equality" among blacks, leading to "gender politics within the slave community that were radically different from those operating in the dominant culture." After slavery, black women "faced ideological expectations of domesticity and subordination emanating from the dominant culture," even as political and economic restrictions on black aspiration "rendered such ideological assumptions flagrantly incongruous."
To Davis's thinking, vintage women's blues derived its power from its rejection of the standards of propriety embraced by the emerging black bourgeoisie. This is a valid way of hearing the blues, and Davis is hardly one of those scholars, like Houston A. Baker or Henry Louis Gates Jr., for whom the blues is an esthetic, a sensibility, a trope -- anything but a form of music worthy of explication on its own terms. Davis has transcribed the lyrics to some 250 songs recorded by Rainey or Smith, a good many of which she analyzes in detail. Her specificity, however, ultimately works against her, because her interpretations can be not just dogmatic but bizarre. She offers the dubious theory that "the blues" is sometimes a coded reference to white oppression. Imagining the female shouts of approval that have greeted most of Smith's live performances of "I Used to Be Your Sweet Mama," Davis neglects to consider that there were also men in Smith's audiences -- men whose audible protests of Smith's denunciations of them were the other half of a comic courtship ritual.
If Davis reduces Smith's legendary showmanship to an early form of feminist consciousness-raising, Holiday's powerful transformations of Tin Pan Alley ballads become a variety of private racespeak. Resolutely text-oriented despite her awareness that a song's "meaning" is not necessarily confined to its lyrics, Davis lacks the ear to do justice to Holiday as a great musician whose instrument happened to be her voice. Hearing Holiday tease Oscar Hammerstein 2d's maudlin lyric to "Lover, Come Back to Me," Davis interprets her real message to be "Lover, please stay away -- I am immensely enjoying this state of freedom from the vagaries of love constructed according to male dominance." The only valid response to such a willful misinterpretation is: Say what? Davis seems to think it a shame that circumstances forced Holiday to perform such material rather than the blues; to the contrary, Holiday embraced pop songs for the same reason that sophisticated contemporaries like Art Tatum and Coleman Hawkins did -- for the harmonic challenge such songs presented, their lyrics entirely aside.
Davis informs us that the blues has always been implicitly "gendered" as male, that the songs performed by Ma Rainey refused to "privilege" marriage over nonmarital or extramarital relationships and that most accounts of how Billie Holiday came to perform "Strange Fruit" have tended to "foreground" the contributions of white males. Leftist academics understandably ruffle at being made fun of for their jargon, but this is what they deserve for not acknowledging the obvious contradiction between their egalitarian politics and exclusionary mumbo jumbo. In addition to her confusion about what can be a transitive verb, Davis assumes that the reader is already familiar with the biographies of her three women singers, as well as with their music. Her failure to say much of anything about her subjects' personal lives is especially telling in the case of Smith, whose exploitation by a philandering husband might undermine Davis's image of her as a positive role model for black working-class women.
Davis sidesteps another potential ambiguity by ignoring Smith's and Rainey's costumes of feathers and rhinestones, as well as the other signs of conspicuous consumption that the performers' (presumably) black working-class audiences identified with as much as with their songs. This is another of those books in which the black bourgeoisie is given its lumps for acquiescing to what we are told are European-American standards of behavior. What I find most objectionable about this is that many of what are now regarded as distinctively African-American cultural traits are really the symptoms of poverty. Class and race have become hopelessly confused in this country, and black intellectuals like Davis should not add to the confusion. Davis chastises those black women's clubs of the 1920's whose efforts to uplift their race entailed virtually disowning free-spirited women like Rainey and Smith. But in attempting to recast these singers as working-class heroines -- to "valorize" them, in the current jargon -- isn't Davis practicing her own brand of social uplift and moral purification? The working class, as defined by Davis and most post-modern Marxists, sounds suspiciously like a middle-class conceit.

HEADLINE: A Different West Side Story

BYLINE: By Stephen O'Connor; Stephen O'Connor is the author of "Will My Name Be Shouted Out? Reaching Inner City Students Through the Power of Writing" and "Rescue," a short-story collection.

 BODY:

ON THE OUTSIDE LOOKING IN
 A Year at an Inner-City High School.
 By Cristina Rathbone.
 385 pp. New York:
 Atlantic Monthly Press. $26. 
 One of the reasons Cristina Rathbone's account of her year observing a Manhattan high school is so gripping is that the events she describes are so commonplace. Virtually every urban public school has students like the girl Rathbone calls Nicole, whose latest foster mother abandoned her for a week at Christmas with only "a $10 bill and an empty refrigerator for company"; or Rasheem, who after years in shelters finally found a permanent home and began to make real academic progress, only to slump back into despair when his best friend was wounded by a stray bullet; or Manny, who lived with his pathetic drug-addicted father and felt he had no choice but to emulate his widely respected uncle, a drug dealer who was eventually murdered, by selling heroin on the street.
Rathbone decided to spend a year at a high school in order to confront her own -- and society's -- fear of contemporary urban teen-agers. She settled on West Side High School, an alternative school marooned by budget cuts on three noncontiguous floors of a midtown high-rise, because it took in the most marginal teen-agers of all -- those already rejected by other high schools. At first Rathbone was too intimidated to do more than sit in on classes, but eventually, as she dared to accompany individual students to their homes, or on visits to relatives in jail, or, most interestingly, to gang meetings in Washington Heights, she stopped fearing the students and started to fear for them. Rathbone's involvement with some West Side students went far beyond mere reporting. In one instance she was horrified to realize that she had helped a boy steal $500 worth of designer clothing from his incarcerated cousin.
Rathbone's sympathy for students does not, however, prevent her from showing some of them at their very worst: going into crack houses, dealing heroin, beating up their classmates. But she never lets these students become the one-dimensional addicts, pushers and thugs of so many political speeches. Always they have their full human complexity, always they are individuals who might have had very different fates had they not been born in such grim circumstances.
Again and again "On the Outside Looking In" shows us good lives being wasted not only by poverty but by society's inadequate response to it. The budget cuts that stranded the West Side High School in an office building without a cafeteria or gym, and with so few textbooks that students cannot take them home, also eliminated desperately needed social services. When Rathbone herself succumbs to despair as she realizes that she can do nothing to protect the troubled students whom she has befriended, her readers share her feelings completely. But like everyone in public education, we are encouraged by the small successes she witnesses: a boy reading his first book, a girl leaving a gang to take a job at a movie theater, another girl getting top grades even as she deals with pain from years of sexual abuse.
While Rathbone's strong identification with West Side's students gives "On the Outside Looking In" much of its power, it is also the source of the book's one significant weakness. Given that she is writing about a high school, Rathbone says surprisingly little about the crucial question of what schools can and should do for their students. In particular, she shows scant appreciation for the important role that authentic academic accomplishment can play in shoring up even the most damaged student egos.
In the end, however, such oversights scarcely detract from the authentic and critically important story Cristina Rathbone has to tell. There are those who believe we have heard enough about the ravages of poverty, who would rather dwell on exceptional individuals who triumph over deprivation or on the majority who suffer it with quiet dignity. But if we are ever to make progress against the soul rot of economic injustice, we must look carefully at how it affects individual lives. And, most important of all, we must keep fixed in our minds the simple truth -- all too often obscured in American political discourse -- that what separates the poor from the rest of society is only, as Rathbone puts it, "the difference in where we were born, and to whom," not the difference of who we are.

HEADLINE: Even Worse Than We Remember

BYLINE: By David M. Shribman; David M. Shribman is the Washington bureau chief of The Boston Globe.

 BODY:

SHOW TIME
 The American Political Circus
 and the Race for the White House.
 By Roger Simon.
 345 pp. New York:
 Times Books/Random House. $25. 
 SONNY BONO, the late Congressman from California and whimsical political philosopher, used to say that politics and entertainment had a lot in common: "Both have lyrics and both have a beat." Indeed, Ronald Reagan proved what Americans have long known but until recently did not fully appreciate: politics is performance art.
Now, 16 months after the curtain fell on the melodrama of the 1996 Presidential election, arrives Roger Simon's review. He finds -- no surprise here -- that the whole shebang was a show, and not a particularly edifying or even entertaining one. In short, "Show Time" gives the campaign two, maybe three, thumbs down, faulting the usual villains: the candidates, the handlers, the press, the voters and the system.
Why anyone would want to push the rewind button on a campaign that interested no one the first time around is beyond me. (By "no one" we can safely include here Bob Dole's forces, which showed almost no interest in winning, and Bill Clinton's team, which did its best to assure that nothing of interest occurred; during the second debate, Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said: "There can't be a television set still turned to this. It takes every ounce of strength not to get up and turn the channel.") For my part, I would sooner relive the Congress of Vienna, which had interesting principals, or even the 1828 tariff debate, which involved economic principles, than the 1996 campaign, which was devoid of both principals and principles.
But Simon, a columnist now newly planted as a White House correspondent for The Chicago Tribune, has concocted a wry cocktail, and he tells a dreary story with a fresh eye and a brisk pace. There is even a tidbit or two -- news magazine correspondents used to call this sort of ephemera "nuts on the fruitcake" -- for the withdrawal symptoms of the politically addicted. Clinton lathered antibacterial foam on his hand after working a crowd to make sure he didn't pick up any germs. Dole didn't tell his sisters of his intention to quit the Senate. Clinton was urged to move toward Dole on the debate set in the hope that he might unnerve him.
IN the old days, campaign books were chronicles about the country, how it was changing, what tensions were shaping it, which great debates were being held in living rooms and on factory floors and in coffee shops in colorful rural crossroads. They were works of probity, even poetry. It can safely be said that no one ever laughed out loud at a single thing Theodore H. White wrote. I laughed out loud twice during "Show Time," which is either a flaw in my character or a commentary on how American politics has gone wrong. Probably both.
Thus the modern campaign book, with almost nothing about demographic shifts, the economy, race, the size and role of government, the meaning of freedom, the balance of power or the balance of payments. This is a book about a campaign between a man who couldn't stop performing and a man who wouldn't start, between a man who found joy, liberation and redemption in campaigning and a man who was bored by it, demeaned by it and diminished by it. In short, it is a spoof of a spoof.
This book is meant to make three arguments: that Bill Clinton is a master practitioner of the modern campaign arts, which is to say that he is a showman; that Bob Dole is old; and that we in the press are fools. It's all true. But you knew that.
So this is an engaging but cynical book about a cynical process featuring cynical men. It is, to be sure, shorter than the 1996 campaign. It's also a good deal funnier. But it will make you want to press fast-forward next time.

LENGTH: 911 words

HEADLINE: Nice Work if You Can Get It

BYLINE: By Paul Levy; Paul Levy, a weekly contributor to The Wall Street Journal Europe, is the author of a memoir of his Kentucky childhood, "Finger Lickin' Good."

 BODY:

TENDER AT THE BONE
 Growing Up at the Table.
 By Ruth Reichl.
 282 pp. New York:
 Random House. $23. 
 THE memoirs of food writers have a particular poignancy, for the child really is father to the man. The tale of the growth and development of appetite, while always personal and specific, is universally interesting -- as is proved by the work of writers as various as Jeffrey Steingarten, A. J. Liebling, Barbara Kafka and M. F. K. Fisher. But while all good food writers are humorous -- it's a feature of the genre -- few are so riotously, effortlessly entertaining as Ruth Reichl.
Unlike her counterparts in London and Paris, who are rarely recognized, even by the waiter, until they pay the bill with a credit card bearing their bylines, the restaurant critic of The Times is a person with such power that she must be a mistress of subterfuge. Judging by this meaty memoir, Reichl is also witty, fair-minded, brave and a wonderful writer. New York's restaurateurs can count themselves lucky.
Reichl's fans will not be surprised to learn that I laughed a lot while reading her sometimes achingly funny book. But I was also moved, and drew a sharp breath of sympathy from time to time at the candor of some of the tougher passages. She is honest about a wide range of subjects, from her fear of driving and panic attacks on bridges to more serious worries about her mother's failure to take her lithium and her venomous warnings that manic depression can be inherited.
All autobiographers have a problem conjuring with the truth. My own strategy is to regard writing about oneself as inadvertent fiction. Reichl's is contained in her first sentence ("Storytelling, in my family, was highly prized") and in the conclusion to which it leads her: "Everything here is true, but it may not be entirely factual." She admits to compressing events, combining characters and indulging in a bit of embroidery. Never mind. I believe all her stories -- and if your mouth has ever watered when you smelled something good or you've ever been overwhelmed with curiosity about how something will taste, you will too.
Before Reichl learned to write about food, of course, she learned to eat. And in writing about her childhood, she confirms my feeling that the best background for becoming a good cook is to be descended through the female line from generations of noncooks, and to be brought up (as was still possible in the early 1950's) by professionals -- by maids who did the cooking. Admittedly, this can be difficult to achieve if you have Jewish grandmothers (my own were indifferent cooks). One of Reichl's was too rich and posh, the other too busy to cook. So Reichl's mentors were her Aunt Birdie's cook-companion, Alice, and Mrs. Peavey, the alcoholic aristocrat who defied her sons' wishes by becoming the Reichls' maid.
Memoir writing gives us a chance to play God and re-create our own families, especially our parents, and Reichl has triumphed in her portrait of her unstable mother, Miriam, a Ph.D. unfazed by moldy food, "taste-blind and unafraid of rot." Her economies (scrape off the decay, throw nothing away, cater large parties with leftovers from the automat) taught her daughter many things: "The first was that food could be dangerous, especially to those who loved it. . . . My parents entertained a great deal, and before I was 10 I had appointed myself guardian of the guests. My mission was to keep Mom from killing anybody who came to dinner."
Jane Grigson used to say that no good food writer ever set out to be one, but invariably fell into the profession by accident. Reichl's career path was straighter than most. Despite degrees in sociology and art history, she worked in restaurants as a waitress and then a cook. Waiting on tables, she learned that the cooks regard running a restaurant as warfare, but when she became a cook herself in the 1970's it was in a pacific, though class-conscious, Berkeley collective. Married to an artist, living in a commune and cooking Thanksgiving dinner for 12 with food rescued from Dumpsters, she was at last able to sympathize with her mother's view of the undesirability of waste.
As her readers will have guessed (but she didn't at the time), all this was an apprenticeship for the one job at which she was bound to excel -- restaurant reviewing. She knew how restaurants worked. Childhood vacations in France and a stint at a French boarding school in Canada, plus travels in North Africa, Greece, Spain, Portugal and Italy, had also endowed her with a terrific taste memory. And she knew she could write -- after all, she started her life in Berkeley by "writing term papers for a living."
After that, it was just a question of meeting a few people: the generous Marion Cunningham, Cecilia Chiang and Kermit Lynch, the odious James Beard. (She tells it like it is.) Yet part of the charm of Reichl's memoir is her refusal to name-drop on the usual scale. Instead, she concentrates on the characters of the people she loves. Chief among these is her mild-mannered, long-suffering, scholarly German Jewish father. Eventually, she comes to realize that he has been a willing accomplice to his more flamboyant spouse, enjoying "the tumult Mom created." And Reichl discovers that her father kept some secrets of his own: he had flown with Wilbur Wright and -- very satisfying for a daughter who was a veteran protester against the Vietnam War -- been a draft dodger back in Germany.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Tourism Slipping, Along With Asian Economies

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
THE long-awaited new Hong Kong airport at Chek Lap Kok is scheduled to open July 6, but the opening ceremony could resemble a funeral unless the Asian economic crisis moderates soon. Tourism has fallen steadily since July, to Hong Kong as well as to other Asian cities for which the new airport is expected to become a major hub. And the World Travel and Tourism Council recently forecast that the drop in tourism to Asia will continue through 1998, at a cost of more than 500,000 jobs.
Many intra-Asia flights have been cut back at least one-third, and flights to and within Asia have been sharply curtailed. Tourist industries in Hong Kong, South Korea, Thailand and Malaysia already show signs of having been flattened by a tsunami. 
 "I just got back from Hong Kong with a group," said Kurt Bodmer, vice president for business development with Japan and Orient Tours in San Diego, "and hotel officials in Hong Kong are scared to death about the outlook for the rest of the year."
As well they should be. In its February monthly bulletin, the Pacific Asia Travel Association said that while slumping tourism has hit most Asian nations hard since last July, "Hong Kong has been the most negatively affected." Asia's overall decline in visitors is likely to be about 12 percent in 1998, the association added, while Indonesia, Malaysia and South Korea could see as much as a 50 percent drop. Even Australia may suffer a 9 percent drop in international arrivals this year, the association said, with as much as a 33 percent decline from Asia.
Cathay Pacific Airways in Hong Kong, a government-owned carrier, is facing especially tough times. Last month it laid off 760 employees, attributing the cuts to a very bad year in 1997. And 1998, a spokesman added, shows little hope of improvement.
Still, Cathay Pacific is fighting back. Last November, hoping to stoke Hong Kong's economy, the government, hotels and the airline offered 20,000 round-trip packages to Hong Kong from the United States for $999 for two, including five nights at a hotel. Now it is offering a round-trip fare of $999 a passenger ($899 for seniors and students) from its New York and Los Angeles gateways, allowing visits to 17 other Asian cities within 30 days.
If the economy is the main culprit in Asia's tourist slump, bird flu in Hong Kong contributed to the falloff, as did the uncertainty following last summer's transfer of sovereignty in Hong Kong from Britain to China. Haze from forest fires in Indonesia last fall damaged tourism in a wide region from Singapore to the Philippines, and caused particular problems for Malaysia, whose goal is to double tourism to 20 million visitors by the year 2000.
"The economic meltdown in Asia caught us and others by surprise," said Nick Varian, chief executive of Venice Simplon-Orient Express, which operates the luxury Eastern and Oriental Express train that runs through Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand. Through March, some fares for the 1,200-mile Singapore-Bangkok journey have been reduced by more than a third, to $975 a person from $1,460.
While Asian governments and tour operators extol the bargains that await tourists, including hotel rates cut in half, many travelers appear to be resisting. Faced with falling passenger loads, Northwest Airlines recently suspended its three weekly flights between Detroit and Seoul, South Korea, while United trimmed its two daily nonstops between San Francisco and Hong Kong to one, and suspended service between San Francisco and Seoul, and between Seoul and Manila.
Two Australian airlines, Qantas and Ansett, also suspended service to South Korea. Korean Air eliminated 3 of its 17 weekly flights to Hong Kong; in April it will reduce its flights to Macao, Guam and Saipan. Japan Airlines is in the process of reducing Japan-Hong Hong flights by 12.5 percent, and recently cut service to Singapore. KLM Royal Dutch Airlines plans to suspend service to Ho Chi Minh City on March 25.
China appears to be weathering the region's cutbacks in flights, mainly because business travel to the Asian giant remains strong. Northwest, for example, recently increased Detroit-Beijing service to four weekly flights from three, while Japan Airlines plans to open new routes to Beijing, Shanghai and Dalian.
The Olympics and business travel to Japan appear to have kept the Japanese tourist industry afloat, if not robust. Despite the economic softening in Japan, the agreement in January to end most restrictions on air travel between the United States and Japan brought a flurry of jockeying for permission among U.S. airlines to fly new routes and with additional frequency.
But with intra-Asian tourism down, it is unlikely that foreign tourists to Japan this year will come close to last year's 4.2 million, a 10.5 percent increase over 1996.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Cancun

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER; LARRY ROHTER reports on the Caribbean for The Times.

 BODY:
From the moment it began beckoning to visitors less than 25 years ago, Cancun has been defined by contradictions. In a part of Mexico dominated by ancient Maya temples, it was envisioned as a modern creation, all glass and concrete and steel. In an area surrounded by nature at its most raw and unspoiled in the form of beaches and jungle, it is a purely man-made place.
Its adolescence over, however, Cancun has begun to learn how to coexist with its surroundings. Tour operators, realizing that vacationers do not live by beach and nightclub alone, now encourage visitors to put down that John Grisham novel or that bottle of Corona and venture out on day trips to such magnificent archeological sites as Chichen Itza and Tulum or the splendid colonial city of Merida. The beach and the bars, after all, will still be there for another day. 
 Cancun is shaped like the number 7, and the continuing construction of hotels the length of the long stem of the island has forced a search for new markets. The result has been a notable influx of middle-class visitors from Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Spain, who, like the Americans and Canadians who preceded them, have brought along their own habits and tastes. The benefit to Cancun can be seen in the opening of several restaurants specializing in Argentine parrillada (mixed grill), the extravagant smorgasbord of grilled meats that Brazilians call rodizio, and Spanish tapas, plus the welcome introduction of some new dance rhythms at local night spots.
Yes, the prevailing atmosphere as one cruises Kukulcan Boulevard, the busy strip where most of Cancun's 122 hotels are clustered, remains that of an Orlando or a Las Vegas dropped intact next to pellucid Caribbean waters. But Mexicans are beginning to talk of a Maya Riviera with Cancun as its core, though not its sole attraction. That may sound a bit far-fetched, but then again, so did the original concept of transforming a tiny Latin American fishing village into a haven for North Americans.
A note on security: Though visitors to Mexico City complain of increasing vulnerability to crime, the situation in Cancun is markedly different. Since tourism means everything to the local economy, a variety of precautions are taken to protect visitors. The main drag is well lighted; hotels and bars generally maintain good security, and cabs, though expensive, are safe. Even public transportation can be recommended; buses run frequently and are clean and cheap.
 
Events
 To the Maya, the spring Equinox, on March 21, was a sacred event, and at the pyramid of Kukulcan in Chichen Itza, modern-day visitors can still get a flavor of how seriously they regarded the date. Beginning at noon, the sun casts a strange shadow on the outside wall of the northern staircase of the temple, until all that is left is one zigzag strip, shaped like a serpent slithering sinuously down the steps. Thousands come each year, which makes it important to book as quickly as possible if you want to see the phenomenon.
The Christian calendar also plays an important role in the city of Cancun and environs in the form of Holy Week, Semana Santa. This year, it runs from April 5 to 11, and though the Cancun beach strip is likely to be overflowing with vacationers from Mexico City, traditional celebrations in the form of plays and processions are scheduled in town. One procession takes place at Cristo Rey Church in the Parque de las Palapas downtown on Good Friday.
Another fiesta marks the anniversary of the founding of Cancun on April 20, with parades, fairs, dancing and music, mostly downtown and on Kukulcan Boulevard; visitors are welcome to join in. For details, call the Cancun Tourism Office: (52-98) 87-33-11, extension 114 or 115.
The Cancun Jazz Festival is part of Festival Week '98, from May 16 to 26. Events will take place at Playa Ballenas: on May 22, hip-hop is the focus; on May 23, rhythm-and-blues, with jazz artists yet to be named. General admission tickets are $35. Information: (888) 625-4246.
 
Sightseeing
 A very pleasant seven-mile ferry ride from Cancun lies Isla Mujeres. There's an old pirate fortress here, and a turtle sanctuary. But the main attraction is Garrafon National Park with its aquarium. Anyone who wants to feel even closer to nature can simply wade into the water at the main beach, which is protected by coral reefs just offshore. There, huge schools of fish in brilliant shades of turquoise and yellow flit around visitors begging to be fed. Passage on the public ferry, which leaves from Punta Sam every two hours, is $1.50; boats also leave from Puerto Juarez every half hour or so ($2); water taxis provide the same service for $11.50 or more. Admission to the park is $4.
Farther away (70 minutes by bus but well worth the trip) is Xcaret (shkah-RET), perhaps best described as an eco-archeological theme park. More than a thousand years ago, the Maya gathered at this site, whose name means "the small cove," to embark for the sanctuary of Ix Chel, their goddess of fertility, on the nearby island of Cozumel, and to swim in sacred cenotes, or underwater rivers. Some ruins remain, but the real attraction is those underground rivers and caverns through which modern-day visitors now swim, snorkel and dive. Xcaret also has an aquarium, a botanical garden and a museum, as well as horseback riding and a swimming area where it is possible to frolic with dolphins ($75 for a one-hour session). Admission: $39. Information: (52-98) 83-31-43. Open daily from 8:30 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Sundays until 5 P.M.
 The best-known Maya ruins in the region, however, are probably Chichen Itza and Tulum. The latter is about an hour south of Xcaret, and includes some 50 temples and towers overlooking the Caribbean. Chichen Itza, on the road to Merida, is on an even grander scale: from A.D. 450 to 1200 it was one of the most imposing centers of wealth and learning in the Maya world, and today is one of the most visited of all Maya sites. One convenient way to get to either destination is to make a reservation on the Gray Line bus service by calling (800) 235-4079 in the United States or 86-79-01 from Cancun. The charge to Chichen Itza is $63 (children half-price), and includes air-conditioned transport, a buffet lunch, admission to the site and a guide. A similar package to Tulum (with breakfast and lunch) and the nearby recreational site of Xel-Ha costs $74, with children half-price.
 
Where to Stay
 Cancun now has more than 22,000 hotel rooms. At most hotels, the high season runs through mid-April, with prices dropping up to 30 percent after that until December -- except for July and August, winter months in the Southern Hemisphere and peak season for South Americans.
The Hotel Fiesta Americana Cancun, with 281 rooms at kilometer 8.5 on Kukulcan Boulevard, began its life as a place for honeymooners, and though it has expanded its clientele, it maintains a Mexican village ambiance that gives it an intimate feel. It also has one of the best beaches on the island and is close to malls, restaurants and the convention center. Doubles start at $165. Reservations: (800) 343-7821 or (52-98) 83-14-00; fax (52-98) 83-18-18.
Also on the northern shore, at kilometer 4.5 near the departure point for water taxis to Isla Mujeres, the Calinda Beach Cancun offers a broad beach with calm surf that makes it an ideal choice for families with small children. With 470 rooms, it may be a bit large, but like many Cancun hotels that are part of Mexican chains, rates tend to be more reasonable than at better-known international rivals, without any appreciable drop in quality. Doubles: $113 and up. (800) 228-5151 or (52-98) 83-27-77, fax (52-98) 83-18-57.
Budget: One of the few hotels not on the beach is the Holiday Inn Express. But it is conveniently situated on a small island, Pok-Ta-Pok, in the middle of the lagoon separating Kukulcan Boulevard from the mainland, just a short distance from the Cancun Club de Golf, with its 18-hole Robert Trent Jones course. There are 120 rooms; doubles start at $88. (800) 465-4329 or (52-98) 83-22-00, fax (52-98) 83-25-32.
On the beach, one reliable bargain, if you want an all-inclusive package, is El Pueblito Inn, at kilometer 17.5. This 239-room hotel spills down to the sea in a series of three-story buildings and even offers a water slide down to the shore, making it especially appealing to children. Rooms are large, running from $110 a person, with meals, drinks and recreational facilities included. (52-98) 85-04-22; fax (52-98) 85-07-31.
In the luxury category, one hotel that has made an effort to acknowledge that Cancun is part of Mexico is the Marriott Casa Magna, at kilometer 14.5. As its name indicates, this is a huge hotel, with 414 rooms and 38 suites. But the imposing scale is eased by a vaguely Maya exterior and an interior that feels like a classic Mexican hacienda, with colonial-style furniture and ceramics. Daily Spanish lessons are free. Doubles begin at $210. (800) 228-9290 or (52-98) 81-20-00, fax (52-98) 81-20-85.
 
Where to Eat
 It often seems that every restaurant and fast-food chain operating in the United States has a branch here, and authentic and deftly prepared Mexican food is not so easy to find. A happy exception is La Joya, in the Fiesta Americana Coral Beach Hotel at kilometer 9.5. Signature dishes include grouper with three kinds of mole to medallions of beef served with nopales (green cactus buds) and several types of fiery chilis. A dinner for two with wine runs about $120. (52-98) 83-29-00.
Maria Bonita, next to the Camino Real Hotel at kilometer 9.5, is more modest in both ambition and cost. The setting is typical Mexican hacienda, and the menu is heavy on classic Mexican dishes, such as Tabasco-style steak (on a banana leaf with peppers, onions and guacamole). The poblano chilies stuffed with lobster and huitlacoche, or corn truffles, were especially intriguing. But there is also a Tex-Mex Corner for fajitas or barbecued ribs. Dinner for two with margaritas: about $80. Open 6:30 P.M. to 12 A.M. (52-98) 83-01-00.
La Dolce Vita, overlooking the lagoon at kilometer 14.5, serves solid Italian cuisine. Antipasti, such as red ravioli of lobster and scallops, draw heavily on local seafood. Main courses, on the other hand, are more traditional, and include chicken parmigiana or veal marsala. Dinner for two with wine: $80. (52-98) 85-01-50.
The same ownership also operates La Fisheria, in the Caracol Plaza shopping center at kilometer 8.5. The seafood ranges from ceviche to daily specials built around perhaps the two tastiest fish coming out of the Caribbean, grouper and huachinango (red snapper). Dinner for two with wine: $65. (52-98) 83-13-95.
Downtown, a good and economical choice is El Pescador, at 28 Tulipanes, (52-98) 84-26-73. The setting is rustic, often filled with locals drawn by the prospect of tasty seafood tacos and other Yucatan specialties. No reservations accepted. Slightly more upscale is La Mesa del Pescador, a sister restaurant in Kukulcan Shopping Plaza, (52-89) 85-05-05. Dinner for two with beer: $35 downtown, slightly higher on the island.
