HEADLINE: An Island of Southern Hospitality

BYLINE: By ALEX WARD; ALEX WARD is editor of special sections for The Times.

 BODY:
FOR a couple of New Yorkers in search of a weekend destination, the Cloister, a famously traditional old Southern resort off the coast of Georgia, does not immediately leap to mind. So why did my wife, Nancy, and I choose it, and why in February? For years, our family has spent time each August on the South Carolina coast, a couple of hundred miles north of Sea Island, where the Cloister is situated. We love that part of the South, but it is usually sweltering when we're there. So we've often talked of traveling back down in cooler weather, and trying someplace different.
We were thinking midfall or midspring, not midwinter. But midwinter was when we found ourselves suddenly in need of a little R and R, and the off-season rates were attractive. So, we thought, what's a few months? 
 About 20 degrees, as a matter of fact, which depending on one's hardiness makes a difference in terms of options. And at the Cloister there are options: horseback riding, bicycling, skeet shooting, tennis, golf, kayaking, nature trips. There is also a plush spa and exercise facility, a heated outdoor pool and a croquet green that looks as if it's trimmed regularly with nail scissors.
Leaving New York at midday on a Friday, we made a tentative plan: be flexible. It would be nice to take advantage of at least a couple of these activities, but a storm had blown through Sea Island and if the weather was still bad, we would just stay inside, reading books and trashy magazines and familiarizing ourselves with room service.
A few hours later, when we pulled out of the car-rental lot at the Jacksonville, Fla., airport and began the 70-mile drive up I-95 north to Sea Island, the wind was blowing briskly and a couple of large drops of rain splattered on the windshield. The sky was gray and getting grayer. It was looking like a literary weekend.
Though the gloom remained for much of the next day and a half, those raindrops would be the last we'd see, as it turned out. And when we crossed the causeway that links Sea Island to its larger neighbor, St. Simons Island, we were already rethinking our strategy.
Part of the reason had to do with simply being in a new place and wanting to get out and look around. That was reinforced by our first glimpse of the Cloister, an inviting complex of Spanish missionary-style buildings surrounded by palmettos and gnarly, rambling old oaks. We checked in at the main building, for which the resort is named, and were shown to our room on the first floor of the nearby River House.
The room, No. 132, was bright if not overly spacious, with a king-size bed and a cranky heating vent that refused to budge from the highest setting. The most notable feature was a picture window looking out on the Black Banks River, which parallels the Atlantic Ocean on the inlet side of the island. Over the next two days, it provided us with views of heron, porpoises, otter and a beautiful sunset.
The rate was $288 a night, plus sales tax and 15 percent gratuities, a sum we estimated would amount to roughly $350. The Cloister is on the American plan, so this covered all of our meals, including lunch on Sunday, checkout day. Our goal was to keep expenses under $1,000, not counting air fare or car rental, so we had about $300 to play with. We dropped our bags and headed out to see how far that would take us.
We went back to the main building, a sprawling structure. Designed by Addison Mizner in the late 1920's. Stucco and red-tiled on the outside, it has a neo-Gothic interior -- beamed ceilings, stained-glass windows and a couple of canyon-sized sitting rooms, each with an enormous fireplace at one end. Norma Desmond would have felt right at home.
The day's events were posted on a large board across from the front desk and the friendly staff was eager to answer any questions about them. We had just missed afternoon tea, but maybe we'd like to try ballroom dancing that night. Hmmm. Skeet shooting? We'd think about it.
We peeked inside the dining room, looked at Herend china in one of the shops and then strolled around the immaculately tended grounds, past the tennis courts, past the impossibly green rye grass lawn with oak trees planted in honor of visiting dignitaries (the President Bush oak, the President Carter oak, the Lady Thatcher oak), and over to the ocean side of the island.
Without doubt, the Cloister's two main attractions are the playing privileges it offers at the two nearby golf clubs it owns (54 holes in all), and its beach, a wide, inviting, mile-and-a-half-long expanse of white sand. We aren't golfers, but as long as there is not a hurricane we will visit the beach anytime. Getting to this particular one requires passing through either the Sea Island Beach Club or the Sea Island Spa, which make up one long facility with a swimming pool in between.
The Beach Club has the resort's most attractive dining area, a cheerful, capacious, ocean-front room. The spa is a gleaming space complete with salon, a fully equipped exercise room and massage rooms. For guests, use of the spa costs $12 a day. An hour's massage is $75.
Indulging in that luxury would set us back half of our remaining weekend trust fund. And there were only two openings, both of them early the following evening. We looked at each other and shrugged: let's go for it.
The spa did advertise one freebie, a brisk walk along the beach at 8 the next morning. I envisioned a gaggle of earnest, arm-swinging race-walkers scattering shore birds in its wake, but I agreed to go along if we were up.
It was time to change for dinner. Coat and tie are required for the evening meal in the main dining room, and in the bar after 6:30. Dress requirements at the Beach Club and at the golf clubs, where Cloister guests can eat, are more relaxed. The food at all the places we tried was more or less the same: solid, unpretentious, plentiful. This is not a place for culinary delights or surprises, but if you go hungry, you have only yourself to blame.
I was pleased by the wine list in the main dining room, though; it was limited, but there were some nice choices at decent prices. We polished off our dinner (veal tournedos for me, soft-shell crabs for Nancy) with a $30 bottle of Brouilly. Service was polite and efficient without being obtrusive. But we found it awkward that the wait staff, with the exception of the wine steward, was black, and the guests all white. This was not the case elsewhere at the resort.
We made the next morning's beach walk with time to spare. The gaggle consisted of the two of us plus a chipper young spa employee and one other guest, whose husband, a physician, was attending a conference at the resort. We ended up talking as much as we walked. In a half-hour we covered two miles, plus topics that ranged from the local architecture to Broadway shows to the paucity of shark's teeth on the beach to, so help me, the economic situation in Indonesia.
BY this time, a patch of blue sky was visible off to the West. We had breakfast at the Beach Club, and energized by the improving weather, rented bikes ($4.50 an hour; $9 for four hours) and pedaled up Sea Island Drive, which bisects the island's tony residential community. The houses on Sea Island are referred to as cottages, but they are large, elaborate and carefully tended manses, some of which appear to have been patterned after the Hearst Castle.
We rode several miles, until the drive dead-ended at the Ocean Forest Golf Club. Eager to peer at more homes through the lush growth of tall pines, broad oaks and Spanish moss, we proceeded onto an adjoining private road that the bike-shed attendant assured us was on-limits.
Nine or so round-trip miles later, our real-estate voyeurism sated, we were back in our room, staring at the marsh and contemplating what to do next. The sun was gone and the wind was picking up. A light lunch seemed appropriate and then, if the rain held off, some tennis. The main board listed a drop-in round-robin at 2 o'clock ($12 a person; normally, court rates are $24 an hour), which sounded appealing.
Only to us. "You're it!" said the pro when we arrived, as if he was greeting the only survivors of a shipwreck. He popped open a can of balls and waved at the 17 immaculate Har-Tru courts, every one of which was available. "Take your pick."
We shouldn't have been surprised. It was getting blustery and the temperature had dropped noticeably. We went out anyway, two tennis nut-cases in golf heaven, and discovered to our delight that the baffling on the fences neutralized the wind and the cool air provided a kick. It may have been only 50 degrees, but back in New York it was 30. Feeling happy and magnanimous, I let my wife serve first.
Actually, tennis is a major lure at the Cloister. But as the pro told us, the season for it runs roughly from March to October, when there is a precipitous falloff. In February, it's nearly nonexistent. "Our winter is pretty short," he said, grinning, "but you've managed to come right in the middle of it."
That was beginning to sink in. If it remained cool the next day, we might want to check out early and go exploring the other nearby islands, St. Simons and, to the south, Jekyll.
This thought led to a moment of temporary insanity on my part. Figuring we would need extra money to carry out this plan and stay within our budget, I called the spa and canceled the massages. After a two-mile walk, a nine-mile bike ride and two hours of tennis, what exactly was I thinking?
Perhaps inspired by that blunder, I committed another by making dinner reservations at the Sea Island Golf Club. We were looking for a less formal alternative to the main dining room, where black tie is suggested on Saturday evenings, and the Sea Island course is beautiful, with a waterfront location that was once a cotton plantation and a long driveway under a canopy of arching oaks.
But the clubhouse, which occupies the plantation's old corn barn, is, well, a clubhouse, and the dining room, with its overhead lighting and paneled walls, is not the setting for a romantic meal. In truth, however, it was a pleasant enough experience. We both had a decent filet and, as everywhere, were greeted warmly, even fussed over, by a staff that seemed surprised at having nonmembers there for dinner. Our waitress, an amiable native of Jekyll Island, convinced us we shouldn't leave the area without seeing it.
Sunday morning threw us for a loop by being sunny and warmer. We repeated the beach walk (by ourselves this time), had a pleasant breakfast at the Beach Club and stopped at the concierge's desk to pick up information about the other islands. But the brighter day had brought with it a different buzz.
There were more people outside, riding bikes, strolling the beach, snoozing in the sun. Off in the distance, we heard the pop-pop of shotguns decimating the clay pigeon population. And, lo and behold, there were even signs of human life on the tennis courts. Maybe we should just stick around awhile.
Room checkout was noon, but the front-desk clerk said we were welcome to make it 3:30, or even later. We played another hour of tennis, lingered over lunch, took a last walk on the beach, loaded the car and went to pay the bill. The total: $863.68, well under our alloted thousand. You wait right here, I told Nancy, while I go for a massage. Just kidding.
We still had a little time before heading back to Jacksonville. We drove to the north end of St. Simons, past countless historical markers, one charming old church, and a number of uninteresting new housing developments, then turned back south, to Jekyll. The waitress's enthusiasm was justified; it's beautiful, especially the small historic district, where Rockefellers, Vanderbilts and Astors once vacationed.
Looming above the cottages they built is the Jekyll Island Club Hotel, a huge Victorian-era concoction of turrets, balconies and walkways. In the early evening light, it looked irresistible. We've made a note of it for our next weekend escape.
 
An island for golf and tennis
 Sea Island is 70 miles north of Jacksonville, Fla, and 80 miles south of Savannah, Ga. The Cloister operates a shuttle to the Jacksonville airport ($36 one way), and to Glynco Airport in nearby Brunswick, Ga. It will also arrange for transportation to Savannah ($135 for two people, one way), A 24-hour notice is required for pickup.
The resort offers a variety of packages, based around golf, tennis, the spa and the shooting school. Rates vary by activity and season. Our room was $144 a person a day, and will be $167 from March 15 through May, the high season. A similar room on the golf package costs $201 a person, double occupancy, through mid-March, then $261 through May. That price includes three meals daily and greens and cart fees. Tennis rates are somewhat lower, spa rates somewhat more. Most packages require a minimum stay of three nights.
Reservations and information: (800) 732-4752, fax (912) 638-5159.
The Cloister conducts wildlife and birding tours, though the more adventurous might want to try getting on the Tuesday or Wednesday boat trip to Little St. Simons Island. The Lodge on Little St. Simons Island charges $75 a person for a tour, lunch and afternoon at the beach at this private wildlife refuge. Its overnight program costs $300 to $500 a couple. Call way ahead: (888) 733-5774.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Down Mean Alleys With John Goodman

BYLINE: By FRANZ LIDZ; Franz Lidz is a senior writer at Sports Illustrated and the author of the memoir "Unstrung Heroes."

 BODY:
JOHN GOODMAN cradles the make-believe bowling ball in his hands as if contemplating Yorick's skull. Standing in the middle of a midtown Manhattan intersection, he takes four careful steps, curls the ball behind him and flapjacks it down 55th Street. With Mr. Goodman's goading, the ball bellies out precariously toward the taxi on the right, then grips the asphalt and shimmies back toward the center of the street. The burly Mr. Goodman stops at the make-believe foul line and poises nimbly on his left foot like a ballet dancer. When the make-believe pins go down, he does a little jitterbug cakewalk.
On this cold morning, the actor, a nonbowler who has surely portrayed more bowlers than anyone in motion-picture history, is cakewalking around his past, revisiting old haunts and reviving memories of a time before his eight-year run as Roseanne's television husband, a time when he was just one more unemployed actor. Despite dark glasses -- or possibly because of them -- he is quickly recognized and accosted for autographs. Mr. Goodman, who now lives outside New Orleans with his wife and his 7-year-old daughter, is unfailingly friendly, charming, courtly, even kind to his fans. 
 "Are you John Goodman?" shouts one woman as he crosses 54th Street.
"Usually," he says in a voice that's surprisingly soft coming from a man the size of a tobacco warehouse. A small boy's smile creases the 45-year-old's pliant pudding face. Mr. Goodman always seems to have a smile, a nice combination of the innocent and the diabolical. Over the last few months he has worn it while helping Denzel Washington bottle a serial killer's evil spirit in "Fallen," while affecting an air of deadpan hipsterism in "Blues Brothers 2000," while squeezing palm-size people in his fist in "The Borrowers." He wears it again in "The Big Lebowski," Joel and Ethan Coen's kidnap-'n'-bowling caper grown from seeds planted in "The Big Sleep," the 1946 Howard Hawks classic starring Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall.
Mr. Goodman is cast in the Bacall role, as Walter Sobchak, a bowling brute with a lighted fuse. "Walter's whacked, a real piece of cake," he says. "He's not the brightest bulb on the Christmas tree." The Coens (Joel directs, Ethan produces, and they both write) tend to populate their intricate, unnerving fables with boldly outlined cartoon characters. Their style demands vivid acting, and Mr. Goodman -- in his third Coen brothers film (he was also in "Raising Arizona" and "Barton Fink") -- plays Sobchak exuberantly, with warmth and a kind of uncontained innocence. "There's something utterly guileless about John," says Joel Coen. "He's an incredibly versatile actor who often gets typecast in uninteresting parts."
Do Mr. Goodman's big guys have anything in common? He offers a wry half-smile with a kind of frank diffidence. "Yeah," he says. "They're all overweight."
Moving briskly across Madison Avenue, he passes the offices of Mad, the magazine that formed his boyhood consciousness. In the backwater of Affton, Mo., Mad was the only cultural event of the month. "I got my education from Mad," Mr. Goodman says. "If I didn't get a joke, I'd consult the encyclopedia." From Mad, he learned smart-aleck skepticism, suspicion of authority figures and Yiddishisms like furshlugginer and potrzebie.
Mr. Goodman's mother, a waitress at Jack and Phil's Bar-B-Cue who raised him from the age of 2, indulged his Mad-ness, but drew the line at James Bond novels. "Her boyfriend thought they were smutty," he explains.
At Ninth Avenue, Mr. Goodman hangs left and bellows, "There's my first apartment!"
He opens the front door of the building and scans the mailbox for familiar names. "I used to call this my hunting lodge," he says. "It had cable and a great brick view. The bathroom was in the hall, and the bathtub was in the kitchen. The stains on the tub's porcelain seemed to indicate that at one time gin had been brewed in there."
Mr. Goodman signed a lease on this distillery in 1976, a year after he had hopped a train for New York. He had arrived at Penn Station with a cardboard suitcase, a degree in theater from Southwest Missouri State and a $1,000 stake from his older brother. "I'd never been in New York before," he says. "I felt like a hick in a straw hat."
He remembers taking a taxi to a friend's digs on the Upper West Side. "I overtipped the cabby 10 bucks," he says. "I had no idea what to give him. My whole idea of tipping came from watching 'The Danny Thomas Show.' "
He made the rounds at audition halls, and within a month found work in a dinner-theater production of "1776."
"We opened and closed in Springboro, Ohio," he recalls. "That's five miles from Ridgeville, which is four miles from Waynesville, which is one mile from Corwin, which is three miles from Harveysburg."
His most memorable line? "When do we get to go back to New York?" deadpans Mr. Goodman, who played Thomas Jefferson. "I did a lot of preparation for the part. I actually kept slaves for a while and grew my own hemp." The research went largely unappreciated: "One of the critics indicated I was a little too antic to be one of the founding fathers."
MR. GOODMAN'S career was not an unfettered ascent. "That first winter in Manhattan I thought about giving up," he says. "It was day after day of nothing. I got to the point where I wasn't doing much of anything except the Sunday crossword puzzles." He patched together a slender living doing television commercials. He sold jeans, root beer, antacid. He got slapped around in ads for Mennen Skin Bracer. It was Mr. Goodman who said, "Thanks, I needed that!"
His stint as an Upper East Side bouncer lasted one night. "The club had this big German head bouncer who told us how to really hurt guys," he says. "You know, fishhook them, rip their cheeks. He giggled a little too much while demonstrating the old Detroit curb stomp, so the next day I called in sick and never came back."
Mr. Goodman flags down a cab, and instructs the driver to drive to 103d and Riverside. It was there in 1978, at the Equity Library Theater, that he made his New York stage debut (the theater closed in 1989). "I was Oberon in 'A Midsummer Night's Dream,' " he says. "People didn't seem to like the play too much, maybe because we did a disco version."
With New York's dailies on strike, the lone review appeared in the German-language paper Aufbau. "One of the cast members translated it for us," Mr. Goodman says. "The highlight: 'Puck is a good leaper.' "
Speeding southward, Mr. Goodman spots various landmarks: the actors' joint where he and Bruce Willis used to nurse Budweisers and leave dollar tips; the pinball arcade where he discovered Pac-Man. Turning down 45th Street, Mr. Goodman points out the Plymouth Theater. "I tried out for 'Equus' here," he says. "I thought I had a good shot at being one of the horses."
The taxi pulls up at 505 Eighth Avenue, the home of WBAI-FM. For three years in the mid-1980's, Mr. Goodman and a couple of pals performed sketches on a monthly radio show called "Citizen Kafka." His most inspired creation was Farmer Bob, a lecherous hayseed who harvested Cabbage Patch love dolls. "Kafka was trashy, deranged, disgusting," Mr. Goodman says. "It played right into my Mad sensibility."
The Coen brothers -- onetime Mad enthusiasts themselves -- say it was that very sensibility that got Mr. Goodman a part in "Raising Arizona." His escaped convict, a "criminal mastermind with a two-digit I.Q.," literally proved to be his breakout movie role. The ticking-bomb performance so impressed the Coens that they later asked him to appear in "Barton Fink," their post-modernist Faustian comedy. "What's it about?" asked Mr. Goodman.
"Well," said Ethan Coen. "You really have to read the script."
Mr. Goodman read it, liked it and played Charlie the insurance salesman with such sunny menace that he was nominated for a Golden Globe. "Only later did I find out what part I'd played in 'Barton Fink's' genesis," Mr. Goodman says. " 'According to Joel and Ethan, the film sprang from a mental picture they had of me and John Turturro sitting on the edge of a bed in our underwear."
The Coens based Lebowski's combustible Sobchak on a softball player they knew in Los Angeles. "We made the film out of a perverse desire to see John on screen blowing hard and pontificating," says Joel Coen.
"In a Norman Schwarzkopf haircut," says Ethan Coen.
"And a Ulysses beard."
"And yellow glasses."
"It's a powerful image."
The afternoon sun has begun to cut lengthening shadows across the theater district as Mr. Goodman spies the facade of the Eugene O'Neill. Thirteen years ago he made a showy splash here as Huck Finn's father, Pap, in the musical "Big River." "I used to shoot squirt guns out of a second-floor window," he says. "Just plain New York tap water. I didn't have the courtesy to use bottled water."
Good notices landed Mr. Goodman in a 1987 production of "Antony and Cleopatra" in Los Angeles, where he was spotted by an ABC talent scout. The network needed a mate for Roseanne. "Somebody furshlugginer," Mr. Goodman says. "And that somebody was me."
The rest is current events.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2085 words

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
Two Reminders of What Theater Is All About

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

 BODY:
TWO PLAYS, three playwrights, a total of seven actors -- and the New York theater seems suddenly bursting with possibilities.
That's all it takes when the productions are of the order of these two works that have come to us by way of London: "The Beauty Queen of Leenane," Martin McDonagh's dark, cheeky, highly theatrical Irish comedy directed by Garry Hynes, and "Art," the ineffably funny, sometimes riotous, very French meditation on male friendship (and other matters), written by the French playwright Yasmina Reza, translated by the British playwright Christopher Hampton and directed by Matthew Warchus. 
 "The Beauty Queen of Leenane," its original four-actor Irish cast intact, is playing a nine-week run Off Broadway, through April 19, at the Atlantic Theater, while "Art," starring Alan Alda, Victor Garber and Alfred Molina, has settled down on Broadway at the Royale. What? You haven't seen a straight play in months? It's time to rethink your priorities.
Though it was only a coincidence that "The Beauty Queen of Leenane" and "Art" opened just four days apart, they provide the sort of one-two punch of accumulating excitement that no amount of prefabricated hype can manufacture. The plays themselves have nothing in common except their display of talent and the heritage of a discipline whose pleasures can only be simulated by films and television.
This is living theater: actors acting in the moment you behold them, creating a relationship in which the members of each particular audience are as integral to a performance as what is happening on the stage. A performance is a spooky, ephemeral thing. Without you, it doesn't exist. When it's over, it's gone. It's never to be repeated in quite the same way again, unlike movies and live-on-tape television that, being frozen in time, are essentially inert.
As the actors are alive in the theater, so is the audience, which makes possible a complicity between the two that gives a special edge to both of these new productions.
There is a moment toward the end of "Art" when a character is given a felt-tip pen and dared to deface a white-on-white painting the audience doesn't much admire, though it is aware that the price was 200,000 francs, or about $40,000. The character pauses only a second. Yet it is enough time for the entire audience to suck in its breath in horror at this possible desecration, then to erupt in glorious belly laughs that signal utter surprise. The surprise is prompted less by what the character does than by the audience's sudden awareness of how completely and joyously it has become implicated in the events on the stage.
When you watch movies you are so wrapped in the dark that you can be persuaded to believe almost any nonsense. It's part of the fun of movies. The darkness absorbs the smells of hot dogs and popcorn and the noises of giant economy-size candy wrappers being ripped apart like packing cases. The darkness isolates the mind and melts the senses. I've wept more tears at junk movies than I ever have at funerals.
Live theater is something very different. There is all that light coming from the stage. You are never unaware of surrounding members of the audience, or of the fact that you are observing actors impersonate other people. The result is that you develop bifocal vision, which allows you to appreciate both the fiction taking place on the stage and the skills of the people making it possible. When you are swept away, you can be sure it is because of a nearly miraculous conjunction of what are -- to us -- arcane forces.
The downside: when the material is second rate and the actors unconvincing, you can't be wheedled into entering that other world. You are too obviously sitting in a theater, behind somebody with a head tic, watching the scenery shake when a door is slammed by an actor whose shoelace is untied. On the stage, every imperfection announces itself.
The pleasures of live theater are many and complex, but so rarely realized that when they are experienced they have a way of prompting you to try to redefine theater. What makes theater different? And, when it works, so fulfilling? The answer is never the same for any two plays.
 
'Art'
 "Art" could not easily exist in any other form, which is not to say that one day it won't be competently adapted as a film or television piece. It has only the slimmest of narratives, being a consideration of friendship, its rewards, liabilities, frustrations and mortality.
Specifically, it is about three middle-aged, middle-class, heterosexual Parisians: Marc (Mr. Alda), an aeronautical engineer who prides himself on his skeptical turn of mind; Serge (Mr. Garber), a successful dermatologist, happily divorced, who is beginning to enjoy the money he is making, and Yvan (Mr. Molina), who, for 15 years, has played comic relief for his far more self-assured friends.
At the start of the play he has just begun a new career in the wholesale stationery business and is, at long last, about to marry. Or, as he puts it, "I've given in to the logic of events, marriage, children, death. Stationery." His pals couldn't care less about his marriage, as long as he continues to attend to them. He has always been a perfect audience.
This long-time friendship begins to unravel when Serge proudly reveals a new aspiration: his desire to become a collector. He unveils the painting he has bought, "an Antrios," and not just any Antrios but "a 70's Antrios," from the painter's first white-on-white period. Marc is appalled. He thinks the painting is a joke and his friend has betrayed him by adopting the attitudes, manners and even the vocabulary of those who live their lives according to fashion. Serge calls Marc an enemy of modernism, "a nostalgia merchant" who refuses to be a man of his own time.
YVAN LOOKS at the painting and squints. He searches for a word to describe it. "Magnetic," Serge says helpfully, and he agrees. If Yvan is more conciliatory, it is largely because he is preoccupied with his new job in stationery and with furious family squabbles, which he recounts in priceless detail, about whether the names of both his mother and stepmother should go on the wedding invitations.
As the play proceeds, it becomes increasingly clear that the concern of "Art" is the shifting power positions of the three men vis-a-vis one another. Each man makes demands that change the rules by which their friendship flourished and endured. Friendships are as fragile as alliances between great nations. They can't easily survive the kind of brutal, broadside, very frank assaults each of these fellows launches when feeling cornered by the other two. Each is ready to go to war to protect his only natural resource: his own carefully guarded sense of self.
Though Mr. Alda, Mr. Garber and Mr. Molina make no attempt to play "French," the manner in which this friendship is conducted remains steadfastly French. It is a tribute to these splendid actors, to Mr. Warchus's direction, and to Mr. Hampton's brilliantly witty adaptation that the New York audience so readily accepts this hybrid social vision.
Friendships have different limits, different modes of expression in different countries. The kind of friendship depicted in "Art" reflects a society in which men feel -- rightly or wrongly -- far more at ease with women than men do in either this country or England. An American wife might encourage her husband to go to the local pub to watch a baseball game with his pals. Yet she would probably be suspicious if instead he said he was going to have dinner with them at a new, in restaurant and then catch a movie.
The machismo of these fellows is expressed not in cartoon attitudes and pursuits that pass for manly, but in arrogantly self-satisfied talk of sometimes overweening intellectual pretensions, which, they would think, they can't get at home. With any luck, they're right.
Did I say that "Art," which runs 90 minutes and is played without an intermission, is not only the shortest new play on Broadway, but also the funniest? It moves like the wind and leaves you exhilarated. It's theater, pure and elegant.
 
'The Beauty Queen Of Leenane'
Martin McDonagh is 27 years old and already a man of the Irish theater, but with a difference. Though he has a gift for language, he demonstrates in "The Beauty Queen of Leenane" that he is not especially interested in language as a poetic end in itself. Rather, he uses it to spin stories that make you laugh out loud as they curl your hair.
The landscape of the play is familiar: a small town (Leenane) in Connemara, County Galway, the kind of community that people are forever leaving in hopes of finding better lives elsewhere. Red-haired, 40-ish Maureen Folan (Marie Mullen) tells herself she would leave in a minute if she didn't have to take care of Mag (Anna Manahan), her whiny, mean-spirited, pinched-mouth old mum. Mag may or may not be as senile and helpless as she behaves. She apparently does have "a you-rine" problem. This gives her license to empty her chamber pot in a sink filled with dishes Maureen hasn't yet washed.
Mag is the cross that Maureen bears with a mixture of fury and fortitude until the appearance of Pato Dooley (Brian F. O'Byrne). He is a handsome, soft-spoken native of Leenane, who briefly returns home from England, where he is a construction worker. Maureen brings him home, spends the night with him, then in the morning walks dreamily around in her slip, flaunting the embarrassed fellow in front of her angry, frightened mum. From that morning on, Maureen imagines a future in which Pato will save her from Mag and Leenane.
More about the narrative cannot be told, if only because "The Beauty Queen of Leenane" depends so heavily on plot, on key information withheld from the audience and preparing for (not always gracefully) what will take place later. Mr. McDonagh's strong suit is creating characters so vivid, unsentimental and heartbreaking that they seem undercut by his melodramatic devices, which, of course, are also part of the play's sardonically comic vision.
The New York presentation by the Atlantic Theater Company, a joint production of the Druid Theater Company of Galway, Ireland, and the Royal Court Theater of London, is flawless as staged by Garry Hynes, the Druid's co-founder and present artistic director.
The fourth member of the extraordinary ensemble cast is Tom Murphy, who plays Ray, Pato's younger brother. Ray's unreliability as a go-between is as important to the events of the play as his dimwitted impertinence is to Mr. McDonagh's scathing view of rural Ireland. As you imagine it beyond Mag and Maureen's cottage, it is a barren, rain-soaked field just this side of a graveyard.
More about Mr. McDonagh later this month when another of his plays, "The Cripple of Inishmaan," begins performances at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.
 
'The Maiden's Prayer'
 "The Maiden's Prayer," Nicky Silver's new comedy at the Vineyard Theater, is less relentlessly wisecracking than his "Food Chain." Yet it is still enjoyably nutty as it examines the lives of Mr. Silver's dysfunctional Manhattanites: Paul, who loves Taylor, who loves his wife, Cynthia, whose sister, Libby, also loves Taylor but drifts contentedly into the life of a high-class prostitute. Don't try to remember these details. They make sense as you watch the play.
The Vineyard production, directed by Evan Yionoulis, is a good one, providing rich material for Patricia Clarkson, who plays Libby with pleased relish, and more difficult material for Joanna Going, who plays the equally neurotic Cynthia. There is a serious problem with the script, however. The center of the play is not the relationship between the sober-sided, promiscuously gay Paul (Geoffrey Nauffts) and the uncertainly straight Taylor (Christopher C. Fuller), but the love-hate relationship between Libby and Cynthia, who have been shortchanged by Mr. Silver.
The final irony (to borrow Oscar Jaffe's phrase from "Twentieth Century") is that the play's funniest performance is given by none of the above but by Daniel Jenkins, whose roles seem to be almost an afterthought. He appears as the various men Paul picks up, most memorably as Andrew, who searches not for Mr. Right but for the Right Apartment. It must have cable television, preferably with the premium channels. Andrew is the only one who stands a chance of realizing his dream.
The playwright's subversive message: think cable.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 16; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 804 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Showcasing 7 Photographers From Heyday of Life Magazine

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

DATELINE: KATONAH

 BODY:
IT is tempting to say that the photographs now at the Candace Perich Gallery here make up a motley exhibition. Though the work is all black and white, the content varies widely. But because the pictures were all published in Life magazine in its heyday, from the 1930's through the early 1960's, they make a dynamic fraternity.
Carl Mydans is a Larchmont resident and one of two photographers in this group of seven who are still living. His contributions recall how seriously Life saw its responsibility to chronicle World War II. In his photograph of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's amphibious landing at Luzon in the Philippines in January 1945, the soldiers and their leader stride confidently. The viewer can imagine Mydans before the landing waiting for General MacArthur to turn his head just so, in order that justice could be done to the exaggerated length of his famous pipe. 
 But Mydans has photographs that show a different mood. Vladimir Nabokov, photographed in 1958 leaning out of a car window, has a pencil prominent in his hand. It is noteworthy in the exhibition as a whole how often cigarettes appear as vital props, so Nabokov's pencil becomes a poignant variant. The portrait was made in Ithaca in 1958 when the writer was teaching at Cornell and is an embodiment of that civilization which wars are fought to preserve.
"Reindeer Running" from 1940 reveals the shadow of a man with a pipe as if he is leisurely contemplating the spectacle in the snow before him. But the reindeer are being herded into Finland during the Russian-Finnish War. An unbelievable swarm of bodies and antlers blurred by the camera blends into a fearsome force of nature.
George Silk, who lives in Westport, is represented by sports photographs, and he seems to be fascinated with the human form in motion, the way that experimenters like Edweard Muybridge and Harold Edgerton were. The exertions of a hammer thrower and trackmen in forceful stride at the 1960 Olympic tryouts in Palo Alto, Calif., seem to be taking place against a background of resolutely parallel lines. This patterning is a sign that the photographer is panning the spectacle with his camera.
A photograph of a diver at Princeton University in 1962 is in a similar dynamically abstract vein. It shows his body making a pronounced shape, something like an inverted iceberg, when it hits the water.
Margaret Bourke-White has almost become a legend, abetted by her intrepid personality. The wonder that Manhattan was in the Art Deco era is caught in a 1939 picture of a DC-4 flying like a gliding silver bird over the city and its grid of tall, thrusting buildings. Bourke-White would have to have been taking pictures from another plane flying above the one in the photograph. The romance ubiquitous in modern life is the major theme represented in her work here, especially sleek abstract close-ups of then wondrous industrial products like a coiled metal rod ready for drawing into wire. Bourke-White covered personalities, too, and is represented by a 1945 portrait of one larger than life, Gen. George Patton.
Bourke-White's flying above her subject is a neat trick, which resulted in an amazing picture, but it is not derring-do. That is left to Alfred Eisenstaedt, who stood on top of the Graf Zeppelin in 1934 to take a photograph of the airship under repair as it crossed the Atlantic; a large hole in its hull is emphatically visible.
Capturing the essential Marilyn Monroe in 1953 must have posed no less a challenge, but Eisenstaedt's portrait is a definitive classic. No embellishments are in evidence, and the picture reveals that Monroe, wearing a simple black sweater, came by her sultriness naturally. The allure of a recumbent Katharine Hepburn is emphasized in a 1938 photograph by her white dress, the pleated skirt clinging to her body and then fanning out in a grand sweep.
Two strong contrasting pictures of America are provided by Andreas Feininger in photographs of the Brooklyn Bridge at night from 1948 and a small Arizona town on Route 66 from 1953. Feininger framed the high sky above the highway with tiers of clouds, which seem to be feats of construction on a par with any New York building.
If Feininger presents the framework for America, Nina Leen populates it with a fetching candid photograph of teen-agers in Tulsa, Okla., dancing at a party in 1947. Leen's 1952 photograph of a home economics class at Cornell speaks volumes about automation; the students are touching, almost hugging, labor-saving appliances, but no one is doing anything with her hands.
Peter Stackpole photographed Hollywood but is represented by only one picture, Errol Flynn, still pirate-like, shinnying up the mast of his own yacht in 1941.
"Life Photographers" is at the Candace Perich Gallery in Katonah through April 1.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Trackmen for the United States taking a hurdle at the Olympic tryouts in Palo Alto, Calif., in 1960 by George Silk, left. Gen. Douglas MacArthur just before going ashore at Lingayen Gulf in Luzon in the Philippines in 1945 by Carl Mydans, bottom left. The Graf Zeppelin with its hull under repair as it crossed the Atlantic in 1934 by Alfred Eisenstaedt. The photographs -- the works are all black and white -- are part of the exhibition "Life Photographers" at the Candace Perich Gallery in Katonah. (Alfred Eisenstaedt, Life Magazine  Time Inc.; Carl Mydans, Life Magazine  Time Inc.; George Silk, Life Magazine  Time Inc.)

LENGTH: 1448 words

HEADLINE: Overall, Reading Scores Increase

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
DURING the first parent-teachers meeting at Public School 8 in Yonkers more than a century ago, the pressing issue was why the stagecoach transporting children to school was running late. In 1997, the buses were running on time but irate parents were still demanding answers -- because reading scores on the state's report cards a year ago were low.
This year parents at the DiChiaro Early Childhood School are singing educators' praises. Scores for third-grade reading almost doubled last year, with 48 percent of the students reading at grade level compared with 25 percent in 1996. 
 "It's still not what it should be," Principal Diane Harkin said, "but change takes place one day at a time." The percentage of students reading at mastery level -- or performing with distinction, as the state calls it -- increased almost fivefold at DiChiaro, also known as School 8, to 46 percent from 10 percent in 1996.
Reading scores also rose dramatically at Pocantico Hills Central School. There, 93 percent of the third-grade students were reading at grade level in 1997 compared with 52 percent in 1996.
Recalling the outrage a year ago when parents learned about the poor performance of their third graders, Peter M. Lisi, Principal of Pocantico Hills School and Superintendent of the district, said, "To get a report card that bad was shocking." Only 31 percent of the students were reading at a mastery level, a figure that rose the following year to 83 percent. He said hundreds of worried parents attended a meeting in the school cafeteria after the release of the 1996 figures to learn what could be done.
At DiChiaro, Ms. Harkin reported a similar scenario. "We were all really upset," she said, "but in a way it was good because it prompted us to focus on our needs."
At the Yonkers school, where almost 60 percent of the students qualify for free lunch, decorated paper plates festoon the hallways, attesting to the growing number of books read by students. It is part of the DEAR program, an acronym for Drop Everything and Read. The administration also sponsors TV turnoff nights (read instead!) and workshops for parents on sharing books with children.
At Pocantico Hills a similar enrichment program is known as BEAR, an acronym for Be Excited About Reading. There chubby paw prints line the hallways, recording books read by students.
In both suburban and inner-city schools, parents and educators are analyzing the results of the state's ratings. Efforts to improve scores have included revising curriculum, hiring new teachers and redeploying others.
The state's Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, said the report cards are part of an effort to raise the academic performance of students.
For most schools, the scores served as a wake-up call that many students were performing below expected levels. "The question many of us had to ask ourselves is, 'Where did we fall down?' " said the Superintendent of the Yonkers schools, Reginald F. Marra, who displays the motto, "Results, not excuses!" on his desk.
At the Carrie E. Tompkins School in the Croton-Harmon Union Free School District, Principal Lauren Allan said teachers blocked out two hours a day for reading. "We took a long, hard look at our curriculum and our priorities," she said.
The percentage of third-grade students enrolled at the Tompkins School who were reading at grade level rose to 89 last year, compared with 71 percent in 1996. The numbers for students reading at mastery level were even more dramatic: 63 percent in 1997, compared with 38 percent in 1996. The school, which serves students in kindergarten through fifth grade, was one of the highest performing in the county.
Other high performers were Meadow Pond Elementary School in the Katonah-Lewisboro School District, the Museum School in Yonkers, the Quaker Ridge and Heathcote Schools in Scarsdale, the Westochard, Roaring Brook and Douglas G. Grafflin Schools in Chappaqua, the Lincoln Titus Elementary School in the Lakeland Central School District, the Chatsworth Avenue and Central Schools in Mamaroneck, the Alice E. Grady School in Elmsford, the King Street and John F. Kennedy Schools in the Port Chester-Rye District, the Anne Hutchinson School in Eastchester, the Prospect Hill, Hutchinson and Colonial Schools in Pelham, Bronxville Elementary and the Mamaroneck Avenue School in White Plains.
Dr. Karen McCarthy, Superintendent of the Katonah-Lewisboro schools, attributed the success at Meadow Pond Elementary to a comprehensive, multifaceted approach to reading. "We refused to get sucked into the controversy of phonics versus the whole-language approach," she said. "We teach whatever works." She also observed that students in well-to-do school districts like Katonah-Lewisboro "come from homes where parents value education, and children come to school with the attitude, 'Teach me.' "
In Scarsdale, Dr. Richard W. Sprague, the Assistant Superintendent for Instruction, agreed that "very able students, well-educated families and a strong teaching staff formed a powerful combination."
At the Colonial School in Pelham, Principal Gerard P. Finelli reported that faculty meetings were spent discussing teaching rather than administrative functions. "Anything that could be taken care of by memo was," he said. "That left us free to talk about strategies and ideas."
Overall, reading scores have gone up, in part because schools last year were not required to test students with limited English. Teachers reported that many foreign-born students sat and stared at the reading test in 1996, unable to understand it. In many cases, the higher scores also reflect increased preparation for the tests. Peggy Sbarra, a third-grade teacher at the DiChiaro school, said she and other teachers familiarized students with the format of the tests the second time around.
Among schools showing the largest gains, parent involvement was also cited as a factor in students' reading success. "The report cards put the entire community on notice," Mr. Lisi in Pocantico Hills said.
Administrators at schools reporting the biggest declines, like the Pennington-Grimes School in Mount Vernon, said they were still studying the results. Pennington-Grimes, in the heart of the ethnically diverse city, was a high scorer for reading on the state report cards last year. More than 4,000 others throughout New York were tested in the program aimed at making all schools accountable to the public.
But this year, results showed that 69 percent of third graders at the elementary school were reading at grade level in 1997, compared with 79 percent the year before, and only 48 percent were reading at mastery level, down from 62 percent in 1996. Petronella Feaster, director of funded programs for Mount Vernon, said a more detailed analysis of the scores would be necessary before educators could comment.
Other low-preforming schools were the Longfellow and Holmes Schools in Mount Vernon, Foxfire, Pulaski Early Childhood School, the Fermi School for the Performing Arts, Martin Luther King Jr. School 9, School 22, School 30 and School 31 in Yonkers; Bedford Hills Elementary, Buchanan-Verplanck in the Hendrick Hudson Central School District, Columbus Avenue School in Valhalla, Mamaroneck Avenue School, Greenvale School in Eastchester, Daniel Webster School in New Rochelle and Van Cortlandtville School in the Lakeland School District.
Educators in both high and low performing schools were critical of aspects of the tests. "The statistical samples were too small," said Dr. Vincent T. Beni, Superintendent of the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, "and the results exaggerated small differences."
He also said the second year's data measured different students and failed to take into account gains made or lost by the same class. Moreover, data should be analyzed over time -- not just a two-year period -- to yield significant results, he contended. "What you have here is something that starts conversations," he said.
Dr. Sherry P. King, Superintendent of the Mamaroneck Union Free School District, challenged the manner in which the state determined poverty levels. Those determinations are used to compare the performance of schools teaching students of similar economic backgrounds, and in most cases, they are based on the number of students qualifying for free lunches. But students in Mamaroneck take their own lunches to school, Dr. King said.
Dr. McCarthy of the Katonah-Lewisboro schools, said the greatest fallacy of the report cards was that they focused on the results of "a single test administered in a single day to a limited group of children."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Louise Kunin, a reading specialist, working with first graders at the Patricia A. DiChiaro Early Childhood School in Yonkers, where a coordinated curriculum to prepare students for later achievement tests has been adopted. (Richard Harbus for The New York Times)
 
Table: "Report Card: How the County's 3d Graders Are Reading"
 The New York State Report Cards allow parents, teachers and administrators to compare schools across the state.
 Student-teacher ratio -- The average number of students enrolled for each teacher at the school, calculated by The New York Times from state report card data.
 Income -- The percentage of students above the Federal income guidelines for free school lunch. Where missing, similar income figures were substituted from the 1990 census.
 Reading at grade level -- Percentage of third graders reading at or above level of typical students in tests given in spring 1997. Plus sign indicates school score increased at least five points from previous year, after adjusting scores to account for differences in the way the test was administered. A minus sign indicates a decline of at least five points.
 Advanced reading -- The percentage of students who read far above the average student, defined aswith distinction by the state.
 Reading performance -- A measure calculated by The New York Times using boxes, which compare schools with similar schools, after taking into account student family income and English-speaking ability as reported by the state. The boxes appear on a scale of 1 to 5 with one-fifth of students who took the test in each category. A score of 5 boxes is the highest and 1 the lowest. Because the scores of many schools cluster around the average, a score of 2 or 4 should be viewed as slightly above, or slightly below average.
 Notes: Only schools with third grades are shown; student totals for each district include only those schools. All data are from the 1996-97 school year. Blank space means no data were available.
 
About the 'Reading Performance' Ratings
 The performance scale uses standard statistical techniques to adjust for the differences that students take to school. It asks the question: How does a school compare with other schools that have similar students? Is a school making a difference in the lives of students?
 Educators have long known that children of affluent and well-educated parents tend to do better than other students, even when they attend seemingly mediocre schools. And they know that other schools that make a dramatic difference in lives of many disadvantaged students will often have lower average test scores than those serving the most affluent.
 To deal with this difference, The Times computed a new benchmark score for each school or group of schools, based on the backgrounds of students, showing the typical score expected of a school with similar students. Schools were then compared with these similar-school benchmarks and ranked by the distance above or below these benchmarks they scored.
 The elementary school analysis was based on third-grade reading scores showing the percentage of students at or above the typical reading level in the third grade. To account for student differences, The Times used the percentage of students above the eligibility limits for free school lunch and the percentage of children classified as having limited English proficiency.
 The analysis found that student background was a strong predictor of school success. About 75 percent of the difference in reading scores from school to school was attributed to differences in student backgrounds alone.
 After schools were compared with their benchmarks, they were ranked from 1 to 5, with schools serving a fifth of students in the state assigned to each category. The top performers were assigned a 5, the bottom to a 1. Many schools, including some ranked 2 or 4, were clustered close to their benchmarks. So a 3 should be seen as average, a 2 or 4 as slightly below or above average, and a 1 or 5 as much below or much above average.
 The performance scale is only one of many ways of looking at a school. It is best used as a starting point for discussion. No single statistical analysis or no one test score can tell the entire story of any school, and schools with fewer than 20 students tested were omitted from the analysis, because the performance of one or two students could sharply alter their results.
 After the first Times analysis of state test scores appeared last year, some school officials objected to it. Some said that school free lunch numbers were incomplete or inaccurate in their schools or did not accurately capture the problems faced by their schools. Others said in some cases a few wrong answers by a handful of students could cause a school to drop from one category to another. Still others said that the state reading test was not designed to compare achievement among schools and that reading scores should therefore not be compared at all.
 But many parents and administrators said that at many schools the reporting of test scores led to new conversations between parents and administrators, self-examinations and changes. Some said it put more focus on reading achievement and learning; others said it led to more time wasted in drill and rote preparation for this year's test. JOSH BARBANEL

HEADLINE: The Coast Guard Gathers Its Forces in New London

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
AFTER the Coast Guard opens its Leadership Development Center in New London later this year, every officer and senior enlisted person in the service will have to go through Connecticut at some point.
Since early in the century, New London has been home to the Coast Guard Academy, which provides about half the officers the Coast Guard needs every year. But the opening of the center on May 12 will bring together the Coast Guard officer candidate school, formerly in Yorktown, Va.; its warrant officer training course, from Pensacola, Fla., and its chief petty officeracademy, from Petaluma, Calif. "This will be a place that will serve more of the Coast Guard, more of the time, in more ways than ever before," said Rear Adm. Douglas H. Teeson, the superintendent of the academy. 
 Construction crews have been busy on a $12 million renovation of Chase, Roland and Yeaton halls, totaling almost 100,000 square feet of space at the south end of the campus. That is more construction than the academy has seen in a quarter-century, and more renovations are planned for two other buildings, Munro and Satterlee halls.
The buildings where the center will be housed are among the earliest put up when the 122-year-old academy relocated to New London in the early 1930's, and many consider it appropriate that as the mission gets redefined the Coast Guard is putting emphasis on its roots.
"The Leadership Development Center represents probably the greatest change that's ever taken place at the academy," said Capt. Jim Smith, deputy superintendent at the academy. "There are people who can spend a career in the Coast Guard now and never see the academy, but that's going to change. Everyone will rotate through the academy at key points in their career now."
Admiral Teeson said during a trial run of the warrant officers' course late last year that he saw first-hand the kind of valuable interchange that results from bringing all training together: the warrant officers, all of them in their 30's, mingled at the mess hall and in the student lounges with academy students, answering questions about life at sea and at various shore commands.
"They bring hundreds of years of experience to the Coast Guard Academy, from today's Coast Guard," Admiral Teeson said. "And I think, from the warrant officers' perspective, that they have a new respect for what the cadets are going through as they work towards their commissions and their degree."
Capt. Thomas E. Bernard, the director of the center, said bringing the leadership schools to the academy will allow for a broader experience than the students are getting now.
Officer candidates can be brought in to use the ship simulator at the academy, which is useful to show them how important it is to function as a team at sea -- better they crash a computer than a ship. Yorktown has never had such specialized equipment.
The academy also has specialty faculty and having all the courses in one location will make possible, for the first time, an external assessment team that will review the courses and recommend improvements. Operating the courses at separate locations would have made that too expensive.
"Now, all the leaders in the Coast Guard will have a personal connection to the academy," Captain Bernard said. "They'll get a better sense that the academy belongs to everybody in the Coast Guard, and that's a sense we want to strengthen."
The academy is going to have to adjust to some changes, though. For instance, as a university it has been used to having 300 students arrive every summer for a four-year tour; now, there will be classes coming in or going out almost every week.
The center will also mean an average of 120 more students on campus at any one time, as well as 80 additional staff -- which should be good for the local economy, officials say.
"The new students coming in will be older, more mature, with service experience and with families -- and with more money," Captain Smith said. "They'll go out to eat, they'll rent cars. From a community point of view, this is a very positive development."
New London City Manager Richard M. Brown agreed. "You're talking about a more permanent investment in the Coast Guard community here," Mr. Brown said, "which will protect us from future reductions, if there is another round of base closures."
And, he said, the Coast Guard is helping to make New London more widely known, just as the Naval Academy put Annapolis on the map. The city has already decided to paint on its welcome signs, "Home of the Coast Guard Academy and Barque Eagle."
"The Coast Guard is giving us another tool to help spur development," Mr. Brown said. "There's a real multiplier effect -- these people will go home and tell their friends and families about what's here, and they'll come and see it themselves,"
He also pointed out that the Coast Guard operates a small boat station in New London, and its Research and Development Center is just across the Thames River, at Avery Point in Groton.
"Southeastern Connecticut is now, in my mind, a center of excellence for all Coast Guard activity," Mr. Brown said.
The Coast Guard began a study of its training and education capabilities in 1994, led by Admiral Teeson before he was named the academy's superintendent.
"The academy was expanded in the 1970's when it looked like we were going to get some of the oceanographic work that ultimately went to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration," Admiral Teeson said.
"Basically, all we're doing is filling that extra capacity. We're using the facility now at about 50 or 60 percent, and that will go up to 70 or 80 percent, which is optimum. That leaves us enough open time to do maintenance and repairs."
Cmdr. J. Scott Burhoe, the center's implementation team leader, said groups from all the centers have been meeting regularly, to discuss the final items needed in the classrooms, the budgets and so forth.
"We're trying to figure out what the highest-priority needs are so we can fill them first," he said. "At this point, all the pieces to the puzzle are out there, we just have to make sure it fits together properly by May."
Although the official opening of the center is not until this spring, one warrant officer course went through in October and November as a sort of trial run. The 24 students spent a part of each day in a critique session. They also designed a logo for the course, started a scrapbook and built a website for the chief warrant officer indoctrination course.
"It was a matter of fine-tuning the course," said Senior Chief Petty Officer Leo Deon, one of those who attended. "We paved the road for future classes."
Commander Burhoe said there were some significant lessons learned. "We ended up using more faculty from the military college than we originally expected to use, so the issue has come, will the academy be able to support those personnel needs as we move forward," he said.
Admiral Teeson said he is working with others to make sure there are no logistical problems when the center begins operations. On paper, there is enough parking and room for everyone to use the athletic fields, he noted, "but in reality, it's going to be tough for the scheduler to fit it all in."
Captain Bernard said the hope is that consolidating all the training in a single location will give the Coast Guard a certain management consistency.
"If we're teaching our chiefs effective communication, we want to make sure it's the same principles that are being taught to our cadets," Captain Bernard said. "Otherwise, they may be out there with enough of a subtle difference in their approaches that it could cause conflict, or at least confusion."
"But that's also going to be one of our most interesting management challenges, internally," Captain Bernard said. "We want to keep the core culture of each of the courses, because the source of pride they feel comes from that. And if we have the same staff serving all of the courses, that could be difficult to maintain."
Admiral Teeson said there is also the danger that by having all the training in one place, if any single element of the training program is weak, it will affect a much broader population.
"I see a lot more opportunity than I see risk, though," said Admiral Teeson. The cadets go on sailing duty every summer, and the warrant officers and chief petty officers will be coming in for training, then returning as instructors, so there will be enough feedback from the fleet to determine very quickly if any area needs attention.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Are Big Retailers Waking Up to a Chelsea Morning?

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
WHEN art galleries started moving from SoHo to Chelsea a few years ago the owners said they were driven by two factors: the influx of retailers in their old neighborhood who could pay higher rents and the availability of old industrial buildings and garages that could easily be converted into galleries.
They said they hoped the new location west of 10th Avenue would prove less attractive to major retailers so that property values and rents would remain stable. 
 But is history beginning to repeat itself? There are some indications it is, although it is not clear whether a trend has begun in Chelsea, which traditionally has been defined as the neighborhood between 14th and 23d Streets and Seventh and 11th Avenues.
Banana Republic has agreed to occupy 5,000 square feet on the ground floor of the old Port Authority building at 111 Eighth Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets with a men's store, putting a national chain in a neighborhood that has held mostly small, locally owned businesses. The high-priced French clothing store Comme des Garcons, is venturing even farther west with a 5,000-square-foot store at 550 west 22d Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues, on a block that includes the Dia Center for the Arts and a number of galleries, including Max Protech.
And other retailers are also said to be looking at the area.
"I have gotten a call from a European retailer who is interested in the area," said Ruth Barone, a senior vice president of The Carlton Group who has been active with gallery owners. "They want to open in Chelsea and bypass SoHo completely."
Ms. Barone said that restaurants were also moving to the area. "It was unexpected that retail would follow so quickly," she said.
Indeed, the owner of one gallery in the area said she was appalled at what she described as the money-fueled rush to development. "I was quite horrified the other day when I got a call from a real estate company pushing a 15-story hotel up the street," said Barbara Gladstone, whose gallery is on 24th Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues. "There are a lot of investors out there who see opportunity but do not understand the fragility of the ecology here."
Faith H. Consolo, a senior managing director at Garrick-Aug Associates, which specializes in retail real estate, noted that the blocks around Eighth Avenue and 17th Street already supported two symbols of young affluence, an American Fitness exercise center and a Starbucks coffee shop.
New restaurants, such as Intermezzo, the Thai Restaurant and Lisello, have also opened along Eighth Avenue recently, she said. And a thrift store between 21st and 22d Streets has been replaced by World Clothing, which sells new apparel, while a candy store near 21st Street has been supplanted by Chelsea Gourmet Foods.
"A lot has to do with affordability," Ms. Consolo said. "Rents in Chelsea average $75 a square foot, while in SoHo the average is more like $150 a foot and you see some deals over $200 a foot."
AS a result, she said, the area may undergo a change, with national companies replacing locally owned businesses, as has happened in other neighborhoods in Manhattan. "This area could go the way of Columbus Avenue or the Flatiron District," she said.
Jonathan D. Switzer, a senior managing director of the Winokur Realty Company, agreed that Eighth Avenue in Chelsea was looking more attractive to retailers put off by the high prices and lack of suitable locations in SoHo, where he leases office space. But he said that Chelsea had a way to go before it became a true rival for SoHo.
"Eighth Avenue in Chelsea is getting stronger," he said. "In fact it is coming up the way SoHo did, following SoHo." He said the restaurants along the avenue were beginning to draw the street traffic that is attractive to retailers.
But west of Eighth Avenue and its subway line, he said, transportation becomes more of a problem, particularly in comparison to SoHo, which is almost completely ringed with underground trains.
"Comme des Garcons is a well run company, and you have to presume that they have done their homework," he said. "But it is not easy to get there by public transportation," he said, referring to subway lines. "You have to walk through several blocks of less developed areas to get there."
Nevertheless, the presence of the Chelsea Piers a block west, with their skating rinks, golf driving range, gymnastics center and other attractions that draw 3.1 million visitors a year may help bring people to a neighborhood that recently was a jumble of rundown industrial buildings, real estate executives say.
Jed Garfield, a vice president of Leslie J. Garfield & Company who has been involved with galleries in Chelsea, noted that a new restaurant, Lot 61, had opened on 21st Street between 10th and 11th Avenues. But he added that "it is a little early" to say that the area will become a retail destination.
In fact, he said, the dominant form of activity in the near future will probably be similar to that of the recent past. That is the conversion of old industrial properties, such as garages and warehouses, to art galleries and architects' offices.
Some retail real estate specialists say it is going to be difficult to bring national retailers to Eighth Avenue, because of what is there already. Much of the avenue between 14th and 24th Streets is occupied by small stores and shops, known in the trade as "little doors."
"You have a lot of very small buildings there," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty Services. "It is a series of 20- and 25-foot storefronts that make assembling larger spaces difficult. And you can't do dynamic retail when you don't have enough space."
HE said he agreed that the complexion of Chelsea had changed in the last 10 years but added that because of the difficulty of putting together properties along Eighth Avenue, retail development, when it comes, may be on the side streets. "Streets like 22d could see the development of SoHo-type retail," he said.
Ms. Consolo acknowledged the pattern of many small stores was a barrier to larger retail development, but said it could be overcome. "A lot of those mom and pop stores have old leases, so you can put a lot of them together to get enough space" when the leases expire, she said. She said national companies in the apparel and housewares fields were negotiating for space in the area, although she declined to name them until the transactions were completed.
She noted that two buildings were combined in SoHo to develop a space suitable for Louis Vuitton at 114 Prince Street.
And the notion of what the Chelsea neighborhood encompasses is expanding with the interest in the area, brokers and other real estate executives say. "The hub is moving northward, with activity on 26th and 27th Streets," Ms. Barone said. "While that is happening, Times Square and Penn Station are spreading south," she added. "At some point they will meet."
Alan Victor, executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation, sees the retail interest in the Chelsea area as an expression of the economic vitality of the city. "Retailers have to start looking at new locations if they want to get into the city or to grow," he said.
Although the low-rise buildings typical in Chelsea mean there is less population density than in the high-rise residential sections of Manhattan, there are still a lot of people in the neighborhood who would benefit from large, modern stores, Mr. Victor added.
Farther west, he said, the traffic generated by the galleries will inevitably draw retailers, because traffic is what they live on. Although it is only one store, he said, the Comme des Garcons decision to pioneer the location between 10th and 11th Avenues is important.
"It says the neighborhood is not a frontier anymore," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Banana Republic is taking 5,000 square feet in the old Port Authority building on Eighth Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets, left. Tazza, which recently followed Twigs at 20th Street, is one of the many restaurants on Eighth Avenue. (Photographs by G. Paul Burnett for The New York Times)
