HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Revitalizing Jersey City's Depressed Journal Square

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A $7.5 MILLION effort now under way to spruce up the Journal Square area of Jersey City is among the latest signs that, after years of decline, the business center of the state's second largest city is slowly rebounding.
While empty stores and office buildings still pockmark the area, their numbers have decreased and rents are beginning to inch up. One landmark 15-story building, at 26 Journal Square, where 30 percent of the 105,000 square feet of space is empty, has just been purchased by developers from Fort Lee who plan to renovate and lease it. 
 And Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus said it would start construction of an up to 550,000-square-foot office building if a tenant signed on for substantial amount of space.
At the same time Rite-Aid has doubled its space on the Square to 13,000 square feet and the Hudson County Community College is expanding in the area with a 32,000-square-foot building under construction at 870 Bergen Avenue. Over the next decade the college plans to increase its presence from 165,000 square feet to 500,000 square feet, said Peter Ciano, executive director of facilities for the college.
The city itself is moving ahead with the restoration of the landmark 1929 Loews Theater at 54 Journal Square, which is to be turned into a film and performing arts center.
The area's changing fortunes did not happen by chance. City officials and property owners decided in 1995 to form a special improvement district, or SID, in which property owners tax themselves to finance physical improvements as well as services, including security and marketing.
The city also contributes funds to the SID at Journal Square, which is a regional transportation hub with a bus center and PATH station; the station will be upgraded at a cost of $9 million beginning early next year.
The SID -- extending for a mile along Kennedy Boulevard from Newark Avenue south to Tonnelle Avenue with side-street branches -- contains 300 properties, with a total of 1,200 stores, office structures, residences and parking garages. It is among the larger of the nearly 40 SIDs created in New Jersey since the state passed a law in 1984 permitting communities to establish such tax-supported districts. "SIDs are a proven mechanism for local business districts to rally around, because they provide an assured financial stream" said Donald Smartt, an industry consultant based in Verona.
Since the Journal Square SID was formed nearly $3 million has been invested into programs aimed primarily at making the area cleaner and safer, said Brian T. Coleman, executive director of the nonprofit Journal Square Restoration Corporation, which manages the SID. Prime among them is a 50-man security and maintenance staff.
A recent study by the Center for Crime Prevention Studies at Rutgers University of the SID's first year of operations found that its programs had been successful in reducing crime and increasing the quality of life for residents and businesses in Journal Square. It said, for instance, that calls to the police concerning crimes against persons dropped an average of 14 percent, while calls on property crimes, such as burglaries, fell 16.5 percent on average.
Elliot Braha, whose family has run Lords, a children's store on the Square for more than 35 years, also sees the improvement. Incidents of shoplifting have dropped, shoppers feel more confident walking the streets and business has improved, said Mr. Braha, who is vice president of the Restoration Corporation.
"Without the SID," he said, "no one would be willing to come here and we would see a lot of boarded-up stores."
Since the SID was formed, the retail and office vacancy rates dropped to 5 percent from 15 percent and to 15 percent from 25 percent, respectively, said Mr. Coleman of the Restoration Corporation. "But for additional development to take place," he said, "Journal Square needs to become more attractive."
THE city's campaign to rejuvenate the Square, to be completed the summer of 1999, covers 10 blocks and includes new lighting fixtures, brick-paved sidewalks and the planting of trees and shrubs. A pedestrian plaza also will be constructed in front of the Port Authority's Journal Square Transportation Center, now used as a taxi queue. Financing is coming from city and Federal funds as well as $1 million from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Journal Square began to decline as the middle-class exodus and poor economy of the 60's and 70's vacuumed commerce from its once vibrant core. It benefited little from the mid-80's building boom when all eyes were on reshaping the city's Hudson River waterfront. Then the recession hit, halting all redevelopment.
But in the last few years, with the economy reviving and the waterfront holding its own amid a second wave of redevelopment, the city shifted its focus to Journal Square.
Getting property owners to agree to a special tax was not easy. But they warmed to the idea when the city agreed to match the money property owners raised, beginning with a 4 to 1 match in the first year and decreasing annually until it phases out in the fifth year
Retailers pay special taxes of $22 a frontage foot a year.Garage and office owners pay 8 to 9 cents a square foot and residential owners pay $31 per residence. Assessments totaled $350,000 this year. Jersey City's contribution raised the budget to $1.8 million, said Mr. Coleman of the Restoration Corporation, noting that as the city's contribution decreased the assessment on property owners would need to rise to meet budgetary needs.
(The city's money comes from the 3 percent sales tax -- instead of the normal 6 percent -- charged by merchants in its Urban Enterprise Zone, which offers tax incentives to businesses and lower sales taxes to customers to increase investment in their borders. The Journal Square SID is within the zone.)
As the Square rebounds it is also redefining itself. Aware of the competition from the city's waterfront for office users, Mr. Coleman said the Square would attract smaller office tenants as well as back-office operations.
That is the intent of Blumberg & Freilich Equities of Fort Lee, which last month bought 26 Journal Square. "Space on the waterfront is tightening and that is being reflected in Journal Square," said Ary H. Freilich, a partner in the company.
Mr. Freilich said the building, which will be renovated over the next year, will offer space to smaller tenants at rents significantly lower than those on the waterfront. He said he expected to draw tenants looking for 1,000 to 5,000 square feet that needed to be close to Manhattan and mass transit links.
"We think there is a demand for such space and that the Square has turned a corner," Mr. Freilich said, noting that without the changes "we probably would not have bought the building."
Emanuel Stern, president of the real estate division at Hartz, said the improvements also convinced his company "to begin aggressively" to market its projected building. The new building would join a 273,000-square-foot building half its size at the site, just off Kennedy Boulevard. It would rise atop an existing parking deck.
Mr. Stern said the Square was benefiting from -- and would be a cost-effective alternative to -- the waterfront, where his company plans to break ground in June on a 417,000-square-foot speculative office building. "I always said a building would not be built on the Square until someone builds on the waterfront and sets the rents," he said.
As for the Square's retail sector, Mr. Coleman of the Restoration Corporation said: "While there will continue to be traditional retailers, the Square, in order to survive, needs to diversify by attracting more national and regional chains and more service oriented stores."
He said he hoped that the current demolition of the State Theater, creating a rare 20,000-square-foot development site, would help to at least partially realize that goal. And he noted that the Loews project would stimulate nighttime activity on the Square.
Work now under way on the old Loews Theater includes upgrading its mechanical systems, refurbishing its 3,000 seats and cleaning its facade, said Colin Egan, the city's project director. He said the theater's 2,000-seat main floor was expected be open by year's end for special events, such as classic film festivals and pop concerts.
"The intent is to revive the experience of the grand old movie palaces and use it," Mr. Egan said, and to make the theater, and by extension the Square, "a destination."

HEADLINE: JERSEYANA;
128 Pages, 200 Photographs and Decades of History

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
Shoppers at Smiley's Country Deli and Gervin's Sport Shop on Main Street in Woodbridge wouldn't know that the spot was once occupied by Blum's Grocery Store, where the proprietor stacked the canned goods in neat pyramids a century ago. Or that the Woodbridge Sons of Veterans' Drum Corps and Firing Squad used to practice out front, dressed in Civil War-era uniforms, in ragtag formation, with fife, drums and bayonets in hand. Unless, of course, they had seen a copy of "Woodbridge," by Robert J. McEwen and Virginia Bergen Troeger.
The book, whose cover features a photograph, circa 1900, of Blum's and the drum corps, is one of 415 titles in the Images of America series published by Arcadia Books, each documenting elements of a single community's history, from the mundane to the occasionally monumental. 
 Like Mr. McEwen and Ms. Troeger, most of the authors recruited by Arcadia are people with close ties to the community and a desire to preserve its past, said Jamie Carter, senior editor for Arcadia's northern office at the company's headquarters in Dover, N.H.
Those ties seem especially strong in New Jersey, where 75 communities have books in the Images series, the most of any state. (Massachusetts is second, with 67. New York has 30, Connecticut 16.)
"What you seem to be seeing is this pride in local history," said Richard Waldron, executive director of the New Jersey Historical Commission. "There's intense sense of place here. It isn't that people disregard the state, but we have a real strong interest in our immediate locality."
Mr. Waldron also said New Jerseyans' pride in their history may be propelled by a shared exasperation with outsiders who insist the state is little more than a stretch of highway between New York and Philadelphia.
Ms. Carter commented on how the state's physical landscape has changed, saying, "I think New Jersey has seen a lot of old buildings come down, and a lot of development," said Ms. Carter. "In other states, particularly New England, preservation is taken for granted. In New Jersey, they have to work extra hard at it."
Some of Arcadia's authors, like John T. Cunningham, whose 36 books include Chatham's entry in the Images of America series, are accomplished writers. Others are first-time authors drafted by Arcadia for their particular expertise, among them Kenneth T. French, the head librarian in the New Jersey Room of the Jersey City Library, who wrote, "Jersey City, 1940-1960, the Dan McNulty Collection."
Mr. French and Ms. Carter met at a New Jersey History Issues Conference at Seton Hall University in South Orange last March. He told her about Mr. McNulty, a funeral director and official city photographer whose streetscapes captured the flavor of Jersey City in the years surrounding World War II. A 1955 aerial photo of the bustling factories, shipyards and rail lines that once occupied what is now the Exchange Place financial district provides newcomers with an instant lesson in the city's economic history. "I wanted to do the McNulty pictures because I've loved them ever since I started working here," said Mr. French, a Jersey City native who now lives in Roselle Park.
Arcadia, which employs 25 people, is well aware how narrow the market is for each of its books, and it relies on producing as many titles as possible for a worthwhile overall sales volume. It is not a vanity press -- a pride press is more like it -- and authors do receive royalties. "I get about $1 a book, which is not a king's ransom," said Mr. French, who just sold out his initial printing of 2,000 copies.
Arcadia also relies on several standard features that help keep costs down in the Images series. The cover design, a sepia-toned print taken from the collection inside, is the same for all the books. And it's no coincidence that "Belmar," "Red Bank, Volume II," "Franklin Township" and every other book is exactly 128 pages.
Arcadia requires that the standard 200 photographs in each book be compiled by the authors, who are also responsible for researching and writing the captions, Ms. Carter said. (Inevitable mistakes, sometimes pointed out by the people who live in the buildings pictured, are corrected in subsequent printings.) Arcadia is sensitive to the historical, personal and sometime monetary value of the photos, she said, and conducts a careful inventory to prevent loss.
As word of the Images of America series has spread, the company no longer has trouble recruiting authors to write works that might seem too parochial to print. "In the beginning, that caused us some skepticism," Ms. Carter said. "People could not believe we wanted to publish a book on their town."

HEADLINE: MILESTONES;
Into Halls of Fame and Second Centuries

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

 BODY:

HALL OF FAMERS, NO. 1 -- It's been more than 50 years since Larry Doby broke the color barrier in the American League, joining the Cleveland Indians on July 5, 1947.
He'll always be No. 2, as far as the history books are concerned, because just 11 weeks earlier, Jackie Robinson had become the first black player in major-league baseball, signing on with the Brooklyn Dodgers in the National League. 
 But Mr. Doby has always been No. 1 with fans in North Jersey, particularly in Paterson, where he grew up. On Feb. 24, Congress gave final approval to legislation that will put Mr. Doby's name on the post office at 194 Ward Street. The bill's sponsor, Representative Bill Pascrell, a former Paterson Mayor, said the honor would be "a small expression of our appreciation in comparison to the trails he blazed."
Another form of recognition came on Tuesday when the 73-year-old former outfielder was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame. On July 26, he is to travel to Cooperstown, N.Y., from his home in Montclair for the formal induction ceremony.
Speaking of Jackie Robinson, he is now standing proud in Journal Square in Jersey City, in the form of a 12-foot-tall bronze statue. The monument, unveiled on Feb. 26, commemorates a day in April 1946 when Robinson came to town with the Montreal Royals, the farm team for the Dodgers, scoring two runs in a victory over the Jersey City Giants.
The 1990's team that made the statue possible includes the Jackie Robinson Foundation, the City of Jersey City, the state Department of Commerce and Economic Development, the New Jersey Sports History Commission and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Speaking of milestones, this is the 25th anniversary of the Jackie Robinson Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded by his wife, Rachel. This year the foundation is supporting the education of 165 J.R. Scholars at colleges across the country.
 
HALL OF FAMERS, NO. 2 -- There's no hall, but there is a Hall of Fame for 10 women chosen as the first members of the state's first "Women's Hall of Fame."
The Newark Commission on the Status of Women chose the honorees, who were recognized last week at a luncheon at the Newark Museum celebrating Women's History Month.
Those inducted -- some dead and some very much alive -- were state Senator Wynona Lipman; Sister Mary Dwyer, a community leader involved with the St. Columba Neighborhood Group; Louise Epperson, an advocate for rights of the elderly; Emily Miles, a fashion designer who has run a charm school for black girls in Newark's South Ward for 30 years; Louise Scott, who opened the state's first black beauty school; Larrie West Stalks, longtime Essex County Registrar; Constance Woodruff, a journalist who was chairwoman of the state Commission on the Status of Women; Queen E. James, a leader in the Essex County Democratic Party; Amelia Stewart, a restaurateur, and Clara Dasher, former president of the Board of Trustees for Essex County College
Until a permanent home is found for the Hall of Fame, a plaque engraved with the names of its members will hang in the Newark Museum.
 
100, AND GOING STRONG
In the beginning, the name was the Society for Work Among the Italians, an organization devoted to teaching English, cooking, sewing and industrial arts to Italian immigrants in Morristown.
Some things have changed. In 1910, the group's leaders decided to affiliate with the National Settlement House Movement. They also adopted a new name: the Morristown Neighborhood House or, more simply, "the Nabe."
Some things haven't changed at all, including the goal of making Morristown a better place to live. The Neighborhood House now offers homework help, sports programs, music appreciation and other programs to more than 500 needy children every day at its 27,000-square-foot building at 12 Flager Street.
The Neighborhood House plans a series of events throughout the year celebrating its centennial. On April 4, the jazz artist Wynton Marsalis is to perform at a gala at the Parsippany Hilton. And last week an exhibition opened at the Morris Museum, which started out at the Neighborhood House at the turn of the century; the exhibition, "100 Years of Caring for the Community," runs through May 17.
To learn more about the Neighborhood House, call (201) 538-5493 or visit its website at http:// www.neighborhood-house.org.
 
100 MORE CANDLES -- In Bergen County, another service organization has also reached the century mark: the Family and Social Services Federation.
It began in 1898 as a day nursery for the children of working parents, established by the Woman's Club of Englewood. Now, the federation offers services to children, the elderly and all ages in between in Englewood, Hackensack and Westwood.
 
WEIGHING IN -- Better late than never, let's point out that the week of March 1 to 7 was Weights and Measures Week in New Jersey.
In an official proclamation, Governor Whitman said: "The week recognizes the important service performed by state and local weights and measures officials. These men and women work to insure that all measurements in New Jersey are accurate."
Woodrow Wilson was Governor in 1911 when the Office of Weights and Measures was established. The agency, now an arm of the division of Consumer Affairs, oversees the calibration of commercial scales in every supermarket, delicatessen, butcher shop and convenience store in the state.
Want to learn more? Group tours can be arranged to see what goes on at the Weights and Measures complex at 1261 Routes 1 and 9 South in Avenel. To make an appointment, call (732) 815-4840. SUSAN JO KELLER
Milestones, a new feature that will periodically appear in this section, will take note of -- what else? -- milestones in the lives of New Jerseyans and their institutions. Suggestions may be submitted by mail to Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036, Attentionn: Milestones, or by E-mail to jersey@nytimes.com.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE/LOWER EAST SIDE;
City Plans to Cast Dormant Theater in a New Role

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE 

 BODY:
Jason Chen and Ralph Fong were chatting on East Broadway beneath the Manhattan Bridge on Wednesday afternoon when a visitor asked them about the vacant two-story building behind them.
"It's just been sitting around," Mr. Fong said, pointing to the building. 
 Mr. Chen added, "It's a waste to leave it like that with Chinatown being so congested."
But since 1993, when the venerable Sun Sing Theater closed, 75 East Broadway has lain fallow. The city owns the property, and there have been a number of plans for it, ranging from retail space to a homeless shelter. Now there is word of a new plan for the 37,000-square-foot building.
In January, the Economic Development Corporation, which manages city-owned property, told Community Board 3 it wanted to lease the building to Bill Lam, a Chinatown developer. Last week the board decided to put off a vote on the city's plan until meetings could be held to inform the neighborhood.
"There have been quite a lot of questions about who the developer is and what the plans are," said Christopher Kui of Asian Americans for Equality, a local nonprofit development group that also had bid for the site to use it as a cultural center. "We would like to have the developer talk to the community."
Mr. Lam, said his company, the Winking Group, was making plans for a meeting in the next few weeks. He said he planned to fix up the building in return for a long-term lease. "We will have a food court," Mr. Lam said. "As well as retail space and space allocated for community groups." He would not give further details or discuss his proposed deal with the city, saying it would be inappropriate before the company holds a news conference and community meetings are held.
But already, the prospect of retailers moving into the building has raised some concerns. "I worry about traffic congestion," said Amy Chin of the New York Chinese Cultural Center. "There are already a lot of stores in the area, and I wonder about the economic impact on these existing stores."
For now, the building gathers dust beneath the roaring and rattling of the subway trains that pass across the bridge. Decaying red signs on its facade advertise former tenants, including the Sun Sing Theater and a furniture shop named Solerwitz & Law, est. 1886.
"People have been wondering about it for a long time," Mr. Chen said as he and Mr. Fong resumed their conversation. EDWARD LEWINE

GRAPHIC: Photos: Around the neighborhood there is word of a new plan for the vacant 37,000-square-foot building that was home to the Sun Sing Theater. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "TIMELINE: Bright Lights to Dark, Under the Bridge"
Through old newspaper clippings it has been possible to piece together a history of the theater at 75 East Broadway.
 
1911 -- Opens, possibly with the name Florence Theater.
1942 -- As New Canton Theater, features Chinese opera. Lobby walls lined with portraits of lavishly dressed famous actors.
1950 -- Converts to movies.
1960 -- Now named Sun Sing; seats reduced to 676 from 706 to make way for supports for upper deck of Manhattan Bridge.
1972 -- Back to featuring live Chinese perfomers, including acrobats and sword-swallowers.
1993 -- Sun Sing Theater closes.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Dialing for Dollars in Brazil's Telephone Privatization

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
BRAZIL is blessed with lush jungles, the samba and joie de vivre. The country's telephone service, however, is another matter. Getting a dial tone and holding a conversation free of static are minor miracles, and the waiting list for lines, now 13 million potential customers long, moves more slowly than an Amazonian swamp.
Many analysts and money managers view this sorry state of affairs as a world-class investment opportunity, now that the Brazilian Government is moving to completely privatize its huge telephone company, known as Telebras, as soon as July, and to divide it into 12 or so separate operations. 
 Analysts expect profits to rise smartly as soon as private managers begin cutting bloated bureaucracy and investing in new infrastructure to meet the tremendous Brazilian demand for both cellular and conventional service. Added revenues are also expected from the introduction of such services as voice mail, call-waiting, call-forwarding and "800" numbers.
"Telebras has to catch an investor's attention, given its growth potential and its current valuation," said Jeffrey A. Everett, manager of the Templeton World I fund, which holds a $100 million stake in the company. "Privatization is going to be positive, and we think the future looks very bright."
Telebras shares, traded as American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange, have taken a wild ride in recent months. Lifted by expectations of the coming privatization, the A.D.R.'s hit a high of $167 early last July. Then turbulence from the financial crisis in Asia spread to Latin America, and a selloff in the Brazilian stock market drove the stock down as low as $83 last fall. Since then, however, fears have subsided that Brazil will devalue its currency, the market has stabilized and the telephone stock has rebounded, to $127.5625 at Friday's close.
A research report this month from J. P. Morgan said its $170 target for the stock this year "is easily achievable" if the Brazilian Government meets its July goal for completing the privatization process. If there are legal or regulatory delays, most analysts predict that they will last no more than a few months.
In mid-February, the Brazilian Government took an important step toward its July target by appointing a consortium led by Salomon Smith Barney to guide the sale of all or virtually all of its remaining stake in the company. That stake, which is worth $25 billion, comprises 21.3 percent of the outstanding Telebras shares and, more important, 50.04 percent of its voting shares. Wall Street analysts say that many foreign companies -- AT&T, MCI, GTE, Bell Atlantic, Bell Canada, Telecom Italia and France Telecom -- are preparing bids for control of the various pieces.
"There are not too many opportunities like this in the world -- huge telephone service markets with pent-up demand," said Raymond E. Liguori, head of Latin American equity research at Merrill Lynch. "There's India, China and Brazil, and Brazil is now."
Analysts note that telephone companies in other Latin American countries have improved service and profits greatly after privatization. For example, the Venezuelan telephone network, Compania Anonima Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela, was privatized in 1991 and management was handed over to GTE. Over the next five years, the number of employees was cut by 28 percent and the number of service lines was increased by 63 percent. The company's stock, which has the symbol VNT, was initially listed on the New York Stock Exchange in November 1996 at $18. It closed on Friday at $35.50.
Donald W. Hoskins, manager of U.S. Trust's Excelsior Latin America fund, sees at least as much upside potential for Telebras. Brazil's telephone market is far less developed than those of its neighbors; it has only 9 telephone lines per 100 inhabitants compared with 20 per 100 in Argentina. Moreover, he said, "23 million out of the 170 million Brazilians have purchasing power equivalent to Europeans."
AND even with the rise in Telebras shares since October, the stock still seems relatively inexpensive. It is trading at roughly 10 times its estimated 1998 earnings per share, Mr. Hoskins said, compared with an average of more than 12 for other Latin American telephone companies and of more than 17 for North American ones.
"It's cheap," Mr. Hoskins said.
When Telebras is privatized, it is also expected to be divided into 12 more manageable pieces, including one long-distance company, eight cellular companies and three regional "baby Brases." So any A.D.R. owned before the privatization will probably be split into 12 separate holdings, and analysts have come up with four possible investment plays.
One strategy is to buy Telebras now, and to sell it just before it is privatized and spun apart. According to this view, many investors will sell the bulk of the spinoffs immediately after privatization because they will not want to keep track of 12 foreign securities with various levels of liquidity and future growth potential.
Also, "investors fear that other investors will dump the little guys," said Luanne D. Zurlo, director of Latin American equity research at Credit Suisse First Boston. "It's a knee-jerk reaction."
Such thinking anticipates a second tack, which is to buy and hold Telebras through the privatization, and then, quickly, jettison the shares of a few of the weaker spinoffs before they tumble. Some possible candidates are the four cellular companies planned for the impoverished northern provinces.
A third option is to hold all 12 securities, weather the expected turbulence in some of the spinoffs in the first year after privatization and then reap the benefits over the long term. And a fourth, contrarian play is to wait for the breakup and the subsequent declines in some stocks, pick up those whose prices are driven down further than seems justified, and then hold them for the long term.
Mr. Liguori, the Merrill Lynch strategist, says he strongly believes in the third approach.
"Most individual investors should follow my Aunt Margaret's strategy," he said. "She owned AT&T prior to the breakup and she held on to all the pieces for more than a decade and she had some phenomenal returns."

That fall and the company's continuing privatization make the security a good buy, some analysts say. Prices since Jan. 1997. Friday's close: $127.5625. (Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Who Cares What Owners Think?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Who owns American companies?
The management, of course. Shareholders are tolerated, but managers rule. 
 That is an exaggeration, to be sure. But it summarizes the attitude of directors at two companies that have faced takeover bids this year. Fearing that shareholders might vote against the incumbent directors, the directors decided to change the rules.
In one case, Computer Associates gave up last week on its effort to acquire Computer Sciences. It wasn't that shareholders bought into claims of Computer Sciences that the $108-a-share offer was too low, for the price plunged when the offer was pulled. Instead, it was the moves the Computer Sciences board took to disenfranchise the owners. It hurriedly changed the company's bylaws to assure that shareholders could not throw out the board at a special meeting and to make it possible for the company to delay its annual meeting. The would-be acquirer was fighting those moves in court, but there was no certainty it would prevail.
Meanwhile, a Connecticut auto parts maker, Echlin Inc., is resisting a takeover proposal from another parts maker, the SPX Corporation. Echlin wants to end the right of shareholders to throw out the board through a special shareholder meeting and has asked the Connecticut Legislature to do just that by amending the state's corporation law. But the proposed law would go further. Even if SPX managed to persuade Echlin shareholders to throw out the current board, the new board would not be allowed to approve a merger with SPX for five years. Only directors who were in office before the offer was made could vote to approve such a deal sooner.
If America worked that way, perhaps the Federalist Party would still run the Government. It's reminiscent of the line about African democracy in the 1960's: One man, one vote, one time.
In the 1980's, shareholders began to wrest power away from managers, in part because of the threat of hostile takeovers. But the trend reversed as companies played on the fears engendered by the layoffs that sometimes followed leveraged takeovers. Legislators and judges became more sympathetic to management.
One indication of that power shift can be seen in the low level of dividends now paid to shareholders. As a percentage of corporate profits, dividends are at a record low.
"The managements of U.S. companies today stride the earth as global folk heroes," says Peter L. Bernstein, the economic historian and investment adviser. "Today, management is responsible for the reinvestment of close to two-thirds of the company's earnings. Tax considerations aside, investors are free to deploy for themselves only one-third of the company's earnings. Does this division lead to optimal allocations of capital? Whatever happened to the notion that the free market knows best?"
The low-dividend policy serves the bosses in another way. Most corporate executives have a lot of stock options in their companies, but few actual shares. And while option holders benefit from rises in the stock price, they do not share in dividend payments.
It is understandable that few shareholders are up in arms about their loss of power. After all, stock prices have zoomed in recent years, and investors are making money. It will probably not be until the good times are over, and a long bear market is in force, that the owners of American companies start looking for ways to take back the prerogatives of ownership.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 833 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Not Alpha or Omega: Risk, Small Caps and Beta

BYLINE: By NOELLE KNOX 

 BODY:
FIRST it was the market drop in October. Next came the Asian financial crisis. Then, last week, Intel delivered its gloomy revenue predictions. The market never lacks for traumas, and when they come it is small-capitalization stocks that often have the wildest fluctuations.
That is why some investors try to control risk in their pursuit of the small caps' historically higher returns. The investors may choose to buy "value," or low-priced, stocks, for example; if volatility arrives and the stocks fall, at least they won't tumble from too high a perch. Others select small companies that pay high dividends, which can help cushion stock price declines. 
 There is another way. Choose small stocks that have been historically less volatile than their peers. The measure of this volatility is called beta. It is a cute word for the results of an ugly regression analysis, but don't worry. You don't have to do any math because you can get stock betas from several places -- your broker, for example, or free on the Internet from America Online.
Betas are small numbers, typically falling between 0 and 2. A beta must always be read in relation to a particular index, which, for purposes of the calculation, is assigned a beta of 1. Stocks with betas greater than 1 are turbo-charged, rising more than the index does on good days and falling more than it does on bad days. Stocks with betas less than 1 are more stable than the index, both rising and falling less than it does.
Pioneered in the 1960's by William F. Sharpe, a Nobel Prize-winning economist at Stanford University, the beta concept led to the invention of index mutual funds. The Vanguard Index 500, for example, holds shares in all the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and hence has a volatility roughly equal to the index itself.
Despite the general volatility of small stocks, there are placid but attractive vehicles for investing in them, like the T. Rowe Price Small Cap Stock fund. It has had annualized returns of 28 percent over the past three years.
"I get morose because the market's up and I'm lagging, but on days when the market's down, I get to go home happy," said Preston G. Athey, one of its portfolio managers. The fund has a beta of 0.63 in relation to the Russell 2000, the benchmark index for small-company issues.
Or consider the Tab Products Company, based in Palo Alto, Calif. This small company, which had revenues of $155 million for the 12 months ended last May, makes office products and filing systems. And it has been successful, with a 36 percent increase in profits last year, a 49 percent jump in its stock price since the start of 1997 and even a 1.5 percent yearly dividend.
But this small-cap stock has been relatively stable, too. When the Russell 2000 plunged 6.1 percent last October, for example, shares of Tab Products fell just 3 percent.
"I would expect it to outperform the market but not be as volatile," said Samuel Eisenstadt, research director of Value Line, a market research organization. Value Line ranks Tab Products near the top of its list of stocks considered good investments based on such factors as earnings and volatility.
But betas, which are based on past performance, do not always predict future volatility.
Consider the Cheesecake Factory, a restaurant and bakery chain in Calabasas Hills, Calif. Analysts would have expected this high-beta stock to fall more than the Russell 2000 on Oct. 27, but instead it fell less, just 5.13 percent.
Even more, if there is a major event for a company -- a scientific breakthrough, say, or the arrest of a chief executive for money laundering -- all bets are off for divining future performance through beta.
Nevertheless, if a stock or mutual fund was risky in the past, it tends to be risky in the future, said James R. Raker, a senior analyst at Morningstar, the financial publisher in Chicago. Many experts say betas are most accurate in predicting the performance of a diverse portfolio of stocks, like Mr. Athey's fund.
Several other small-cap mutual funds have low betas and solid returns. For example, the Royce Total Return fund has a beta of 0.35 in relation to the Russell 2000; its 1997 returns modestly outpaced those of that index, 23.7 percent to 22.3 percent. The Scout Regional and Schwartz Value funds had respective betas against the Russell of 0.55 and 0.60, and 1997 returns of 23 percent and 28 percent.
Investors should not look to beta alone, however. They should consider a company's earnings, debt level and the like, or, for a fund, its managers' reputations and its performance compared with similar funds.
"Over the last few decades there have been major advances in academic finance to help us forecast the future volatility of a stock," said Theodore R. Aronson, managing partner of Aronson + Partners, quantitative investment managers with $1.2 billion in assets. But, he said, "you need to look at more than the statistical zigs and zags."'

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3706 words

HEADLINE: America's Treadmill Economy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: SCRANTON, Pa.

 BODY:
THE caller insisted that a telephone number must exist for the Kimberly-Clark Corporation in Voorhees, N.J. He had called there once, and now he demanded that Sandra Singh find the number. His voice rose in anger when she said that only one New Jersey listing for Kimberly-Clark popped up on her computer screen -- in the town of Spotswood, not Voorhees. "Perhaps they moved," Ms. Singh offered, sympathetically. Only gradually did he give in, finally accepting the Spotswood number she proferred so amiably.
The call had lasted three minutes, an eternity in the world of telephone directory assistance, with its bent toward electronic voices and 10-second automated responses. But in corporate America, where the talk everywhere is of greater productivity -- producing more, faster, without adding human labor -- the AT&T Corporation has gone in the opposite direction, adding dozens of directory-assistance operators like Ms. Singh, who works at a new operator center here. She is trained to be patient with customers, so they won't hang up in anger and jump to a competitor. 
 "Our new directory assistance service has less to do with traditional notions of productivity than it does with using a personalized service to create a competitive advantage," said Howard McNally, AT&T's vice president for consumer product management.
The AT&T story is showing up in various guises at many companies. While productivity may be a national goal, conflicting pressures are getting in the way, pushing companies to add thousands of hours of labor as they fight to hang onto increasingly demanding and flighty customers.
The effect is a frantically busy economy -- call it the Treadmill Economy -- that has been creating more than 300,000 new jobs a month. It is an economy that adds workers rather than operate more efficiently. And while that keeps unemployment low, it is greater productivity that makes possible healthy raises and higher living standards.
"What we are beginning to recognize," said Paul David, an economic historian at Stanford University, "is that companies are increasingly embracing strategies that pay off in added revenue and higher profits for individual companies, but not necessarily in greater productivity for the nation."
That conclusion runs counter to a view that has become popular over the last two years among many experts -- including, at times, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. They have proclaimed a new era of rising productivity, in which a computer-equipped nation is returning to the rapid rate of improvement of earlier generations.
The trouble is that the new era fails to show up in the Government's productivity data, which measure how much national income, or output, is generated from an average hour of work, or input. The optimists say that the statistics are wrong, or that they have not yet caught up to the improvement taking place, or that they fail to reflect the higher quality built into some products and services.
But the experiences of American companies like AT&T suggest that the statistics are closer to the truth than the optimism is. Considerable amounts of labor are apparently going into design, advertising and marketing -- to make one pair of sneakers, for example, or one telephone directory system seem different from another, but without increasing the total output of sneakers or of responses to requests for directory assistance. As for quality, the improvements are much less substantial than the optimists claim.
The question of whether a new era is near is of more than academic interest. In any country, productivity is the main road to a rising standard of living. Only when a nation's workers produce more in a given amount of time can hourly or weekly or annual wages rise across the board. Rising output from the same amount of labor can also free workers and capital for other endeavors that a society deems desirable -- more day care for children, for example; the development of supersonic jets; more schools and teachers, or 100-mile-an-hour commuter trains.
But the country's standard of living, in fact, has not been rising in any significant way. Median household income is very much in line with the meager increases in productivity over the last quarter-century -- a prolonged slowdown unprecedented in the American experience. That helps to explain the feeling expressed by so many people -- particularly those whose incomes are not linked to the rapid rise in the stock market -- that they are working harder and longer with no appreciable sense that their wealth is growing.
The new-era talk has been circulating only in the last two years, as the economy has boomed and as wages have begun to improve. Profits have also done well in the last couple of years -- another bit of evidence, at least in the optimists' eyes, that productivity is improving. There has, in fact, been an upward spurt in productivity in the last year, but the average annual increase in the 1990's is only 1.2 percent, almost unchanged from the 70's and 80's. For 100 years until the early 70's -- America's industrial heyday -- productivity rose at an average annual rate of over 2 percent.
Critics of the new-era thesis note that a corporation can raise profitability, at least for awhile, without improving productivity. It can invest more in marketing and innovation, for example, to make a product or service seem different, and better, than a competitor's. The issue, they say, isn't that the growing service sector is less efficient than manufacturing or harder to measure, as some argue in explaining the nation's poor productivity performance. Rather, the critics say, the drag on productivity comes from the great quantities of labor that are expended, in both manufacturing and the service sector, to hold on to customers or to lure them away from other companies.
 
Now, Four Ways to Get a Phone Number
That is what is happening at AT&T. Even as it makes a point of paring its work force, it adds other workers -- either on its own payroll or through outsourcing -- to stave off new challengers to its bread-and-butter long-distance phone service.
Ms. Singh is one of the additions. Dial zero twice from most telephones, and people like Ms. Singh come on the line. She is a 35-year-old divorced mother of four who joined AT&T when the company opened a directory-assistance center last May on the upper floors of a stately former department store here. The store had flourished when Scranton was a prosperous coal mining and railroad center; now the city is riddled with unemployment and low wages.
"What we are betting is that consumers will be so captivated by our new 'Double 00' service that they cannot imagine dealing with our competitors," said Mark Siegel, an AT&T spokesman.
Ms. Singh and her colleagues, who earn $6.20 an hour, are paid to be pleasant and patient. Ask one to list the names and phone numbers of all the delicatessens on Sixth Avenue in Manhattan and she -- the majority are women -- will go patiently through 30 delis that come up on the screen before the caller has had enough.
"You get a warm feeling from these conversations," Ms. Singh said. "You don't come away from the job feeling brain-dead."
But Ms. Singh's role represents a considerable deterioration in productivity. Once, AT&T funneled requests for directory assistance to the Bell companies that provide phone service in each region of the country. Because the Bell companies actually operate the phones, they also have the most up-to-date information. For years, national directory assistance consisted of this single, linked system, orchestrated by AT&T.
But then the regional Bell companies began jockeying to enter long-distance phone service in competition with AT&T. And in 1995, AT&T decided that it no longer wanted to rely on potential competitors for national directory assistance.
That was when the proliferation in manpower began. Call 411 today, and you still reach a local operator. (In some cities, like Denver or Tampa, Fla., local operators for the first time will provide long-distance numbers, too.) A second layer of manpower kicks in when an AT&T customer dials 555-1212 preceded by an area code. No longer does an operator from a Bell company respond. Instead, the voice is that of a recently hired AT&T operator, one of more than 4,000 working directly for the phone company or for a contractor, Excell Agent Services, based in Phoenix.
Ms. Singh represents still another layer of new workers, a small but growing group of elite operators stationed in Scranton and in another recently opened AT&T center in Augusta, Ga. Their job is to offer the extra courtesy and patience not available at 555-1212, with its electronic voices and faster pace.
And, finally, a fourth layer of workers has sprung up: the hundreds of people who scramble to put together new data bases of telephone numbers, now that the Bell companies no longer make their numbers available through the cooperative system that AT&T once organized.
Excell is AT&T's data-base supplier. In Rube Goldberg fashion, it draws from published phone books, the Internet, postal and real estate records, mail-order houses and a cottage industry that has mushroomed to supply phone companies with phone numbers.
"I would say that 500 people are probably employed collecting numbers who would not be necessary if the regional Bell companies were still making their numbers available," said Dan Evanoff, chief executive of Excell. The Bells offer their numbers to others, but under terms that AT&T considers unpalatable.
 
How Novelty Gnaws At Productivity
Beyond AT&T, the drag on productivity seems woven into modern American business. Dozens of entrepreneurs, for example, invested thousands of hours to develop 4,000 computer games for the Christmas selling season last year, but fewer than 10 percent actually caught on with customers. In the productivity data, that represented a lot of labor input and not much output.
The obsession with novelty is also a big consumer of labor. New Balance Inc., the sneaker company, introduces a new, slightly different shoe every 17 weeks, investing thousands of labor hours in the design and marketing of each variation. And inexpensive labor dents productivity at United Parcel Service, which operates a huge package distribution center in Louisville, Ky., that looks like a 19th-century factory, crisscrossed with conveyor belts.
Seven thousand people work at the center, picking packages off the belts, sorting them and loading them into cargo containers for shipment. The work force has doubled in a decade as U.P.S.'s cargo planes bring in more and more packages.
If the Louisville center were to be automated, the work force could be reduced by 15 to 20 percent, said Kenneth E. Shapero, a company spokesman. Until now, the high cost of automating the center could not be justified, Mr. Shapero said, not in a city where U.P.S.'s wage bill averages only $11 an hour. For U.P.S., raising productivity -- increasing the number of packages that each employee can sort in an hour with the help of equipment -- has been less profitable than adding workers. But labor costs keep rising, Mr. Shapero said, and as a result, U.P.S. announced last week that it would build an $860 million labor-saving distribution center in Louisville.
The greatest drag on productivity, however, appears to be coming from the huge investment in manpower to develop products and services that are only slightly different from their predecessors, and then to advertise and market these variations. AT&T's national directory service falls into this category. So do New Balance's sneakers. And so, too, do the 401(k) plans managed by the Principal Financial Group, an insurance company based in Des Moines.
Principal administers the 401(k) plans of 37,000 companies with two million participating employees. The contracts are with the companies, but Principal deals directly with each worker. From one point of view, efficiency at Principal is greatly improved, said Steven Hensley, a vice president. Thanks to computers and new software, the 4,000 employees in Principal's pension division have in recent years doubled the amount of work they get done in an hour. But this is largely offset by the proliferation of tasks and services that Principal requires of its workers to satisfy customers.
"We are returning to a kind of contemporary crafts economy," said Jeffrey Madrick, an author specializing in economics who is writing a book on productivity. "We have shifted from a kind of standard mass-market economy to one that requires more creative input from its workers."
Mr. Hensley ticks off the labor and the skills involved in Principal's 401(k) services. There are the hours spent reaching new employees at the 37,000 companies, soliciting their enrollment. And the hours invested in a Spanish-language operation, in seminars for retirees and in the installation of a sophisticated system that allows people to see their 401(k) balance sheets on the Internet, at any time, rather than calling an "800" number or waiting for quarterly statements. And finally there are the hours invested by 150 consultants, hired in the last seven years, who give avuncular advice over the phone on taxes, investment, estate planning and the like.
"You don't do this if there is not a payback," Mr. Hensley said. The payback last year was an increase of 4,000 in the number of companies that contract with Principal. But only 2,000 were newly establishing 401(k)'s for their workers. The remaining 2,000 already had 401(k) plans and only switched them to Principal from other suppliers.
For Principal, that competitive victory is fine. But in the national productivity statistics, the company's investment in extra hours of work shows up as a labor "input" not entirely offset by a rise in "output," because half the new business is simply a shifting of existing business -- existing output -- to a new supplier.
Economists argue that the losers in this competition start to downsize, cutting back labor hours no longer needed to serve customers that have switched to Principal. But Mr. Hensley doubts that these cutbacks actually occur. Too many companies try to hold on and make a comeback.
"The marketplace may be forcing out some inefficient suppliers," Mr. Hensley said. "Maybe over the long run there will be a lot of that. But the fact is that we have more competitors today than 10 years ago. There is an oversupply."
What is true for fund managers is true for manufacturers, too. The Gillette Company finds that it cannot sell the same model of razor for more than three or four years without innovations. "People don't want to pay a premium anymore for aging models," said Edward DeGraan, an executive vice president.
So, in July, Gillette will begin to ship the fourth version since 1985 of its "wet shave" razor -- one not yet put on public view but likely to be only marginally different from the last version. That has been the pattern. One feature of the current model, for example, is a set of fins, resembling a miniature Venetian blind, designed to expose more of the facial hair for a cleaner shave. Another feature is a white strip above the twin blades that produces "a highly lubricious chemical that increases glide across the cheeks," Mr. DeGraan said. The strip grew wider and more lubricious from one model to the next.
Gillette spends tens of millions of dollars in the redesign and testing of such innovations, in new or retooled machinery and in advertising and promotion -- outlays that show up in the national productivity data as roughly the equivalent of thousands of hours of labor input. In Gillette's case, the total cost of this input has risen to 18 percent of net sales, from 14.4 percent in 1990.
Gillette makes up for much of these costs by finding ever more efficient ways to run its assembly lines. And, indeed, manufacturing's portion of the company's sales dollar has fallen.
"What we have managed to do is add to the value of the shaving experience," said John F. Bush, another Gillette vice president, "and we get a higher price and a greater profit margin when we do this."
Yet Gillette, a much-admired manufacturer, may not be doing much more than a struggling services company like AT&T to build the nation's income through greater productivity. "When we contrast what is happening today with 1960, we find many hours of labor going into the development of novelty features that are not durable," said Mr. David of Stanford. "There appears to be a greater outlay of labor today in replacing existing products with new ones that are not that much different."
 
Finding Some Gains Through Innovation
Of course, there are some real productivity gains in America. Allied Signal Inc., based in Morristown, N.J., has introduced an airplane cockpit device that warns pilots of obstructions 60 seconds before a potential collision. Until 1996, the most up-to-date devices offered only a 10-second warning, often not enough time for an airliner to avert trouble.
Advances in computer memory, which became cheaper, made the new device possible. It stores a terrain map of the world in a container not much larger than a shoe box, incorporating geographic data declassified only after the cold war.
"We thought up the concept 10 years ago," said Frank Daly, a vice president at Allied Signal, "but the computers needed then to store a map of the world would have taken up three rows of seats."
In productivity data, however, the device is potentially important because of its spinoffs. The device improves flight safety in bad weather, which means that flights are less likely to be canceled. More flights mean more output from the same crews, who spend fewer hours on the ground, waiting for the weather to clear.
Safer flights also constitute a quality improvement, which some economists say should be counted in the productivity data as greater output from the same labor input. Many such improvements are indeed included, and if every innovation counted as better quality, "the productivity growth rate would soar," said Richard Nelsen, an economist at Columbia University.
But not every innovation is an improvement in quality, and often for good reason.
AT&T argues that the "Double 00" directory assistance furnished by Ms. Singh and her colleagues is a quality improvement. But maybe not. Every time Ms. Singh cannot find a phone number, she worries that the customer may indeed be right -- that the number exists and that her data base is out of date.
So she shifts the call to a customer assistant like Laura Wolfe, a 29-year-old college dropout who earns $1 an hour more than Ms. Singh and is counting on AT&T to subsidize tuition so she can go back to school. If Ms. Wolfe cannot find the number either, she makes a discreet call to the local Bell operator in the city in question. What she does, in effect, is dial 411, as if she were calling from any household in the city.
Eight times in less than an hour late last month, she dialed 411 in various cities to come up with numbers, giving them to callers and also logging them on a sheet of paper that would be faxed to Excell in Phoenix later in the day for inclusion in the growing data base.
Some callers are clearly annoyed by the delay, even when they finally get the number they want. "Do you know what the problem was?" one caller asked after being made to wait for several minutes.
"No, ma'am," Ms. Wolfe replied.
 
A Simple Equation With Complicated Results
Productivity, as measured by the Labor Department, comes in two flavors.
The most common one, illustrated in the chart below, measures changes in productivity by adding up all of the nation's output in a given period and dividing that total by all the hours of work required to produce that output.
If American industry produced $100,000 in new goods and services in each of two years and spent 10,000 hours each year producing that output, then the productivity growth rate would be zero. But if the labor input declined in the second year to 9,700 hours for the same $100,000 in output, then productivity would have risen by 3 percent.
From 1870 until the early 1970's, America's productivity, in the nonfarm business sector, rose by more than 2 percent a year on average.
That average was pulled up by the economy's strong performance in the roughly 30-year golden age after World War II, when technological advances -- and the devastation left elsewhere by the war -- helped American industry to dominate the globe.
Since 1973, however, the average has been roughly 1 percent, despite occasional upward spurts -- including a blip over the last year or so. Explanations for the drop include the industrial rebirth of the rest of the world, but the exact reasons remain a matter of huge debate.
In measuring productivity, the trickiest factor in the equation is output. It is not simply the sum of what people pay for goods and services -- the cost of a razor, for example, or of getting a phone number from a telephone directory- assistance operator.
Rather, when the Government calculates output, it factors out inflation, to make the output figure more representative of the quantity of goods and services produced in the economy. And it factors in quality. Improved food packaging, for instance, maintains freshness -- and thus raises the quality of food products and their contribution to national output.
Some economists argue that the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics fails to give enough credit in the output column for improvements in quality. If the critics are correct, the productivity growth rate may be understated.
The second measure of productivity growth, called multifactor productivity, differs from the statistics shown here in one major respect. Input, the denominator in the productivity equation, is expanded to include not just the hours worked but also capital investment -- in essence, the machinery and tools that labor uses.
Multifactor productivity also showed robust growth before 1973 and a sharp slowdown ever since. LOUIS UCHITELLE

Chart: "Going Nowhere Fast"
The economy is generating millions of new jobs every year, but most Americans' standard of living is stagnant. What's wrong? With new competitors all around and customers growing more demanding, companies are spending furiously just to hang onto market share. And that means the nation's productivity -- the source of new wealth -- is growing very slowly. (Photo by Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times)
 
MANUFACTURING Companies pour money and labor into minor refinements of products. But the design and promotion costs offset manufacturing efficiencies. Gillette, for example, has fiddled with the design of its "wet-shave" razor four times in 13 years.
 
SERVICES To suit a public that wants mass services tailored to individual needs, businesses from insurers to phone companies add staff faster than customers. AT&T has hired hundreds of low-paid workers to patiently field directory-assistance calls it doesn't want to lose to the Baby Bells and other competitors.
 
LOGISTICS In a nation that wants its packages delivered overnight, it has been cheaper for United Parcel Service to maintain high staffing levels at some distribution centers than to eliminate jobs -- but bolster productivity -- through automation.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1114 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Another Victory For Death in Serbia

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: PRISTINA, Serbia

 BODY:
OF all the tinderboxes in the Balkans, Kosovo may be the nastiest. It is the place where an armed rebellion by the ethnic Albanian majority against their Serb rulers could easily draw in restive Albanian minorities in neighboring Macedonia and Montenegro. Perhaps it could then draw in Albania itself, then Turkey and Greece. That would produce the true nightmare: an international conflict that would pit the region's Orthodox Christians against its Muslims on a large scale.
Such nightmares have been part of the world's thinking about the Balkans for a decade now. Indeed, when NATO forces were sent to Bosnia three years ago, policy makers felt they were forestalling just such a messy escalation. 
 Now, it seems, they are going to have to think again about Kosovo, a tiny Serbian province where 90 percent of the people are ethnic Albanians, where armed rebellion is surfacing and where the Serbian government has vowed to keep control no matter what the world thinks of its methods.
It may sound like Kosovo is Bosnia all over again, but that is wrong -- both because escalation may be much more difficult to control here and because Kosovo came first.
The scenario of warfare radiating from Serbia was, in fact, first written not about Bosnia but about Kosovo in the late 1980's. It was there that the Serbian dictator Slobodan Milosevic set Yugoslavia on the path to disintegration by appealing to the ethnic insecurity of Kosovo's tiny, but powerful, Serb minority, which attaches mythic importance to the region as the site of a medieval battle lost to the Turks.
What followed offers a lesson in how intricately fear, distrust and intrigue can act together to defeat the best instincts of people who would prefer to use nonviolent political methods in the Balkans. Americans and others may have thought they were calming the region by enlisting Mr. Milosevic as a partner in the accords that have pacified Bosnia. But people in Kosovo see it differently: To them, watching Bosnia has only confirmed their worst fears about Serbian force and Western detachment, and this is a big reason their land now seems on a descent into open warfare.
When Yugoslavia was a Communist federation, Kosovo enjoyed the status of an autonomous province within the Serbian republic. But in 1989, Mr. Milosevic had chosen as his path to power an appeal to Serb fears of groups like Kosovo's Albanians, and he revoked the region's autonomy. That was what set off the first alarm bells.
 
The Nonviolent Approach
The response within Kosovo defied the worst predictions, however. Most of the rest of Yugoslavia dissolved in bloodshed in the next three years, but a remarkable civility reined in the tactics of Kosovo's ethnic Albanian leaders. They too wanted independence, but they knew the terrible price to be paid for indulging in violent revolt.
So instead, they sent activists to seminars in Norway to study nonviolence. They withdrew from all Serbian state institutions, forming their own shadow government, school system and health care service. Taxes were dutifully collected, even from the hundreds of thousands of ethnic Albanians living abroad, to run the administration. And there was little violence.
As Kosovo's Albanians see it today, though, the lack of drama in their land lulled Washington into a false belief that there was always another day to work things out -- and room to naively hope that Mr. Milosevic's brutal Serbian regime could be reformed.
It is ironic that the Dayton accord of 1995, which produced the uneasy peace in Bosnia, was probably the signal event in the formation of an armed insurgency in Kosovo. The leadership in the capital, Pristina, watched in disbelief as the fate of Kosovo was never raised in Dayton, and as other Yugoslav groups that had mounted armed rebellions achieved recognition and even independence. It was especially galling that the self-styled Bosnian Serb republic, which had overseen the expulsion and murder of tens of thousands of Muslims, obtained quasi-legitimacy in Dayton while Kosovo was ignored.
"It was a terrible, terrible lesson," said a minister in the self-styled government who asked to remain unidentified. "We learned that violence works. It is the only way in this part of the world to achieve what you want and get the attention of the international community."
Meanwhile, in the years that the dispute in Kosovo was allowed to drag on without being addressed from outside, the animosities and divisions between the province's ethnic Albanians, most of whom are Muslims, and its Serbs, who are Orthodox Christians, only deepened. Today, most students are handed diplomas from "the Republic of Kosovo" and know Serbs only as policemen and soldiers. The police patrol Pristina in flak jackets and carry automatic assault rifles. A privileged Serb minority of fewer than 100,000, which has a lock on authority and runs the state companies, lords it over an impoverished populace of 2 million, among whom the unemployment rate is 85 percent.
 
The End of Illusions
Any remaining illusions that Belgrade might begin a dialogue with the ethnic Albanians or restore the region's autonomy were shattered last week when police and paramilitary units, some of which served in Bosnia, responded to the emergence of a Kosovo guerrilla army by going on a killing spree that took scores of lives. Mr. Milosevic has ordered his forces to conduct an all-out campaign to put down the rebels despite warnings from Washington that what is needed is dialogue, and that Serbia could again become a pariah nation.
But such warnings present a quandary for Washington that recalls its deep initial ambivalence about getting too deeply involved in Bosnia. However much the Clinton Administration wants to see Kosovo's problems settled peacefully, it has made it clear that it also wants to see Kosovo remain part of Serbia -- if with more autonomy -- rather than set a precedent for further splintering the Balkans.
So even if Mr. Milosovic is facing a new round of sanctions, he may feel secure in the calculation that there is little more that Washington seems ready to do. Certainly, the ethnic Albanians would be hard put to stand up to his Interior Ministry's well-trained special police units, who have never shied away from wholesale slaughter.
But that is not the way many ethnic Albanians see it. For them, the guerrillas hold out their final hope for an independent state amid a bitter sense that the outside world betrayed them by ignoring the resistance movement when it was nonviolent. And there is the naive belief that because violence worked in Croatia and Bosnia it can work here.

HEADLINE: The World;
Hero to U.S., Yawn to Russia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
WHEN Russia's Prime Minister summed up his accomplishments for the past five years, he was a little weak on what former President George Bush liked to call the vision thing.
"If one considers what could have been done, and then what we did do over this long time, one can conclude that something was done," Viktor S. Chernomyrdin said. 
 This week the steady but uninspiring Mr. Chernomyrdin is to meet in Washington with Vice President Al Gore to discuss everything from foreign investment to arms control. But will Mr. Gore be meeting Russia's future president, as many American policymakers hope, or simply a gray and unelectable political survivor?
From Mikhail Gorbachev to Boris N. Yeltsin, the United States has a long history of pinning its hopes on Russian leaders even after their authority has begun to wane.
Mr. Chernomyrdin's power is growing. But Russia's second most important official looks very different through the prism of Washington politics than he does in Moscow. The Clinton Administration sees Mr. Chernomyrdin as a stabilizing figure to whom Washington can turn to smooth over the rough patches in the American-Russian relationship. He may not always deliver the answers Washington wants, but he is always there to take the call.
"He has been a steady Eddie," a senior Clinton Administration official said. "He has not been an outspoken proponent of reform but a lot of reform has moved forward under his authority. He has learned and grown a great deal."
 
A C-plus Student
But where Americans see stability, Russian reformers see stagnation. In Moscow, Mr. Chernomyrdin is viewed as a "C-plus" student whose principal talent is his ability to get along with seemingly everyone while avoiding tough decisions.
The Communists like him because he is amenable to compromise, even if it means agreeing to a budget that vastly exceeds any credible projection of revenue. Mr. Yeltsin likes him because he has demonstrated his loyality and is not a political threat.
Russia's bankers and energy barons have embraced him as their best hope of retaining their inside connections after Mr. Yeltsin leaves the scene.
"Chernomyrdin has been practically selected by the oligarchy as a successor to Yeltsin," said Andrei Piontkovsky, a Russian political analyst. "They choose him because he is ready to insure the status quo, the same incestuous relationship between power and money."
If Mr. Chernomyrdin can get along with Communists as well as energy barons, it is because he has been both. The son of a truck driver, the 59-year-old Mr. Chernomyrdin began as a compressor operator in central Russia.
Later, he worked for the local Communist Party in the city of Orsk, and became the minister of the Soviet gas industry in 1985. When the ministry was transformed into Gazprom, the huge and semi-privatized natural gas monopoly, Mr. Chernomyrdin became its first chairman.
His big political break came in 1992 when Yegor T. Gaidar, the pro-capitalist reformer, was ousted as prime minister. Mr. Chernomyrdin had assailed the "romantic" infatuation with the free market. But as a pragmatist, he now talks about the need for economic reform.
Because of his long connection to Gazprom, he is commonly viewed as one of Russia's wealthiest men. Mr. Chernomyrdin has reported an annual income of about $7,800, reflecting his annual salary, and an estate worth about $50,000, but no securities or shares in Gazprom, an income declaration virtually nobody in Russia takes at face value.
In a sense, Russia has had a preview of a Chernomyrdin Government. Mr. Yeltsin's drinking and poor health have meant that there have been long periods when Mr. Chernomyrdin has been the dominant figure, and when Mr. Chernomyrdin has held the reins, Russia has tended to drift. Mr. Chernomyrdin, however, is by no means the worst alternative. He showed flashes of conscience in resisting the war in Chechnya and is committed to constructive relations with the West.
 
Cozy With the Money Barons
Still, one of Russia's greatest challenges is to break the grip that the small cluster of financiers and industrialists have on the economy. And few think Mr. Chernomyrdin is up to it. If he decides to run in the 2000 election, he has some political strengths. For want of an alternative, much of Russia's business elite seem prepared to back him if Mr. Yeltsin does not run.
And Mr. Chernomyrdin has been cozying up to the financial barons and potential campaign contributors. When he blessed the merger that created Russia's largest oil company, he urged Russian companies to concentrate on competing with foreign interests abroad instead of each other at home, comments that did not fit easily with his boilerplate rhetoric about building a market economy.
Mr. Chernomyrdin has also proved himself a resilient bureaucratic infighter. He recently expanded his authority at the expense of Anatoly B. Chubais and Boris Nemtsov, the most reform-minded senior officials in the Yeltsin Government. They were left with such politically thankless tasks as compelling Russians to pay their taxes and phasing out housing subsidies.
What Mr. Chernomyrdin, however, has still not been able to do is make himself popular with the voters. His poll ratings are so low that the Russian media that support him tend not to report them.
The Prime Minister is constantly being ridiculed for his mixed metaphors, fractured grammatical constructions and gross insults to the Russian language.
It was Mr. Chernomyrdin who defended the gas and electrical monopolies as "the backbone of Russia's economy" and then added pointedly he would "defend this backbone as the pupil of an eye."
He appears to be calculating that the Kremlin political machine and the financiers' money will enable him to succeed, much as it helped Mr. Yeltsin reverse his disastrous ratings in the 1996 election. But Mr. Yeltsin had a spirit, lust for combat and even charisma that Mr. Chernomyrdin lacks.
To boost his image, Mr. Chernomyrdin is launching a new show on the RTR state television channel on which he will respond to questions from the public. But he is such a wooden speaker that it's not clear whether this will help or hurt his prospects.
"Chernomyrdin will be answering citizens' questions live on TV," quipped the newspaper Russky Telegraf. "Is this the first sign of the upcoming presidential election? Or maybe Yeltsin simply wants to ruin the Prime Minister's chances?
