HEADLINE: Albright Warns Serbs on Kosovo Violence

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: ROME, March 7

 BODY:
Blaming President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia for the bloodshed in Kosovo, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that the United States is "not going to stand by and watch" Serbian authorities crush political freedoms in the province.
Ms. Albright is to attend a meeting on Monday in London of the group of six countries monitoring developments in the former Yugoslavia. She said she wants the so-called Contact Group to insure that "Serbia pays a price" for its actions in Kosovo, the southern Serbian province where Belgrade is attempting to crush an independence movement led by ethnic Albanians. 
 "We are not going to stand by and watch the Serbian authorities do in Kosovo what they can no longer get away with doing in Bosnia," Ms. Albright said.
A senior American official said Ms. Albright would propose that the six nations take "strong measures that would signal the disapproval and condemnation of the international community for this crackdown," in which at least 45 Albanians and 6 Serbian policemen have been killed in recent days.
The "strong measures" that she will propose are largely economic and meant to be punitive, but American officials acknowledge that some members of the Contact Group -- which includes France, Russia, Germany, Britain and Italy -- are less enamored of a stiff response.
"There may be some governments that need some reminding of what happened last time," a senior American official said, referring to the horrors of the 1992-95 civil war in Bosnia. "It's important to have a firm response now," the official said.
Ms. Albright said of President Milosevic, "Unfortunately, the one thing he truly understands is decisive and firm action on the part of the international community."
But Russia has opposed sanctions over Kosovo, and other nations, including France and Italy, are understood to be less than enthusiastic about another confrontation with Serbia. The Americans have already taken some small steps in response to the violence in Kosovo, lifting modest economic concessions granted Belgrade only a week ago in response to Mr. Milosevic's support for Milorad Dodik, the new, more moderate Prime Minister of the Serbian republic in Bosnia.
The Americans had also granted landing rights for charter flights of JAT, Yugoslavia's national airline, and permission to open a new consulate and to add staff members at the Yugoslav Mission to the United Nations in New York.
"By his actions, Slobodan Milosevic has made it clear he is spurning the incentives that the United States and others have offered him in recent weeks," Ms. Albright said. "We have already taken steps to insure that Serbia pays the price for its conduct in Kosovo and we urge our allies to follow suit."
American officials have always regarded Kosovo as the main threat to continued stability in the region after the 1995 Dayton accords ended the war in Bosnia. Ms. Albright said Washington believes that "it is important that there be a peaceful pursuit of the legitimate political rights of the people of Kosovo."
Italy's Foreign Minister, Lamberto Dini, for his part, expressed "extreme concern" over Kosovo and condemned Serbia for the "violence and brutality" of its forces there.
Mr. Dini returned this week from a trip to Iran, the first by a European Foreign Minister since the European Union lifted its ban on high-level visits there. He said that "the changes under way in Iran are substantial and significant," and that "this process is likely to continue" under Iran's new President, Mohammad Khatami.
Mr. Dini said he and Ms. Albright agreed that Mr. Khatami's policies "deserve encouragement, but at the same time we need to understand that deeds must follow."
Ms. Albright was more cautious, saying, "In our effort to encourage change, declaring success prematurely is the surest way to delay success indefinitely."
She said Washington is looking for "a pattern of action" that would demonstrate, over time, that Iran is moderating its behavior on three main points: the pursuit of weapons of mass destruction, support for terrorism and opposition to the Middle East peace effort.
She said the United States and the Europeans agreed on their aims in Iran, but "might have some difference in pacing and tactics."
Ms. Albright also met with Pope John Paul II at the Vatican for 30 minutes, a meeting that focused on his visit to Cuba in January.
The Pope clearly wanted to discuss Cuba with Ms. Albright, and has suggested using Cuba's promises of increasing religious freedoms as a way for Washington to measure political changes that could lead to a loosening of the American economic embargo. The Vatican opposes the sanctions.
Ms. Albright's spokesman, James P. Rubin, said that in the meeting with the Pope, she "stressed America's desire to find ways to help the Cuban people without strengthening their repressive Government."
An American official said later that Ms. Albright told the Pope that his visit to the island could be a "point of departure" for eventual political change in Cuba.
A Vatican statement said the two discussed Washington's "responsibilities on the world stage" and problems like the Middle East, Kosovo, ethnic clashes in Africa and the promotion of religious freedom in China. They had "a useful exchange of opinions," the Vatican said, a formulation implying that the two did not always agree.
The Vatican statement said the Pope and Ms. Albright devoted particular attention to "the future of Cuba following the Pope's recent visit to that country." After he returned, the Pope said he hoped the island would see the same type of democratic changes that took place in his native Poland after his first trip there as Pope in 1979.
An American official said Ms. Albright told the Pope that his visit to Poland "was crucial to the collapse of Communism there." Although Cuba and Poland were different, she said, his visit could have a similar impact.
A senior American official expressed hope that Cuba would follow up by allowing the kind of religious and political freedom "that one saw a signal of during the Pope's visit.". If such moves were "sustained and concrete," he said, "we would respond appropriately."
But he said it was too early to define what "appropriately" might mean, saying Ms. Albright was in "an assessment stage."
While reporters were in the Pope's private study, the Pope told Ms. Albright, "I shall do what you said." But officials did not explain the Pope's reference.
Ms. Albright began her conversation with the Pope in his native Polish, and then the two switched briefly to her native Czech. But they soon decided to continue in English, Vatican officials said.
As reporters left the frescoed library, the Pope asked Ms. Albright if she still has family in Prague. "Not anymore," she said, and then added, "I have a cousin there."
Ms. Albright gave the Pope a old, leather-bound book about the first Polish immigrants to the United States, while he gave her and her party rosaries and commemorative medals of his pontificate.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, on an official two-day visit to Italy, met for 30 minutes yesterday at the Vatican with Pope John Paul II. Officials said their talk focused largely on the pontiff's recent visit to Cuba. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: From Swagger to Statecraft: Hussein's Newfound Elan

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, March 6

 BODY:
From the onset of the latest gulf crisis, Iraq has had four goals: avoiding a military attack; casting doubt on the objectivity of Richard Butler, the Australian who heads the United Nations special commission charged with weapons inspections; drawing the United Nations into more active involvement, and insuring that the principle of easing economic sanctions on Iraq be accepted before President Saddam Hussein cooperates with inspections.
In conversations over the last three weeks in Baghdad and Amman with a score of Iraqi, Jordanian and United Nations officials and foreign diplomats, a consensus has emerged that Iraq has by and large come closer to achieving these goals. 
 "If the aim of the United States is to keep Saddam in a box," said an Asian ambassador in Baghdad who has extensive experience in Middle East affairs, "he is out of this box. He has received considerable sympathy from most of his neighbors. In addition, the person who built him a bridge was none less than the Secretary General of the United Nations, acting in the name of the international community."
It is not unrelated that in the last three weeks, at least six planeloads of medicine and food from the United Arab Emirates, Morocco, Qatar and Egypt have arrived at Baghdad's airport -- even though the sanctions prohibit flights except for those carrying inspectors. There have also, of course, been the flights bringing Russian officials and reporters covering the visit of Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General.
The sanctions imposed after the 1990 invasion of Kuwait are to remain in place until Iraq is judged in full compliance with the terms ending the 1991 gulf war. But at Iraq's borders, these strictures are clearly fraying.
Commercial shopping malls in Baghdad are filled with smuggled goods from Syria, Turkey and Iran -- and legal ones from Jordan, which buys a limited amount of Iraqi oil under a United Nations exemption to the embargo.
Many experts say President Hussein, having achieved some of his aims, is likely to give his diplomatic establishment, headed by Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz, greater license to continue managing the situation.
The team includes Foreign Minister Mohammad Said al-Sahhaf and his deputy, Riyadh al-Qaysi; Iraq's United Nations representqtive, Nizar Hamdoon, and the representative to UNESCO in Paris, Abdelamir al-Anbari.
There are also two senior Information Ministry officials who, against the advice of Iraq's security establishment, opened the door to foreign journalists -- some 2,000 of whom have poured into Baghdad.
For now, hard-line members of the Revolutionary Command Council, including Taha Yassin Ramadan, the council's vice chairman, and senior family members like President Hussein's son Uday, appear to have been eclipsed.
"The strategy was to turn this from a military confrontation to a political one," said Saad Nagi Jewad, a political scientist at the University of Baghdad. "Undoubtedly the palpable sympathy with Iraq this time around, particularly in the Arab world, and the clear opposition to a strike by Russia, France and China in the Security Council, played a role."
Some Iraqi officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, concede that they were surprised by the scale of the American military buildup.
And the Asian ambassador said President Hussein might have become convinced that any attack would be heavy and directed against him and his entourage.
But the experts also point out that, as one put it, the "style and manner" in which Mr. Annan approached President Hussein made a big difference.
"Now," one of the Iraqis said, "the concept of preserving the dignity of Iraq is there in writing."
This issue of respect is of paramount importance in Iraq's fiercely tribal and clannish society.
Four years after the end of the gulf war, a Central Intelligence Agency officer stationed in Amman mused in a long conversation about the American plan to bring down Mr. Hussein.
It was, he said, premised on "usurping" the President's authority in the eyes of his people, through food-distribution programs and a permanent system of monitoring entirely controlled by foreigners. The idea was to chip away at the edifice of leadership.
This policy proved successful episodically, provoking the kind of impetuous reactions from which the Iraqi leadership had to back down or be punished with military attacks or more sanctions.
But in the latest instance, things played out differently.
Those interviewed in Jordan and Iraq nearly unanimously said the new Iraqi style stressing cooperation and diplomacy is likely to persist over the next few weeks. This, they add, will offset the mood in the United States which, under pressure from Congress and the public, seems confrontational.
"We were surprised by how agile Tariq Aziz has been," said a senior adviser to King Hussein of Jordan who has managed several aspects of the Jordanian-Iraqi relationship over the last decade.
If Mr. Aziz did not have carte blanche from Mr. Hussein, the adviser added, "if you know Iraq well, you know he could not respond to each criticism from the United States on CNN and other media as swiftly and broadly as he was doing." The official said it was obvious that Mr. Aziz no longer needed to clear every statement with President Hussein. "This is not the Iraq I know," he added.
He also said Iraq's greatest challenge would be resisting the temptation to react to what he called "provocative behavior" by United Nations weapons inspectors.
But, he noted, this time there will be other "witnesses" from the United Nations. In fact the new agreement requires that the inspectors in locations like presidential palaces be accompanied by diplomats.
Regardless of the reasons, Iraq has seemed more open to foreigners in the last few weeks than in the preceding decade.
There is West European support for the conviction that Baghdad's new diplomatic approach will help Mr. Hussein make further inroads. A few days ago Gunter Verheugen, a foreign policy spokesman for Germany's opposition Social Democrats, said world opinion would require that the new agreement be accepted. He added, "The Americans would find themselves in dangerous isolation if, pointing to some trifling detail or another, they insisted on a military strike."
The French Defense Minister, Alain Richard, said that if Iraq abided by the terms of the agreement, and United Nations weapons inspections showed that Iraq no longer had any nuclear, biological or chemical weapons capability, economic sanctions should be lifted. This, French officials say, is the only long-term incentive for Mr. Hussein to comply with the arms agreements.

HEADLINE: Questions Following a Former Mayor

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 4

 BODY:
Two years ago, East Orange awarded about $300,000 in Federal housing money to a small nonprofit group to buy five rundown buildings. Last year, Federal officials found that the group had failed to properly account for the money, and ordered the city to repay it.
The matter -- like dozens of others handled each year by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development -- might have been quietly resolved but for one thing: the Mayor of East Orange at the time was Cardell Cooper. And Mr. Cooper, who chose not to seek re-election, is now being considered by the White House for a top job at HUD. 
 While no one is suggesting that this could derail Mr. Cooper's expected nomination as assistant secretary for community planning and development, officials of the Clinton Administration said privately that it had become part of the "vetting process" that all potential nominees go through.
Regional HUD officials referred all questions about their review of the grant money to the White House. Officials at the White House would not comment, nor would they make Mr. Cooper available to respond to questions.
News of the review also comes as the State Attorney General is investigating East Orange's Water Commission and as the city continues to search for $10 million in revenues to balance its budget.
Mr. Cooper, a 16-year veteran of New Jersey politics, served as a New Jersey coordinator of the Clinton re-election campaign in 1996. The housing department job, in which he would oversee the Community Development Block Grant program, homeless shelter assistance and enterprise communities, is not the first administration post for which he has been mentioned. There were reports last year that he was being considered to run the Superfund program in the Environmental Protection Administration until some Republican senators who would have to vote to confirm him for the post raised questions about his qualifications. He is now a $455-a-day consultant to the environmental agency.
Many of Mr. Cooper's supporters suggested that the issue over the HUD review was the result of the fractious local politics of the city and the desire of some of Mr. Cooper's longtime opponents to embarrass him.
"We have complete confidence that when the process is complete Cardell Cooper will be nominated," said Jamie Fox, a spokesman for Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, one of Mr. Cooper's main backers for the housing post.
One of Cooper's opponents is the current Mayor of East Orange, Robert Bowser. Mr. Bowser, a Democrat who defeated a candidate supported by Mr. Cooper in last year's Democratic primary, denied that he was trying to politically embarrass his predecessor. But he said that he had been troubled by the "laxness" he found upon taking over City Hall in January.
Mr. Bowser said that Mr. Cooper had left him with an unapproved budget with a funding gap of $10 million, largely due to unrealistic revenue estimates. In addition, the State Attorney General is investigating a decision by the city's water commissioners, all of whom were appointed by Mayor Cooper, to allow the top engineer in the Water Department to resign and take with him six of his assistants. The engineer and his assistants formed a private company that was then hired by the Water Commission to manage the city's water system and the water systems of at least six other towns, two of which had previously contracted with the city.
"We haven't been able to send out tax bills because we don't have a budget," Mr. Bowser said. He added that questions raised by the Attorney General's investigation had for the time being closed off one source of money -- some Water Department revenues -- that could have balanced the city's budget. "We knew there were problems. They are just wider and deeper than we thought."
The Water Department arrangement has been challenged as anti-competitive in a civil lawsuit filed by a private water company as well as in proceedings before the state's Board of Public Utilities. And last week, said Mayor Bowser, the State Attorney General's office seized records concerning the transactions.
A spokesman for the Attorney General would not comment on any investigation. But Anthony Scillia, the former chief engineer of the Water Commission who now heads Utility Management and Engineering Inc., confirmed that state investigators had been looking into allegations that there was an ethics violation in the arrangement between his company and the commission.
"There is no conflict," said Mr. Scillia, adding that his company has made it possible for the local water agency to sell their billing and management expertise to other cities throughout the state under contracts that will bring East Orange a projected $99 million over the next 20 years. "Mayor Cooper was supportive of what the Water Commission had done because we were the only agency bringing in new revenue and creating tax relief."
Mr. Bowser said he is preparing a speech to East Orange residents next week detailing what he has found in his first 60 days in office and explaining some of the reasons for the city's plight.
"I will make it clear that where the problems began was with Cardell Cooper," he said. "We're not out to get him but this is not a problem that I created."

HEADLINE: Fierce Bidding Expected on 2 Sites in Times Square

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The dilapidated storefronts and pornographic theaters in Times Square have given way in recent years to two musical theaters, a giant music and entertainment store, splashy theme restaurants, and soon, Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum and 50 movie screens.
Now, Prudential Insurance Company of America is selling control of the last two of four development sites in Times Square where the insurance company was supposed to build office towers. Bids are being taken on Wednesday in what promises to be a fierce battle among old-line real estate families and their new rivals, the financial operators and publicly traded real estate companies that emerged in recent years. Real estate executives and bankers expect the buyers to pay as much as $240 million and to build a pair of skyscrapers. 
 The parcels are particularly attractive because development sites are scarce in Manhattan and these properties are accompanied by extraordinary tax breaks.
"These are probably the best sites in the city available for development," said William Adamski, co-director of real estate banking at Credit Suisse First Boston, which is negotiating with several prospective bidders.
Real estate brokers and bankers expected the bidders to include George Klein, Prudential's former partner who is now teamed up with Blackstone Partners, and his rival, Douglas Durst, whose family once opposed the state's redevelopment of Times Square, as well as Steven C. Witkoff, Daniel Brodsky, Vornado Realty Trust, TrizecHahn Corporation; Mortimer Zuckerman, publisher of The Daily News and chairman of Boston Properties, and Jerry Speyer, chairman of Tishman Speyer Properties.
The first and perhaps more valuable site is at the southwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, which is now occupied by the Disney Store. According to a sale document issued by Prudential, a builder would get property tax breaks worth $9.5 million a year, or $262.6 million over 20 years, on a planned 40-story office tower. The other parcel is across the street, a small block bound by Seventh Avenue and Broadway between 41st and 42d Streets, and has tax breaks valued at $236 million over 20 years for a proposed 49-story tower.
As the bidding date draws near, the developers also have been chasing potential tenants for the prospective towers. Disney wants to retain its retail store at the corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street and lease up to 100,000 square feet of office space, real estate executives said. Home Box Office, which occupies 650,000 square feet of space in Manhattan, has been looking for a new home in Times Square, as has ESPN, the cable sports station.
The sale of the two parcels would mark Prudential's exit from Times Square after a 12-year run. In the early 1980's, the city and the state selected the insurance company and the developer George Klein to build the four towers that were expected to transform Times Square. But after a series of delays and the recession in the early 1990's, Prudential lost its desire to be a developer.
Prudential wanted only to recover the $433 million it had spent on condemnation, land acquisition, architectural plans, theater renovation and the development of retail space. Ultimately, the revival of Times Square was led by media and entertainment companies, rather than office towers. The insurance company decided in 1996 to sell control of one site on the east side of Broadway, between 42d and 43d Streets, to Mr. Durst, who is building a 50-story tower. It sold the second site, on the west side of Seventh Avenue, between 42d and 43d Streets, to Reuters and the Rudin real estate family.
The plans for two more towers does not enthrall the Municipal Art Society, a civic group that has long opposed oversized projects in Times Square.
"The office towers only became possible after entertainment pulled Times Square out of the muck," Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society, said. "We'll now get two big, blunt office towers on two scrawny sites. Given the level of public subsidies, New Yorkers should get some fabulous buildings, not just two towers like any others in Manhattan."

LENGTH: 1276 words

HEADLINE: Africans Resentful as Asia Rakes In Aid

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, March 7

 BODY:
There was a slightly forced quality to the smiles of officials from the International Monetary Fund and the Ivory Coast Government when they met here last month to sign a major pact on restructuring this country's ailing economy.
Ivory Coast had just been granted $2 billion in new loans. But to get there, the Government had negotiated for nine months, finally agreeing to stinging measures that gave the uncomfortable impression that economic policy would henceforth be made at the fund's headquarters in Washington. 
 Under the new "structural adjustment program," Ivory Coast must quickly complete a sell-off of state-owned companies under which everything from water and electricity to telephone service has already been auctioned to foreign investors. The Government must also freeze hiring and institute strict guidelines for promotion on merit.
And in perhaps the most politically painful measure, in a country that is the world's largest cocoa producer and seventh-largest exporter of coffee, the agreement stipulates that the Government must get out of commodity marketing altogether, removing the hand of politicians from the most lucrative game in the land.
Across Asia, similarly sweeping steps have been imposed by the International Monetary Fund and its affiliate, the World Bank, in recent weeks, provoking demonstrations against those institutions in South Korea and Thailand and riots against austerity measures in Indonesia.
But seen from Africa, where many countries like Ivory Coast have been following "adjustment" programs for two decades, the rush to help Asia's distressed economies with quick loan packages worth tens of billions of dollars looks more like a genuine rescue effort than what appears to many here to be a stingy and never-ending program of life-support for Africa.
"We have observed the speedy reaction to Asia, and seen the huge sums of money they have been able to come up with almost instantaneously, often bending the rules pretty freely," said Niamien Ngoran, Ivory Coast's Finance Minister. "When it comes to us, our negotiations can drag on for months while they split hairs and act very finicky. One can easily get the impression of a double standard."
World Bank and I.M.F. officials say the size and speed of their response to the crisis in Asian countries is justified by the importance of their economies to the global financial system. They also say that had more African countries embraced economic liberalization years ago when the first structural adjustment programs in Africa were begun, rather than resisting change, this continent would not find itself as marginalized as it is today.
"Africa has got to find a way to get more capital to flow here," said Shigeo Katsu, the World Bank's director for Ivory Coast. "Right now this continent represents a very small portion of world investment. If we had seen changes this sweeping 10 years ago, maybe that would be different now."
But critics of the World Bank and I.M.F. say that even those African countries that have been praised in the past as star "pupils" of the international institutions' reform programs have proved poor performers over time, calling into question the validity of the institutions' approach to the continent.
Zimbabwe and Ghana, for example, widely cited in the 1980's and early 1990's as World Bank success stories, are both in financial distress today. In Zimbabwe, gross domestic product is lower now than when its structural adjustment program began.
"If you go by World Bank projections, sub-Saharan Africa will be back to the levels of per-capita income that it had in the 1970's by the year 2005," said Kevin Watkins, a senior policy adviser at Oxfam International, the British relief advocacy group. "This is a very poor record, and whether you argue that the problem is with implementation or approach, the fact is that the World Bank's policies in Africa have not worked."
In the past, critics of World Bank and I.M.F. programs have said their reliance on austerity measures like higher interest rates has proved devastating to African countries where governments, however inefficient, typically account for most economic activity. Slashing government budgets in this context has often meant not just higher unemployment but also fewer vaccination programs or schools.
In response to these criticisms, the World Bank has slowed its lending for big projects like roads and dams, which often ended as costly failures, and stepped up its investment in "human capital."
In practice, this has meant providing more money for schools and health care. Still, according to World Bank data, Africa is the only continent where the percentage of school-age children who do not attend school is increasing, making it unlikely that it will be in a better position to compete in the future.
Where international financial institutions could arguably make the biggest impact in Africa is also where they have, in contrast to their swift reaction to Asia's crisis, moved slowly: writing off Africa's huge debt. In a fairly typical example, Tanzania spends six times as much paying off its debt -- most of which is owed to international financial institutions or to Western governments -- than it does for education.
A program of debt relief for Africa's most heavily indebted countries was worked out last year after years of discussion, but countries are not eligible until they have completed six years of stringently monitored structural adjustment.
"This is clearly an area where we have failed these countries," said a senior World Bank official with responsibility for African programs. "The political will to do better just did not exist."
The speed with which the international financial system has raced to reverse Asia's financial slide, and the huge amounts of money already committed to the effort, are not the only things that distinguish Africa's relationship to the World Bank and I.M.F. from that of Asia. There is also a huge difference in the reaction of the populations of both continents.
People in many Asian countries have begun to demonize the fund as a cruel institution that threatens their job security, or will allow foreigners to take over their companies. But in Africa, where political pluralism has begun to take hold in this decade, the institutions are no longer seen as ogres.
In recent years, few countries in Africa have seen the kinds of street demonstrations or denunciations of the I.M.F. that have become common in Asia. And where demonstrations against economic hardship have occurred, as in Zimbabwe recently, the Government, rather than some sinister foreign hand, has been the target.
Instead, opposition politicians and newspapers in many African countries have taken to prodding governments to respect the terms of their structural adjustment programs, and chiding those that do not.
For many, this change is less an expression of confidence that the formulas for economic restructuring imposed from Washington will work now, or indeed ever will, but rather a feeling that the scrutiny attached to multilateral lending helps limit corruption and increases government accountability.
"For years, under one-party rule, we were told that our difficult straits were due to the austerity imposed from abroad," said Diegou Bailly, editor of the Ivory Coast daily Le Jour. "In fact, the I.M.F. and others were lending money to us blindly, and it was being spent for purposes that had nothing to do with the reasons for the loans. Today, there is a new feeling of scrutiny, and even if there is still some waste, the population won't pay as dearly."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1300 words

HEADLINE: Little Rock Growing Weary Of the 4-Year Siege by Starr

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 5

 BODY:
Skip Rutherford, one of this city's most faithful Friends of Bill, and William H. Kennedy 3d, a former associate White House counsel, were sharing lunch a few months ago at La Scala, an Italian restaurant in Little Rock's Hillcrest neighborhood, when an acquaintance stopped by their table.
"This guy walks over," Mr. Rutherford recalled, "and says, 'Are y'all just catching up?' And I said, 'Yeah, but unless you've been subpoenaed, you can't sit at this table.' " The man grinned at the quip and began to walk away, then spun around and returned to the table. "You know," he said, "I got mine yesterday." 
 As Little Rock has been transformed from the permanent home of Bill Clinton into the temporary home of Kenneth W. Starr, this intimate little town has increasingly taken on the feel of an occupied state. After four years of high-profile trials and endless rounds of grand jury testimony, Mr. Starr's investigation into the Whitewater land deal and its many offshoots has become so pervasive that few members of the city's political, legal and business elite have escaped its tentacles.
As Mr. Rutherford's story demonstrates, subpoenas have become as ubiquitous as Clinton-Gore bumper stickers in this city of 175,000 people. And the subpoenas, in turn, have created a cottage industry for the city's lawyers, some of whom have been retained by as many as six grand jury witnesses.
At the Little Rock Club the other day, William H. Bowen, the recently retired dean of the law school at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock, looked around the room at the lunching lawyers and ticked off name after name of those with Whitewater clients.
The investigations have profoundly changed the politics of the city and the state by bringing down a former municipal judge, David Hale, a former Mayor, Webster L. Hubbell, and a Governor, Jim Guy Tucker, a Democrat who was replaced by a Republican, Mike Huckabee.
They have created a strong campaign issue for Nate Coulter, a Democratic lawyer who is winning attention in his race for United States Senate this year by calling for strict limits on the powers of the independent counsel.
"All these people leading the investigation are from elsewhere," Mr. Coulter said, "and they've been led to believe that this is some sort of rogue state run by rogue people and that it was O.K. to come in here and treat everybody like criminals."
The investigations have touched hundreds of average residents, who now swap horror stories about the legal fees they have incurred or the inconveniences they have suffered while searching through voluminous records at the insistence of the independent counsel's office.
Susan Pfeifer, the owner of Design Center, a small shop in a stylish neighborhood known as the Heights, recalled that it took more than a week of looking to respond to a subpoena that requested records of all purchases made by Mr. Hubbell, who pleaded guilty in 1994 to charges stemming from the overbilling of legal clients.
"They wanted to know his buying habits, and so we were taking boxes of credit card receipts home at night," Ms. Pfeifer said.
"We came up with about $1,000 over five years. I was really outraged."
As when any community feels threatened by an outside force, Little Rock has responded to Mr. Starr's persistence with equal parts frustration, revulsion and fear.
Bumper stickers have cropped up around town urging: "Kenneth Starr -- Go Home." Others joke: "I Slept with Kenneth Starr."
"I'd like to tar and feather the man," said Lisa Matthews, who designed the "Go Home" stickers. "He's hurt a lot of people in our town, and to what end?"
But many here are far more circumspect, fearing that public pronouncements against Mr. Starr and his colleagues will simply buy them trouble, perhaps at great expense.
"People just want to lay low," said one prominent businessman, who insisted on anonymity. "There's a feeling that if you say too much there's no telling what these guys may do."
The independent counsel's office declined requests to be interviewed for this article.
The sense of siege here is reinforced by the compactness of the place, and the rapidity with which word travels, particularly among longtime allies of President Clinton. It is the kind of network that allows Mr. Rutherford, who serves Mr. Clinton in Little Rock as the Central Intelligence Agency does in Moscow, to revel playfully in his ability to know the constant whereabouts of every visiting reporter in town.
The notion that the city is under attack by outsiders is buttressed by the location of the independent counsel's office on the fringes of town in a three-story office building of dark glass and gray stone. It is about as distant as possible, both in miles and in character, from the establishment's downtown gathering spots, like the cozy bar at the grand old Capital Hotel and the well-appointed dining rooms of the Little Rock Club, which overlook the Arkansas River from the 30th floor of the First Commercial Bank building.
Mr. Starr, who is based in Washington, where another grand jury is impaneled, shuttles regularly to Little Rock to consult with the five prosecutors in his office here. The lawyers are assisted by a staff of five and a sizable contingent of F.B.I. agents.
The two worlds come together at the old stone Federal courthouse on West Capitol Street, where the Whitewater grand jury meets two or three times a week on the fourth floor.
The sidewalk outside the courthouse has become the site of a semipermanent news media encampment, nicknamed "the beach." Photographers lounge in folding chairs outside the main entrance, tossing away novels and grabbing their cameras whenever an unidentified person approaches the front door. As they are shooting, they ask the person whether he or she is a witness for the Whitewater grand jury. Some respond. Others do not.
Like airport police officers searching for drug couriers based on a universal profile, the photographers and television producers look for Whitewater witnesses by noticing their attire (a topcoat on a temperate day is a sure sign of an out-of-town witness) and their level of nervousness. Those who do not voluntarily give their names may have their license plates traced. "People are starting to take luggage tags off of briefcases, which I find very annoying," said Ron Blome, a freelance producer under contract for NBC News.
This week, The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, Little Rock's morning newspaper, ran photographs of two unidentified men entering the courthouse, who, it turns out, were there for an unrelated case.
If there has been a silver lining for Little Rock, it has been that the constant presence of the national news gatherers has been good for business at hotels and restaurants. Many hotels are raising rates, demanding advance payments and imposing stiff cancellation fees for the Paula Corbin Jones trial, which is scheduled to begin on May 27. Ms. Jones's civil suit charges that Mr. Clinton made a crude sexual advance toward her in a Little Rock hotel room in 1991, when he was Governor and she was a state employee. Mr. Clinton has denied it.
Mayor Jim Dailey says he hasheard complaints of price gouging, and he has already killed a deal that would have allowed a local businessman to charge exorbitant rates to television networks wanting to set up camera positions on a sidewalk across the street from the Federal courthouse.
But any economic gain for city businesses, the Mayor suggested, has been far offset by his city's communal angst.
"It's become a very threatening force," Mayor Dailey said of the investigations. "The entanglements of this thing are just so pervasive now. They touch so many lives in our community. People are just asking how far does this have to go."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Susan Pfeifer, a shop owner who received a subpoena from Kenneth W. Starr, with a sticker that reflects the exasperation in Arkansas' capital. (Karen E. Segrave for The New York Times)(pg. 22)

PUB-DATE: March 8, 1998

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 2148 words

HEADLINE: Warily, Baseball Prepares to Make Murdoch Owner of the Dodgers

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
On Feb. 5, on the Fox studio lot in Los Angeles, three baseball executives, including the sport's acting commissioner, Bud Selig, conducted one of the more critical interviews the game had ever undertaken. The topic was the proposed $320 million sale of the Dodgers, one of the game's fabled franchises, to the buyer seated across the lunch table: Rupert Murdoch.
Baseball's wariness about Mr. Murdoch was deep. The prospective owner, Mr. Murdoch's Fox Group, has extraordinarily deep pockets, and the baseball executives feared its ability to spend without constraint could accelerate the payroll explosions that endanger the sport's finances. More important, however, was the influence of Mr. Murdoch's company over the local television rights to nearly two dozen baseball clubs; granting Fox the franchise, and with it access to the financial statements of all the 29 other clubs, could instantly make Mr. Murdoch the game's most powerful figure. 
 The baseball contingent emerged from the two-hour face-off impressed but still wary, and that apprehension suffuses the sport as its owners pore over an investigative report and financial documents trying to determine Mr. Murdoch's makeup and motives.
But interviews with club executives and baseball officials indicate that, absent a late bout of nerves, the sport will by March 19 formally approve the sale of the Dodgers -- the most expensive purchase of a sports franchise ever -- to an outfit run by an aggressive, continent-hopping dealmaker with no sentimental or historic attachment to the country's most tradition-bound sport.
If baseball does welcome Mr. Murdoch, though, it will do so with fingers crossed -- that rules governing revenue sharing or precluding outside licensing or sponsorship deals will not be broken and that, in short, Mr. Murdoch will not run roughshod over their game.
"I can't judge whether he would be a good or a bad owner," said Michael Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, which owns the controlling stake in the Anaheim Angels.
"But I don't think he would not follow the rules."
In 1957, Walter O'Malley convulsed baseball's economics by moving the Dodgers from Brooklyn to California's virgin major league market, proving that even the most beloved team is a bottom-line business property to be exploited for its strategic value.
Now, Mr. O'Malley's son, Peter, who had grown disaffected with the sport's other owners in recent years, is about to unsettle baseball again -- leaving the sport with the disquieting parting gift of selling his legacy to a media powerhouse known for shaking up every business he acquires.
The deal for the Dodgers -- including Dodger Stadium and its 300 acres, the Dodgertown spring training site and minor league team in Vero Beach, Fla., and a training complex in the Dominican Republic -- closes an era when families like the Yawkeys and Griffiths and Stonehams made owning a baseball team their exclusive business. Soaring player salaries have routed them, and they have been replaced primarily by investors made wealthy elsewhere and giant corporations.
The Dodgers' prospective owner, the Fox Group, is part of Mr. Murdoch's publicly traded multinational media empire, The News Corpation, which has annual revenues exceeding $11 billion.
The opposition of five of the other 14 National League teams would block Fox's purchase of the Dodgers, but most baseball officials suspect that even such modest resistance will not materialize.
"Fox was the ideal successor to our family," Peter O'Malley said recently. "I'm at peace."
 
'A Big Load Of Influence'
With media interests on five continents, Rupert Murdoch comes to baseball with enormous financial clout.
He owns network television rights for baseball, the National Football League and the National Hockey League.
His FX and Fox Sports Net networks carry games for $43 million a year. His substantial investment in baseball, then, is seen either as a vote of confidence in the sport's recovery from labor strife or worrisome leverage over his future partners in ownership.
But it is Mr. Murdoch's consolidation of the once balkanized universe of regional sports networks into the Fox Sports Net that worries people.
Mr. Murdoch has parlayed alliances with Liberty Media, a unit of the cable television giant Tele-Communications Incorporated, and Cablevision Systems, into ownership stakes in 20 regional sports networks like Fox Sports West in Los Angeles, Fox Sports South in Atlanta and the MSG Network in New York.
In Los Angeles, the network, through its two Fox Sports West outlets, has the television rights to the Dodgers, Angels, Lakers, Clippers, Kings and Anaheim Mighty Ducks. In all, Mr. Murdoch pays at least $100 million a year for the local cable television rights of 22 baseball clubs.
No team owner with media interests possesses such influence. Disney owns 80 percent of ESPN, a national rights holder. Time Warner, the Atlanta Braves' owner, televises Braves game over its TBS cable network. The Tribune Company owns the Cubs and WGN-TV, which carries Cubs games, and five stations, like Channel 11 in New York, that televise the local games of six teams, like the Yankees.
"He's going to wield a big load of influence," said Tony Tavares, the Angels' president.
"Every team is supposed to have one vote, but can he influence more than one? If he pays enough for a team's rights, is it tantamount to his having a profit participation in another team?"
Baseball has long been suspicious of media companies' owning teams because they can offset club losses with profits from their main businesses.
Baseball was so concerned about the impact on local team revenues by the satellite delivery of Braves and Cubs games by the TBS and WGN superstations, respectively, that it imposed a separate fee structure for them. But now, entertainment goliaths like Fox, Time Warner, Tribune and Disney view baseball as essential assets.
"What are we in baseball if not programming and software for media companies?" said Eddie Einhorn, vice chairman of the Chicago White Sox.
"Sure, there's concern about their influence, but they've made the market for sports teams."

Tangled Holdings And Interests
Local baseball is good business for Fox. Ratings are stronger than they are nationally, so advertising is easy to sell. Underlying Fox's acquisition of the Dodgers is the guarantee that Dodger games will be the bulwark of Fox Sports West.
"We'll be a good owner, because we have such a big bet on baseball," said Chase Carey, chairman of Fox Television.
"We're already in a major partnership with baseball. We have good relationships with owners. We're part of the family."
Fox has won high marks from football and hockey officials. But Fox does not own teams in those sports, although an alliance with Cablevision brought Fox a 20 percent stake in the Knicks and Rangers.
"We respected the N.F.L. for what it was and brought new things to it," Mr. Carey said.
"The Dodgers are a unique franchise in a unique sport, and our goal is to bring new levels of excitement and to respect and enjoy what's there."
But some teams want Fox to stay in the television business.
Larry Lucchino, the Padres' president, said that "Fox's disproportionate influence on two dozen teams through its TV deals creates an opportunity to manipulate the arrangement for political purposes. Fox can say, 'If you don't vote for X, you'll have trouble on your TV deal.' "
The Padres and other teams worry that as an owner, Fox, controlled by Murdoch, will have access to their financial statements and use that knowledge at future television rights negotiations. Or, knowing how important local rights payments are, teams are concerned that Fox can influence the signing of free agents through well-timed extensions of cable rights deals.
Last year, Fox Sports Rocky Mountain extended its rights deal with the Colorado Avalanche hockey team just in time to help pay the team's star, Joe Sakic, a $15 million signing bonus and keep him from the Rangers. In that instance, the shared interests for Fox and the Rockies were benign. But it was an example of how, if circumstances were different, Fox's array of overlapping holdings and interests could affect critical decisions and even perhaps competitive balance.
Fox discounts any trepidation. "The teams have the business we need and can get rid of us for another competitor," said Jim Martin, executive vice president of the Fox/Liberty Networks.
"If we try to influence anybody's votes, the teams have other options and can tell us to go to hell."
Baseball's sense of Mr. Murdoch's full candor was shaken slightly when owners learned that T.C.I., one of Fox's television partners, had had an undisclosed option for half-ownership of the Dodgers, although T.C.I. waived it.
And Mr. Murdoch's audacious creation of a new rugby league in Australia made some baseball executives question whether he would ignore any rules that constrained him.
Three years ago, Mr. Murdoch launched his own rugby league by spending vast sums to poach 80 star players and several teams from the long-established Australian Rugby League. Rugby league, Australia's most popular sport, was deemed crucial programming for Mr. Murdoch's fledgling pay-TV service.
"It was viewed as treachery," said John Brady, a spokesman for the A.R.L., which has since merged with Mr. Murdoch's money-losing league. Now, Mr. Brady said, the old-line A.R.L. views Mr. Murdoch with grudging admiration for having the vision to sense the expanding popularity of professional rugby.
One baseball official summarized the concerns: "Let him into the club, he can cause problems. He does what he wants and he's litigious."
Fox has verbally agreed with baseball to abide by constraints on its behavior as an owner, including not beaming Dodger games to Japan on Mr. Murdoch's JSkyB TV satellite network. Baseball wants to insure those television revenues would be shared.

The Changing Face Of Dodger Stadium
Despite having a marquee team that drew three million customers a year, the family-owned Dodgers were increasingly an anachronism. Thus Mr. O'Malley had many reasons to sell the Dodgers: estate planning for his three children and his sister Terry Seidler's 10; $35 million in losses since 1994 and dissatisfaction that Los Angeles pulled its support for his plan to build a pro football stadium near Dodger Stadium.
But, Mr. O'Malley said, greater foresight might have kept the franchise his.
"The storms of the past four years caused central revenues to go down," he said, referring to money from networks and sponsors.
"I thought they'd come back earlier. I miscalculated. If I were accurate, we would have been fine."
But he is surrendering to modern sports finance -- and nearly pristine Dodger Stadium will sport advertising signs. This season, some field-level box seats will be removed for rotating signs that will cost 17 advertisers $200,000 each.
"Changes were coming with or without me," Mr. O'Malley said.
The planned luxury suites will be easier for Fox to finance.
Seventy-five to 80 suites should lease for at least $200,000 each, the peak price in baseball, the industry publication Team Marketing Report said.
Fox will modernize the stadium and add retailing, a hall of fame and an interactive entertainment center to compete with Disney's $110 million modernization of Anaheim Stadium.
"A lot can be done to create value that the Dodgers haven't done," said Mr. Carey, the Fox Television chairman. But he said Fox has no intention of selling Dodgertown and moving spring training west.
Mr. O'Malley speaks with a calm reserve, barely showing emotion as his Dodger epoch ends. But he is quietly adamant that he chose the right buyer.
"We checked them out," he said. "I talked to the N.F.L. I talked to people in baseball. Everybody without exception said Fox has done everything they said they would, and more. They've been an excellent partner."
Mr. O'Malley, who insists he has not succumbed to nostalgia, probably will not stay long to see the changes. He has no contract.
"I'm looking ahead," he said, in the final days of his 29-year tenure as the Dodgers' president and his family's 57-year connection to the Dodgers -- which began when his father became the team's lawyer.
"No, I'm not going to look back at my first day at Vero Beach or watching Dodger Stadium being constructed," he said. So there will be no warm memories of Koufax or Jackie or his days as a Dodgertown counselor.
Clark Griffith, whose family owned the Washington Senators and the Minnesota Twins, said, "I sense a great sadness in Peter that he has to sell."
Not so, Mr. O'Malley said. Maybe $320 million is sufficient balm against melancholy.
"I'm going to support this team," he said, "whether I'm here or not."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Same Old, Same Old For Two Top Teams

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The French say it, "Plus ca change, plus c'est la meme chose." The Atlanta Braves and the Cleveland Indians might not be able to translate that saying into the language of balls and strikes, but it fits these two teams perfectly: the more they change, the more they stay the same.
Both teams made major changes last year, but both continued to dominate their divisions. The Indians reached the World Series; the Braves fell one step short. Now both have made significant changes again and await the outcome. 
 The Braves have turned over three-fourths of a veteran infield and have a new center fielder and leadoff hitter. The Indians have half of a new infield and a new center fielder.
Earlier in spring training, the Braves' general manager, John Schuerholz, said he talked at a staff meeting about the need to manage change effectively in the business that baseball has become.
"We're talking about managing change with the roster, managing change in the economic circumstances in the industry," he said. "Change is thrust upon us far more frequently than it used to be. That stability isn't there. There's a lot of roster flux. We have to make moves to move guys off so we can bring a guy in we want."
Just before the start of last season, the Braves and the Indians made a major trade. Center fielder Kenny Lofton went from Cleveland to Atlanta, and outfielders David Justice and Marquis Grissom moved to the Indians. Cleveland had previously acquired third baseman Matt Williams and let outfielder Albert Belle leave as a free agent.
This winter, Lofton, a free agent, returned to the Indians, who traded Grissom and swapped third basemen, Williams for Travis Fryman. They also added Geronimo Berroa as the designated hitter and Shawon Dunston to fill a hole at second base.
The Braves moved Andruw Jones to center to replace Lofton, but that was simple compared with their infield maneuvers. Andres Galarraga has replaced Fred McGriff at first base, Walt Weiss has taken over from Jeff Blauser at shortstop, and Tony Graffanino and Keith Lockhart are the platoon that has replaced Mark Lemke at second.
Schuerholz credited Manager Bobby Cox with doing a great job at incorporating new players.
"One of the things Bobby has done more effectively than anybody I've seen," Schuerholz said, "is to deal with the changes that come to a roster every year and assimilate an effective group of guys every year. He does it every year. We've changed our roster substantially over the years since we won our first pennant in 1991. Even the pitching has changed. It has remained stable, but we have different guys."
Cox, in his 16th year of managing in the major leagues, said, "It's easy to assimilate guys like Galarraga and Walt Weiss to your team." He added, "We've always lost good people, but we've always got good people in return."
The manager said he has never done anything to ingrain the Braves' system in the newcomers, but he acknowledged that he does talk to them more than the returning players. By design, Cox said, he talked to the new players individually before the exhibition schedule began. "I let them know their roles, what we expect, stuff like that," he said. "We do all that in a meeting as a whole team but not specifically what we expect from them personally. We try to work out the kinks real quick. If there's going to be a problem, we try to talk about it early at least. Some guys might get the feeling they're going to be everyday players or play more than other guys or whatever, but we try to lay it out immediately and see what happens."
Mike Hargrove has the responsibility of making John Hart's acquisitions work in Cleveland. Assimilating new players, he said, is a major part of the job today.
"A manager's job is to get them together, get them to feel good about each other and do it as quickly as possible," Hargrove said. "So far, so good. We have a system we believe in. We believe it works. We're able to plug in people in that system. So far it has perpetuated itself."
Melding the newcomers keeps Hargrove busy in spring training, especially in the early days.
"We make a point to try to talk to everybody during the day," he said. "You wouldn't think that would be hard to do, but it is. You have 55 guys out there. If you spend 10 minutes with each guy, that eats up your day. We at least try to say, 'Hi, how you doing, how's it going, getting enough swings?' We let them know we're in this together. We care about them."
Like Cox, Hargrove said his job is easier when the new players are veterans.
"When you trade Matt Williams for Travis Fryman, that's about as even a trade as you can get," he said. "We've been able to sustain the talent, as opposed to trading Matt Williams and we have to start a Russell Branyan at third. The kid's got a lot of talent, but he's a kid."
On the other hand, Hargrove said, sometimes it can be tougher to bring in veterans "because they can be used to doing things a certain way."
 
The New Lofton
For all of the success Bobby Cox and the Braves have had in meshing new players, Kenny Lofton proved to be an exception last year. Lofton, a talented center fielder in the American League, left his new teammates disillusioned by his play and his seemingly negative attitude.
His Atlanta teammates particularly noticed the way he played center and the way he ran the bases. His reputation for both in the A.L. had been impeccable. But as one member of the Braves said, "He was awful" and "he was overrated."
In the outfield, team members said, Lofton often failed to get a good jump on fly balls, and too often when he reached balls, he did not hold them or, in baseball parlance, he fought them. On the bases, he tried to score when he shouldn't have and didn't try to score when he should have.
In 1996, Lofton was successful stealing bases 75 of 92 times, an 82 percent success ratio. Last year, he was safe only 27 of 47 times, a 57 percent rate. No one in the major leagues was thrown out as many times. He did not endear himself to the team or to a new set of umpires by constantly complaining about umpires' out calls on his attempted steals and on called strikes. Lofton did suffer from a groin injury and missed six weeks around midseason, but even then he was disgruntled about the team's medical staff. And he did not win any friends when he was spotted dunking basketballs when he was supposedly hurt.
But Lofton is back with the Indians, and he apparently has responded to the friendly surroundings.
"It's obvious that he wasn't entirely happy over there," said Mike Hargrove, Cleveland's manager, "but he doesn't gripe and moan about it. He hasn't knocked anyone. I respect a person who doesn't do that."
Instead of being negative, Hargrove said, Lofton has worked as hard this spring as he has ever seen him work. "Kenny has always worked hard in certain areas, but there are other areas that Kenny might have taken for granted," Hargrove said. "I think Kenny took the health of his legs for granted for a number of years. I think last year showed him he's vulnerable just like everybody else."
Lofton, the manager said, worked with a personal trainer during the winter. "He's done a lot of work on his legs; that's obvious," Hargrove said. "He's running a lot right now. Kenny's also stepped up and is trying to assume a leadership role. It's the first time we've seen that. It's good that he's asserting himself."
 
Sign on Dotted Yankee Line
 After Ricardo Aramboles and Orlando Hernandez, can Guillermo Quiroz be far behind?
In the last two weeks, the Yankees have signed Aramboles, a 17-year-old Dominican pitcher, who had been declared a free agent because the commissioner's office ruled that he signed with the Florida Marlins before he was old enough, and Hernandez, who defected from Cuba.
Quiroz is a 16-year-old Venezuelan catcher who will be eligible to sign next July 2. He worked out for scouts at the Mets' camp at Port St. Lucie, Fla., last Thursday. The report of one scout who attended the workout: "He's well-developed for his age, he's a well-below-average runner, has below-average arm strength, shows power in batting practice." But, the scout added: "the way the business operates he will probably command a decent bonus. In that kind of atmosphere you create a competition where somebody is going to want to beat somebody else."
That somebody may well be the Yankees, who gave Aramboles a $1.52 million bonus to sign and Hernandez $6.6 million over four years.

HEADLINE: A Bigger NATO Is Good for Europe

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You express doubts about expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (editorials, March 1 and 5). If you truly believe that NATO's "core purpose, defense against the Soviet bloc, is obsolete," you should take the next step and propose that we disband the alliance altogether. But if you concede that in a dangerous world the United States still needs an alliance with Europe, you need to come up with a better rationale for closing NATO's doors to some of our closest European friends. 
 You rightly say that "East-West divisions are evaporating." Yet you do not ask what would happen to this trend if we told 200 million people in a dozen Central and Eastern European countries that they can never be part of Europe's pre-eminent security alliance just because of Russia's outdated suspicions.
You are right that the stability of Europe "depends heavily on whether Russia completes its transition to democracy and a market economy." But you forget that Russia will not become a modern European power if it continues to look upon Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic as a buffer zone that separates it from the rest of Europe.
You sell Russia short when you assume that Russian attitudes about Central Europe will never change. You ignore the progress Russia has made, with the United States, on arms control: from accelerating the destruction of weapons under the Start 1 treaty, to agreeing on the outlines of Start 2, to ratifying the Chemical Weapons Convention.
Your suggestion that the European Union will promote unity in a way that embraces rather than excludes Russia is also puzzling. Russia is not only excluded from the foreseeable course of E.U. enlargement, but the E.U. has also told likely entrants such as Poland and Hungary that they must put up new barriers to travel and trade with their eastern neighbors.
NATO enlargement, on the other hand, positively requires all aspiring allies to build closer ties with all their neighbors, particularly with those not likely to join the alliance soon.
 
JAMES P. RUBIN
Asst. Secy. for Public Affairs
Department of State
Washington, March 5, 1998

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 4; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: NOTICED;
A Benz for the Wrist

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
ON a Tuesday night last month, a Swiss watchmaker named Franck Muller held a party at the Plaza Athenee Hotel on East 64th Street to introduce his new line of timepieces to a group of about 50 nattily dressed watch enthusiasts -- pardon, horologists.
While Mr. Muller, who wore a Versace sweater and navy blue double-breasted blazer, passed around photographs of himself flanked by smiling women in bikinis at Hamptons parties last summer, his guests clustered in front of the bulletproof case at the end of the room. 
 A woman in a light blue Chanel suit leaned forward and scrutinized one watch, a gold timepiece fat as a granola bar, on a bright blue alligator strap.
"How much is it?" she asked, her lipsticked mouth in a quizzical moue, her champagne flute bearing a red splotch that looked like a map of the Mississippi Delta.
"Two hundred and thirty-three," a Franck Muller spokeswoman replied.
"Oh, well," the woman said, in the slightly exhausted tone New Yorkers use to camouflage utter astonishment, and flounced away.
Because Franck Muller's timepieces don't cost $233. (And one doesn't pronounce his first name as you would Sinatra's; it's "Fronk.") This one -- the limited edition 5850 RMT Minute Repeater Tourbillon -- costs $233,000.
People are buying, despite the fact that the average American home costs less than Mr. Muller's new watch. Manhattan jewelers report that sales of high-end watches have risen strikingly. Although not everyone is dropping six figures, sales of luxury Swiss watches -- in the trade, "luxury" means anything priced over a few thousand dollars -- have risen steadily for the last six years, said Joe Thompson, the editor of American Time magazine, a trade journal. Sales in the United States rose 13 percent in 1997, to $1.1 billion.
W E'VE got pretty much a boom market here," Mr. Thompson said. "Sales on the cheaper Swiss watches are declining and the luxury products are doing extremely well."
So long, Swatch. Hello, Patek Philippe, Vacheron Constantin, Cartier, Audemars Piguet, Rolex, Breguet and Blancpain.
The new watch buyers, mostly men in their late 20's to early 40's, are from all walks of moneyed Manhattan life: real estate, manufacturing, Wall Street.
Although it's possible to drop $90,000 on a Breguet or $300,000 on the highest-end Patek Philippe, luxury sales are most brisk in the $25,000 to $75,000 range. (Most of Mr. Muller's pieces, for example, are priced from $19,000 to $27,000.)
The cultural significance of the power watch has even snuck into the art world; a painting titled "The Romance of Conspicuous Consumption" currently hangs in the front window of the Magidson Fine Art gallery on Madison Avenue. It shows a love-struck man and woman, pointing at each other's watches; balloons coming out of their mouths say, "Love your watch!"
The watch boom is one of the latest, logical extensions of the champagne economy. Real estate moguls, manufacturing titans and mini-masters of the universe already have their duplexes, houses in the Hamptons, Porsche Boxsters and closets full of custom-made shirts.
"And now they need the watch," said Stewart Unger, the owner of the Madison Avenue watch store Time Will Tell and a co-author of "American Wristwatches: Five Decades of Design and Style" (Schiffer Publishing, 1988). "There are watch crazies out there. To these young guys, in their 20's and 30's, with large amounts of money, a watch is about owning a wonderful mechanism, and it is also a power thing. Because you can't go into a business meeting with a Mercedes-Benz or a Rolls-Royce on your wrist. You can go into a meeting with a Breguet."
In a marked shift from the 1980's, buyers are now looking for expensive but more subtle watches. What the color gold was to the 80's -- symbolic of luxury in all things from Giorgio perfume to credit cards -- platinum is to the 90's, a metal even more expensive than gold, but less ostentatious. A platinum watch can be mistaken for stainless steel to the untrained eye on the street, but never to the guys in the executive washroom. Today's buyers also go for more subtle designs: slim and curvy shapes over diamond-encrusted, squarish watch faces.
The new breed of buyer loves to talk shop, said Edward Faber, the owner of Aaron Faber Gallery jewelers on Fifth Avenue and the other author of "American Wristwatches." Back in the 80's, Mr. Faber's clients didn't know a minute repeater from a Movado, or a Swatch from a sub-dial. "Now, they ask technical questions," he said. "They do due diligence. 'Should I choose a Patek 1535 with a calendar or a second-hand Patek moon-phase? Will this appreciate? How much?' "
In part, the high-end watch boom is due to a bit of clever marketing on the part of manufacturers, jewelers say. In 1997, about 25 of the luxury watchmakers sold limited-edition timepieces, which quickly became coveted for their implied rarity and their hoped-for resale value.
Cartier, Patek Philippe, Breitling, Audemars Piguet and Harry Winston all issued popular limited-edition watches -- multipurpose machines that do everything from measure the owner's heart rate to correct the havoc wreaked upon the watch's timekeeping by gravity. Most of these timepieces sold during the last year have already appreciated, jewelers maintain.
One 30-something chief executive of a toy manufacturer owns about 30 high-end watches. His latest purchase was the Patek Philippe Pagoda, a limited edition available in platinum or gold; jewelers like Mr. Faber call it "the buzz watch." When the executive bought it last year, he paid about $24,000 for one of 150 Pagodas made in platinum; now it's worth $50,000 in New York and about $70,000 in Hong Kong, Mr. Faber said.
"If I'm in a meeting and the guy across from me is boring," said the executive, who agreed to talk only if he remained anonymous, "then I can gaze at my watch and daydream about it. It's a very personal, private relationship you have with your watch."
"Rarely does anyone say to me, 'Nice watch,' " he added. "Because I'm getting away from the flash and I'm into the classic. My platinum watch is not going to attract a whole lot of attention. It's not ostentatious. A $50,000 watch is something only you know about."
Not really, if two investment bankers in their late 20's at Club Macanudo on the Upper East Side of Manhattan were any testament. On a recent Thursday evening, the two men put down their single-malt Scotches, rolled up their sleeves and did point-by-point, my-watch-is-better-than-yours comparisons of their timepieces. One wore a Breguet, the other a Patek Philippe Pagoda in yellow gold -- a steal, said the owner, at $13,000, retail.
NEITHER man was disturbed by the fact that his timepiece cost as much as some people earn in a year.
"That's not relevant," said the owner of the Pagoda. He was more interested in the appreciated value of his purchase. "Now this watch is worth $20,000," he said. (Mr. Faber said the watch was actually worth about $14,500.)
"It's all about who has what," said Mr. Unger, the owner of Time Will Tell. "The friend sees his friend has a Pagoda, and these are people who have a certain intuitiveness; they know how much things cost. They ascertain what a guy's capability or monetary status is by looking at his watch. They know if he's a player. Or they think they know."
 
Become a Horologist: Terms to Know
 Ready to trade in that Timex and spend $10,000 or more on a watch? Here are some of the terms to know.
 
BEZEL -- The grooved ring that surrounds the face of the watch, to secure the crystal.
 
GUILLOCHE -- A type of engraving on the dial in which thin lines are interwoven, creating a patterned surface.
 
MINUTE REPEATER -- A device that chimes a different note for each hour, quarter-hour and minute. Some even chime the half quarter-hours (seven and a half minutes). The minute repeater was invented to accommodate people who wanted to know the time in the dark, before the advent of luminous paint.
 
MOON-PHASE INDICATOR -- A disk with depictions of the moon rotating underneath the dial to show the lunar phases. The phases can be seen through a guichet, or little window.
 
PULSIMETER -- A scale on the dial used to measure heart rate, calibrated on the basis of 15 or 30 heartbeats. Typically, the hand is started and continues until the 30th beat. It then shows the beats per minute.
 
TOURBILLION -- A mechanism that corrects errors in timekeeping due to the effect of the shifting of gravity as the watch changes position during ordinary use. The tourbillion, invented in 1795, compensates for such shifts by rotating the carriage of the watch once every minute.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/70 Pine Street;
An Art Deco Tower With Double-Deck Elevators

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE American International Group is completing a multiyear restoration of the elevators in its 1932 skyscraper, at 70 Pine Street in downtown Manhattan. The cabs are dazzling, in the Art Deco style of the spectacular marble lobby. It seems unlikely anyone will notice, but the most unusual element is missing. Although they are now run conventionally, the originals were the first double-deck elevators, conceived as office developers squeezed the last square feet of space from the sky.
The 66-story building at 70 Pine was the accomplishment of a grade-school dropout, Henry L. Doherty. Born in 1870 in Ohio, Doherty left school at age 10 to sell newspapers in saloons. At 12 he was an office boy in a gas company office; he rose quickly as a manager and engineer, came to New York and at 40 founded the Cities Service Company, which both explored oil and gas fields and supplied local users. 
 Doherty lived on top of an office building at State and Liberty Streets -- where 1 Battery Park Plaza is now -- with a gym, squash court and motorized bed that slid out onto the terrace. He bought several downtown sites for redevelopment but was hindered by recurrent bouts of arthritis. Doherty almost died in 1927 from complications of the disease -- causing Cities Service stock to plunge -- but recovered with the help of a family friend, Grace Eames, whom he wed in December 1928. She was a widow; it was his first marriage.
In January 1929 Doherty assembled a good-sized plot on the east side of Pearl Street, from Pine to Cedar Streets. He did not file plans until May 1930, eight months after the stock market crash, for what became Wall Street's last jazz-age skyscraper.
Designed by Clinton & Russell, Holton & George, the new building took the street address 70 Pine Street but, by an aerial bridge connection with 60 Wall Street, initially took the name 60 Wall Tower for cachet.
For a 66-story building it was a tight plot, only 120 feet wide on Pearl. Engineers estimated that the economic height of the building was 48 stories -- beyond that the service core of plumbing, stairs and, especially, elevators, took up too much space relative to rentable area.
But in January 1930 D. L. Lundquist, chief engineer for Otis Elevator, had been interviewed by The New York Sun on the limiting factor for tall buildings, and had predicted that double-deck elevators -- two connected cabs using the same shaft -- could solve the problem.
Doherty adopted the Otis plan, and the resulting design provided 60 floors of rentable offices, plus six smaller floors, including a kitchen and a mechanical floor, in the tower served by a separate small elevator from the 60th floor.A 1932 article in Engineering News-Record stated that eight shafts with double-deck cabs saved $200,000 in construction costs over 14 regular elevators, and freed up 40,000 square feet. At the time $3.50 a square foot was a typical annual rent for such office space.
The slope of the site helped the double-deck plan -- people entering on Pearl Street were naturally drawn to the lower lobby, while those entering on Pine were drawn to the upper lobby. Elevators in one lobby served even floors, those in the other served odd floors, and starters directed foot traffic accordingly.
As soon as the doors of both cabs closed, the double cab went up, stopping at, for instance, the 29/30th floors, the 31st/32d floors, and so on to the 59th/60th floors. Double-deck service was restricted to peak periods; at other times half the cabs were closed and the elevators stopped on all floors.
Unless the cab stopped without opening its door -- a sign that the other cab was opening on another floor -- passengers were not particularly aware of the double-deck operation. Perhaps they were still recovering from the lobby, an eye-burning Art Deco symphony of figured marble in high colors and sinuous metalwork.
On the outside the architects created a tapering shaft of simple streamlined design with sophisticated touches -- in the corners at the upper floors, every third brick is rounded instead of squared, giving animation to the tower. The topmost floor, an observation deck, is a greenhouse-aerie, perhaps 30 by 20 feet square, with 360-degree views.
TO judge from period telephone listings, few tenants used the 60 Wall Street address -- 70 Pine Street was good enough -- and the building was widely known as the Cities Service Building. Doherty's company occupied many of the lower floors, and lawyers and financiers made up most of the other tenants. Emanuel Celler, a longtime Brooklyn Congressman, was an initial tenant, as was Adolf A. Berle Jr., the diplomat and lawyer.
In 1935 News-Week magazine, as it was then known, described Cities Service as a $1 billion company; Doherty's fortune was often reckoned at $25 million. Doherty died in 1939; Cities Service became Citgo in 1965, and later moved to Tulsa. In 1976 an insurance company, American International Group, bought the building, and in the last few years has cleaned and repointed the facade, installed new windows, and replaced the elevators.
Gerard Dengel, an executive at A.I.G., declined to provide information on the building renovation. The elevator project has been under way for five or six years, dealing with cabs that had been modernized in the 1960's, when double-deck service was eliminated. The current work has included an agreeable Art Deco design based on original photographs in Otis archives. Otis still takes care of the building's elevators. There are now about three dozen double-deck elevator installations worldwide, like those in the 88-story Petronas Towers project in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Otis has installed most of them.
No one considered rebuilding the double-deck service at 70 Pine. Passenger loads have changed from 70 years ago, with staggered arrival times and lower densities of office workers. People come and go through the upper lobby, and the lower lobby is a quiet place: a few phones, a bank, a few shops, and rows of intricate Art Deco elevator doors, pristine and calm.
Although parts of the lobby are open to the public, A.I.G., which occupies most of the building, requires passes for the floors above.
Robert Makla, a preservation and parks advocate and a partner at the law firm of D'Amato & Lynch, a tenant in the building since 1976, recently gave a visitor a tour of the building. On the upper floors the stair tower runs up an outside wall, zigzagging past small windows and doors leading out onto narrow parapets.
At the top, the former observation deck is closed to the public but in near-original shape, a glass jewel box at the top of the world. It has tiny outside balconies; a dizzying look down at 950 feet of upward streamlining can make one appreciate the view from street level.
Mr. Makla's office on the 41st floor is a Victorian thicket of high-wheel bicycles, subway maps and other memorabilia. It has a certain distinction; when the ceilings were lowered several years ago for air-conditioning Mr. Makla declined. He has the original 9-foot-high ceiling and streamlined incandescent fixtures. Air-conditioning? He just opens his windows.
