HEADLINE: THE FLYING CAPITALIST; The Frequent-Flier Economy

BYLINE: By David Noonan; David Noonan last wrote for the Magazine in December about "Really Big Football Players."

 BODY:
Jeff Pollak doesn't spend much time in the air, but that hasn't stopped him from accumulating an impressive pile of frequent-flier miles. Pollak, 28, has earned about 600,000 miles in the last six years, 80 percent of them without leaving the ground. "A lot of people collect coins and stamps," says Pollak, who lives in Washington. "I collect frequent-flier miles." An equal opportunity deal-hunter, he now has 180,000 miles to his credit with British Airways, 60,000 with American, 25,000 with United and 10,000 with Alaska, though he has never flown on a revenue ticket with any of those airlines.
"I analyze information, and I see what's the best way to get the miles with as little effort as necessary without having to spend much money," says Pollak, whose current goal is to earn enough miles for a free trip to China on Singapore Airlines. "There's nothing more satisfying than calling up the elite line and punching in my frequent-flier number and finding out that I have over 100,000 miles in the account. I love collecting them more than I do spending them." 
 Pollak, an acquisitions analyst, estab-lished his reputation as a "mileage junkie" with a stunt he pulled a few years ago. He rented five cars at the cheapest available rate, about $20, on five different days from Budget to earn a free round-trip ticket anywhere in the United States on American Airlines. He kept each car for just five minutes, driving out of the parking lot and right back in again. When an attendant pushed to know what was wrong with one of the cars, Pollak confessed. "I'm just here for the miles," he said.
Introduced in 1981 as a marketing tool to secure the loyalty of 283,000 of American Airlines's best customers, frequent-flier miles have evolved beyond all expectations into the coin of the realm of a borderless, globe-spanning consumer technoland inhabited by more than 70 million people. The abstract form of currency -- minted out of the literally thin air that passenger planes fly through -- is the basis of a multibillion-dollar economy nearly as elaborate as the real thing.
While Jeff Pollak may be an extreme example of the type, the nonflying frequent flier is hardly rara avis these days. Forty percent of all the frequent-flier miles earned last year were earned on the ground, and that percentage is expected to increase as more nontravel businesses and services offer miles as a way to attract customers. Today more than 17,000 businesses in the United States are giving away miles. In 1994, the art collector Eli Broad earned 2.5 million miles when he used his American Express card to pay $2.5 million for the Roy Lichtenstein painting "I. . .I'm Sorry" during an auction at Sotheby's in New York. Using frequent-flier-tied credit cards to pay for big-ticket items, including college tuitions, has become standard practice among aficionados. Newer ways to earn miles without sweating through all those takeoffs and landings include being a good person -- some charities are giving miles in return for donations -- and surfing the Net. A San Francisco cyber-marketer called Netcentives has made deals with six airlines to award miles to people who are involved in Internet activities like purchasing products, downloading software and participating in surveys.
Frequent-flier programs were made possible by two things -- the deregulation of the airline industry in 1978 and the subsequent development of sophisticated data-processing systems by the airlines (which was driven in turn by advances in computer technology). Prior to deregulation, Federal law prohibited the airlines from giving anything of substance to distributors or ultimate users. Immediately upon their introduction, frequent-flier miles became the best thing about flying frequently, easily supplanting the little bags of peanuts and the tiny pillows. Worldwide, 70 airlines operate frequent-flier programs. Today 47 percent of the passengers on any given flight are earning frequent- flier miles; there are three trillion miles on the books.
The reason that securities firms, florists, flea-collar distributors and other earthbound entities can award miles to customers is simple -- they buy them from the airlines. Randy Petersen, editor of Inside Flyer, a magazine for frequent fliers, estimates that the airlines are generating about a billion and a half dollars a year "selling miles" to their "partners." At a going rate of about two cents apiece, that's a whole bunch of miles changing hands.
"Basically what all of these companies are purchasing is marketing," says Bruce Chemel, president of American's AAdvantage marketing program, which sells miles to 2,000 companies. "They are not purchasing air transportation. We are selling them AAdvantage miles, and in doing so, we are selling them the ability to market their product, to increase their market share, to retain their current customers, to generate awareness for a new product, whatever the normal marketing functions in a company are."
It's a great deal for the airlines, Petersen explains, since they can sell 25,000 miles to a partner for $500, and it costs them only about $20 to grant the award those miles represent. Such extraordinary profit margins are a function of the strict control the airlines maintain over the free tickets earned by their frequent fliers. While more than 11 million such tickets were redeemed last year, just 5 percent of them were completely free of restrictions. Using blackout dates and other controls, the airlines pursue a standard policy of never displacing a paying passenger with a passenger flying free.
Usually, the only costs to the airline of honoring a free ticket are the incremental ones of adding a single passenger to a flight -- additional fuel, insurance, a meal, peanuts. All together it works out to about $20.
This gap between the perceived value and the actual value of a free ticket is the reason the frequent-flier system works as well as it does.
Right from the start, the main appeal of frequent-flier programs was the idea that the consumer was getting something for nothing. In fact, the airlines were so successful in their marketing of frequent-flier miles as a valuable currency that they created a truly mind-boggling new source of revenue for themselves -- money generated by business travelers making unnecessary trips and pursuing other wasteful strategies to maximize their frequent-flier miles. A study by two professors from the University of Georgia estimates that at one point this form of frequent-flier-related "corporate waste" amounted to more than $4 billion a year.
With trillions of unredeemed miles on the books, the airlines might seem at risk of being overwhelmed by a sudden stampede of frequent fliers seeking free tickets. Yet in spite of the steady increase of the popularity of frequent-flier programs, the annual redemption rate has remained constant, averaging 200 billion redeemed miles a year.
While most of the people who redeem their miles for free tickets remain blissfully ignorant of the actual value of air travel, almost all of them know more than they want to know about the airlines' complicated rules for using award tickets. Difficulty getting the flights they want, when they want them, is the No. 1 complaint among members of frequent-flier programs. Unfortunately, given the underlying economics, the situation is not likely to change.
There are occasional victories for the masses, however. Just last month, United, under pressure from unhappy members of its Mileage Plus program, reversed a recent policy change and stopped requiring a Saturday night stay when booking its most basic award.
As in life, in the frequent-flier economy it's better to be rich. For the true frequent fliers, the high-mileage business travelers who make up the elite minority in these programs, blackout dates and Saturday night stays are not an issue. Their award tickets are usually unrestricted. Indeed, free air travel holds so little appeal for them that the airlines have had to cook up special promotions to maintain their enthusiasm and help them spend their vast stores of miles. Several airlines, for instance, have sponsored auctions. Caribbean cruises, trips to the Super Bowl, shopping sprees and celebrity encounters (a party with Arnold Schwarzenegger, a skating lesson from Nancy Kerrigan) are some of the things members have been invited to bid on with their miles.
New options for spending miles are available to the nonelite as well. In a trend that is expected to expand as the currency continues to take hold outside the travel world, miles can now be used to pay for hotel rooms, meals in restaurants and catalogue merchandise.
A good measure of just how entrenched frequent-flier miles have become in the culture and the larger economy is the recent attempt by the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund to freeze any frequent-flier miles earned by or credited to Randall Terry, the founder of the militant antiabortion group Operation Rescue.
The NOW lawyers got the idea from a previous case, in which a drug dealer forfeited his miles to the Government. Terry owes NOW more than $600,000 in court-ordered fines and fees. Though the organization has recovered just $6,000, Terry claims NOW has turned him into a "pauper." Yolanda Wu, staff counsel for the fund, says NOW's pursuit of Terry's miles is more than symbolic. The miles are a legitimate asset, Wu says, and NOW plans to use them for its own work. "Let them use my frequent-flier miles on their train ride into Hades," Terry said in response to the NOW action. While it might seem at first that Terry has his travel modes mixed up, Amtrak in fact does accept frequent-flier miles on one route, although Hades is not a scheduled stop.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 8, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 37; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2513 words

HEADLINE: The New Business Class

BYLINE: By Pico Iyer; Pico Iyer, who writes frequently on cultural affairs, is completing a book on the global soul.

 BODY:
In Hong Kong recently, I spent a layover with one of my closest friends from school in England. The guest room in his modest, functional apartment was furnished almost entirely with suitcases. On the desk sat a Hewlett-Packard Desk Jet printer, a box of Chinese Standard Version 3.2 diskettes and some personalized stationery (for someone I'd never heard of) from the Oberoi hotel, Bombay. Against the wall were a travel iron, a worldwide power adapter and a timetable for Dragonair Systems, a Hong Kong airline. In the bathroom I found a bottle of Thai Air hair treatment, a Delta Airlines business-class toilet kit and a British Airways towelette. Some toothpaste from an Imperial Hotel, a bottle of conditioner from the Westin Tai Ping Yang, Shanghai, and some Princess Cruises French formula shampoo. Otherwise, nothing.
The apartment was part of a four-story shopping complex (called simply -- definitively -- the Mall) linked to three luxury 500-room hotels; it had a Cathay Pacific check-in counter downstairs and 97 high-fashion boutiques farther down. Two other guests, who had just flown in for the weekend from L.A., on our host's unused frequent-flier awards, now consulted a room-service menu. 
 "It's an odd life you lead here," I told my friend, Richard Rawlinson, whom I habitually think of as a Victorian district officer transferred to a digital age.
"It is," he said. "Look at this" -- and he opened out his wallet to display a rainbow spread of cards: for the Red Carpet Club and Passages membership, for Marriott Miles and Singapore Airlines. He had a Europlus card and a Priority Passenger Service card, as well as 12 different telephone cards, "and, of course, an E.T.I. -- you know, Executive Telephone International -- and a G.S.M. phone with two S.I.M. cards." (He pulled out a mobile phone to demonstrate how the card could be slipped in or out, depending on whether he was in Asia or Europe.) All the cards were linked to a credit card for which he got miles -- miles enough, in fact, to send his wife around the world every month free.
I was still taking in the S.I.M. (subscriber identity module) cards when Richard began pulling out envelopes from his briefcase -- I counted 27 in all -- thick with bus tokens, coins and bank notes for the 27 countries he was likeliest to find himself in the next day. Then he began extracting a stash of crumpled, half-used plane tickets for Hong Kong-London, Hong Kong-Madrid, Boston-Tokyo and all his other regular itineraries. He actually had to petition the Foreign Office to get permission to carry two passports simultaneously -- he went through their pages so quickly -- and in the previous year alone (he checked his laptop) he crossed borders -- let's see --139 times.
The thing to stress here is that Richard is not extravagantly rich, and certainly no captive to luxury or ambition; he's just an extremely hard-working management consultant in his late 30's who lives and works in a global marketplace that asks him to move as fast as it does. He flies more than most flight attendants do, and courted his wife while she was at business school by flying around the world -- London-San Francisco-Tokyo-London -- almost every weekend for two years. He could be reached, he assured me, at 14 numbers on three continents, and when we went for a walk in the hills, he pulled out a cell phone and asked his secretary to fix up an appointment for breakfast with his wife. He would, after all, be in 13 different countries in the next 13 days.
Richard is, as it happens, one of the most settled and loyal people I know, but all around us are tens of thousands of other members of a new floating class who may be very much up in the air. The "borderless economy" we hear trumpeted so often means that today's businessmen and women have to live everywhere at once, and the speed of global communications means that they can be anywhere tomorrow. Frequent Business Travelers (or F.B.T.'s) are the new breed for whom "globalization" takes root in the stomach and the heart.
Everyone and everything is moving more than ever, of course; in San Francisco International Airport last year I came upon an exhibition on the history of airports -- wheels within wheels. It informed me that in 1932, Berlin's Tempelhof, then the busiest air facility in the world, processed 34,000 passengers a year. Now Chicago's O'Hare sees that many in three hours. And F.B.T.'s could, therefore, be seen as just the traveling salesmen of a multinational age, aero-commuters carrying their personal digital assistants and laptops to intercontinental meetings and clients in Turkmenistan. Not the movie-star checking in 40 pieces of luggage to first class, but, equally, not the man in coach, holding his daughter's hand.
Yet I suspect that they are something more than just supersonic versions of the Phoenician traders or Bedouin merchants of old, and are separated from Willy Loman by differences of kind as much as of degree. For one thing, these new ungrounded bodies operate in a world where many companies are richer than most countries, and the very notion of the nation-state -- like loyalty -- has been privatized. In a post-ideological world, they cannot know, as easily as the encyclopedia salesman surely did, exactly where they stand. And flying from winter to summer in an afternoon -- or waking up alone in 14th-century Nepal and sitting down for dinner that night with the family in Century City -- they face, and are forced to find new answers for, the most basic human questions: Where do they belong, what is their community and to whom are they most responsible ?
The business-class world affects us all, moreover, because it exists as much on the ground as in the air. My friend in Hong Kong, for example, has no car and no real office (save for a tiny desk jammed against a window); his service apartment allows him to function as if he were in a semi-permanent hotel (on the rare days when he's not orbiting the globe). And more and more of us are apt to find ourselves, in Robert Kaplan's pregnant phrase, "resident expatriates," living as if we were abroad even when we're at home, in gated communities, with hired housewives, enjoying the quality services of a "concierge lifestyle." For expat traders at least, a city like Hong Kong is a business class writ large, a huge convenience-store-cum-stock-exchange-cum-conference-center, here the lingua franca is the dollar, there are few taxes and no government and you can do business round the clock. From my friend's $7,000-a-month apartment, it was hard to recall that the place is 98 percent Chinese.
I describe these decentered souls as "they" because it's easier than saying "we." I choose to fly economy even when I'm on business trips, and in any case I hardly leave my apartment for months on end; as a writer, I am free to stay in the middle of the Japanese countryside with nothing more complex than pen, desk and paper. Yet after I visited Richard, I realized, with a shock, how many symptoms of Global Man I share. On a superficial level, I find myself reflexively checking for Cirrus signs and hunting for lunch, all too often, at 4 A.M. Larry King is the only American newsman I know because CNN is the only English-language station available in the hotel rooms of Havana and Hanoi. At a deeper level, I realize that I live in a country where I've never had a job, and rely, often, on World Phones to keep me in touch with a partner 17 time zones away. When I need to see a dentist, I get on an 11-hour flight; when asked to identify myself, sometimes, I key in a 16-digit number.
Some time ago, when I realized that I had accumulated 1.2 million miles on one airline alone, and was paying $823 for just one of my monthly telephone bills, I decided to take concrete measures to remind myself of silence and stillness and space -- all the steadying essentials obscured in the F.B.T. rush. Nowadays, like more and more people, I retreat several times a year to a monastery. But even for those of us who try to resist the accelerating pressures of the age, the very conveniences that make our ease and even our quiet possible propel us into the fast-forward orbit of the World Perks being. Flying into Hong Kong this year, I noticed that even in economy class there was a video monitor on my armrest, and the Entertainment Guide outlining my options for the three-hour flight was a 64-page glossy magazine. I could send faxes from the plane, receive calls, even draw cash from an A.T.M. machine. And when I opened the in-flight magazine I felt, as I do more and more often these days, as if I were an alien in need of a new kind of dictionary. The ads sang of Skytel alphanumeric paging services, and videophones, voice-file portable I.C. chip recorders and digital cameras with "built-in pc cards."
At my friend's breakfast table, I picked up the daily newspaper and read that British Airways offered 282 flights to Europe. There is a putting green in Palm Springs Airport, the international paper told me, and a casino in Amsterdam's Schiphol. You can go bowling in Frankfurt Airport, or do your dry cleaning, or take in a racy movie. A small guidebook has been written on how to live while between planes at O'Hare. We're almost accustomed now to the fact that airports, with their discos, dental clinics, in-house wineries and 120-store Sky Malls, are often as compendious as cities. (Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport is larger than Manhattan.) But that sometimes obscures how many cities, set up for speed and convenience, and catering to a swirl of tongues and tribes from somewhere very distant, now look more and more like airports, with their food courts, chain stores and signs for Pizza Hut Express. The practical assumption is that everyone's passing through.
The irony of all this, of course, is that so much of our technology -- fax machines, modems, E-mail, video-conferencing -- is designed to help us get around the distances of space: I can sit here in Japan and transmit this article to editors 6,000 miles away with an ease almost unimaginable even a decade ago. Yet somehow all our new opportunities seem to run ahead of our understanding of them. We spend more and more time fixing timesaving devices, and our communications facilities are adept at communicating communications glitches. The very efficiency with which we've eliminated the need to meet face to face has made "the human touch" all the more precious. Study after study shows that now that we can get from Hong Kong to New York in 14 hours, instead of 21 days, we're not using those extra 20 days for doing something useful; we're just moving back and forth more, and recovering from the flights.
If the first rule of technology is that nothing, once discovered, can be undiscovered, the second, more troubling, is that no device, once created, will go unused. We fall captive to our implements in much the same way that frequent fliers will pay $400 more for a ticket in the hope that, if they do so often enough, they will ultimately get a $300 ticket free (or, if the company is paying, will route themselves from New York to Boston via Chicago, with an imaginary stop in Atlanta). Doctors warn us that frequent flying can lead to severe back injuries and hearing loss, to moodiness and divorce. But the moral and emotional effects of jet lag haven't yet been gauged, or don't show up on the screen. Even Marshall McLuhan, the John the Baptist of the wired universe, remarked, "You get moving very quickly and you end up in the wrong place."
It's no coincidence, surely, that last year's audaciously heartless independent movie "In the Company of Men" began in some Nowhere International late at night -- that fluorescent limbo of garment bags and monitors -- with two departure-lounge lizards off on an out-of-town assignment, and deciding, in the terminal emptiness, to leave their humanity at home. The film's most chilling moment of inhumanity is executed, fittingly, in a borrowed hotel room. The very language of flight -- the notion of flight -- seems made for tricky liberties: red-eye, fly-by-night, transit-lounge, duty-free.
We're not ourselves when we're up high, we often say, and it's easy to feel that the F.B.T., serene in his half-real world five miles above the earth, strapped into his headphones, with his four-course meal brought to him in the comfort of his seat, is subject to no regulations save those of the International Air Transport Association. And it's easy to suspect that in this zone of privilege -- all rights and few responsibilities -- this new kind of being has all his needs taken care of, except the ones that really matter. When Richard's wife and I waited for him to come home for dinner, we had to turn on the TV set. (International Arrivals were shown on Channel 6.) The trouble was, neither of us knew which country he'd be coming from.
The brave new world of F.B.T.'s represents, of course, only a tiny fraction of a planet in which something like half of all people have never used a telephone. But it's a highly visible and influential fraction that is in a position to design a world according to its needs. Global technology has already doubled the gap between the richest and the poorest in the past 30 years. And the very point of business class is that it allows you to be screened off from the world at large, behind a curtain; we will pay -- or, better yet, let the company pay -- $1,800 extra for just six hours free from the clamoring riffraff (with a different counter at which to check in, a separate lounge in which to wait). That such divisions are increasingly popular in a world where other borders are collapsing is evident from the fact that connoisseur class services are booming, and have spun off cousins in hotels (with their executive floors) and car-rental agencies (with their gold card lines). Virgin Atlantic, incorrigibly cheeky, calls its top-deck and front-of-the-plane seats "upper class."
Business class belongs, I suspect, to a globe in which, in many cities from Addis Ababa to Port-au-Prince, air passengers are literally separated from the less fortunate by huge barbed-wire fences and armed guards. And if its driving truth is the line delivered by a Russian en route to Kazakhstan at the end of Don DeLillo's "Underworld" -- "Geography has moved inward and smallward" -- its consequence is given voice by DeLillo's literary cousin, Haruki Murakami, in "The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle," in which the out-of-body narrator amiably reports, "My reality seemed to have left me and now was wandering around nearby."
"Perhaps the strangest thing," Richard told me just before I left Hong Kong, "is when I'm sitting here next to my wife, and I'll call up her voice mail in Massachusetts to leave a message."
"Because she can listen to it repeatedly, and take down all the details ?"
"Yes," he said, sounding almost as bemused as I was.
What a terrifying thought, I reflected -- until, a few weeks later, I found myself doing exactly the same thing.

HEADLINE: Is There a Doctor On the Plane?

BYLINE: By Brian Alexander; Brian Alexander writes frequently about travel and health.

 BODY:
William Abranowicz, a photographer who racks up around 200,000 miles on airplanes every year, is living proof that frequent fliers face other dangers than plane crashes and the American Airlines dinner calzone: "I can get off a plane and have giant red marks on each side of my nose, develop a dry scalp, my skin will be inflamed. My skin freaks out."
Yikes! It turns out that very frequent fliers might be earning more than platinum status. They could be collecting conditions like "economy-class syndrome," and suffering symptoms ranging from flatulence to death. 
 "We see lots of passengers," says Dr. John Dellorso, medical director for Kennedy Medical Offices at Kennedy airport in New York. Chest pain and heart attacks account for most medical incidents, followed by food-borne diseases, gastric upsets, ear problems and dehydration. "We've also had our share of deaths. I'd say we get inbound flights with dead bodies on them between 5 and 10 times per year." When the World Bank studied its employees' insurance claims in 1993, it discovered that frequent international travelers made claims much more often -- 80 percent more often for men and 18 percent more for women -- and concluded that "sudden changes in climate, environment and time zones and the related physical and psychological stress associated with travel" pose a hazard in and of themselves.
The Aerospace Medical Association publishes "Medical Guidelines for Airline Travel" for doctors, but much remains unknown. Airlines are not required to report medical incidents to the Government, though over the years studies have been done for isolated time periods. In January, for example, the industry's Air Transport Association said that there were 10,471 medical incidents on the nine largest U.S. airlines during 1996. In the context of millions of passengers, that number seems small, but Mark Rosekind -- president of Alertness Solutions, a company that specializes in problems concerning fatigue on the job -- thinks the real damage might be hidden.
"There will be long-term effects," he says. "We just don't know what they are yet. You cannot do this to people over a long time and not have some effects." Which might cause passengers to ask how many frequent-flier miles a bad back is worth.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Injuries caused by objects tumbling from overhead bins result in a significant number of accidents, says Jane Goodman, a spokeswoman for the Association of Flight Attendants. At the group's November conference, an orthopedic surgeon reported 462 injuries on one airline over a three-year period, more than 90 percent of which were head injuries -- mainly to those seated in aisle seats -- and 160 of which required medical attention.; Of the 10,471 medical incidents reported by the Air Transport Association for 1996, the single largest diagnosis group was syncope/dizziness. These symptoms can be caused by hypoxemia, or low oxygen levels in the blood, a result of relatively low oxygen in the cabin air.; Psychological problems soared for frequent travelers in a World Bank study of its employees' insurance claims. The research indicated that workload and separation from family and friends were important factors. "We occasionally see panic attacks, anxiety and depression cases," says Dr. Evan Berman of Kennedy airport's medical offices. "It's people who have been traveling a long time -- they are sleep-deprived and they sort of wig out."; Aerotitus media (trauma to the middle ear) and barosinusitis (trauma with pain and bleeding) can occur if ear- or sinus-pressure equalization fails. In very rare cases, flying with sinusitis could cause the disease to spread to the central nervous system. Passengers with even mild ear infections can suffer tympanic membrane ruptures (imploded ear drums) during descent.; Heart attacks are the leading cause of death during air travel. The heart muscle becomes stressed by the anxiety of travel, by sprints through the airport, by cabin air that can create up to a 10 percent drop in blood-oxygen-saturation levels and by a relative humidity as low as 10 percent.; The air-sickness bags are there for a reason. Nausea -- caused by motion sickness and airline food -- is the single largest passenger complaint.; Infectious diseases spread on airplanes. "You do have an increased risk," says Dr. Lucy Tompkins, a Stanford University professor of infectious disease. Tuberculosis, for example, has been transmitted in airplane cabins thanks to coughing passengers and close quarters.; Back injuries were a significant complaint of travelers in the World Bank study. "Fractures, sprains and strains" were nearly 80 percent greater for male travelers than for male nontravelers -- probably a result of carrying heavy luggage and sitting for long hours on flights. But travelers should be wary of aid for backaches. According to the journal Aviation, Space and Environmental Medicine, one flight attendant treated a passenger's lumbar injury with a cold pack of dry ice, causing third-degree frostbite.; Beware "economy-class syndrome": deep vein thrombosis (D.V.T.), which can develop even in young, healthy passengers from long periods of immobilization in cramped seats under very low humidity. A thrombus, or clot, can form in the lower leg, and if a piece of it breaks off and makes its way to the lungs, it becomes a pulmonary embolism. In rare cases, the embolism can cause respiratory failure. (Photograph by Davies & Starr)

HEADLINE: Very Risky Business

BYLINE: By Sebastian Junger; Sebastian Junger is the author of "The Perfect Storm: A True Story of Men Against the Sea."

 BODY:
The last phone call Peter Zarate, an ex-Navy SEAL from California, made was to his wife. A commercial real-estate broker working in Mexico City, Zarate stayed late at the office one night in mid-December to close several big deals. Around 8 o'clock, he picked up his cell phone, called his wife and told her that he would be home soon. Ten minutes later, carrying a briefcase and dressed in a dark blue pin-stripe suit, he walked out of the three-story building on Galileo Street where his employer, the American company Cushman & Wakefield, has its offices.
Apparently Zarate had trouble getting a cab, because around 8:20 he called his wife again and said that he was going to walk to a taxi stand down the street. These would be "sitio" cabs -- meaning they had license plates and were registered with the Government -- and so would be more or less safe. Unlicensed gypsy cabs have become infamous in Mexico City for elaborate mugging and kidnapping schemes, and in fact, a few days earlier an American had been savagely beaten in the back of one. The United States Embassy has issued strong warnings against taking them. 
 According to the account of a friend who was later involved in the police investigation, Zarate never made it to the taxi stand. He may have been shoved into a gypsy cab or he may have just gotten into one. At any rate, he found himself held at gunpoint by at least two men and tailed by several more in another gypsy cab. First they beat him -- beat him so badly that the friend, who identified the body, thought Zarate had been shot in the head. And then they did what robbers in most gypsy cab holdups do: they drove him around from one automatic teller to another, taking out cash. The problem was that Zarate's bank account limited the amount of cash he could withdraw to around $200, and he wasn't even wearing any expensive jewelry. But the robbers looked in his briefcase and there they struck gold. They found papers that told them where he lived.
The collapse of the peso in 1994 has spawned a crime wave of unprecedented brutality in Mexico, and kidnappings of both Mexicans and visitors have become a particular specialty. In a high-profile case late last year, nine heavily armed men in Federal police uniforms kidnapped an American businessman in Acapulco, killing a local police officer and seriously wounding another. As of 1996, murders in Mexico City had risen to three a day, and last year there were hundreds of violent crimes every day.
Zarate would have known all this, and he also would have known that his wife and four children were home alone. Three blocks away from his house, on Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra street, the two taxis slowed down for a speed bump and Zarate made his move. He apparently hit Recall and Send on his cell phone, and then leapt out of the car.
Presumably he was trying to buy enough time to tell his wife to call for help, but it didn't work. The phone rang at his house, but when his wife answered, the line was dead. And Zarate himself only made it a couple of steps before he was shot with a .380-caliber handgun, loaded with a large, slow bullet that ricocheted around inside of him rather than passing through him. It tore through his rib cage and abdomen and killed him within minutes. The robbers fled in their cars, and the first policeman who arrived on the scene found Zarate dead in the street with the cell phone still in his hand.
As international trade barriers fall, Americans are increasingly going abroad to do business, often in crime-ridden developing countries where personal safety is an everyday concern. Mexico City, along with Moscow, Johannesburg and Karachi, is considered one of the most dangerous cities in the world for American businessmen, according to Kroll Associates, the international security company. But with the risks come irresistible rewards. There is no better example of this than Mexico, where a 7 percent growth rate and near-doubling of trade with the United States in the past five years have produced tremendous financial opportunities, even though doing business there means putting up with a wary, nearly paranoid existence.
"Everyone who comes in here has a story," says Grant Lussier, managing director of the headhunting firm of Spencer Stuart, sweeping a hand at his wood-paneled office. "Nightmarish stories, like waiting at a green light and all of a sudden three guys get into your car with guns and say, 'O.K., let's go to your house.' This is a hugely fertile environment for American companies, but the lack of security is a real detriment to the people who come down with their families. You can imagine the wives: 'What are we doing here? We have a house in Greenwich -- let's go back."'
The danger to American businessmen like Zarate is mainly random crime -- carjackings, muggings, taxicab holdups. A whole other level of threat is directed at high-profile executives. Dupont, Xerox, Citibank, Goodyear, I.B.M. -- the list of American companies in Mexico goes on and on, and their top managers are all prime targets for kidnapping. In 1996, a Japanese Sanyo executive was taken hostage and only released after a $2 million ransom was paid, and since then, foreign executives have become an enormous liability for their employers. According to American International Group, an insurer, United States companies pay fat premiums for kidnapping insurance for their executives in Mexico. And many top American businessmen live as virtual prisoners of their own security.
The American business community in Mexico seems to be divided into two groups: those who are in the country temporarily to seize an opportunity and those who plan to stay. The residents share a belief that the crime wave will abate and that Mexico -- America's second-largest trading partner, thanks to the 1994 Nafta accords -- will eventually pull itself out of poverty and corruption. Peter Zarate was a member of this group; he had been in Mexico for four years and had no plans to leave. The others -- who tend to have more security and less freedom -- are here for a few years before they move back to their home offices.
If you're ambitious enough, the benefits apparently outweigh the risks. "I have several armored cars, guards armed with pistols and drivers trained in evasive driving," says the C.E.O. of an American company that does more than $1 billion worth of business in Mexico every year. "I don't go out too much; I have no extracurricular activities. When I want to buy something, I pick up the phone, order it and pick it up the next time I get to the States. But now what am I losing? I'm not losing that much. When I get back to the States, I'll be able to do whatever I want."
This man, who lives in a suburb of Mexico City with his wife and children, doesn't walk to the corner store without an armed escort. Every morning, he takes a different route to work, and he always has at least one guard in the back seat. "You deal with it by knowing that one day you're going to leave," he says. "My employer knows that if something were to happen, I can simply pick up the phone and say, 'The moment has come.' I'm a person who's going to leave one day. I don't have to put my life on the line."
The fear of violent crime has prompted a rapidly growing security industry. In front of any expensive restaurant in Mexico City, groups of private gunmen in cheap suits can be seen keeping vigil while their bosses -- important American and Mexican businessmen -- have lunch inside.
Twenty car-armoring outfits have sprung up in the city, and there are several international security firms who do risk analysis and give safety courses. A typical traveling arrangement for upper-level executives is to have an armored Jeep Cherokee with a driver and another car following with three armed guards. If the executive has children, he might assign guards to take them to school in the morning, wait outside all day and take them home in the afternoon. Guards carry semiautomatic pistols and many have gone through training courses. Like the police, they are generally not well educated, and they are never let into the house of a client they are hired to protect.
"Every person I know, middle-class or better, will talk to you about a security problem they've had in the past year," says a Mexican executive who works for a large American company in Mexico City. "We ride armored cars -- my wife has a Jetta and I have a BMW. They're designed for random attacks, nothing else. And I have a guard, just because if you're riding with someone else, it lowers the probability of being attacked."
One recent morning, a visit to this man's house in an exclusive suburb in the hills above the city found his bodyguard inspecting two cars that were to be used on the drive to work that day. It's a neighborhood where cobblestone streets run between high garden walls, and men in commando outfits stand in front of compound gates, holding attack dogs on chains.
The bodyguard, a big-shouldered man with a bulging stomach and jet-black hair slicked back, said that ideally it takes four guards to protect someone, all of them armed. The driver almost never leaves the car. When he drops a client off, his job is to step out, close the door behind him and assess the situation on the street. A second guard walks well in advance of the client and scouts out the area, and the two others walk immediately in front of and behind him. In the event of an attack, the closest bodyguard grabs the client by the hand and leads him to safety while the other two provide protection.
This executive, however, chooses to have only one bodyguard and prefers to drive his own car to work. At about 10 A.M., the executive emerged from his house and got into his BMW. He backed it out of the courtyard, through an electrically controlled front gate and onto the narrow street. His guard climbed into a Jeep Cherokee and followed closely behind, cutting off cars on the highway and running red lights to keep up. After about a half-hour drive, they pulled into a secured parking garage in the basement of the executive's office building and took an elevator to the third floor. The guard stayed right beside his charge, eyes sweeping the area.
As it happens, the office building was in Polanco, a neighborhood blocks away from where Peter Zarate was killed. It's a wealthy area filled with glittering boutiques and hotels, most guarded by uniformed men carrying weapons -- a place where you can get just about anything you want, except a basic sense of safety and freedom.
The American C.E.O. who prefers to do his shopping in the United States recalls a previous posting, in a city where he was also accompanied everywhere he went by a guard and a chauffeur. "When I got back to the States, I bought myself a sports car because I just wanted to be alone. There was" -- he shook his head in amazement -- "no back seat."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 74; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 827 words

HEADLINE: Airheads

BYLINE: By Walter Kirn; Walter Kirn is the author of "She Needed Me," a novel.

 BODY:
Maybe it's the depleted oxygen ration, maybe it's the sense of anonymity or maybe it's a side effect of eating too many salted almonds, but there is something about airline travel that causes otherwise discerning readers to lower their standards and binge on pulp. Like literary adulterers, even the snobbiest readers, once airborne, will abandon their beloved classics and embrace the cheap and easy.
Or maybe it's the crowds. The culture of air travel in America is a mass culture, dissolving independence and eccentricity in a lukewarm plasma of uniformity. Esperanto only spoken here. Local color, where it exists at all, is a matter of airport souvenir shops selling the local pro sports teams' caps and jerseys, of snack bars peddling regional variations on the chocolate chip cookie and the cinnamon roll. 
 It's the same in airport bookstores, where the lowest common denominator rules. Consider the best-seller list of Benjamin Company, a national chain with stores in La Guardia, Dulles International, Atlanta Hartsfield and other hubs: at No. 1, "The Partner," by John Grisham, a legal mystery. At No. 5, "Total Control," by David Baldacci, a mystery about a missing businessman. Here and there a novel of quality surfaces ("Cold Mountain," by Charles Frazier, is No. 16), but mostly if it has already gone double-platinum in the world at large. Like fifth graders, hard-line Communists and wolves, airborne readers prefer to run in packs, showing their devotion to the group by inhibiting any urge to wander into untracked cultural territory.
For the business-class traveler, the paradigmatic escapist read is surely "Total Control," a thriller featuring the sort of people one might meet over cocktails in an airport clubroom. The heroine, Sidney Archer, is a crackerjack Washington lawyer whose husband, Jason, a computer whiz, is in a suspicious plane crash that happens to kill the Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
"Total Control" is, at bottom, a fantasy of upper-middle-class competence -- an extended fictional celebration of "The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People." Sid deftly manipulates cell phones, paging devices, laptop computers and other high-tech tools in pursuit of truth and justice. As if life itself were a business trip, everything hinges on problem-solving skills. The values are traditional and practical, straight from Ben Franklin and the Boy Scout handbook. Irony is the enemy of the action. And when hard-working, quick-thinking Sid finally triumphs, her reward is not spiritual but monetary. For saving the world's economy, Sid gets a check from the Government.
No doubt what's really at the root of this taste for trash is anxiety. No matter how plush the first-class seat, it's still a long way down if trouble strikes. Fear of falling, philosophically speaking, is jet travel's existential bottom line, and stories of suspense and death address that sense of peril more directly than do textured coming-of-age tales or elegant satires of social mores.
The anxiety thesis is further borne out by the presence on Benjamin's Top 20 list of not one but three other books concerning air disasters: "Airframe," by Michael Crichton (about a possible design flaw in a fleet of airliners), "Mayday," by Nelson Demille and Thomas Block (about a missile attack on a supersonic jet), and "Sole Survivor," by Dean Koontz (about a family wiped out in a crash). The only imaginable reason for a traveler to read such stories at 30,000 feet would be to inoculate a troubled mind with a homeopathic dose of angst. Or maybe it's magical thinking that's at work here: an illogical belief that the likelihood of a fiery plunge to earth is somehow reduced by holding on one's lap a fictional description of one.
If there's an exception that proves the rule on Benjamin's list, it's "Don't Sweat the Small Stuff . . . and It's All Small Stuff," coming in at No. 2. Don't worry, be happy, it teaches. At this moment, high above Nebraska, miniature bottle of Cabernet in hand, salted almond melting on your tongue, you're alive and conscious, so make the most of it. In an hour or two a missile might hit.
Personally, I can't read books on airplanes, books of any kind. The nature of my anxiety is such that I'm afraid to become absorbed in anything that might interrupt my vigilant back-seat piloting. At least once a minute, I check the flaps, the engine sounds, the expressions on the faces of the flight attendants. The more people I see around me reading, absorbed in lurid paperback fantasies and thus unable to do the vital work of mentally keeping the plane aloft, the more obligated I feel to keep my head up.
Once in a while, I can read a magazine on an airplane, but only if it's published by the airline and has on its final page a diagram of the emergency exits. Unlike my fellow fliers with their tales of murder and midair tragedy, I just have to face the window to be on the edge of my seat.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Top 10: The titles currently flying out of airport bookstores, according to Benjamin Company, a national chain. Tried-and-true pulpists (Grisham, Clancy, Crichton) fare well, as do books about plane disasters ("Total Control," "Airframe"), perhaps because air travelers think an escapist version of tragedy can somehow ward off the real thing.; TUES., 12 P.M., ALAMEDA, CALIF.: Mike leaves the meeting cautiously optimistic; more discussions will follow. (Bill Steele for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: March 8, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 62; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1806 words

HEADLINE: Vendorville

BYLINE: By Jim Yardley; Jim Yardley is a reporter for the Metro section of The Times.

 BODY:
In late January, Chris Burch hopped a commuter plane from Dallas to Bentonville, Ark. -- or, more precisely, to Fayetteville, since Bentonville doesn't have a movie theater, much less an airport. Although the flight covers only 269 miles, it costs nearly $500, and Burch complains that he can fly to London for less. But Wal-Mart isn't in London; it's in Bentonville, which explains why Burch has visited about 200 times. And to do business with Wal-Mart, first you have to get there. Just when Burch's flight should have been touching down, the pilot pulled into a sudden climb. It had been so foggy that Burch couldn't see the runway. Neither, apparently, could the pilot. "After the third miss," Burch says the flight attendant told him, "we go back to Dallas." Fortunately, the plane landed safely, averting not only a crash but also another unpleasant possibility -- that Burch would miss his morning appointment.
Burch is a vendor, Wal-Mart-speak for one of three groups in Bentonville, population 17,000 and rising. The vendors are the estimated 7,000 salespeople who call on Wal-Mart every month. Then there are "associates," the 7,000 people who work for Wal-Mart locally. And then there's everyone else. You could call them support staff. 
 You almost expect to find Wal-Mart's stock price posted on the city-limits sign in Bentonville, hometown of the world's largest retailer. Located in the Ozark Mountains of northwest Arkansas, Bentonville is 60 miles from the nearest Interstate. The nearest airport, Drake Field in Fayetteville, does not offer jet service, because the runway is too short. And because fog often means canceled or rerouted flights, a trip to Bentonville can be a parody of business travel. Maybe you'll get there, or maybe you'll discover the joys of Tulsa.
Bentonville is about as convenient to corporate America as excise taxes. Of course, inconvenience is practically a corporate philosophy with Wal-Mart. What other company has built an empire by erecting stores in such obscure places? Why should a trip to the corporate HQ be any different? "It's like another world," says Burch, a 46-year-old apparel executive, whose white blond hair and winter tan give him the look of an aging lifeguard. "It's so weird."
Weirder still is that in this cellular era, this remote little town has become an international business center. If you want to do business with Kmart or Sears, you visit their offices in suburban Detroit and Chicago. You can stay in a five-star hotel. Eat at a five-star restaurant. If you want to do business with Wal-Mart, you look for the stars in the Arkansas sky, depending on the fog.
It's tempting to laugh when the Chamber of Commerce president, Curt Loyd, describes Bentonville and outlying towns like Rogers and Springdale as a "metroplex. Maybe he's counting livestock and people. Or maybe he's right. More than 100 Wal-Mart suppliers, including corporate giants like Hewlett-Packard, Clorox and Nabisco, have opened satellite offices. Tyson Foods, the world's largest chicken processor, is located in Springdale. Bentonville's service industry used to consist of the local Farm Bureau. Now you can get a $75 facial and a massage at a local strip-mall spa.
Once, it took a prime ocean port or a choice river location for a business hub like Boston or St. Louis to be born. In Bentonville, it took a shopkeeper named Sam Walton. He parlayed his five-and-ten into an empire of 3,359 stores in nine countries with annual sales exceeding $118 billion. "Vendorville," says Tom Jensen, who holds the Wal-Mart lectureship in retailing at the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville. That's what we call it."
When Burch began working as a salesman 22 years ago, he sold wide-flare Landlubber jeans out of the trunk of a humpbacked, baby blue Gran Torino. He barnstormed the Southwest, stopping at every dusty town with a department store. Nearly all those local stores are gone now, either driven out of business by discounters like Wal-Mart or gobbled up by other national chains. And because Wal-Mart is so huge, it is now virtually Burch's sole customer.
He makes his sales pitches in the main office of Wal-Mart Stores, a sprawling, unpretentious brick building that looks more like a textile mill than a corporate headquarters. Each vendor is given a badge and sits in an enormous waiting area until a guard ushers him to his appointment. On any given weekday, Burch is one of hundreds of salespeople awaiting entrance to vendor row, a long blue-and-gray hallway with plain linoleum floors. In small, bare rooms decorated only with copies of the company's Gifts & Gratuities policy, vendors sit at folding tables and pitch their lines to Wal-Mart's harried buyers.
"These people are the million-pound gorilla," Burch says with reverence. "They don't want you to come in here with your $1,800 suit and your limousine. They want you to come in and tell how low you can go. And then they want you to be under that."
The Spartan nature of this no-frills capitalism fits in easily with Bentonville. The town closes by about 9 P.M. Though private clubs can sell alcohol, Benton County is dry. On past business trips to Los Angeles, Burch has spent as much as $1,000 entertaining clients at dinner. In Bentonville, his main entertainment is spending $5 to work out at a local gym. He usually eats alone, reading Road & Track magazine. Because Wal-Mart prohibits its employees from accepting gratuities, restaurants like Fred's Hickory Inn, a local landmark with $4.50 barbecue sandwiches and $23 steaks, will happily divide a lunch bill 20 ways.
"You come here, you have your meeting and you leave," Burch says. "That's it. The culture is different."
It's hard to find Bentonville, even when you're there. "Downtown? asks Burch, who has come here for 10 years. Is there one? There may be a nice little downtown square here. I don't know if there is or not. Isn't that wild?"
There is, in fact, a town square with a Confederate statue and a courthouse, just like those in hundreds of other small Southern towns, though many of those towns are waiting to die. There are lakes and fine hunting and good schools and gracious people who attend church and wave to strangers. But the real action in Bentonville is on Highway 71B, dutifully named Walton Boulevard, where a second city is rising, a sprawling strip dedicated to serving Wal-Mart with the charmless efficiency of a convenience store. This is Vendorville.
Not too many years ago, there was almost nothing along the old bypass except cow pastures and chicken coops. "If a dignitary came to Bentonville," recalls Keith Dowell, a local businessman, "we could feed him in the high-school cafeteria, but we had to send him to Rogers for a place to sleep."
Now vendors like Burch can choose among a Courtyard by Marriott, two Ramadas, a Holiday Inn Express, a Best Western or a Comfort Inn. Two other hotels are under construction. Where once Fred's Hickory Inn was about the only restaurant in town, now nearly every fast-food joint imaginable is there, as well as chains like Applebee's.
It is the same sort of placeless, ready-to-order edge city found near Atlanta or Dallas or Denver, only on a smaller scale. A new regional airport offering jet service is under construction. There are secretarial pools available for out-of-town executives, and there are office parks named Beau Terre and Raintree that look like corporate Quonset huts.
There are still plenty of pickup trucks, but the rush hour on Walton Boulevard -- and there is a rush hour -- is also crowded with sport-utility vehicles and luxury sedans, symbols of the sort of conspicuous consumption frowned upon by Sam Walton before he died in 1992.
Looking to sample some local fare, Brenda Smith and Ross Gluck, vendors for Solo Cup in Chicago, fell for the dessert pies -- called tall pies because of their layers of meringue -- served at Marty's Cafe. Otherwise, Bentonville was a hard sell. A Chicago native who craved a good slice of pizza, Gluck once asked for a recommendation of the best local joint. "They said Little Caesars," he recalls. They learned Arkansas jokes (How do you know the toothbrush was invented in Arkansas? Otherwise, it would have been named the teethbrush), and eventually Bentonville's homey charms grew on them just enough that they no longer hated it. "When you hear for the first time that you're going to Bentonville, Ark., you get the feeling that you're going to the most backward place," Gluck says. "You have the worst image possible. But it's really not that bad."
It's fortunate that Billy Melton is a peaceable man. A few miles south of Walton Boulevard, a large gated subdivision of expensive new homes called the Pinnacle Country Club spreads over acres of former farmland. Across a two-lane road, Champions Estates, another subdivision for the newly rich, continues to rise. Blink and you could be on the outskirts of Dallas. But like a tiny island in an ocean sits Melton's modest frame house on a single acre. He bought the land six years ago, along with chickens and rabbits, so he could raise his family in the country. In the evenings the sunset burned an orange sky.
The chickens and rabbits are still there, but now Melton is surrounded by a gated community. Champions Estates has built a white hard-plastic wall around his property line, high enough to block the sunset.
"They did that to kind of hide our place," says Melton, a factory worker. "It didn't go with what they're doing. They just boxed us off."
This is not the best example of the neighborliness or the classless society that Bentonville prides itself on. Melton admits that he now wouldn't mind selling to a developer. He says they've shown little interest so far. Perhaps he'll buy some more chickens -- the odor might deliver the appropriate message. Nonetheless, Melton says he isn't angry. We take this all in stride," he says. It's just part of progress."
Progress is, of course, the steroids of Vendorville. It is hard to argue with 2 percent unemployment and a Wal-Mart stock plan that has spawned a good number of country millionaires. "Every business in this city recognizes that Wal-Mart butters our bread," says Skip McHardy, managing partner of Fred's. "If Wal-Mart ever has problems, I hope I'd have sold out the week before."
Civic leaders say that more chain restaurants are coming; what better sign of progress is there? When the new airport opens, jet service is expected to bring Bentonville travel into the modern era. There's a renewed push to promote Ozarks tourism -- all those new hotel rooms are empty on weekends, when the vendors have left. There's also a plan to spruce up the old town square, perhaps redirect traffic and make it more efficient. Maybe people will even be able to find it.
